Not for Redistribution INDIA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.118489 gram of fine gold per Indian Rupee. A central rate of Rs 18.9677 = £ stg. 1 has been established. The Reserve Bank of India main- tains fixed buying and selling rates for sterling and consequently transactions in all currencies other than sterling and currencies directly linked to sterling and other than the Nepalese rupee take place at fluctuating rates. At the end of December 1974, the Reserve Bank's buying and selling rates for its operations in sterling with authorized dealers were Rs 18.75 and Rs 18.85 per £ stg. 1. The rates of exchange for transactions in sterling have been prescribed by the Reserve Bank. Transactions in foreign currencies other than sterling and currencies directly linked to sterling and other than the Nepalese rupee are conducted through authorized dealers at rates fixed on the basis of market conditions, subject to spot transactions being done at or between the London market rates for sterling against the other currency concerned. In addition, the Reserve Bank stands ready to purchase U.S. dollars, deutsche mark, and Japanese yen, spot and forward. Authorized dealers are permitted to cover their re- quirements of foreign currencies in the London market and to cover their permitted transactions in certain listed currencies (the "permitted currencies")1 against rupees or any one of these currencies, either spot or forward for periods not exceeding six months, with authorized banks in any country outside the Bilateral Account group.2 On December 31, 1974, market rates for telegraphic transfers on New York were US$12.53 buying (clean) and US$12.40 selling, per Rs 100, and the Reserve Bank's rates were US$12.4950 buying spot, and US$12.4575, US$12.3850, US$12.3150, and US$12.1700 buying forward (for 1, 2, 3, and 6 months' delivery, respectively) per Rs 100. The Reserve Bank provides forward cover to autho- rized dealers by purchases of sterling for up to 9 months' delivery initially (and extendable up to 12 months), of U.S. dollars for 1, 2, 3, and 6 months' delivery, and of deutsche mark and Japanese yen for 1, 2, and 3 months' delivery. In addition, the Bank offers forward cover in these four currencies in respect of exports of specified capital and producer goods, for periods of 18 months to 10 years from the date of conclusion of the export contract. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Reserve Bank of India in accordance with the general policy laid down by the Government of India in consultation with the Reserve Bank. Much of the routine work of ex- change control is delegated to certain commercial banks, which act as authorized dealers permitted to buy 224 and sell foreign exchange for specified purposes under regulations laid down by the Reserve Bank. With re- spect to direct investments in India, all collaboration proposals, with or without equity participation, are re- viewed by the Foreign Investment Board. Under the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, the general or spe- cific approval of the Reserve Bank is necessary for the continuance of commercial, industrial, and trading ac- tivities in India of companies with more than 40 per cent nonresident interest or for the establishment by them in India of any branch, office, or other place of business for carrying out any such activity. The Reserve Bank's prior permission is also required by nonresi- dents, noncitizens, nonbanking companies not incorpo- rated under Indian law, and Indian companies with more than 40 per cent nonresident interest for acting or accepting appointment as agents or technical advisers of any person or company in India in the trading or commercial transactions of such persons or companies. Import and export licenses are issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports. Prescription of Currency India has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. For prescription of currency purposes, countries are divided into two groups: Bilateral Account countries,2 and External Account countries (all other countries). Payments to and from Bilateral Account countries must be settled in Indian rupees through the appropri- ate clearing account. Payments to 14 External Account countries3 may be made in rupees to the credit of the account of a resident of any country in this group or in the currency of any country or territory in this sub- group. Payments to all other External Account countries may be made in (1) the currency of the coun- try concerned; (2) the currency of any country of the subgroup mentioned; or (3) rupees to the account of a resident of any country in the External Account group.4 Receipts from 14 External Account countries3 may be obtained in rupees from the account of a bank in any External Account country, or in the currency of any territory in this subgroup. Receipts from all other Ex- ternal Account countries may be obtained in (1) the currency of the country concerned; (2) the currency of any territory in the subgroup mentioned; or (3) rupees from the account of a bank in any External Account country. Notwithstanding the foregoing, special rules may be applicable in respect of Afghanistan, Bangla- desh, Burma, Egypt, the Sudan, and exports under lines of credit extended by the Government of India to the governments of certain foreign countries. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Nonresident Accounts The accounts of Indians and of Nepalese and Bhuta- nese nationals resident in Nepal and Bhutan, as well as the accounts of offices and branches of Indian, Nepa- lese, and Bhutanese firms, companies, or other organi- zations in Nepal and Bhutan are treated as resident accounts.5 Accounts related to all other foreign countries are treated as nonresident accounts. The treatment of these accounts distinguishes between those of banks and of others. The accounts of banks are classified in two groups corresponding to the division of countries for prescrip- tion of currency purposes, i.e., Bilateral Accounts and External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with payments for imports, interest, dividends, and other authorized purposes, with authorized transfers from the nonresident accounts of private firms (includ- ing banks) or persons, with proceeds from sales of the currency of the country or monetary area of the ac- count holder, and with proceeds from sales of the cur- rencies of External Account countries. They may be debited for payments for exports and for other pay- ments to residents of India. These accounts may also be debited for transfers to nonresident accounts of persons and firms (including banks), provided that both the transferor and transferee accounts are of External Ac- count countries. Transfers may be made from External Accounts to other External Accounts. All other entries on Bilateral and External Accounts, with the exception of debits by way of payments to residents, require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Ordinary nonresident accounts of private individuals or firms may be credited, without prior approval, for payment of dividends and interest on securities, shares, and deposits; refunds of amounts previously debited or overcharged; proceeds of remittances in appropriate foreign currency or transfers from appropriate nonresi- dent banks' rupee accounts (see section on Prescription of Currency, above); proceeds from checks issued by the Life Insurance Corporation in respect of maturity or death claims and surrender value of policies held by nonresidents, provided that the Corporation certifies that premiums had been received in India in an ap- proved manner and that actuarial reserves are held in India; and proceeds of checks, provided that the aggre- gate of such credits during a month does not exceed Rs 2,000 and no individual credit is in excess of Rs 750. Where the nonresident account holder is an Indian national, maturity proceeds of all types of secu- rities and shares as well as sale proceeds of securities and shares sold on stock exchanges in India and the repurchase price of units issued by the Unit Trust of India may be freely credited to his account. Where the account holder (in the case of a joint account, any of the account holders) is a foreign national, authorized dealers may freely credit the sale and maturity proceeds of all types of securities and the repurchase price of units, provided that the securities had been originally INDIA purchased either out of funds held in the account or by remittance from abroad, and in the case of sale pro- ceeds, that the sale was made on the stock exchange. Ordinary private nonresident accounts, as well as blocked accounts maintained by persons of Indian na- tionality or origin who are resident abroad, with a bal- ance of Rs 50,000 or less may be freely debited for local payments. Other ordinary private nonresident accounts may be debited without prior approval for such items as payments for premiums on life insurance policies of the account holder or his dependents; all taxes due from the account holder in India; contributions to the Na- tional Defence Fund, the Prime Minister's National Relief Fund, or any government-sponsored charity; al- lowances not exceeding Rs 1,000 a month to relatives and dependents in India; investments in Indian Gov- ernment securities and in units issued by the Unit Trust of India; and for checks up to Rs 1,000 a week drawn in favor of beneficiaries resident in India or in favor of the account holder while temporarily resident in India. For ordinary nonresident accounts of Indian nationals or persons of Indian origin, as well as blocked accounts of such persons with balances in excess of Rs 50,000, the holders may draw up to Rs 2,000 a week during their stay and, in addition, a lump sum of up to Rs 10,000 annually may be debited for any purpose during an account holder's stay in India. Other credits and debits require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Transfers are not normally permitted from non- resident accounts of individuals or firms to nonresident accounts of banks, unless the amounts originally cred- ited to such accounts could have been transferred abroad. Special regulations cover funds lodged in National Defence Remittance Scheme Special Accounts repre- senting rupee proceeds of inward remittances for the account of nonresidents and rupee proceeds from sales of certificates issued under the Scheme, which expired on May 31, 1966. Balances in such accounts cannot be remitted abroad; they may, however, subject in some cases to prior approval by the Reserve Bank, be in- vested domestically or be used for other expenditures in India. Withdrawals from such accounts with bal- ances of Rs 50,000 or less held by persons of Indian nationality or origin may be made freely for any pay- ments in India. Nonresident (External) Accounts may freely be opened by authorized dealers in India for persons of Indian nationality or origin resident outside India. They may be freely credited with new funds remitted through banking channels from the country of resi- dence of the account holder. They may also be credited, after approval by the Reserve Bank, with funds from any other nonresident account of the holder, provided such funds are eligible for remittance. The accounts may be freely debited for disbursements in India and for transfer abroad. Interest on moneys standing to the credit of such accounts is exempt from income tax and freely transferable. 225 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA There are also blocked accounts, to which are cred- ited capital proceeds and payments that are due to nonresidents and may not be remitted abroad. Assets in India of Indian emigrants in excess of the amount allowed to be remitted are also required to be credited to blocked accounts. Balances in blocked accounts may be placed on fixed deposit or invested in Indian rupee securities and shares quoted on stock exchanges in In- dia (other than bearer securities); the income derived from such investments can be remitted to the owner's country of residence in accordance with the special instructions issued by the Reserve Bank at the time of opening a blocked account. For Indian nationals who were granted emigration facilities prior to January 1, 1963, net income from investments financed from blocked accounts is allowed to be remitted in fu l l. For those granted such facilities between January 1963 and April 1968, remittances of income from assets left be- hind are limited to Rs 20,000 a year. No income of any kind is remittable to persons who obtained emigration facilities after April 30, 1968. Imports and Import Payments Specified items may be freely imported under an open general license. Practically all other imports re- quire individual licenses. Imports of specified raw ma- terials, spare parts, and components required by "core" and "priority" industries, including small-scale indus- tries, and by units in other industries that had an export performance of 20 per cent or more of their production during the previous year, are licensed liberally. Licenses for raw materials and components are issued on a con- tinuing basis generally by way of importers claiming replenishment of goods actually consumed during a period of not less than 3 and not more than 12 months. As for spare parts, licenses are issued annually on the basis of prescribed percentages of the c.i.f. value of the imported machinery and of indigenous machinery hav- ing imported components. Licenses to actual users for imports of raw materials, components, and spare parts are not granted wholly against free foreign exchange, but partly against tied-aid credits from particular countries or against rupees in bilateral clearing ac- counts. However, a greater preference with respect to the permitted origin of imports is accorded to actual users with specified minimum export performance. In- dividual licenses may be issued (1) ad hoc, (2) on the basis of quotas allocated to established importers in accordance with their imports in a base period, (3) to actual users on the basis of their requirements, and (4) to registered exporters in accordance with the import content of their exports. Generally, licenses may be used to import from any country except Namibia (South West Africa), Pakistan, Portugal, Rhodesia, South Africa, and the Tibet region of the People's Republic of China; imports from these countries (except Pakistan) are prohibited.6 Such li- censes are referred to as General Currency Area Li- 226 censes, as distinct from Specific Licenses, which are issued for capital goods and other supplies against tied aid and are valid only for imports from the country or countries providing the assistance. Single Country Li- censes are issued for certain imports from countries with which bilateral trade or payments agreements are in force. Licensing policy generally accords priority to food- stuffs, fertilizers, capital goods, raw materials, and other industrial requirements, while the import of other items is severely limited or prohibited. The import pro- gram for the period ending March 31, 1975 contains a prohibited list7 of 1,090 commodities and a list of 455 items that are licensed on a "restricted basis," i.e., in minor amounts and only if comparable domestic prod- ucts either are not available or are inadequate. Licens- ing is in most cases on an annual basis. There are special procedures applicable to imports of capital goods, heavy electrical plant, and goods imported to fulfill government contracts and for irrigation projects. Favored treatment in allocating foreign exchange for imports of capital goods and equipment is given to "core" industries and "priority" industries. An import replenishment scheme enables registered exporters to obtain specified raw materials and other items needed for their export production; these commodities include certain items whose import otherwise is banned. In licensing imports of a capital nature, their essentiality, their potential for earning or saving foreign exchange, and the availability of medium-term or long-term cred- its for financing such imports are taken into account. Import licenses for machine tools and other capital goods valued at more than Rs 750,000 are not granted until Indian producers have been given an opportunity by public advertisement to supply them; licenses are only issued if offers by domestic producers are dispro- portionately expensive or unacceptable for other rea- sons, or when no offers are received within 45 days. For certain types of steel castings and forgings, this policy applies to all orders of more than Rs 50,000. Where a valid import license is held, the required exchange is released by an authorized bank on presen- tation of the exchange control copy of the license. Li- cense holders may make payments by opening letters of credit or by remitting against sight drafts. Advance remittances before shipping documents can be submit- ted are not normally allowed; but in special cases, e.g., imports of machinery and capital goods, where depos- its have to be made with overseas manufacturers, the Reserve Bank grants special authorization for advance payment for a part of the value of the import. The import of certain commodities, including food- grains, certain oils and fats, a number of pharmaceuti- cal products, corkwood, raw cotton, raw jute, cashew nuts, most fertilizers, most nonferrous metals, and many categories of steel is reserved for the Government or state trading enterprises, the most important of which are the State Trading Corporation (STC), the Jute Corporation of India, the Food Corporation of ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution India, Hindustan Steel Ltd., and the Minerals and Met- als Trading Corporation. For 1974/75, the number of such commodities was raised by 10 items to 210 items. In addition, imports of natural rubber, sulfur products, vitamins, and antibiotics are normally arranged under the auspices of the STC. Bulk imports of certain raw materials that are not reserved for the public sector may also be arranged by state agencies, including the Indus- trial Raw Materials Assistance Centre (IRMAC). In addition to any applicable import duty, imports are subject to an auxiliary duty of 5, 15, or 20 per cent ad valorem. Exemptions include foodgrains, raw cot- ton, tallow, and books. Payments for Invisibles In general, payments abroad for invisibles require approval. Foreign exchange is granted freely for a few such payments, mainly for expenses incidental to trade transactions and transfers of recurring contractual obli- gations. Premiums on insurance policies issued in foreign cur- rency to foreign nationals temporarily resident in India may be paid in rupees or in the currency in which the policy is issued; Indian residents are prohibited from taking out life insurance policies in foreign currencies. Branches of foreign banks are not allowed to transfer abroad any profits arising from the sale of nonbanking assets. Profit remittances by branches of foreign firms, companies, and banks require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Remittances of dividends by Indian companies to their nonresident shareholders also re- quire prior Reserve Bank approval. Remittances of div- idends by entirely foreign-controlled companies are limited when reserves are drawn on to finance the divi- dends. Otherwise there are no restrictions on the remit- tance of profits, dividends, and interest to beneficiaries permanently resident outside India (except any income accruing to beneficiaries of the National Defence Re- mittance Scheme), provided that all current tax and other liabilities in India have been cleared, except where such repatriation rights have been voluntarily surren- dered. However, remittances to Indian nationals who were granted exchange facilities for emigration on or after January 1, 1963 but before April 30, 1968, of pensions and dividends and interest on shares, securi- ties, and deposits held in India are subject to an overall limit of Rs 20,000 a year and to any special directions given to the person concerned when he was granted emigration facilities. For persons who have been granted emigration facilities af ter April 30, 1968 on grounds of hardship, no remittance of income is al- lowed. Foreign nationals temporarily resident in India on account of their business, profession, or employment are permitted to make reasonable remittances to their own countries to pay insurance premiums, for the sup- port of their families, and for other expenses. Autho- rized dealers may allow such remittances by foreign INDIA nationals, other than nationals of the People's Republic of China, Pakistan, Portugal, and Rhodesia, to the ex- tent of 50 per cent of net income, subject to a maximum of Rs 2,360 a month (Rs 1,500 a month for nationals of Bangladesh). Requests for the remittance of larger amounts are considered on their merits by the Reserve Bank. Applications for foreign exchange for travel or edu- cation abroad are considered on an individual basis and require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Under the Foreign Travel Scheme, 1970, residents are permit- ted to travel abroad without "P form" formalities pro- vided they have not visited any place outside India, other than Bangladesh, Mauritius, Nepal, or Sri Lanka, during the period of three years immediately preceding the date of the journey; if traveling by Indian carrier on a round-trip ticket, they are entitled to foreign ex- change up to US$100 or its equivalent. The scheme is applicable to all destinations except Bangladesh, Mau- ritius, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. Under the Mauritius Travel Scheme, substantially the same facilities are available for travel to Mauritius, except that any visits to Mauritius with either a grant of foreign exchange by the Reserve Bank or passage booked with the prior approval of the Reserve Bank, as well as visits to other countries under the Foreign Travel Scheme, are to be ignored for determining the traveler's eligibility under the three-year rule. There are no restrictions on travel to Bangladesh and Nepal, while passages may be booked freely for air travel from Madras, Tiruchirapalli, or Trivandrum to Colombo, Sri Lanka. The schemes mentioned do not preclude access to other travel facilities (for purposes such as business travel or attendance at conferences or semi- nars, etc.) that may be approved under normal proce- dures. Foreign exchange for tourist travel, however, is not normally granted except under the two schemes mentioned above. Travel agents and airlines and steam- ship companies are not permitted to book passage abroad for persons resident in India (other than foreign nationals temporarily resident in India) unless the trav- eler is eligible under the Foreign Travel Scheme or the Mauritius Travel Scheme, has been granted travel ex- change by the Reserve Bank, or has been specifically granted permission by the Reserve Bank to book his passage.8 Travel abroad to attend conferences is unre- stricted provided expenses are covered by the host insti- tution. The export of Indian currency notes and coins, ex- cept to Nepal, is in general prohibited. The export to Nepal of Indian currency notes in denominations of Rs 100 or higher is also prohibited. Deck passengers to Burma, Malaysia, Singapore, Persian Gulf ports, and East Africa and passengers to Pakistan or Sri Lanka may take with them Rs 20 a person at any one time in Indian notes and coins (within the limit of Rs 30 for Indian and foreign currency notes combined). Resi- dents proceeding to Bangladesh for business or private purposes may take with them Indian currency notes up 227 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA to Rs 20 a person a trip. Residents may take out for- eign notes and coins up to £ stg. 3.50 or its equivalent a person; exchange bureaus of authorized dealers and authorized money changers at airports and seaports are permitted to sell foreign currency notes up to a value of £ stg. 3.50 or its equivalent a person to all passen- gers, whether Indian or foreign, but not to deck passen- gers or travelers proceeding to Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, or Sri Lanka, or to foreign nationals who are transit passengers or passengers holding open-dated tickets (including return tickets) issued out- side India. Travelers to Pakistan may take Pakistan rupees in notes or coins up to the equivalent of Rs 30 a person; travelers to Sri Lanka and deck passengers to Burma, Malaysia, Singapore, Persian Gulf ports, or East Africa may take £ stg. 1.50 a person. Nonresi- dents may take out the foreign currency which they declared on entry, less the amounts sold to authorized dealers and authorized money changers in India. A foreign travel tax, at the rate of 15 per cent on first class fares and 10 per cent on economy/tourist class fares, is payable where the fare for an international journey is paid in Indian currency; tickets paid for in foreign exchange are exempt from the levy. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are required for only a few items, and most commodities may be exported without a license. Most of the controlled commodities are licensed freely to all shippers; a few may be exported through estab- lished shippers; and a few commodities are subject to export quotas. Exports to Namibia (South West Af- rica), Portugal, Rhodesia, South Africa, and the Tibet region of the People's Republic of China are prohibited.9 Exchange control is exercised over the proceeds of exports to countries other than Bhutan and Nepal. An exporter must declare that the full export proceeds will be received and dealt with in accordance with the pre- scription of currency regulations. Foreign exchange holdings, including the proceeds of exports, in most currencies10 must be offered for sale against rupees to an authorized dealer, unless the holder has been authorized by the Reserve Bank to retain them, or he is a foreign national not permanently resident in India and the funds do not represent the proceeds of an export. Export proceeds must be surren- dered within six months of shipment or, if the goods are sold to Afghanistan or Pakistan, within three months of shipment. The Reserve Bank may allow an extension of the six-month period where exports of capital goods or engineering goods are concerned. Some major exports, including jute manufactures, are subject to export duties. Some exports, including engineering goods, mica, tobacco, handwoven woolen carpets, and lac are subject to minimum prices. Some exports, mainly new manufactures such as engineering goods, receive cash assistance. The cotton textile indus- 228 try also receives cash assistance. An import replenish- ment scheme provides preferential import licensing fa- cilities for producers of manufactured goods for export. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles in most currencies10 must be surrendered. All bills rendered by hotels to foreign tourists and to nonresident Indian nationals, other than bills rendered to nationals of Bilateral Account countries, Bhutan, and Nepal, and such other foreign nationals and nonresident Indians as are specifically exempted from compliance with this rule by the Indian Government, must be collected by the hotels in foreign currency. The import of Indian currency notes and coins is, in general, prohibited. However, deck passengers from Burma, Malaysia, Singapore, Persian Gulf ports, and East Africa, and travelers from Pakistan and Sri Lanka, may import into India Rs 20 a person against presenta- tion of evidence that they previously had exported this amount from India. Persons coming to India from Burma, other than deck passengers, are allowed to bring in Indian currency notes up to a value of Rs 50 for an adult and Rs 25 for a child between the ages of 12 and 18. Travelers from Nepal may bring in up to Rs 75 a person. Foreign currency notes may be brought into India without limit, provided that a decla- ration of the total amount brought in is made to the customs authorities upon arrival if the value of foreign notes and coins together with the value of the travelers checks brought in exceeds US$1,000 or its equivalent. Persons holding foreign currency notes may sell them to any authorized dealer in foreign exchange or to any authorized money changer. Capital Inward capital transfers are, in general, unrestricted, but their subsequent utilization in India in most cases is subject to approval. Foreign investments, once ad- mitted, are eligible for the same treatment that Indian enterprises receive. Banks in India may borrow freely from their branches and correspondents abroad, provided that borrowings in excess of Rs 2 million are utilized for the purchase of rupees from the Reserve Bank or in the interbank market to finance their normal business oper- ations in India; repayment of such borrowings requires the prior approval of the Reserve Bank and may be effected only when the debtor bank has no outstanding borrowings in India from the Reserve Bank or any other bank. Foreign borrowing by nonbank Indian companies is subject to Reserve Bank approval; only in exceptional cases is permission granted for any loan which has not been obtained as an official or officially guaranteed credit by the Central Government. Reserve Bank permission is required for initiating, expanding, or continuing in India any business activity, ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution or holding or acquiring shares of any company carrying on a trading, commercial, or industrial activity in India, by nonresidents, noncitizens, nonbank companies not incorporated under Indian law, and Indian companies with over 40 per cent nonresident interest. The Reserve Bank will allow the latter companies to continue their activities, provided Indian participation is not less than 26 per cent of the equity of the company and the com- pany is engaged in production in "core" industries, in predominantly export-oriented production (i.e., at least 60 per cent of output for exports), or in manufacturing activities which require sophisticated technology; tea plantations are included among companies benefiting from this provision. Companies engaged predomi- nantly in trading activities or not meeting the other criteria listed will be required to reduce their foreign shareholding to 40 per cent within a specified period or convert their character to meet the above criteria or wind up their activities in India. In exceptional cases, companies not meeting the criteria but which have de- veloped skills, expertise, or facilities, or use technolo- gies not indigenously available, may be permitted greater than 40 per cent foreign participation, provided that the latter does not exceed 76 per cent. Branches of foreign companies other than airlines and shipping companies must in all cases convert themselves into Indian companies. All companies are subject to "dilution" formulas, as follows: companies with foreign direct holdings exceed- ing 75 per cent must raise 40 per cent of the estimated cost of expansion through additional equity capital is- sued to Indians; for companies with foreign holdings above 60 per cent but below 75 per cent, and above 51 per cent but below 60 per cent, the corresponding pro- portions are 33 V3 per cent and 25 per cent, respectively. No new foreign equity is permitted in companies en- gaged predominantly in internal trading and commer- cial activities. Without the permission of the Reserve Bank, residents are prohibited from lending to, or de- positing money with, a nonbank firm or company in which the nonresident interest is more than 40 per cent. Noncitizens, non-Indian firms, and nonbank Indian firms with more than 40 per cent foreign participation must obtain Reserve Bank permission in order to ac- quire, hold, transfer, or dispose of immovable property within India (except when a lease for a period of not more than five years is involved). Nonresidents besides the above categories of persons and companies must obtain Reserve Bank permission to allow the use of their trademarks by others for any consideration, and to obtain or continue employment in India as agent or technical or management adviser of Indian persons or companies. Residents are prohibited from engaging in any trans- action which increases the nonresident share of a busi- ness outside India in which the nonresident interest is 49 per cent or less, and they are prohibited, except with Reserve Bank permission, from holding, acquiring, transferring, or disposing of immovable property out- INDIA side India (except where a lease of not more than five years is involved). Residents also require Reserve Bank approval for transferring any interest in a business in India to a nonresident, a noncitizen, a nonbank com- pany not incorporated under Indian law, or an Indian company with over 40 per cent foreign participation. Furthermore, Reserve Bank approval is required for residents exporting Indian securities to any place out- side India and transferring Indian securities to nonresi- dents. Residents are prohibited—except with Central Government or Reserve Bank permission—from guar- anteeing the obligation of a nonresident or the obliga- tion of a resident in favor of a nonresident, and are also prohibited, except with Central Government permis- sion, from associating with or participating in any busi- ness concern outside India. Capital invested in approved projects after Janua- ry 1, 1950 by residents of other countries, including capital appreciation on the original investment, may be repatriated at any time; the public has been advised, however, to obtain the Reserve Bank's prior approval before effecting a sale when repatriation of the assets may exceed Rs 1 million. The proceeds of approved sales are allowed to be remitted in installments, usually of Rs 1 million a year, when the amounts sought to be repatriated are significant. The proceeds from liqui- dated foreign investments not eligible for repatriation are blocked (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). Indian nationals (including persons permanently res- ident in India) are not normally granted any foreign exchange facilities for emigration purposes. In excep- tional cases of hardship, foreign exchange may be re- leased up to a limit of the equivalent of Rs 25,000 in one lump sum at the time of emigration; the remainder of the emigrant's assets and income are blocked and no further remittances, including pensions, if any, are al- lowed. Foreign nationals who are temporarily resident in India (other than foreign diplomatic personnel and Bangladesh, Chinese, Pakistani, Portuguese, and Rho- desian nationals) are permitted at the time of their retirement to transfer to their own countries the pro- ceeds from the sale of their investments, subject to a limit of Rs 100,000 for each family at the time of retire- ment and the remainder in annual installments not ex- ceeding Rs 30,000, provided that the shares and securities concerned are quoted on recognized stock exchanges in India; in addition, they may transfer all their current remittable assets in India. Bangladesh na- tionals temporarily resident in India are permitted to transfer, besides their current assets in full, the sale proceeds of their capital assets up to a limit of Rs 50,000 for each family at the time of their retire- ment, and the remainder in annual installments of Rs 20,000. There are no restrictions on the import into India of Indian or foreign securities. The acquisition, sale, trans- fer, export, or other disposal of foreign securities re- quires approval. Persons resident in India are permitted 229 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA to hold foreign securities that have been acquired in a manner not involving a breach of the Indian exchange regulations; residents, other than foreign nationals not permanently resident in India, who are private persons are not normally permitted to purchase securities or personal real estate outside India. Indian nationals resident abroad and wishing to re- turn to India to take up employment or to set up small industrial units are upon application exempted, for a period of three years, from the requirement that any foreign currency balances in their possession be surren- dered within 30 days of arrival. As an alternative to holding such balances in the form of foreign currency, the holder may use the funds for the import, subject to import license, of equipment and capital goods. Fur- thermore, these persons have the option of surrender- ing their balances immediately, with the right to reacquire them within three years in the event of their deciding to go back to a foreign country. These various facilities are not available in respect of earnings arising from employment abroad with any Indian-owned orga- nization. Gold Detailed control is exercised over the manufacture, acquisition, possession, and disposal of gold in various forms through a Gold Control Administrator. There is a total ban on private possession of primary gold. Al- though there is no ban on possession of finished articles of gold (including coins) previously declared, there is restriction on their manufacture and fresh acquisition. There is no restriction on the acquisition, disposal, or possession of gold ornaments, except that holdings of such ornaments (which may be of any purity) above specified limits are subject to the requirement of decla- ration. The consumption of gold by industrial users is regulated through permits and authorizations. Control is exercised over dealers and goldsmiths through a sys- tem of licensing. Gold refining is under state manage- ment. The Government Mint is licensed to accept tenders of gold for purposes of refining and conversion into standard gold bars, for which strict specifications as to fineness, weight, dimensions, and markings are prescribed. Forward trading in gold or silver is prohib- ited; exports of silver are subject to licenses, which are granted freely. With the exception of jewelry constituting the per- sonal effects of a traveler, imports of gold in any form by residents other than the monetary authorities re- quire special authorization from the Reserve Bank and are not normally permitted; in certain cases, however, jewelers are permitted to manufacture gold jewelry in bond from imported gold, for export purposes only. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry pro- duced in India for export and jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler are prohibited unless the export is made by or on behalf of the monetary authori- 230 ties. The export of gold ornaments and jewelry to the Bilateral Account countries and Pakistan is prohibited. Changes during 1974 January 1. The Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973 came into force. It revoked and replaced the For- eign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947. The new or modi- fied provisions of this Act were as follows: (1) Legal sanctions were provided against false invoicing of im- ports or exports and against remittances of funds into India through unofficial channels. The Central Govern- ment was given the right to specify goods which, if exported on a consignment basis, could not (without Reserve Bank permission) be sold at a price less than the price declared at time of shipment. (2) The Reserve Bank was given the right to block securities of persons who had emigrated abroad as well as the bank accounts and securities of prospective emigrants. (3) The Central Government was given the right to require payment in foreign exchange for specific goods and services from persons resident outside India who are on a visit to India, and to exempt any person or class of persons from this requirement. (4) Residents were prohibited, without Reserve Bank permission, from holding, or engaging in any transactions with respect to, immov- able property outside India; exempt from this provision was the acquisition or transfer of such property by lease for a period not over five years. (5) Residents were prohibited from engaging without Reserve Bank per- mission in any transaction which increased to more than 49 per cent the nonresident share of a business outside India in which the nonresident interest was 49 per cent or less. (6) Residents were prohibited from transferring, without Reserve Bank permission, any in- terest in a business in India to a nonresident, a nonciti- zen, a nonbank company not incorporated under Indian law, or any company in India with a nonresident interest of more than 40 per cent. (7) Residents were prohibited, except with Reserve Bank permission, from giving a guarantee in respect of any obligation of a nonresident or in respect of any obligation of a resident due or owing to a person resident outside India. (8) Residents were prohibited, except with Reserve Bank permission, from lending to, or depositing money with, a nonbank firm or company in which the nonresident interest is more than 40 per cent. (9) Residents were prohibited, without Central Government permission, from associating with, or participating in, any business concern outside India. (10) Nonresidents, noncitizens, nonbank companies not incorporated under Indian law, and companies with over 40 per cent nonresident interest, could not take up new employment or con- tinue to be employed in India as agent or technical or management adviser of Indian persons or companies without Reserve Bank permission. (11) Compensation for the use in India of trademarks belonging to the four categories of persons or compa- nies listed in (10) above was made subject to Reserve ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Bank permission. (12) Reserve Bank permission was made mandatory for carrying on in India any activity of a trading, commercial, or industrial nature, or estab- lishing a place of business in India for such purposes, or acquiring the whole or any part of any undertaking in India (including the purchase of shares) by the four categories of persons or companies listed in (10) above. Reserve Bank permission would be required even for continuing already established businesses of the type described or continuing to hold shares already ac- quired. However, the Reserve Bank was empowered to exempt both specific individuals (or companies) and classes of individuals (or companies) from the require- ment of obtaining its permission for continuing already established businesses or continuing to carry on activi- ties of the types described other than trading activities. (13) Reserve Bank permission was made mandatory for non-Indian nationals taking up any employment, prac- tising any profession, or carrying on any occupation in India, in cases where the individual involved wished to acquire foreign exchange in order to remit abroad earn- ings from such activities. (14) The four categories of persons and companies listed in (10) above were pro- hibited, unless with Reserve Bank permission, from acquiring, holding, transferring, or disposing of any immovable property in India, except in the case of ac- quisition or transfer of such property by a lease for a period not exceeding five years. January 1. The Ministry of Finance guidelines for administering the foreign investment provisions of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973 came into ef- fect. Major features of these guidelines were as follows: (1) All branches of foreign companies, except airlines and shipping companies, would be required to convert themselves into Indian companies. (2) Indian compa- nies with more than 40 per cent foreign shareholding engaged in production of priority industries, or export- ing at least 60 per cent of their total production, or engaged in manufacturing requiring sophisticated tech- nology, or consisting of tea plantations, would be per- mitted to continue their activities if they increased Indian participation to not less than 26 per cent within a specified period. (3) Indian manufacturing and trad- ing companies with more than 40 per cent foreign shareholding, and not engaged in the activities specified in (2), would be required either to bring their foreign shareholding down to 40 per cent within a specified period or to change their character to predominantly manufacturing activities of the type listed in (2); certain exceptions might be made where such companies had developed expertise or facilities not indigenously avail- able and were contributing significantly to exports. (4) Indian manufacturing companies with more than 40 per cent foreign shareholding engaged in trading activi- ties in respect of products not manufactured by them would be permitted to trade products in the overall interest of the consumers provided the value of such products did not exceed 25 per cent of the value of total production or Rs 50 million, whichever was less. INDIA January 1. The Reserve Bank issued two Press Notes and a Circular to authorized dealers regarding Sec- tions 28 and 29 of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973. In terms of these sections, persons resident outside India (including Indian citizens), foreign citi- zens resident in India, and companies (other than bank- ing companies) incorporated abroad or in which the nonresident interest was more than 40 per cent, as well as branches of such companies, were required to obtain the permission of the Reserve Bank for the following: Under Section 28: (1) To act, or accept appointment, as agent in India of any person or company, in the trading or commercial transactions of such person or company. (2) To act, or accept appointment, as techni- cal or management adviser in India of any person or company. (3) To permit any trademark, which the said persons or companies are entitled to use, to be usedjby any other person or company for any direct or indirect consideration. Under Section 29: (1) To carry on in India any activ- ity of a trading, commercial, or industrial nature. (2) To establish in India a branch, office, or other place of business for carrying on such activities. (3) To acquire, either wholly or partly, any undertaking in India of a person or company carrying on any trade, commerce, or industry. (4) To purchase shares in India of Indian companies. (5) To continue to hold shares of Indian companies which were acquired before the commence- ment of the new Act, i.e., prior to January 1, 1974. The permission of the Reserve Bank also was re- quired for the continuance of the arrangements relating to items (1), (2), and (3) under Section 28 above, which were entered into by the said persons or companies prior to January 1, 1974, as also for the continuance of their existing trading, commercial, or industrial activi- ties. January 1. The Reserve Bank issued a Notification stating that under subsection (1) of Section 31 of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973, it permitted any company referred to in that subsection: (1) To acquire or hold any immovable property situated in India, provided that (a) such acquisition or holding of immovable property was necessary for or incidental to carrying on by such company of any activity permitted under Section 28 or Section 29 of the Act; and (b) such company filed a declaration, not later than 90 days from the date of such acquisition or holding, giving full particulars of the transaction as might be required by the Reserve Bank in that regard. (2) To transfer, by way of security for any borrowing permitted under subsec- tion (7) of Section 26 of the said Act, any such immov- able property so acquired or held. January 1. The Reserve Bank issued a Notification canceling its Notification of September 12, 1958, which had permitted the transfer of any security or the cre- ation or transfer of any interest in any security by any person resident in India to a foreign national also resi- dent in India. 231 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA January 1. The Reserve Bank issued a Notification permitting any person who is resident in India but is out of India to open with a bank situated out of India an account in foreign exchange and operate thereon during his stay out of India, provided that certain con- ditions were met. The permission would cease to be effective upon the account holder's return to India. January 1. The ban on exports of raw silk was lifted. January L The export du ty on semifinished hides and skins and on leather (excluding leather manufac- tures) was increased from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. January 1. The Reserve Bank issued a number of other notifications, most of which served to continue previous exchange control regulations or exemptions. January 3. Exports of natural rubber were channeled through the STC. January 3. Exports of beef tallow and buffalo tallow were banned. January 3. The Reserve Bank issued a Press Note about immovable property in India. Persons who were not citizens of India and companies (other than bank- ing companies) which were not incorporated under any law in force in India, or in which the nonresident inter- est was more than 40 per cent, had to obtain the permis- sion of the Reserve Bank to acquire, hold, transfer, or dispose of in any manner (except by way of lease for a period not exceeding five years) any immovable prop- erty situated in India. This was in accordance with Section 31 of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973. Applications for acquiring, holding, transferring, or disposing of any immovable property in India by for- eign citizens and also by foreign companies (the latter as permitted under the notification issued by the Re- serve Bank on January 1, referred to above) and appli- cations for the sale of tea, coffee, and rubber estates in India, which were owned by sterling companies, and remittance of the sale proceeds thereof outside India had to be made in a prescribed form to the Controller of the Exchange Control Department of the Reserve Bank. Persons and companies holding any immovable property in India on January 1, 1974 were required to declare such holdings to the Reserve Bank in a pre- scribed form before April 1, 1974. (This deadline was later extended to May 31, 1974.) Such declarations as well as those under the Reserve Bank notification of January 1, in respect of foreign companies referred to above, were also required to be submitted to the Cen- tral Office of the Reserve Bank. January 4. The Reserve Bank issued a Press Note regarding immovable property outside India. Without the permission of the Reserve Bank, no Indian citizen resident in India or firm or company registered or in- corporated in India could acquire, hold, transfer, or dispose of any immovable property situated outside India. Such permission was not, however, required in respect of immovable property acquired or transferred by way of lease for a period not exceeding five years. Applications for permission had to be made to the 232 Controller of the Exchange Control Department of the Reserve Bank's Central Office. Persons, firms, or companies already holding im- movable property abroad had to declare the holdings to the above office of the Reserve Bank in a prescribed form before April 1, 1974. January 11. The Reserve Bank issued a Notification by which, under subsection (7) of Section 26 of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973, it permitted, with respect to a firm or company (other than a bank- ing company) referred to in the said subsection: (1) the making of any security deposit by any employee of such firm or company and the acceptance of such deposit by such firm or company; (2) the making of any payments (whether by way of advance or otherwise) to such firm or company by purchasing, selling, or other agents in the course of, or for the purpose of, the business of such firm or company, or against orders for goods, proper- ties, or services, and the acceptance of such payments by such firm or company; and (3) the lending of any money to, or the making of any deposit with, such firm or company, as had been permitted under (1) and (2) to borrow money or, as the case might be, to accept deposits. January 11. The Reserve Bank issued a Notification under subsection (6) of Section 26 of the Foreign Ex- change Regulation Act, 1973 permitting authorized dealers to give performance bonds or guarantees (in- cluding those in lieu of earnest money) in favor of over- seas buyers on account of bona fide exports from India. The same Notification redelegated powers, as fol- lows: (1) to authorized dealers, to give guarantees in favor of persons resident in India in respect of any debt or other obligation or liability of persons resident out- side India; and (2) to firms and companies resident in India, to give guarantees to income tax officers and other authorities under the Income Tax Act, 1961 in respect of taxes due by nationals of foreign states in the employ of such firms or companies. January 14. The Reserve Bank issued a Press Note explaining the provisions of its notification issued on January 11 about lending money to, or making depos- its with, foreign firms and companies, and advising persons who intended to lend money to, or make de- posit with, a firm or company of the kind referred to, to satisfy themselves that the firm or company con- cerned had been permitted to borrow money or accept deposits. Firms or companies of the kind referred to intending to borrow money from any bank authorized to deal in foreign exchange in India were required to submit an application in the prescribed form to the bank con- cerned. Where, however, they proposed to borrow from other sources or to accept deposits from residents in India, the registered, head, or principal office of the firm or company had to make an application in the prescribed form direct to the office of the Reserve Bank within whose jurisdiction the applicant's office was sit- uated. ©International Monetary Fund. The ban imposed in 1943 on exports of silver was lifted. On February 21 it was announced that exports of silver would be licensed freely (except on a consignment basis). March 1. April 1. A commercial cooperation agreement with the EEC and special agreements with the EEC relating to Indian exports of jute goods and coir products came into effect. April 1. Export licensing policies were tightened for iron and steel products. April 2. The "auxiliary import duty" on goods sub- ject to ad valorem duties of 60 per cent to 100 per cent was increased from 10 per cent to 15 per cent. April 2. The Import Policy for 1974/75 included the following modifications of the import-export regime: (1) Import licenses for raw materials, components, and spare parts issued for the fiscal year 1973/74 were to be automatically valid for utilization on a repeat basis for 50 per cent of their value for the period April-Sep- tember 1974. (2) Manufacturer-exporters were also al- lowed the facility of repeat operation in respect of import replenishment licenses and release orders for items channeled through state trading agencies for 1973/74; the value of licenses utilized under this facility was subject to adjustment against normal import enti- tlements over a period of 18 months from April 1, 1974. Established importers were also permitted to uti- lize on a repeat basis their quota licenses for 1973/74, subject to certain conditions. (3) For units in specified industries, import licenses were to be issued provided that at least 10 per cent of their production was set apart for sales to registered exporters. (4) Units in non- INDIA priority industries were now to get priority treatment if they exported at least 20 per cent of their output. (5) Large-scale industrial units were allowed to import spare parts at the rate of 2V2 per cent of the values of imported machinery (as against 2 per cent previously); the rate of 4 per cent for small-scale units was contin- ued. (6) The ceiling on emergency licenses to actual users for imports of spare parts was doubled to Rs 20,000 for large-scale units and Rs 8,000 for small-scale units. (7) Eligibility criteria for the scheme giving special treatment to export houses were revised in order to make the scheme more export oriented. (8) Ten additional import items were channeled through public sector agencies, bringing the total of such items to 210. (9) An additional 75 import items were prohib- ited. (10) An additional 61 import items were re- stricted. April 4. India signed the Asian Clearing Union Agreement. The agreement came into force on Decem- ber 9. April 25. The Reserve Bank extended until May 31, 1974 the period for submission of declarations of im- movable property held in India by foreign citizens and foreign companies. April 25. Exports of all types of cotton yarn (except singles and folded) were banned until January 1, 1975. May 23. Exports of certain aluminum products were banned. May 29. The Reserve Bank was prepared to purchase Japanese yen spot and forward for one, two, or three months' delivery. June 1. The Reserve Bank offered long-term forward cover in respect of exports of capital and producer goods on deferred payment terms. Such cover was of- fered for deutsche mark, Japanese yen, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars, and for periods ranging from 18 months to 10 years from the date of conclusion of the export contract. Ineligible were exports whose proceeds were to be cleared through the Asian Clearing Union or under any special clearing arrangement between In- dia and the foreign country concerned, and exports under contracts containing an exchange variation clause linking the price of the goods to the ruling value of the foreign currency concerned in terms of gold or SDRs. June 1. The Mica Trading Corporation of India Ltd. was established. Exports of mica were channeled through it. June 4. The Reserve Bank issued instructions to en- force the provisions of the Foreign Exchange Regula- tion Act, 1973 which made Reserve Bank permission mandatory for remaining outside India beyond the date or period, or for traveling to any place outside India other than such place or places, that might be specified by the Reserve Bank in a traveler's passport, foreign exchange permit, or application for booking passage. The limit on remittances to educational institutions outside India toward fees in respect of ex- aminations held by them in India was raised from £ stg. 12 to £ stg. 30 a calendar year an applicant. June 2L The stand-by arrangement with Nepal was renewed. June 29. The Reserve Bank announced the extension until August 31 of the time limit for the submission of applications to receive permission for: (1) nonresidents, non-Indian citizens, and nonbank companies incorpo- rated abroad or in which the nonresident interest is more than 40 per cent, to continue to carry on trading, commercial, or industrial activities in India; (2) such persons or companies to continue to hold shares of Indian companies; (3) such persons or companies to continue to hold appointments as agents or technical (or management) advisers; and (4) such persons or companies to continue arrangements by which they had permitted the use of trademarks by others. July 8. Following an extension by the import licens- ing authorities of the grace period for effecting ship- ment from 30 days to 60 days beyond the final date for shipment stated on an import license, authorized deal- ers were permitted to open import letters of credit valid up to 75 days beyond the final date for shipment stated on the license, instead of up to 45 days, as previously. July 24. The limit of Rs 20,000 on applications for the import of capital goods and machine tools by small-scale industrial units was raised to Rs 50,000, for imports from the Rupee Payment Area only. July 31. The Reserve Bank permitted remittances abroad to nonresidents of dividends earned for the pe- riod ended June 30, 1974 to be made also where no permission of the Reserve Bank had been obtained by the nonresident concerned to continue to hold the cor- responding shares. However, such permission would be necessary for remittance of dividends for the period commencing July 1, 1974; in the absence of this per- mission, Reserve Bank approval would have to be ob- tained for the particular remittance. August 5. Surplus fares and freight collections of Indian airline and shipping companies operating in Bangladesh, which had previously been repatriated in Indian rupees through the Nonconvertible Rupee Ac- count No. 1 of the Bangladesh Bank with the Reserve Bank (Calcutta), became repatriable in free foreign ex- change. This applied to earnings from July 1, 1974. August 7. Following the promulgation of the Compa- nies (Temporary Restrictions on Dividends) Ordi- nance, 1974, authorized dealers were advised by the Reserve Bank to refer the applications for remittances of dividends to the Bank for prior approval. Such appli- cations were approved as follows: (1) Where the divi- dend proposed to be remitted was declared by the 234 applicant company prior to July 6, 1974, and if such dividend was also paid to the resident shareholders before that date, the applications were approved after the usual scrutiny. (2) Where the dividend was declared and paid to resident shareholders after July 6, 1974, applications were approved after submission of a certif- icate from the applicant company's auditors to the ef- fect that the dividend so declared and paid was within the limits permitted under the Companies (Temporary Restrictions on Dividends) Act, 1974. August 14. Authorized dealers no longer were per- mitted to effect remittances in foreign exchange, or to make rupee transfers to nonresident bank accounts, for amounts of Rs 50,000 or more unless payment was received in the form of a check in the name of the person or firm in whose name the remittance or transfer had been approved by the Reserve Bank. August 17. A special payments arrangement was con- cluded with Burma. Special rupee accounts would be opened by the Punjab National Bank in the name of the Union of Burma Bank, to record payments in respect of imports and exports of specified commodities up to specified amounts. This payments arrangement came into operation on September 21. The relevant instruc- tions were issued by the Chief Controller of Imports and Exports on November 28 and by the Reserve Bank on December 28. August 24. The Reserve Bank tightened certain pro- cedures with respect to the issue of exchange permits. August 31. Outstanding export/import contracts be- tween India and Yugoslavia completed before Decem- ber 31, 1972 could be transacted in nonconvertible rupees until December 31, 1974. The previous limit had been June 30. September 7. Exports of 40 specified chemicals were banned, while those of 7 other chemicals were placed on a "merit" basis. September 9. The Government announced a scheme whereby priority allotments of Indian automobiles and motor scooters would be made to individuals against certain inward remittances of foreign exchange. The scheme could be utilized by foreign nationals coming to stay in India continuously for at least two years, Indian nationals returning from abroad, and relatives of non- resident Indian nationals who remitted foreign ex- change to them for purchases under this scheme. The Ministry of Heavy Industry accepted applications from September 16. These had to be presented within three months of the date of receipt of the inward remittance. Under the instructions issued by the Reserve Bank, the rupee proceeds of such remittances were to be placed in nonconvertible accounts in the names of the benefi- ciaries; debits for payment in respect of allotted auto- mobiles and motor scooters and for other local payments in India were freely permitted, but all other debits required prior approval by the Reserve Bank. The import of textile machinery was prohibited. Previously, Indians residing abroad or re- turning from abroad had been permitted to import such machinery up to a c.i.f. value of Rs 2.5 million, but no commercial imports were permitted. November 8. The export of H.P.S. groundnuts was channeled through the Indian Oil and Produce Export- ers Association. November 27. The Reserve Bank granted to compa- nies incorporated in India in which the nonresident share did not exceed 74 per cent, and which satisfied certain other requirements, a general exemption from the provision of the Foreign Exchange Act, 1973, which required foreign or foreign-controlled companies to obtain permission of the Reserve Bank to continue their activities in India. The special requirements for this exemption were (1) that such a company was en- gaged exclusively in producing "core" items or in an industry exporting at least 60 per cent of its output, (2) that such a company was licensed after February 1970, (3) that its production did not exceed its licensed capac- ity, and (4) that it did not undertake expansion or diversification of its activities without the prior permis- sion of the Reserve Bank. November 30. (The existing permission was valid until December 31, 1974.) December 17. Agreement was reached to terminate the trade and payments agreement with Bangladesh with effect from January 1, 1975. The minimum value added prescribed for exports of engineering goods was reduced from 25 per cent to 10 per cent. December 27. The prohibition on the import of diesel generating sets was suspended for a period of six months.
