Not for Redistribution INDONESIA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Indonesian Rupiah has been established with the Fund. In the Jakarta foreign ex- change Bourse, transactions in U.S. dollars have since August 23, 1971 been effected at rates within 1 per cent cither side of Rp 415 per US$1; on December 31, 1974 the buying and selling rates were Rp 414 and Rp 416, respectively, per US$1. Exchange rates for other cur- rencies are determined on the basis of the Jakarta rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, and rates for the currencies concerned in international markets. In the Jakarta foreign exchange Bourse three calls for exchange are conducted each week under the manage- ment of Bank Indonesia. Bidding for exchange in the call is restricted to the authorized foreign exchange banks and licensed foreign exchange dealers. Bank In- donesia is committed to deal with any willing buyer or seller at the going rate. Representatives of the foreign exchange banks notify Bank Indonesia of their supply to the market and each presents a bid for the total of his bank's requirements at a particular rate. Bank Indo- nesia clears the market at the intervention rate. The Bank also offers authorized banks certain facilities for forward contracts in respect of aid exchange and for swap transactions in U.S. dollars. Sabang is entirely outside the Indonesian exchange and trade control system,1 but the Indonesian rupiah is legal tender there. Administration of Control The implementation of exchange and trade control is entrusted to Bank Indonesia, the Ministry of Trade, the Ministry of Finance, authorized foreign exchange banks, and the customs authorities. Exchange control is administered by Bank Indonesia and the Ministry of Finance. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected through the authorized banks and are normally effected in convert- ible currencies. Export proceeds must be received in Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Italian lire, Japan- ese yen, Malaysian dollars, Netherlands guilders, New Zealand dollars, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escu- dos, pounds sterling, Singapore dollars, Swedish kro- nor, Swiss francs, or U.S. dollars. Indonesia has no operative payments agreements.2 Nonresident Accounts There are no restrictions on the opening by foreign nationals of accounts in Indonesia in rupiahs or foreign currencies with authorized foreign exchange banks. No distinction is made between resident and nonresident accounts. Imports and Import Payments There is a registry of authorized importers and an initial deposit is required for registration. Since Octo- ber 31, 1968, only Indonesian nationals may obtain an importer's license, but certain established foreign firms have been enabled to retain their licenses and new for- eign investors can obtain an importer's license re- stricted to the import of materials required for their own projects. Imports from Angola, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, as are imports from all sources of any secondhand goods and of specified commodities. The latter include built-up sedans and station wagon se- dans; components for the assembly of luxury-type au- tomobiles; built-up commercial vehicles and motorcycles; radio and television sets in built-up or semi-knocked-down condition; sarongs; galvanized iron sheets; iron roofing sheets; mosquito sticks; matches; monosodium glutamate; mattresses; certain types of cotton yarn; and specified types of textiles, car tires, batteries, printed matter, office supplies, animal traps, bottles, and lamps and bulbs. The importing of cloves, fertilizers, rice, refined sugar, and wheat and wheat flour is restricted to specified approved import- ers. Imports of certain commodities for the "national iron stock" are reserved for state enterprises; they in- clude newsprint and certain types of paper, tires, cotton weaving yarn, and pharmaceutical raw materials. No licenses are required for imports. All permitted imports may be paid for either with general exchange (Devisa Umuni) or aid exchange {Devisa Kredid- For imports financed with aid exchange a compensation payment is granted after customs clearance; this payment ranges from Rp 20 to Rp 45 per U.S. dollar of the import value, depending on country of origin and /or donor country. Except for textiles, importers may without bank gua- rantee contract short-term credit under "merchant let- ters of credit,"3 but otherwise sight bankers' letters of credit are required for all private sector imports with the exception of parcel imports, goods brought in by travelers of a value not exceeding US$100, and imports specifically authorized by the Ministry of Trade (such as goods constituting part of a foreign investment). A rupiah deposit of 100 per cent of the amount of the letter of credit must be lodged with Bank Indonesia when a letter of credit is opened in respect of imports financed with aid exchange; for imports financed with general exchange, importers are required to make an advance deposit of at least 40 per cent of the letter of credit value when they submit applications for letters 237 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDONESIA of credit to authorized banks, and to settle the balance within 75 days of the opening of the letter of credit. Applications to foreign exchange banks for imports under merchant letters of credit must be accompanied by a deposit of 25 per cent of the value. The deposits are released to the importer only after the issuance of the KPP (customs clearance document) or when he presents correspondence from suppliers indicating that the merchant letter of credit has been canceled. The amount of the deposit against letters of credit for non- government imports financed with aid exchange is left to the discretion of the authorized bank if the latter purchases aid exchange forward from Bank Indonesia. Import duties, which are almost without exception ad valorem, are imposed on the c.i.f. value of the com- modities converted at the customs valuation rate (Rp 415 per US$1 on December 31, 1974). Sales taxes of 5, 10, and 20 per cent are levied on most impor ts on their c. & f. value plus import duty. Items which are exempted from import duties are also exempted from sales taxes. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted or subject to control. Pro- ceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered. Travel- ers may take out and bring in any amount in foreign banknotes but only Rp 2,500 in Indonesian notes and coins other than gold and silver commemorative coins; Indonesian commemorative gold and silver coins is- sued in August 1970 may be taken out freely up to Rp 65,000 a person, while the limit applicable to gold and silver coins issued in October 1974 is Rp 130,000. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Angola, the People's Republic of China, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohib- ited, as are exports to all countries of gold ore and pure gold; copra; coconut oil; clove seeds; pepper seeds; fer- tilizers; rawhides of cattle; certain categories of unpro- cessed or low-quality rubber; certain logs and timber; all types of waste paper (from Java and Madura); scrap of bronze and copper (except f rom Irian Jaya); iron scrap; and scrap of steel (from Java, Madura, and Su- matra). The prior authorization of the Minister of Trade is required for the export of f la tba rk crepe, cin- chona bark, silver, and antiques of cultural value. Oth- erwise, all commodities may be freely exported by registered private f irms and state trad ing firms. All exporters except the petroleum companies, cer- tain m in ing companies, and licensed "border-crossing" traders must require their buyers to open a bank letter of credit covering the value of the goods to be exported. For certain m inor exports, inc lud ing hand ic ra f ts, the exporter must surrender the full foreign exchange value prior to shipment if there is no buyer's letter of credit .4 For the principal export commodities other than pe- troleum, the sales price must not be lower than "indica- tion" prices ("check" prices) determined periodically by 238 the Minister of Trade. The full proceeds from exports other than petroleum, products of certain mining com- panies, and goods exported by licensed "border- crossing" traders are subject to surrender (except in "border-crossing" trade, see below) and, except for fin- ished goods, batik textiles and other handicrafts, ply- wood, fresh fish, and a number of other items, are subject to a 10 per cent export tax. Exports of petro- leum and of products of certain mining companies are also exempt from export tax. A specific cess is levied on exports of certain agricultural products and on inter-island trading in the same products. Certain commodities produced in border regions may be exported to Malaysia and the Philippines in exchange for certain eligible goods. In this "border- crossing" trade with Malaysia, the value of import or export shipments must not exceed M$600 a mon th, if transported overland, and M$600 a shipment, if trans- ported by sea. Capital Foreign capital invested in Indonesia is governed primarily by the Foreign Capital Investment Law of January 10, 1967, as amended in August 1970, and by Presidential Guidelines issued on January 22, 1974 and September 11, 1974. In principle, such investments may be undertaken only through a jo int venture with an Indonesian partner. All investments in Indonesia re- quire the approval of the Investment Coordinating Board (BKPM). Enterprises that are wholly or largely operated in Indonesia as separate business units must be incorporated under Indonesian law and must have their domicile in Indonesia. The operating permit for foreign inves tment is usually valid for a maximum of 30 years. Among the inducements offered are exemption from, or reduction in, corporate and dividend taxes for a certain number of years. Investors are granted the right to transfer prof i ts (after settlement of taxes and f inanc ial obligations in Indonesia) and to make trans- fers relating to expenses connected with the employ- ment of foreign na t iona ls in Indonesia, and in respect of depreciation allowances after the expiration of the tax holiday from corporation tax. The law provides that no transfer permit shall be issued for capital repa- triation as long as the investments benefit from tax relief; at present, however, foreign payments do not require a transfer permit. The exploration and develop- ment of petroleum resources are governed by the Petro- leum Law of 1960. A special regime applies to enterprises previously nationalized but now restored to the original owners. Such enterprises are allowed tax holidays for a period of three years on new capital in foreign currency brought in within the context of rehabilitation and ex- pansion programs that have been approved by the Gov- ernmen t. The transfer of proceeds from the sale of the assets of those restored enterprises which ceased opera- tions could take place w i th effect from January 1, 1972 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution at the rate of one f if th of the proceeds each year, with a full guarantee as to their value in foreign currency. The transfer of proceeds from the sale of assets of enter- prises whose period of operation has expired or whose operations have been terminated by the Government is allowed at the rate of one f i f th a year effective from the time of the sale of assets. This transfer is guaranteed as to its value in foreign currency. A Debt Investment Conversion Scheme (DIGS) ex- ists for the benefit of foreign creditors holding non- guaranteed claims against Indonesia. Rupiahs covered by the Scheme are administered in two kinds of DICS-Rupiah Accounts, A and B, the former relating only to claims of which the creditor is the first holder. Private creditors willing to accept the terms of the Scheme and prepared to make investments under the Foreign Investment Law of 1967 are paid in rupiahs in settlement of their claims. These claims are transferable to other potential investors in Indonesia, but only the original creditor's DIGS rupiahs may be used, in the creditor's own projects that have been approved under the Foreign Investment Law of 1967, for the purchase of foreign exchange for the import of equipment and raw materials necessary for the establishment and oper- ation of those projects. There are no limitations on the remittance to Indone- sia of capital in the form of foreign exchange or in commodities. Both residents and nonresidents may hold foreign currency deposits with foreign exchange banks. However, foreign exchange banks, nonbank fi- nancial institutions, and private companies are subject to Bank Indonesia directives with respect to borrowing abroad, the acceptance of deposits from nonresidents, and the issuance of certificates of deposit to nonresi- dents. Furthermore, a uniform reserve requirement of 30 per cent is applicable to the foreign currency liabili- ties of the foreign exchange banks. Certain other bor- rowing abroad is subject to clearance by and reporting to Bank Indonesia. The prior approval of the Minister of Finance is required before any public enterprise or public sector body may accept a loan from abroad. Indonesian citizens and residents of foreign national- ity may freely transfer, negotiate, import, and export securities denominated in rupiahs or in foreign cur- rency. Gold Indonesia has issued six commemorative gold coins, which are legal tender. Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold and gold coins in Indonesia. Exports of gold ore and pure gold, unless made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, are prohibited by virtue of Decision No. 6 8 /K P / IV / 70 of April 17, 1970 of the Minister of Trade. Travelers may freely take out Indo- nesian commemorative gold and silver coins issued in August 1970 up to Rp 65,000 a person, and gold and silver coins issued as part of the "conservation coinage" in October 1974 up to Rp 130,000 a person; amounts INDONESIA in excess require the prior approval of Bank Indonesia. Imports of gold are free of license but require prior notification to the Ministry of Industry and are subject to an extra levy of Rp 25 per US$1. Changes during 1974 January 1. A circular issued by Bank Indonesia on December 31, 1973 came into effect, which regulated the activities of nonbank financial institutions in the field of foreign exchange. January 21. Exports of iron and steel scrap were prohibited. January 22. With minor exceptions, the import of built-up sedans and station wagons and of components for the assembly of luxury automobiles was prohibited. January 22. The President announced certain new principles that would govern new foreign investment in Indonesia. Except in off-shore oil exploration and cer- tain off-shore manufacturing industries (those estab- lished in restricted areas, such as bonded warehouses and private entrepots), new investments could only be made through a joint venture with Indonesian partners. The number of economic activities closed to foreign investors would be increased. A target date would be set by which the Indonesian share in new and existing foreign investments should attain at least 51 per cent. April 1. Foreign banks and insurance companies hav- ing representative offices in Jakarta were allowed to undertake specified operations outside the capital, sub- ject to certain conditions. April 9. Bank Indonesia set individual ceilings on each foreign exchange bank's permissible receipts of foreign funds. April 9. Bank Indonesia set individual ceilings on each nonbank financial institution's acceptance of for- eign loans. April 9. Bank Indonesia directed nonbank financial institutions and private companies to deposit with it, at no interest and in the form of foreign exchange, at least 30 per cent of all cash loans received from abroad. There were exemptions for funds received within the framework of the Inter-Governmental Group on Indo- nesia (IGGI); loans with a maturity in excess of 15 years; funds to be used to finance imports of goods or services; and borrowing related to projects approved under the Foreign Investment Act (No. 1 of 1967) and the Domestic Investment Act (No. 6 of 1968). The 10 per cent deposit requirement against the foreign cur- rency liabilities of foreign exchange banks was in- creased to 30 per cent. A 30 per cent reserve requirement was introduced against banks' rupiah lia- bilities to nonresidents and to residents (for funds origi- nating abroad). June 1. Imports of certain types of cotton weaving yarn were reserved for state enterprises. June 12. A decision of the Minister of Finance im- posed an export tax of 10 per cent on the f.o.b. value on all goods except those classified as finished prod- 239 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDONESIA ucts. This tax replaced the 10 per cent exchange tax on export proceeds, which had involved a multiple cur- rency practice. July 15. Imports of built-up air conditioners, refrig- erators, and electric sewing machines were prohibited. August 8. An agreement on border trade was signed with the Philippines. August 14. The import of unregistered pharmaceuti- cals, foods tuffs, beverages, and cosmetics was prohib- ited. August 24. A basic agreement on economic and tech- nical cooperation was signed with Singapore. With the coming in to force of this agreement, border trade with Singapore was considered terminated. August 26. Rupiah liabilities originating abroad were reclassified as "rupiah liabilities" and thus became sub- ject to the rupiah reserve and deposit requirements. Previously, such liabilities had been treated as foreign exchange liabilities. September 21. The President issued guidelines on the transfer to Indonesians of shares in foreign-owned or foreign-controlled companies. September 30. The prohibition on exports of corn and corn products was lifted. October 1. As part of the "conservation coinage" of the World Wildlife Fund, a gold coin with a face value of Rp 100,000 and two silver coins w i th face values of Rp 5,000 and Rp 2,000 were issued. They were legal tender. October 11. The Chairman of the BKPM issued a circular outlining how and when the Indonesian share in joint ventures should be increased to 51 per cent. November 11. Imports of textiles could no longer be settled under a merchant's letter of credit; a documen- tary letter of credit opened by an authorized foreign exchange bank was required. November 11. Domestic banks were no longer per- mitted to finance imports of textiles. November 11. Imports of cotton yarn and raw cotton were reserved for designated state enterprises. December 28. The 30 per cent deposit requirement against foreign borrowing by private enterprises and nonbank financial institutions was abolished. The 30 per cent reserve requirement against the foreign cur- rency liabilities of foreign exchange banks and the 30 per cent deposit requirement against the foreign bor- rowings of foreign exchange banks remained in force. December 31. The prohibition on the export of copra and coconut oil was extended for another year. Not for Redistribution IRAN (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0108055 gram of fine gold per Iranian Rial, corresponding to Rls 68.1747 = US$1, and Iran avails itself of wider margins. The official rates of Bank Markazi Iran (the Central Bank) for the U.S. dollar, the only currency that is officially quoted, are Rls 67.50 buying, and Rls 67.75 selling, per US$1. The Central Bank also publishes daily exchange rates for 14 other currencies1 for purposes of the calculation of import registration fees and import duties; these rates are based on the official rates for the U.S. dollar and the London market rates for the currencies con- cerned. There is a dual exchange market, consisting of a commercial market (or official rate market), with fixed U.S. dollar rates, and a noncommercial market, with fluctuating rates. Both markets operate within the banking system. As of December 31, 1974, the free market rates for the U.S. dollar were Rls 67.50 buying, and Rls 67.75 selling. The Central Bank stands ready to purchase from the commercial banks, at official rates, any foreign exchange proceeds from exports of goods and services. Import payments must in principle be settled in the official rate market. Also settled at official rates are basic allocations for certain authorized current payments (travel, study, and medical treatment abroad) and, on the supply side, any export proceeds and other current receipts converted by public sector agencies (including the National Iranian Oil Com- pany). Proceeds from exports other than oil, oil prod- ucts, and natural gas, as well as the proceeds from exports of services, may be sold either in the official or the noncommercial market. All other payments and receipts are settled at the noncommercial market rate. However, transactions over clearing accounts denomi- nated in U.S. dollars are in all cases settled at the official buying and selling rates. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Central Bank. In principle, all foreign exchange transactions must take place through the Central Bank or autho- rized banks. The import and export of goods is gov- erned by regulations issued annually by the Ministry of Commerce and approved by the Council of Ministers. Foreign trade relations with Albania and the Republic of China are under the control of the Foreign Transac- tions Company within the Ministry of Commerce. Prescription of Currency Transactions with six of the nine countries with which Iran has bilateral payments agreements2 must be conducted through agreement accounts denominated in U.S. dollars, while those with the People's Republic of China, the German Democratic Republic, and North Korea must be conducted through accounts de- nominated in Iranian rials. Payments to and from Paki- stan and Turkey relating to visible trade (excluding border trade, petroleum and petroleum products, and defense materials) are settled over clearing accounts maintained by the respective central banks in U.S. dol- lars. Payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Settlements with other countries normally are settled in the quoted currencies.1 Nonresident Accounts Foreign nationals are permitted to maintain ac- counts freely, in rials as well as in foreign currencies, with authorized banks; rial accounts may be used both for payments in Iran and for conversion into foreign currencies through the noncommercial market. Foreign nationals as well as Iranian physical or juridical per- sons may maintain sight or time deposits in foreign currencies in Iran; these accounts may be used for transfers abroad or for sales to authorized banks. Imports and Import Payments All imports into Iran are subject to control by the Government. The import policy is re-examined annu- ally, and a new Import List, effective for the next Ira- nian year, is published by the Ministry of Commerce. The Import List distinguishes between "authorized," "unauthorized," and "prohibited" goods. "Authorized" imports, consisting of goods whose importation is con- sidered essential and including items which either are not produced in Iran or are produced in Iran but not in quantities sufficient to meet domestic requirements, are divided into two main categories: (1) imports for which orders may be placed without prior approval by government agencies,3 and (2) imports that are subject to prior approval by government agencies (generally the Ministry of Commerce) before the import order is placed. "Unauthorized" imports are goods whose im- portation is not considered essential, including goods whose local production is sufficient to meet domestic demand. Commodities may be shifted from the "authorized" list to the "unauthorized" list, and vice versa, as and when deemed necessary. For "prohibited" goods, no authorizations are given; these comprise only a few items such as opium and firearms. Imports without payment through the official ex- change market of "authorized" goods require prior ap- proval by the Ministry of Commerce and the Central Bank. However, imports of "authorized" goods without payment are permitted without any limitation, pro- vided that registration is made before the order is placed. Such imports up to US$5,000 are permitted without prior registration but are subject to the regis- 241 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAN tration deposit; payments may be made either through the commercial or the noncommercial exchange mar- ket. In addition, permission is given for the following: imports destined for official charitable institutions or government organizations; machinery; spare parts, and raw or intermediate materials for productive entities, up to US$1,000 a shipment; and all other imports of "authorized" goods up to US$300 a shipment. Imports on this basis are exempt from the import registration deposit. The import of gifts, whether "authorized" or * 'unauthorized" commodities, is restricted to Rls 10,000 for each person a year. Specified commodities, such as sugar, wheat, to- bacco, and cigarette paper, are imported under state monopoly. Payments may be made either against bills for collec- tion or documentary letters of credit. Payments against bills for collection may be made without prior authori- zation for goods (mainly capital goods and raw materi- als) listed in the Schedule attached to Circular No. 116 of August 3, 1965 (Iranian date 12 /5 /1344). Payments for imports of other goods may also be made against bills for collection without prior permission from the Central Bank, provided that bills are settled within nine months. All orders for imports must be registered with the Central Bank through an authorized bank; registra- tion is effected against a pro forma invoice. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited and special regulations apply to certain commodities when origi- nating in Hong Kong. At the time of registration of imports, an import registration fee of 1 per cent of the amount of an import order, calculated on the basis of the official selling rate of Rls 67.75 per US$1, is collected by authorized banks. Imports brought in under the Law for the At- traction and Protection of Foreign Investment in Iran are exempted from the fee. For some goods, importers must at the time of registration deposit with the Central Bank, through an authorized bank, a deposit of 15 per cent of the invoiced value. Most food items are exempt from the registration deposit. The deposit is refundable upon presentation of the customs clearance certificate after the respective goods have been cleared through customs, or if and when the order is canceled. The Central Bank may permit, when necessary, the shifting of imports from the category in which an advance im- port deposit is required to the exempt category. Authorized banks make payments for permitted im- ports against the presentation of shipping documents. Approval of the shipping documents by the authorized banks represents approval of the foreign exchange transfer. Almost all imports are subject to commercial profit taxes, which are either specific or ad valorem and are in addition to any applicable customs duty. The ad valorem commercial profit tax ranges from 1 per cent to 200 per cent. Monopoly taxes are included in the commercial profit taxes. The authorities specify in the Import List the commercial profit taxes for each year. 242 These taxes are paid to the customs before customs clearance. The clearance through customs is authorized upon the presentation of shipping documents endorsed by the authorized banks, specifying that payment has been made or will be made, and, when required, that the special import authorization has been received from government agencies prior to lading of goods in the country of origin. Payments for Invisibles Payments for all current invisibles may be made freely through the noncommercial market. In addition, there are certain allocations at the official rate for travel, study, and medical treatment abroad. Payments for invisibles related to imports are made on the same basis as payments for the f.o.b. value of those imports. Official exchange is granted to importers for insurance of imports against bills for collection; for imports covered by documentary letters of credit, in- surance must be taken out in Iran. Official exchange is not granted to exporters for insurance of Iranian ex- ports sold f.o.b. Official exchange also is not granted for the payment of other insurance premiums, although reinsurance premium payments are permitted. Autho- rized banks are permitted to remit interest on import- ers' suppliers' credit not exceeding 8.5 per cent; higher interest rates require special permission from the Cen- tral Bank. Foreign nationals working in Iran as technical assis- tants whose employment has been recognized as neces- sary by the Government may remit at the official rate about 50 per cent of their net salaries; any additional amounts may be remitted through the noncommercial market. The basic travel allowance for Iranian and for- eign nationals, the equivalent of Rls 50,000 a person a trip, may be made available by authorized banks at the official rate upon presentation of a valid passport and exit permit; each accompanying member of the pass- port holder's family is entitled to the same allowance, and there is no limit on the number of times a person may avail himself of this facility. Additional funds in respect of personal or business travel may be purchased freely in the noncommercial market. Banks may sell, at the official rate, up to the equivalent of Rls 200,000 a person to Iranian nationals traveling or residing abroad, for medical treatment; additional foreign ex- change at the official rate can be obtained against medi- cal bills certified by an Iranian consulate abroad, and any fur ther amounts may be purchased in the noncom- mercial market. Iranian physical and juridical persons may also freely make remittances abroad from domestic current accounts in which they retain foreign exchange received from sources abroad, including export proceeds; bal- ances in such accounts are freely transferable. Iranian nationals leaving the country are required to pay a travel tax of Rls 10,000 for each single-journey exit permit, also for pilgrimage travel. Lower rates ap- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ply to family members traveling on the same passport (wife and children from 7 to 18 years of age), viz., Rls 750 a person. Iranians resident abroad and stu- dents studying abroad but visiting home temporarily are exempt from payment of the tax. Travelers leaving Iran may take with them Rls 20,000 in Iranian banknotes. Travelers of foreign nationality may not export foreign currency in excess of the amount they imported less the amounts they have sold to authorized banks, as recorded in their passports; they may, however, convert rials up to the equivalent of US$100 into other currencies at the offi- cial rate, upon presentation of their visaed passport, and may freely convert any additional amount in the noncommercial market. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports of some commodities require licenses. The commercial profit tax and customs duty charged at the time of import of raw materials contained in manufactured goods for ex- port may be returned to the exporter after the export has taken place. Certain minor exports are granted incentive payments by the Center for the Promotion of Exports. The Central Bank offers preferential discount facilities for export bills. The foreign currency proceeds of commodities other than oil, oil products, and natural gas may be retained abroad; if they are repatriated, they may be kept as foreign currency deposits with domestic banks or sold to the banking system either in the official exchange market or in the noncommercial market. Authorized banks normally accept export proceeds only in U.S. dollars and other quoted currencies,1 but they are per- mitted to accept other currencies at their discretion. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles may be retained in a foreign currency account with an authorized bank, where they remain at the free disposal of the account holder. Travelers may freely bring in Rls 20,000 in Iranian banknotes; higher amounts require the prior approval of the Central Bank. The repatriation of Iranian bank- notes through the mail is not permitted. Capital Iranian nationals may retain in domestic foreign cur- rency accounts any capital receipts accruing in foreign exchange; transfers abroad from such accounts may be made freely, as may domestic transfers to other Iranian nationals. Private outward capital transfers may be made through the noncommercial market, irrespective of their purpose. The retransfer abroad at the official selling rate is permitted, provided that the inflow had been specifically authorized by the Central Bank. Au- thorized banks may freely accept inflows of foreign IRAN exchange from abroad (both deposits and borrowings) and lend the foreign currency to residents or sell it in the noncommercial market for rials; the rial counter- part may be lent to residents, but such lending is sub- ject to the applicable credit ceilings. In accordance with the Law for the Attraction and Protection of Foreign Investment in Iran (1955) and regulations implementing the law, foreign capital in- vested in approved development or productive activi- ties in industry, mining, agriculture, or transport may be repatriated, together with net profits (in accordance with Article 1 of the law and the provisions contained in the implementing regulations), in the form of foreign exchange and /or goods. Transfers of exchange must be made at the official market selling rate prevailing at the date of transfer. However, the Central Bank has the option of buying the exchange or accepting it as a deposit to be converted into rials at a rate mutually agreed upon in a separate agreement, and this rate remains applicable to the funds when they are repatri- ated. Capital imported under this law in the form of foreign exchange must be in currencies acceptable to the Central Bank; the exchange is converted into rials at the buying rate prevailing on the date of application for conversion. All conversions must take place in the official market (capital, profits and dividends, amorti- zation, and liquidation proceeds). The law does not set up any limit of participation with respect to the ratio of foreign to domestic investment, but the Supervisory Board encourages participation by Iranians in the pro- posed investment. Gold No Iranian gold coins are legal tender.4 Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold and silver in any form in Iran, and there is a free market for both. Authorized banks may freely import and export gold and silver (bullion only, which for gold must be at least "Yiooo fine), against settlement through the official rate market, and sell these metals to any person in Iran. The import and export of gold for monetary purposes or for international settlements is reserved for the Central Bank, while the import for industrial and dental use is effected by professional organizations, at the official rate and subject to supervi- sion by the Central Bank. The Central Bank accepts gold bullion on deposit from domestic banks as well as nonbank residents and issues gold certificates against such deposits. Travelers may freely import and export gold bullion and coins up to 1 kilogram a person a trip; the Central Bank is empowered to approve larger quan- tities. The export of Iranian gold coins for numismatic purposes requires prior approval by the Central Bank. Imports of gold are free from customs duty and com- mercial profit tax but are subject to the 1 per cent import registration fee. Bank Melli Iran and other com- mercial banks give daily quotations for domestic sales. 243 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAN Changes during 1974 January 10-14. A dual exchange market was intro- duced with the creation of a noncommercial market, and exchange restrictions were abolished in principle. The Central Bank took the following measures, which it instructed banks in Iran to execute immediately: (1) Exporters of goods other than petroleum, petro- leum products, and natural gas were exempted from exporters' undertakings and hence from the obligation of repatriating and surrendering export proceeds; they were given an option, if they did repatriate the pro- ceeds, either to sell their foreign exchange earnings to authorized banks at the official rate or to sell these proceeds in the noncommercial market; in addition, they could retain repatriated export proceeds in foreign currency accounts with domestic banks.5 (2) Banks were allowed to purchase foreign exchange earnings resulting from exports and services at current noncommercial market exchange rates, rather than the official rates quoted by the Central Bank, and to sell this foreign exchange at noncommercial market rates in any manner and for any purpose permitted by existing or fu ture directives of the Central Bank. (3) Banks could also purchase, either at their own discretion or on the basis of existing or fu ture regula- tions of the Central Bank, the foreign exchange pro- ceeds from inward capital transfers or from foreign currency loans taken up in Iran, and sell this exchange at free market rates in any manner and for any permit- ted purpose. (4) The Central Bank stood ready to purchase from banks at the official rate any excess supply of foreign exchange resulting from proceeds of exports and ser- vices (excluding capital inflows). (5) Individuals and institutions intending to sell to the Central Bank the foreign exchange proceeds from inward capital transfers and to repurchase these at the official rate for transfer abroad, were required to obtain the approval of the Central Bank and abide by other regulations prior to the transfer to Iran. (6) Provided they observed the relevant Central Bank regulations, banks could accept foreign currency de- posits from any physical or juridical person and make use of such deposits in any way they considered advis- able. (7) Foreign exchange purchased or accepted on de- posit in accordance with the rules under (2), (3), and (6) above would be referred to as "noncommercial foreign exchange," and banks were required to record in sepa- rate accounts all transactions in such foreign exchange. (8) In principle, the amount of "noncommercial for- eign exchange" sold by any individual bank could not at any time exceed the amount it had purchased. (9) In order to maintain an orderly exchange market, banks were required to compile, in a manner to be prescribed by the Central Bank, all data relating to the purchase and sale of foreign exchange, and to submit specified data to the Central Bank at the close of busi- 244 ness on the last day of each week and also at the end of each month. (10) The Central Bank's sales of foreign exchange to banks at the official rate for imports and for authorized noncommercial purposes would continue to take place on the same basis as previously; thus, the allocations at the official rate for travel or study abroad remained unchanged. January 17. The ban on imports of trucks and com- bined radio/tape recorders was lifted. March 21. The export-import regulations for the Ira- nian year 1353 were issued. The import registration fee for all goods would be reduced from 5.5 per cent to 1 per cent. (After approval by Parliament on April 21, this measure took effect retroactive to March 21.) Commercial profit taxes were either eliminated or re- duced on a wide range of goods, including biscuits, tea, wool, chemical products, and agricultural machinery. In addition, import duties on many items were reduced. March 21. Import subsidies were introduced on wheat, meat, sugar, and soybeans. June 9. Certain import items, such as iron, sheet steel, and certain yarn and textiles, ceased to require the prior approval of the Ministry of Commerce. July 20. The import deposit was generally reduced from 100 per cent or 40 per cent to 15 per cent, while it was eliminated for certain other goods (including butter, certain types of cheese, eggs, rice, wheat, barley, corn, black tea, and cement). July 22. Eight items on the "unauthorized" list were shifted to the "authorized" list; of these items, the Min- istry of Commerce authorized the import without prior approval of refrigerators and radio and television re- ceivers. July 27. Import payments henceforth could be made either against bills for collection or under documentary credits, provided that bills for collection in respect of nonessential goods were settled within nine months. Previously, only payments for specified essential goods could be made on a collection basis, letters of credit being prescribed in all other cases. September 17. The Government lifted the restrictions on authorized banks' imports and exports of gold and silver bullion and introduced a free market for gold and silver in Iran. All commercial and specialized banks authorized to deal in foreign exchange were permitted to import these metals and to sell them to any person in Iran; gold imports had to be in the form of bullion at least 995/iooo fine. However, banks were not permit- ted to sell these metals forward, and gold and silver held by banks could at no time exceed in value 10 per cent of the total of their paid-up capital and nonstatu- tory reserves. Applications from goldsmiths and silver- smiths and other professional groups to import gold and silver for industrial use would be screened by the Central Bank. Previously, imports of nonmonetary gold had been made only by the Bank Melli Iran, and exports had been prohibited, while the import and ex- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution port of monetary gold had been reserved for the Central Bank. Private citizens were permitted to hold gold and sil- ver in any form (previously only jewelry and orna- ments) and to import or export up to 1 kilogram of gold (bullion or coins) a person a trip. Central Bank permis- sion was required to bring in or take out more than 1 kilogram. Banks were permitted to lend up to 50 per cent against gold or silver collateral put up by private individuals. The Central Bank was authorized to issue negotiable gold certificates against gold bullion deposited with it. Banks dealing in gold or silver were required to post daily buying and selling prices. The Central Bank re- served the right to intervene in the gold or silver market whenever necessary. October 6. The Central Bank authorized export con- tracts to be denominated in Iranian rials for those com- modities not subject to repatriation and surrender requirements in respect of the exchange proceeds. December 1. Borrowing abroad by banks became subject to a deposit requirement of 15 per cent. The IRAN deposits were to be lodged with the Central Bank.
