Not for Redistribution IRAQ (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of f ine gold per Iraqi Dinar, corresponding to ID 1 = US$3.3778, and Iraq avails itself of wider margins. Transactions in the off i- cial market are carried out in any of the listed curren- cies l or in Iraqi dinars through nonresident accounts in Iraq. The Central Bank of Iraq quotes official rates for the listed currencies for its transactions with autho- rized dealers. The Bank's buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar, which is the intervention currency, were US$3.394678 and US$3.377778, respectively, on De- cember 31, 1974. Administration of Control The Board of Administration of the Central Bank of Iraq is entrusted with all powers and responsibilities in connection with exchange control; it has delegated this au thor i ty to the Foreign Exchange Committee (headed by the Governor of the Central Bank, his Deputy, or a member specified in advance by the Board of Admin- istration), to the Department of Foreign Exchange of the Central Bank, and to the licensed dealers. Foreign exchange transactions must take place through a li- censed dealer unless otherwise authorized by the Board of Administration. Import and export policy are deter- mined by the Council for the Regulation of Trade. The Directorate-General of Economics (Government and Private Import Section) in the Ministry of Economy, the General Organization for Trade, the General De- partment for Industrial Promotion in the Ministry of Indus try, and the Industrial Organization in the Minis- try of Industry are the principal licensing authorities for imports and exports, but import licenses are also issued by certain other public organizations and gov- ernment departments. A foreign exchange budget, in- cluding an import program, is established annually, and foreign exchange allocations under the import pro- gram are supervised by the Import Program Commit- tee. Prescription of Currency Settlements must be made in any of the listed curren- cies 1 or, under the bilateral payments agreements with the People's Republic of China, Egypt, and Yugoslavia, in dinars or pounds sterling through the appropriate clearing account.2 Payments to and receipts from Is- rael, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The opening of a nonresident account requires the approval of the exchange control authorities. Transac- tions permitted in convertible currencies may alterna- tively be settled in Iraqi dinars through nonresident 246 accounts. Nonresident accounts are divided into ordi- nary nonresident accounts, which arise from transac- tions in respect of current payments, and special nonresident accounts, which arise from transactions in respect of capital transfers. Furthermore, Iraqi nation- als who have been working abroad for at least a year or who become residents after having been nonresi- dents may open accounts in foreign currencies with banks in Iraq and credit these with up to 50 per cent of their foreign savings. Balances in such accounts may be used for a variety of purposes, including imports for the holder's personal use, imports of certain capital goods, or meeting expenditures abroad for travel, medi- cal treatment, and s tudy purposes; payments f rom these accounts up to the equivalent of ID 500 a year do not require Central Bank approval. Imports and Import Payments Imports of many commodities, including jute, sugar, tea, edible oil, certain medical supplies, machine tools, and automobiles, are a government monopoly. All pri- vate imports except those of the private sector oil com- panies require licenses; in principle these are issued in accordance with an annual import program, but this program has been made increasingly flexible, also for consumer goods. All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa and all imports from Hong Kong other than certain essential goods are prohibited. Im- ports of some commodities on a Protection List are in principle prohibited from all sources. A tax is levied on the amount of the import license at the fo l low ing rates: V2 per mill for producer goods, 1 per mill for consumer goods, and, in addition, up to 15 per cent on any supplementary import licenses above a private importer's annual quota. To finance the Export Subsidy Fund, a tax of V2 per cent is levied on imports of capital goods and a tax of 1 per cent on impor ts of consumer goods. All imports subject to im- port du ty are also subject to a customs surcharge of 15 per cent of the applicable customs du ty. Licensed dealers make exchange available upon pre- sentation of the exchange control copy of the import license, except in some instances where reference has to be made to the Central Bank. Payments for Invisibles With the exception of certain payments from foreign currency accounts (see section on Nonresident Ac- counts, above), all payments for invisibles require per- mission. Exchange is usually granted for educational and medical expenses abroad, freight on exports carried on a c. & f. basis, insurance premiums, royalties, etc. Exchange is not granted to merchants for the insurance abroad of their imports or exports. Licensed dealers are ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution permitted to transfer up to ID 50 a month for family maintenance on behalf of foreign nationals resident in Iraq, provided that remittances do not exceed half of the resident's monthly income; it is necessary to refer to the exchange control authorities for amounts exceed- ing this limit. There is a basic exchange allowance for tourist and business travel of ID 150 a calendar year for each per- son 18 years of age or over and of ID 100 for persons under 18 years of age, for trips of at least one week to Arab countries, socialist countries, Iran, and Turkey (ID 100 a person, irrespective of age, for trips of less than a week, or for five or more members of a family traveling together, irrespective of the length of their stay abroad). For travel to other countries, the basic allowance is ID 200 for each person 18 years of age or over and ID 100 for each person under 18, regardless of the length of the trip. In addition, there are special allocations of up to ID 1,000 a person for medical treatment abroad, and of ID 200 for persons accompa- nying a patient. Travelers may take out ID 5 in Iraqi currency notes, in addition to 50 per cent of the domestic currency equivalent of the foreign exchange allocated, which is considered part of the basic travel allowance, and the balance of that allowance in travelers checks. Residents on a pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia are permitted to take out the equivalent of ID 150 in listed currencies or in Saudi Arabian riyals (ID 75 for persons over 5 and under 18 and ID 25 for children 5 years of age or younger). Travelers leaving Iraq must deposit with an autho- rized bank 10 per cent of the Iraqi dinar equivalent of the foreign exchange granted. The deposit is refunded upon the traveler's return to Iraq, subject to the fulfill- ment of certain formalities. Exempt from the deposit requirement are officials of government, semigovern- ment, and public utility departments; students travel- ing for study purposes; pensioners; foreigners, except non-Iraqi wives of Iraqi nationals; and persons leaving on a pilgrimage. On leaving the country, Iraqi nationals must pay an exit tax of ID 20, except when traveling to Gulf countries or on an official mission the entire expense of which is borne by the Government. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Hong Kong, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa and exports of certain goods to all other countries are prohibited. The Ministry of Economy has authority to prohibit the export of any commodity when supply falls short of domestic demand. The Council for the Regulation of Trade may also prohibit the export of certain commodities. The export of cer- tain items is reserved for the Marketing and Services Corporation. All other exports are licensed freely. Exporters must generally undertake to repatriate their foreign exchange proceeds through a licensed dealer and to surrender them. Proceeds from exports of IRAQ dates taken by sailing boats to countries of the Gulf area (excluding Iran), India, and Pakistan are exempt from these requirements when the amount does not exceed ID 600 in value or 25 tons in weight. Some commodities may be exported on a compensation (bar- ter) basis. This system links the export of certain "new" exports to the import of prohibited items. Exports of certain goods are subsidized through an Export Sub- sidy Fund. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to a licensed dealer. Travelers may bring in foreign exchange, including currency notes (other than Israel currency), in unlimited amounts, provided that the funds are declared on an exchange control form; amounts not intended to be taken out of the country are exempt from declaration. Travelers may bring in ID 25 in Iraqi notes. Nonresidents who are engaged in border trade, however, may bring in ID 600 in Iraqi currency. Capital Nonresidents may import capital freely, except from Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa, but they must de- posit it with a licensed dealer; such deposits may be converted into local currency at the official rate, and repatriation to the country of origin is permitted. With minor exceptions, foreign companies starting opera- tions in Iraq must use Iraqi capital to the extent of at least 51 per cent of their total capital. The transfer of profits net of income tax from foreign investments is limited to 10 per cent per annum of the paid-up capital for trading companies, and to 20 per cent of the paid-up capital for industrial companies. These percentages are applicable for each year separately. They also apply to profits on capital resulting from the mandatory rein- vestment of profits in excess of the transferable percent- age. Arab capital invested in Iraq is exempt from these percentage limitations and entitled to preferential treat- ment in several other respects; interest payments are not subject to any ceilings. All transfers of capital abroad by residents, whether Iraqis or foreigners, re- quire exchange control approval; such transfers are se- verely restricted. Special facilities allow Arab investors to bring in convertible currency freely through a li- censed dealer for specified investment purposes; such capital and any net profits may be transferred abroad in convertible currency. Similar facilities permit Iraqi nationals to bring in convertible currency through a licensed dealer and deposit the funds in foreign cur- rency accounts, balances in which are freely transfer- able abroad. Under the Industrial Promotion Law (No. 22 of 1973), certain incentives and guarantees may be granted to approved investments of domestic or foreign capital in Iraq. Under the Iraqization Law of June 1961, all branches of foreign firms and all foreign- owned firms except banks 3 must have a majority of 247 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAQ equity capital held by Iraqi nationals; this law does not cover export agencies and operations requiring special skills. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in Iraq in any form other than gold bars. Imports and exports of gold in any form require the approval of the Central Bank. Since mid-1961, the Rafidain Bank has held a monopoly over the import and domestic distri- bution of gold needed for industrial purposes; it sells gold to registered goldsmiths only, under a quota sys- tem based on their past turnover of gold. Travelers may freely bring gold into Iraq, provided that it is declared at the point of entry on a foreign exchange form. Changes during 1974 February 12. The amount in listed currencies that authorized dealers were allowed to keep on deposit with their foreign correspondents was increased from 10 per cent to 15 per cent of their foreign liabilities. February 21. The limitations imposed under the 1972 austerity program on the transfer abroad of airline companies' net receipts were removed. March 4. The Japanese yen was included among the listed currencies. March 19. The embargo on petroleum exports to the United States was lifted. April 1. The import program for 1974/75 came into effect. It made provision for imports valued at ID 1.26 billion, nearly ID 1 billion in excess of the initial alloca- tions of the previous year's program. A number of import items were added to the Protection List; these included butter, biscuits, chocolate, alcoholic bever- ages, cement, soap, detergents, fabrics of man-made fibers, clothing, and air conditioners. Items taken off the Protection List included sulphuric acid, paints, cos- metic products, cotton yarn, leather footwear, ceiling fans, and television sets. July 10. The embargo on petroleum exports to Den- mark and the Netherlands was lifted. NOTES 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dol- lars. 2 In January 1975, agreement was reached with Yugoslavia to terminate the payments agreement in February. 3 All commercial banks and insurance companies were na- tionalized on July 14, 1964. 248 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Irish Pound. Since June 23, 1972, however, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the Irish pound within prescribed margins, except for sterling. The Central Bank of Ireland quotes the pound sterling at par with the Irish pound, and transactions in sterling are free of commission. The Bank also quotes buying and selling rates for other currencies, which are approx- imately equal to the rates quoted against sterling in London. As of December 31, 1974, the Central Bank's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$2.3500 and US$2.3495 per Irish pound. Certain capital transactions involving investment currency (see section on Capital, below) take place at different effec- tive rates; on December 31, 1974 the investment cur- rency premium was 69 Y8 per cent (based on the spot exchange rate of US$2.3495 per Irish pound). Forward transactions between authorized banks and their cus- tomers must have an underlying commercial transac- tion. On February 15, 1961, Ireland formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Exchange control is operated by the Central Bank. Much of the authority for approving normal payments is delegated to commercial banks authorized for this purpose. Import licenses, where necessary, are issued by the Department of Industry and Commerce if the goods are of an industrial nature, or by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries if the goods are agricul- tural in character. Import licensing is not used for ex- change control purposes. Import and export controls are administered by the Revenue Commissioners. Prescription of Currency Irish exchange control regulations distinguish be- tween (1) the Scheduled Territories, consisting of Ire- land, Northern Ireland, Great Britain, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, and Gibraltar, and (2) the rest of the world. The latter is subdivided into (1) the Over- seas Sterling Area (OSA), i.e., the countries which on June 23, 1972 ceased to be regarded as Scheduled Terri- tories;1 (2) EEC member countries other than the United Kingdom and Ireland; (3) Rhodesia; and (4) the Rest of the Non-Scheduled Territories (RNST), which consist of all other countries. Payments to and from other Scheduled Territories may be made freely in Irish pounds or pounds sterling; certain insurance payments between Scheduled Territories, however, may be made foreign currencies.2 Authorized payments in to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia may be made in Irish pounds or sterling through an External Account or in any foreign cur- rency other than Rhodesian currency. The proceeds of exports to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia must be received in Irish pounds or sterling through an External Account or in any for- eign currency other than Rhodesian currency. The pro- ceeds of permitted exports to Rhodesia must be received in foreign currency other than Rhodesian cur- rency; payments to Rhodesia are subject to special reg- ulations. Residents are defined as persons who are permanently resident, for exchange control purposes, in the Scheduled Territories. However, some Irish regu- lations are in terms of Irish residents (residents of Ire- land) only. Ireland is a Scheduled Territory for purposes of the exchange control regulations of the United Kingdom. Nonresident Accounts Accounts of persons resident in the Scheduled Terri- tories are treated as resident accounts. Accounts of persons resident in countries outside the Scheduled Territories are treated as nonresident accounts and, with the exception of Rhodesian Accounts, are desig- nated External Accounts. These may be credited with payments authorized for transfer to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia, with transfers from other External Accounts in Irish pounds or in sterling, and with the proceeds in Irish pounds of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency sold by a resident of a country outside the Scheduled Territories to an authorized bank in Ireland. Balances on these accounts may be transferred freely to other External Accounts in Irish pounds or in sterling, used for payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories, or converted through an authorized bank in Ireland into any foreign currency other than Rhodesian cur- rency. Accounts held by or on behalf of residents of Rhode- sia are designated Rhodesian Accounts. The opening of such accounts, and all debits and credits thereto, re- quire the prior approval of the Central Bank. Imports and Import Payments All imports of commodities originating in Rhodesia require a special license. With this exception, the im- port of goods into Ireland is subject to two types of administrative control. Under one type, which covers only a limited range of commodities for protective and other nonbalance of payments purposes, imports of certain commodities are subject to quantitative restric- tions, which, in most cases,are on a world-wide basis.3 Individual import licenses are required for these goods and are used to limit the quantity of goods im- 249 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND ported. In addition, special quota restrictions apply to certain textiles and yarns originating in any of 16 speci- fied countries or territories.4 All other imports are free of quantitative restriction. Under the other type of con- trol, prior permission of the Central Bank is required before orders may be placed for goods originating out- side the Scheduled Territories, if they are not to be used in Ireland or are to be delivered more than nine months after the date of the order. For permitted imports, appropriate exchange or per- mission to credit Irish pounds or sterling to an External Account is granted automatically. Exchange control forms are required for import payments exceeding £Ir 2,000 to countries outside the Scheduled Territo- ries. Payments for Invisibles Payments to the Scheduled Territories are not sub- ject to exchange control unless they are for transactions outside the Scheduled Territories. Payments to resi- dents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories require approval. Approval to make payments for most invisibles is delegated to the authorized banks; for other invisibles, it is given by the Central Bank. For tourist travel outside the Scheduled Territories (other than to Rhodesia) there is a basic allowance for residents of the State of £lr 300 a person for each trip. For business travel, up to £Ir 2,000, at a rate of £Ir 40 a day, is allowed for each journey, or alternatively up to £Ir 300 for each trip. Limits are also established for allowances for education and other purposes. Applica- tions for larger amounts are approved, provided that no unauthorized export of capital is involved. Not more than £Ir 250 of an allowance of foreign currency may be issued in the form of currency notes. Persons travel- ing to destinations outside the United Kingdom (other than to Rhodesia) may also take with them up to £Ir 25 in Scheduled Territory currency notes. Travelers who are resident outside the Scheduled Territories (other than Rhodesia) may take with them any foreign currency notes that they brought into Ireland. There is no restriction on the amount of Irish or other bank- notes that may be taken to the United Kingdom. Exports and Export Proceeds A system of export licensing is applied to a limited range of goods. There is a special restriction on the export of a number of items to Rhodesia. Exporters of goods to countries outside the Scheduled Territories must obtain payment for the goods within six months of shipment, if the value of the goods exceeds £lr 100. When payment is received in foreign currencies, the exchange must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Exchange control forms are required for exports exceeding £Ir 2,000 to countries outside the Scheduled Territories. 250 Proceeds from Invisibles There are no specific requirements governing ex- change receipts from invisibles, but if foreign currencies are received they must be offered for sale to an autho- rized bank or permission for their retention must be obtained. Any foreign currency held by a person after his return from a trip abroad may be retained for three months from the date he received the exchange, for use on a subsequent trip abroad. There are no limitations on the import of Irish or foreign banknotes. Capital Inward and outward movements of capital between Ireland and other Scheduled Territories are not subject to exchange control. Exchange control approval is re- quired for all transfers of capital to countries outside the Scheduled Territories. Applications for transfer of capital at the official market rate of exchange by resi- dents of the State emigrating to OSA countries, EEC member countries other than the United Kingdom, or RNST countries are approved up to a limit of £Ir 20,000 a family; there is no such allowance for emigration to Rhodesia. Where the total value of an emigrant's assets exceeds £lr 20,000, the transfer of the excess amount is restricted for a period of four years from the emigrant's redesignation as a nonresident, i.e., from the date of departure from Ireland. After the four-year period, the assets are to be treated in the same way as those of non-Scheduled Territory residents who have never been resident in Ireland. However, permis- sion is given at any time after redesignation for the restricted funds to be transferred outside the Scheduled Territories through the investment currency market (see below) or invested in Irish registered securities or in sterling securities.5 For Irish residents taking up employment and resi- dence in an EEC country other than the United King- dom, applications are considered to transfer Irish or U.K. assets to their new country of residence in excess of £lr 20,000; the additional facilities are authorized at the official rate of exchange if they are shown to be appropriate to ensure the applicant's freedom to take up employment in the country concerned. Applications for the transfer of resident-owned capital for purposes other than emigration are considered on their merits, but there are special facilities for residents taking up employment in EEC countries other than the United Kingdom and for direct investment in such countries. There are no restrictions on the inflow of capital, but net inflows into the banks may be subject to guidelines set from time to time by the Central Bank. Banks have been requested to deposit with the Central Bank 50 per cent of any net capital inflows after January 16, 1973; however, subject to prior consultation with the Central Bank, the deposit requirement may be waived for capi- tal inflows that assist in the financing of major indus- trial development projects. Purchases of unquoted Irish securities by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution require exchange control approval, and the purchase of nonurban land by foreign nationals in most cases re- quires approval by the Land Commission. Incoming capital received in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. However, investment currency, i.e., the foreign currency proceeds from the sale mainly of foreign currency securities6 sold outside the Scheduled Territories, may be fully reinvested in foreign currency securities, provided that the securities sold were held prior to April 7, 1965, or acquired by "switches" from securities so held, and that the invest- ment is carried out within six months from the date of sale through a bank, a stockbroker, or a solicitor. Where the securities sold were purchased with invest- ment currency on or after April 7, 1965, 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be surrendered at the official rate. Investment currency may be invested temporarily in foreign currency certificates of deposit and similar pa- per with up to six months to run to final maturity, without incurring the need to comply with the 25 per cent requirement on maturity or resale, provided that the limit of six months for the holding of investment currency is not exceeded. The entire foreign currency proceeds from the sale outside the Scheduled Territo- ries of property for personal use owned by residents are normally regarded as investment currency where the whole of the property is sold; where part of such a property is sold, the full foreign currency proceeds must be sold in the official exchange market. Residents may obtain, subject to individual permission, reason- able amounts of investment currency to purchase from non-Scheduled Territory residents property outside the Scheduled Territories for personal use; payments for attendant expenses and improvements must also be made with investment currency. Approval is normally limited to one property a family. Purchases from resi- dents of the Scheduled Territories must be settled in sterling. Transactions in securities are controlled to en- sure that capital is not transferred outside the Sched- uled Territories. Direct investment outside the Scheduled Territories requires prior approval and may normally be financed with investment currency or by borrowing foreign cur- rency; in certain cases the use of official exchange may be approved, depending on the merits of the project. Use of official exchange is allowed, however, for all approved new direct investments in EEC member countries other than the United Kingdom, subject to a limit of £lr 250,000 a project a year, and applications to transfer larger amounts at the official exchange rate are considered on their merits.7 The foreign currency proceeds of the sale or liquidation of direct investments outside the Scheduled Territories are not normally eli- gible for sale in the investment currency market. Dealings in Irish registered securities are permitted freely between residents of the Scheduled Territories. Specific approval is required for all dealings by Irish residents in securities payable in Rhodesian currency. IRELAND Remittances of cash gifts or personal loans to OSA countries are normally permitted up to £Ir 1,000 a donor a calendar year; the corresponding limit for other non-Scheduled Territories except Rhodesia is £lr 300 a donor a year. For dependents, an additional amount of up to £Ir 2,000 a donor a year in cash gifts or per- sonal loans may be remitted to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia. Authorized banks may freely accept deposits in for- eign currency from nonresidents of the Scheduled Ter- ritories and lend such deposits on to other nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories. Application must be made to the Central Bank for nonbank private sector borrow- ing from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories; such applications are considered on their merits and, except as regards borrowing for the acquisition of prop- erty for personal use, on the benefit likely to accrue to the economy. Public sector borrowing outside the Scheduled Territories is undertaken following consulta- tion with the Central Bank. Lending of Irish currency to nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories is not nor- mally permitted, except to the extent that overdraft facilities may be provided by the banks to members of non-Scheduled Territories' diplomatic and consular missions in Ireland, and except that banks may freely make available loan and overdraft facilities in Irish pounds or sterling to residents of OSA countries, pro- vided the underlying transaction is a trade transaction or one associated with the movement of goods. Pro- vided that the company is not a medium for portfolio investment, a subsidiary or branch of an EEC- controlled company can, subject to exchange control approval, obtain from Irish banks all the finance it requires for its operation in Ireland. Gold* Residents may freely hold, buy, borrow, sell, or lend gold coins in Ireland. Dealings in gold bullion are re- stricted, and no dealings take place in Ireland. Al- though there are no import restrictions, residents require exchange control permission to purchase gold coins or bullion abroad. Exchange control permission also is required for the export of gold coins and bullion. Specific permission is not required to import gold coins from elsewhere in the Scheduled Territories. Specific permission is required to export gold coins to elsewhere in the Scheduled Territories, but this is given for all bona fide transactions. Specific permission is also re- quired for imports and exports of gold coins from and to countries outside the Scheduled Territories. Resi- dents of Ireland are not permitted to hold gold abroad. Changes during 1974 January 1. A revised customs tariff schedule took effect. The changes included (1) a further reduction of 20 per cent in duties on imports from other EEC countries other than the United Kingdom, and the re- moval of duties on goods covered by the Euratom 251 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND Treaty with respect to trade with all member states of the EEC (all of these reductions were applied also to goods of U.K. origin not subject to tariff reductions under the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Area Agreement); (2) the first move toward alignment of the full and prefer- ential rates of customs duties to the rates in the Com- mon Customs Tariff of the EEC; and (3) a fur ther reduction in duties on goods originating in certain countries having preferential agreements with the EEC, no tab ly the seven EFTA countries that had not applied for EEC membership. January 1. Ireland adopted the EEC generalized scheme of tariff preferences for imports from develop- ing countries, subject to a transitional period of two years for footwear and textiles. The scheme superseded the corresponding Irish scheme. March 27. Preferential treatment accorded to OS A countries in respect of certain transactions in securities was terminated. Proceeds from the redemption or sale of securities held by Irish residents payable in OSA currencies, which since June 23, 1972 had been eligible for transaction in the investment currency market, be- came subject to the surrender rules applicable to securi- ties payable in nonsterling area currencies. Henceforth, 25 per cent of the sale or redemption proceeds of all foreign currency securities was to be sold in the official exchange market. March 27. Some of the rules governing direct invest- ments outside the Scheduled Territories were revised. Direct investments in the Overseas Sterling Area now were normally to be financed with borrowed foreign currency or with investment currency, and the foreign currency proceeds of liquidations of direct investments in RNST countries were no longer normally eligible for sale as investment currency. Thus, the rules for direct investment outside the Scheduled Territories became uniform, apart from the relaxed arrangements which came into force in 1973 in relation to EEC member countries other than the United Kingdom. May 30. Ireland signed the OECD Declaration on Imports, Exports, and Other Current Account Trans- actions. June 4. A revised set of exchange control notices was issued. The country classification was changed from Scheduled Territories, External Account Area, and Rhodesia, to Scheduled Territories, OSA, EEC mem- ber countries (other than U.K. and Ireland), Rhodesia, and RNST. New definitions were provided of Irish registered securities, sterling securities, and foreign cur- rency securities. June 4. The basic foreign exchange allowance for tourist travel was increased from £Ir 250 to £Ir 300 a person a trip. Allowances for business and health travel were also raised. The cash gift allowance was increased from £lr 250 to £Ir 300 a donor a year for remittances to RNST countries. June 21. It was announced that, subject to prior consultation with the Central Bank, the requirement whereby banks must deposit with the Central Bank at 252 least 50 per cent of any net capital inflows after Janu- ary 16, 1973 could be waived for capital inflows that would assist in the financing of major industrial devel- opment projects. July 1. The n in th and penultimate annual reduction in duties on imports from the United Kingdom under the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Area Agreement took ef- fect. July 1. Increased global import quotas for specified industrial items came into effect for the period to Ju- ly 1, 1975, when these items would be fully liberalized from all sources. September 18. In addition to the existing allowance for cash gifts or personal loans of up to £Ir 1,000 for OSA countries and £Ir 300 for RNST countries, an exchange allowance of £Ir 2,000 a donor a year for cash gifts or personal loans was introduced for depen- dents in countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia. December 9. The period allowed for the purchase of land for personal use for building purposes, when situ- ated outside the Scheduled Territories, and for comple- tion of the related project, including any payments to a nonresident builder, was increased from 18 months to 2 years. The full foreign currency proceeds from the sale of any part of such a property were henceforth required to be disposed of in the official exchange mar- ket; previously, 75 per cent of such proceeds could be sold in the investment currency market. Where the whole of a property was sold, the full sale proceeds would normally continue to be regarded as investment currency. December 9. Residents of Ireland henceforth could apply for permission to accept foreign currency cash loans (from resident banks or nonresidents) for the purchase of property situated outside the Scheduled Territories, provided the foreign currency was immedi- ately sold at the official rate of exchange to an autho- rized dealer and provided the purchase transaction was financed in the usual way with investment currency. The loan proceeds could be used immediately for the purchase if a "switch and surrender" transaction (pur- chase of investment currency and simultaneous resale at the official rate) was first effected in respect of the full amount of the loan. In addition, applications could now be made by residents of Ireland for permission to enter into extended credit arrangements (including mortgages) offered by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories. The full amount of the credit had to be covered by a "switch and surrender" transaction in the investment currency market; irrespective of the credit period, the purchaser would be required to cover the complete sum with investment currency within the ap- propriate six-month or two-year period allowed for the completion of the sale. In all cases, interest, at a rate acceptable to the exchange control authorities, could be paid at the official rate of exchange, subject to prior approval from the Central Bank. Capital repayments could be made at the official rate of exchange once the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution total capital sum borrowed had been covered with in- vestment currency. Once the borrowing (under either facility) had been covered by an investment currency transaction, so that capital repayments could be made with official exchange, rental income could be applied to capital repayments. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.122777 gram of f ine gold per Israel Pound, which corresponds to I£6.00 = US$1, and Is- rael avails itself of wider margins. The Bank of Israel's official buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were I£6.0000 and I£6.0042, re- spectively. The Bank also establishes buy ing and selling rates for certain other currencies. Authorized banks are permitted to buy and sell foreign currencies at spot rates different from those officially quoted by the Bank of Israel, but they may quo te rates only w i th in the range established by the quo ta t ions of the la t ter. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Depar tment of Foreign Exchange Control of the Ministry of Fi- nance, under the responsibility of the Controller of Foreign Exchange and in cooperation with other gov- ernment agencies and is carried out th rough authorized banks. Prescription of Currency Paymen ts and receipts must be effected in the cur- rency and manner prescribed by the exchange control authorities. Settlements w i th countries w i th wh ich pay- men ts agreements are in force1 are usua l ly made in U.S. dollars as an accounting unit. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents' funds are held either on foreign cur- rency accounts or on local currency accounts. The opening of nonresident foreign currency accounts does not require prior approval. The principal type of non- resident foreign currency account is the PATACH ac- count. The holder may freely effect transfers from his foreign currency account; he may also convert funds held in the account in to local currency at the official rate of exchange. Local currency accounts of nonresidents are of two types: (1) Registered Accounts —for payments to and hold- ings of foreign av ia t ion, shipping, insurance, and f i lm companies and for non transferab le holdings of former residents —may be established on ly w i th special ap- proval. Funds acquired from the sale of real estate and awa i t ing repatriation must also be held in Registered Accounts. Aviation, shipping, and insurance compa- nies may freely convert at the official rate of exchange any amoun ts held on these accounts which are surplus to local requirements; film companies may do so under ind iv idual arrangements made w i th each company. Registered Account funds held by former residents may be used for investment in listed Israeli securities, 254 for purchase of real estate, for tourist expenses in Israel up to an amount of I£250 a day for the account holder and for each member of his fam i ly, for remittances of up to I£15,000 a year in support of relatives who are residents of Israel, for the settlement of taxes payable in Israel by the owner of the account, and for donations to public and charitable ins t i tu t ions. Funds represent- ing the sales proceeds of certain real estate become transferable after five years, in equal installments over the fo l low ing f ive-year period. Ownership of Registered Accounts may not be t rans fe r red. (2) Other nonresident accounts in local currency may be used to hold funds derived f rom former inves tmen ts that are eligible for transfer at the official exchange rate. Balances may be transferred freely between nonresi- dents. The accounts may be liquidated at any time by the purchase of fore ign exchange at the official rate; such foreign exchange may be freely transferred abroad or credited to a PATACH account. Funds in these ac- counts may also be used w i th in Israel by conversion in to Israel pounds, and no limit is placed on the amount that may be w i thd r awn. Israeli citizens who are temporar i ly living and earn- ing abroad may maintain foreign currency in tempo- rary PAMAZ accounts in Israel. Balances in such accounts may be freely used abroad when the holder is abroad; when he is in Israel he may only convert these funds in to local currency at the official exchange rate. Resident Accounts in Foreign Currency Residents may ma in ta in foreign currency deposits w i th authorized banks in Israel on either PAZAK ac- counts, which may be held by all recipients of foreign exchange other than those to whom exchange has been allocated from domestic sources, or TAMAM accounts, which may be held by recipients of res t i tu t ion pay- ments and disability pensions. PAZAK accounts are demand or t ime deposit ac- counts denominated in convertible currencies. All for- eign exchange receipts, except those derived from exchange allocations by the M in is try of Finance but including export proceeds, may be placed in PAZAK accounts. Account holders may retain foreign exchange in this manner or may exchange it in to local currency. Account holders may use foreign exchange balances in PAZAK accounts to make any authorized foreign pay- ments. Balances in PAZAK accounts are not negotiable between residents, but only among members of the immediate fam i ly of the account holder. TAMAM accounts also are demand or time deposit accounts in convertible currencies. One th ird of con- vertible exchange receipts derived from personal resti- tu t ion paymen ts and from pensions, etc., of disabled soldiers who served during World War II may be cred- ited to TAMAM accounts. The permitted uses of TAMAM ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution accounts include the following: (1) the purchase through the medium of the authorized bank holding the account of foreign securities denominated in convert- ible foreign currency that are registered on a stock exchange in specified foreign countries; (2) payment of premiums on existing life insurance policies denomi- nated in foreign currency; (3) payment of expenses in connection with travel and subsistence abroad in excess of the basic travel exchange allocation of the equivalent of US$450 a trip, provided that not more than the equivalent of US$1,800 a year is drawn by the account holder and for each member of his family; and (4) payment of legal expenses resulting from restitution claims. NATAD accounts are transfer accounts in foreign ex- change that are used mainly for transactions in foreign securities. As stated above, holders of TAMAM accounts may purphase abroad foreign securities denominated in convertible foreign currency and registered on a stock exchange in specified foreign countries. Foreign securi- ties thus acquired may be traded freely between resi- dents, through the intermediary of the authorized bank that is the depository, against payment either with NATAD or TAMAM funds or in Israel pounds. If the original buyer resells securities bought with TAMAM account funds for foreign currency he may deposit the proceeds in TAMAM accounts. Residents who are not holders of TAMAM accounts may deposit the foreign exchange proceeds from the sale of foreign securities in NATAD accounts. Balances in NATAD accounts may be used to purchase fu r ther foreign securities but are not negotiable between residents. If foreign securities are sold between residents against Israel pounds, the con- version factor used to establish their domestic currency value is the so-called NATAD rate. On December 31, 1974, it stood at I£6.00 per U.S. dollar. Imports and Import Payments A few imports are prohibited from all sources and all imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. In addition, 31 import items, mainly luxury goods, are temporarily prohibited.2 All commodities whose importation is not liberalized are listed in a Negative List. Imports of goods listed in the Free Import Orders are free of all licensing and administrative or quan t i ta t ive restric- tions. All other imports are subject to licensing. For commodities on the Automatic Approval List, licenses are issued automatically upon application. All other permissible imports constitute the Restricted List. All individual import licenses must be countersigned by the Department of Foreign Exchange Control of the Minis- try of Finance. The currency and method of payment are prescribed in each license; if a convertible currency is prescribed, payment may be made in any convertible currency. Six basic food products (frozen meat, milk powder, wheat, oilseeds, edible fats, and sugar) are im- ported exclusively by or for account of the Government of Israel. ISRAEL Exchange to pay for items listed in the Free Import Orders or to pay for licensed imports is granted auto- matically. If payment is to be made by documentary credit, the foreign currency required may be purchased at the time of opening the credit. Funds not transferred abroad immediately must be deposited in a special ac- count with the Bank of Israel until transfer is made. Licenses are not issued for imports of goods on con- signment unless the recipient of the license imports goods valued at US$100,000 or more within three months and undertakes to deposit 10 per cent of the value of the goods in local currency with the Bank of Israel through an authorized bank. Each license is valid only for a single commodity, and an importer cannot receive more than two such licenses a year. The ap- proval of the Department of Foreign Exchange Control is required for all imports effected under foreign credits; foreign currency financing is not normally permitted except for raw materials or capital goods valued at US$100,000 or more. Importers are required to deposit with the Treasury, at the time of paying the import duty and for a period of one year, without interest, 20 per cent of the c.i.f. value of imports. Exempt are commodities subject to customs du ty at a rate of less than 40 per cent (includ- ing the 15 per cent surcharge, see below), imports by or for the Government, goods imported for personal use by residents and immigrants, imports for re-export, and imports with a c.i.f. value of I£5,000 or less. Virtu- ally all imports are subject to an import surcharge of 15 per cent of the c.i.f. value. The main exemptions are for a few basic foods tuffs and uncut diamonds. A pur- chase tax is levied on almost all imported and domesti- cally produced goods, other than capital goods. Payments for Invisibles Most payments abroad for invisibles require individ- ual licenses. Each resident is allowed exchange equiva- lent to US$10-250, which is obtainable on demand, for certain purposes such as the purchase of books, mem- bership dues, and registration in a university. For tour- ist travel abroad, there is an exchange allowance equivalent to US$450 a traveler for each journey (US$350 for children under 12); emigrants are allowed to take out US$10. For travel for business reasons, the allowance is US$50 a day for the first 21 days; applica- tions for additional amounts are approved by the Con- troller of Foreign Exchange when it is established that the exchange is to be used for genuine travel expendi- ture, and exporters are not subject to these limits. Not more than I£200 in Israel banknotes may be taken out by travelers. Foreign tourists leaving Israel are permit- ted to repurchase through authorized dealers foreign currency up to US$30. Residents traveling abroad must pay a travel tax of I £7 50 plus 15 per cent of the price of the ticket. Travelers to specified countries are taxed at a lower rate; these include Cyprus, Ethiopia, and Romania. Exporters doing more than US$100,000 of 255 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL export business a year are exempt from travel tax on business trips. Imm igran ts and their families are ex- empt from travel tax for three years from the date of imm igra t ion or of en t ry as temporary residents. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports do not require licenses if paid for in freely convertible currencies. For some commodities, however, export li- censing is retained for the purpose of qua l i ty control. The M in is t ry of Commerce and Indu s t ry ma in ta ins a check on export transactions w i th a low value-added content which are made w i th bilateral partners; this is done to discourage switch transactions. Export pro- ceeds in fore ign currencies must be surrendered or held in a PAZAK account. Exports of most commodities are eligible for incen t ive payments calculated on the gross value of exports and based on domestic value added; they are designed to rebate estimated in ternal indirect taxes and the import surcharge. At the end of 1974, the payment for diamonds was I£0.20 per US$1 of gross export value, and for other commodities the payment ranged f rom I£1.08 to I£1.30 per US$1 of gross export value, w i th the higher rates applicable to commodities w i th a higher proportion of domestic value added.3 For i n p u ts directly imported by an exporter there is a sys- tem of rebate of customs duties, wharf charges, etc. Proceeds from In visibles Exchange proceeds f rom invisibles mu s t, in general, be surrendered. A l te rna t ive ly, they may be kept in fo r- eign exchange on PAZAK accounts, balances on which may be exchanged in to Israel currency at any time or used to make authorized paymen ts abroad. Any resi- dent is free to accept specified convertible currencies f rom tourists in payment for services and commodities other than commercial exports, securities, and real es- tate; such receipts must be surrendered w i th in a few days. One third of the foreign exchange received by resi- den ts of Israel as res t i tu t ion paymen ts, and as pensions by disabled soldiers who served in World War II, may be retained in TAMAM accounts and the other two th i rds may be held in PAZAK accounts. For ten years a f t er en ter ing Israel, new imm ig r an ts are exempt f rom surrender ing the ir fore ign exchange to the Treasury, and they may keep these fore ign curren- cies w i th authorized banks in Israel or w i th banks abroad. Tourists v is i t ing Israel are expected to bring w i th them the amounts of foreign currency that they will need du r ing the ir stay. Not more than I£200 in Israel bankno tes may be b rought in by travelers. Tourists and others visiting Israel who are holders of Registered Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above) may draw upon such accounts to the extent of I£250 a day for themselves and the same amount for each member of their families; if they are holders of 256 other non res ident local currency accounts, they may draw on them w i thout l im i t. Capital Foreign exchange representing incoming capital and belonging to a resident must be surrendered at the o f f ic ial rate or held in a PAZAK account. Capital b rought in to Israel for the purpose of inves tment may, subject to approval, be granted preferen t ial trea tment in accordance w i th the Law for the Encouragement of Capital Inve s tmen ts of August 16, 1959, which, in ter alia, permits a nonresident who has made an "ap- proved" inves tment in foreign currency to transfer all his p ro f i ts abroad in the same currency at the official rate. Repayments and amortization of capital may also be transferred on the fo l low ing terms: if the inves tment has been kept for less than f ive years, the capital may be w i thd r awn in f ive equal installments; if the invest- ment has been kept for more than f ive years, it may be w i thd r awn immed ia te ly. Current policy is to grant "approved" status only to enterprises in selected fields of produc t ion that f u l f i ll one of the fo l low ing condi- t ions: (1) that they are established in "priority areas"; (2) that they are export-oriented, i.e., either at least 50 per cent of ou tput is exported or existing productive capacity is increased by at least 50 per cent wh i le at least 50 per cent of the add i t ional ou tput is exported; or (3) th a t, a l though for economic reasons the enter- prise cannot be established in a priority area, its pro- duction is of the impo r t -subs t i tu t ion type. There is no longer any d i f fe rence between an "approved invest- ment" and any other investment made by a nonresident in fore ign cu r rency inso far as his rights to transfer abroad the pr inc ipal or the interest or prof i ts on his inves tment are concerned. The difference does still exist as regards o ther bene f i ts, such as income tax conces- sions and gran ts. The principal of fore ign inves tmen ts made prior to Janua ry 1, 1958, or made a f ter that date in foreign exchange, can be transferred abroad. The proceeds of inves tmen ts in real estate, however, can on ly be trans- fe r red f ive years a f t er its purchase, in f ive equal annual installments over the following five-year period. Proceeds accruing f rom the repatriation or liquida- tion of fore ign assets held by residents are treated in the same way as proceeds f rom invisibles. Any resident may retain real estate abroad, but not money, securi- ties, or the income f rom real estate; new imm igran ts may retain l iqu id assets as well. Transfers abroad of a capital na tu re by residents other than new immigrants are generally not permitted. Owners of TAMAM deposits are entitled to purchase foreign securities registered at stock exchanges in speci- fied foreign countries. Foreign securities purchased to the debit of a TAMAM deposit can be sold abroad by their owners, or in Israel either against foreign currency to owners of other TAMAM or NATAD deposits or against Israel pounds. The proceeds of the sale may be ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution credited to the TAMAM account previously debited for the purchase. The owner of foreign securities bought through TAMAM or NATAD accounts is also allowed to sell them to residents against Israel pounds, and the purchaser in his turn may sell them either against Israel pounds or against foreign currency (abroad or to hold- ers of TAMAM or NATAD deposits); he is entitled to deposit the foreign currency proceeds in a NATAD ac- count. This is the only manner in which NATAD ac- counts can be established. The holder of a NATAD account may draw on it to purchase foreign securities abroad, or to pay to a holder of a TAMAM or NATAD account foreign currency for foreign securities. It is also permissible to purchase gold from monies in TAMAM and NATAD accounts, the pro- cedure being the same. A general license allows authorized dealers to pur- chase real estate in Israel for nonresidents. Nonresi- dents may freely purchase shares, provided that purchases are financed w i th converted foreign cur- rency; debentures, however, may be purchased by non- residents only if they are quoted on the Tel Aviv stock exchange. Direct loans in any form to or from nonresi- dents are subject to licensing. Gold Residents, including private persons, may freely hold gold in any form either in Israel or abroad; purchases by private persons must be financed out of TAMAM or NATAD accounts, except for purchases of jewelry and of articles containing a minor quan t i ty of gold, such as watches. Gold can be sold only to an authorized dealer and can be bought only from an authorized dealer. Other residents are forbidden to trade in gold, to trans- fer it from place to place, or to take it out of Israel. Imports of gold are permissible only if an import li- cense is obtained. Imports of gold for industrial pur- poses are transacted by five importing wholesalers. These wholesalers may sell the gold only to purchasers registered with the Purchase Tax Administration. The latter checks these purchases by each manufacturer against the gold content of products marked as "pur- chase tax paid" in order to eliminate the possibility of sales of these quantities of gold on the market as bul- lion. Changes during 1974 January 1. The import deposit scheme was abolished under which for most imports valued at over I £5,000 a domestic currency deposit of 20 per cent of the c.i.f. value had to be lodged with the customs for a period of six months. January 1. Customs duties on a wide range of im- ports were reduced by 2.5 to 8 percentage points. January 1. Final reductions in tariffs under the pref- erential trade agreement with the EEC came into effect. January 6. The negative interest rate was abolished which had been levied on nonresidents' holdings of ISRAEL Belgian francs in nonresident foreign currency accounts in excess of balances on February 19, 1973. This termi- nated the last remaining ruling under the Bank of Israel directive of April 2, 1973 which had introduced a nega- tive interest rate. April 1. The temporary import surcharge of 25 per cent of the c.i.f. value levied on virtually all imports was extended to April 1, 1975. May 4. The par value was changed from 0.194884 gram to 0.175396 gram of f ine gold per Israel pound, equivalent at the time to I£5.06665 per SDR 1. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar re- mained unchanged at I £4.20 = US$1. Israel continued to avail itself of wider margins. May 24. A new import deposit scheme was intro- duced. Importers were required to deposit with the Treasury domestic currency equal to 20 per cent of the c.i.f. value of imported goods bearing duties of 35 per cent and over (including the 25 per cent import sur- charge). The deposit was payable at the time of paying customs duties and would be held for one year without interest. Government imports, imports with a total c.i.f. value of I£5,000 or less, and imports for personal use or for re-export were exempt. July 2. The temporary import surcharge was in- creased from 25 per cent to 35 per cent of the c.i.f. value. July 2. The import deposit requirement was modified to cover imports bearing customs duties of 60 per cent or more (including the increased import surcharge of 35 per cent). July 2. Export rebates were increased from a range of up to I£1.42 to up to I£1.84 per U.S. dollar of gross export value. July 2. Customs duties were reduced by 5 percentage points on a wide range of imports. November 10 (November 9, Washington time). The par value of the Israel pound was changed from 0.175396 gram to 0.122777 gram of fine gold, corre- sponding at the time to I£7.23807 per SDR 1. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar became I£6.00 = US$1. Israel continued to avail itself of wider margins. November 10. The temporary import surcharge was reduced from 35 per cent to 15 per cent of the c.i.f. value. Seven exempt commodities (crude petroleum, wheat, maslin, rice (both rough and in other forms), soybeans, soybean oil, and copra) became subject to the surcharge. November 10. The import deposit requirement was modified to cover imports bearing customs duties of 40 per cent or more (including the reduced import sur- charge of 15 per cent). November 10. Export rebates were reduced from a range of up to I£1.84 to up to I£1.30 per U.S. dollar of gross export value. The special rebate for exports of diamonds was reduced from I£1.10 to I£0.20 per U.S. dollar of gross export value. 257 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL November 10. Imports of 31 items, mainly luxury goods, were temporarily prohibited. The ban was to be lifted on May 1, 1975, except for passenger automo- biles, for which this was to occur on September 1, 1975. November 10. A temporary increase in customs duties of 10 percentage points was imposed on 38 items, mainly luxury goods. The increase in duties was to be removed on May 1, 1975. Simultaneously, an increase of 10 percentage points in the purchase tax was im- posed on 16 commodities. November 10. A levy was imposed on stocks of im- ported goods and on imported goods cleared through customs before November 10 but not released from harbors. The levy was applied at the rate of 43 per cent plus any difference between the amount of taxes and surcharges paid prior to November 10 and the amount of such taxes and surcharges due on November 10. Goods sold before November 10 for the personal use of private persons, and stocks on which the levy did not exceed I£5,000, were exempt. November 10. A levy of generally I £1.80 per US$1 was imposed on devaluation increments on wo rk ing capital in foreign currencies held by banks or by f irms (other than maritime and insurance companies) which had received allocations of foreign currency for such capital. November 10. The travel tax was increased to I £750 plus 15 per cent of the cost of the ticket and was made uniform for sea and air travel. November 10. The foreign exchange allowance for business travel was reduced to US$50 a day for the f i r st 30 days, and US$40 a day for the next 20 days, up to a maximum of US$2,300 a person a trip. Exporters were not subject to the new limits. November 19. Importers were permitted to seek fo r- eign currency f inanc ing on imports of raw materials and capital goods valued at US$100,000 or more (pre- viously, US$250,000 or more); in addition, the Ministry of Finance was prepared to guarantee the exchange risk. November 25. It was announced that banks' author- ity to grant general approval for foreign exchange transactions by firms ho ld ing foreign currency balances in Domestic banks or in designated banks abroad was being suspended, w i th effect f rom February 1, 1975. Following a review by the M in is t ry of Finance, banks would again be allowed to grant general permissions on the basis of a f i rm 's anticipated transactions needs. December 6. The foreign exchange allowance for business travel was f u r t h er reduced to US$50 for the f i rst 21 days of each trip.
