Not for Redistribution ITALY (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.00142187 gram of f ine gold per Italian Lira. A central rate of Lit 581.500 = US$1 has been established. On February 13, 1973, however, I ta ly notified the Fund that for the time being the exchange rate for the lira on the official market for current trans- actions would not necessarily be confined within the announced limits either in respect of the U.S. dollar or in respect of EEC currencies. The rate for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 was about Lit 650 per US$1. The monetary authorities do not in principle inter- vene in the fo rwa rd exchange market; forward premi- ums and discounts are normally left to the in terp lay of market forces, although the Bank of Italy (the central bank) may f rom time to time offer the commercial banks certain swap facilities. Authorized banks are al- lowed to engage in spot exchange transactions in any currency, and in forward exchange transactions up to 360 days in major convertible and externally convert- ible currencies,1 when dealing with other banks, or up to 180 days when dealing with nonbanks. The permissi- ble amount of forward transactions against lire is sub- ject to a limit on net transactions set individually for each bank. Forward cover is freely permitted only for commercial transactions; cover in respect of financial transactions requires authorization. Public corpora- tions which have been instructed to borrow abroad on behalf of the Bank of Italy receive full forward cover for their debt service payments. Italy formally accepted the obligations of Article V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Administration of Control The exchange control system is operated by the Ital- ian Exchange Office (Ufficio Italiano dei Cambi) on the basis of instructions issued by the Ministry of Foreign Trade. All sales and purchases of exchange pass through banks authorized for this purpose. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Minis- try of Finance at the request of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. Certain imports and exports require the prior visa of the National Foreign Trade Institute. Issues of securities by nonresidents require the prior approval of the M in is try of Foreign Trade and are subject in addi- tion to the rules governing the issuing in Italy of Italian securities. Payments to and f rom the Republic of San Marino or Vatican City are not subject to exchange control. Prescription of Currency Settlements with foreign countries must normally be made in convertible currencies or in lire on Foreign Accounts. For settlements with Egypt, special arrange- ments are applicable under a debt liquidation agree- ment with that coun try. Nonresident Accounts The main types of accounts in Italian lire which non- residents are allowed to maintain with authorized banks in Italy are Foreign Accounts and Capital Ac- counts. The use of these accounts, and of Special Ac- counts for certain investments, is described below. 1. Foreign Accounts may be credited w i th transfers from other Foreign Accounts, from Capital Accounts, and from Special Accounts Under Law No. 43, with lire from authorized current and capital payments, and with the proceeds from sales of convertible currencies. They may be debited for purchases of any of these currencies in the ordinary market, for transfers to any other Foreign Account, Capital Account, or Special Account Under Law No. 43, for payments to residents of I ta ly for current and capital transactions, for pay- ments due to residents on account of their disinvest- ments abroad, and for drawings in cash by the holder of the account or his delegates. 2. Capital Accounts may be credited w i th transfers from Foreign Accounts, from Special Accounts Under Law No. 43, and from other Capital Accounts, and with the proceeds from the liquidation of foreign in- vestments in Italy not made under the provisions of Law No. 211 of March 2, 1948 or Law No. 43 of Feb- ruary 7, 1956 (see below). Capital Accounts may be debited for transfers to any other Capital Account or to Foreign Accounts, and for the purchase of invest- ments not made under Law No. 43, including pur- chases of personal property or real estate in I ta ly. 3. Special Accounts Under Law No. 43 of February 7, 1956 are accounts in the names of nonresidents who have invested in I ta ly convertible currencies or exter- nally convertible European currencies in accordance with the above-mentioned law. These accounts may be credited with the countervalue of convertible currencies sold in I ta ly, with transfers from Foreign Accounts, or from other Special Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of investments that have been made in accor- dance with Law No. 43. They may be debited for pur- chases of the same currency that was originally sold and for investments in Italy, and balances on them may be transferred to Foreign Accounts, Capital Accounts, or any other Special Account Under Law No. 43. Imports and Import Payments All imports of Rhodesian origin are prohibited. Practically all imports from other countries except Ja- pan, the People's Republic of China, North Viet-Nam, and the CMEA countries are free of quantitative re- 259 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY striction; all goods, however, require a bank certificate for submission to the customs authorities and some- times also a license issued by the Ministry of Finance at the request of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. Com- modities that still require individual licenses when im- ported from these other countries are included in a negative list ( Tabella A Import).2 Some items in the list require an import license only when originating in Is- rael or Yugoslavia. The general permission to import goods not included in the Tabella A Import applies to Egypt and Yugosla- via only if the goods both originate in and are shipped direct from the country concerned; in addition, in re- spect of imports of raw cotton, rice, and crude petro- leum f rom Egypt, the payee must reside in that country or in one of the European OECD countries. (Seventy per cent of the value of other imports from Egypt must be paid to creditors residing either in that country or in any OECD country, and 30 per cent must be paid in lire to Egypt's lire account with the Italian Exchange Office.) A more extensive negative list {Tabella B Import) contains those commodities which require an individ- ual license when originating in and imported from Al- bania, Bulgaria, the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hunga ry, No r th Korea, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., or No r th Viet-Nam. There is a special list of commodities, also included in Tabella B Import, whose importation is unilaterally and de facto liberal- ized when they both originate in and are shipped f rom Albania, Bulgaria, the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania, or the U.S.S.R. These goods may be admitted by the customs w i thout a li- cense, a l though some require a visa issued by the Insti- tu te of Foreign Trade. A separate negative list applies to Japan indicating the goods that are subject to restrictive import licensing when imported f rom that coun try; some other items are included in a special list of commodities for which im- port licenses are issued free ly. All other goods of Japan- ese origin3 may be imported freely w i thout an ind iv idual license, irrespective of the coun t ry from which they are shipped. Impo r ts f rom non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to variable import levies that have replaced all previous barriers to imports; common EEC regulations are also applied to imports from non-EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock prod- ucts. For imports not exceeding Lit 1 m i l l ion in value, no exchange control form is required; for imports f rom Lit 1 million to Lit 2 million in value, a form com- pleted by the importer is required; for imports over Lit 2 million in value, an import document completed by an authorized bank is required. The impor ter must choose an authorized bank as his bank of domicile, 260 through which he must carry out all payments opera- tions related to his import transactions if settlement takes place more than 360 days after importation. Ad- vance payments for imports require special approval when they are to take place more than 30 days before importation. All advance payments of Lit 1 million or more must be made with foreign currency borrowed from Italian authorized banks. Imports from all sources of most commodities other than raw materials, capital goods, and beef and cattle are subject to an advance import deposit of 50 per cent of the c.i.f. value, which is retained at the Bank of Italy for six months.4 For all authorized imports, the authorized banks provide exchange or permit payment in Italian lire to a Foreign Account, provided that appropriate payment terms are observed (see section on Capital, below). In- ternational postal money orders may be used for im- port payments, subject in the case of payments to Switzerland to a limit of Lit 100,000 for each remitter and foreign beneficiary. Payments for Invisibles In principle, payments abroad for invisibles require licenses issued by the exchange control authorities. Un- der general authorization, however, the authorized banks may sell foreign exchange freely, provided that the necessary documents are submitted, except for tourist travel and travel for business, study, or health reasons. Exchange is granted freely for remittances of earnings on investments. Residents may use interna- tional postal money orders for payments, subject in the case of payments to Switzerland to a limit of Lit 100,000 for each remitter and foreign beneficiary. All advance payments of Lit 1 million or more for impor ts of services must be made with foreign currency borrowed f rom Italian authorized banks. Certain transactions (but not the related payments) in respect of services are subject to approval by the M in is t ry of Foreign Trade or the Ministry of Industry. These transactions can be divided into two groups: (1) contracts which require a permit if they involve resi- dents of specified countries5 and (2) contracts which require a permit regardless of the nationality of the nonresidents involved. The first group includes trans- actions g iv ing rise to expenditures for chartering ships (excluding charters for a single trip); repairs to ships which are not urgent and not necessary for safety of operation; news agencies and newspaper correspon- dents (for amoun ts exceeding Lit 5 million a month for the same payee); purchases of publication rights, infor- mation agencies, etc. (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 mil- lion for each contract); copyrights (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million a year for each contract); ser- vices of professional workers and company managers (for amoun ts exceeding Lit 5 million); and services of en ter ta iners and athletes (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million). The second group includes transactions giving ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution rise to expenditures for production abroad of films, utilization of films, scripts, synchronization, etc.; col- laboration in cinematography; insurance of ships and aircraft against risks of operation;6 and other transac- tions not permitted by general authorization (when the amounts involved exceed Lit 1 million). Residents traveling to foreign countries may obtain from the banks exchange equivalent to Lit 500,000 a person a year for tourism, business, medical treatment, and education (the corresponding amount for group travel also is Lit 500,000); the Exchange Office grants foreign exchange above these allowances (except for tourism), provided that it is satisfied that this is justi- fied in the light of the duration and purpose of the trip. To the extent that he refrains from obtaining an alloca- tion of foreign exchange, a resident traveler may take in addition a proportionate amount in Italian bank- notes, up to Lit 35,000.7 Nonresident travelers may take out any amount in foreign banknotes that they have previously declared upon entry as well as Lit 35,000 in Italian banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to any country of a few commodities in a special list ( Tabella Espori) require export licenses. For exports not exceeding Lit 1 million in value, no ex- change control form is required; for exports from Lit 1 million to Lit 2 million in value, a form completed by the exporter is required; for exports exceeding Lit 2 million in value, an export document completed by an authorized bank is required. The exporter must choose an authorized bank as his bank of domicile, through which he must carry out the payments operations re- lated to his export transactions if settlement takes place more than 90 days after exportation. Unless special approval is obtained for different terms of payment (see section on Capital, below), 90 per cent of exchange receipts must be collected within 90 days of shipment, and these must be offered for sale to an authorized bank within 7 days of receipt, while 10 per cent must be collected within 24 months of shipment. Proceeds in U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Japanese yen, and externally convertible European cur- rencies may be retained by authorized banks on behalf of the recipients in Ordinary Foreign Currency Ac- counts (Conti Valutari Ordinari) for one month, during which period such balances may be used for permitted transactions or be sold to authorized banks; the banks are allowed to sell these currencies to residents for authorized transactions or to negotiate them freely with the Italian Exchange Office or among themselves.8 Af- ter expiration of the retention period, unused balances must be sold to the Italian Exchange Office at the lowest exchange rate quoted during the retention pe- riod (these rates are determined daily on the basis of the average closing rates in Milan and Rome). Export pro- ceeds may also be received by international postal money order, up to Lit 100,000 for each payment, and ITALY in certain circumstances, in foreign banknotes that are accepted in the country of issue for credit to bank accounts, balances in which are convertible at official market rates. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from current invisibles are subject to the same collection, retention, and surrender requirements as receipts from exports.8 Shipping and insurance com- panies and travel and forwarding agencies may keep operating accounts (Conti Autorizzati) in U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Japanese yen, and externally con- vertible European currencies. Residents may not retain any foreign banknotes left over from trips abroad but must sell them to an authorized bank. Persons may bring in any amount in foreign banknotes and Lit 35,000 in Italian banknotes. Capital Inward and outward movements of nonresident cap- ital are free. However, loans of any kind from nonresi- dents to residents and from residents to nonresidents require specific authorization from the Ministry of the Treasury or the Ministry of Foreign Trade, respec- tively, except, with regard to OECD countries, long-term loans (other than loans from financial insti- tutions to nonresidents) for the purpose of establishing or maintaining lasting economic relations and loans to relatives up to the third degree of relationship, and, with regard to EEC countries, short-term (up to one year and not exceeding Lit 250 million) and medi- um-term (up to five years and not exceeding Lit 250 million) financial loans (i.e., loans not connected with commercial operations or the performance of services); for none of these is any kind of authorization required. Repayment of such loans may be made freely. A deposit requirement is applicable to outward transfers of resident-owned capital for direct invest- ments, portfolio investments, financial loans, purchases of real estate, and personal capital movements. The transferor must lodge a lira deposit equivalent to 50 per cent of the amount transferred (25 per cent for invest- ment fund securities, but mutual funds investing en- tirely in Italian securities are exempt) in a noninterest-bearing account with the bank effecting the transfer. In addition, when foreign investments are transferred between residents against lire, the transferee is subject to the deposit requirement, regardless of the date when the investment was made. The deposits are released only when, and to the extent that, disinvest- ment operations occur, and their release requires the prior approval of the local Bank of Italy office. Pur- chases by residents of certain bonds issued by specified EEC institutions are exempt. Outward direct invest- ment transactions have from time to time been given an ad hoc exemption. Foreign investment in Italy is, in principle, governed by Law No. 43 of February 7, 1956 and subsequent 261 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY implementing regulations. Foreign investments of any kind in Italy, including both direct and portfolio invest- ment and the purchase of real estate, are permitted freely, and no restrictions are applied to their repatria- tion. Direct investment in OECD countries by physical or juridical persons (other than participation by a finan- cial ins t i tu t ion that has its main office in I ta ly in a foreign company not having the same corporate pur- pose), is permitted in any form and w i thout any l im i t .9 Direct investment in other countries may be made only (under the supervision of the Italian Exchange Office) by juridical persons in firms that are in the same line of business as that of the Italian firm mak ing the investment; other types of direct investment in such countries require special authorization from the Minis- try of Foreign Trade. The general license to make these investments also covers the reinvestment of earnings and the use for this purpose of the liquidation proceeds of previous investments (after crediting the proceeds of the disinvestment to bank accounts similar to those established for proceeds from exports and invisibles; see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, above). Residents of I ta ly are free to buy and sell, through the Bank of I ta ly or the authorized banks, any foreign securities issued or payable abroad and quoted on for- eign stock exchanges, and to deal in such securities among themselves against payment in lire. Such foreign securities, except securities of Lit 100,000 or less, have to be deposited with an Italian bank or w i th a bank abroad for account of an Italian bank. The purchase by residents of shares of foreign financial institutions of any k ind (including mu tual funds), as well as convert- ible bonds issued by such institutions, requires prior approval by the Italian Exchange Office. In practice, however, a resident is able to freely purchase shares of foreign funds that have received authorization from the Ministry of Foreign Trade to sell their shares in I ta ly, since that authorization is in fact valid also for the individual resident subscriber. Such authorization is given only to funds meeting certain requirements, in- cluding that of investing at least 50 per cent of their portfolio in Italian securities and that of setting up a branch office in Italy. Residents do not require authori- zation to purchase real estate in EEC countries. All issues of securities by nonresidents on the Italian capital market require the prior approval of the Minis- try of Foreign Trade, and are subject to the rules gov- erning the issue in Italy of domestic securities. These rules include the prior approval of the Bank of Italy, and, for issues beyond Lit 500 million, that of the Min- istry of the Treasury, the Ministry of Indus try, and the Interministerial Credit Committee. Issues are normally restricted to international institutions. Transfers in connection with donations, inheritances, and dowries may be made freely. The transfer of prop- erty of residents leaving Italy permanently is allowed in two stages: up to the equivalent of Lit 6 million a per- son upon presentation of specified documents to an 262 authorized bank at the time of leaving Italy, and the remainder subject to examination of the documents by the Italian Exchange Office, when residence has been established abroad. Special regulations apply to commercial credits and credits related to the performance of services. Advance payments for imports must be made with foreign cur- rency borrowed f rom an authorized Italian bank; in other cases, the prior approval of the Ministry of For- eign Trade is required. When prepayments for imports exceed Lit 5 million, an advance deposit of 5 per cent is required. Deferred payments for imports are permit- ted freely if settlement is to take place, to the extent of at least 90 per cent, w i th in 360 days af ter importation, and the balance within 24 months after importation; such payments require the prior approval of the Italian Exchange Office if the settlement is to take place be- tween 12 mon ths and 24 months after importation. In all other cases, the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade is required; where, according to the con- tract, settlement is to take place more than 360 days a f ter the date of impor ta t ion, the approval of the Minis- try is required to make the payment prior to the due date set in the contract. Advance payments for exports may be received freely if exportation is to take place within 360 days; in all other cases, such receipts require the prior approval of the Italian Exchange Office. Deferred payments for exports are permitted if settlement is to take place to the extent of at least 90 per cent within 90 days after exportation, and the balance within 24 months after exportation. For settlement between 90 and 360 days a f ter exportation, the approval of the Exchange Office is required; in all other cases, such receipts require the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. V ir tua l ly identical regulations are in force for the permitted credit terms for imports and exports of ser- vices. In relations with EEC countries, the reciprocal gran t ing of credits for commercial transactions or the performance of services, with a ma tur i ty longer than the time limits that banks are authorized to approve and up to f ive years, may be effected after examination of the documents by the Italian Exchange Office. This applies also in relations with Austria, Finland, Nor- way, Sweden, and Switzerland. Loans and credits (the latter only beyond a certain duration, generally 180—360 days) not connected with commercial transactions or with the performance of services require the approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. However, financial loans may be granted to or by residents of EEC countries as indicated above. The export of Italian and foreign securities is permit- ted only when they are owned by nonresidents and have been purchased against U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Japanese yen, or externally convertible European cur- rencies, or against funds on a Foreign Account or a Capital Account. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution The net external position of the banks is subject to control by the Exchange Office. This control encom- passes (1) the spot position vis-a-vis nonresidents in foreign currencies and lire together; and (2) the overall position, spot and forward combined, in all foreign currencies; a balanced foreign currency position on a daily basis is required separately in (a) U.S. dollars, (b) EEC currencies, and (c) all other con to valuta no curren- cies combined. Authorized banks are not permitted to increase their net foreign liability position beyond the level on July 19, 1974, and are prohibited from main- taining a net foreign asset position. Gold Residents may freely hold and negotiate gold in any form in Italy, with the exception of unrefined gold imported under ministerial license for industrial pur- poses. The monetary authorities may freely acquire un- refined gold abroad. Agent banks that have been authorized by the Ministry of the Treasury may acquire unrefined gold abroad upon submission of licenses is- sued by the Ministry of Foreign Trade to Italian firms for industrial use. Exports of wrought and semimanu- factured gold, other than jewelry, are subject to licens- ing. Imports of unrefined gold are subject to value-added tax at 12 per cent. Imports of gold coins for numismatic purposes are subject to value-added tax at 18 per cent. Changes during 1974 January 1. A new tax law came into effect. Among other things, it introduced a 15 per cent withholding tax on interest payments, but it exempted bank depos- its held by nonresident banks from this tax. February 3. The amount of the swap agreement be- tween the Bank of Italy and the U.S. Federal Reserve System was increased from US$2 billion to US$3 bil- lion. February 25. Imports of beef from "third" countries were restricted. March 5. It was announced that notes to be issued shortly by the European Coal and Steel Community would not be eligible for exemption from the deposit requirement against capital outflows. March 6. Borrowing and lending between residents of Italy and residents of Finland or Norway, in respect of imports originating in those countries and exports to those countries, with maturities in excess of those which banks could approve but not in excess of five years, henceforth were permitted subject to prior exam- ination of documents by the Exchange Office. March 8. The amount of Italian banknotes that resi- dent and nonresident travelers could freely bring in or take out was reduced to Lit 20,000 a person a trip (previously Lit 500,000 for departing travelers and un- limited upon entry); for persons living in border areas, the same daily limit was applicable for imports and exports of Italian banknotes, but within this limit they ITALY could take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the equivalent of Lit 10,000. The foreign exchange allow- ances to residents for all types of personal foreign travel were maintained unchanged, but henceforth had to be marked in the traveler's passport. Furthermore, return- ing residents no longer were permitted to retain any leftover foreign banknotes or travelers checks for subse- quent use. Additional reporting requirements were in- troduced for certain outward remittances. March 11. The supervision over the import of unre- fined gold for industrial use was tightened further. March 12. Medium-term loans granted or received by Italian banks in connection with imports or exports of goods or services, whether expressed in lire or foreign currency, henceforth had to be settled in Foreign Ac- count lire or in foreign currency related to an Ordinary Foreign Currency Account. Previously, such loans were settled through the financial exchange market. March 22. The dual exchange market was unified by the abolition of the financial exchange market. The regulations regarding permitted debits and credits to Foreign Accounts and Capital Accounts were revised accordingly. The Conti Valutari Finanziari were abol- ished. Italy did not resume its participation in the Euro- pean common margins arrangement. April 26. Special exchange control measures regard- ing inward remittances by emigrants came into effect. April 26. The Bank of Italy concluded a reciprocal credit arrangement for Can$250 million with the Bank of Canada. May 6. Restrictions were imposed on the allocation of foreign exchange for tourist travel. The basic alloca- tion for tourism and for travel for business, study, and health reasons was reduced from the equivalent of Lit 500,000 a person a trip to Lit 500,000 a person a year; for tourism, applications for exchange in excess of the basic allocation were no longer considered. Appli- cations for additional amounts for travel for business, study, and health reasons had to be screened by the Italian Exchange Office. The supervision over the allo- cation of exchange for certain other current invisibles (family remittances, gifts, and remittances for medical treatment) was tightened; the approval authority dele- gated to banks for these items was reduced from Lit 1 million for each remitter during a period of three months to Lit 35,000 a transfer. May 6. The amount of Italian banknotes that could be exported from or imported into Italy by travelers was raised from Lit 20,000 to Lit 35,000 a person a trip, except for persons living in border areas, for whom this amount was increased from Lit 10,000 to Lit 15,000. May 6. The Italian Exchange Office announced that foreign bank credits to Italian importers could no longer be guaranteed by Italian banks. Italian banks continued to be free, however, to open confirmed lines of credit for importers. May 7. Importers were required to make a cash de- posit in lire of 50 per cent of the c.i.f. value of imports 263 ©International Monetary Fund. These related primarily to (1) the reciprocal g ran t ing of credits for imports of goods originating in OECD countries, for exports to those countries, and for the performance of services (except for EEC countries, Austria, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland); and (2) the extension of commit- ments for prepaymen ts and postpayments in respect of imports and exports of goods and services f rom and to all countries. Not for Redistribution IVORY COAST (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Ivo ry Coast has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the CFA Franc, l which is off ic ia l ly maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange trans- actions in French francs, the in terven t ion currency, be- tween the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de TOuest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place on the basis of CFAF 1 = F 0.02; the BCEAO levies a commission of Y10 of 1 per mil for transfers w i th in the West African Monetary Union and a commission of 2.50 per mil for transfers to countries outside the Un ion. Exchange rates for foreign currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French f ranc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West African Mone tary Un ion, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. With the exception of those relating to gold, Ivo ry Coast's exchange control measures do not app ly in f inanc ial relations with (1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Terri- to ry of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked w i th the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Came- roon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta). Hence, all paymen ts to these countries may be made free ly. All other countries, except Ivo ry Coast itself, are considered fo r- eign countries, and in principle f inanc ial relations only w i th foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Directorate of External Finance and Credit in the M in is t ry of Econ- omy and Finance, which also supervises borrow ing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or o f fe r ing for sale of fo re ign securities in Ivo ry Coast, fore ign inwa rd direct inves tmen t, and all ou twa rd inves tment in foreign countries. The BCEAO is authorized to collect any in fo rma t ion necessary to compile the balance of pay- men ts statistics, either direct or th rough the intermedi- ary of banks, other f inanc ial ins t i tu t ions, the Postal Adm in is t ra t ion, and notaries public. All exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be ef- fected th rough authorized banks or the Postal Admin- is tra t ion. Impo rt and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Foreign Trade in the M in is try of Com- merce. 266 Prescription of Currency Ivory Coast is an Operations Account coun try of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settle- ments with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account coun try. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. All settlements w i th Rhodesia are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO bank- notes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Abidjan by authorized banks' foreign corre- spondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident ac- counts of such banknotes is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Certain im- ports f rom the People's Republic of China, Hong Kong, Japan, and Portugal are suspended. A few im- ports f rom all sources are prohibited (e.g., a specified type of coffee-husk ing machine and wheat flour) or subject to import license (e.g., sugar, paints, matches, and detergents). Impo r ts of rice are related to domestic production in such a manner that imports are made complementary to purchases of domestically produced rice. All other impor ts f rom countries in the French Franc Area may be made freely. Virtually all imports originating in EEC countries other than France or shipped from those countries also are free from quanti- ta t ive restrictions and free of license; the exceptions are some 16 items on a special list. As a rule, imports from non-EEC countries outside the French Franc Area re- qu i re import licenses and may be made in accordance w i th an import program, which is determined annually by the M in is try of Commerce. Under this program, semiannual global quotas are established for imports from such countries and special quotas for imports f rom countries w i th which Ivory Coast maintains bilat- eral trade agreements. 2 The program also includes in- dicative quotas for the EEC countries and a quota for Hong Kong and Eastern European countries. The quo- tas establish limits up to which import licenses may be issued, for specified commodities, to licensed importers and, in exceptional cases, to industrial or agricultural producers who are considered as end-users of the im- ported goods. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution All import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000; transactions of lower value must be domiciled if a financial transaction is to be undertaken before customs clearance. The import licenses or import attestations entitle importers to pur- chase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than one month before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles Payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to approval. Payments for invisi- bles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresi- dents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely when the basic transaction has been approved. Any resident may freely and at any time make remittances abroad up to the equivalent of CFAF 50,000 without indicating their purpose. Resi- dents traveling to countries other than France (as de- fined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may ob- tain an exchange allocation for tourism of an amount equivalent to CFAF 175,000 a person a year (CFAF 87,500 for children under ten); any foreign ex- change remaining in excess of CFAF 5,000 after return to Ivory Coast must be surrendered. The transfer of the full basic salary of a foreigner working in Ivory Coast is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period. Resident and nonresi- dent travelers going to foreign countries may take out BCEAO banknotes up to CFAF 25,000. Travelers to other Franc Area countries may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes, but if going to a country that is not a member of the West African Monetary Union, the amount taken out must be declared to the customs if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may freely take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the equivalent of CFAF 175,000, as well as any travelers checks, etc., issued abroad. Subject to documentation, they may also take out any amount of travelers checks, etc., in foreign currency established in their name after conversion of foreign currency into CFA francs or drawn against a Foreign Account in Francs or a foreign currency in Ivory Coast. Nonresidents who have made a currency declaration upon entry or are able to show the proper banking notices may take out higher amounts. IVORY COAST Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports are free of license and require a declaration only. Ex- ports of agricultural commodities, however, require the visa of the Directorate of Foreign Trade. The due date for payments in respect of exports to foreign countries must not be later than 180 days after the arrival of the goods at their destination. The proceeds must be col- lected and, if the contract is invoiced in a currency other than that of a country of the Franc Area, surren- dered on the exchange market, within two months of the due date. All export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when valued at CFAF 500,000 or more. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Ac- count countries in the French Franc Area may be re- tained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date or the date of receipt. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area; residents bringing in foreign banknotes or other foreign means of payment must sell any amount in excess of CFAF 5,000 to an authorized bank within eight days and must declare them to the customs upon entry. Capital All capital movements between Ivory Coast and Rhodesia are prohibited. Capital movements between Ivory Coast and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital trans- fers to all other countries require exchange control ap- proval, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over foreign inward direct in- vestment, over all outward investment in foreign countries, and over the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Ivory Coast; these con- trols relate to the transactions themselves, not to pay- ments or receipts. With the exception of those relating to foreign securities, these control measures do not ap- ply to relations with France (as defined above), Mo- naco, the other member countries of the West African Monetary Union, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an 267 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IVORY COAST Operations Account. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the solicit- ing of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over all public- ity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special controls also apply to France (as defined above), Mo- naco, and the Operations Account countries. All investments abroad by residents of Ivory Coast require prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance. 3 Foreign direct investments in Ivo ry Coast, 4 must be declared to the Minister of Economy and Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to him. The liquidation of invest- ments, whether direct investments or not, in Ivory Coast or abroad must similarly be declared in advance to the Minister. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Ivory Coast investments abroad or foreign investments in Ivory Coast, must be reported to the Minister within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as invest- ments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct invest- ment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of for- eign securities in Ivory Coast requires prior authoriza- tion by the Minister of Economy and Finance, as do issues by Ivory Coast companies. Exempt from autho- rization, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Ivory Coast Gov- ernment and (2) shares similar to securities whose issue, offering, or sale in Ivory Coast has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents f rom nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans cons t i tu t ing a direct invest- ment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indi- cated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance transactions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports in to or exports f rom Ivory Coast, or by approved international trading houses to finance inter- national merchanting transactions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; and (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount ou ts tand ing of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 50 million for any one borrower, and provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate. The repayment of loans consti- tu t ing a direct investment is subject to the formalities prescribed for the liquidation of direct investments. The repayment of other loans requires authorization only if the loan itself was subject to prior approval. Lending abroad is subject to exchange control au- thorization. 268 Law No. 59-134 of September 3, 1959 provides tax and customs du ty benefits and other special privileges for new enterprises recognized as having priority status. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Ivo ry Coast. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Fi- nance, which is rarely granted. Exempt from this re- quirement are (1) imports and exports by the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufac- tured articles containing a m inor quan t i ty of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold articles up to a weight of 250 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports and exports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Changes during 1974 January 19. The fixed exchange rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02 was maintained following the announcement of the French authorities that during the next six months, and on a provisional basis, the interventions of the Exchange Stabilization Fund in the official exchange market would no longer aim at limiting the exchange rates between the French f ranc and certain other cur- rencies w i th in predetermined margins. An official deci- sion to this effect was taken by the Council of the West African Monetary Union on January 24. March 21. Following the abolition of the dual ex- change market in France, the dual market arrange- ments in Ivory Coast also ceased to operate. The financial f ranc market and the Financial Accounts in Francs were abolished and settlements with countries outside the French Franc Area henceforth took place only th rough the official exchange market and through Foreign Accounts in Francs. The relevant exchange control regulations were issued in Ivory Coast on May 6 and June 11. May 6. Notice No. 36 revoked and replaced Notice No. 2 of December 31, 1968 and revised the regula- tions concerning nonresident accounts in francs and foreign securities dossiers in light of the abolition of the dual exchange marke t. June 11. Order No. 861 revoked Order No. 1819 of August 26, 1972. All purchases and sales of foreign currencies (spot or forward) and all payments between Ivory Coast and foreign countries or between a resident and a nonresident henceforth had to be made through the official exchange market. IVORY COAST 269 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.900364 gram of f ine gold per Jamaica Dollar. On February 20, 1973, a central rate of J$l = US$1.10 was established, corresponding to J$1.09668 — SDR 1 or 0.810328 gram of fine gold per Jamaica dollar. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar and Jamaica avails itself of wider margins. In practice, the Bank of Jamaica's dealings against Jamaica dollars are confined to transactions in Cana- dian dollars, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars, to pur- chases of Canadian, U.K., and U.S. banknotes, and to purchases of certain Caribbean and European bank- notes (see below). It deals in other currencies only against sterling and U.S. dollars. The Bank buys and sells U.S. dollars at par, plus a commission of 3/i6 of 1 per cent on the selling side. Exchange rates for curren- cies other than the U.S. dollar (except the East Carib- bean dollar, the Guyana dollar, and the Trinidad and Tobago dollar) are based on the Bank of Jamaica's buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar and the rates against the U.S. dollar for the currencies concerned in international markets. The Bank of Jamaica sets daily off ic ial buy ing and selling rates for dealing w i th the banks in s ter l ing and Canadian dollars on the basis of the previous day's closing quotations in New York. On the basis of these rates, the Bank also fixes daily rates at wh ich commercial banks must deal w i th their cus- tomers in transactions invo lv ing Jamaica dollars against Canadian dollars, pounds sterling, or U.S. dol- lars. The Bank of Jamaica is authorized by law to fix its buy ing and selling rates of exchange. On December 31, 1974 these rates relating to spot dealings with the com- mercial banks reflected no commission charge on pur- chases but a charge of Y16 of 1 per cent on sales. The commercial banks applied a commission charge (pre- m ium) of 3/8 of 1 per cent on sales of foreign exchange to customers and a commission charge (discount) of Yg of 1 per cent on purchases. For purchases equ iva lent to J$ 1,000 or more, the commission charge (discount) was waived. The Bank of Jamaica's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were US$1 = J$0.9075 and US$1 = J$0.9125, respectively. Under an arrangement with the central banks of Guyana and Trinidad and Tobago and w i th the East Caribbean Currency Au tho r i ty, the Bank of Jamaica purchases bankno tes and coins issued by these mone- ta ry authorities and repatriates them in re tu rn for reci- procity of trea tment w i th respect to collections of Jamaica dollars. The Bank's purchases are made at the middle rate determined on the basis of the preva i l ing sterling-U.S. dollar rate; for transactions in these cur- rencies, the commercial banks charge a commission of Y4 of 1 per cent either side of the middle rate, buy ing and selling. 270 There is a "bourse" (interbank exchange market) in which all commercial banks participate and in which only Canadian dollars and sterling are traded against U.S. dollars. The Bank of Jamaica does not provide forward cover to banks. Capital transactions between nonresidents and non- bank residents are in principle channeled through an investment currency market, which, however, is inoper- ative. Transactions are subject on the buying side to a premium of 10 per cent on the Bank of Jamaica's buy- ing rate and on the selling side to a premium of 20 per cent on the Bank of Jamaica's buying rate (plus the normal commission charged on sales of exchange). Jamaica formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 22, 1963. Administration of Control The Bank of Jamaica administers exchange control on behalf of the Minister of Finance, subject to certain limitations in respect of which the approval of the Min- ister is required. The commercial banks are designated as authorized dealers and have authority to provide foreign exchange for imports up to J$ 10,000, and for basic travel allowances and certain other payments up to specified lesser amounts. Import licenses are issued by the Trade Administrator, who is responsible to the Minister of Marketing and Commerce. Prescription of Currency Jamaica has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U .K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U .K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Paymen ts to all countries may be made by crediting Jamaica dollars to an External Account or in any for- eign currency.1 Receipts from all countries must be received by debit of an External Account or in any foreign currency. Special regulations apply to settle- ments w i th Rhodesia, and all payments to Rhodesia require specific authorization. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts in Jamaica dollars may be held by persons who are regarded for exchange control pur- poses as norma l ly permanently resident outside Ja- maica. These accounts are fu r ther designated External Accounts or Blocked Accounts. The commercial banks are empowered to open Ex- ternal Accounts in Jamaica dollars for nonresidents except residents of Rhodesia, provided that no credit of Jamaica dollars is made to the Accounts without the specific approval of the Bank of Jamaica. The funds on ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution these accounts may be transferred freely between non- residents. External Accounts may be credited with pay- ments by residents of Jamaica approved by the exchange control authorities, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from the sale to an authorized dealer of gold or foreign currencies. They may be debited for payments to residents of Ja- maica, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for the purchase of foreign currencies. Accounts which are credited with funds that may not be placed at the free disposal of nonresidents of Jamaica (including the proceeds from the sale of undeveloped land) are designated Blocked Accounts. Blocked funds may be invested in local mortgages and in Jamaica dollar securities; the income from such securities is nor- mally available for credit to an External Account. Funds originally held on a Blocked Account and the proceeds of Jamaican securities purchased with blocked funds are normally available for credit to an External Account four years after the date of blocking. Applications for the release of funds in Blocked Ac- counts for use in Jamaica by the nonresident owner must be referred to the Bank of Jamaica. The assets of residents emigrating to countries outside Jamaica in excess of the prescribed settling-in allowance of J$l 0,000 are restricted for a period of four years (see section on Capital, below). Imports and Import Payments Virtually all imports from member countries of the Caribbean Common Market (CARICOM)2 are unre- stricted under an open general license, as are a small number of goods from most other countries.3 Imports originating in Portugal, Rhodesia, or South Africa are prohibited and all imports originating in the People's Republic of China or Cuba require individual import licenses.4 A number of tariff items or groups of tariff items included in a special schedule of exceptions to the open general license are subject to individual licensing irrespective of country of origin unless (for some of the items in this schedule) the goods originate in and are consigned from other CARICOM countries. The special schedule comprises (1) goods for which specific quotas are assigned to importers according to their past per- formance, e.g., certain types of footwear, cheese, rice, and various consumer durables (for these items import licenses are granted by the Trade Administrator against allotted quotas); (2) goods which are prohib- ited, e.g., certain automobiles, radios, television sets, canned milk, cement, cigars, citrus products, cheap clothing, household detergents, sugar, and coffee; (3) goods the licensing of which depends upon local sup- ply, e.g., poultry, eggs, and vegetables; and (4) goods licensed to meet the requirements of the tourist indus- try only (including some liquors and sports goods). Payments for imports equivalent to J$ 10,000 or more are subject to prior registration with the Bank of Ja- maica and all payments for imports are subject to the JAMAICA licensing requirements, if any, being met, and the im- porter presenting a copy of the settlement invoice or other evidence of purchase and value, together with documentary evidence that the goods either have been shipped or are about to be shipped, or that the importer is under contract to make prepayment up to six months prior to shipment; specific exchange control approval is required for advance payments. Certain goods are subject to a consumption tax, whether they are imported or manufactured domesti- cally. Where such goods are imported, the tax is col- lected at the port of entry and is calculated on the sum of the value accepted for customs and the customs duty. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles require the approval of the exchange control authorities. Except for transactions involving residents of Rhodesia, the following applies. With the exception of payments in respect of foreign travel, bona fide current payments are not restricted. Approval is granted freely for payments for all com- mercial transactions, when the application is supported by the appropriate documentary evidence. A basic ex- change allocation of J$500 a person for each 12-month period for foreign travel other than for business and professional reasons is made available automatically to residents by the authorized dealers; this allowance may be accumulated for up to two years. Additional amounts are granted in cases of hardship. Facilities for travel for business and professional reasons may be provided by authorized banks at the rate of J$60 a day for up to ten days a trip while applications for higher amounts are dealt with by the central bank. Expenses for hotel accommodations, meals en route, etc., that are settled in Jamaica in domestic currency must be de- ducted from the travel allocations. Authorized dealers may, subject to the presentation of supporting evidence, approve payments for the fol- lowing: consular fees without limit, as well as transfers from the Ministry of External Affairs to accounts in the names of embassies and their established staffs, High Commissioners, and diplomats; and up to a limit of J$100 for subscriptions to trade organizations and pro- fessional organizations, and for membership dues, reg- istration fees, correspondence courses, examination fees, and imports of books, magazines, periodicals, and other publications. Requests for additional amounts (except for travel) or for purposes for which there are no standard limits (e.g., remittances by charitable insti- tutions) are approved if the authorities are satisfied that no capital flight is involved. Non-Jamaicans working in Jamaica under a work permit are allowed, as a rule, to credit only 40 per cent of their gross salary to an Exter- nal Account. Residents going abroad may take with them Jamaica banknotes not exceeding J$20 and other banknotes not 271 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA exceeding J$100. Nonresidents may take out the for- eign currency notes they brought in. Exports and Export Proceeds All goods valued at not more than J$200 (f.o.b.) for g i f ts and JS500 (f.o.b.) for other exports may be freely exported by post or air express to any country not on the prohibited list.5 Where the value exceeds these amoun ts the goods may be exported to all countries except those on the prohibited list, but a specific license is required for the export of certain agricultural prod- ucts, ammun i t ion, explosives, firearms, an t ique fu rn i- ture, ready-made garments, gold bullion, mineral and metal ores, and an t ique paintings. Exporters are re- quired to surrender their exchange proceeds to autho- rized dealers within three months from the date of sh ipmen t. However, certain exporters may retain, with the approval of the exchange control authorities, an agreed portion of their settlement of overseas commit- men ts necessary for their operations; such retained ex- port proceeds must not be sold to other nonbank residents. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in foreign currencies must be sold to an authorized dealer. Residents returning to Jamaica may bring in Jamaica banknotes up to J$20 a traveler, provided this amount was declared on leaving the country, and all travelers may bring in any amount of other banknotes; resident travelers are required to sell their holdings of foreign currencies to a local autho- rized dealer upon re turn. Capital Outflows of resident-owned capital are restricted, ir- respective of their destination. Investments abroad by residents require the approval of the exchange control authorities and are not approved unless they result in tangible benefits for Jamaica. Residents must obtain prior approval from the Bank of Jamaica to make cash gifts, which are normally limited to JS100 in any 12-month period from each adult donor, to nonresi- dents of Jamaica. With the exception of certain types of investment in real estate, all direct investments in Jamaica by nonresi- dents are granted "approved status," under which the investor is given written assurance that he will be able to repatriate at any time his original investment plus any capital gain. In order to obtain approved status, the investor must register his investment with the Bank of Jamaica. Repatriation of investments in real estate is not permitted within a period of five years following the sale of the investment if the investor failed to make any significant improvements on the land. Remittances of current items, such as profits and dividends, are permit- ted in full when the application is supported by the appropriate set of accounts. 272 Payments for amortization of, and interest on, for- eign loans approved by the Bank of Jamaica are permit- ted upon application to the exchange control authorities. However, nonresidents are not normally permitted to take security in respect of loans made to Jamaican companies owned or controlled by them. Do- mestic bank credit to nonresidents of Jamaica and to nonresident-controlled companies is subject to selec- tive credit controls; for this purpose, firms are consid- ered to be nonresident-controlled when the controlling interest is held beneficially, either directly or indirectly, by persons resident outside the CARICOM area. Such lending is subject to approval by the Bank of Jamaica; authorized dealers may, however, without reference to the exchange control authorities, make loans or over- draf ts to nonresidents of Jamaica up to J$2,000 for certain specified purposes. Authorized dealers may also w i thout reference to the exchange control authorities make loans or overdraf ts to resident companies or branches controlled by nonresidents up to J$20,000, provided that the borrower is not specifically precluded under some prior conditional permission from the ex- change control authorities. Other requests are referred to the Bank of Jamaica. Repatriates taking up residence in the country of their na t iona l i ty may transfer all their assets, with the exception of capital gains from the sale of undeveloped land; such gains are repatriable at the end of a five-year period from the date of the initial repatriation of the proceeds of the sale of other assets. However, foreign nonresident owners of land who sell it to the Govern- ment or to private individuals will receive payment in foreign exchange, subject to a minimum remittance of J$ 10,000, in equal annual installments, except where the owner had received a previous undertaking that the investment in land carried "approved status." The pol- icy of permitting nonresidents working in Jamaica un- der a work permit to acquire a house to live in continues, but the permissible amount of mortgage is restricted to 50 per cent, and the transfer of capital gains made from real estate transactions by such per- sons is restricted on their emigration to J$ 10,000 a year. Foreign sellers of land whose funds are blocked under the regulations of January 1974 and persons whose funds are restricted under Section 43 of the Exchange Control Act can invest the blocked or restricted funds locally in local registered stocks and mortgages, and income therefrom can be remitted without limit. For- eign nonresident owners of condominiums in Jamaica, when selling these to residents of Jamaica, are allowed to remit from Jamaica, in the first instance, the amount they paid originally from funds brought into Jamaica; the balance of the sale price can be remitted in ten equal installments, subject to a minimum remittance in any one year of J$ 10,000. Foreign nonresident owners of houses built on residential lots are dealt with in the same manner, provided the nonresident seller can sat- is fy the Bank as to the amount spent in Jamaica, in acquiring the lot and constructing the building thereon. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Jamaican nationals emigrating are granted a settling- in allowance of the equivalent of J$ 10,000 at the official market rate of exchange; any assets in excess of the allowance are restricted for four years. Releases after four years are limited to J$ 100,000 a family unit imme- diately and J$50,000 annually thereafter. Furthermore, emigrants in possession of overseas assets at the time of emigration are expected to apply the proceeds thereof to any settling-in allowance to which they are entitled, and thereafter to any remittances from Jamaica. These arrangements are applicable also to naturalized Jamai- can citizens and to nonnationals resident in Jamaica ten years before the enactment of the Work Permit Law. Remittances to beneficiaries under wills or intesta- cies are limited to J$ 10,000 divided among them in the first instance; J$ 100,000 for all beneficiaries at the end of the fourth year after first approval of a distribution in cash or kind; and J$50,000 among them a year there- after. Gold A J$20 commemorative gold coin issued in 1972 is legal tender but does not circulate. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Jamaica for numismatic pur- poses. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and ex- ports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. All commercial imports of jewelry are prohibited. Changes during 1974 January 1. The net short-term foreign borrowing of commercial banks became subject to a ceiling of J$30 million. Subsequently, the short-term foreign borrow- ing of the specified financial institutions was restricted to the amounts outstanding on January 31, 1974. January 1. The Bank of Jamaica ceased to make forward cover available to banks. January 9. Exports of sugar to the United Kingdom were temporarily suspended. January 15. The permission for travelers to bring in J$20 in Jamaica banknotes was restricted to residents. January 23. It was announced that imports of con- sumer goods in 1974 would be reduced from estimated 1973 levels by J$79 million and that total imports would be limited to J$645 million, c.i.f., some J$36 million more than the estimated total for 1973; certain items were banned, textile quotas were reduced, and imports of automobiles would be limited to J$5 million, subject to a c.i.f. value limit of J$3,000 for each vehicle and a rating limit of 3,000 cubic centimeters; imports of commercial vehicles would be limited to J$10 mil- JAMAICA lion. All existing import licenses for motor vehicles were revoked. January 23. Non-Jamaicans working in Jamaica un- der a work permit no longer were permitted to credit their gross salary to an External Account; henceforth, normally only 40 per cent of gross salaries and allow- ances could be so credited, but existing holders of work permits were not affected. January 23. Residents were given six months to dis- pose of any foreign assets and remit the proceeds to Jamaica. Exempt were holdings of Jamaican securities issued in London, and the foreign assets of insurance companies holding foreign assets in the same propor- tion as they had foreign liabilities. January 23. With retroactive effect from January 1, 1974, the exchange allowance for cash gifts to nonresi- dents was reduced from J$200 in any 12-month period for each donor, to J$ 100 a calendar year for each adult resident. January 23. Henceforth, imports of all commodities required a specific import license when not of CARICOM origin. The open general import license was amended accordingly. January 23. Currency declarations were required of arriving and departing travelers. January 23. The period within which exporters are required to surrender their exchange proceeds to autho- rized dealers was reduced from six months to three months after shipment. January 23. The rules for the disposal of the proceeds from the sale of land were revised. Foreign nonresident owners of land who sold it to the Government or to private individuals would receive payment in foreign exchange in ten equal annual installments, except where the owner had received a previous undertaking that the investment in land carried "approved status." The policy of permitting nonresidents working in Ja- maica under a work permit to acquire a house to live in was continued, but the transfer of capital gains made from real estate transactions by such persons was re- stricted on their emigration to J$ 10,000 a year. Foreign sellers of land whose funds were blocked under the new regulations and persons whose funds were restricted under Section 43 of the Exchange Control Act could invest the blocked or restricted funds locally in local registered stocks, and income therefrom could be re- mitted without limit. Foreign nonresident owners of condominiums in Ja- maica, when selling these to residents of Jamaica, were allowed to remit from Jamaica in the first instance, the amount they paid originally from funds brought into Jamaica; the balance of the sale price could be remitted in ten equal installments, subject to a minimum remit- tance in any one year of J$ 10,000. Foreign nonresident owners of houses built on residential lots would be dealt with in the same manner, provided the nonresi- dent seller could satisfy the bank as to the amount spent in Jamaica, in acquiring the lot and constructing the building thereon. The practice of making local 273 ©International Monetary Fund. January 23. Releases of assets of emigrating Jamai- can nationals af ter the four-year restriction period were limited to J$ 100,000 a family unit immediately and J$50,000 annually thereafter. On December 5, it was again extended for six months. June 8. The Bauxite Production Levy Act was en- acted. June 24. June 27. Holders of securities or titles to property abroad were given the following alternative arrange- ments whereby their foreign assets could be controlled without being actually transferred to the official re- serves. Where Jamaican owners of foreign assets did not elect to repatriate these, they were required by July 31, 1974 either (1) to deposit the foreign securities or titles to property abroad with an approved depository, who could not release, sell, switch, or pledge those foreign assets w i thout the general or specific permission of the Bank of Jamaica; or (2) to transfer the foreign securities or titles to property abroad to an approved nominee holder, who would hold them at the order of the Bank of Jamaica. In either case, income earned would con- tinue to accrue to, and be payable to, the owners, but such income had to be remitted to Jamaica.
