Not for Redistribution JAPAN (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.00246853 gram of fine gold per Japanese Yen. A central rate of Y 308.00 = US$1 has been established, and Japan avails itself of wider mar- gins. Since February 14, 1973, however, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the yen within any announced margins, and therefore all spot ex- change transactions take place at a fluctuating ex- change rate. The interbank selling rate for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 was about Y 301 per US$ 1. Authorized banks may freely carry out spot and forward exchange transactions with nonresident banks and among themselves; their forward transactions with resident customers must have a permitted underlying transaction. Japan formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from April 1, 1964. Administration of Control The exchange control system is operated by the Min- istry of Finance, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI), and the Bank of Japan as the Government's agent. However, most of the authority for approving normal payments is delegated to autho- rized banks referred to as foreign exchange banks. Im- port and export licensing is handled by MITI. Inward direct investments of a long-term character require the approval of the Minister of Finance and the competent minister, which is automatically granted for liberalized industries. (Most industries have already been liberal- ized, see section on Capital, below.) Outward direct investments require the approval of the Minister of Finance in exceptional cases only. Prescription of Currency Payments to all countries may be made in any cur- rency, including yen, and receipts also may be obtained in any currency. Settlements in yen with foreign countries must be made through a Nonresident Free Yen Account. All payments to Rhodesia require prior approval by the Minister of Finance or the Minister of International Trade and Indus try; in many cases such payments are prohibited or restricted for security rea- sons. Nonresident Accounts There are two main nonresident accounts, as de- scribed below. 1. Nonresident Free Yen Accounts, These accounts may be opened by any nonresident with any authorized bank in Japan and may be credited with the yen pro- ceeds f rom exports of goods to Japan and from other 276 authorized transactions, with yen proceeds from sales of all foreign currencies, with transfers from other Free Yen Accounts, with interest accrued on balances in these accounts, and with the countervalue in yen of authorized outward payments. There are no restric- tions on payments from these accounts, and balances may be converted freely into any foreign currency. 2. Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts. These accounts may be held by any nonresident with any authorized bank in Japan. They may be credited with yen proceeds from transactions other than those which are autho- rized to be credited to Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. Permitted credits to Nonresident Yen Deposit Ac- counts are limited mainly to proceeds from the sales of debentures and beneficiary certificates sold within six months from the date of validated acquisition. Balances outstanding on December 31, 1970 were permitted to be transferred to Nonresident Free Yen Accounts or to be remitted abroad. Balances accrued after that date are not convertible into foreign currencies, although remittances are permitted each year up to 30 per cent of the balance at the end of the previous year or the equivalent of Y 720,000, whichever is higher. With- drawals from these accounts are authorized for certain purposes, such as meeting the outlays involved in man- aging investments in Japan and the expenses of nonresi- dents staying in Japan. Transfers to other Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts may be made freely, thus en- abling the individual account holder to repatriate his funds by selling them to another nonresident in return for foreign currency, but there is no market for such funds in Japan. Imports and Import Payments With the exception of books and periodicals, imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Other imports are sub- ject either to individual licensing by the authorized banks or, if liberalized, to declaration to such banks. Most private imports are liberalized. There are two procedures for imports requiring payment in foreign currencies: (1) Under the Import Quota System (cover- ing imports of goods on the "negative list," which com- prises 84 items, in terms of the four-digit Brussels nomenclature; 29 of the 84 items on the "negative list" have been notified to the GATT as residual restrictions while the other 55 items have been notified as falling under the national security, public health, and moral protection provisions of the GATT), the importer must first obtain from MITI ah import quota, which is based on the quantitative principle. If the quota is granted, the importer receives an import quota certificate which entitles him to receive an import license from an autho- rized bank automatically upon application. Practically all import quota certificates are issued on a global basis, without regard to the country of origin or the currency ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution of settlement, by MITI. (2) Under the Declaration Sys- tem, imports are free of quantitative restriction and licensing and require only a declaration by the importer to a foreign exchange bank. All items subject to the Declaration System may be imported from any country except Rhodesia. Items under state trading include cer- tain dairy products, certain cereals, salt, and raw and manufactured tobacco. Payment for imported goods must be made under one of the "standard" methods of settlement for im- ports. When the settlement proposal is not in accor- dance w i th one of the "standard" methods (i.e., when certain advance payment is proposed or payment is to be made more than four months after customs clear- ance), prior approval of MITI must be obtained. Payments for Invisibles All payments to Rhodesia are subject to the ap- proval of the Minister of Finance or the Minister of International Trade and Industry. Payments to other countries for invisibles also require approval, but cur- rent payments are not restricted and most such pay- ments are approved freely by foreign exchange banks without any limitation or w i th in certain established limits. Payments for certain invisibles, including pay- ments that exceed the established limits, are referred to the Bank of Japan for the purpose of capital control; they are automatically approved without undue delay, upon verification of the authenticity of the current transaction. Residents may purchase foreign currencies for payments in connection with travel abroad up to US$1,500 a person a trip, subject to validation by a foreign exchange bank; applications in excess of US$1,500 a person a trip require the approval of the Bank of Japan. A traveler is permitted to pay in yen or in foreign currency, before departure, the cost of trans- portation to and from his destination and for all side trips. Residents may freely and at any time make payments abroad up to US$200 a remittance, for virtually any purpose other than import payments, repayments on loans, and technical assistance payments, etc.; the cor- responding amount for current invisibles related to trade is US$1,000 for each remittance. Certain insur- ance and technical assistance contracts require ap- proval; but when a license for a contract has been granted, any payment resulting from the contract may be made freely. Settlements which are not made under a "standard" method require, in principle, individual approval; without such approval, payments for ser- vices, etc., may not be made more than three months before, or later than six months after, receipt of the services, etc. Both residents and nonresidents may take out freely up to Y 30,000 in Japanese currency. Subject to verifi- cation, i.e., upon presentation of documentation show- ing any prior conversion of foreign currency, a nonresident may freely purchase foreign currencies up JAPAN to the amount which he brought into Japan; without verification the conversion into foreign currencies is limited to the equivalent of US$1,000. Exports and Export Proceeds With minor exceptions exports to Rhodesia are pro- hibited. All exports to Iran, Iraq, and Nigeria require special authorization. All exports (except exports with- out exchange) must be registered with a foreign ex- change bank ("bank certification"). Licenses are not generally required, except for goods subject to the following restrictions: restrictions on cer- tain goods to control their export to specified commu- nist countries; restrictions on goods in short supply in the domestic market (e.g., minerals, fertilizers, and sta- ple foods); and restrictions designed to forestall the imposition of import restrictions by other countries (e.g., on sewing machines and certain textiles). Exports under processing and consignment sale contracts and exports for which settlement is not under the "stand- ard" method also require individual licenses. Under the "standard" method of settlement for ex- ports, the value of the exported goods must, in general, be settled by drawing a bill of exchange payable within f ive months after sight or within six months after ship- ment. There are no surrender requirements for foreign currency earnings. The conversion into yen of advance receipts in respect of exports, i.e., proceeds received before shipment, requires an individual license when they exceed the equivalent of US$500,000. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts under the "standard" method of settlement may be accepted without a license. Under this method, receipts for the value of services, etc., must be obtained within one year before, or within six months after, ren- dering the service, etc., but contracts for services per- formed for nonresidents when payment is to be received by a nonstandard method are subject to individual li- censing. Receipts from invisibles need not be surren- dered. Both residents and nonresidents may bring in freely any amount in foreign or Japanese currency. Capital Foreign investments in Japan are generally subject to approval, mainly in accordance with the Law Concern- ing Foreign Investment (Law No. 163 of May 10, 1950) or the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Control Law (Law No. 228 of December 1, 1949). All acquisitions of stocks, bonds, debentures, beneficiary certificates, and claims in the form of loans by foreign investors are, in principle, subject to validation or li- cense. However, acquisitions of stocks for portfolio in- vestment are automatically approved by the Bank of Japan provided the limits on foreign ownership are not exceeded; in addition, acquisitions of stocks in excess of 277 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAPAN those limits are automatically approved by the compe- tent ministers, provided the corporation concerned (ex- cept when belonging to one of the 21 nonliberalized industries mentioned below) consents to foreign partic- ipation. All these acquisitions must be made against yen proceeds from the sale of foreign exchange or its equivalent, if the investor wishes to obtain remittance rights upon validation. Stocks in the form of stock dividends from earned surplus or revaluation of assets may be acquired freely, but application for remittance rights must be made within three months from the date of acquisition. At present, the acquisition of Japanese securities by nonresidents is not restricted, although subject in the case of shares to the foreign ownership limits. The following are deemed to be the same as yen proceeds from the sale of foreign exchange, if they are reinvested in Japan and if approval had been obtained for their acquisition: proceeds from the redemption af- ter maturity of debentures, beneficiary certificates, or claims in the form of loans; dividends on stocks, inter- est on debentures or on claims in the form of loans; distributed profits from beneficiary certificates; receipts from technological assistance contracts; and proceeds from sales of stocks, debentures, and beneficiary certifi- cates. In the event of expropriation or compulsory sale of a foreign investment, the amount paid because of ex- propriation may be repatriated freely. The remittance of the proceeds from the sale of vali- dated stocks (shares), as well as the transfer abroad of earnings on foreign investments acquired w i th foreign currency, is permitted. Proceeds from the sale of stocks may be deposited in Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. Proceeds from the sale of bonds, debentures, and bene- ficiary certificates normally may be deposited in Non- resident Free Yen Accounts, if the securities have been held for six months from the date of acquisition. Pro- ceeds from the sale of stocks, bonds, debentures, benefi- ciary certificates, etc., acquired with yen w i thd rawn from Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts may be de- posited in Nonresident Free Yen Accounts, provided that the securities have been held for at least three years from the date of acquisition. There are no special rules prescribing that the yen proceeds from sales of securi- ties by nonresidents must within any specified period be either reinvested in securities or converted into foreign currency for transfer abroad. Repayments of loans extended to residents from Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts become remitta- ble, subject to licensing by the Bank of Japan, begin- ning three years from the date of the loan. When foreign companies desire to establish a branch or a plant in Japan, they are required to inform the Ministry of Finance and MITI in advance through the Bank of Japan. When branches or plants established by foreign companies wish to bring in funds from their main offices abroad, they are required to obtain li- censes. The branches established in accordance with 278 approved procedures are permitted to remit their prof- its and principal abroad. Foreign direct investment in Japan generally requires approval by the Minister of Finance and the competent minister after deliberation (in certain important cases) by the Foreign Investment Council. Foreign ownership up to 100 per cent is permitted in new or existing enterprises in all but 21 industries. Among these 21, foreign ownership in 16 industries, most of which are 50 per cent liberalized, is to be fu l ly liberalized in stages between May 1975 and May 1976,1 from which time 100 per cent foreign ownership will be permitted in all but 5 industries. In 4 of these 5 industries, investment will be subject to case-by-case screening and in one, foreign ownership will be permitted up to 50 per cent. The present liberalization applies both to the establish- ment of new firms and (provided in all cases that the firm concerned consents) to take-overs of existing firms or participation in existing firms. Purchases by nonresidents of real estate in Japan for residential or other nonprofit purposes and of offices require approval by the Bank of Japan, and those of real estate for other purposes require approval by the Minister of Finance. The approval of the Bank is given automatically. The transfer abroad of capital by residents and the making of investments abroad are subject to approval, but approval generally is either automatic or freely given for outward direct investment, purchases of real estate abroad, and outward portfolio investment. How- ever, the acquisition by residents of foreign short-term securities with maturities of one year or less is subject to case-by-case screening and at the end of 1974 was not normally permitted. Furthermore, for residents other than institutional investors, there are certain re- strictions on purchases of unlisted securities. In addi- tion, foreign exchange banks and securities firms were informed in January 1974 that the public should not be encouraged to buy foreign securities, but no formal controls were imposed. Japanese emigrants may remit any amount from their assets to any country subject only to verification by a foreign exchange bank. Emi- grants of foreign nationality leaving Japan also may remit to any country any amount of personal assets, subject to verification by a foreign exchange bank. Cer- tain types of outflows of long-term capital are facili- tated by a foreign currency lending system under which government institutions and foreign exchange banks are authorized to make foreign currency loans to resi- dents for 50 per cent of their direct investment opera- tions abroad and for advance payments in respect of imports. Outward financial credits and loans are sub- ject to licensing. The issuing of bonds abroad, includ- ing issues for conversion into yen for domestic use, also is subject to licensing; at the end of 1974 such issues were being permitted selectively. Securities acquired with approval under the Law Concerning Foreign Investment may be imported and exported freely. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Foreign exchange banks are subject to controls over their overall net position in foreign currency (spot and forward combined). The switching of foreign funds into yen by foreign exchange banks is also subject to regula- tion; their interoffice liabilities on Nonresident Free Yen Accounts are regarded as foreign exchange liabili- ties for the application of this regulation. The interest rates on Nonresident Free Yen Accounts must not ex- ceed those on resident-owned deposits, but otherwise are not subject to control. Gold Residents, including domestic producers of gold, may freely hold gold and purchase and sell it in domes- tic transactions. The import of gold bullion containing more than 45 per cent gold in weight normally is per- mitted, provided a payments license is obtained from the Bank of Japan; the volume of gold bullion imports may, however, be restricted at the discretion of the authorities if it reaches a level that would result in a disruptive influence on international gold markets. Im- ports of other gold bullion, gold coins, and articles of gold are freely permitted, subject only to verification by a foreign exchange bank. Travelers (resident or nonresi- dent) are freely permitted to bring in up to one kilo- gram of gold bullion a person a trip and up to the equivalent of US$200 in articles of gold and gold coins. Gold bullion, gold coins, and gold articles acquired by donation or inheritance may be imported freely, subject only to verification by the customs authorities. Exports of gold bullion, gold coins, and articles of gold by residents require licenses from the Minister of Finance; exports of gold bullion are not normally permitted. Changes during 1974 January 5. A trade agreement with the People's Re- public of China was signed; it included a most-favored- nation clause. January 5. It was announced that the yen-conversion ceiling on "impact loans" (untied loans from nonresi- dents to nonbank residents) would be raised progres- sively. January 7. The acquisition by residents of all foreign short-term securities (i.e., with maturities of one year or less) became subject to approval and case-by-case screening; also, the authorities informed the securities firms and foreign exchange banks concerned that the public should not be encouraged to buy foreign securi- ties, and that any net acquisition of foreign securities was considered undesirable. (The acquisition of foreign securities maturing within six months had been subject to case-by-case screening since November 13, 1973.) January 7. It was announced that resources under the Foreign Currency Lending Program of September 1972, under which government institutions and foreign exchange banks were entitled to make foreign currency loans to residents for 90 per cent of their direct invest- ment operations abroad and of their import prepay- JAPAN ments, would not be available for nonurgent invest- ment in such sectors as services or real estate; further- more, the percentage that could be lent in foreign currency would be reduced to 50 per cent. (Loans un- der the program had ceased to be available for real estate operations as from December 17, 1973.) January 7. Exporters were allowed to convert into yen prepayments of up to US$100,000 a transaction from foreign importers. (The limit had previously been set at US$10,000. The ceiling was again increased to US$500,000 on July 30.) January 17. The special rules of October 1972 were revoked which provided that the yen proceeds from sales of securities by nonresidents must within one month of receipt be either reinvested in securities or converted into foreign currency for transfer abroad. January 29. A ceiling was imposed on resident for- eign currency deposits with banks in Japan. The ceiling was set at the average of end-of-month deposit balances for each account for October-December 1973, and was to be enforced from February 26. (This restriction was, however, partially adjusted on February 27, when the ceiling was set at US$10,000 for accounts with balances of less than US$10,000.) At the same time, a similar system was introduced for companies (mainly in ship- ping and insurance), and securities dealers were re- quired to dispose of their foreign exchange proceeds (either by conversion into yen or reinvestment in securi- ties) within seven business days after each transaction. February 13. It was announced that the conversion into yen of advance export receipts in excess of the ceiling of US$100,000 a transaction would be automati- cally approved by the Bank of Japan provided they were received less than six months before shipment. March 23. In keeping with earlier moves to liberalize capital movements, the requirements for listing foreign stocks in Tokyo were relaxed; henceforth, foreign cor- porations would only be required to disclose whatever financial information is required to be disclosed by their national legislation. April 1. Import duties were reduced on 96 products. April 1. Japan's scheme of generalized tariff prefer- ences for developing countries was expanded in both country coverage and commodity coverage, and some preferential tariff rates were reduced. The scheme was also fur ther liberalized administratively. April 1. Imports of gold necklaces with a gold con- tent of not less than 50 per cent were liberalized. April 1. All purchases of foreign currency for travel again required validation or approval. Validation was required from a foreign exchange bank for amounts up to US$1,500, while larger amounts required approval by the Bank of Japan. Previously, allowances were granted freely up to US$1,000 a person a trip, higher amounts up to US$3,000 required validation by a for- eign exchange bank, and amounts in excess of US$3,000 required Bank of Japan approval. 279 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JORDAN (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.29184 grams of fine gold per Jor- dan Dinar, corresponding to JD 1 = US$3.1111, and Jordan avails itself of wider margins. On December 31, 1974, the Central Bank of Jordan's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$3.1847 and US$3.1646 per dinar, and those for sterling were £ stg. 1.3514 and £ stg. 1.3405 per dinar.1 The buying and selling rates quoted by the commercial banks for these and other currencies must be based on the spot rates quoted by the Central Bank. A fee of 4 per cent is levied on the issue of import licenses. A fee of YIQ of 1 per cent is levied on exchange permits approved by the Central Bank for sales of exchange for imports, except imports of government departments and certain other approved institutions. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Foreign Re- lations Department of the Central Bank of Jordan, which also issues exchange permits; the Central Bank has, however, delegated to authorized banks the issu- ance of exchange permits for import payments, and, up to a permitted annual limit, for payments for educa- tional expenses of Jordanians studying abroad and for various other purposes. An Import Committee com- prising representatives of the Ministries of National Economy and Finance and Customs and the Central Bank presents from time to time suggestions and rec- ommendations concerning changes in import policy to the Minister of National Economy. In addition, an Economic Security Committee is empowered to amend existing regulations or issue new ones concerning any aspect of Jordan's economic policies when this is con- sidered necessary to the national interest. Prescription of Currency Jordan has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. All settlements in respect of trade with Egypt must be made in pounds sterling through clear- ing accounts under a special bilateral payments ar- rangement with that country. Payments to other countries may be made in any currency. Proceeds from exports (except those of perishable vegetables to neighboring Arab countries) and invisi- bles must be collected, and surrendered where required, in any convertible currency through an authorized bank in Jordan or in Jordan dinars from a nonresident account with an authorized bank in Jordan. Nonresident Accounts Subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank, authorized banks may open nonresident accounts in domestic currency. These accounts must be fed with approved funds; the approval of the Central Bank is necessary for transfers from resident to nonresident accounts, but transfers between nonresident accounts are permitted freely. In addition, nonresidents, includ- ing Jordanians working abroad, may freely open inter- est-bearing foreign currency accounts with authorized banks; balances on these accounts may be withdrawn freely in convertible currency, while the interest rate is fixed in accordance with rates prevailing in interna- tional markets. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain items2 from any source, some im- ports from Romania, and all imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. All other imports, unless cov- ered by an agreement between Jordan and the export- ing country (i.e., agricultural products from neighboring countries), require import licenses if their c.& f. value is JD 50 or more. These are granted freely by the Ministry of National Economy, except for cer- tain items3 which are subject to scrutiny by the Minis- ter of National Economy (whose prior approval is also required for imports of industrial machinery and of all materials needed for the establishment or expansion of an industrial firm) or scrutiny by the competent minis- try. Importers of tea and certain other goods must obtain a specified minimum proportion of their require- ments from Indian sources. Imports shipped by sea should, in principle, enter the country through the port of Aqaba; goods that do not meet this requirement are subject to a penalty of 20 per cent of the c.i.f. value (7 per cent for industrial raw materials and Brazilian coffee; foodstuffs, pharmaceuti- cals, and a few other items are exempt). The Council of Ministers may grant exemptions from these rules on a case-by-case basis upon special recommendation by the Ministries of National Economy and Transport. Bank guarantees in favor of the Ministry of Finance and Customs are required on most imports shipped through ports other than Aqaba, to ensure their importation into Jordan. Imports that require an import license also require an exchange permit which is granted automatically when an import license has been obtained; the importer holding an exchange permit may either open a letter of credit or pay against documents. A fee of YIO of 1 per cent is levied on exchange permits for imports, except those made by government departments and certain approved institutions. The use of suppliers' credit is subject to prior Central Bank approval, which nor- 281 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JORDAN mally is given for essential imports only. Most im- ported commodities are subject to an import du ty of 4 per cent of the c.& f. value, payable on the issue of the import license. Payments for Invisibles Remittances by postal order do not require exchange control approval, provided that they do not exceed JD 10 a person a mon th. W i th th is exception, all pay- ments for invisibles are subject to exchange control approva l. Paymen ts for the fo l low ing types of invisibles are generally permitted up to certain limits: income of nonresidents; savings of foreign na t iona ls who in tend to re tu rn to the ir own countries; remittances to refugee dependents; reasonable living expenses of Jordanian na t iona ls abroad; expenses of Jordanian residents trav- eling abroad; expenses for education; expenses for med- ical t rea tmen t; business expenses abroad; and insurance paymen ts in accordance w i th special regulations.4 The exchange allowance for travel to Arab countries (except Lebanon and the Syrian Arab Republic), Cy- prus, and Turkey is the equivalent of JD 100 a person a trip. The allowance for travel to other countries is the equivalent of JD 16 a person a day for business travel and JD 12 a person a day for other travel (half of these amoun ts for children under 15). These allowances are granted for trips of up to 30 days; each person may annua l ly make three business trips and two tourist trips to such other countries. For fam i ly suppor t, an annual allowance of between JD 600 and JD 1,200 for each donor is permitted; however, remittances by postal or- der may be made at a rate not exceeding JD 10 a mon th to any one person resident abroad and are not subject to the ceiling of JD 600-1,200. The policy in respect of payments for invisibles is, in general, liberal and non- discriminatory. In practice, the Central Bank does not restrict remittances of income accruing to nonresidents or of savings of foreign nationals re turn ing to their own coun try. In addition to any travel allocation, residents travel- ing abroad may take out up to JD 300 in any combina- tion of Jordanian and foreign notes and coins. Furthermore, all travelers may take out checks, travel- ers checks, or letters of credit issued by authorized banks in Jordan in accordance with exchange permits authorized by the Central Bank. Tourists and other nonresidents may also take out foreign currency notes and coins and any other foreign means of payment that they had previously brought in and declared upon en- try. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Ex- port proceeds exceeding JD 50 must be collected and the foreign exchange surrendered w i th in six mon ths of shipment. Exempt are the proceeds from perishable vegetables and f ru i ts. 282 Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to an authorized bank or, if banknotes are received, to an authorized exchange dealer. Travelers entering Jordan may bring in any amount in Jordanian and foreign notes and coins.5 Any person regarded for exchange control purposes as resident in Jordan may be required by the Central Bank to surrender to an autho- rized bank any foreign currency at his disposal. Capital Capital may be imported freely, but exports of capi- tal require approval and are not normally allowed ex- cept under special conditions. Current income resulting from nonresident investments in Jordan may be trans- ferred abroad. Under the Law for the Encouragement of Inves tmen t, which took effect on October 16, 1972, prof i ts f rom approved foreign investments may be re- m i t ted, w i thout l im i ta t ion, in the currency of the origi- nal investment or in any other convertible currency approved by the Central Bank. Af ter two years, repatri- ation of the capital is permitted in three equal annual ins ta l lmen ts in the same foreign currency in which the original inves tment was made or in any other convert- ible currency approved by the Central Bank. The In- vestment Committee may approve more liberal provisions, and exchange permits are granted accord- ing ly. Gold The Central Bank has issued four gold coins under the Gold and Silver Coins Regulation No. 61 of 1968; these coins, although legal tender, do not circulate and are available only to nonresidents and domestic numis- matists. Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Jordan for num isma t ic or investment purposes. W i th this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not, in principle, allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewe lry, at home or abroad. Licenses for imports of gold in any form other than jewelry are issued by the M in is try of National Economy on the recommendation of the Central Bank, while exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require a license from the Central Bank. Licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the mone tary authorities and industrial users. Changes during 1974 January 1. Not for Redistribution KENYA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.103133 gram of fine gold per Kenya Shilling. A central rate of K Sh 7.14286 = US$1 has been established, and Kenya avails itself of wider margins. The Central Bank of Kenya deals with the Government and with authorized banks in Tanza- nia shillings and Uganda shillings against Kenya shil- lings at par; the authorized banks also deal with the public in these currencies at par.1 In transactions with authorized banks, the Central Bank of Kenya stands ready to issue Kenya shillings in exchange for U.S. dollars and to supply U.S. dollars in exchange for Ke- nya shillings; its buying and selling rates are K Sh 7.1384 and K Sh 7.1450 per US$1. The Central Bank deals with the Government and commercial banks, on the basis of the daily closing rates in New York, in deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs, and, at corresponding rates, in Burundi francs and Zambian kwacha. The Central Bank does not deal in other foreign currencies,2 except occasionally on behalf of the Government. The Central Bank deals up to six months forward in sterling and U.S. dollars with commercial banks, to cover their contracts with export- ers and importers; commercial banks may cover their forward exchange contracts in other foreign currencies against U.S. dollars or pounds sterling in outside mar- kets. Applications for foreign exchange allocation licenses for imports are subject to a charge of 1 per cent of the amount of the application. Administration of Control The Minister of Finance and Economic Planning has delegated the administration of exchange control to the Central Bank of Kenya. Authority for approving pay- ments for imports with an invoiced value of less than K Sh 2,000, many payments in respect of current invis- ibles, and some capital payments to countries other than Tanzania and Uganda is delegated to the autho- rized banks. Import and export controls are administered by the Director of Trade and Supplies in the Ministry of Com- merce and Industry. The responsibility for issuing im- port and export licenses rests with the Director, to whom applications must be submitted by the importer and exporter in Kenya before orders are placed abroad or exports are shipped. Applications for foreign ex- change allocation permits for imports also must be submitted to the Director of Trade and Supplies, who forwards these to the Central Bank; applications are screened by the Foreign Exchange Allocation Commit- tee, composed of representatives of the Central Bank, the Treasury, and the Director of Trade and Supplies. 284 Orders for imports of goods on open general license must be preregistered with the Central Bank before shipment. The government-owned Kenya National Trading Corporation, Ltd., has a monopoly over the import of specified commodities and the export of cer- tain agricultural commodities is controlled by State Marketing Boards. Together with Tanzania and Uganda, Kenya is part of the East African currency area. Payments from Ke- nya to Tanzania and Uganda are free of restrictions, but the export or import of Kenya banknotes is prohib- ited. Prescription of Currency Kenya has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Settlements with Tanzania and Uganda normally are effected in East African currency.3 Pay- ments to residents of countries other than Tanzania and Uganda (except Rhodesia and South Africa) may be made in Kenya shillings to the credit of an External Account in Kenya or in any foreign currency except Rhodesian currency. Receipts from countries other than Tanzania, Uganda, and Rhodesia may be ob- tained in Kenya shillings from an External Account in Kenya or in any marketable foreign currency. All pay- ments and transfers to Rhodesia are prohibited. Remit- tances to South Africa also are prohibited, with the exception of those of pensions payable by the Govern- ment of Kenya or by the East African Community organizations. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Kenya shillings held by residents of countries other than Tanzania, Uganda, or Rhodesia with authorized banks in Kenya are, with exchange control approval, designated External Accounts. They may be credited freely with authorized payments to such countries by residents of Kenya, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any currency (other than East African or Rhodesian currency) and gold by nonresidents to au- thorized dealers. External Accounts may be debited freely for payments to residents and nonresidents. Nontransferable funds of residents of countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are credited to Blocked Accounts. Subject to prescribed procedures, balances on Blocked Accounts (other than those in the beneficial ownership of residents of South Africa or Rhodesia) may be used for approved domestic expenditures and for the purchase in Kenya of specified bonds issued by the Kenyan Government or by local authorities and ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution officially quoted in Kenya;4 the redemption proceeds of these securities, which must have a life of five years at the time of acquisition, are transferable, and interest is freely transferable to nonresidents as and when it ac- crues. Imports and Import Payments Some imports from all sources are prohibited for reasons of public policy; imports of certain other goods are not being licensed. All imports from metropolitan Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. With certain exceptions, imports from Tanzania and Uganda are unrestricted, but many goods imported from these countries require a specific license unless they are of Tanzanian or Ugandan origin. Many goods may be freely imported from other sources under open general license, but others require a specific license. Certain items are imported only by the Kenya Na- tional Trading Corporation, Ltd. These include sugar, salt, rice, edible oils, fertilizers, blankets, and cotton piece goods. In addition to the open general import license, there are four commodity schedules for imports. With minor exceptions, all private sector imports of commodities in Schedules I, II, III, and IV from countries other than Tanzania and Uganda require a foreign exchange allo- cation license issued by the Central Bank; applications must be submitted before firm orders are placed. Im- ports of goods on open general license do not require an exchange allocation license but must be preregis- tered with the Central Bank before firm orders are placed. All goods in the first three schedules require a spe- cific import license from the Director of Trade and Supplies. Once the specific import license has been ob- tained, foreign exchange is granted freely for goods in Schedule I and on the basis of quotas reflecting past imports for goods in Schedule II. No foreign exchange is granted for Schedule III items. For items in Schedule IV, a specific import license is not required but foreign exchange is allocated on a quota basis. When an exchange allocation license has been ob- tained from the Central Bank or when such a license is not required, authorized banks are permitted to pro- vide exchange automatically, but not normally prior to customs entry. Prior exchange control approval must be obtained for imports of capital goods on deferred payment terms, and for imports of machinery and equipment when the value is required to be regarded as a contribution toward capital or to be accounted for on a loan basis. Most imports with a pro forma invoice value in ex- cess of K Sh 20,000 are also subject to preshipment inspection as to quality, quantity, and price by the General Superintendence Company acting for the Cen- tral Bank of Kenya. A "Clean Report of Findings" must be obtained before shipment, and authorized banks in Kenya may not issue shipping guarantees for KENYA the clearance of imports until this "Clean Report" has been received. The buying and confirming commission with respect to imports into Kenya may not exceed 3 per cent of the value of the import. The interest rate on suppliers' credit normally is limited to 11 per cent per annum. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are controlled. Authorized banks are empowered to approve specified categories of current payments without limitation or up to estab- lished limits; amounts above these limits as well as other current payments may be approved administra- tively, and most current payments are in fact unre- stricted. Fees for education up to the equivalent of K Sh 14,000 a person for a full scholastic year and fees for other specified purposes may be approved by an authorized bank upon production of evidence of debt. Facilities exist whereby nationals of countries other than Tanzania and Uganda who come to work in Ke- nya as employed persons (as well as certain categories of the self-employed, such as doctors and dentists) for not more than four years may remit abroad as savings up to 33V3 per cent of their monthly salaries but not more than K Sh 3,000 a month; in addition, they may remit funds to cover maintenance, education expenses, etc., provided that their total remittances including sav- ings do not exceed 50 per cent of their monthly salaries. Expatriates who have stayed for over four years in the Scheduled Territories5 may continue to effect remit- tances from salaries as above, but those who avail themselves of the facilities for remittance of savings from salaries are not entitled to exchange facilities upon emigration. Remittances to South Africa, other than those of certain pensions, are prohibited. Nonresident individual property owners may remit up to K Sh 20,000 of net rental income in each 12-month period. Any excess of net rent over the per- mitted transfer is placed in a Blocked Account and may be invested in approved securities with at least five years to maturity, after which period the redemption proceeds may be remitted to the nonresident benefi- ciary. Real estate companies deriving income solely from rent are permitted to transfer annually up to 10 per cent of the book value of their properties as at September 25, 1970, or an amount not exceeding 10 per cent of issued capital. Where income is derived from rent as well as other sources, the exchange control au- thorities must approve the remittance of such incomes. The basic allowance for travel outside the Scheduled Territories by adults holding round-trip tickets is K Sh 4,000 a person (K Sh 2,000 for children between 3 and 12 years of age) every two years, which may be taken out in foreign banknotes.6 Holders of one-way tickets are entitled to a basic travel allowance of K Sh 2,000 for adults and K Sh 1,000 for children. 285 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KENYA The basic allowance is not available for travel to Rho- desia or South Africa. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency notes up to the amount they brought in upon entry. Residents of Kenya traveling abroad on international flights and holding return tick- ets may carry up to K Sh 100 with them for local expenses on return, but otherwise the export of Kenya banknotes is prohibited. Exports and Export Proceeds Export transactions must be registered with the Cen- tral Bank. Exports of certain foodstuffs and agricul- tural products require licenses and may be subject to restriction in order to ensure sufficient supplies for con- sumption in Kenya. Exports of tea, certain minerals, precious stones, and strategic materials are also subject to licensing. Export licenses for some commodities are required only for destinations other than Tanzania or Uganda. Other goods may be exported without li- censes. Exports of coffee are made through the interme- diary of the Coffee Marketing Board. All exports to metropolitan Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Export proceeds in foreign currencies must be col- lected within six months of exportation7 and offered to an authorized bank in Kenya for conversion into Ke- nya shillings.8 Exports of manufactured goods to countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are eligible for special incentives. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in foreign currencies must be sold to an authorized bank. Travelers may bring in freely foreign currency notes. The import of domestic banknotes is prohibited, with the exception that resi- dents returning to Kenya may bring in up to K Sh 100 previously taken out by themselves. The import of East African shilling notes also is prohibited. Capital Capital transfers to all countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are restricted. Transfers to Rhodesia or South Africa are not allowed. With the exception of expatriate employees who have opted for remittance of savings from salaries, persons leaving Kenya perma- nently may transfer their assets up to the equivalent of K Sh 50,000 for each family unit if they take up resi- dence in a country outside the Scheduled Territories; they may additionally every 12 months thereafter, dur- ing a period of five years, apply for the release of K Sh 20,000 from their Blocked Accounts. All remain- ing funds must be credited to a Blocked Account; they may then be invested in approved securities, and re- demption proceeds become transferable, provided that redemption does not take place earlier than five years from the date of purchase. If an emigrating or repatriat- ing person's assets in Kenya are valued at K Sh 1 mil- 286 lion or more, the total assets must be liquidated before any exchange control approvals are sought and the proceeds must be invested in prescribed securities. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Kenya, but to ensure eventual repatriation it is necessary to obtain from the Treasury a "certificate of approved enterprise" for the investment. Foreign and domestic investment in specified types of production requires approval under the East African Licensing Or- dinance. Local borrowing by nonresident-owned or nonresident-controlled companies requires exchange control approval and is restricted. The same is true of borrowing by residents from nonresidents. Except in respect of Tanzania and Uganda, all im- ports and exports of securities require approval. Ap- proval is freely granted for the purchase by nonresidents of Kenyan securities on a recognized stock exchange, provided that payment is received in an appropriate manner. The income from such securities is remittable, but the proceeds on resale must normally be credited to a Blocked Account. Purchases of securities outside Tanzania and Uganda by residents are not nor- mally permitted. A resident of Kenya may not send as a cash gift to a country other than Tanzania or Uganda more than K Sh 200 a year without specific exchange control approval. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Kenya for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require exchange control approval. The import of the following from all sources other than Tanzania and Uganda, and from Tanzania and Uganda when origi- nating in other countries, is subject to individual licens- ing: jewelry of gold, silver, or platinum; goldsmiths' or silversmiths' wares, including set gems; bullion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coins. Imports of gold jewelry require specific import licenses as Schedule III items and no foreign exchange is allocated for them; import licenses for gold bullion (ingots, bars, or sheets) are issued to goldsmiths only and are issued restric- tively, while imports of gold coins are not being li- censed. Changes during 1974 January 11. The Local Manufacturers (Export Com- pensation) Act, 1974 was gazetted. It provided for ex- port subsidies on exports of selected manufactures to countries other than Tanzania and Uganda. The rate of compensation payment was 10 per cent of the f.o.b. value of goods declared for payment or of the payment in respect of such exports received in foreign currency (other than Tanzania or Uganda currency) by an autho- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution rized dealer, whichever was less. Assent was given on June 12, 1974 and the Act came into operation on the same day. January 14. The central rate was changed from K Sh 6.90000 = US$1 to K Sh 7.14286 = US$1, equivalent as previously to 0.103133 gram of fine gold per Kenya shilling and corresponding to K Sh 8.61675 = SDR 1. Kenya continued to avail itself of wider margins. The relationship to the Tanzania shilling and the Uganda shilling remained unchanged. New buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were set at K Sh 7.1407 and K Sh 7.1471, respectively, per US$1. February 4. Exports of maize were prohibited. February 4. Exchange Control Circular No. 2 re- quired persons arriving in Kenya by air or sea, with the exception of residents returning from Uganda or Tan- zania, to declare all foreign currency in their possession; on departure, they could only'reconvert Kenya shil- lings upon showing that they were obtained from docu- mented conversion of the registered foreign currency. February 8. The Central Bank henceforth advised authorized dealers daily of the rates applicable to its transactions with authorized dealers in Burundi francs, deutsche mark, commercial and financial French francs, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, U.S. dollars, and Zambian kwa- cha. (Previously, the Central Bank did not normally deal in currencies other than deutsche mark, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars.) Banks could make their own quotations to customers, but the spread between buy- ing and selling rates for telegraphic transfers was not allowed to exceed 7/8 per cent; they were encouraged to deal within the spread determined by the quoted mar- gins but could not exceed them. Circular No. 29 /1971 was canceled. March 18. Exports of meat and cereals were prohib- ited. April 18. Circular No. 3/1974 revised Exchange Con- trol Notices Nos. 20 and 28 concerning securities and emigration treatment, respectively. Emigrants with to- tal assets exceeding in value K Sh 1 million were now required to liquidate all their assets before applying for emigration treatment, and prior to any release these funds had to be held in the form of prescribed securi- ties. The new notice on securities specified that blocked funds could not be invested in government securities or otherwise utilized without specific exchange control ap- proval and that companies directly or indirectly con- trolled by nonresidents required exchange control approval to acquire shares of Kenyan companies in ways other than through the Nairobi stock exchange. June 5. Import controls were tightened by Circular No. 4/1974. The four import lists were altered as fol- lows: Schedule I, containing items subject to specific import licensing but for which foreign exchange is freely granted once a license has been issued, was re- duced in coverage; Schedule II, containing items sub- ject to specific licensing and for which foreign exchange is provided on a quota basis, was increased in coverage; KENYA Schedule III, containing items prohibited from import, was increased in coverage; and Schedule IV, containing items not subject to specific import licensing but for which exchange is provided on a quota basis, was in- creased in coverage (previously it consisted of only one item—passenger automobiles). Items previously under open general license which were shifted to Schedule IV included tobacco, jute, woolen fabrics, certain cotton fabrics, agricultural tractors, buses, trucks, and news- papers and periodicals. June 12. Import duties on certain foodstuffs were reduced. The sales tax on radios, tape recorders, pas- senger automobiles, refrigerators and other domestic appliances, alcoholic beverages, and certain other con- sumer goods was increased from 10 per cent to 15 per cent. Withholding tax on dividends payable to nonresi- dents was raised from 12 per cent to 15 per cent. June 12. Nonresident travelers in Kenya were re- quired to pay hotel bills and domestic tour bills with foreign exchange. June 12. Foreign-controlled companies henceforth normally were to restrict their local borrowing to 20 per cent of their issued capital. June 19. Circular No. 6 /1974 raised the maximum allowable interest rate on foreign loans (including sup- pliers' credit) from 9 per cent to 11 per cent per annum. Commission charges payable to foreign suppliers (in- cluding buying and confirming commission on im- ported goods) continued to be limited to 3 per cent of the value of the goods. July 26. Circular No. 9/1974 established a charge, to be collected by the Central Bank with effect from Au- gust 1, of 1 per cent of the c.i.f. amount of each applica- tion for foreign exchange allocation licenses for imports. Exempt were imports not involving the provi- sion of foreign exchange from Kenya at any time. September 17. Circular No. 10/1974 provided that approval for the remittance of interim dividends or any profits by nonresident-controlled firms would no longer be given prior to the completion of the annual audit of the company concerned. November 4. Imports of paper other than newsprint, tissue, and coated paper were prohibited. November 6. Circular No. 11/1974 revoked the 11 per cent ceiling on the interest rate on foreign borrow- ing; applications for exchange control approval for for- eign borrowing would be considered on their merits, provided that the rate of interest to be charged was in line with published rates in the appropriate market. However, the maximum interest rate of 11 per cent per annum on bills received for collection and the maxi- mum commission charge of 3 per cent of the value of imported goods payable to nonresident agents were retained. Circular No. 6/1974 was cancelled. November 7. The Central Bank withdrew the conces- sion under which emigrants who remitted savings had been permitted to export, in addition to the maximum emigration allowance set out in Circular 1 /1969, auto- mobiles or proceeds from the sale of automobiles which 287 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KENYA had been in their possession for a reasonable period. November 14. The general permissions in paragraphs 2(4) and 2(5) of Circular No. 2 9 / 73 allowing commer- cial banks to lend to foreign-controlled companies up to specified limits, were withdrawn by Circular No. 12/1974, except for companies wholly or mainly oper- ating in agricultural production, manufacturing, export business, or tourism. The Central Bank would review the facilities of affected companies already enjoying local borrowing facilities. The new instructions did not affect companies whose proportion of equity held di- rectly or indirectly in the beneficial ownership of non- residents did not exceed 15 per cent. November 14. The Central Bank instructed foreign- owned companies not to remit interim or final divi- dends to nonresident shareholders until the companies had liquidated their local borrowings. There was no intention, however, to limit remittances of prof i ts and dividends as such. December 9. Circular No. 16/1974 consolidated in Notice No. 19 the current instructions on borrowing by nonresident-controlled companies. Circulars Nos. 29 /1973 and 12/1974 were canceled. All exchange con- trol authorities granted before July 10, 1974 for bor- rowing in excess of the limits set out in paragraph 2 of the new Notice No. 19 were now obsolete or would become obsolete on or before January 10, 1975. Ap- provals dated July 10, 1974 or later for companies wholly or mainly operating in agricultural production, manufac tur ing, export business, and tourism were valid un t il the dates stated therein. Credit facilities granted w i th in the limits of paragraph 2 of the previous Notice No. 19 could be continued if the borrowers were in one of these four classes. Facilities granted to other nonresi- dent-controlled companies had to be reviewed upon expiration or by December 31, 1974, whichever was earlier. Applications for approval or renewal of facili- ties not within the authority delegated by the new No- tice No. 19 were to be accompanied by a specific program for reduction and eventual elimination of local borrowing. December 11. With effect from January 1, 1975, Cir- cular No. 15 /1974 reduced the period w i th in which payments for exports have to be obtained from six mon ths to three mon ths af ter shipment.
