Not for Redistribution KHMER REPUBLIC (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System No par value for the currency of the Khmer Repub- lic, the Kiel, has been agreed with the Fund. There are three exchange markets, the "new exchange market," the "CIP exchange market," and the free market. The selling rates for the U.S. dollar in these markets on December 31, 1974 were KR 1,650-1,680 (a range of rates for different importers); KR 1,320 (KR 1,565 for imports from "Code 941 countries");1 and KR 1,650-1,670, respectively, per US$1. The principal transactions eligible for each market are as follows. In principle, all imports not on a negative list are settled in the "new exchange market" unless they may be paid for in the "CIP exchange market." Imports eligible for settlement in the latter market are goods covered by the U.S. Commodity Import Program and procured di- rectly in the United States; when the same goods are procured in "Code 941 countries," they are settled in the same market but at a different exchange rate. Ex- port proceeds and receipts from tourism, other invisi- bles, and inward capital transfers must be sold in the free market. In principle, all financial transactions must take place in the free market. Outward payments chan- neled through the free market are mainly those relating to (1) the import of specified commodities (only com- modities eligible for the "new exchange market" may be paid for in the free market);2 (2) all noncommercial expenditures abroad of the Khmer Government; (3) student expenses and expenses of medical treatment abroad; and (4) services rendered by foreign sources. Subject to prior approval by the National Exchange Office, outward capital transfers may also be settled in the free market. Participation in the exchange markets is limited to authorized commercial banks which buy and sell for- eign exchange in transactions with the National Bank; they act on behalf of customers only and are not al- lowed to maintain foreign exchange balances for trade purposes, except as these may arise in connection with their normal operations. Foreign exchange transactions of the Government and its departments and agencies are subject to the same conditions as transactions of the private sector, but are generally channeled through the National Bank. The National Bank of Cambodia maintains official quotations for 13 currencies.3 These quotations all pro- vide for a spread of 0.4 per cent between the buying and selling rate expressed in riels. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the National Exchange Office, an autonomous agency within the National Bank; this office is empowered to authorize all operations related to settlements with foreign countries, to foreign investments, and to nonresident accounts. The Ministry of Commerce is in charge of the administration of import and export controls. The Ex- change Support Fund, an independent unit within the National Bank, reimburses the latter for foreign ex- change sold for most general imports and for freight and insurance on imports provided under U.S. P.L. 480. Prescription of Currency Settlements with five countries with which the Khmer Republic has bilateral payments arrangements are made through bilateral accounts. Those maintained for Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, and the U.S.S.R. are denominated in pounds sterling, and those for Bulgaria and Poland in U.S. dollars. Set- tlements with other countries take place in convertible currencies. Foreign investments must be made in a currency acceptable to the National Bank. Profits on and pro- ceeds from the liquidation of foreign investments may be transferred abroad in the currency in which the in- vestment was made. Nonresident Accounts The following categories of account may be main- tained for nonresidents: Foreigners' Accounts in Riels, Capital Accounts, Nonresident Accounts, and Foreign Currency Accounts. In addition, Khmer nationals staying abroad temporarily but not recognized as non- residents, and foreigners staying in the Khmer Repub- lic but not recognized as residents, may maintain Internal Accounts of Nonresidents. There are separate regulations concerning nonresident accounts that may be used to finance transactions in the free trade area of Kompong-Som. Foreigners'Accounts in Riels may be opened, without permission, for foreigners residing outside the Khmer Republic. They are related to the country of residence of the account holder. They may be freely credited with (1) proceeds from the sale on the Phnom Penh exchange market of the currency (but not banknotes) of the coun- try of the account holder; (2) payments for authorized imports (including incidental expenses) from the coun- try of the account holder; (3) earnings on investments in the Khmer Republic and receipts from repayments on Khmer stocks and bonds and on other investments made in the Khmer Republic after May 1956; and (4) interest paid by the banks on funds kept in the ac- counts. These accounts may be freely debited for nor- mal expenses in the Khmer Republic and, provided that it is quoted on the Phnom Penh market, for pur- chases of the currency of the country of the account holder (except in the form of banknotes). Transfers 289 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KHMER REPUBLIC between Foreigners' Accounts in Riels related to the same country may be made freely. Capital Accounts may be opened without permission. Subject to authorization, these accounts may be cred- ited with (1) proceeds from the sale in the Khmer Re- public of Khmer stocks and bonds; (2) proceeds from the sale in the Khmer Republic of participations in corporations other than by purchases of stocks and bonds; (3) contractual or advance repayments of Khmer stocks and bonds; (4) proceeds from the sale through an authorized notary of real estate or busi- nesses located in the Khmer Republic and in the pos- session of a nonresident since before January 1, 1955 or acquired by him at a later date either through inheri- tance or with the permission of the National Exchange Office; (5) repayment of loans granted to residents prior to January 1, 1955, or after that date with the approval of the National Exchange Office; and (6) transfers from another capital account related to the country of the account holder. Capital Accounts may be freely debited for (1) living expenses of the account holder or his family up to KR 1,000 a person a day, and up to a maximum of KR 50,000 mon th ly, and (2) expenses connected with the administration of foreign assets in the Khmer Re- public (stocks and bonds, buildings, land, etc.). Subject to authorization from the National Exchange Office, these accounts may be debited for (1) purchases in the Khmer Republic of Khmer stocks and bonds; (2) sub- scriptions to, or increases in the capital of, a Khmer firm; (3) purchases through an authorized notary of title to real estate or businesses located in the Khmer Republic; (4) loans in riels to residents; (5) transfers to another capital account related to the country of the account holder; (6) living expenses in the Khmer Re- public of the account holder's employees if the account is held by a firm (corporation, bank, etc.); and (7) gifts to individuals and to social, cultural, and religious asso- ciations. Nonresident Accounts may be opened only upon au- thorization. They may be freely debited for (1) taxes in the Khmer Republic, (2) miscellaneous accounting, correspondence expenses, etc., and (3) living expenses in the Khmer Republic of the account holder and his fam i ly. They may be freely credited with the proceeds from foreign currency sold on the Phnom Penh market and with interest on funds held in the account con- cerned. All other operations through these accounts are subject to individual licensing. Foreign Currency Accounts may be opened only upon authorization. They may be freely credited with foreign exchange transferred from abroad. Account holders may use balances on these accounts (1) to cover ex- penses abroad, such as those related to travel, missions, and the purchase of foreign merchandise, and (2) to cover expenses of any kind in the Khmer Republic by converting balances on these accounts in to riels on the Phnom Penh exchange market. 290 Internal Accounts of Nonresidents may be opened only upon authorization. Balances on these accounts may not be used for transfers abroad. The accounts may be freely credited with (1) proceeds from the sale of foreign exchange on the Phnom Penh market; (2) transfers from Foreigners' Accounts in Riels; (3) wages, salaries, allowances, and payments for expenses of Khmer nationals employed by Khmer firms and temporarily residing abroad; (4) income earned in the Khmer Republic by account holders; (5) redeposits of previous withdrawals; and (6) repayment of loans granted to residents out of balances in such accounts. The accounts may be freely debited for (1) living ex- penses in the Khmer Republic of the account holder or his family, (2) administrative expenses related to the account holder's property in the Khmer Republic, and (3) loans to residents. All other operations through these accounts require authorization. There are separate regulations for resident-held for- eign currency accounts. Imports and Import Payments The import of certain commodities is prohibited for reasons of health or security and that of certain other goods for protective reasons. In view of the availability of commercial aid resources, several important import commodities have been placed on an "exclusive list"; their importation is permitted only against commodity aid financing, unless a waiver is granted. The list in- cludes tobacco leaves, cotton fibers, certain vegetable oils, wheat flour, and cotton thread under the U.S. P.L. 480 program, and some foodstuffs, rubber and rubber products, petroleum, chemicals, timber and paper products, iron and steel, metals, cars and trucks, and U.S. equipment in general, under the U.S. CIP. For all other permissible imports, including those eligible for CIP financing that are not on the "exclusive list," cash foreign exchange resources may be provided under li- censes granted ad hoc; they are referred to as general imports. There are also a "restrictive list," comprising commodities for which foreign exchange is not nor- mally made available, and separate lists specifying the goods eligible for settlement in the "new exchange mar- ket" and the "CIP market," respectively. Specified imports may be made freely when no pur- chase of foreign exchange is involved (sans devises) and the goods are not intended for resale, and provided that the goods are eligible either for the "new exchange market" or the "CIP exchange market." All imports financed by foreign exchange purchased in the exchange market must be settled against irrevo- cable letters of credit opened by the commercial banks. Importers are required to submit their requests for pur- chases of foreign exchange to the commercial banks, accompanied by the payment of a deposit in riels; the deposit requirement is varied from time to time and is d ifferent for CIP imports and other imports. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Each importer is required to obtain an import busi- ness license. Importers are permitted to trade with for- eign countries only if they have assumed corporate status (societes anonymes). The equity capital of such corporations should be at least KR 5 million; 51 per cent of the equity should be held by Khmer nationals and one third of board membership should be Khmer. Upon completion of the import transaction, import- ers are required to submit proof that the foreign ex- change has actually been used to finance imports, and that the goods have arrived and have been cleared through customs with full payment of import duty and other levies. Payments for Invisibles Foreign exchange for freight and insurance for im- ports under U.S. P.L. 480 is normally eligible for fi- nancing by the CIP. All other payments for invisibles require individual authorization, and only those trans- actions explicitly mentioned in the exchange control regulations are permitted. In principle, the exchange allocations granted are those set out below, but at the end of 1974 several of these were inoperative. A foreigner working in the Khmer Republic and receiving a monthly salary exceeding KR 5,000 in Phnom Penh, or KR 3,500 in the provinces, may in principle transfer up to 30 per cent of his net monthly salary —after payment of taxes—plus 15 per cent of his monthly salary if a dependent wife stays abroad, plus an additional 10 per cent if dependent children, par- ents, or grandparents stay abroad. (The additional per- centage of transferable income is 2 per cent for each legitimate child or dependent parent or grandparent, with a maximum of 10 per cent of the net monthly income for each family.) Such transfers may not exceed the equivalent of KR 20,000 a worker a month. Trans- fer facilities are not granted for salaries and wages ex- empt from income tax. Overtime pay is considered transferable income only when it is received in payment for courses given in public educational institutions. Women of foreign nationality married to Khmer na- tionals and working in the private sector are not per- mitted to transfer savings from salaries or wages to their country of origin. Foreign landlords domiciled in the Khmer Republic may transfer up to 30 per cent of the taxable portion of their income from rent, provided that the rent ex- ceeds KR 5,000 for landlords living in Phnom Penh or KR 3,500 for landlords living in the provinces. Foreign landlords living abroad may transfer up to 20 per cent of the taxable portion of rent. Foreigners residing in the Khmer Republic, when leaving the country permanently, are permitted to transfer abroad, up to prescribed limits, savings out of their salaries earned in the Khmer Republic, provided that the savings have been regularly deposited with an authorized bank in the Khmer Republic. KHMER REPUBLIC The transfer of the full net profits from nonresident investments made prior to May 31, 1956 is authorized, subject to proof that the investment was made with foreign currency other than the former Indo-Chinese piastre; otherwise, the transfer of profits on pre-1956 investments is limited to 80 per cent and is permitted only if the investment is recognized as useful to the economic development of the Khmer Republic. Net profits that do not exceed 20 per cent of foreign investments made after May 31, 1956 may be trans- ferred annually. Khmer nationals studying abroad may receive monthly exchange allocations equivalent to up to US$108 for Asian countries and up to US$126 for any other country, in addition to installation, holiday, and clothing allowances. The allocation of foreign exchange for tourist travel and business travel has been sus- pended. The export of Khmer currency is prohibited and for- eign tourists require special authorization to reconvert riels into foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports are classified into three groups: a prohibited list, a licensing list, and a free list. Prohibited exports comprise mainly goods whose exports have been banned for social and political reasons, while the pur- pose of the licensing list is to avoid shortages of supplies needed for domestic use. The exportation of rubber and precious and semiprecious stones is a state monopoly and is effected through SONEXIM. The expor- tation of rice also is a state monopoly. All other com- modities except gold may be freely exported, provided that the transactions are arranged through a commer- cial bank, which must issue an export certificate for each shipment and must surrender the export proceeds to the National Bank. A Committee on Export Price Quotations sets weekly minimum export prices. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered. Ap- proved hotels, airlines, and other organizations autho- rized to receive payment in foreign exchange are required to keep adequate records of such transactions and to surrender all receipts to the commercial banks at least once weekly. Foreign visitors are required to settle their hotel bills in foreign currency or provide evidence that local currency was acquired by selling foreign exchange to an authorized bank. The import of Khmer currency is prohibited. Capital All capital transfers require individual licenses. No transfer abroad of proceeds from the sale of property by a foreigner to a foreigner is permitted. Foreigners who sell their property to Khmer nationals and leave the Khmer Republic permanently may transfer initially 291 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KHMER REPUBLIC up to 20 per cent of the proceeds of the sale; up to 20 per cent of the remainder may be authorized for trans- fer annually, when the total amount involved is small. Funds representing the repayment of loans originally granted in foreign currency may be considered transfer- able income. Since May 31, 1956, all foreign investments have been subject to authorization from the Ministry of Fi- nance, which requires that a certain percentage of the capital of an enterprise should be reserved for Khmer participation and that its employees should be Khmer nationals. Only investments for the creation of activi- ties recognized as useful to the economic development of the country and not involving monopoly or special privilege may be authorized. Proceeds from the liquida- tion of authorized investments made after May 31, 1956 may be transferred in yearly installments not ex- ceeding 20 per cent of the total investment. Up to 10 per cent of the proceeds from the liquidation of invest- ment made prior to May 31, 1956 may be authorized for transfer every year. Foreign capital invested after May 31, 1956 is guar- anteed the same tax treatment that is applied to resi- dent investments; in addition, special incentives (partial exemption from duties and taxes on reinvested profits and on equipment goods or raw materials imported during the first year of operation) may be accorded to foreign investment considered as exceptionally useful to the Khmer economy. There is a guarantee of 10-30 years against risks of nationalization or expropriation, and for a just and equitable indemnity in the event of nationalization or expropriation of investments. Gold Residents may freely acquire, hold, and sell gold in the Khmer Republic. Residents other than the mone- tary authorities, SONEXIM, and authorized industrial us- ers are not allowed to hold or acquire abroad gold in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require authoriza- tion by the National Bank; such authorization is not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and SONEXIM. Changes during 1974 January 3. The basic exchange rate in the "new ex- change market" was depreciated from KR 302 to KR 375 per US$1, selling, and the preferential ex- change rate for imports under the U.S. CIP from KR 257 to KR 302 per US$1. These rates were subse- quently modified on several occasions. March 28. The amount in riels that importers under the CIP had to deposit with SONEXIM at the time the import certificate was granted was increased from 10 per cent to 100 per cent of the c.i.f. value, except for sugar and petroleum products. May 14. Restrictions were imposed on the import of a large number of commodities deemed nonessential, 292 following the shifting to the "new exchange market" of a substantial volume of imports previously financed exclusively with CIP aid funds. May 14. The amount per shipment up to which gen- eral imports could be made freely on a sans de vises basis was increased from US$1,000 to US$2,000. This ceiling was removed in November, when imports on this basis were limited to raw materials, capital equipment, and spare parts for industrial or agricultural use. May 24. Payments for a further group of commodi- ties previously financed at the preferential rate under the CIP were shifted to the "new exchange market"; among these items were sugar, coffee, tea, textiles, and fertilizers. Freight payments on U.S. P.L. 480 ship- ments also were shifted from the preferential rate to the "new exchange market." A commission was set up in the Ministry of Commerce to screen applications for CIP imports. August. The requirement of a supplementary deposit on imports was abolished. September 18. Notices Nos. 113, 114, and 115 of the National Exchange Office were signed and came into effect. A three-tier exchange market was established by the creation of a "free exchange market" (marche libre des changes), where the exchange rate would fluctuate according to supply and demand. It was announced that a list of imports to be financed in the free market would be published by the Ministry of Commerce. In principle, all financial transactions were to take place in the free market instead of the "new exchange mar- ket"; in addition, all sales of private foreign exchange by residents and nonresidents (including export pro- ceeds) had to be made in the free market. Access to this market for outward transfers would be restricted, nota- bly with respect to capital transfers. The regulations governing the operation of the "new exchange market" were modified, particularly with respect to the fixing of exchange rates and the validity of import certificates; the latter were now valid for three months following the date they were domiciled with the authorized interme- diaries, and the operation of the "new exchange mar- ket" was placed on an auction basis, subject to a floor rate (with the possibility that individual transactions took place at various exchange rates at and above this floor rate). A "CIP exchange market" was formally established to handle spot transactions in U.S. dollars for pay- ments in respect of imports eligible for financing under U.S. aid. Importers could have access to this market only through SONEXIM. As part of the exchange reform measures, import duties, export duties, turnover tax, and the "war effort tax" were removed from a wide range of commodities. September 19. The exchange rate in the "new ex- change market" was depreciated from KR 420 per US$1 to an initial floor rate of KR 1,100 per US$1; the exchange rate in the free market was initially set at KR 1,204 per US$1, and the CIP exchange rate was depreciated from KR 336 per US$1 to KR 915 per ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution US$1. The previous effective exchange rate of KR 55 per US$1 applicable to government transfers to Khmer diplomatic, consular, and religious missions abroad and to transfers by students for the purchase of text- books was abolished. September 19. Residents were freely permitted to ac- quire, hold, and sell gold and articles of gold in the Khmer Republic. The restrictions on the import and export of gold were maintained. September 19. Export licenses ceased to be required for most commodities other than rubber. The export prohibition on rice and rice products and on scrap iron was maintained. October 1. Procedures for the purchase of commodi- ties under the CIP were revised by Communique No. 125 of the Permanent Committee on Commercial Aid in the Ministry of Commerce. In addition, a list was issued of imports eligible for financing in the "CIP exchange market." November 2. The Ministry of Commerce issued a new and more extensive list of products the import of which KHMER REPUBLIC was prohibited when financed in the "new exchange market." The list replaced the one issued on May 13. December 5. Agreement was reached that the Ex- change Support Fund would be continued into 1975. December 13. A change was made in the quotation procedures for exchange rates. The minimum rate (cours minimum retenii) in the "new exchange market" was used as the buying rate in the free market. December. Further restrictions were placed on sales of official exchange for imports. All imports deemed nonessential were excluded from official financing and quotas were imposed on imports of essentials payable through the "new exchange market." Not for Redistribution KOREA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Korean Won has been estab- lished with the Fund. The exchange rate in the ex- change certificate market is maintained around W 484 per US$1. On December 31, 1974 the buy ing and sell- ing rates of the Bank of Korea for the U.S. dollar were W 483.40 and W 484.60, respectively, and the tele- graphic transfer buying and selling rates of the foreign exchange banks were W 483 and W 485, respectively. Exchange certificates valid for 30 days are issued by the foreign exchange banks against all foreign exchange earnings in prescribed currencies surrendered by resi- dents. All foreign exchange proceeds, however, may alternatively be exchanged for won at the buying rate posted by the foreign exchange banks. Exchange certifi- cates may be changed in to equivalent foreign means of payment. There is a limited forward exchange market restricted to exporters covering their export earnings; the foreign exchange banks may in turn cover their forward transactions with exporters by engaging in such transactions abroad. Administration of Control The Ministry of Finance is in charge of exchange control. It carries out policy with respect to prescrip- tion of currency and method of settlement, foreign ex- change operations, payments for nonmerchandise transactions, and capital transactions and transfers. The Bank of Korea, as the Government's agent, exe- cutes the above func t ions in large part; it regulates operations in the certificate market and is authorized to intervene in it. The Bank has also been delegated au- thority to control payments related to invisibles. The foreign exchange banks, as well as the branch offices in Korea of foreign banks, are authorized to engage in commercial international banking and in foreign ex- change dealings. The trade program for imports financed from Ko- rea's own foreign exchange resources (KFX) is pre- pared by the Ministry of Commerce and Indus try. Imports financed by foreign loans are programmed sep- arately by the Economic Planning Board in consulta- tion with the Ministry of Commerce and Indus try. Import licenses are issued by the foreign exchange banks. Prescription of Currency All settlements between Korea and other countries are made in convertible currencies. The proceeds of exports must be obtained in prescribed currencies.1 The methods of payment on account of other settlements require the approval of the Ministry of Finance. 294 Nonresident Accounts Nonresident and Korean workers abroad may main- tain foreign currency deposit accounts with foreign ex- change banks. Remittances from such accounts and withdrawals in the form of currency notes upon depar- ture from Korea may, in general, be made freely. The approval of the bank where the account is held is re- quired for remittances from balances that have accrued from remuneration for services in Korea, air or ship passage fares, or insurance premiums received in Ko- rea, or from exchange deposited in accordance with a decision of the Ministry of Finance (except exchange registered at the customs on entry or remitted from abroad). The deposits may be disposed of by sale to a foreign exchange bank at the prevailing exchange rate, and they may be debited for salary payments to foreign employees. Foreign residents and nonresidents are per- mitted to hold time deposit accounts in prescribed cur- rencies with the foreign exchange banks. Certain residents of Korean nationality, such as the airline and some insurance companies, as well as enter- prises in which foreign capital is invested, may maintain demand deposit accounts in foreign currencies with the foreign exchange banks. Companies registered to oper- ate in the Masan Free Export Zone also may maintain demand deposit accounts in foreign currencies with the foreign exchange bank within the zone. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. All imports require licenses; for certain imports (see below) licenses are issued upon application. No licenses are issued for any goods originating in the People's Republic of China, Cuba, North Korea, or North Viet-Nam and for certain imports from all other countries. Imports are divided into three categories: those paid for with Korean foreign exchange (so-called KFX im- ports), those paid for with foreign loan funds, and those financed by Japanese reparations (PAC imports). KFX imports are classified as automatic approval, restricted, or prohibited items. All commodities may be imported freely (i.e., applications for import licenses are auto- matically approved) unless they are in a list of restricted or prohibited commodities. Automatic approval items (on December 31, 1974 these were 678 out of 1,312 basic items in the SITC classification) consist mainly of essential consumer goods not domestically produced and certain raw materials and capital goods. Restricted items (563) in a negative list are subject to individual licenses. Prohibited items (71) are mainly luxury goods, items prohibited for reasons of public health or morals, and some domestically produced goods. Imports of raw materials for the production of exports are normally ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution approved automatically, irrespective of their classifica- tion. Import licenses are granted only to registered trad- ers; to maintain the status of a registered trader, a minimum value of US$300,000 of exports is required each year for ordinary exporters. The commercial terms of payment on which imports may be contracted are regulated, and advance import deposits are required for most categories of imports by the private sector; these are met, for KFX imports, by deposit of exchange certificates and/or local currency at the time of applying for import licenses (or, for raw materials for export production, when the letter of credit is opened).2 The exchange certificate deposits are, in effect, advance payments offset against the im- port settlement; the won equivalent of any amount of deposit in excess of the import settlement is repaid to the importer at the time of the release of the relative bill of lading. Imports with Japanese Property and Claims Funds (PAC imports) are subject to prior payments of part of the import settlement in exchange certificates. Advance deposits for KFX imports range between 5 per cent and 200 per cent according to the nature of the import and the commercial terms of payment (sight letter of credit, documents against acceptance (D/A), documents against payment (D/P), or bonded ware- house transaction (BWT) terms); however, there are certain exceptions. The customs tariff is a "flexible" tariff. Furthermore, the Government may alter import duty rates adminis- tratively by up to 50 percentage points. The Govern- ment also has authority to impose import surcharges of up to 30 per cent on all dutiable imports, but by the end of 1974 had not invoked this authority. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require individual li- censes. Payments for invisibles connected with foreign trade transactions and for certain other items, such as banking charges, insurance premiums, communication fees, and periodicals are licensed automatically. There are certain standard allocations for business travel. In addition, exporters are authorized to use exchange earnings up to US$3,000 a month for the expenses of their overseas branches; the authorization is US$6,000 a month if exports to the country concerned exceed US$5 million and US$10,000 a month if exports to the country concerned exceed US$50 million. All residents departing for travel abroad may purchase foreign ex- change up to the equivalent of US$65 a day;3 they may purchase an additional US$100 for each trip for extra expenses. Students studying abroad may receive a monthly living allowance of up to US$500.4 Foreign and Korean currency notes may not be exported with- out special permission. Nonresident foreigners need not register foreign exchange in specified currencies that they bring into Korea and, when departing, they may reconvert unused won notes into U.S. dollars up to KOREA US$200, subject to confirmation of the original sale of exchange (up to US$50 without such confirmation). Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to certain specified countries designated by the Government are prohibited, as are exports of certain goods (such as raw cotton, platinum ores, wood charcoal, pulp, and waste paper) to all other countries. Certain exports require individual licenses. All other exports may be made freely under an automatic ap- proval procedure. The export proceeds in foreign ex- change must either be surrendered to a foreign exchange bank at its posted customer rate or be ex- changed into equivalent foreign exchange certificates. Exporters are not permitted to retain their export pro- ceeds as foreign currency demand or time deposits with foreign exchange banks. Proceeds from Invisibles All proceeds derived from invisibles must either be sold to a foreign exchange bank or be exchanged for equivalent exchange certificates. Travelers may bring with them any amount of foreign exchange, but the import of Korean currency by travelers is restricted. Capital All capital remittances require approval. Foreign capital investment, loans from abroad, and imports of capital goods on a long-term basis can secure a guaran- tee of repayment and repatriation under the Foreign Capital Inducement Law. No limits are placed on the conversion and remittance of legitimate profits and div- idends, or on the repatriation of the original capital invested, but proposed remittances must be notified to the Economic Planning Board 90 days prior to the end of the fiscal year. Gold Certain commemorative gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may freely buy, hold, and sell gold in any form in Korea. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users; there have been no imports or exports since 1965. Domestically produced gold may be disposed of in the free market. The free market price at public gold auctions was about W 2,200 a gram at the end of 1974. Changes during 1974 January 1. The trade program for the first half of 1974 came into effect. Increased emphasis was placed on the timely procurement of needed raw materials. The breakdown of import items by category again was 683 automatic approval items, 556 restricted items, and 73 prohibited items. January 1. Imports of heavy trucks were suspended. January 4. Import duties on 24 items were reduced. January 14. Import duties on 45 items were reduced. Those on 17 luxury consumer items were increased. January 14. An amendment to the implementing de- cree issued under the Foreign Capital Inducement Law required firms with foreign capital participation to re- port their planned foreign remittances to the Economic Planning Board 90 days prior to the end of each fiscal year. January 17. The Ministry of Agriculture and For- estry prohibited exports of fertilizers during 1974. January 22. The Foreign Exchange Requirement Program for 1974 was announced. Unlike the 1973 program, which had emphasized advance repayment of foreign debts and relaxation of import restrictions, the new program aimed at maximizing foreign exchange receipts and minimizing current account payments. Its basic principles were (1) to balance the supply and demand for foreign exchange and strengthen the coun- try's external reserve position; (2) to increase the avail- ability of foreign currency loans to local importers; (3) to continue restrictions on the use of foreign exchange for such purposes as nonessential imports and nones- sential current invisibles; and (4) to operate the import guarantee deposit requirements (advance import de- posits) in a flexible manner. January 23. The Monetary Board raised the maxi- mum interest rate for banking institutions' export fi- nancing loans from 7 per cent to 9 per cent per annum and lowered the interest rate on their stockpiling loans for imports of raw materials from 10 per cent to 9 per cent per annum. The Board also reduced the discount rate on Bank of Korea loans for imports of raw materi- als for stockpiling from 6Y2 per cent to 3V2 per cent per annum. January 24. Many of the advance import deposit requirements were modified. The rates of deposit were lowered for raw materials for export processing and for some other items. January 31. The Bank of Korea introduced a floating interest rate system under which interest rates for all foreign currency loans granted by Korean banking in- stitutions would fluctuate in accordance with the aver- age six-month Euro-dollar interest rate during the preceding month, but not beyond a maximum (12 per cent) set by the Monetary Board. Previously, a fixed interest rate of 9Y2 per cent was applied. February 1. October 25. The Ministry of Finance announced cer- tain measures to centralize and conserve the national foreign exchange resources. The measures came into effect on October 26. Exporters' foreign currency de- mand deposits had to be closed, and the balances were to be sold immediately to the Bank of Korea. The foreign currency time deposits of both exporters and importers also had to be closed, and the balances were to be sold to the Bank of Korea on maturity. The validity period of foreign exchange certificates was shortened from 45 days to 30 days, and the issuing of such certificates for local won was prohibited. Foreign funds refinanced by foreign exchange banks could ei- ther be held on deposit with banks abroad or be sold to the Bank of Korea on a swap basis, with the right of repurchase. Other measures to conserve foreign ex- change would also be taken. October 26. The Ministry of Commerce and Indus- try announced the trade program for the first half of 1975, to take effect on January 1, 1975. It provided for tighter import restrictions on most goods other than such basic commodities as crude petroleum, cereals, raw materials for export processing, and essential capi- tal goods, but there would be some liberalization of items whose domestic counterparts could compete with foreign goods. Advance deposits for restricted items would be increased. On the import side, 11 items previ- ously banned would be shifted from the restricted or prohibited lists to the automatic approval category, while 21 items were to be shifted in the opposite direc- tion and 15 items ceased to require the recommenda- tion of the competent ministers. As a result, the number of items on the automatic approval list went up from 665 to 678, that of restricted items went down from 574 to 563, and prohibited items were reduced from 73 to 71. On the export side, the number of prohibited items was unchanged at 23, the number of restricted items was increased from 255 to 263, and the number of automatic approval items was reduced from 1,034 to 1,026. Not for Redistribution KUWAIT (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Ku- waiti Dinar, corresponding to KD 1 = US$3.37778, and Kuwait avails itself of wider margins. The Central Bank of Kuwait quotes daily buying and selling rates for sterling and U.S. dollars; on December 31, 1974, these were KD 0.67893 buying, and KD 0.67977 sell- ing, respectively, for sterling, and KD 0.28946 buying, and KD 0.28982 selling, respectively, for U.S. dollars. On April 5, 1963, Kuwait notified the Fund that it was prepared to formally accept the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control There is no exchange control and residents and non- residents may freely purchase and sell foreign curren- cies in Kuwait. Dealings in the currencies of Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa, however, are prohibited. General and individual import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. The limited control over exports is administered by the Cus- toms and Ports Administration of the Ministry of Fi- nance and Oil. Prescription of Currency Kuwait has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. There are no prescription of currency requirements. All settlements with Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may freely open accounts in Kuwaiti dinars and foreign currencies. The use of such accounts is not restricted. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses are required for all private imports other than foodstuffs; licenses are issued freely, except for wheat, flour, and asbestos pipe. Registered import- ers handling a variety of commodities may obtain a general license valid for one year. Other importers must obtain specific licenses for individual commodities, which are also valid for one year. All imports from Israel, including imports of Israeli manufacture and those that contain Israeli materials or are manufactured by companies financed by Israeli capital, and all im- ports from Portugual, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Imports of a few items (mainly oxygen, certain steel pipes, alcoholic beverages, and used trucks and buses not using gasoline for fuel and over ten years old) are prohibited from all sources. To be registered, the importer must be either a Ku- waiti citizen or a firm in which all partners are Kuwaitis or a shareholding or limited liability company in which Kuwaitis own at least 51 per cent of all stock. Commer- cial imports normally are limited to registered import- ers. Imports from any permitted source may be paid for freely. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely, except to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa. There are no limitations on the export of domestic or foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of live sheep and poultry and of certain other items (such as sugar, fats, rice, meat, eggs, fish, milk, cheese, butter, olive oil, fresh fruits, vegetables in any form, beans, lentils, chick-peas, jams, and cement) are prohibited in time of emergency or shortage in Kuwait. These items may be exported in limited quantities only, under a special license issued by the Ministry of Com- merce and Industry. Exports of arms, ammunition, and scrap metal require licenses. Licenses are not required for other exports or re-exports. All exports to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re-exports, except that these must not accrue in Israel pounds, Portuguese escudos, Rhodesian cur- rency, or South African rand; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surrendered, and they may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Proceeds from Invisibles No requirements are attached to the use or disposal of receipts in any currency other than Israel pounds, Portuguese escudos, Rhodesian currency, or South Af- rican rand. Travelers entering Kuwait may bring with them any amount in Kuwaiti or other banknotes except Israel, Portuguese, Rhodesian, or South African cur- rency. Capital There are no exchange control obligations on the transfer to Kuwait of resident or nonresident capital in any currency. Government agreement is necessary for the participation of nonresident capital in corporations in Kuwait, and a license is required for the establish- ment and operation of industries in Kuwait; at least 51 299 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KUWAIT per cent of ownership of new Kuwaiti companies must be held by Kuwaiti nationals. No restrictions are imposed on outward capital pay- ments by residents or nonresidents to other countries except Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa. home or abroad. Other residents may, on arrival or departure, bring in and take out their holdings of gold in any form, without restriction or license. Imports of gold in any form are exempt from all customs duties and taxes. Gold The monetary authorities and merchants registered with the Ministry of Commerce and Indus try may im- port and export gold in any form, provided that such gold is not less than 18-karat fine; gold jewelry, how- ever, cannot be imported or sold unless it is properly hallmarked. Not for Redistribution LAOS (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Laotian Kip has been estab- lished with the Fund. The official exchange rate is K 600 = US$1. This rate applies to a few specified imports, to government payments covered by the for- eign exchange budget for official transactions, to a few types of private sector payments in respect of current invisibles, to the portion of export proceeds that must be surrendered (except for exports of tin, plywood, and furniture), and to any proceeds from invisibles or capi- tal voluntarily sold to the banking system. An ex- change rate of K 840 per US$1 results from the application of an exchange tax of 40 per cent to the official rate. This rate is applicable to certain imports. An exchange subsidy of K 220 per US$1, applicable to the official exchange rate, is granted on the proceeds from exports of coal, plywood, and furniture. All other exchange transactions take place in the unofficial free market (parallel market), access to which is unre- stricted; on December 31, 1974, the exchange rate in that market was about K 1,250 = US$1. The official exchange market is supplied mainly by the Foreign Exchange Operations Fund (FEOF), which sells foreign exchange to banks at K 605 = US$1. The commercial banks' selling rates are K 606 per US$ 1 for transactions eligible for official exchange and K 846 per US$1 for transactions subject to the 40 per cent exchange tax. Administration of Control The FEOF sells and buys foreign exchange only in transactions with the four commercial banks and the Development Bank of Laos, which act for the account of their customers. The National Bank of Laos (the central bank) conducts foreign exchange transactions only with exporters making the obligatory surrender of export proceeds, with Laotian public agencies selling their exchange receipts, and with foreign embassies and international organizations; receipts from these sources are used to meet the foreign exchange expenditures of the Laotian Government, including its contributions to the FEOF. The approval of the Exchange Control Commission (Commission d'Octroi des Devises Etran- geres or CODE) in the Ministry of Finance is required for purchases of exchange by the public at the rate of K 600 = US$1 and the rate of K 840 = US$1. Ex- change authorization for certain invisibles eligible for the K 600 rate is granted, however, by the National Exchange Office in the Ministry of Finance, acting on behalf of CODE. The Commission for the Coordina- tion of Foreign Finance is empowered to modify the lists of imports eligible for official exchange. The For- eign Trade Department of the Ministry of Economy issues export licenses and keeps an annual register of importers and exporters. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are im- posed on receipts or payments, but the National Bank provides and accepts only U.S. dollars, French francs, and pounds sterling. There is a bilateral payments agreement with the U.S.S.R. providing for payments to be made through a clearing account maintained in French francs as the unit of account. Nonresident Accounts Both residents and nonresidents are permitted to maintain accounts in foreign currencies with authorized banks in Laos. Imports and Import Payments Importers must be listed on the annual register of importers, for which a yearly registration fee has to be paid to the Government. Imports of charcoal, bricks, matches, rubber sandals, coffee, ice cream, soft drinks, beer, detergents, oxygen, and plastic bags are prohib- ited, although they may be authorized when shortages arise. Financing at the official rate is normally permit- ted for certain commodities deemed essential; for some of these, the official rate is subject to a surcharge of K 240 per US$1. Letters of credit must be opened with the commercial banks for all import transactions set- tled at the official rate or the K 840 rate. Import transactions at the official rate are subject to exchange control approval. To apply for this approval, the importer is required to complete an exchange con- trol form obtainable from the banks, which are to for- ward the form to the CODE. The latter applies various criteria in deciding on exchange applications, including the applicant's compliance with prevailing require- ments regarding letters of credit, advance import de- posits, payment of import duties, and appropriate use of previous exchange purchases. Also, imports from Thailand are subject to price verification procedures. Import transactions for which no exchange is granted at the official rate may in practice be freely settled in the unofficial free market. On being notified that exchange approval will be granted the importer must within 7 days (14 days out- side Vientiane) make an advance import deposit in kip at the Treasury. The advance deposit requirement is 40 per cent of the c.i.f. value for imports from Thailand and 30 per cent for imports from all other sources; it is not applicable when imports are financed through the free market. The CODE requires evidence of payment of this deposit before forwarding the exchange authori- zation form to the commercial bank. Before the depos- 301 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LAOS its can be returned by the Treasury, the importer must show proof, including customs evidence, that the goods have arrived in Laos, that they have been properly priced, and that the transaction has generally con- formed with the prevailing regulations on imports. Raw material impor ts by export industries and installa- tion equ ipment imported by firms benef i t ing from in- vestment incentives are exempt from advance import deposit requirements. Payments for Invisibles Payments eligible for the official rate are subject to exchange control approval by the CODE and most are restricted. Payments for all invisibles, however, may in practice be made freely th rough the free marke t. Appli- cants for off ic ial exchange for current invisibles are required to complete forms indicating their iden t i ty as well as the intended use of the desired foreign exchange. There is a foreign exchange budget detailing the Gov- ernmen t's paymen ts in foreign exchange dur ing the fis- cal year; for such paymen ts the National Bank of Laos makes exchange available at the official rate. There are no regulations l im i t ing the export of domestic or fo r- eign banknotes by travelers. Exports and Export Proceeds Exporters must pay an annual registration fee to the Government. Exports of wood in any form other than plywood or fu rn i tu re are prohibited. Exports of gold and silver also are prohibited, except when made by or on behalf of the mone ta ry authorities. All other exports are subject to authorization, but licenses normally are automatically issued. Exports of tin require the opening of a letter of credit. The fu ll proceeds from exports of tin and 80 per cent of proceeds from all other exports must be surrendered to the National Bank in U.S. dol- lars, French francs, or pounds sterling at the official rate; the remainder may be kept abroad or used freely. Exporters are required to deposit w i th the National Bank, prior to domiciling the export license with this Bank, the portion of their anticipated export proceeds that is subject to surrender; the National Exchange Office gives its visa only on export licenses that have been annotated by the National Bank to show that th is requirement has been complied with. Except for tin, an exporter may, however, be permitted to make a prior surrender of only 40 per cent of the export value, the remaining 40 per cent being due in a maximum of ten days from the settlement of the transaction; a commer- cial bank's guarantee may be accepted by the National Bank in lieu of the initial deposit. For tin, the corre- sponding advance surrender requirement is 50 per cent of the export value. Should an exporter be paid in a currency other than U.S. dollars, French francs, or pounds sterling, he must exchange the part that is sub- ject to surrender into one of the acceptable currencies. Exports of coal, plywood, and fu rn i tu re are entitled to an exchange subsidy of K 220 per US$1. 302 Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange converted by foreign embassies, missions, representatives, and institutions to cover their official expenses in Laos must be surrendered at the official rate. All other receipts from invisibles may be retained by the recipient. There are no regulations lim- iting the import of foreign or domestic banknotes by travelers. Capital Under the Investment Law of February 1970, vari- ous incentives are available to foreign investors in Laos. Capital in f low is free from exchange control regulations and the foreign exchange need not be surrendered. No off ic ial exchange is granted for outward capital trans- fers other than debt repayments approved by CODE. However, access to the unofficial free market is unre- stricted. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form w i th in the country. Banks and other residents who are recognized as industrial users or as importers of gold also may freely import gold in any form, subject to payment of a tax of K 42,000 a kilogram and an import du ty of 3.5 per cent. Exports of gold by or on behalf of physical or juridical persons other than the mone tary authorities are not officially approved. Ex- ports of gold coins issued under Decree No. 784 /PC of June 26, 1969, however, are permitted. Commercial imports and exports of articles containing a minor quan t i ty of gold are freely permitted. Changes during 1974 January 15. Not for Redistribution LEBANON (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System All exchange transactions, including those in clear- ing dollars, take place at the free market rate, which for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 was Lebanese Pounds 2.2825 per US$1. There also exists a "moving parity" used for the calculation of duties and taxes levied on amounts invoiced or expressed in foreign cur- rency, particularly customs duties; for December 1974 the "moving parity" was LL 2.35 per US$1. There are no restrictions on foreign payments. Prescription of Currency In general, no requirements are imposed on exchange payments abroad or receipts in Lebanon. Some transac- tions with certain countries with which Lebanon has payments agreements1 specifying the method or chan- nel of payment may be made through specific accounts denominated in U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few goods (mainly arms and ammuni- tion, narcotics, and similar products) are either prohib- ited or reserved for the Government. All imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports of certain other commodities (including wheat, barley, beet and cane sugar, olive oil, poultry, gasoline, kerosene, and liquid gas) that are for the most part produced locally are subject to prior licensing. Import licenses are also required for all machinery for the installation or expan- sion of manufacturing plants. All other commodities may be imported freely without license. Exchange to pay for imports may be obtained freely through the free market, but a cash deposit of 15 per cent must be made in foreign currency against import letters of credit. A municipalities tax of 3.5 per cent is levied on the value of all goods imported, except those of Arab origin, and a stamp tax of 1.2 per cent is applicable to all imports except gold and banknotes. A surcharge of 10 per cent of the applicable import duty is levied on specified textiles and garments. Payments for Invisibles No restrictions are placed on payments for invisibles. Exchange may be obtained freely through the free mar- ket. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain goods (such as arms and ammuni- tion and narcotics and similar products) to any destina- tion, and all exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports of certain metals and a few other items and exports valued at over LL 200 of certain other items—livestock, wheat and wheat products, bar- 304 ley, rice, sugar, edible oils, dairy products, canned or frozen meat, newsprint, petroleum and petroleum products, and industrial and agricultural machinery and equipment —to any country and all products in- tended for export to North Korea require export li- censes. Exchange receipts from exports may be retained, used, or sold freely in the free market. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles may be retained, used, or sold freely in the free market. Capital There are no limitations on capital payments or re- ceipts. Exchange may be obtained or sold freely through the free market. Banks are prohibited from paying interest on nonresident-held deposits denomi- nated in Lebanese pounds. They have been requested not to extend credits in Lebanese pounds to nonresi- dents. Gold Residents may freely hold gold in any form at home or abroad and may freely negotiate gold in any form with residents and nonresidents at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form are freely permitted and do not require a license but must be officially recorded. The import, export, and domestic sale of foreign gold coins must be covered by a certifi- cate indicating the gold content and weight and issued by the Office for the Protection of the Consumer. Changes during 1974 During 1974 the issuance by foreign borrowers of bonds denominated in Lebanese pounds was officially discouraged. January 23. The central bank allowed commercial banks to meet 25 per cent of the reserve requirement against deposits by depositing foreign exchange. This percentage was increased to 50 in April. The facility was terminated in May. April 3. Exports and re-exports of many foodstuffs and feedstuffs and of certain manufactured goods were made subject to prior licensing. The relevant list was modified on September 24 and November 26. August 1. Banks were required to demand a cash payment in foreign currency equivalent to 15 per cent of the value of newly opened import letters of credit in the currency of the credit. These amounts had to be deposited with the central bank, where they did not bear interest. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LEBANON August 1.
