Not for Redistribution LESOTHO (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange and Trade System Lesotho's currency is the South African Rand. The par value of the rand is 1.04550 grams of f ine gold per rand. However, no exchange transactions take place at the par value, since an exchange rate policy of indepen- dent managed floating has been adopted. The South African Reserve Bank on December 31 ,1974 quoted a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.4500 per R 1. Exchange rates are based on the South African Reserve Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar against rand and the London market rates for the currencies con- cerned against the U.S. dollar. Lesotho has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a coun try of the Overseas Sterling Area. Lesotho also forms part of the Rand Monetary Area, which is a single exchange control ter- ritory comprising Botswana, Lesotho, South Africa, and Swaziland. For purposes of exchange control over transactions in securities or gold, residents of a member country of the latter area are not regarded as residents of another member country. The Ministry of Finance controls all external currency transactions. No restrictions are applied to payments w i th in the Rand Monetary Area, and in principle these are uncon- trolled and unrecorded. In relation to countries outside the Rand Monetary Area, Lesotho applies exchange controls that are generally similar to those of South Africa. Payments to nonresidents for current transac- tions, while subject to control, are not restricted, but applications for outward transfers of capital are consid- ered on their merits. The rulings on applications for inward and outward capital transfers may depend on whether the applicant is a temporarily resident foreign national, a nonresident, or a resident. Au thor i ty to ap- prove some types of current payments is delegated to commercial banks up to established limits; this is true, for example, of the basic exchange allowance for tourist travel (the equivalent of R 2,000 in a calendar year for an adu lt and R 800 for a child) and a smaller annual allocation for travel to neighboring countries. There are no bilateral payments arrangements. Lesotho is a member of a customs union with Bot- swana, South Africa, and Swaziland, and there are no import restrictions on goods originating in any country of the customs union. Imports from South Africa do not require licenses and include an unknown quantity of goods originating outside the customs union. Insofar as Lesotho imports goods direct from countries outside the customs un ion, such imports are usually licensed in conform i ty w i th South Africa's import regulations. Im- port licenses are valid for all countries and entitle the holder to buy the foreign exchange required to make the import payment. Lesotho's trade licensing arrange- ments, however, are designed mainly to raise revenue and to prevent tax evasion and are confined in practice to exports of diamonds; permits are issued by the Min- is t ry of Commerce and Indus t ry. Certain tax incentives for inward direct investment are provided by the Pioneer Industries Encouragement Act, 1969 to manufac tur ing activities approved by a Pioneer Industries Board. Residents may freely pur- chase, hold, and sell certain Lesotho gold coins that are legal tender. Changes during 1974 June 24. South Africa discontinued the existing prac- tice of ma in ta in ing a fixed rate of exchange between the rand and the U.S. dollar for leng thy periods and, in- stead, adopted an exchange rate policy of independent managed f loa t ing. A new middle rate was set for the U.S. dollar at R 1 - US$1.50 (formerly R 1 = US$1.49). The middle rate was changed in 1974 on a number of occasions. September 6. It was announced that within two years Botswana would establish a central bank and issue its own currency, which would replace the rand as legal tender. Botswana w i thdrew from the negotiations with South Africa, Lesotho, and Swaziland on a formaliza- tion and revision of the Rand Monetary Area arrange- ments. Past arrangements would continue, however, un t il the central bank started operations. September 6. Swaziland issued its own currency, the lilangeni, which was at par with the rand. December 5. Agreement was reached in negotiations between Lesotho, Swaziland, and South Africa con- cerning a formalization of, and certain changes in, the existing Rand Monetary Area arrangements. The re- sulting Monetary Agreement came into force on the same date. 306 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBERIA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.736662 gram of f ine gold per Liberian Dollar, corresponding to $1 = US$1. U.S. currency is legal tender in Liberia and circulates along w i th Liberian coinage. Official accounts are kept in U.S. dollars and cents. There is no exchange control and there are no restrictions on foreign exchange trans- actions. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requ iremen ts are in force. Imports and Import Payments There is no general system of import control. A few items (e.g., arms and ammun i t ion, explosives, used clothing, and Pharmaceuticals) require prior licenses; imports of cement are not being licensed. Also, impor ts of certain goods (e.g., obscene l i tera ture, narcotics other than for medicinal purposes) and all impor ts f rom Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohib- ited. In practice, meat is imported only by the Liberian Supply Corporation and petroleum only by the Libe- rian Re f in ing Company. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Export licenses are required for precious metals, precious stones, ivo ry, agricultural products other than rubber, and certain other items, such as arms and ammun i t ion and explosives. Licenses are gen- erally issued free ly and no licenses are required for direct exports by foreign concession holders; licenses serve ma in ly to enforce taxation or, for agricultural products, to assure certification of qua l i ty and origin and to safeguard the export monopoly of the Liberian Produce Marke t ing Corporation. The surrender of ex- port proceeds is not required, and exchange receipts are freely disposable. An export tax is levied on diamonds. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles There are no limitations on payments for or receipts f rom invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresi- dents. Under an Inves tment Incentive Code of 1966 (as amended in 1973), enterprises under tak ing new invest- ment projects may be granted a five-year 90 per cent du ty exemption on impor ts of raw materials and ma- chinery, total tax exemption on reinvested profits, a 50 per cent exemption on distributable profits, and a pro- tective tar iff on competing imported products. The five-year incentive is eligible for a two-year renewal if ex tenua t ing circumstances warrant it. Gold Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Impo r ts and exports of gold in any form are subject to licenses issued by the Minister of Finance; import li- censes are issued freely but export licenses are granted restrictively. Changes during 1974 May 20. The Customs Tariff Act 1974, which re- pealed the Tariff Act 1966, came into force. May 28. A central bank, the National Bank of Libe- ria, was established. August 2. Liberia informed the Fund that it was prepared to subscribe to the Vo lun tary Declaration on Trade and Other Current Account Measures for Bal- ance of Payments Purposes. 307 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Lib- yan Dinar, corresponding to LD 0.296053 = US$1, and the Libyan Arab Republic avails itself of wider margins. The U.S. dollar is the intervention currency. The Central Bank of Libya publishes daily buying and selling rates for 15 currencies.1 It deals with commer- cial banks only in pounds sterling and U.S. dollars, at rates fixed daily. The Central Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were LD 0.29531 buy- ing, and LD 0.29679 selling, per US$1; for the pound sterling the buying and selling rates were LD 0.69266 and LD 0.69614, respectively, per £ stg. 1. The commercial banks are permitted to buy or sell other currencies against pounds sterling and U.S. dol- lars through their foreign correspondents. The com- mercial banks' buying and selling rates for currencies other than sterling and U.S. dollars are based on quota- tions in London, New York, and other centers abroad. They may not deal among themselves in foreign curren- cies. Neither authorized banks nor importers or export- ers are allowed to enter in to forward commitments in foreign currencies. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Central Bank, which has delegated some of its powers to the authorized banks. Policy relating to import and export licensing is determined by the Ministry of Economy. Import and export licenses generally are issued by the Ministry of Economy; for certain imports the approval of another Ministry (Interior, Health, Agriculture and Agrarian Reform, or Defense) is required. Imports of petroleum and petroleum products, wheat, f lour, rice, barley, vegetable oils, tomato paste, tea, sugar, salt, tobacco, cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, and phar- maceuticals are confined to public sector companies and ins t i tu t ions. Impor ts of unprocessed gold are con- fined to the Central Bank. Prescription of Currency Settlements w i th other countries are made in con- vertible currencies, usually U.S. dollars or pounds ster- ling. All settlements with Israel, Mozambique, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts A nonresident, as defined by the Central Bank, who is ga infu l ly employed in the Libyan Arab Republic is permitted under the existing exchange control regula- tions to open and maintain a nonresident account in Libyan dinars w i th any authorized bank in the Libyan Arab Republic. Legitimate earnings from employers of 308 such nonresidents, including overtime payments, can be credited to their nonresident accounts. Similarly, authorized banks have authority to credit interest earned on balances in these nonresident accounts. All other credits to nonresident accounts require the prior approval of the Central Bank. Remittances abroad from such accounts maintained by nonresident laborers and technicians can be allowed by banks up to 60 per cent of net salary each month; for those whose con- tracts specify that lodging and /or board will be made available free of charge by the employer, remittances up to 90 per cent of net salary are permitted. Banks may issue travelers checks and foreign currency notes to nonresident laborers and technicians within the limits mentioned. Applications for amounts in excess of these limits must be submitted to the Central Bank. Such nonresidents may take w i th them when going abroad on vacation or on final departure certain goods whose value is not deducted f rom the balances in their nonres- ident accounts; a nonresident may also export one auto- mobile during his period of service in the Libyan Arab Republic. Funds brought in to the Libyan Arab Republic by nonresident contractors undertaking contracts in their own names are required to be kept in "special resident accounts" w i th a bank in the Republic. Payments re- ceived in the Libyan Arab Republic by such contrac- tors in respect of their contracts may also be credited to these accounts. Remittances from the Libyan Arab Republic to the debit of these accounts are subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank after submission of all the prescribed evidence. Nonresident-owned capital that is not permitted to be transferred abroad is credited to blocked accounts. With the approval of the Central Bank, funds in blocked accounts (with certain exceptions) may be used for expenditures in the Libyan Arab Republic up to LD 500 a year to cover the cost of current visits to the Libyan Arab Republic by the owner of the funds or a close relative; for payments in the Libyan Arab Repub- lic of legal fees, taxes, etc.; for remittances to the owner of the funds in his coun t ry of permanent residence, up to LD 1,000 in a calendar year; and for remittances in cases of hardship. When the funds have been in a blocked account for f ive years, they qua l i fy for remit- tance in full to the owner in his country of permanent residence. The blocked accounts of persons (with cer- tain exceptions) who have left the Libyan Arab Repub- lic permanently are being released in installments; balances credited prior to March 31, 1966 have been released. Imports and Import Payments Import transactions are governed by Law No. 64 of 1971, which, among other things, stipulates that import ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution and export activities for trading purposes shall be con- fined to Libyans and to Libyan companies whose capi- tal is wholly owned by Libyan nationals. Most imports are under open general license and do not require an individual import license. The import of some items, including alcoholic beverages and narcotics, is prohib- ited. Imports of petroleum and petroleum products, sugar, salt, tea, rice, barley, wheat, flour, vegetable oils, tomato paste, tobacco, cigars, cigarettes, cigarette pa- per and Pharmaceuticals are confined to public sector companies and institutions and may be imported only by the National Oil Corporation, the National Supplies Corporation, the Tobacco General Company, or the National Company for Medicines. The Central Bank has a monopoly over the import of unworked gold. All imports from Israel, Mozambique, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Imports from the United Kingdom of specified consumer goods are sus- pended. Exchange permits required for imports are readily granted by the authorized banks, provided that there is a firm contract and any necessary import license has been obtained and, if the import is to be made on a letter of credit basis, that a marine insurance policy from an insurance company in the Libyan Arab Repub- lic is submitted before the letter of credit is established. However, no letter of credit in respect of the import of consumer durable goods may be opened by an autho- rized bank without obtaining a cash margin of 25 per cent of the import price. Importers must submit to the bank granting the exchange permit, within two months of customs clearance, a customs declaration confirming clearance and stating the valuation. The approval of the Exchange Control Department of the Central Bank is required for advance payments. Deferred payments (for up to 90 days after customs clearance) and payments for consignment shipments may be approved by the authorized banks. Imports are subject to customs duty and to customs surcharges totaling 15 per cent of the applicable cus- toms duty. Payments for Invisibles The authorized banks are empowered to approve ap- plications by residents to remit foreign exchange up to LD 100 in a calendar year for meeting genuine per- sonal commitments abroad of a noncommercial nature, including family assistance and gifts. They may also approve transfers abroad of up to LD 1,320 a year for each student (plus tuition fees, an allowance for books, etc.) for educational purposes, as well as allocations for travel as indicated below. Remittances from nonresi- dent accounts may be approved by authorized banks up to certain limits (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). All other payments for invisibles, as well as payments in excess of the approval authority delegated to the banks, require licenses from the Central Bank. Applications are considered on their merits. LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC Persons leaving the country may take with them Lib- yan currency notes not exceeding a total of LD 20 (LD 10 for children under 12); these may not be spent or exchanged outside the Libyan Arab Republic, but are intended for immediate expenses in the Libyan Arab Republic upon return to the country. Residents leaving for personal travel abroad, including tourist travel may, in addition, take out foreign exchange in the form of foreign currency notes, travelers checks, and letters of credit not exceeding a total value of LD 300 in a calendar year as a basic travel allowance; the ex- change may be obtained from any authorized bank in the Libyan Arab Republic. Children under 12 years of age are allowed half of this amount. Amounts in excess of the above may be granted in special circumstances. Pilgrims are entitled to a special quota of LD 300 in addition to the basic travel allowance. For business travel, residents may take out the equivalent of LD 500 a trip, subject to a maximum of LD 2,500 in any calen- dar year. All fares may be settled in Libyan dinars in the Libyan Arab Republic. Temporary residents may take out any travelers checks or foreign currency notes which they had previously brought in and declared to the customs. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are only required for fish and for commodities which are not of Libyan origin. Export proceeds must be received through an authorized bank within six months of shipment. Exports of nonmone- tary gold (other than for processing abroad), vegetable oils, and scrap metals are prohibited, as is the export or re-export of wheat, wheat flour, crushed wheat, bar- ley, rice, tea, sugar, and macaroni. All exports to Israel, Mozambique, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. Travelers checks or foreign currency notes may be cashed only at an authorized bank or at an exchange office licensed by the Central Bank of Libya. Travelers entering the Libyan Arab Republic may bring with them Libyan currency notes, not exceeding a total of LD 20, and other currency notes, travelers checks, letters of credit, securities, coupons, and other negotiable instruments in unlimited amounts. Capital Many aspects of the activities of oil companies oper- ating in the Libyan Arab Republic are governed by Petroleum Law No. 25 of 1955, as amended. However, 51 per cent or more of the Libyan interests of certain international oil companies has been nationalized. Un- der the provisions of the Foreign Capital Investment Law No. 37 of July 31, 1968, foreign capital invested in projects deemed to contribute to the economic devel- 309 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC opment of the country, as well as profits thereon, and salaries of foreign staff employed on such projects may be transferred freely to the country of origin, provided that the paid-up capital is not less than LD 200,000 and that at least 51 per cent of the shares is held by foreign nationals. Foreign participation in new indus- trial ventures (i.e., those set up after March 20, 1970) is permitted only on a minority basis, and only if it leads to increased production in excess of local require- ments, introduction of the latest technology, and coop- eration w i th foreign firms in exporting the surplus production. Insurance companies and foreign share- holdings in banks have been nationalized. Commercial firms have been Libyanized in vary ing degrees. Real estate in the Libyan Arab Republic may be sold only to Libyans, save in exceptional circumstances specified in a law of May 24, 1960 governing this sub- ject. The net sales proceeds af ter tax of real estate be- longing to foreign nationals are transferable, subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank. Nonresi- dent-owned capital that is not permitted to be trans- ferred abroad is credited to blocked accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). Residents require the prior approval of the Central Bank to bor- row funds abroad. As a rule, residents require prior permission to purchase real estate situated outside the Libyan Arab Republic or to invest abroad in securities. Residents of the Libyan Arab Republic tak ing up per- manent residence abroad are permitted to t ran s fer up to LD 5,000 for a fam i ly; applications may be subm i t- ted for the release of the balance of the ir assets over a number of years. The investment of na t ional capital abroad is governed by Law No. 25 of April 20, 1973. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form other than bars in the Libyan Arab Republic. The Central Bank has a monopoly over the import of unworked gold. It sells bars to domestic goldsmiths in limited quantities, to meet genuine commercial needs, at prices announced from time to time; at the end of 1974 this price was LD 1,902 a kilogram. Provided that a license is obtained from the Ministry of Econ- omy, goldsmiths may have such gold processed abroad, after which it must be reimported. Bars purchased from the Central Bank must be melted and processed before they can be sold to the public. Exports of unworked gold not for processing are not permitted unless made by or on behalf of the Government. Unworked gold is subject to an import du ty of 15 per cent. Changes during 1974 February 15. The bilateral payments arrangements with Romania were terminated. March 3. The export and re-export of wheat, flour, crushed wheat, barley, rice, tea, sugar, and macaroni was prohibited. March 5. The National Supplies Corporation was granted a monopoly on the import of tomato paste. Import licensing of motion pictures became the respon- sibility of the General Film Corporation. May 31. The bilateral payments arrangements with Bulgaria were terminated. June 1. The Central Bank's price for gold sold to domestic goldsmiths was changed from LD 1,302 a kilogram to LD 1,788 a kilogram. On December 1, the price was increased to LD 1,902 a kilogram. Not for Redistribution MALAGASY REPUBLIC (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange System No par value for the currency of the Malagasy Re- public has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the Malagasy Franc, which is officially maintained at the rate of FMG 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transactions in French francs, the interven- tion currency, between the Central Bank of the Mala- gasy Republic and commercial banks take place at the rates of FMG 50.25 selling, and FMG 49.75 buying, per F 1. The Central Bank quotes seven other curren- cies.1 Its buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were FMG 221.11 and FMG 223.34, respectively. The authorized banks are not permitted to maintain an exchange position in any foreign currency. All countries other than the Mala- gasy Republic itself are considered foreign countries, and financial relations with all foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Office of External Finance of the Directorate of the Treasury in the Ministry of Economy and Finance, which also su- pervises borrowing and lending abroad by residents, the issue, sale, or introduction of foreign securities in the Malagasy Republic, all outward investments, and inward direct investment. Some of the exchange control approval authority has been delegated to the autho- rized banks. All exchange transactions relating to for- eign countries must be effected through authorized banks. Import licenses are issued by the Foreign Trade Bureau of the Directorate of Commerce and Prices in the Ministry of Economy and Finance, including those for gold. Export authorizations are issued either by the Foreign Trade Bureau or by other specified public agencies, mainly stabilization funds or marketing of- fices for agricultural products. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected through the authorized banks, which may deal with the Central Bank of the Malagasy Republic only in the currencies quoted by the latter. Nonresident Accounts The principal type of nonresident account is Foreign Accounts in Malagasy Francs; these accounts may be debited and credited only for transactions between nonresidents and for explicitly authorized transactions between residents and nonresidents. When Malagasy francs accruing to a nonresident are not immediately eligible for credit to a Foreign Account, they must be credited to a Special Account, balances in which may be used by the holder for personal expenses in the Malagasy Republic, subject to a limit of FMG 10,000 a day during a period not exceeding 30 days. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to import licensing; the im- port of certain other items is prohibited or suspended until further notice. Imports of fruit juices are condi- tional on purchases of domestic fru it juices (jumelage). Imports are effected within the framework of an annual import program. The import program is based on the establishment of global quotas that set the limits up to which specified commodities may be imported. For cer- tain goods automatic licenses are issued. The import of certain items is reserved for the Regie Malgache des Monopoles Fiscaux and the Societe Nationale de Com- merce (SON AGO). All import transactions valued at FMG 10,000 or more must be domiciled with an authorized bank. The import license entitles importers to purchase the neces- sary exchange (not earlier than eight days before ship- ment when a documentary credit is opened); the payment can be made when the shipping documents are submitted to the authorized bank. Payments for Invisibles Most payments for invisibles require the prior ap- proval of the Ministry of Economy and Finance. For some types of transactions the approval authority has been delegated to authorized banks, either up to speci- fied limits or for any amount that is properly docu- mented. Residents may obtain an exchange allocation for tourism equivalent to FMG 75,000 a person a trip, for up to two trips a year (FMG 35,000 for children under ten); any foreign exchange remaining after return to the Malagasy Republic must be surrendered. There also is an exchange allocation for business travel up to the equivalent of FMG 10,000 a person a day, subject to a maximum of FMG 200,000 a person a trip, for any number of trips a year. Authorized banks may not make available foreign banknotes in excess of the equiv- alent of FMG 20,000 a person a trip for tourist or business travel. Applications for amounts in excess of the basic tourist and business travel allocations, and applications for exchange for any other type of travel, must be submitted to the Ministry of Economy and Finance. Allocations for different types of travel may not be combined without the prior approval of the Directorate of the Treasury. There are basic allocations for study expenses and certain other current invisibles. Dividends are transfer- able in full when distributed by industrial firms and up to 75 per cent in other cases; they may only be trans- ferred to nonresident physical or juridical persons of 311 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAGASY REPUBLIC foreign na t iona l i ty. The transfer of savings from wages and salaries earned by a foreigner wo rk ing in the Mala- gasy Republic is permitted, upon presentation of his employment contract and provided that the transfer takes place w i th in three mon ths of the pay period, up to 25 per cent of the net salary for bachelors and per- sons having their fam i ly in the Malagasy Republic, and up to 45 per cent for those whose fam i ly lives outside the Malagasy Republic (100 per cent for all concerned during leave spent outside the Malagasy Republic). Resident and nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to FMG 5,000 in Malagasy banknotes. Nonresident travelers may take out any re- ma in ing foreign banknotes and coins and other foreign means of payment declared by them on en t ry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to all destinations of products under quota and of so-called controlled products require an exit permit (autorisation de sortie) issued by the Foreign Trade Bureau or the appropriate commodity stabiliza- tion office; these products include coffee, vanilla, cloves, pepper, sugar, rice, and petroleum and petro- leum products. Export proceeds received in foreign currencies must be surrendered; such export proceeds normally must become due not later than one mon th af ter arrival of the goods at their destination. All export transactions valued at FMG 50,000 or more must be domiciled w i th an authorized bank and a commitment to repatriate the proceeds must be signed. Proceeds from Invisibles All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services, and all income or proceeds accruing in those countries or from nonresidents, must be col- lected and, when received in foreign currency, surren- dered within one mon th of the due date. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of means of payment denominated in a foreign currency. The import of Malagasy banknotes is prohibited. Capital Capital movements between the Malagasy Republic and foreign countries and between residents and non- residents are subject to exchange control; capital trans- fers to all countries require exchange control approval, but capital receipts from foreign countries normally are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, ad- vertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in the Malagasy Republic. Foreign direct investments in the Malagasy Repub- lic,2 and Malagasy direct investments abroad,3 require 312 prior approval of the Minister of Economy and Finance (i.e., the Directorate of the Treasury). The total or par- tial liquidation of such investments must be declared to the Minister. Both the making and the liquidation of direct investments, whether these are Malagasy invest- ments abroad or foreign investments in the Malagasy Republic, must be reported to the Minister of Economy and Finance w i th in 20 days following each operation. Mere participation is not considered as direct invest- ment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company, but such participation is sub- ject to prior declaration to the Ministry of Economy and Finance. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of for- eign securities in the Malagasy Republic requires prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Fi- nance. Exempt from authorization, however, are opera- tions in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Malagasy Government and (2) shares similar to securities whose issue, offering, or sale in the Malagasy Republic has previously been autho- rized. Borrowing abroad by physical or juridical persons, whether public or private persons, requires prior autho- rization by the Minister of Economy and Finance. However, loans contracted by authorized banks or credit ins t i tu t ions with special legal status are exempt from approval. Lending abroad is subject to exchange control authorization and is restricted. In accordance w i th the Investment Code of Septem- ber 19, 1973, foreign or domestic enterprises of special interest for the economy may be granted preferential treatment in accordance with an "order of approval" (arrete d'agremeni). Such enterprises may benefit from specified advantages relating to import and export duties, income taxes, import licenses, the introduction of quotas for competing imports, etc. The same benefits may be granted temporarily to investments not qualify- ing for an "order of approval." Exceptional treatment beyond the benefits provided for by the Investment Code and other existing legislation may be granted in a participation contract (contrat de participation). Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in the Malagasy Republic. Imports and exports of gold require prior authorization by the Ministry of Economy and Finance. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Central Bank; (2) imports and exports of manu- factured articles containing a minor quan t i ty of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports by travelers of gold jewelry and other articles of gold up to 500 grams a family and collector's coins up to 200 grams a family. Imports of gold, whether licensed or exempt from license, are subject to customs declaration. Newly mined gold must be surrendered to ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution the Directorate of Mines, which, in principle, must de- liver it to the Central Bank after processing. Changes during 1974 January 19. The exchange rate of FMG 1 = F 0.02 was maintained following the decision of the French authorities to float the French franc in the official ex- change market. February 4. Circular No. 1419 gave details regarding the implementation of Order No. 3393 of Septem- ber 20, 1973 and completed Circular No. 30409 of Oc- tober 10, 1973 with respect to the transfer to nonresidents of rents on property. February 13. Order No. 530 regulated the import regime. With minor specified exceptions, all imports required an import license issued within the framework of a general import program. Licenses would be issued to importers holding an importer's card according to a quota allocation system based on (1) the fiscal tax paid (patente); (2) the degree of specialization; and (3) the percentage of nonutilization of earlier allocations. Au- tomatic licenses (without prior allocation of quotas) would be issued for the following: supplies for industry, particularly raw materials and spare parts for machin- ery; pharmaceutical products and supplies for medical purposes; and parts of all kinds, especially for rolling stock, motors, and any type of apparatus. Licenses were personal and nontransferable. May 21. Order No. 1975 delegated to authorized banks the power to allocate foreign exchange within prescribed limits for (1) study abroad; (2) correspon- MALAGASY REPUBLIC dence courses; (3) subscriptions to permitted periodi- cals and newspapers; and (4) specified commercial transactions. May 21. Circular No. 13230 gave details regarding the implementation of Order No. 1975 with respect to exchange allocations for study abroad. July 13. Notice No. 1019 was published containing the import quotas for the second half of 1974. September 18. Order No. 3747 authorized, subject to the prior approval of the Ministry of Economy and Finance, the transfer abroad of dividends distributed by companies established or operating in the Malagasy Republic. The transferable portion of a declared divi- dend was, in principle, 100 per cent for industrial firms and 75 per cent for other firms. Transfers could only be made in favor of nonresident physical or juridical per- sons of foreign nationality. These provisions would first be applicable to the fiscal year 1973. Dividends relating to earlier fiscal years would be transferable as follows: 50 per cent before June 30, 1975, and 50 per cent one year after the effective transfer of the first portion. Not for Redistribution MALAWI (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.06641 grams of f ine gold per Ma- lawi Kwacha. However, no exchange transactions take place at the par value. Since November 19, 1973 the Reserve Bank of Malawi has set daily buy ing and sell- ing rates for the U.S. dollar and the pound sterling in light of exchange market developments abroad. On De- cember 31, 1974 the Reserve Bank's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were MK 1 = US$1.1927 and MK 1 = US$1.1867, respectively, and those for ster- ling were MK 1 = £0.5086 and MK 1 = £0.5060, respectively. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Reserve Bank of Malawi under powers delegated to it by the Minister of Finance. Much of the authority for approv- ing normal current payments is in turn delegated to commercial banks designated as authorized dealers. Import policy is formulated by the Minister of Trade and Indus try, subject to the approval of the Cabinet. The Minister is also responsible for the issue of import and export licenses. Prescription of Currency Malawi has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. For prescription of currency purposes, a distinction is made between the rest of the Sterling Area (the Nonresident Scheduled Area) and all other countries except Rhodesia (the External Account Area).1 Settlements with residents of other countries in the Sterling Area may be made in Malawi kwacha through a Nonresident Scheduled Area Account, in sterling, or in any other Sterling Area currency. Pay- ments to residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia may be made in sterling or in Malawi kwacha to the credit of an External Account, or in any non-Sterling Area currency other than Rho- desian currency. Payments from residents of countries outside the Sterling Area except Rhodesia may be re- ceived in sterling or in Malawi kwacha from an Exter- nal Account, or in any non-Sterling Area currency freely exchangeable for sterling. Special regulations ap- ply to settlements with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Malawi kwacha held by residents of other parts of the Sterling Area are designated Nonresi- dent Scheduled Area Accounts. These accounts may be credited with the proceeds from sales of any Sterling 314 Area currency, with authorized payments to Sterling Area countries by residents, and with transfers from other Nonresident Scheduled Area Accounts. Balances on these accounts may be used to make payments to residents of Malawi for any purpose and may be trans- ferred freely to other Nonresident Scheduled Area Ac- counts; these accounts may also be debited for payments to the account holder while temporarily resi- dent in Malawi. Transfers to External Accounts require specific approval. Accounts in Malawi kwacha held with authorized banks by residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia are designated External Ac- counts. These accounts may be credited with authorized payments by residents to countries outside the Sterling Area except Rhodesia, with transfers from other Exter- nal Accounts held in Malawi or any other Sterling Area territory, with individually approved transfers from Nonresident Scheduled Area Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any non-Sterling Area currency except Rhodesian currency by nonresidents to autho- rized dealers. They may be debited for payments for any purpose to residents of Malawi and of any other country of the Sterling Area, for transfers to other External Accounts held in Malawi or any other Sterling Area territory, or to Nonresident Scheduled Area Ac- counts in Malawi, and for purchases of any Sterling Area or non-Sterling Area currency other than Rhode- sian currency from authorized dealers; they may also be debited for withdrawals by the account holder while temporarily staying in Malawi. External Accounts—Rhodesia are accounts in Ma- lawi kwacha that are held by persons regarded as resi- dents of Rhodesia. They may only be credited with (1) the proceeds from the sale of Rhodesian currency to an authorized dealer in Malawi, and (2) transfers from another Rhodesian External Account. The accounts may be debited with (1) payments to residents of Ma- lawi for any purpose; (2) payments to the account holder while temporarily staying in Malawi; (3) trans- fers to another Rhodesian External Account; and (4) transfers to the account holders in Rhodesia. Blocked Accounts in Malawi kwacha held with au- thorized banks by residents of any country other than Malawi are credited with nontransferable capital sums in Malawi currency which have accrued to nonresi- dents. All debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. Normally, approval is given for the investment of bal- ances of Blocked Accounts in Malawian securities, pro- vided that these are held in Malawi to the order of an authorized dealer. The interest on Blocked Account balances is freely transferable to the account holder's country of residence. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Imports and Import Payments The statutory basis of the principal import restric- tions is the Control of Goods Act, which authorizes the Minister of Trade and Indus try to control and regulate the import, export, distribution, disposal, purchase, sale, wholesale price, and retail price of any goods. It also has provisions which, when brought into opera- tion, will require all importers and exporters to be regis- tered. The import from Rhodesia of asbestos, iron ore, pig iron, chrome, tobacco, copper, and hides and skins is prohibited. For a number of items,2 import licenses are required regardless of the coun try of origin. All other goods may be imported under an open general license when originating in Commonwealth countries or in non-Commonwealth countries that are members of the GATT. Imports originating in the Republic of China are treated similarly but require an individual license. With respect to other countries, an import license is required for all commodities except certain items such as petroleum products, exposed cinematographic films, bona fide unsolicited gifts not exceeding MK 50 in value, samples, and advertising materials. Payments for imports from all countries must be made w i th in six mon ths a f ter the date of impor t, except with the express permission of the exchange control authorities. Foreign exchange for these payments is au- tomatically granted by the authorized dealers, subject only to the presentation of relevant documents and compliance with import licensing requirements. Any transfer of funds in anticipation of imports is prohib- ited, except with the permission of the exchange control authorities. Advance payments may, however, be made for imports valued at up to MK 100 on presentation of an invoice or other evidence indicating that the seller requires payment in advance. Imports from any Sterling Area country may be paid for in Malawi currency to a local Nonresident Sched- uled Area Account, in sterling, or in any other Sterling Area currency. Imports from other areas, except Rho- desia, may be paid for in Malawi currency to a local External Account, in sterling to an External Account held elsewhere in the Sterling Area, or in any non-Ster- ling Area currency. A surtax of 10 per cent is levied on most goods imported into Malawi, irrespective of their origin; the surtax is calculated on 120 per cent of the sum of the value for customs du ty purposes and any customs du ty payable. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to impor ts, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes, such as travel, is provided by the authorized dealers without prior reference to the exchange control authorities. The basic exchange allowance for private travel is MK 20 a day for an adult, with a maximum of MK 600 a calendar year, and MK 10 a day for each child under MALAWI 18 years of age, with a maximum of MK 300 a calendar year for children between 10 and 18, and of MK 200 a year for children under 10. The annual allowance is not cumulative but may be increased by up to 50 per cent if the traveler has not applied for a travel allow- ance during the preceding three years. These alloca- tions are subject to a combined maximum of MK 2,000 a year for a family traveling together. The basic ex- change allowance for business travel is MK 40 a day, up to MK 400 a trip for any number of trips a year. Exchange is provided, subject to certain limits, for other purposes, such as education, medical treatment, and family remittances. Applications for amounts ex- ceeding the standard allocations may be submitted to the exchange control authorities. Foreign nationals em- ployed in Malawi on contracts or holding a temporary employment permit are allowed to remit up to two thirds of their current net earnings to their country of normal residence. Travelers may take out up to MK 20 in Malawi currency and the equivalent of MK 20 in foreign cur- rency in addition to their basic travel allowance. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of goods of any description that exceed MK 100 in value are prohibited, unless the Controller of Customs and Excise is satisfied that payment has been made or will be made in an appropriate manner to a resident of Malawi not later than six months after the date of exportation. Certain commodities3 are sub- ject to export licensing, mainly to ensure the adequacy of their domestic supplies. Export proceeds in foreign currency must be sold to an authorized dealer. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any foreign currency must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes and coins that may be imported by travelers, but not more than MK 20 in Malawi currency notes and coins may be imported. The import of currency notes and coins of the former Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is prohibited. Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted, with the exception that the taking up of loans from abroad by residents requires prior exchange control approval. This is normally granted, provided that the terms of repayment are realistic. Outward transfers of capital, inc lud ing those to other parts of the Sterling Area, are controlled, but nonresidents are permitted to repatriate their investments when they have satisfied the authori- ties that the original investment was made with funds brought in to the coun try f rom sources outside Malawi; there are no restrictions on the transfer abroad of divi- dends and prof i ts of foreign-owned companies, pro- 315 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAWI vided that no recourse is being made to local borrow- ing. In general, residents are not permitted to transfer capital abroad and, with certain exceptions, are re- quired to offer for sale to an authorized dealer any foreign exchange which accrues to them. However, resi- dents may purchase foreign securities (except bearer securities) quoted on recognized stock exchanges in the Sterling Area, provided that the securities so acquired are registered in the names of specified nominees and held to the order of an authorized dealer, and that in the event of subsequent disposal of these securities the sales proceeds are permitted to be repatriated by the exchange control authorities of the country concerned. All income earned from these investments must be re- patriated, and the corresponding foreign exchange must be sold to an authorized dealer. Emigrants are granted exchange as follows: (1) Per- sons 50 years of age and over are allowed exchange up to MK 15,000 whether single or married. (2) Married persons who have not reached the age of 50 are allowed MK 6,000 on departure, together with MK 500 for each child, up to a maximum of MK 8,000 for a family. (3) Unmarried persons who have not reached 50 years of age are allowed MK 3,000 on departure. (4) The balance of the emigrant's funds is blocked, but he is permitted to transfer to his new country of residence a sum equal to the original emigration allowance on each anniversary of his departure from Malawi, up to a max- imum of MK 8,000. Applications for emigrants' allow- ances, whether initial or subsequent, must be submitted to the exchange control authorities for approval. Residents require prior approval to lend to nonresi- dents or to resident firms controlled directly or indi- rectly from outside Malawi. Approval to lend to nonresident-controlled firms may be withheld if it is felt that excessive recourse is being had to local borrowing, and that the firms have brought in insufficient working capital from abroad. Gold Residents of Malawi may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Malawi for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary au- thorities and authorized industrial users are not al- lowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Minister of Trade and Indus t ry in consultation w i th the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports by or on behalf of the mone- tary authorities and industrial users. Changes during 1974 November 1. Malawi subscribed to the Fund's Vol- un ta ry Declaration on Trade and Other Current Ac- count Measures for Balance of Payments Purposes. Not for Redistribution MALAYSIA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.290299 gram of fine gold per Malaysian Dollar, and Malaysia avails itself of wider margins. Since June 21, 1973, however, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate within an- nounced margins. The closing buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in the Malaysian foreign exchange market on December 31, 1974 were MS2.3125 and M$2.3130 per US$1, respectively. The commercial banks are free to determine and quote exchange rates for all currencies to customers and are permitted to deal forward in all currencies. Malaysia formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from November 11, 1968. Administration of Control The Central Bank of Malaysia administers exchange control on behalf of the Malaysian Government throughout Malaysia, the Governor of the Bank being the Controller of Foreign Exchange. Much of the au- thority for approving normal current payments is dele- gated to commercial banks authorized for this purpose. The authority for import control rests with the Central Government. The day-to-day administration of import control throughout Malaysia is carried out jointly by the Ministry of Trade and Industry and the Royal Customs and Excise. * Certain import and export trans- actions are effected by a state trading corporation, the National Trading Corporation (PERNAS). Prescription of Currency Malaysia has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. All payments to countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa may be made either in Malaysian dollars through an External Account, or in any currency other than Israel, Rhodesian, and South African currencies. Receipts from exports to countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa must be obtained, within six months from the date of exportation, either in Malaysian dollars obtained from the sale of a specified currency to a bank in Malaysia, or in any specified currency. Special regulations apply to settlements with Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa. Nonresident Accounts The accounts in Malaysian dollars of residents of countries other than Malaysia are treated as nonresi- dent accounts and, unless specially restricted, are desig- nated External Accounts. There are no restrictions on debits to External Accounts. Credits to these accounts for whatever purpose are freely permitted subject only to the completion of exchange control forms for amounts above M$ 1,000; the proceeds from the sale of any foreign currency may be credited to External Ac- counts. For amounts exceeding M$ 1,000 and up to M$l million, permission may be given by commercial banks; above M$l million, permission is given by the Controller of Foreign Exchange. Balances on External Accounts may be transferred to any other account, whether resident or nonresident, and may be converted into any currency except Israel, Rhodesian, and South African currencies. Accounts of residents of Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are designated as Israel Accounts, Rhodesian Accounts, and South African Accounts, respectively. All debits and credits to such accounts require prior approval. Imports and Import Payments Tariffs and import controls of the various parts of Malaysia have not yet been fully unified, although steps toward unification are being taken. Some internal tar- i f fs and other trade restrictions still exist between the territories of Malaysia. Most imports are permitted freely. Depending on the nature and origin of the goods, specific licenses are required for certain imports for health, security, or moral reasons; various condi- tions must be satisfied before licenses for such goods are issued. Certain other imports are subject to quanti- tative restrictions as a temporary measure to protect local industries; these restrictions are reviewed from time to time. Imports into all parts of Malaysia of all commodities from Israel, South Africa, Rhodesia, or any territory administered by any one of these are prohibited. Im- ports into all parts of Malaysia of all commodities from the People's Republic of China are prohibited except under specific license, and applications to import must be submitted through PERNAS. Imports into all parts of Malaysia of all commodities from the German Demo- cratic Republic and North Korea also require specific licenses. Imports into West Malaysia of primates from all sources, including Sabah and Sarawak, are prohibited except under specific license; imports of other live ani- mals (except sheep and goats), bones, and bone meal from Brunei, Burma, Indonesia, the Khmer Republic, Laos, Thailand, and Viet-Nam also require a specific license. Imports into Sarawak of sulphur, certain chem- icals, and live sheep and goats from all sources, includ- ing West Malaysia and Sabah, are prohibited, except under specific license. Imports of motor vehicles and certain types of textiles into all parts of Malaysia are also subject to specific import licensing; however, im- ports of textiles into Sabah and Sarawak are allowed 317 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAYSIA freely. Imports of wheat flour, bran, and sugar2 from all sources are subject to quantitative restrictions for protective reasons; licenses for wheat flour and refined sugar are not being issued. Other goods subject to quantitative restriction in West Malaysia include rolled oats, certain cotton fabrics, jute, and fu l ly assembled or completely built-up motor vehicles. Payment for per- mitted imports is freely allowed after exchange control requirements have been met. Virtually all imports into Malaysia (including Pe- nang but excluding Labuan) are subject to a surtax of 4 per cent ad valorem. Some essential goods, such as rice, common salt, and kerosene, are exempt, and a drawback may be granted on goods intended for re-export or for export after processing. In addition, most imports into Malaysia (excluding Penang and La- buan) are subject to a sales tax; the standard rate of tax is 5 per cent ad valorem, but certain luxury goods are subject to a rate of 10 per cent ad valorem. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa may be made freely after exchange control requirements have been met. There are no restrictions on the amount of foreign ex- change made available for travel abroad. Remittances to nonresidents of dividends, interest, and prof i ts on all bona fide investments are freely permitted, subject only to the completion of exchange control forms for amounts in excess of M$ 1,000. Unless special permis- sion is obtained, not more than M$ 1,000 in Malaysian notes and the equivalent of M$ 1,000 in foreign notes may be taken out of Malaysia by travelers. Nonresident travelers are allowed to take out foreign currency notes up to the amount declared upon en try. Exports and Export Proceeds The three territories of Malaysia at present maintain separate export control systems, although the Federal Government retains the right to legislate in respect of exports from any Malaysian territory. Exchange con- trol forms have to be completed and authorized by banks in Malaysia for exports valued at M$5,000 f.o.b. or more.3 Proceeds f rom exports must be received within six mon ths of shipment either in a specified currency or in Malaysian dollars obtained from the sale of a specified currency to a bank in Malaysia. Exports of rubber from West Malaysia require a certificate is- sued by the Malaysian Rubber Exchange and Licensing Board. Exports of rubber and tin to South Africa and any territory administered by South Africa are prohib- ited, as are exports of sugar to any destination. All exports to Israel and Rhodesia and any terr i tory ad- ministered by either are also prohibited. Exports of cement, scrap iron, steel bars, formic acid, wheat f lou r, rice bran, and sugar are subject to licensing, and li- censes for these are administratively denied. Exports of 318 certain confectionery items, tiles, fish meal, and bricks are also subject to licensing. Proceeds from Invisibles The exchange control requirements governing ex- change receipts from invisibles are, in general, the same as those for export proceeds. Travelers may bring in up to M$ 1,000 in Malaysian currency notes; otherwise, permission is required for the import of Malaysian notes. No limitations are imposed on the import by travelers of currency notes of other countries. Capital Inward investment covered by the Guidelines issued on February 20, 1974 regarding the acquisition of as- sets, mergers, and take-overs requires prior approval by the Foreign Investment Committee. The proceeds of investments may be repatriated freely on resale, subject to the completion of exchange control forms for amounts above M$ 1,000. Malaysian residents require approval for borrowings from nonresidents in either Malaysian dollars or in foreign currencies. Companies in Malaysia controlled by nonresidents are permitted to borrow in Malaysia up to M$500,000 without exchange control approval. The permission of the Controller of Foreign Exchange is freely given for direct and portfo- lio investment by Malaysian residents in countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa. Gold Residents other than authorized dealers in gold are not permitted to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than gold that has been materially increased in value by skilled craftsmanship. The manufacture, import, or export of gold coins is prohibited, as is do- mestic t rad ing in gold coins other than the M$100 gold coin of Malaysian currency and the S$ 150 gold coin of Singapore currency. Resident and nonresident travel- ers, however, may freely bring in or take out, on their person, one M$100 gold coin. In addition, each traveler is allowed to bring in from any country outside Malay- sia one S$ 150 gold coin issued by the Singapore Board of Commissioners of Currency, and each traveler may take out one such coin, but only to Singapore. Licensed goldsmiths are permitted by the exchange control au- thorities to purchase certain quantities of gold from an authorized dealer at local free market prices for the manufacture of bona fide jewelry and ornaments. Fur- thermore, producers of gold are permitted to sell their output at local free market prices to authorized dealers in gold. Imports of gold are restricted under the Customs Act, 1967, and require licenses from the Ministry of Trade and Indu s t ry. Permission for imports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler is not normally given except for imports by authorized dealers in gold to meet the genu- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ine requirements of goldsmiths for manufacturing jew- elry and ornaments and for industrial use. Imports are allocated to authorized dealers in gold by means of a tender system; successful tenderers must pay a pre- mium to the Government. Imports are subject to a 2 per cent import duty and a 4 per cent surtax (suspended until December 31, 1975), as well as a sales tax of 10 per cent ad valorem. Domestic transactions in gold or gold ornaments are subject only to the sales tax, at 10 per cent ad valorem. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a trav- eler are prohibited under the exchange control regula- tions. Changes during 1974 February 20. Guidelines were issued regulating the acquisition of assets or interests in Malaysia, as well as mergers and take-overs of companies and businesses in Malaysia. These would not normally be permitted un- less they led to a more balanced Malaysian participa- tion in ownership and control that would conform to the objectives of the New Economic Policy proclaimed in 1971. The Guidelines applied to any proposed acqui- sition by foreign interests of any substantial fixed assets in Malaysia and to any merger or take-over of compa- nies and businesses in Malaysia, whether by Malaysian or foreign interests. They did not apply to specific projects approved by the Government. Within the framework of the Guidelines, foreign investment in Malaysia would continue to be encouraged. For the purpose of implementing the Guidelines, a Foreign In- vestment Committee was established on the same date. Approval from the committee would be needed for the following: (1) any proposed acquisition by foreign in- terests of any substantial fixed assets in Malaysia; (2) any proposed acquisition of assets or any interests, mergers, and take-overs of companies and businesses in Malaysia by any means, which would result in owner- ship or control passing to foreign interests; (3) any proposed acquisition of 15 per cent or more of the voting power by any one foreign interest or associated group, or by foreign interests in the aggregate of 30 per cent or more of the voting power of a Malaysian com- pany or business; (4) control of Malaysian companies MALAYSIA and businesses through any form of joint venture agree- ment, management agreement, technical assistance agreement, or other arrangements; (5) any merger or take-over of any company or business in Malaysia, whether by Malaysian or foreign interests; and (6) any other proposed acquisition of assets or interests exceed- ing in value M$l million, whether by Malaysian or foreign interests. March L The licensing requirement for imports of completely knocked down passenger automobiles, buses, and motorcycles previously applicable only in West Malaysia was extended to Sabah and Sarawak. March 12. Restrictions were formally applied to the making of payments and transfers between residents of Malaysia and residents of Israel. Imports from and exports to Israel were prohibited. April 1. Unless otherwise specified, the value date for spot exchange transactions henceforth was two work- ing days after the transaction date. July 18. Major rubber exporters and owners of large rubber estates agreed to reduce their rubber sales by 10 per cent for an initial period of one month. Subse- quently, these arrangements were extended indefinitely. Also, on November 28 they were supplemented by stock-building requirements for packers, remillers, and exporters, as part of a six-point national program to stabilize rubber prices. August 15. The Investment Incentives (Amendment) Act, 1974 amended the Investment Incentives Act, 1968. October 10. Additional tax incentives for exports of manufactured goods were introduced by the Income Tax (Promotion of Exports) (Amendment) Rules, 1974. October 16. Imports into West Malaysia of certain woven fabrics of man-made fibers from all sources re- quired a specific license. Not for Redistribution MALI (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System No par value for the currency of Mali has been estab- lished with the Fund. The official un it of currency is the Mali Franc, which is officially maintained at the rate of MF 1 = 0.01 French franc. There is also a fixed rate for CFA francs of MF 2 = CFAF 1. Exchange rates for other currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned. With the exception of those relating to gold, Mali's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Mali itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only w i th foreign countries are subject to ex- change control. Administration of Control The Minister of Finance has sole au tho r i ty in ex- change control matters; certain exchange control pow- ers have been delegated to authorized banks. The bilateral paymen ts agreements are operated by the De- velopment Bank of Mali. Licenses for impor ts and ex- ports are issued by the Directorate-General of Economic A f f a i rs in the M in is t ry of Commerce. Ex- change control is applicable on ly to foreign countries. Prescription of Currency Settlements on account of transactions covered by bilateral payments arrangements are made in curren- cies and through accounts established under such agreements. Bilateral accounts are maintained with the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, the Ger- man Democratic Republic, Egypt, Hunga ry, Morocco, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and No r th Viet- Nam.1 Mali is an Operations Account coun t ry of the French Franc Area, since its Central Bank ma in ta ins an Opera- tions Account w i th the French Treasury; settlements w i th France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in Mali francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account coun t ry. Settlements with all other countries w i th which no pay- ments agreement is in force are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies 320 of those countries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are, in principle, based on those applied in France. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few commodities are prohibited for health, safety, and similar reasons, and licenses are not normally issued for certain other goods. Imports of all other goods, irrespective of origin, require individual licenses, and imports from foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank. Imports are licensed in accordance with an annual import program. The program consists of two parts: an allocation for clearing countries and one for the con- vertible area (defined as comprising all other countries, including the French Franc Area). Certain aid-financed imports are not included in the import program and do not require an import license. Imports may be made either by private importers or by state enterprises, among which the Societe Malienne de 1'Import-Export (SOMIEX) is by far the most impor- tan t, hav ing a monopoly over the import of a number of items.2 All imports from and exports to countries that have payments agreements with Mali are made by SOMIEX or UNICOOP. The Office des Produits Agricoles du Mali (OPAM) has a monopoly over the import of cereals. An allocation commission establishes quotas for each private importer on the basis of his turnover. Im- port licenses are issued to the private importer up to the l im it of the quota accorded to him. In addition, import- ers may w i th an import license import any goods under the EXIC (Exportation et Importation Concomitante) procedure. The authorized banks are permitted to make foreign exchange available for all licensed imports. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above) and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to approval. Payments for invisi- bles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresi- dents in the form of prof i ts, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely. For tourist travel, residents traveling to countries other than France (as defined above) and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to MF 150,000 a person, which may be ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution taken up twice a year; any foreign exchange remaining after return to Mali must be surrendered. For business travel, there is a special allocation of the equivalent of MF 40,000 a day, subject to a maximum of MF 400,000 a trip.3 The transfer of the entire salary of a foreigner working in Mali is permitted upon presenta- tion of the appropriate pay voucher, provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period. Resident travelers, irrespective of destination, may take out up to a maximum of MF 50,000 in Mali banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries (MF 5,000 for trips of less than 24 hours). Nonresident travelers may freely take out foreign banknotes up to the equivalent of MF 150,000; higher amounts may be taken out only if declared upon entry. They may also take out MF 50,000 in Mali banknotes and any payments instruments drawn up abroad in their name. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank, and export proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Oper- ations Account country must be surrendered; export proceeds must normally be collected and repatriated within 90 days after the arrival of the goods at their destination. Exports require individual licenses in order to ensure the repatriation of export proceeds. The ex- port of cotton, groundnuts, meat, and hides and skins is reserved in principle for SOMIEX and the Societe Ma- lienne du Detail et des Peaux et Cuirs (SOMBEPEC); in practice, hides and skins may also be exported by pri- vate firms and individuals. Under the EXIC procedure, exporters may retain 75 per cent of proceeds from exports of commodities of the traditional sector except those covered by the monop- oly of state trading companies, for payment for their own imports that are made through regular official channels. Balances on EXIC accounts and import rights under the EXIC procedure are not transferable. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above) and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the Central Bank of Mali, the Bank of France, or a bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. MALI Capital Capital movements between Mali, France (as defined above), and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (in addition to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad; the Development Bank of Mali is exempt. The special control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above) or to countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account. Under an Investment Code of May 23, 1969 and Law No. 62 of January 15, 1962, the Government may grant special privileged status, providing for transfer, tax, and other preferential treatment to foreign invest- ments that would be of special interest to the Malian economy and that are compatible with the goals of the Economic Plan. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Mali for numismatic purposes and for ornaments. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authori- ties and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted. Changes during 1974 January 19. The fixed exchange rate of MF 1 = F 0.01 was maintained following the announcement of the French authorities that during the next six months, and on a provisional basis, the interventions of the Exchange Stabilization Fund in the official exchange market would no longer aim at limiting the exchange rates between the French franc and certain other cur- rencies within predetermined margins. March 21. Following the abolition of the dual ex- change market in France, the dual market arrange- ments in Mali also ceased to operate. The financial franc market and the Financial Accounts in Francs were abolished and settlements with countries outside the French Franc Area henceforth took place only through the official exchange market and through For- eign Accounts in Francs. No exchange control regula- tions to this effect were issued in Mali. June 6. Exports of oils (refined or unrefined), groundnuts, and soap were suspended for the rest of 1974. September 10. Notice of termination was given of the bilateral payments agreement with Czechoslovakia. The agreement expired on December 31. 321 ©International Monetary Fund.
