Not for Redistribution MALTA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Malta pound. In December 1971 a central rate of 2.18613 grams of fine gold per Malta pound was established, corresponding at the time to £M 0.374412 = US$1, or £M 0.406504 = SDR 1 and Malta avails itself of wider margins. However, as at the end of 1974, the prescribed margins were not being observed for the time being, and the Central Bank of Malta quoted daily rates for sterling based on developments in the princi- pal exchange markets abroad. l The Central Bank's basic rate for the pound sterling on December 31, 1974 was £ stg. 113.75 buying, and £ stg. 113.50 selling, per £M 100. The commercial banks' rates for non-Ster- ling Area currencies are based on London market rates for sterling against other currencies. Indicative buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were US$2.6744 and US$2.6626 per £M 1. Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Central Bank as agent for the Minister of Finance and Cus- toms; trade controls are administered by the Director of Trade in the Ministry of Trade, Industry, Agricul- ture, and Tourism. Certain authorities to approve ap- plications for the allocation of foreign exchange have been delegated to the authorized banks. Prescription of Currency Malta has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations Malta continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Authorized payments to all countries may be made by crediting Malta pounds to an External Account or in any foreign currency; 2 the proceeds of exports to all countries may be received in Malta pounds from an External Account or in any foreign currency. Nonresident Accounts Residents of all countries outside Malta may main- tain with authorized banks nonresident accounts in Malta pounds, designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited freely with authorized pay- ments by nonresidents, with transfers from other Exter- nal Accounts, with the proceeds from sales of gold or any foreign currency (including banknotes), and with Malta banknotes mailed from outside Malta. External Accounts may be debited freely for payments to resi- dents, for transfers to other External Accounts, for payments in cash in Malta, and for purchases of any foreign currency (including banknotes). Authorized dealers may also freely open and main- tain foreign currency accounts for nonresidents. These accounts may be credited with payments in foreign currency to the account holder, with transfers from another foreign currency account belonging to a non- resident, and with interest payable on foreign currency accounts. They may be debited for payments by the account holder to residents, for transfers to other for- eign currency accounts, and for transfers abroad. Blocked Accounts in Malta pounds are maintained for nonresidents of Malta for certain funds of a capital nature which, under the existing exchange control regu- lations, may not be transferred outside Malta. The principal type of funds that must be credited to a Blocked Account are assets of emigrants in excess of the amount that may be transferred to the new country of residence; the remaining funds are normally released four years after the date of departure on application to the Central Bank. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain commodities manufactured in Malta are either prohibited or restricted. All imports from Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, North Korea, Poland, Rhodesia, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and North Viet- Nam are subject to specific licensing, as are imports of some 100 items from any country of origin. Imports from countries other than those mentioned that are not prohibited and do not require a specific license may be made freely under open general license. Payments for all authorized imports may be made freely, provided that the prescription of currency regulations are com- plied with and that supporting documents, including the customs entry form, are submitted to the intermedi- ary bank. Advance payments for imports may be made against the invoice if the goods are to arrive within six months but otherwise require Central Bank approval. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles in excess of £M 50 re- quire the approval of the exchange control authorities; the approval authority has been delegated to autho- rized banks for certain types of payment. There is a standard exchange allocation for tourist travel of the equivalent of £M 250 a person a trip; a business travel allowance of £M 250 or £M 30 a day (for up to 30 days a trip), whichever is the larger; and an allowance for educational expenses abroad of £M 2,000 a person for an academic year. 3 Applications for allowances in ex- cess of these amounts are approved by the Central Bank if the latter is satisfied that there is no illicit capital outflow involved. 323 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALTA The transfer of genuine profits, dividends, and inter- est for approved foreign investments requires Central Bank permission, which is normally given, after com- pliance with certain formalities. Life insurance ex- pressed in Malta currency may be contracted with nonresidents lawfully engaged in insurance business in Malta, provided the policy is made for a term exceeding five years and is not linked to equity or property units. Maintenance remittances to beneficiaries abroad are allowed on application accompanied by documentary evidence of hardship; authorized banks may also ap- prove moderate remittances for family living expenses. Travelers may export Malta banknotes and coins up to £M 25 for each person. Exports of foreign currencies may be made by resident travelers up to £M 250 for each person and by nonresident travelers up to the amount brought in. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of works of art and strategic war materials are prohibited and, with the exception of some 80 items that may be exported freely, all other exports are sub- ject to specific licensing. The proceeds of exports are subject to surrender within six months of shipment. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Travelers may bring in any amount in Malta and other currency notes. Capital No control is exercised over receipts. Receipts in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an autho- rized bank, and payments of a capital nature in such currencies require prior approval. Applications for out- ward direct investment by residents of Malta and for direct investment in Malta by nonresidents are consid- ered on their merits. The purchase of real estate in Malta is controlled by the Immovable Property (Acqui- sition by Non-Residents) Act, 1974. This Act, which is administered by the Ministry of Finance, prohibits the acquisition of immovable property in Malta by nonresi- dents, with the exception of certain special cases which would be mainly related to the economic development of Malta. Purchases of all securities issued outside Malta require prior permission from the authorities. However, the Central Bank has delegated to authorized dealers the authority to approve the acquisition of secu- rities abroad up to the equivalent of £M 500 a person a calendar year by resident persons over 18. Purchases of personal real estate situated outside Malta require prior exchange control approval and are not normally permitted to resident nationals. Foreign nationals who repatriate or take up resi- dence outside Malta normally are allowed to transfer all their assets to their new country of residence; in certain circumstances, however, restrictions may be 324 placed on foreign assets acquired, other than by way of income or capital appreciation, while the person has been resident in Malta. Maltese nationals who emigrate may transfer abroad up to £M 5,000 for each family; any excess amount is normally released four years after the date of departure on application to the Central Bank. Banks, other than those licensed to borrow and lend outside Malta only, are restricted in the acquisition of net foreign assets. Gold Malta has issued six gold coins which are legal tender. Residents other than authorized banks and reg- istered jewelers are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than coins or jewelry, at home or abroad. Residents may freely purchase, sell, and hold any gold coins. The import of gold coins for numis- matic purposes is controlled to ensure that such coins are genuinely for numismatic purposes. A specific im- port license is required for imports of gold coins, gold bullion, and manufactured or semimanufactured arti- cles of gold; imports of filigree work of gold or silver are prohibited. Authorized importers are permitted to import gold (bullion and coins) only for the purpose of disposing of it to jewelers and other industrial users. The export of gold by residents other than the mone- tary authorities requires the permission of the exchange control authorities. Gold bullion and gold coins are free of import duty. Changes during 1974 During the year a number of items were added to the list of commodities requiring specific import licenses. January 7. The Central Bank delegated to authorized dealers the power to approve new outward portfolio investment by resident private individuals, within the limits previously applied by the Central Bank. At the same time, the minimum qualifying age for the invest- ment facility was reduced from 21 years to 18 years. January 30. The Central Bank began to compute the exchange rate of the Malta pound on the basis of a revised formula. While the Malta pound continued to be pegged to a "basket" of currencies rather than to any single currency, the U.S. dollar now was included di- rectly in this basket. March 20. The Minister of Finance and Customs, acting under the terms of Section 38 of the Central Bank of Malta Act, 1967, determined the par value of the Malta pound to be 2.13281 grams of fine gold, and, on the recommendation of the Central Bank and with the consent of the Prime Minister, suspended the par value of the Malta pound. August 5. The Immovable Property (Acquisition by Non-Residents) Act, 1974 prohibited, with minor ex- ceptions, the acquisition of immovable property on the Maltese Islands by nonresidents. ©International Monetary Fund. MALTA 325 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAURITANIA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Mauritania has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the Ouguiya, which is defined as equivalent to 0.016 gram of fine gold. Since January 22, 1974 the Central Bank of Mauritania has quoted daily buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar and 16 other currencies1 on the basis of variations in the relationship between the U.S. dollar and selected European currencies. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Central Bank and the Minister of Finance. The former also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Mauritania, inward direct investment and all outward investment, the purchase abroad of domestic and foreign securities, and the solicitation of funds in Mauritania for place- ment in foreign countries. The approval authority in respect of exchange control has been delegated to the Central Bank, which in turn has delegated some ap- proval authority to authorized banks. The Central Bank is authorized to collect, either direct or through the intermediary of the banks and the Postal Adminis- tration, any information necessary to compile the bal- ance of payments statistics. All exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks or, in some cases, through the Postal Administration (PTT). Import and export licenses are issued by the Foreign Trade Department in the Minis- try of Commerce which also issues import certificates. All import licenses and import certificates require ex- change control approval by the Central Bank. The Na- tional Import and Export Corporation (SONIMEX) has a monopoly over imports of sugar, tea, rice, and certain textiles and over exports of gum arabic. Prescription of Currency All settlements with Israel, Portugal, and South Af- rica are prohibited. Settlements with other countries usually take place in convertible currencies. Nonresident Accounts There are two kinds of nonresident accounts in do- mestic currency: Convertible Accounts, which may only be credited with proceeds from the sale of foreign currency or transfers from other Convertible Accounts, and Internal Nonresident Accounts, which may be credited with domestic banknotes. Convertible Ac- counts may be debited without Central Bank approval for any payment inside or outside Mauritania. 326 Imports and Import Payments Imports of Israel, Portuguese, and South African origin and /or provenance are prohibited. The import of a few goods is prohibited from any source for reasons of health or public policy. Imports from all non-EEC countries require an import license, while imports from EEC countries need an import certificate. Only holders of importer-exporter cards are permitted to engage in import transactions. SONIMEX has a monopoly over the import of sugar, rice, green tea, percales, and Guinea cloth. Import transactions relating to countries of the French Franc Area must be domiciled with an autho- rized bank when their value exceeds UM 20,000, and import transactions relating to other foreign countries when their value exceeds UM 4,000. After the approval of the Central Bank has been obtained, the import license or import certificate entitles the importer to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported. Advance payments for imports require prior approval by the Central Bank. There are special arrangements for im- ports in border areas. Payments for Invisibles Payments to Israel, Portugal, and South Africa are prohibited. Payments for invisibles to other countries are subject to the approval of the Central Bank, which has delegated its approval authority for certain speci- fied payments and subject to conditions laid down in circulars, to authorized banks. Basic exchange allocations have been established for various types of invisibles. For tourist travel, residents traveling to any foreign country may obtain an annual exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to UM 10,000 a person (UM 5,000 for children under ten). There are special arrangements for travel to neigh- boring countries. The use of all travel allocations must be marked in a personal travel exchange booklet (cornet de change). The transfer of savings from salaries by foreigners working in Mauritania is permitted up to varying percentages, according to family status. Travel- ers are not allowed to take out domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel, Portugal, and South Africa are prohibited. Only holders of importer-exporter cards are permitted to engage in export transactions. Export transactions to all countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds UM 5,000. Exporters must sign an undertaking to repatriate and surrender the foreign exchange proceeds (engagement ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution de change). Exports to all countries require an export license and the approval (visa) of the Central Bank. Export proceeds must be surrendered not later than the due date of the payment, which must not normally be more than 60 days after shipment. Exports of gum arabic are the monopoly of SONIMEX. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles must be sur- rendered. All amounts due from nonresidents in respect of services and all income earned abroad from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date of the payment. The importa- tion of domestic banknotes by travelers is prohibited. Capital Transfers of capital between Mauritania and Israel, Portugal, and South Africa are prohibited. Capital movements between Mauritania and all foreign countries are subject to exchange control; capital trans- fers to all countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts normally are permitted freely, although the subsequent investment of the funds in Mauritania may require approval, as indicated below. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, over the issuing, advertis- ing, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Mauritania, and over the solicitation of funds in Mauritania for placement in foreign countries; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. All investments abroad by residents of Mauritania require prior authorization by the Central Bank. For- eign direct investments in Mauritania2 and Maurita- nian direct investments abroad,3 must be declared to the Central Bank before they are made. The Central Bank has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which it may request the postpone- ment of the projects submitted to it. The full or partial liquidation of inward or outward investment also re- quires declaration. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Mauritanian invest- ments abroad or foreign investments in Mauritania, must be reported to the Central Bank within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are de- fined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as di- rect investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of for- eign securities in Mauritania requires prior authoriza- tion by the Central Bank. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection with loans MAURITANIA backed by a guarantee from the Mauritanian Govern- ment. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Central Bank. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans con- tracted by authorized banks; and (3) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount out- standing of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed UM 10 million for any one borrower and provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authorization of the Central Bank if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Furthermore, such prior approval is required for the repayment of all amounts borrowed abroad prior to the publication of Decree No. 72.249 of November 27, 1972. Lending abroad is subject only to exchange control authorization. Domestic bank credit is restricted. The Investment Code (Law No. 71-028 of Feb- ruary 2, 1971) provides for various benefits for private investments in Mauritania. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Mauritania. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the Central Bank. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by the Central Bank, and (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles). Changes during 1974 January 1. By virtue of agreements signed with these companies in January and February, the export pro- ceeds of MIFERMA and SOMIMA became subject to repa- triation and surrender. Each was entitled to a monthly foreign exchange allocation and their exchange require- ments in excess of these allocations would be approved upon application. January 15. Central Bank Circular No. 74 /1 pro- vided that authorized banks must buy from and sell to the Central Bank the full amounts of foreign currency negotiated during the day for the account of their cus- tomers, instead of only the balance of such transac- tions, as previously. January 22. The fixed relationship between the ou- guiya and the French franc of UM 1 = F 0.10 was discontinued. Henceforth a daily rate was set for the U.S. dollar, on the basis of variations of the quotations of the U.S. dollar in terms of a "basket" of European currencies. Exchange rates for 16 other currencies, including the "basket" currencies, were based on quotations for the U.S. dollar and the currencies 327 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAURITANIA concerned in international markets. For banknotes, the previous fixed rates for French francs, CFA francs, and Mali francs were maintained. January 24. Law No. 74.022 concerning financial relations with foreign countries and their statistical registration replaced Law No. 73.137 of June 18, 1973 concerning financial relations with foreign countries. The new law consolidated the existing regime. It restated the requirement of prior approval by the Central Bank for all foreign exchange transactions (unless such authority was specifically delegated to the banks) and the surrender requirement for all foreign claims. The import and export of Mauritanian banknotes and coins and the holding by residents of any means of payment in foreign currencies was prohibited without the prior authorization of the Central Bank. April L The Central Bank changed the transfer and exchange commissions that authorized banks could charge to 1.5 per cent and 0.25 per cent, respectively. May 28. Ministry of Finance Circular No. 4 regulated exports. All exports required prior authorization by the Ministry of Commerce; the approval of the Central Bank; registration of the export transaction with an authorized bank if the transaction exceeded UM 5,000; an undertaking by the exporter to repatriate the foreign exchange proceeds; and the ap- proval of that undertaking by the authorized bank. June 21. The limits on salary remittances established on August 8, 1973 by Instruction No. 6 were in- creased. The period within which such transfers could be made was extended from one month to six months after receipt. June 25. Central Bank Circular No. 74 /3 specified the provisions subject to which authorized banks could from July 1 open and conduct Foreign Accounts in Convertible Foreign Currency on behalf of foreign em- bassies, etc. July 1. Central Bank Circular No. 74 /4 regulated transfers in respect of transportation by air. Resident travelers could freely pay in ouguiyas their air passages to any destination, including round-trip tickets. July 2. Central Bank Note No. 74/17 introduced a more flexible system for the sale of foreign exchange for business travel, consisting of nine annual limits that ranged from the equivalent of UM 50,000 to the equiv- alent of UM 350,000, depending on the applicant's business turnover. The basic allocation (a person a trip) was fixed at the equivalent of UM 3,000 for each day abroad, up to a maximum of UM 40,000 a trip. Appli- cants were required to use a foreign exchange booklet for business travel. November 28. The nationalization of MIFERMA was announced. Not for Redistribution MAURITIUS (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.159961 gram of fine gold per Mauritian Rupee. No transactions take place at the par value. The official rate for sterling is Mau Re 1 = £ stg. 0.075, and the currency issuing authority, the Bank of Mauritius, maintains fixed rates for sterling of Mau Rs 13.312/3 buying, and Mau Rs 13.362/3 sell- ing, per £ stg. 1. Consequently, the Mauritian rupee is floating with sterling, and all exchange transactions except those in sterling or currencies linked to sterling take place at fluctuating rates. Commercial banks are authorized to deal with customers in sterling at spot rates based on the rates of the Bank of Mauritius and in other foreign currencies1 at rates based on the Lon- don market rates. The commercial banks' rates for ster- ling on December 31, 1974 were Mau Rs 13.25 buying and Mau Rs 13.40 selling per £ stg. 1, and for the U.S. dollar the rates were Mau Rs 5.63 buying and Mau Rs 5.74 selling (for transactions in excess of US$12,000). A different effective rate results from the application of a stamp du ty of 35.70 per cent to out- ward capital transfers other than transfers of banking funds and to payments for gold coins and gold bullion. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Mauritius under powers delegated to it by the Financial Secretary. The authority for approving practically all current payments is in turn delegated to the commer- cial banks. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry is responsible for the issue of import and export licenses, where required. Prescription of Currency Mauritius has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. For prescription of currency purposes Mauritius distinguishes between Sterling Area countries2 and External Account countries. Payments to residents of Sterling Area countries may be made in rupees to a Sterling Area Account in Mauritius or in any Sterling Area currency. Payments from residents of the Sterling Area may be received in rupees from a Sterling Area Account in Mauritius or in any currency of the Sterling Area. Payments to residents of countries outside the Sterling Area may be made in rupees to a Sterling Area Account or an External Account in Mau- ritius, in sterling to an External Account in the United Kingdom, or in any non-Sterling Area currency other than Rhodesian currency. Payments from residents of countries outside the Sterling Area may be received in rupees from an External Account in Mauritius, in ster- ling from an External Account in the United Kingdom, or in any non-Sterling Area currency other than Rho- desian currency. Special regulations apply to settle- ments with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts There are two main types of nonresident accounts: Sterling Area Accounts and External Accounts. Sterling Area Accounts, which may be opened by persons and firms resident in countries of the Sterling Area,2 may be credited with (1) authorized payments by residents of Mauritius; (2) any transfers from other Sterling Area Accounts; (3) any payments from Exter- nal Accounts held in Mauritius or elsewhere in the Sterling Area; and (4) the proceeds of the sale to an authorized dealer of any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or gold by nonresidents of Mauri- tius. They may be debited for (1) payments from resi- dents of the Sterling Area to residents of Mauritius; (2) transfers to other Sterling Area Accounts; (3) transfers to External Accounts in Mauritius or elsewhere in the Sterling Area in respect of which the permission of the exchange control authorities in the appropriate Sterling Area country has been given; and (4) the cost of pur- chase of any Sterling Area currency. External Accounts may be opened by persons and firms resident outside both Mauritius and the Sterling Area. They may be credited with (1) authorized pay- ments by residents of Mauritius; (2) payments from Sterling Area Accounts in respect of which the permis- sion of the exchange control authorities of the appropri- ate Sterling Area country has been given; (3) any transfers from other External Accounts; and (4) the proceeds of the sale to an authorized dealer of any non-Sterling Area currency (other than Rhodesian cur- rency) or gold by nonresidents of Mauritius and the Sterling Area. They may be debited for (1) any pay- ments to residents of Mauritius; (2) any transfers to Sterling Area Accounts; (3) any transfers to other Ex- ternal Accounts; and (4) the cost of purchase of any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or gold. In addition to the above, there are also Blocked Ac- counts to which are credited funds owned by persons and firms resident outside Mauritius realized from in- vestments made by them prior to April 5, 1966, as well as funds representing emigrants' assets in excess of Mau Rs 67,000. Such accounts may be credited with payments by residents of Mauritius that have been spe- cifically authorized for credit to a Blocked Account and may be debited for certain specified transactions. Funds from Blocked Accounts may, with approval, be invested in Mauritius. Upon the realization of such investments, the proceeds are directed once more to a Blocked Account. 329 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAURITIUS Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. There is a list of commodities for which a specific license from the Ministry of Commerce and Industry is required regard- less of origin. All other goods may be freely imported under open general licenses granted to individual trad- ers when imported from countries of the Sterling Area (as defined before June 23, 1972), but most of these goods require a specific license when imported f rom non-Sterling Area countries. General licenses are granted liberally. Specific licenses are issued on the basis of domestic requirements. The issue of a general or specific license automatically carries w i th it ex- change control authority to make the corresponding import payments, subject to compliance w i th the pre- scription of currency regulations. Certain impo r ts are subject to temporary customs surcharges. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain l im i ts, for certain other purposes such as travel, is provided by the commercial banks w i thout prior reference to the exchange control au thor- ities. The basic travel allowance for tourist purposes is the equ iva lent of £400 a person a year for travel to any coun try except Rhodesia. The allowance for business travel is the equ iva lent of £250 a tr ip or £20 a day up to a maximum of £1,000 a trip for travel to countries of the Sterling Area (as defined before June 23, 1972), or up to a total of £750 a trip for travel to countries outside the S ter l ing Area. Applications for exchange for business travel are examined by the Bank of Mauri- tius when exceeding the equivalent of £250 a person a trip. There are also established limits for payments and t ran s fe rs to Sterling Area countries and to non -S te r l ing Area countries in respect of fam i ly support, salary re- mittances by non-Maur i t ian nationals, t rade commis- sions, subscriptions to clubs and societies, publishing rights, adve r t is ing outside Mau r i t iu s, royalties, profes- sional and technical services, education, and leave sala- r ies. App l ica t ions for amoun ts exceeding the s tanda rd allocations may be submitted to the exchange control authorities. Residents and nonresident travelers may take out Mau Rs 350 in domestic cu r rency. Resident trave lers may take out foreign currency notes up to the amount of their travel allowance. Nonresident trave lers may take out any foreign currency declared upon en try. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Also prohibited, unless permission is obtained f rom the Financial Secre- tary, are exports of (1) articles made wholly or partially of gold, p l a t i n um, or silver; (2) diamonds, precious and semiprecious stones, pearls, and articles moun ted w i th these; and (3) wo rks of a r t. All exports valued at more 330 than Mau Rs 1,000 and all exports of food valued at over Mau Rs 50 require a license from the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. The Mauritius Sugar Syndi- cate is the sole exporter of sugar, and a 6-10 per cent export tax is levied on sugar exports. All export pro- ceeds in any currency other than Mauritian rupees must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer. How- ever, permission may be given to large export-import companies to retain export proceeds for a reasonable period of time to meet payments for imports. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any currency other than Mauritian rupees must be offered for sale to an autho- rized bank. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes and coins that may be imported, but not more than Mau Rs 700 in domestic currency notes and coins may be imported by travelers. Capital Inwa rd transfers of capital are not restricted. Out- ward transfers of capital are subject to certain restric- tions. Nonbank residents of Mauritius may transfer a reasonable amount of capital to any country in the Sterling Area2 on payment of a 35.70 per cent stamp du ty (a d u ty of 34 per cent plus a surcharge of 5 per cent thereon); they may, subject to permission, which is free ly granted, also transfer a reasonable amount of capital to External Account Area countries on payment of the s tamp du ty. Nonresidents require permission to t ran s fer capital to any coun try; transfers are subject to the payment of stamp du ty at the rate of 35.70 per cent and, if directed toward a country outside the Sterling Area by a resident of the Sterling Area, require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities of the Sterling Area coun t ry concerned. Foreign-owned companies may free ly transfer abroad dividends, prof- its, and interest on capital. Permission for the repatria- tion of capital is not granted for capital brought in before April 5, 1966, irrespective of the coun try of ori- gin, but is, in normal circumstances, given for capital b rought in on or a f ter that date. Proceeds from the sale, liquidation, etc., of foreign capital that may not be repatriated must be credited to Blocked Accounts. Emigrants may take out, at the official rate of ex- change and free of s tamp d u t y, the equivalent of Mau Rs 67,000 from their Mauritian assets when emigrating to any coun t ry except Rhodesia; this facility is available upon redesignation as a nonresident, which occurs upon depar ture. The balance of an emigrant's funds must be credited for an indefinite period to a Blocked Account; any releases that may be approved for trans- fer abroad are subject to payment of the 35.70 per cent s tamp d u t y. Persons em igra t ing from Mauritius are not entitled to draw their personal travel allowance in addi- tion to the emigration facilities. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Gold Residents other than the monetary authorities are permitted to hold gold in the form of numismatic coins (including a commemorative gold coin of Mau Rs 200 issued by Mauritius in 1971) or personal jewelry and ornaments. The import and export of monetary gold are prohibited, except when made by the monetary authorities. Imports of gold for industrial purposes are subject to a quota and specific import license. Exports of articles made wholly or partially of gold, other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler, are prohibited. Payments in respect of private imports of gold coins and gold bullion are subject to the 35.70 per cent stamp duty. Imports of certain jewelry are subject to temporary customs surcharges. NOTES 1 The exchange control regulations of Mauritius define for- eign currencies as all currencies other than the Mauritian rupee. 2 The exchange control regulations of Mauritius define the Sterling Area as comprising the United Kingdom, the Chan- nel Islands, the Isle of Man, and the Republic of Ireland. 331 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0589330 gram of fine gold per Mexican Peso, corresponding to Mex$12.50 == US$1. On December 31, 1974 the official rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, were Mex$ 12.49 buy- ing, and Mex$12.51 selling, per US$1. Banks may freely engage in exchange transactions between the peso and any other currency. There are limited forward exchange facilities for transactions between Mexican pesos and foreign currencies. On November 12, 1946, Mexico notified the Fund that it was prepared to formally accept the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Prescription of Currency No obligations prescribing the method or currency for payments to or from nonresidents are imposed on importers, exporters, or others. In accordance with payments agreements with Hungary, Poland, and Yu- goslavia, payments for direct commercial transactions and related expenses with those countries handled through the Mexican banking system may, with the prior authorization of the Bank of Mexico, be made through special accounts denominated in U.S. dollars. Payments between Mexico and Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, and Venezuela may be settled through ac- counts maintained with each other by the Bank of Mex- ico and the central banks concerned, within the framework of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system. A similar arrangement exists for payments between Mexico and the Dominican Republic. Payments to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua in respect of trade and invisibles may be settled in Mexican pesos or Central American curren- cies in accordance with the reciprocal credit agreement between the central banks of those countries. Imports and Import Payments Payments and transfers abroad may be made freely. A few imports are prohibited. All imports must be accompanied by an exporter's declaration of shipment. For a considerable number of items, import licenses from the Ministry of Industry and Trade are required before firm orders are placed; the issuance of such li- censes may be subject to quantitative restriction, but most of the items concerned do not require an import license when they originate in LAFTA countries. For specified commodities, "open end" import licenses (per- misos abiertos) may be granted that permit limited im- portation during a specified period of time, such as six months or a year; subject to screening of the importer's performance, repeated renewal of the license is possible. 332 Applications for import licenses are screened by the Ministry of Industry and Trade with the aid of commit- tees composed of importers, producers, and consumers. Import licenses for certain goods, including leather goods, alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, and automobiles and their spare parts, are subject to an overall annual limit. Imports of certain goods for which licenses from the Ministry of Industry and Trade are required (such as unassembled automobiles and trucks, iron and steel pipe, firearms, watches, synthetic fibers, some types of jewelry, radio and television sets, and whiskey, wines, and other liquors) are subject to the payment of a fee of usually between 1 per cent and 6 per cent of the value of the import transactions, the proceeds of which are allocated to a fund handled by the Mexican Foreign Trade Institute (IMCE) for the promotion of exports. Imports by official Mexican agencies are subject to prior approval by the Mexican Foreign Trade Institute; this approval is not given if a reasonably competitive domestic equivalent is available at a price differential of 15-20 per cent. Many nonessential imports are subject to an import surcharge of 10 per cent ad valorem, the proceeds of which accrue to an export trust fund the Federal Government has established in the Bank of Mexico. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are not restricted. The con- tracting of insurance for persons in Mexico, or on prop- erty of Mexican ownership, or where the risks are for the account of persons in Mexico or may occur in Mex- ico, is permitted with Mexican companies or with branches of foreign companies established in Mexico in accordance with Mexican law. Exports and Export Proceeds Certain exports require licenses. No exchange con- trol requirements apply to the proceeds of exports. Re- bates of indirect taxes by means of a system of CEDIs (certificados de devolution de impifestos) are granted on exports of certain manufactured and semimanufactured products (and of certain services), provided that at least 50 per cent of the direct cost of production is of Mexi- can origin and that they are on a list of products autho- rized by the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit. Proceeds from Invisibles No exchange control requirements apply to proceeds from invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresi- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution dents. New foreign investment in the capital of Mexi- can banking or insurance companies and investment funds is prohibited. Certain sectors, such as petroleum, basic petrochemical production, radioactive minerals, electricity and nuclear energy, certain mining activities, railroads, and telecommunications, are reserved to gov- ernment investment. Investment in a number of activi- ties is reserved exclusively for Mexican individuals or corporations (radio and television, the public transpor- tation system, forestry, etc., as well as any other areas specified by the Federal Government), while new in- vestments in other sectors must have a majority partici- pation of Mexican capital. Foreign investments in Mexico must be registered with the National Foreign Investment Register in the Ministry of Industry and Trade. Applications by foreign physical or juridical persons to acquire more than 25 per cent of the capital of a Mexican company, or over 49 per cent of its fixed assets, require the prior authorization of the competent ministry, after the National Foreign Investment Com- mission has granted the necessary registration. All ac- quisitions of stock in Mexican companies by foreign physical or juridical persons must be registered within 30 days with the National Foreign Investors Registry. Borrowing abroad (or within Mexico in foreign cur- rency) by the public sector and by state-owned banks is subject to approval by the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit. Borrowing abroad by private banks is subject to approval by the Bank of Mexico. Gold Domestic transactions in nonmonetary gold are lim- ited to purchases of gold bars by licensed goldsmiths or manufacturers. With this exception, residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Mexico or abroad. The Bank of Mexico does not buy or sell gold in transactions with private banks, individ- uals, or firms. There is a 15 per cent tax on "first hand" sales of newly mined gold. Producers of gold undertak- ing not to sell it at prices exceeding international quota- tions plus normal marketing costs are eligible for an automatic subsidy corresponding to 33 per cent of the tax, when selling newly mined gold in Mexico to private banks reselling such gold to licensed goldsmiths or manufacturers in Mexico. Exports of gold are prohib- ited unless they are made by the Bank of Mexico. Im- MEXICO ports of gold are permitted and when licensed by the Bank of Mexico are free of customs duty. Changes during 1974 January 1. A reciprocal credit agreement signed with the Dominican Republic on December 3, 1973 came into operation. January 3. The General Law of Credit Institutions and Auxiliary Organizations of July 10, 1951, was amended. The acquisition of 25 per cent or more of the capital of a credit institution or of any organization controlling a credit institution required the prior autho- rization of the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit. The establishment of branches of foreign banks or fi- nancial institutions in Mexico also required authoriza- tion by the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit. Mexican banks and financial institutions required prior authorization to acquire any shares of, or to participate in the share capital of, foreign banks. February 12. Regulations issued on December 29, 1973 for the establishment of a National Foreign Inves- tors Registry came into effect. Any foreign physical or juridical person acquiring stock in a Mexican company, whether on a stock exchange or otherwise, and any Mexican company selling its shares to a foreign physi- cal or juridical person, were required to register the transaction within 30 days thereafter. March 16. Banks and financial institutions intro- duced new instruments to attract savings. Certificates of deposit were created for peso time deposits for terms of three and six months. May 13. Banks and financial institutions increased their interest rates on peso time deposits, including those of nonresidents. September 27. Banks were permitted to increase by 1Y2 per cent the interest rate on U.S. dollar time depos- its received from nonresidents or from persons resident in the northern border area. November 18. Banks were permitted to increase the interest rate on U.S. dollar deposits received from non- residents and from persons resident in the northern border area to 7 per cent per annum plus an additional amount, exempt from income tax, of up to 1.5 per cent, 2 per cent, or 2.5 per cent, respectively, for time depos- its of 90-95 days, 180-185 days, and 12-24 months. December. A 50 per cent export tax was imposed on crude oil. 333 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.175610 gram of f ine gold per Moroccan Dirham. However, no transactions take place at the par value. The Bank of Morocco quotes daily buy ing and selling rates for the French f ranc; its rates for the f r anc is determined in the l ight of quo ta- tions for certain ma jor currencies on the off ic ial ex- change market in Paris and tak ing in to account the geographic d is tr ibu t ion of Morocco's foreign trade transactions. The Bank of Morocco also quotes buy ing and selling rates for specified "convertible currencies,"1 based on quo ta t ions in the leading foreign exchange ma rke ts abroad and the Bank of Morocco's daily quo- ta t ion for the French f ranc. The rates of the Bank of Morocco for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were DH 4 .1389 buy ing, and DH 4.1607 selling, per US$1 and those for the French f r anc were DH 0.93229 buy ing, and DH 0.93509 selling, per F 1. All sales and purchases of foreign currency are cen- tralized in the Bank of Morocco, but the authorized banks are permitted to ma r ry (offse t) the ir purchases and sales on behalf of their private customers in each currency separately. The authorized banks must pur- chase f rom or sell to the Bank of Morocco each day, at the rates communicated to them by the Bank, the bal- ances of the ir purchases and sales in each currency; compensation between banks is not permitted so that no fore ign exchange ma rket exists in Morocco. The Bank of Morocco makes its own purchases and sales of fore ign currency in exchange marke ts abroad. The Bank of Morocco also establishes buy ing and selling rates for transac t ions w i th travelers in bankno tes, t rav- elers checks, and letters of credit expressed in French francs, CFA f rancs, and the "convertible currencies"; the au thor ized banks sell to the Bank of Morocco the ir excess ho ld ings of bankno tes and replenish them at the Bank whenever necessary. Forward exchange transac- tions are not permitted. Foreign currency repatriated in the fo rm of bank or postal transfers by Moroccan workers abroad is eligible for a premium of 5 per cent payable on the dirham equ iva len t. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Exchange Office, an agency under the M in is t ry of Finance. This Office has delegated the execution of certain exchange control measures to authorized banks. Impo rt cer t if i- cates and export licenses are issued by the M in i s t ry of Commerce; they must be countersigned by the Moroc- can Exchange Office. Import commitments for liberal- ized goods are signed by the importer h imse lf; they do not requ i re the visa of the Exchange Office unless the coun t ry of origin of the goods is not the coun t ry of 334 sh ipmen t, or the goods are bought on a c.i.f. basis. A part of the port of Tangier is designated as a free trade zone and is exempt from taxation and from trade, cus- toms, and exchange control. Prescription of Currency Although Morocco's regulations still make a distinc- tion between the French Franc Area and the so-called area of conver t ib i l i ty, Morocco applies exchange con- trol also to transac t ions w i th the former .2 For prescrip- tion of currency purposes, countries are classified as fo l lows: (1) the French Franc Area countries; (2) the paymen ts agreement group, comprising countries with which Morocco ma in ta ins bilateral payments agree- ments;3 and (3) all other countries, the so-called area of conve r t ib i l i ty. Settlements w i th the French Franc Area are made in French francs or, w i th the exception of settlements for impor ts, in dirhams th rough French Franc Area Ac- counts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, below); certain noncommercial settlements w i th Algeria and Tunisia, however, are made in dirhams, Algerian di- nars, and Tunisian d inars th rough special accounts at the three central banks. Settlements w i th the payments agreement group are made by debiting or crediting the paymen ts agreements accounts established for this pur- pose. Impo r ts or ig ina t ing in countries in the area of conve r t ib i l i ty may be paid for on ly in "convertible cur- rencies" negotiated by the Bank of Morocco.1 Other settlements w i th countries in the area of conver t ib i l i ty may be made on ly in "convertible currencies" negoti- ated by the Bank of Morocco or th rough Foreign Ac- counts in Convertible Dirhams. Nonresident Accounts The various types of nonresident accounts are as fo l lows: 1. French Franc Area Accounts are held in Moroccan currency by residents of countries of the French Franc Area. These accounts may be used for settlements with residents of countries in the French Franc Area, except for the payment for impo r ts (and related invisibles) f rom those countries.4 They may be freely credited with and debited for sales or purchases of French francs (except bankno tes) sold to or bought f rom the Bank of Morocco. Transfers between French Franc Area Ac- coun ts may be made f ree ly. 2. Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are re- served for residents of countries in the area of convert- ib i l i ty. These accounts may be credited freely with authorized paymen ts due to residents of countries in the area of conve r t ib i l i ty (but not in respect of imports or related invisibles) and w i th dirhams obtained from the sale to the Bank of Morocco of "convertible curren- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ties" negotiated by it, excluding banknotes. They may be debited freely for payments in Morocco and for purchases from the Bank of Morocco of the "converti- ble currencies" negotiated by it. Transfers between For- eign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams may be made freely. 3. Payments Agreement Accounts are held by the Bank of Morocco for central banks (or similar institu- tions) of the countries with which Morocco maintains bilateral payments agreements;3 they are used only for settlements with these countries, including settlements for imports and exports. 4. Capital Accounts, which may be held by any non- resident, are credited with funds that may not be trans- ferred abroad. These include the proceeds from the sale on the Casablanca stock exchange of Moroccan securi- ties held under foreign dossier and proceeds from the contractual or accelerated redemption of such securi- ties. Transfers between Capital Accounts related to (1) countries either in the area of convertibility or the French Franc Area or (2) the same country in the pay- ments agreement group, are permitted freely. Capital Accounts may be debited freely for (1) pur- chases of specified 5Y2 per cent, seven-year government bonds; interest and redemption proceeds are transfer- able, and the bonds are freely negotiable between non- residents; and (2) personal expenses of the account holder and his immediate relatives during visits to Mo- rocco, up to DH 150 a person a day, subject to a limit of DH 5,000 a year for each account. All other opera- tions through Capital Accounts require individual ap- proval. These include purchases on the Casablanca stock exchange of Moroccan and non-Moroccan secu- rities; purchases of Moroccan securities not quoted in Casablanca or of participation in a Moroccan firm; subscriptions to either; investments of any kind, includ- ing purchases of businesses or office buildings; lending to residents; payment of local expenses in excess of DH 5,000 during the holder's stay in Morocco; any such payments to beneficiaries other than the holder of the account or a close relative of his; any such payments from an account held by a foreign juridical person; gifts to social, cultural, or religious institutions; subscrip- tions to capital increases of Moroccan companies whose shares are quoted on the Casablanca stock ex- change; subscriptions at the time of issue to long-term or short-term securities with a fixed yield issued by a Moroccan public entity; custody charges and commis- sions on securities; and payment of the costs of mainte- nance, repairs, real estate taxes, and insurance on real estate taxes, and insurance on real estate located in Morocco. Subject to approval, Capital Accounts may also be debited for investments in Morocco, w i th in the framework of the 1973 Investment Code, provided that the amounts debited do not exceed 50 per cent of the investment undertaken by the nonresident or 25 per cent of the company's total capital. 5. Suspense Accounts are used for holding nonresi- dent funds not available for credit to any of the ac- MOROCCO counts mentioned above. Balances on these accounts may be used freely to pay taxes due to the Moroccan authorities, but all other debits to these accounts re- quire approval. 6. Two Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are held by the Bank of Morocco for the Central Bank of Algeria and the Central Bank of Tunisia. Specified non- commercial transactions between Morocco and the two other countries concerned are settled through these ac- counts. Imports and Import Payments Imports are admitted in accordance with an annual General Import Program. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports are divided into three categories applicable to all countries. Goods in List A are liberal- ized. Goods in List B are restricted, in some cases by a global quota, or are subject to state trading; for a large number of List B items, no quotas are established and imports are approved according to need (SB items). In principle, the importation of goods in List C is not permitted. To import goods in List A, the importer signs an import commitment {engagement d'importa- tion), which does not require administrative approval unless the goods are imported from a country other than that of origin or are purchased on a c.i.f. basis,5 but for goods in List B, an import license {autorisation d'importation or certificat d'importation) must be ob- tained. For all imports the import title—import certificate or import commitment —must be domiciled (regis- tered) with an authorized bank, which may make pay- ments upon submission of the required documents. Import certificates require the visa of the Exchange Office before the foreign exchange is made available. Import commitments require this visa only when the country of origin and the country of shipment of the goods concerned differ or when imports are contracted for on a c.i.f. basis. Import certificates must be domi- ciled within 15 days from the date that the Exchange Office approves the license. Import commitments must be domiciled at the time of their subscription. Special procedures are applicable to specified imports financed by foreign aid or loans. Most imports from countries in the payments agree- ment group are made in accordance with the quotas established in the respective trade agreements. Imports can also be licensed under compensation transactions. Payments for In visibles Payments for most current invisibles require the ap- proval of the Exchange Office upon presentation of the necessary justification; in several instances the ap- proval authority has been delegated to the banks. The authorized banks are permitted to make payments and settle expenses incidental to the commercial transaction covered by the relevant import or export documents. Earnings after tax on approved nonresident invest- 335 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO men ts in Morocco are transferable to the investor's coun t ry of residence. The transfer of dividends on non- resident-owned shares of Moroccan companies hav ing their main office in Morocco requires the approval of the Exchange Office. Undistributed prof i ts relating to the financial year 1968 or later remain transferable in- def in i te ly. Some paymen ts are subject to limitations. A foreign employee may transfer to his coun try of origin, subject to the initial approval of the Exchange Office, 50 per cent of his mon th ly wages or salary if his fam i ly does not reside in Morocco, or 30 per cent if he is single or his fam i ly lives in Morocco. The same percentages of their mon th ly earnings may be transferred by foreign nationals engaged in professions (except for the medical and paramedical professions), subject to a limit of DH 1,000 a mon th .6 Subject to a mon th ly limit of DH 300, the same percentages of earnings may also be transferred by foreign nationals engaged in agricul- tura l, industrial, or commercial activities, or in skilled craf ts. Foreign nationals employed in the hotel sector are authorized to transfer between 60 and 80 per cent of the ir mon th ly salaries or wages. An allocation of foreign exchange equivalent to DH 100 a person a year is granted to residents of any na t iona l i ty for travel abroad, provided that they do not make periodic trans- fers abroad. There is a special allocation for pilgrim- ages. Residents of foreign na t iona l i ty may acquire exchange for tourist travel up to the equivalent of DH 2,500 for each passport a year by selling to an authorized bank a corresponding amount in foreign exchange (other than banknotes) from their own for- eign assets not subject to surrender requirements. For business travel by persons other than exporters a s tandard allowance of DH 150 a day is granted; exporters may be granted up to DH 200 a day for up to 60 days a year, up to a l im it of 1 per cent of the foreign exchange surrendered dur ing the preceding year. The allocation issued for business travel may be added to the allocation issued for tourist travel. For study abroad, a monthly allocation of foreign exchange up to DH 834 is granted, provided that no comparable educational facilities are available in Morocco; Moroc- can s tuden ts tak ing college or un ive rs i ty level courses abroad are entitled to an annual installation allowance equ iva lent to DH 1,000. For fam i ly maintenance, the Exchange Office generally gran ts a mon th ly allocation in the order of DH 250-300. The export of Moroccan bankno tes is proh ib i ted. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports may be made free ly, a l though export licenses are re- quired for a few items. All f ru i ts, fresh vegetables, canned goods, raw cotton, and cotton by-products may be exported on ly by a state trad ing agency, the Office of Ma rke t ing and Export (Office de Commercialisation 336 et d'Exportation —OCE). That Office also is in charge of wine exports. All exporters must sign an under tak ing to repatriate and surrender the foreign exchange proceeds of their exports. The surrender of the proceeds to the exporter's bank must take place w i th in one mon th from the date the payment is due. The date on which the payment is due is the ma tu r i ty date fixed in the commercial con- tract; this date must not be set, in principle, more than 90 days a f ter the date of arrival of the merchandise at the place of destination. When the bank receiving the funds that represent the proceeds from exports receives the advice of credit in foreign currency from abroad, it must surrender the foreign exchange immediately to the Bank of Morocco. Proceeds from In visibles Residents of Moroccan na t iona l i ty and Moroccan companies must repatriate exchange receipts accruing f rom all their noncommercial claims and surrender them to an authorized bank. Other residents must sur- render noncommercial receipts only if the receipts re- sult from current transactions, and only when they accrue in foreign currencies other than those of the French Franc Area. Moroccans work ing abroad must surrender such currencies within one month of re-entry, but are permitted, when leaving again, to repurchase 15 per cent of the amount surrendered (the currencies so purchased may also include French francs); they are entitled to a bonus of 5 per cent on the dirham equiva- lent of any foreign exchange repatriated in the form of bank or postal transfers. The importation of Moroccan banknotes is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may bring in freely foreign banknotes; foreign exchange brought in in excess of the equivalent of DH 5,000 must be declared to the customs authorities. Resident travel- ers also may bring in any amount in foreign banknotes, but these must be surrendered w i th in 30 days of re-entry. Capital Residents of Moroccan na t iona l i ty, as well as com- panies established in Morocco, are obliged to declare to the Exchange Office all foreign-held assets exceeding DH 250, and to repatriate and surrender certain of these assets. The disposal of other foreign-held assets requires permission. The transfer of capital abroad by residents must be approved. Remittances in respect of the assets of emigrants and transfers of gifts are not normally approved. Exchange allocations for the trans- fer of inheritances are limited to DH 35,000 a benefi- ciary. Those for the transfer of their assets by repatriates vary w i th the length of their stay in Mo- rocco, from DH 35,000 a family with family residence of 3 to 5 years to DH 100,000 a family where the period of residence has been 15 to 25 years. New foreign investments in specified sectors of the economy may benefit from the provisions of the Invest- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ment Code of August 15, 1973. The Code consists of six laws and several implementing decrees providing various tax concessions and other incentives. It guaran- tees the transfer of dividends distributed to nonresi- dents and of proceeds from the liquidation of the capital brought in by the foreign investor. Investments financed with funds held in Capital Accounts (see sec- tion on Nonresident Accounts, above) also are eligible for the benefits of the Code; proceeds from the liquida- tion of investments financed in this manner become transferable after a minimum investment period of 5 years. Foreign investments approved under the previous Investment Code (of February 10, 1961) continue to benefit from the retransfer guarantee for the liquidation proceeds. Proceeds from the liquidation of other invest- ments are credited to Capital Accounts. Certain government bonds acquired with funds from Capital Accounts are freely negotiable between nonres- idents. All other transactions in securities involving nonresident interests, as well as the import and export of securities, require approval. Banks are permitted to engage in short-term borrowing abroad within the framework of Dahir No. 1-74-385 of August 5, 1974 and the Orders issued for its implementation. Under this facility, they may accept convertible currency funds from nonresidents for credit to Special Deposit Accounts, provided these funds are reinvested abroad in the same currency and for the same maturity period; the rate of interest paid by banks on deposits received must not exceed that received by them on the placing made for their account. Gold Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Morocco for numismatic or investment purposes. Ten different types of foreign gold coins are traded on the Casablanca stock exchange, which does not, however, deal in gold bars. Imports and exports of gold are prohibited unless authorized by the Directorate of Cus- toms and Indirect Taxes, which derives its approval authority from the Minister of Finance. Every year the Minister of Finance fixes a quota for the importation of gold ingots, which is then allocated among jewelers and industrial users of precious metals. Changes during 1974 January. By virtue of Dahir No. 1-74-385 of August 5, 1974, authorized banks designated by an Order of the Minister of Finance were permitted to receive freely, from nonresident physical or juridical persons of foreign nationality, deposits in convertible foreign cur- rencies, for placing on the international capital market. Specified conditions were to be observed. Thus, the amount and maturity of the deposits and the nature of the placements had to conform to instructions issued by ministerial Orders, and the rate of interest paid by banks on deposits received could not exceed that re- ceived by them on the placement made for their ac- count. August 7. Order No. 750-74 of August 6, 1974 was published. It permitted six specified authorized banks to open freely in the names of nonresident physical or juridical persons of foreign nationality, upon the re- quest of such persons, accounts denominated in foreign currencies and to be called Special Deposit Accounts. These accounts could be opened both for sight deposits and for time deposits with a maturity of 1 to 24 months. In either case, the minimum deposit was equivalent to US$500,000. Time deposits had to be reinvested on the international capital market, for their full amount and for the same maturity, in the form of time deposits denominated in the currency received. October 7.
