Not for Redistribution NEPAL (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0808408 gram of fine gold per Nepalese Rupee. On February 20, 1973 a central rate was established of NRs 12.7390 = SDR 1, corre- sponding at the time to NRs 10.56 = US$1, and Nepal avails itself of wider margins. The Nepal Rastra Bank (the central bank) maintains fixed buying and selling rates for U.S. dollars and Indian rupees as follows: NRs 10.50 buying, and NRs 10.60 selling, per US$1, and NRs 139.00 buying, and NRs 139.15 selling, per 100 Indian rupees. Daily rates are quoted for Austra- lian dollars, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs. Different effective exchange rates arise from the opera- tion of an Exporters' Exchange Entitlement Scheme. Most of Nepal's foreign exchange transactions are in terms of Indian rupees. Residents may freely purchase Indian rupees from Nepalese banks and they may hold any amount of Indian notes and coins, but the Indian rupee is not legal tender. Administration of Control A Foreign Exchange Committee, consisting of repre- sentatives from the Nepal Rastra Bank and the Minis- tries of Finance, Foreign Affairs, and Industry and Commerce, prepares an annual foreign exchange bud- get for foreign currencies other than the Indian rupee and excluding transactions with the clearing countries. Permission is required from the Ministry of Finance for all foreign payments, except payments for certain speci- fied invisibles that require authorization from the Ne- pal Rastra Bank. Import and export licensing is the responsibility of the Ministry of Industry and Com- merce. All exchange transactions with countries other than India must be settled through authorized dealers, i.e., the Nepal Bank Ltd. and the Rastriya Banijya Bank. Within Nepal there are 68 additional authorized dealers licensed to purchase foreign currencies; any sale of such currencies other than Indian rupees is subject to the prior approval of the Nepal Rastra Bank. All import and export transactions with payments agree- ment countries, as well as all barter trade, are con- ducted through a state trading agency, the National Trading Ltd. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements apply to outgoing payments to countries with which no pay- ments agreement is in force and these may be made in the foreign currency supplied by the Nepal Rastra Bank. Payments for imports from India normally are settled in Indian rupees, but the Nepal Rastra Bank sometimes makes convertible currencies available for sucn imports at the recommendation of the Ministry of Finance. The proceeds of exports to India are obtained in Indian or Nepalese rupees; the proceeds of exports to other countries must be received in any of the con- vertible currencies quoted by the Nepal Rastra Bank. Nepal has bilateral payments agreements with Bul- garia, the People's Republic of China, Pakistan, and Poland; payments between Nepal and these countries must be made through special accounts. The agreement with Pakistan is inoperative. Nonresident Accounts The Nepal Rastra Bank permits nonresidents upon request to open "convertible rupee accounts" with Nep- alese banks, the balances of which may be freely trans- ferred abroad. Indian nationals are allowed to open current accounts in Indian rupees with Nepalese banks. Foreign currencies brought into or received in Nepal by nonresidents, which are converted into Nepalese rupees and deposited with a Nepalese bank, may be recon- verted for transfer out of the country, subject to prior permission of the Nepal Rastra Bank. Imports and Import Payments All imports of goods except those originating in In- dia or the Tibet region require import licenses from the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. Imports of vege- table oil, margarine, animal fat, beef, arms and ammu- nition, explosives, chemicals to be used for explosives, and wireless transmitters are prohibited. Under the Trade and Transit Treaty of August 13, 1971, Nepal and India agreed to freedom of trade between them- selves in Nepalese and Indian goods; Indian goods may in principle be imported freely (although some are sub- ject to temporary import licensing in order to prevent their re-exportation), and reimbursement of tax is made by the Government of India to the Government of Nepal on direct imports from Indian manufacturers of commodities subject to excise duty in India. With the exception noted below, applications to the Ministry of Finance for foreign exchange to pay for imports from countries other than India are considered on their merits; any application must, however, be in accordance with the annual foreign exchange budget. Exporters entitled to import goods with exporters' ex- change entitlements are, within the limits of their enti- tlement, granted a license automatically for goods specified by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below); the entitlements are transferable and may be used by other holders. Many imports payable in convertible currencies and most government imports are effected through state trading agencies, mainly the National Trading Ltd. and the Agricultural Input Corporation. 339 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEPAL Certain imports from all sources are subject to im- port surcharges. Payments for Invisibles Payments to India may be made freely in Indian rupees, but for purchases of Rs 500 or over the purpose of the payment must be indicated. Payments for freight and insurance are given the same treatment as the re- lated import payments. For travel to countries other than India for medical treatment, foreign exchange is allowed as recom- mended by a panel of doctors; students studying at their own expense in these countries are allowed up to US$2,160 a year for board and lodging, while payments for tuition fees are allowed as required. Payments for other invisibles depend on the essentiality of the trans- action and the availability of foreign exchange. Nepa- lese and Indian currency may be taken out freely to India by Nepalese and Indian nationals only; the ex- port of these currencies to countries other than India is prohibited. Foreign banknotes other than Indian bank- notes may not be taken out by residents without per- mission. Nonresidents may take out the unchanged amount of any foreign banknotes they brought in; how- ever, nonresidents other than Indian nationals may not take out Nepalese or Indian banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of old coins, gold and silver, and coins and jewelry made of these metals, cows, buffaloes, and rhi- noceros horns are prohibited. There is also a temporary prohibition on exports of oilseeds and edible oils. The re-export to India of non-Nepalese goods is not permit- ted, and re-exports to any destination of goods im- ported from India are prohibited.1 All other goods, except rice, may be exported freely to India. All exports to other destinations require export licenses. The Jute Development and Marketing Corporation has a mo- nopoly over exports of raw jute. The exchange proceeds of exports, except Indian ru- pees, must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an authorized bank at the official buying rate of ex- change, within six months of shipment. The exporter receives from the Nepal Rastra Bank an exporters' ex- change entitlement corresponding to a specified pro- portion of his export proceeds in foreign currencies other than Indian rupees; the entitlement may be used to obtain exchange at the official rate for the import of goods specified by the Ministry of Industry and Com- merce. Entitlements are negotiable. Exporters engaged in bilateral trade (i.e., the Na- tional Trading Ltd. when selling to countries with which Nepal maintains payments agreements) are granted entitlements corresponding to 100 per cent of their export earnings; in principle, 40 per cent of these earnings may be used for imports of their choice from the partner country concerned, while the remaining 60 340 per cent must be used to import specified commodities from the partner country concerned. When exports are made to convertible currency countries, exchange entitlements are granted at ratios ranging from 20 per cent for raw jute to 90 per cent for stainless steel goods. At least 25 per cent of the entitle- ment must be used to purchase goods on a list of devel- opment goods, up to 50 per cent may be used to purchase specified essential goods, while up to 25 per cent may be spent on any type of goods. Proceeds from Invisibles With the exception of Indian rupees, foreign ex- change proceeds derived from transactions in invisibles must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an authorized bank at the official rate of exchange. Nepa- lese and Indian currency may be brought in from India only, and by Nepalese and Indian nationals only; the import of these currencies from countries other than India is prohibited. Nonresidents other than Indian nationals are not allowed to bring in Nepalese or Indian banknotes. Other foreign banknotes may be brought in freely by residents and nonresidents, but residents and Indian nationals must declare any foreign banknotes they bring in. Capital No conditions are laid down concerning receipts and remittances in respect of capital transactions, but offi- cial exchange is not normally provided for capital re- mittances by Nepalese nationals. Nepalese citizens, whether resident in Nepal or not, are prohibited from making any type of investment in foreign countries except investment specifically exempted by government notice published in the Official Gazette; the exemptions include the purchase and sale of insurance policies abroad, investments abroad by any banking or finan- cial institution incorporated in Nepal, and the purchase of shares of foreign companies under a rights issue. The Industrial Enterprise Act, 1974 provides certain incentives for foreign investment in Nepal. Foreign in- vestors who obtain an investment guarantee may remit yearly profits of up to 25 per cent of the total profit on the foreign capital invested and, in any one year, up to 10 per cent of the principal; if the exchange situation permits, profits in excess of 25 per cent are remittable. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Nepal. No import licenses for gold are issued under the Exporters' Exchange Entitlement Scheme. Imports of gold from any country other than India require a license and are subject to an import du ty of NRs 6.65 a troy ounce; such imports are not normally allowed. Exports of gold may be made only by the monetary authorities and require prior approval by the Ministry of Finance. Domestic dealings in gold ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEPAL do not require a license but are subject to sales tax at 10 per cent. Changes during 1974 January 3. Rice exports were made conditional on the sale to the Government, at fixed prices, of 25 per cent of exporters' stocks. Procedures for issuing rice export licenses were simplified. May 31. A new trade and payments agreement with the People's Republic of China was signed. June 21. The stand-by arrangement with India was renewed. July 1. Restrictions were placed on the import of certain items from India in order to prevent their re-export; items that henceforth required an import li- cense included raw jute and mica. July 16. The Industrial Enterprise Act, 1974 came into force. It replaced the Industrial Enterprise Act, 1961. August 6. The export of oilseeds and edible oils was prohibited. October 22. The central bank quoted daily rates for the Australian dollar. NOTE 1 Under the Trade and Transit Treaty with India, national origin for manufactured products is defined in terms of the import content of the ex-factory value. 341 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.245489 gram of f ine gold per Netherlands Guilder. On September 17, 1973, the Netherlands established a central rate of f. 3.35507 = SDR 1, corresponding at the time to 0.264874 gram of f ine gold per Netherlands guilder, and avails itself of wider margins. A maximum margin of 2V4 per cent is maintained for exchange rates in the official market between the Ne ther lands guilder and the Danish krone, the deutsche ma rk, the Norwegian krone, and the Swedish krona; margins of IV2 per cent either side of the cross-parity are observed for the Belgian f ranc and, by implication, the Luxembourg f ranc (BF /L ux F 100 = f. 6.89531). No announced margins are ma in ta ined for other currencies.1 The authorized banks' buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were f. 2.5065 and f. 2.50775, respectively, per US$1. Authorized banks are free ly permitted to buy and sell convertible and inconvertible currencies, both spot and fo rw a rd, against convertible currencies, inc lud ing guilders on Convertible Guilder Accounts, and incon- vertible currencies; they are free to deal w i th residents and nonresidents, whe ther banks or nonbanks. For- ward exchange contracts are not limited as to delivery period nor is an unde r ly ing transaction required. Resi- dents are permitted to conclude spot transactions w i th other residents, including authorized banks, and they may conclude forward transactions for any period with authorized banks. Nonbank residents are free to hold foreign currency accounts at home and on application are permitted to hold such accounts (normally demand deposits only) in their own names with banks abroad; overdraf ts on these accounts are not allowed. The Kingdom of the Netherlands formally accepted the obligations of Article V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as f rom February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory Transactions w i th the Netherlands Antilles and Suri- nam are subject to the same exchange controls as trans- actions with other countries. Vis-a-vis any th ird countries with which payments agreements might be in force, the Netherlands, the Netherlands Antilles, and Surinam constitute the Netherlands Monetary Area. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Nether- lands Bank on behalf of the Ministers of Foreign Af- fairs, Finance, Economic Affa irs, and Agriculture. Import and export licensing are handled by the Central Import-Export Agency (CDIU) and the delegated of- fices, under directives from the Directorate-General for Foreign Economic Relations. Invisibles and capital 342 transactions are licensed by the Netherlands Bank, as are transit trade transactions, except those in strategic goods and scrap, which are licensed by the CDIU.2 All commercial banks of any importance are authorized to hand le foreign exchange transactions within the scope of general and special licenses granted by the licensing authorities. For all payments to, or receipts from, non- residents exceeding f. 1,000, nonbank residents have to indicate, by subm i t t ing an exchange control form, the na ture of the unde r ly ing transaction as well as the cur- rency and amount paid or received.3 Prescription of Currency Payments to nonresidents, if eligible for transfer abroad, must be made through an authorized bank, either in guilders to the credit of a nonresident guilder account held w i th an authorized bank in the Nether- lands or to the debit of the authorized bank's currency holdings abroad. There are special regulations, how- ever, for paymen ts in respect of certain direct imports from Egypt.4 All financial transactions, whether direct or indirect, between the Netherlands and Rhodesia are prohibited unless a license is granted by the Nether- lands Bank. Since there are no bilateral payments agreements, all foreign countries are included in the "convertible guil- der area." Payments to countries in the convertible guil- der area may be made in any foreign currency or in guilders to the credit of any nonresident account. Re- ceipts from countries in the convertible guilder area may be obtained in any convertible currency or in guil- ders to the debit of a Convertible Guilder Account (see section on Nonresident Accounts, below); however, re- ceipts may also be collected in other currencies, pro- vided that the amounts received are deposited with the Netherlands Bank or an authorized bank. Payments between residents may be made freely in any foreign currency, provided that the amount in- volved is debited to a foreign currency account in the Netherlands or abroad and is credited to a foreign currency account in the name of the beneficiary w i th an authorized bank in the Netherlands. Nonresident Accounts The principal nonresident guilder accounts are Con- vertible Guilder Accounts. These accounts may be held by any nonresident. They may be credited with trans- fers from other Convertible Guilder Accounts, with permitted payments by residents of the Netherlands to residents of countries of the convertible guilder area, with proceeds from the sale of gold or convertible cur- rencies, and with Netherlands notes and coins remitted or deposited by nonresidents. They may be debited for payments to residents for exports and services rendered ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution to any country and for other permitted transactions, including purchases of foreign currencies. Balances may be transferred to any other nonresident account. However, Convertible Guilder Accounts may not be debited for the purchase of Netherlands treasury paper or guilder bank acceptances; they may not be credited with interest on guilder demand deposits,5 and may be subject to a negative interest charge. No time or savings deposits may be established on Convertible Guilder Accounts.6 If held by residents of Rhodesia, Convert- ible Guilder Accounts may not be debited or credited without special licenses, which are granted only for the exceptional cases referred to in the relevant UN Reso- lution. Imports and Import Payments Imports from the Belgian-Luxembourg Economic Union are free from import licenses. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Import licenses are required for imports originating in Hong Kong, Japan, and state trading countries, and for the import of goods of un- known origin. In addition, import licenses are required for a limited number of products mainly from the agri- cultural and textile sectors. Except for imports from Rhodesia, practically all imports that require an import license are free from quantitative restriction. Most im- ports from Eastern European countries are formally liberalized. Commodities corresponding to some 19 tariff headings or subheadings are subject to quantita- tive restriction when originating in Japan. Imports from non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to import levies that have replaced all previous barriers to imports; common EEC regulations are also applied to imports from non-EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products, some of which are subject to variable import levies. Imports of cattle and beef from "third" countries (i.e., countries that are neither members of, nor associated with, the EEC) are suspended. Payments for imports may be made freely, provided that the method of payment conforms with the general prescription of currency regulations. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of imports of commodi- ties,7 but they require prior approval from the Nether- lands Bank to accept credit for periods in excess of those traditional in the trade concerned; such permis- sion is not normally granted. Payments for Invisibles Payments abroad for invisibles are permitted freely. Exchange for travel is provided in any currency and up to any amount, and the entire amount may be taken, if the traveler wishes, in Netherlands banknotes. A resident traveling abroad may in addition have any further amounts remitted to him through banking channels. Exchange purchased for travel purposes must not be spent for other purposes; it may be used for NETHERLANDS purchases for personal use, however. Payments for in- terest, dividends, and contractual amortization due to nonresidents are permitted freely by crediting the ap- propriate nonresident account. The export of domestic or foreign banknotes by resi- dent travelers is not subject to limitation. Nonresidents may export all unutilized negotiable instruments and foreign and Netherlands banknotes and coins which they have imported or have obtained in the Nether- lands by drawing on their accounts or exchanging other currencies. Exports and Export Proceeds Virtually all exports to Rhodesia are prohibited; those which are permitted require an export license. For exports to other countries, export licenses are re- quired only for a few commodities, mostly of a strategic character, and for some agricultural products, scrap of iron and steel, and certain nonferrous metals. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of ex- ports of commodities,7 but they require prior permis- sion from the Netherlands Bank to accept payment in advance of delivery where such advance payments are not traditional in the trade concerned; such permission is not normally granted. The surrender of export pro- ceeds is not obligatory, but any surrender that is made must be at the official rate. The collection of export proceeds through an authorized bank is obligatory. A license may be obtained on application, however, to hold a foreign currency account with a bank abroad, to which account export proceeds may be credited; bal- ances in excess of a maximum amount (generally equiv- alent to f. 10,000) must be transferred periodically to the Netherlands. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles must be collected through an authorized bank but need not be surren- dered and may instead be credited to foreign currency accounts. A license may be obtained on application to hold a foreign currency account with a bank abroad, to which account proceeds from invisibles may be cred- ited. Nonresidents may bring into the Netherlands unlim- ited amounts in Netherlands banknotes, foreign bank- notes, and negotiable instruments. These may be sold only to an authorized bank, to an authorized exchange office, or, in the case of foreign banknotes, to an autho- rized depository, or they may be used to pay tourist expenses in the Netherlands. Residents are obliged to bring back to the Netherlands any unutilized portion of the banknotes and coins that they took with them on their outward journey; there is no limitation on the amount in Netherlands or foreign banknotes and coins that they may bring in. 343 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS Capital Inward and outward capital transfers and the shift- ing of foreign-owned capital within the Netherlands from one asset to another are subject to control, but general licenses have been granted for many types of capital transaction. Borrowing and lending abroad by bank and nonbank residents (with the exception of specified bank ing operations and of the granting of credit in respect of imports or exports of commodities) are restricted for reasons of capital market policy and, as far as borrowing is concerned, either to control the contracting of foreign debt by local authorities or for reasons of monetary and reserve policy. Apart from guilder issues on the Netherlands capital market (see below), most lending to nonresidents is liberally per- mitted. Borrowing abroad by nonbank residents is at present restricted, in principle, to amounts used for investments abroad (which is considered to include the purchase of ships and aircraft abroad). Borrowing from nonresident banks by private industry and other non- bank residents is not normally permitted, and loans from other nonresident sources (except suppliers' cred- its with a ma tur i ty customary in the trade concerned) are subject to individual approval; licenses for borrow- ing abroad from nonbank nonresidents are granted on application, provided that the funds are used for direct investment abroad or for lending to nonresidents, but the Netherlands Bank, in principle, does not permit nonbank residents to take up financial credits abroad other than loans with a fixed ma tur i ty of at least f ive years from nonresident enterprises belonging to the same concern as the borrower. There is a general license for loans up to f. 100,000 taken up by residents from nonresidents, provided that a resident in any calendar year does not borrow more than f. 100,000 from the same nonresident. A similar license has been issued for lending to nonresidents. Furthermore, a general license permits authorized banks to grant financial credits for up to 12 mon ths to nonbank nonresidents and for any period to nonresident banks; authorized banks are on application granted licenses to lend to nonbank nonres- idents for periods in excess of 12 months. Special regulations exist for borrowing and lending between head offices (in the Netherlands or abroad) of multinational corporations and their branches and sub- sidiaries; at present, the Netherlands Bank does not permit financial loans to be taken up abroad within a multinational corporation, except as indicated above. Nonbank residents are not normally permitted to pur- chase foreign treasury bills or other foreign short-term instruments. Purchases of Netherlands treasury paper and guilder bank acceptances by nonresidents, includ- ing central banks, are prohibited. Capital transactions, whether freely permitted or not, must be notified to the Balance of Payments Department of the Netherlands Bank; this is true also of all import and export credits for periods in excess of one year and of advance pay- ments in excess of f. 250,000 to be received for exports. 344 Capital issues in the Netherlands on behalf of non- residents are restricted. During the last ten years or so, international financial institutions and the authorities of the nonmetropolitan areas of the Kingdom of the Netherlands have been the only nonresidents allowed to make bond issues denominated in guilders. Such issues are individually licensed by the Netherlands Bank in accordance with the prospects for the domestic capital market and the balance of payments. The Neth- erlands Bank, subject to certain conditions, allows non- residents access to the debt certificate sector of the domestic capital market (the market for onderhandse leningeri). Authorized banks may on request be licensed to lead syndicates for the issue of medium-term Euro-guilder notes, the proceeds of which normally must not be spent in the Netherlands. Unless special permission to the contrary is obtained from the Netherlands Bank, authorized banks' foreign liabilities must not exceed their foreign claims, i.e., they are not allowed to maintain a negative net external position. In observing this regulation, each bank has a leeway of f. 5 million; the calculation of the net foreign position is based on the foreign position in all curren- cies, including guilders, and on the sum of short-term and long-term assets and liabilities. Subject to this limi- tation, banks may freely accept demand deposits from nonresidents, in domestic or foreign currency, as well as time deposits in foreign currency. However, subject to minor exemptions for physical persons, banks are prohibited from paying interest on nonresident-held guilder demand deposits and from accepting guilder time deposits from nonresidents. Inward direct investment by nonresidents and local borrowing by nonresident-owned or nonresident-con- trolled companies for use in the Netherlands are sub- ject to license, which is usually granted. The transfer abroad of the proceeds from the sale or liquidation of nonresident investments in industrial enterprises and other businesses established in the Netherlands is freely permitted. Nonresidents may freely purchase real es- tate in the Netherlands for personal use or investment. Direct investment abroad by residents is authorized on application. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in foreign securities and domestic securities take place at official market rates and, with minor exceptions, are unrestricted; the regulations concerning securities are not applicable to treasury bills or certificates of deposit. Residents may freely purchase officially listed securities abroad, with the exception of guilder-denominated Euro-bonds issued by nonresidents; foreign bonds de- nominated in guilders or otherwise linked to the parity of the guilder may be purchased freely only when listed on the Amsterdam stock exchange. The foreign cur- rency proceeds from securities sold abroad by residents must be deposited with an authorized bank or securities broker in the Netherlands and may be sold or retained. The proceeds of securities sold in the Netherlands by nonresidents are transferable in any currency, irrespec- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution tive of the seller's country of domicile or residence. Nonresidents may have their securities, Netherlands or foreign, exported to them; for the exportation of listed guilder bonds an individual authorization is required, which is granted upon application. Domestic and for- eign securities held abroad by a resident are subject to a deposit requirement, but the Netherlands Bank grants exemptions on application; securities held in the Netherlands are not subject to deposit. Residents may freely purchase real estate abroad. Gifts and donations to nonresidents are free.8 Emi- grants may export any amount in foreign and domestic currency. They acquire the status of nonresidents upon leaving the Netherlands, provided that they have de- clared their intention to settle abroad for more than three years, and may upon departure have remitted to them their total assets in the Netherlands. Payments to nonresident beneficiaries may be made freely in respect of inheritances from estates being dis- tributed in the Netherlands. Gold Certain prewar gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. The Netherlands Bank engages in gold trans- actions only with monetary authorities and interna- tional financial institutions. Neither the Bank nor any government agency imports or markets gold for indus- trial use. Authorized banks and other residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold (fine gold, gold coin, and gold alloys) in the Netherlands or abroad; gold held abroad, however, must be kept on deposit with the foreign correspondent of an authorized deposi- tory. Imports and exports of gold require neither ex- change licenses nor import and export licenses. There is a free gold market in Amsterdam. Domestic sales of gold coins, if legal tender in the country of issue, are free of value-added tax; those that are not legal tender are subject to value-added tax at 4 per cent. The value- added tax on medallions and commemorative coins is 16 per cent; sales of gold bars and nuggets are exempt. Commercial imports of gold jewelry and of articles containing minor quantities of gold, such as watches, require import licenses only when originating in Hong Kong, Japan, or state trading countries. Changes during 1974 January 22. The French franc ceased to be included among the currencies in respect of which the Nether- lands Bank observed margins of 2V4 per cent. The official buying and selling rates for the French franc were suspended. February 1. The bond-circuit or "O-guilder" circuit, which had obliged nonresidents to finance their pur- chases from residents of listed guilder bonds with the proceeds from nonresidents' sales of such bonds, was abolished. Its abolition was decided upon within the framework of monetary cooperation of the countries participating in the European common margins ar- NETHERLANDS rangement. At the time, the premium on the "O-guil- der" was a fraction of 1 per cent. March 4. The limit of f. 50,000 on both the amount up to which demand deposits in Convertible Guilder Accounts held by physical persons could bear interest, and on the amount up to which nonresident physical persons could establish guilder savings deposits with banks, was raised to f. 100,000. May 30. The Netherlands signed the OECD Declara- tion on Imports, Exports, and Other Current Account Transactions. June 20. To facilitate the implementation of the in- demnity agreement with Egypt, a regulation was issued prescribing that all payments for direct imports from that country had to be channeled through the Nether- lands Bank (with the exception, as before, of payments for imports of rice, raw cotton, and crude petroleum). June 20. A revised regulation was published regard- ing the "special commission" (negative interest charge) on balances on Convertible Guilder Accounts, which was to be activated whenever circumstances would make this advisable. July 15. Medium-term export financing facilities available with the Netherlands Bank for small export transactions were increased. July 15. Imports of cattle and beef from "third" countries were suspended in accordance with a decision of the EEC Ministers of Agriculture. July 17. The import and export licensing require- ments were revoked which had been imposed in Octo- ber and November 1973 in respect of petroleum and petroleum products. September 3. The Netherlands informed the Fund that it had decided to subscribe to the Voluntary Decla- ration on Trade and Other Current Account Measures for Balance of Payments Purposes. The decision was binding only for the European part of the Kingdom. On November 8 the Fund was informed that Surinam and the Netherlands Antilles also subscribed to the Declaration. September 11. The authorized banks' reporting re- quirements in respect of spot assets and liabilities in foreign currencies were simplified. They no longer had to report a maturity breakdown of their spot position. Banks henceforth were to submit to the Netherlands Bank copies of all forward exchange contracts with nonresidents. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS ANTILLES (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.471230 gram of fine gold per Netherlands Antilles Guilder.l The gold content of the currency has been established at 0.411543 gram of fine gold. The central rate is Ant. f. 1.79000 per US$1, and the Netherlands Antilles avails itself of wider margins. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar. Exchange transactions between commercial banks and the public take place at Ant. f. 1.79 buying, and Ant. f. 1.81 selling, per US$1, plus a tax of 8/10 of 1 per cent on sales of exchange, making the effective selling rate for the U.S. dollar Ant. f. 1.8245 per US$1.2 The official buying and selling rates for certain other cur- rencies are set daily on the basis of rates for the U.S. dollar abroad. The Bank of the Netherlands Antilles (the central bank) deals with commercial banks at interbank rates. The Bank does not normally deal with the public. Com- mercial banks require the approval of the central bank to invest or hold foreign currency balances.3 Administration of Control Exchange licenses, where required, are issued by the central bank. Import licenses are issued by the Depart- ment of Economic Affairs. The commercial banks are permitted by the central bank to provide foreign ex- change for most current transactions without prior ap- proval. The central bank may grant an exemption from the obligation of surrendering foreign exchange, insofar as the assets or moneys concerned were acquired from nonresidents and are not being held in favor of or on behalf of, or for the account of, third parties who are residents; the foreign exchange may then be held or used freely until further notice or until revocation by the central bank. Prescription of Currency Payments may be made in any currency except Neth- erlands Antilles guilders. Receipts may be accepted in any convertible currency except Netherlands Antilles guilders. For statistical purposes, all payments made by residents through the authorized banks in foreign ex- change must be reported to the central bank. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may freely open nonresident accounts in any foreign currency. Nonresidents (including for- eign investment funds, etc., with nonresident status) are permitted to hold nonresident accounts in Netherlands Antilles guilders only if the authorized bank concerned considers that they have certain interests in the Nether- lands Antilles which render such an account desirable; balances in such accounts may not without central bank approval exceed Ant. f. 10,000. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain items, such as narcotics and explo- sives, are subject to license for public policy reasons. Imports into the islands of Aruba, Bonaire, and Cura- cao of nonvacuum-packed cereals (other than rice), cer- tain wheat meal and wheat flour, cement floor and street tiles, terrazzo tiles, and chicken eggs are prohib- ited unless the Minister of Economic Affairs grants applicants an exemption; for price control purposes only, certain other commodities, including alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, Pharmaceuticals, cement, and new or used automobiles, are subject to licensing by the Department of Economic Affairs upon customs clear- ance. Payments for permitted imports may be made freely. Companies with nonresident status normally fi- nance their imports with their own foreign exchange. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles are not restricted. For most types of current invisibles remittances may be made freely through the authorized banks. Licenses are required, however, for the purchase of travel exchange in excess of Ant. f. 180 a person for each day to be spent abroad and for certain personal remittances in excess of Ant. f. 2,500 each or in excess of Ant. f. 10,000 a person a year. Such licenses are freely granted when no illegal capital transfer seems to be involved. For payments representing interest on loans or net income from other investments and for amortiza- tion of loans or depreciation of direct investments, li- censes are granted on application, subject to verification of the facts. Nonresidents may take with them on departure any foreign currency which they brought in on arrival. The export of Netherlands Antilles banknotes is limited to Ant. f. 200 a person. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require licenses, which are usually granted. Exchange proceeds must be surrendered to an authorized bank within six months of shipment, with the exception of export proceeds received by companies with nonresident status. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles (except those of firms with nonresident status) must in princi- ple be surrendered to an authorized bank within eight days of receipt, but in practice the public is allowed to hold foreign banknotes and coins, since the domestic 347 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS ANTILLES currency and the U.S. dollar circulate concurrently. Travelers may bring with them checks, travelers checks, or banknotes in foreign currency in unlimited amounts. Each traveler may also bring in Ant. f. 200 in Netherlands Antilles banknotes. Capital Foreign investment in the Netherlands Antilles re- quires a license, which is, in general, granted if the investment is in the economic and social interest of the islands; the Investment Incentives Program, as amended, provides for duty-free entry of many com- modities as well as tax facilities. New industrial compa- nies primarily engaged in exporting may be granted nonresident status by the central bank, which confers on the company concerned exemption from exchange control (except in its transactions with residents), in- cluding exemption from the requirement of surrender- ing their foreign currency receipts. Such exemption may also be granted to investment companies, patent hold- ing companies, shipping companies, and insurance companies. Outward flows of resident-owned capital are subject to control, and certain capital transactions by or on behalf of residents are restricted. Life insurance con- tracts between residents and foreign insurance compa- nies for a minimum term of ten years are licensed freely up to an amount which is fixed annually, depending on the foreign exchange position. Investment by residents in real estate situated abroad requires a license. Invest- ment in foreign securities (i.e., securities issued outside the Netherlands Antilles or payable or optionally pay- able in the currency of a country other than the Nether- lands Antilles) requires a license only when exceeding Ant. f. 2,500 a transaction or Ant. f. 10,000 a person a year. Investments by residents in officially quoted foreign securities (other than shares in mutual funds, investment in which is not permitted) are licensed freely up to amounts fixed annually, depending on the foreign exchange position. In considering applications by such residents as pension funds and other institutional inves- tors, the central bank takes into account the merits of each case and, in particular, the limited opportunity for domestic investment; the bank may exert moral sua- sion, however, to discourage excessive outflows of resi- dent-owned capital. Authorized banks may freely borrow foreign cur- rency abroad from nonresidents (including residents with nonresident status), or accept foreign currency deposits from nonresidents, for relending to nonresi- dents or redeposit abroad; their borrowing from non- residents for relending to residents is restricted for monetary policy reasons and banks require central bank approval to incur a net foreign liability position. Nonresidents are not normally permitted to acquire balances in Netherlands Antilles guilders. Local bor- rowing in domestic currency by nonresidents (includ- ing resident companies regarded as nonresidents for exchange control purposes) is restricted. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in the Netherlands Antilles for numismatic and investment purposes; authorized banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents. Resi- dents other than the monetary authorities and autho- rized industrial users are not allowed without special permission to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry or coins, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the central bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports of coins by authorized banks, and for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and indus- trial users. Changes during 1974 October 1. Imports of additional commodities (ce- ment floor and street tiles and terrazzo tiles) were pro- hibited unless a prior import license was obtained. November 8. The Fund was informed that the Neth- erlands Antilles subscribed to the Voluntary Declara- tion on Trade and Other Current Account Measures for Balance of Payments Purposes. Not for Redistribution NEW ZEALAND (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.99531 gram of fine gold per New Zealand Dollar, corresponding to $NZ 0.892857 = SDR 1, and New Zealand avails itself of wider margins, although since July 9, 1973 no announced margins have been observed. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand adjusts the exchange rate for the U.S. dollar daily so as to maintain the effective relationship between the New Zealand dollar and the currencies of the main trading partners as at September 25, 1974. Except for the Aus- tralian dollar and the pound sterling, the rates for spot transactions in currencies quoted by the New Zealand trading (commercial) banks are based on the closing buying and selling rates of the previous day in London. The rate for the pound sterling is derived by crossing the U .S ./London rate quoted in New York with the New Zealand/U.S. rate. The banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were US$1.3205 and US$1.3105, respectively, per $NZ 1. The trading banks are permitted to conclude with their customers forward exchange contracts for up to 6 months to cover import transactions and for up to 12 months to cover export transactions. Forward transac- tions in Canadian dollars and pounds sterling take place at rates of exchange determined daily by the Re- serve Bank and based on the closing buying and selling rates of the previous day in London. Forward exchange contracts written in U.S. dollars are concluded at the relative spot rates, adjusted in the case of contracts covering imports with a loading of US$0.0050 a month on the spot rate. The Reserve Bank provides a facility whereby trading banks may obtain day-to-day cover for their net positions in Canadian dollars, pounds ster- ling, and U.S. dollars, spot and forward. Contracts in other currencies may be covered through the London or New York foreign exchange markets, against ster- ling or U.S. dollars. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Reserve Bank under powers delegated to its Governor by the Minister of Finance. The Reserve Bank in turn has given discretionary authority to the trading banks in New Zealand to approve applications for certain remit- tances of funds overseas. The Overseas Investment Commission administers the regulations governing for- eign direct investment in New Zealand. Export and import licensing is the responsibility of the Customs Department and the Department of Trade and Indus- try, respectively. Prescription of Currency New Zealand has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Payments to and from residents of countries other than New Zealand may generally be made or received in any foreign currency.1 Payment to and from the New Zealand currency accounts held with banks in New Zealand by banks not domiciled in New Zealand or Rhodesia generally also is an acceptable form of payment. Nonresident Accounts The Reserve Bank supervises certain specified ac- counts in New Zealand of residents of other countries ("controlled accounts"). The accounts in New Zealand dollars of overseas banks may be used for the settle- ment of transactions with other countries, but they may only be funded from overseas or by amounts which would otherwise be remittable from New Zealand. Imports and Import Payments Imports are controlled through an annual Import Licensing Schedule, which groups imports into differ- ent categories to which various import procedures are applied. On a value basis, about 70 per cent of all private imports are exempt from licensing. The import categories included in the Schedule for July 1, 1974-June 30, 1975 are as follows: Category "E" (ex- empt) includes petroleum, lubricating oils, certain other raw materials, green coffee, cocoa beans, jute, many textiles, specified sporting goods, tires, and printed books which may be imported without license. In addition, certain imports of Australian origin are exempt from licensing, irrespective of the licensing cat- egory to which they belong.2 A "Basic" category com- prises items for which licenses are granted by reference to qualifying licenses issued or actual imports in a pre- vious licensing period. Category "C" licenses are granted on an individual basis on such criteria as essen- tiality, availability, and price; for some "C" items, how- ever, an initial allocation based on a previous period is provided, while applications for further licenses are considered individually. "Administrative basic li- censes" are issued automatically to ensure continuity of importation for certain regularly required goods that correspond to only part of an item code. In order to assure continuity of imports of specific items, mainly raw materials and consumer goods, in the 1974/75 program, the Government undertook that over a three-year period importers would receive licenses at least equal in value to the basic allocation for 1974/75. All licenses issued may be used for imports from any source at the applicant's discretion. Imports from Rho- desia, however, are prohibited. A degree of flexibility in the application of the Licensing Schedule is achieved 349 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEW ZEALAND through the use of Group Schemes (for Industry and Interchangeability Groups) that enable importers to transfer individual entitlements to a composite license, instead of holding licenses for separate items, and to import, up to the total amount, any item or combina- tion of items in the group. "No-remittance licenses" for imports outside the Im- port Licensing Schedule may be issued in special cir- cumstances, viz., for advertising material supplied free of charge; gifts, passengers' baggage, replacement of fau l ty or damaged goods; trade samples supplied free of charge; and temporary imports. The trading banks have authority to make foreign exchange in an appropriate currency available for pay- ments in respect of all licensed imports and all imports that do not require a license. Payments for Invisibles The trading banks are permitted to sell exchange for overseas payments up to established limits for many categories of invisibles, subject in appropriate cases to the submission of jus t i fy ing documents. Payments be- yond the established limits, and for categories not in- cluded in the commercial banks' permitted list, require the specific approval of the Reserve Bank; applications must be supported, where appropriate, by jus t i fy ing documents. Banks are authorized to sell foreign ex- change for genuine foreign travel purposes without prior reference to the Reserve Bank up to $NZ 1,000 a person a mon th or part thereof, with a maximum of $NZ 4,000 a person in any 12-month period. Requests for amounts in excess of $NZ 1,000 a mon th or for a total of more than $NZ 4,000 in any 12-month period must be referred to the Reserve Bank. Larger amounts of exchange for any type of travel are authorized at the discretion of the Reserve Bank, which meets all reason- able requests for genuine travel purposes. In addition to the above allocations, banks in New Zealand and their branches or agents in London and Australia may sell foreign currencies, without limit as to amount, to New Zealand travelers against these persons' privately held foreign funds. The remittance abroad of dividends, interest, and profits due to nonresidents is approved, subject to for- mal authentication; for dividends and interest, the ap- proval authority up to $NZ 1,500 in any 12-month period to any one remittee has been delegated to the authorized banks. Most contractual obligations in- curred in the ordinary course of business also are nor- mally approved, but each remittance requires approval and new commitments such as royalty agreements with overseas licensors or overseas borrowing require the prior consent of the Reserve Bank. Allocations for remittances on account of mainte- nance a n d / or gifts are made on a yearly basis without discrimination. Remittances by recognized New Zealand religious and charitable organizations or indi- viduals operating as members of such an organization 350 are not subject to any limitation. Allocations to indi- viduals for religious and charitable remittances, other than of the type specified above, are approved by the Reserve Bank up to $NZ 500 a remitter, and applica- tions for larger amounts are considered on their merits. Any resident may freely make personal remittances up to a total of $NZ 100 a year to any destination overseas except Rhodesia, for any purpose except gambling or building up assets in the remitter's name, provided no individual remittance exceeds $NZ 20. Travelers may take with them up to $NZ 50 in New Zealand currency, regardless of destination. Banknotes taken out may not be in denominations larger than $NZ 5. Up to $NZ 4 of the permitted total may be in coins. Exports and Export Proceeds With minor exceptions, all exports require export licenses. These are issued by the Customs Department and carry the condition that the net export proceeds must be surrendered to a trading bank in accordance with the prescription of currency regulations. General export licenses valid until December 31, 1975 are is- sued to regular exporters. Payments for exports must, unless prior consent is obtained, be received within six months from the date of shipment. Exports to Rhode- sia are prohibited. Certain items classified as strategic goods may only be exported when particular require- ments have been met and subsequent to the issue of a permit to export. Temporary restrictions have been im- posed on exports of tallow and specified types of mut- ton and on exports and re-exports of sugar. Exports of beef and veal to the United States and cheddar-type cheese to the United Kingdom are subject to restraint. Under an export bonus scheme, manufacturers sub- m i t t ing evidence of exportation may receive a replace- ment import license of the same value as the imported raw material or components still subject to import con- trol that are incorporated in the exported goods, as well as, subject to certain conditions being met, an addi- tional bonus license; goods imported against the bonus license may be used for the manufacture of goods for the home market or for export. The bonus license must not exceed the difference between the f.o.b. value of the goods exported and the c.i.f. value of imported materi- als a n d / or components used in manufacture by the exporter. Proceeds from Invisibles When remuneration for services provided or to be provided in New Zealand for overseas residents by New Zealand residents (including corporate bodies or- dinarily resident in New Zealand) is paid in the form of foreign assets,3 their foreign currency proceeds must be sold to the New Zealand banking system; interest and dividends earned overseas from portfolio invest- ment are excluded from this surrender requirement. If the remuneration is in a form other than a foreign ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution currency or a balance with an overseas bank, it must be converted into foreign currency before the surrender takes place. The disposal overseas by New Zealand residents of foreign income from other invisibles such as interest and dividends is permitted, but such income is not eligible for sale in exchange for new Zealand currency, except that the foreign currency proceeds may be sold to a New Zealand bank. Travelers may bring into the country unlimited amounts of foreign and domestic banknotes and coins, provided that any New Zealand banknotes brought in are in denominations not exceeding $NZ 5. Capital With the exception of certain capital issues outside New Zealand and certain overseas borrowings by cor- porate bodies, consents are not required in respect of capital receipts. Applications for consent to borrow abroad by companies operating in the property sector are not normally approved, unless the project involved is consistent with the Government's housing policy. While overseas borrowing by financial institutions is strictly controlled, consents are usually granted where the funds are required for industrial development pur- poses. To be eligible for repatriation, capital must have been initially transferred to New Zealand through nor- mal banking channels or in some other way approved by the authorities, e.g., as imports of plant or machin- ery. Capital so transferred, including capital gains and capitalized profits, may be repatriated, after the formal approval of the Reserve Bank has been obtained. In the case of overseas borrowing, repayments are not permit- ted within 12 months of the receipt of the proceeds. Overseas companies seeking to commence business in New Zealand require the approval of the Overseas In- vestment Commission, under the terms of the Overseas Investment Regulations, 1974. Capital issues outside New Zealand by companies incorporated in New Zealand require the approval of the Overseas Investment Commission; overseas bor- rowing by such companies also requires prior approval. Forward exchange cover is provided for borrowings abroad by New Zealand companies and by foreign- owned companies but, in order to qualify, borrowings must be for a specific project which directly assists the development of New Zealand industry. In addition, forward exchange cover is for the amount of the capital sum only and is normally limited to not less than $NZ 50,000 and not more than $NZ 1 million for each project. New Zealand subsidiaries and branches of overseas companies must obtain the consent of the Overseas Investment Commission if they wish to borrow in New Zealand, whether for long-term or short-term finance; the ratio between New Zealand and overseas borrow- ing that is permitted is generally related to that between New Zealand and overseas equity holdings, and the NEW ZEALAND ceiling on local borrowing for working capital purposes by nonfinance companies that are predominantly or wholly foreign-owned or controlled is 10 per cent of the previous year's turnover. Nonresident persons or com- panies desiring to make a direct investment in a New Zealand company through the purchase or exchange of shares are required to give notice of any offer made for such shares whenever the investment would result in the control by the offerer of 25 per cent or more of the New Zealand company's voting capital. Emigrants to any destination other than Rhodesia may upon designation as nonresidents transfer the whole of their assets to their new country of residence. Applications for the remittance abroad of legacies from the estate of a New Zealand resident are normally ap- proved in full. The authorities do not normally make exchange available to private persons or firms for the purchase of overseas securities for portfolio investment. New Zealand Government bonds purchased overseas by New Zealand residents after September 5, 1969 may not be transferred from the United Kingdom to the New Zealand register. A New Zealand resident owning overseas securities is free to sell them to overseas resi- dents for any foreign currency, which may be rein- vested in other overseas securities, surrendered, or retained at the disposal of the New Zealand resident. With limited exceptions, sales of overseas securities by one New Zealand resident to another may be made only in exchange for other overseas securities or for any overseas currency. The only overseas securities that may be traded between New Zealand residents in ex- change for New Zealand currency are those of any overseas country which were registered in the names of New Zealand residents on June 16, 1966 and for which scrip or other documents evidencing title were issued; the purchaser must lodge the share scrip with an ap- proved depository (i.e., the Reserve Bank of New Zealand). These securities may also be sold for any overseas .currency, in which case the proceeds must immediately be remitted to New Zealand through the banking system or reinvested in other overseas securi- ties within three months and the resulting scrip depos- ited. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in New Zealand for numismatic purposes. Since the revocation in 1954 of the Gold Acquisition Notice, 1948, it is no longer necessary to offer gold to the Reserve Bank, and sales within New Zealand do not require Reserve Bank approval. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Customs De- partment; such licenses are not normally granted ex- cept for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Commercial 351 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEW ZEALAND imports of gold jewelry are licensed restrictively, but the importation of gold coins is exempt from license. Changes during 1974 March 15. The Reserve Bank reduced permitted local borrowing by wholly or partly foreign-owned nonfi- nance companies. The ceiling on borrowing for work- ing capital purposes was set at the pre-June 1973 level of 10 per cent of annual turnover. April 4. The 1974/75 Import Licensing Schedule was announced, to become effective on July 1. Allocations would generally be 20 per cent higher than in 1973/74 and a number of items would be added to List E. Imports of automobiles would be increased by about 4,000 units. New arrangements were introduced to give an assurance to importers of specific items involving basic licenses, mainly raw materials and consumer goods, that over a three-year period they would receive licenses for the later years at least equal in amount to the basic allocation for 1974/75, unless an emergency situation were to arise. List D (comprising items of a type also produced in New Zealand for which licenses were issued only in exceptional circumstances) and the system of token licenses for severely restricted items were to be terminated on June 30, 1974. The items which were previously on List D were shifted to the "Basic" Category and Category C, and token licenses were replaced by "basic" licenses. May 20. The Overseas Investment Regulations, 1974 were made, which came into force on May 24. They consolidated and extended the provisions of the Over- seas Takeovers Regulations, 1964 and the Capital Is- sues (Overseas) Regulations, 1965, both of which were then revoked. The new regulations were administered by the Overseas Investment Commission comprising two private members appointed by the Governor-Gen- eral on the recommendation of the Minister of Finance. The Governor of the Reserve Bank, the Secretary to the Treasury, and the Secretary to the Department of Trade and Industry (or their nominees) were also mem- bers. The Reserve Bank provided the Secretariat for the Commission. May 27. The method of quoting public exchange rates was changed. (1) The spread between telegraphic transfer buying and selling rates was reduced in respect of Canadian dollars, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars. (2) Thereafter the telegraphic transfer rates fixed daily by the Reserve Bank would be outer limits and trading banks would be permitted and encouraged to quote rates within these outer limits. (3) Forward exchange charges were reduced slightly. May 30. Improvements in export incentives were an- nounced. Some affected nontraditional, unprocessed commodities only. Also, a suspensory loan scheme for agricultural and horticultural procucers outside the tra- ditional pastoral industries would be introduced. The latter came into operation on September 25. 352 May 30. New Zealand signed the OECD Declaration on Imports, Exports, and Other Current Account Transactions. June 25. The Meat Board set a minimum export price for beef produced during the next two seasons. July 1. A new customs tariff came into operation. The second stage of the phasing-out of Commonwealth preferences on goods of U.K. origin began. July 26. The cost of forward cover was increased for importers and decreased for exporters. The maximum period for which the Reserve Bank would provide for- ward cover for imports was reduced from 12 to 6 months. August 16. Financial institutions, which previously had not been permitted to borrow abroad, were given permission to do so, provided the proceeds were used for industrial development purposes. August 30. Changes were announced in the arrange- ments for borrowing in New Zealand by nonfinance companies that are predominantly or wholly foreign- owned or controlled. The main change was that in assessing the amount of local borrowing permitted for such companies a lower weighting would be given to New Zealand equity where it was a minority holding as compared with ventures where there was equal or pre- dominant New Zealand shareholding. In addition, the borrowing ceiling for working capital requirements of 10 per cent of turnover would henceforth be related to the previous year's turnover rather than estimated fu- ture turnover. September 3. Installment credit restrictions were tightened for automobiles, light trucks, and motorcy- cles, in order to reduce imports of these items. September 12. It was announced that administrative measures were being taken to restrict the value of im- port licenses granted, particularly where overstocking had occurred, by a closer screening of applications. No exempt items were brought under import licensing. September 18. It was announced that the Govern- ment had arranged a five-year multicurrency revolving credit of US$400 million with a syndicate of interna- tional banks. September 18. It was announced that exporters fac- ing liquidity problems could obtain credit assistance. Banks would be able to obtain replacement funds from the Reserve Bank to the extent of discounted export bills drawn in respect of commodities broadly covered by the tax incentive for increased exports, in practice, manufactured goods and most traditional commodities other than meat and wool. September 25. The New Zealand dollar was effec- tively depreciated by approximately 6.2 per cent against the weighted basket of currencies of New Zealand's main trading partners. The Reserve Bank would continue to determine exchange rates daily by adjusting for changes in the exchange rates of the cur- rencies in the weighted basket of currencies, but with September 25, 1974 as the new base date. The new rate against the U.S. dollar was $NZ 1 = US$1.3, and that ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution against the Australian dollar was $NZ 1 = $A 0.9932; the buying rates quoted by the Reserve Bank on Sep- tember 24 had been $NZ 1 = US$1.4339 and $NZ 1 = $A 0.9626. October L The Meat Board reimposed a levy on beef and veal for export. November 8. A bill to amend the legislation govern- ing petroleum prospecting and mining licenses was in- troduced. It was not enacted during 1974. December 13. It was announced that financial assis- tance to nonfarm exporters under the Export Credit Assistance Scheme would be increased. December 15. Exports and re-exports of sugar were made subject to licensing. Not for Redistribution NICARAGUA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.105237 gram of fine gold per Nicaraguan Cordoba, corresponding to C$7.00 = US$1. The Central Bank of Nicaragua deals with the commercial banks in U.S. dollars, the intervention cur- rency, at C$7.00 per US$1, buying and selling, and sells exchange to the Government at C$7.0525 per US$1. All exchange transactions between commercial banks and the public take place at the official rates of C$7.00 buying, and C$7.0525 selling, per US$1. Nicaragua accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from July 20, 1964. Administration of Control The exchange control system is administered by the Central Bank, which by law has the sole authority to buy and sell foreign exchange. This authority has been delegated to the commercial banks, and the Central Bank deals with the public only to the extent that it accepts deposits in foreign currency, and for purposes of monetary control. Certain agencies are also autho- rized to buy and sell foreign exchange, but they may sell exchange only for payments for invisibles. The Central Bank is responsible for classifying imports and deter- m in ing any advance deposits required; no advance de- posit requirements are in force at present. Prescription of Currency There is no prescription of currency, but the customs authorities have the power to prohibit an export if the currency stipulated for payment is not readily convert- ible in to U.S. dollars in international markets. Pay- ments to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras in respect of trade and invisibles may be settled in Nicaraguan cordobas through the Camara de Compensation Centroamericana, a clearinghouse es- tablished by the central banks of Central America to foster the process of economic integration of their countries. Payments to Mexico may also be settled in Nicaraguan cordobas through the clearinghouse. The Central Bank does not accept banknotes of El Salvador for compensation through the clearinghouse in excess of 400,000 Salvadoran colones a mon th. of Economy. Import licenses are not required, but im- port transactions must be registered with the Central Bank by means of import declarations. All imports on credit and all prepayments for imports require ap- proval by the Central Bank, which is normally granted only for capital goods, industrial materials, and other essential goods; when payment is not being made on sight of documents, an application for registration of the order must be submitted to the Central Bank. Im- ports of certain types of footwear and some pharmaceu- tical and veterinary supplies are prohibited, except when produced in countries signatory to the General Treaty for Central American Economic Integration. Payments for imports must be made with exchange purchased from banks. * Payments are usually made by sight drafts. Letters of credit are mostly confined to imports from Japan. Central Bank approval is not re- quired to open an import letter of credit. The banks are not permitted to sell exchange for import payments in advance of the arrival of the documents. The Central Bank may authorize deferred payment or payment with funds derived from properly authenticated credits ob- tained abroad, provided that the imports are capital goods intended for development or production or for basic works complementary to production; such per- mission is at present limited mainly to industrial and agricultural machinery and, for certain industries, raw materials. Imports are not released from customs un- less evidence is submitted either that payment has been made through a bank (constancia de pago) or that ac- ceptance has been made through a bank {constancia de aceptacion). In the latter case, the Central Bank must also approve the importation on credit terms; this re- quirement does not apply to duty-free imports from member countries of the Central American Common Market. Most imports originating outside the Central Ameri- can Common Market are subject to an import sur- charge of 30 per cent of the applicable import duty. Certain commodities are subject to a compensatory (selective) consumption tax irrespective of their origin. Furthermore, most commodities are subject to a 6 per cent general sales tax, whether they are imported or domestically produced. Imports and Import Payments All importers are required to be registered. There are two categories of registered importers: those who are permitted to import any kind of merchandise and those who may import only for their own industrial needs. Imports from all countries, except the other Central American countries, must be consigned to persons or firms holding a commercial license from the Ministry Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are not subject to license and may be made freely. Persons purchasing foreign cur- rency to make payments for invisibles are required, for statistical purposes, to complete a declaration specify- ing the purpose for which the foreign currency obtained will be used. Domestic and foreign currency notes may be exported freely. 354 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are not required, but a declaration to the customs authorities must be completed for statisti- cal purposes. The exchange proceeds of exports do not have to be surrendered; however, they may not be used to pay for imports (exchange for which must be pur- chased from a bank, with the exception stated in note 1). For certain agricultural exports (live cattle, beans, rice, corn, and cottonseed), the Ministry of Economy can fix minimum export prices or temporarily prohibit their export in order to avoid domestic shortages. Proceeds from Invisibles The surrender of foreign exchange derived from in- visibles is not required. Domestic and foreign currency notes may be imported freely. Capital Remittances on account of foreign capital and capi- tal transfers by residents and nonresidents may be made freely under the general provisions of the Ex- change Law of March 1, 1963 or under the Law on Foreign Investments of February 26, 1955 (effective March 11, 1955). Under the 1955 law, foreign invest- ments approved by the Central Bank and registered are guaranteed the following privileges: repatriation of the registered capital; transfer of earnings, profits, or inter- est on the capital; and re-exportation of goods imported for investment. Commercial banks and private invest- ment companies require the prior approval of the Cen- tral Bank for all borrowing abroad. Gold Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Nicaragua. Producers of gold sell their newly mined gold at free market prices to buyers abroad. The Central Bank purchases gold NICARAGUA abroad for resale to domestic industrial and other us- ers. Nonmonetary imports and exports of gold do not require import or export licenses but must be registered with the Central Bank and require prior government authorization. Commemorative gold coins were issued in 1967. Changes during 1974 January 17. The commodities that had on March 15, 1973 been added to the list of goods whose importation on credit terms could be authorized by the Central Bank, were taken off that list again. On March 21, construction materials and transport vehicles not for private use were added to the list. March 26. Decree No. 26 of 1951 was revoked which prohibited trade with socialist countries. November 16. The stamp tax of V2 of 1 per cent on sales of foreign exchange by the commercial banks to the public was abolished. Since the tax had involved a multiple currency practice, this action unified the ex- change rate structure. November 16. The 10 per cent emergency tax on traditional exports was abolished. November 16. The general sales tax applicable to most commodities, whether imported or domestically produced, was increased from 5 per cent to 6 per cent; certain services and additional goods became subject to the tax. November 16. Compensatory (selective) taxes were revised to reduce the number of rates; additional goods became subject to these taxes.
