Not for Redistribution NIGER (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Niger has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the CFA Franc1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transac- tions in French francs, the intervention currency, be- tween the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de POuest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02, subject to a commission from which transactions for the account of the public Treasury and transactions in banknotes and travelers checks are exempt; the commission is Yio of 1 per mill for transfers within the West African Monetary Union and 2.50 per mill for transfers to countries outside the Union. Exchange rates for foreign currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West African Monetary Union, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. With the exception of those relating to gold, Niger's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mali, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Niger itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only with foreign countries are subject to ex- change control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Division in the Ministry of Finance which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Niger, and inward and outward investment. The BCEAO is autho- rized to collect, either direct or through the intermedi- ary of banks, financial institutions, the Postal Administration, and notaries public, any information necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. All exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through the BCEAO or authorized banks. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Economic Affairs in the Ministry of Eco- nomic Affairs, Commerce, and Industry, subject to the visa of the External Finance Division, except those for gold, which are granted by the Ministry of Finance. Import certificates for liberalized commodities are 356 made out by the importer himself and, when imports are payable prior to importation, are first approved by the External Finance Division. Prescription of Currency Niger is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settle- ments with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in foreign cur- rencies or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. Certain settlements with Nigeria, however, are made through special accounts. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO bank- notes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Niamey by authorized banks' foreign corre- spondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident ac- counts of BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments All imports of commodities originating in Portugal or its overseas provinces, Rhodesia, or South Africa are prohibited. The import from any source of rice, paddy, hulled rice, wheat flour, butane gas, many types of fabrics, and certain footwear and plastic goods requires prior authorization, irrespective of whether an import license or import certificate is also required. A similar regime applies to imports of sugar, except from member countries of the Common Organization of African and Mauritian States, and to imports of matches, except from countries of the West African Customs Union. Imports from France and the Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area of all goods other than those mentioned may be made freely without a license or certificate. Imports from other countries re- quire either a license or an import certificate. Imports of virtually all goods from Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, and EEC countries, many goods from other former OEEC countries and their past or present dependent territories, and a smaller number of items from the United States and Canada are liberalized and require only an import certificate. Imports of nonliberalized goods from non-EEC countries outside the French ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Franc Area are made under global quotas in accor- dance with an annual program that is determined each year by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Commerce, and Industry; the program generally reflects the re- quirements indicated by importers and is established in mutual agreement within a joint French-Nigerien Com- mittee. Licenses for printed or unprinted cotton fabrics and for jute bags, however, are issued in proportion to duly substantiated imports from France of a specified quantity of these goods. Goods not subject to quantita- tive restriction may be imported on an import certifi- cate, i.e., a declaration made out by the importer. The Societe Nationale de Commerce et de Produc- tion du Niger (COPRONIGER) has a monopoly over the import of specified commodities. These include wheat, wheat flour, green tea, and certain textiles. All import transactions with foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when valued at more than CFAF 25,000 c.i.f. Niger border. The import licenses or import certificates entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, provided that the authorized bank is satisfied that the import transaction is genuine and in accordance with the import title. Import certificates require the visa of the External Finance Division if the goods are payable before importation. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to the approval of the Exter- nal Finance Division, which for certain transactions has delegated its powers to the authorized banks. Pay- ments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, divi- dends, and royalties are also permitted freely when the basic transaction has been approved. Residents travel- ing on tourist trips to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Ac- count countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to CFAF 100,000 a person a trip (CFAF 50,000 for chil- dren under ten), which may be taken up twice a year; any foreign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 remain- ing after return to Niger must be surrendered within eight days by sale to an authorized bank. The transfer of salaries of foreigners working in Niger is subject to prior approval by the External Finance Division. Resident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a maximum of CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries, in addition to their travel allocation. Resident travelers to other countries of the French Franc Area may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes but, when traveling to a French Franc Area country outside the West African NIGER Monetary Union, must declare these if they exceed CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may freely take out up to CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries, and foreign notes up to the amount declared upon entry,2 or, if no declaration was made, up to CFAF 25,000; they may also take out freely any amount of foreign currency travelers checks, etc., is- sued abroad in their name. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. All exports of rice and paddy require the prior authorization of the Directorate of Economic Affairs. Exports of millet and sorghum are prohibited unless covered by a shipping document in the name of the Office des Produits Vivri- ers du Niger (OPVN). Gum arabic may be exported only by COPRONIGER. With the exception of peanuts, peanut oil, peanut cakes, sisal, cotton, cottonseed, and certain imported commodities, all of which require a license, all other exports to France (as defined above) and the Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be made freely. Exports to all other countries of domestic products and imported commod- ities require a license and an exchange commitment. The due date of payments for exports to foreign countries must not, in principle, be later than 180 days after arrival of the goods at their destination. The pro- ceeds must be collected and, if the contract is denomi- nated in a non-Franc Area currency, surrendered by sale on the exchange market, within two months after the due date. All export transactions with foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their total value exceeds CFAF 100,000. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Ac- count countries in the French Franc Area may be re- tained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services, and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets, must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date or the date of receipt. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or a bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins). Residents must surren- der within eight days of entry any foreign currency in excess of CFAF 5,000. Capital Capital movements between Niger and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Ac- count countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other 357 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NIGER countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward and outward in- vestment, and over the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Niger; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. With the exception of those over foreign securities in Niger, these control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member countries of the West African Mone- tary Union, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account. Special controls are maintained also over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special controls do apply also to France (as de- fined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All investments abroad by residents of Niger require prior authorization by the Minister of Finance.3 For- eign direct investments in Niger4 must be declared to the Minister of Finance before they are made. The Min- ister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postpone- ment of the projects submitted to him. The full or partial liquidation of investments, whether direct or not, also requires prior declaration. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Nigerien investments abroad or foreign investments in Niger, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and the BCEAO within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of for- eign securities in Niger requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Nigerien Government, and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issuing or offering for sale in Niger has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authoriza- tion: (1) loans constituting a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans contracted by authorized banks; and (3) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 2 million for any one borrower, provided that the annual interest rate 358 does not exceed the "normal" market rate and that the proceeds of the loan are immediately sold on the ex- change market or debited to a Foreign Account in Francs. The repayment of a foreign borrowing consti- tuting a direct investment is subject to the same formal- ities as the liquidation of a direct investment; the repayment of other borrowings requires authorization only to the extent that the borrowing itself was subject to prior authorization. Lending abroad is subject to prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. Foreign investments in Niger may be granted certain guarantees and facilities under the Investment Code of July 31, 1968 (Law No. 68-24), as amended by Law No. 71-2 of January 29, 1971 and Law No. 74-18 of March 11,1974. Existing benefits accorded under the previous Investment Code (Law No. 61-21 of July 12, 1961) have been maintained. The new Investment Code provides for privileged or regular treatment. The latter provides, for both new and existing enterprises, assurances, with respect to indemnities in the event of nationalization and concern- ing nondiscrimination between Nigerien nationals and foreign nationals; tax exemptions will be granted to new investments. Privileged treatment is reserved for enterprises deemed to be of special importance to na- tional economic development and falling within speci- fied categories of industrial activities. Such treatment may be accorded under two different regimes, the ap- proval regime and the agreement regime. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Niger. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authoriza- tion by the Minister of Finance, which is seldom granted. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufactured arti- cles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) articles of gold up to a combined weight of 500 grams when car- ried by a traveler. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Changes during 1974 January 19. The fixed exchange rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02 was maintained following the announcement of the French authorities that during the next six months, and on a provisional basis, the interventions of the Exchange Stabilization Fund in the official exchange market would no longer aim at limiting the exchange rates between the French franc and certain other cur- rencies within predetermined margins. An official deci- sion to this effect was taken by the Council of the West African Monetary Union on January 24. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution March 11. Law No. 74-18 amending Law No. 68-24 and Law No. 71-2 modified the regime governing for- eign investments in Niger. March 11. Law No. 74-19 was enacted, which com- prised an Investment Code for Nigerien enterprises. March 21. Following the abolition of the dual ex- change market in France, the dual market arrange- ments in Niger also ceased to operate. The financial franc market and the Financial Accounts in Francs were abolished and settlements with countries outside the French Franc Area henceforth took place only through the official exchange market and through For- eign Accounts in Francs. The relevant exchange con- trol regulations were issued in Niger on July 22 (Order No. 183/MF/SFE and Circular No. 23). April 6. Law No. 74-26 exempted gold imported for the use of manufacturing jewelers from fiscal du ty, cus- toms duty, and statistical import tax. April 24. Decree No. 74-58 conferred on COPRONIGER a monopoly over the importation of matches, tomatoes, NIGER and tomato puree. May 28. Decree No. 74-110 regulated the holding of, trading in, and exportation and importation of gold. NOTES 1 The CFA franc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de FOuest (BCEAO) and is the common cur- rency in Dahomey, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 2 This amount is reduced, when appropriate, by the amount sold for CFA francs and increased by the amount of foreign notes acquired in Niger by debit to a Foreign Account in Francs or a foreign currency account, by exchange for other foreign means of payment brought in, or by repurchase with CFA francs (such repurchase being limited to the equiv- alent of CFAF 25,000). 3 Including those made through the intermediary of foreign companies that are directly or indirectly controlled by per- sons in Niger and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Niger. 4 Including those made by companies in Niger that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Niger of foreign companies. 359 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NIGERIA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The currency of Nigeria is the Naira. On April 17, 1963 an initial par value of 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Nigerian pound was established. On February 14, 1973 a central rate was established of 1.11973 grams of fine gold per naira, corresponding at the time to ** 0.793648 = SDR 1 or 2* 0.657893 = US$1. Since April 1, 1974, however, Nigeria has followed an inde- pendent exchange rate policy. Nigeria avails itself of wider margins and the intervention currency is the U.S. dollar. The Central Bank of Nigeria quotes daily rates at which it is prepared to deal in U.S. dollars and sterling with authorized dealers and the public; such dealings are for approved transactions and are on a spot basis only. The Central Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar are set at V2 of 1 per cent either side of the middle rate, and those for sterling are determined on the basis of the prevailing U.S. dollar rate and the previous day's dollar/sterling middle rate quoted in London. The Central Bank does not normally publish rates for other foreign currencies.1 On December 31, 1974, the Cen- tral Bank's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$1.6309 and US$1.6147, respectively, per N 1, and its buying and selling rates for sterling were £ stg. 0.6881 and £ stg. 0.6813, respectively, per £* 1. For approved transactions authorized dealers may deal at market rates, spot or forward, between them- selves and with resident and nonresident customers. Authorized dealers may enter freely into contracts with residents of Nigeria for the purchase or sale of any foreign currency except Rhodesian currency for deliv- ery at a future date, provided that the transaction is one that would be acceptable on a spot basis and relates to a firm commercial contract for the import or export of goods or to freight charges on a specific shipment of goods, and is expressed as payable in a foreign cur- rency. Forward contracts related to imports must not extend more than six months beyond the expiration date of the import license, or beyond the date of import when the license has no expiration date or when no license is required. Forward contracts related to ex- ports may cover any necessary period, provided that payment for the goods is to be received within three months of shipment, or within such longer period as may have been authorized. Administration of Control The Federal Ministry of Finance is responsible for basic exchange control policy and, in principle, for ap- proving applications for the following: copyrights; the payment of shipping and marine insurance dues; the repatriation of capital and transfer of profits to any country outside Nigeria; the raising of external loans, including repayment of such loans; borrowing in Nige- 360 ria by companies controlled directly or indirectly from outside Nigeria (other than locpl bank overdrafts to pay for imports); the granting of "approved status" to nonresident investments in Nigeria (other than invest- ments in fishing, shipping, and insurance); and any dealings in foreign securities. The Central Bank of Ni- geria is the principal administrator of exchange control. Most commercial banks and acceptance houses have been appointed as authorized dealers by the Ministry of Finance and thus are empowered to deal in foreign currencies and to approve applications in accordance with instructions issued by the Central Bank. Any ap- plication that does not fall within the scope of the authority of these authorized dealers must be submitted to the Central Bank, or, for the transactions mentioned above, to the Ministry of Finance. Certain hotels and rest houses have also been appointed authorized buyers for the purchase of foreign currency and travelers checks from foreign visitors and Nigerians newly ar- rived in the country. All export proceeds and other proceeds in foreign currencies (except the proceeds of oil exports) are cen- tralized with the Central Bank, which supplies the au- thorized banks with foreign exchange for approved payments. The Central Bank allocates foreign exchange daily to authorized dealers. Allocations are determined within the framework of a foreign exchange budget, which, however, is essentially an indicative manage- ment tool rather than an allocation device. The administration of trade controls is carried out by the Federal Ministry of Trade and the Import Quota Allocation Committee, comprising officials of the Min- istries of Trade, Finance, Industry, and Economic De- velopment, as well as representatives of the Central Bank and the customs administration. Import licenses for petroleum products, however, are issued by the Federal Commissioner of Mines and Power. Prescription of Currency Nigeria has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Authorized payments to countries other than Rhodesia may be made in naira to an External Account in Nigeria or in any foreign currency. The proceeds of exports to foreign countries except Rhode- sia may be received in naira from an External Account or in any foreign currency. However, settlements with Niger are channeled through special accounts. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia; most payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Nonresident Accounts Accounts in naira of persons resident outside Nigeria are divided into three categories: External Accounts, Rhodesia Accounts, and Blocked Accounts. External Accounts, which are maintained for resi- dents of all countries other than Rhodesia, may be credited with authorized payments by residents of Ni- geria to residents of foreign countries other than Rho- desia, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with proceeds from sales of foreign currencies other than Rhodesian currency. They may be debited for payments to residents of Nigeria, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for purchases of foreign cur- rencies other than Rhodesian currency. Rhodesia Accounts are maintained for residents of Rhodesia and have been blocked since July 3, 1969. Blocked Accounts axe accounts to which are credited funds that are blocked by directives given under Sec- tion 27 of the Exchange Control Act. Imports and Import Payments Importers must be registered if they wish to obtain individual import licenses. All imports from Namibia (South West Africa), Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, and the import from any country of certain specified commodities is banned, mostly for health, safety, moral, or religious reasons; the import of a few other commodities is also prohibited unless specific conditions have been complied with that are specified in the license authorizing such imports. Individual im- port licenses are required for a small number of items from all sources, including raw or manufactured to- bacco, stock fish, and certain types of paper. Imports which are neither prohibited nor subject to specific licensing may be imported under open general license from any country other than Namibia (South West Africa), Rhodesia, or South Africa. Some imports are effected by an autonomous public agency, the National Supply Company. Capital equipment with a value in excess of & 100,000 must be imported on specified deferred pay- ment terms, with up to 15 per cent payable against documents or on signing of the contract. Authorized dealers may otherwise grant foreign exchange for au- thorized imports at sight of shipping documents (in- voice, bill of lading, and customs bill of entry) or in accordance with such credit terms as may be arranged between importer and exporter (subject to the approval of the Central Bank for the private sector or the Minis- try of Finance for the public sector). Payment in ad- vance of shipment requires the approval of the Central Bank and is not normally allowed.2 Payments for Invisibles Most payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Pay- ments for invisibles to residents of other countries are subject to individual approval; for some categories of NIGERIA invisibles this is granted by authorized dealers, either up to specified limits or up to the amount of the bill or invoice. Applications for payments that cannot be ap- proved by authorized dealers and are not among those (such as profits and dividends)3 that require approval by the Ministry of Finance are forwarded to the Central Bank for decision. All insurance other than that for which facilities do not exist in Nigeria must be taken out with a company in Nigeria and all insurance com- panies operating in the country must reinsure with the National Insurance Corporation. Sixty per cent of ship charter payments must be settled in local currency, except when government-sponsored shipping compa- nies are involved. Residents are entitled to a basic tourist travel allow- ance of N 400 a person a year4 for travel outside Africa (N 200 a year for a child, subject to a limit of £f 1,200 for any one family unit). Foreign exchange for this purpose may be sold to residents by authorized dealers. In addition, travel agents and shipping and airline com- panies in Nigeria may sell transportation tickets for any destination, except Rhodesia, against payment in Nige- rian currency. The cost of services rendered by travel agents in respect of hotel accommodation, meals en route, etc., must be covered from the basic travel allow- ance. There is a separate basic allowance for travel within Africa. This allowance is £* 200 a person a year (half of that for a child). There is a separate basic travel allowance of £f 500 an adult a year for pilgrimages, which may not be combined with the tourist allocation. Business travel allowances are limited to Nt 50 a day,5 up to 30 days a trip, for any number of trips. Alloca- tions also are available for medical care and study abroad. Exchange applications for nontourist travel must be submitted to the Central Bank.6 Foreign na- tionals residing in Nigeria may purchase annually for- eign currency up to 50 per cent of their gross taxable earnings in Nigeria for all personal remittances (includ- ing insurance, education, and medical expenses, but excluding the basic travel allowance), up to a maximum of N 9,000 a person in any financial year. Applications in excess of this limit are examined on their merits by the Central Bank. Residents are permitted to take out the equivalent of their basic travel allowance in foreign currency notes and travelers checks; nonresident visitors may take out any foreign currency notes and travelers checks that were declared upon entry, minus the amount converted locally into Nigerian currency. The export of Nigerian currency notes and coins is prohibited. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most locally produced goods may be exported freely, under open general license, to any country except South Africa and Namibia (South West Africa), exports to which require individual licenses. Individual export licenses are re- quired for cigarettes and tobacco, columbite, tin and 361 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NIGERIA by-products of tin, tantalite, unrefined gold, petroleum products, goods made wholly or partly of imported components, and products subject to control by Mar- keting Boards (mainly cocoa, cotton, cottonseed, ben- niseed, groundnuts, groundnut oil, palm oil, and palm kernels). The selling abroad of all export crops pur- chased by the Marketing Boards is the responsibility of the Nigerian Produce Marketing Company. The export of certain goods (African antiquities or works of art produced before 1918 and objects that are being used or have been used in African ceremonies) is prohibited, except under prescribed conditions. The export of ex- plosives, other than industrial explosives, and of certain foodstuffs is prohibited, and exports of cattle and groundnuts have been suspended. Exports of petro- leum and petroleum products are subject to special arrangements. Export proceeds must be surrendered, through a commercial bank, to the Central Bank within three months of shipment. Exports of petroleum and petro- leum products, however, are exempt from the surrender requirements. For all exports, the exporter is required to submit an exchange control declaration at the time of shipment. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer, who is required to surrender them to the Central Bank. Persons enter- ing Nigeria may freely bring in foreign banknotes. The import of Nigerian currency notes and coins is prohib- ited. Capital Except for the purpose of financing imports or ex- ports, permission from the Ministry of Finance is re- quired for any individual, firm, company, or branch resident in Nigeria to borrow abroad. In addition, offi- cial agencies and state-controlled corporations require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance for any foreign borrowing. The taking up of suppliers' credit abroad also is subject to approval by the Ministry of Finance. The permission of the Ministry of Finance is also required for borrowing in Nigeria (1) by any non- resident individual or company, and (2) by any com- pany registered in Nigeria (other than a bank) which is controlled directly or indirectly from outside Nigeria. However, to enable entities mentioned under (2) to meet temporary shortages of funds, licensed banks in Nigeria may grant loans or overdrafts for periods not exceeding 14 days, or may increase the amount of any advance or overdraft by the amount of loan interest or bank charges payable thereon. General permission is also given for any loan, bank overdraft, or other credit facility to be arranged to finance Nigerian imports or exports of goods. Banks have been directed to allocate 40 per cent of their total loans and advances to Nige- rian persons and firms. 362 Residents of Nigeria may not deal in foreign cur- rency securities nor may they buy from or sell to non- residents of Nigeria any security payable in Nigerian pounds or naira without the permission of the Ministry of Finance. The capital proceeds of securities registered in Nigeria and owned by nonresidents may be collected and negotiated through authorized dealers, provided that the prior permission of the Ministry of Finance is obtained. Remittances of cash gifts to nonresidents normally are restricted to the equivalent of & 100 for each trans- feror a calendar year in favor of charitable organiza- tions outside Nigeria. Exchange for the transfer of certain assets by emigrants or repatriates is granted on final departure from the country, but the transfer of the proceeds of assets realized to comply with the Nigerian Enterprises Promotion Decree, 1972 is subject to spe- cial rules. Nonresidents intending to make direct investments in Nigeria are invited to apply to the Ministry of Fi- nance for "approved status," the granting of which means that sympathetic consideration will be given to future requests to repatriate the capital. The granting of "approved status" is not applicable to the purchase of shares on the stock exchange in Nigeria unless this forms an integral part of the approved investment project. Furthermore, this status is not normally granted when internally generated funds from profits, dividends, rents, or locally raised loans or bank credit are invested in local enterprises. With minor excep- tions, foreign-owned companies and commercial banks operating in Nigeria must be incorporated in Nigeria. The repatriation of foreign capital requires approval from the Ministry of Finance. Gold With the express permission of the Federal Commis- sioner for Finance, residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Nigeria for numismatic purposes. Residents other than the monetary authorities, producers of gold, and authorized industrial users are not allowed without special permission to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry or coins, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require specific licenses issued by the Ministry of Fi- nance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, producers of gold, and industrial users. Furthermore, the import of gold coins current in the United Kingdom requires a license from the Commis- sioner of Customs and Excise, and the import of other gold coins requires a specific import license. Imports of gold coins and of gold and silver bullion are duty free when made by the Central Bank for monetary pur- poses; otherwise, such imports are subject to customs duty at 100 per cent ad valorem. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Changes during 1974 January 16. Exports of groundnuts were suspended. March 26. Decree No. 13 was published, amending the Nigerian Enterprises Promotion Decree, 1972. April 1. Nigeria adopted an independent exchange rate policy, under which the naira was appreciated in terms of both the U.S. dollar and sterling. (Previously, exchange rates had been based on the central rate estab- lished in February 1973, and the rate for the U.S. dollar had been & 1 = US$1.52.) The Central Bank began to quote both currencies daily, with its buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar V2 per cent either side of the middle rate. On April 5, the initial rate for the U.S. dollar was set at & 1 = US$1.54. April 1. It was announced that the remaining arrears of profit and dividend remittances would be fully set- tled during the fiscal year 1975, and that all newly accruing investment income of nonresidents would be fully transferable without delay; new profits and divi- dends could be remitted as soon as they were declared. April 1. It was announced that remittances of techni- cal fees, management fees, and royalties would be per- mitted where it could be shown to the Ministry of Finance that these related to the import of modern technology. April 1. The system of mandatory deferred payments for imports, under which, generally, trade credit of at least 90 days after customs entry had been prescribed, was abolished, except for certain capital goods. Hence- forth, payments for imports of all goods except plant and machinery costing more than & 100,000 could be made at sight of shipping documents (or on such credit terms as might be arranged between supplier and im- porter). Payments for plant and machinery costing more than N 100,000 could be made according to a liberalized schedule. April 1. Imports of meat, fruits, rice, wheat, maize, brandy, rum, whiskey, gin, tires and tubes for automo- biles, and certain other items were placed under open general license. Previously, meat and fruits were on the prohibited list and rice, wheat, and maize on the spe- cific licensing list. The import of silver or metal alloy coins that are not legal tender in Nigeria became totally prohibited. April 1. The basic exchange allowance for tourist travel outside Africa was doubled to the equivalent of £t 400 a person a year (N 200 a year for each child) and that for travel within Africa to N 200 a person a year (£t 100 for each child). The pilgrimage allowance for adults was increased from £f 300 to N 500 a person a year. A basic business travel allowance was reintro- duced, at £i 50 a day, up to 30 days per trip, for any number of trips; previously, applications had to be sub- mitted to the Central Bank, which generally granted N 40 a day. April 1. Authorized dealers were empowered to ap- prove exchange applications in respect of miscellaneous items (such as examination fees, annual membership NIGERIA subscriptions, correspondence courses, and tuition fees) and remittances to meet the educational expenses of Nigerian students attending colleges and higher in- stitutions of learning outside Nigeria. April 1. The national reconstruction surcharge of 5 per cent of the applicable import duty was abolished, which had been levied on most imports. April 1. The Nigerian Enterprises Promotion Decree, 1972 came into force, March 31 having been the "appointed day." The deadline for compliance by alien enterprises was extended by six months. April 1. Import duties on a large number of goods were reduced substantially. April 1. Export duties on rubber were abolished. April 18. Imports of a number of foodstuffs and household articles were prohibited. May 20. The Government acquired a 55 per cent participation in all oil prospecting companies operating in Nigeria, with retroactive effect from April 1. July 1. It was announced that foreign procurement by the Federal and State Governments would hence- forth be handled through the Nigerian National Supply Company, including such procurement as was previ- ously channeled through the U.K. Crown Agents. July 1. Import duties on additional goods were re- duced or abolished. September 30. The extended deadline for compliance by alien enterprises with the provisions of the Nigerian Enterprises Promotion Decree, 1972 expired. The Ni- gerian Enterprises Promotion Board granted a further extension of six months. December 5. Government Notice No. 1746 extended the duration of all unused or partly used import licenses issued in 1974 for a period of three months, to March 31, 1975. Each application is treated on its merits within these broad guide- lines. Not for Redistribution NORWAY (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.124414 gram of fine gold per Norwegian Krone. In 1973 a central rate was estab- lished of NKr 1 = SDR 0.145530 or NKr 6.87145 = SDR 1, corresponding at the time to 0.129328 gram of fine gold per NKr 1, and Norway avails itself of wider margins. Margins of 2Y4 per cent are maintained for spot rates in the official exchange market between the Norwegian krone and the Belgian franc, the Danish krone, the deutsche mark, the French franc, the Lux- embourg franc, the Netherlands guilder, and the Swed- ish krona. No announced margins are maintained for other currencies. On December 31, 1974 the buying and selling rates of the authorized banks for the U.S. dollar were NKr 5.1925 and NKr 5.2175, respectively. Forward premiums and discounts are left to the inter- play of market forces. Authorized banks' forward transactions with nonbank residents must have a com- mercial basis. Norway formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from May 11, 1967. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Ministry of Commerce and Shipping in cooperation with the Bank of Norway. The authority to approve most current pay- ments has been delegated to authorized banks. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Ministry of Commerce and Shipping and, in certain cases, by the Ministry of Agriculture or the Ministry of Fisheries. Imports and exports of precious metals, and of semimanufactured articles thereof, are licensed by the Bank of Norway. Prescription of Currency Payments between Norway and Rhodesia are pro- hibited when they relate to imports, exports, or transit trade, and in all other cases are subject to special license issued by the Bank of Norway. Settlements with all other countries may be made in any convertible cur- rency, including Norwegian kroner on Convertible Krone Accounts (see section on Nonresident Ac- counts, below). Nonresident Accounts The main type of nonresident account is the Convert- ible Krone Account. Such accounts may be held by residents of all countries, subject to the proviso that without special permission from the Bank of Norway the total balance held by a nonbank nonresident must at no time exceed NKr 100,000. They may be credited with authorized payments to any country, with trans- fers from other Convertible Krone Accounts, and with proceeds from the sale in Norway of convertible cur- rencies. They may be debited for authorized payments from any country to residents of Norway, for transfers to other Convertible Krone Accounts, and for pur- chases in Norway of any foreign currency. Imports and Import Payments Most commodities do not require an import license. Industrial goods may be imported freely from the im- port free list area1 upon presentation of the original invoice. Imports of certain agricultural products are restricted, irrespective of origin. There are two re- stricted lists for industrial goods for specified coun- tries—one applicable to imports from Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R., and the other applicable to imports from Japan and the Repub- lic of Korea; many of the goods on these lists are li- censed automatically. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. A global quota list contains a few quotas for agricul- tural products for which imports are permitted up to fixed limits; these quotas apply to all countries. New and secondhand ships built abroad, other than ships that are 20 years old or older and certain categories of fishing vessels, may be imported freely,2 but special permission is required in order to supervise compliance with certain regulations regarding payments in advance of delivery. The import of a small number of commodi- ties is prohibited for health and similar reasons, and certain goods (some grains, alcoholic beverages, equip- ment and materials for the fishing industry, pharma- ceutical products, and drugs) are imported by government monopolies. If no license is required or when an import license has been obtained, payment may be made without delay, provided that the method of payment is in conformity with the general rules (see section on Prescription of Currency, above). Payments for Invisibles Payments to any country except Rhodesia for all current invisibles, including income from capital and contractual amortization, may be made freely. Pay- ments for any purpose to any country other than Rho- desia do not require verification by authorized banks, provided that these payments do not exceed the equiva- lent of NKr 500. The granting of exchange for travel purposes is not restricted. The basic exchange allowance for tourist travel abroad is equivalent to NKr 5,000 a trip for each person. For business travel, the banks may sell reason- able amounts. Each person leaving Norway may take 365 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NORWAY with him up to NKr 800 in Norwegian banknotes, in denominations not exceeding NKr 100. Nonresidents leaving Norway may, in addition, export any foreign banknotes brought into the country by them. Exports and Export Proceeds Most goods may be exported freely to countries in the export free list area,3 against a declaration or a license, which is granted automatically. Exports sub- ject to regulation are listed and require export licenses. All exports to countries outside the export free list area require an export license. Exports valued at not more than NKr 500 to any country are exempt from export license. Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited, with the exception of shipments for medical, humanitarian, or educational purposes. Payments must be received within 12 months of ship- ment and in conformity with the regulations (see sec- tion on Prescription of Currency, above). In principle, all exchange from exports must be surrendered. Proceeds from Invisibles In principle, receipts from invisibles must be surren- dered. Each person entering Norway may bring in any amount in Norwegian currency, in denominations not exceeding NKr 100, and in other means of payment. Capital Inward transfers of capital and investments in Nor- way by nonresidents must be approved by the Bank of Norway. Outward transfers of capital require individ- ual licenses; the granting of these licenses depends on the merits of the case. Licenses for outward transfers of proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments made in Norway by nonresidents are granted freely, and nonresident capital may be repatriated automati- cally. Payments for contractual amortization are also permitted freely. Most transactions in securities involv- ing nonresident interests are subject to approval. Nor- wegian securities denominated in Norwegian kroner and purchased by nonresidents from Norwegian resi- dents by special permission may be resold to Norwe- gian residents who will be granted licenses for the transfer of the proceeds from the sale; the purchase of shares of Norwegian banking and industrial firms by nonresidents is licensed restrictively on a case-by-case basis. Personal capital transfers, such as transfers relating to family loans, gifts, inheritances, legacies, dowries, emigrants' assets, savings of nonresident workers, and amounts in settlement of immigrants' debts, may be made freely. In general, resident-owned capital assets abroad, other than securities, real estate, and other authorized investments, have to be surrendered. Applications for capital transfers to make direct investments abroad are considered on their individual merits, and portfolio in- 366 vestment abroad is approved only exceptionally. Resi- dent-owned foreign securities quoted on a recognized stock exchange, with the exception of securities issued by foreign investment companies or mutual funds, are freely negotiable between residents, provided that the securities originally were acquired by a resident before October 1, 1966, or that they were bought with the proceeds of foreign securities acquired before that date. Transactions in foreign securities between residents against settlement in kroner require a license from the Bank of Norway if the securities were not included in an authorized broker's safe deposit for customers on May 31, 1969. Residents may upon application trans- fer capital abroad to purchase, for recreational pur- poses, real estate valued at up to NKr 80,000 a family; such purchases by business firms, staff associations, etc., are approved liberally, also for higher amounts. In accordance with guidelines of December 13, 1971, the aggregate net foreign liability position of the banks may not deviate by more than NKr 260 million from the position at the end of October 1971, i.e., it must not be less than NKr 555 million or more than NKr 1,075 million. On May 23, 1972, however, these guidelines were modified slightly to allow the banks some addi- tional flexibility in determining their net liability posi- tion. There are limits on the commercial banks' borrowing abroad. Thus, they may borrow funds or accept deposits in foreign currency from foreign banks within a ceiling fixed at 20 per cent above their total foreign borrowing at the end of December 1970. Residents other than banks require the prior ap- proval of the Bank of Norway before raising loans, accepting other forms of capital, or incurring or provid- ing guarantee obligations abroad. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Norway. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Bank of Norway; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. No customs duties or other charges or fees are payable on imports or exports of gold bullion and gold coins not contained in jewelry. Domestic sales of gold coins are subject to sales tax at a rate of 20 per cent. Changes during 1974 January 1. Following the expiration on Decem- ber 31, 1973 of the bilateral payments agreement, set- tlements with the German Democratic Republic took place in convertible currencies. Payments for all current invisibles to the German Democratic Republic could henceforth be made freely. February 20. The limit up to which residents could, on application, transfer capital abroad for the purchase of recreational real estate, was increased from NKr 60,000 to NKr 80,000 for a family unit. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution May 21. The arrangements for government export guarantees were renewed, with an increase in the over- all ceiling from NKr 3 billion to NKr 5 billion; the special ceiling for export to and investment in develop- ing countries was increased from NKr 0.6 billion to NKr 1 billion. May 30. Norway signed the OECD Declaration on Imports, Exports, and Other Current Account Transactions. July 22. The export licensing requirement for sawn timber was abolished. August 29. Norway notified the Fund that it was subscribing to the Voluntary Declaration on Trade and Other Current Account Measures for Balance of Payments Purposes. September 27. A licensing system was introduced for all imports of sugar for domestic consumption and for industrial use. The purpose was to secure long-term supplies of sugar for domestic consumption through centralized imports, not to limit the quantities imported. September 27. The Ministry of Finance informed the Bank of Norway that permission to foreign banks to establish branches in Norway would not be given for the time being. December 3. The Bank of Norway issued new rules governing nonresident krone accounts. No changes were made in the types of transactions permitted on such accounts, but henceforth all transactions had to be reported to the Bank of Norway. Deposits from foreign banks could be accepted by authorized foreign exchange banks only. No formal limit was set on such deposits, but deposits of unusual size and nature were to be refused. If deemed necessary, limits on foreign NORWAY banks' krone accounts with Norwegian banks could be stipulated, and the establishment of new krone accounts for foreign banks could be prohibited. Deposits from nonbank nonresidents could be accepted by foreign exchange banks as well as other banks. The total balance belonging to any one nonbank nonresident could at no time exceed NKr 100,000 without special permission from the Bank of Norway. If the balance on any existing account exceeded that amount, application had to be made to the Bank of Norway as soon as possible for keeping a higher bal- ance. For such accounts permitted to be maintained, the Bank of Norway would stipulate a special maxi- mum balance, and monthly statements would have to be submitted. New deposits exceeding NKr 100,000 were to be refused until the Bank of Norway's approval had been obtained. December 17. The Bank of Norway instructed autho- rized brokers that with effect from January 1, 1975 they could freely sell to, and buy from, nonresidents shares in the Norwegian company Norsk Hydro a.s. Forward transactions could not take place. Not for Redistribution OMAN (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System On July 4, 1974, Oman established an initial par value of 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Rial Omani, corresponding at the time to RO 0.416667 = SDR 1. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, is RO 1 = US$2.89524. Oman avails itself of wider margins. The Oman Currency Board maintains fixed buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar, while the commercial banks' rates for other currencies are based on market rates in London. On December 31, 1974, the official buying rate for the U.S. dollar was RO 0.342 per US$1, and the official selling rate was RO 0.3488 per US$1. On the same date, the buying and selling rates for sterling were RO 0.803 and RO 0.819 per £ stg. 1, respectively. Oman informed the Fund on June 19, 1974 that it formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sec- tions 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control There is neither exchange control legislation nor an exchange control authority in Oman. Prescription of Currency All settlements with Israel and Rhodesia are prohib- ited. The use of the currencies of Israel and Rhodesia also is prohibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force. * Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports of a few commodities are prohibited from all sources for reasons of health, morals, or security. Im- ports of Maria Theresa dollars also are prohibited. Im- port licenses are not required and exchange for payments abroad may be obtained freely. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited and exports or re-exports of live animals and foodstuffs may be prohibited in times of shortage in Oman. All other commodities may be exported freely. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or 368 re-exports; the proceeds need not be repatriated or sur- rendered, and they may be disposed of freely, regard- less of the currency involved. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments for and proceeds from invisibles are not restricted. Payments must not, however, be made to or received from Israel or Rhodesia. Travelers may bring in or take out any amount in domestic or foreign bank- notes. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresi- dents, except that no payments must be made to or received from Israel or Rhodesia. Investment in busi- ness firms in Oman by foreign physical or juridical persons requires prior approval. Such investment is reg- ulated by a foreign investment law enacted in 1973. Gold The monetary authorities and all other residents and nonresidents, including private persons, may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form at home or abroad. They may also, without a license and without payment of any customs duties or tax, import and export gold in any form. Transactions involving Israel and Rhodesia, however, are prohibited. The effective parity relation- ship for the U.S. dollar also remained unchanged, at RO 1 = US$2.89524. Oman also availed itself of wider margins. July 10. The ban on exports of crude petroleum to the Netherlands was lifted. July 20. Not for Redistribution PAKISTAN (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0744103 gram of fine gold per Pakistan Rupee, and Pakistan avails itself of wider mar- gins. The U.S. dollar is the intervention currency, and the State Bank of Pakistan (the central bank) maintains official rates of PRs 9.8844 buying, and PRs 9.9312 selling, per US$ 1 for dealings of banks with the public. All transactions in foreign exchange must be conducted through authorized dealers, whose transactions with the general public must be effected at rates authorized by the State Bank. Authorized dealers in Pakistan are permitted to cover their requirements of specified cur- rencies in foreign exchange markets abroad. They may also cover their permitted transactions in specified cur- rencies against U.S. dollars or Pakistan rupees, either spot or forward for a limited period, with their agents in the countries concerned. Administration of Control The State Bank has delegated to a number of banks and financial institutions authority to deal in all foreign currencies, to supervise surrender requirements, and to sell exchange for specified purposes within limits pre- scribed by the State Bank. The Chief Controller of Imports and Exports is responsible for the issue of licenses and the implementation of import and export policies. Certain foreign trade transactions are con- ducted through the Trading Corporation of Pakistan, Ltd. (TCP), a state trading agency. Prescription of Currency Exchange receipts and payments abroad must be ef- fected through an authorized foreign exchange dealer, in principle in any convertible currency or in Pakistan rupees from or to nonresident rupee bank Accounts. Certain settlements with specified countries, however, are channeled through special accounts. Letters of credit for imports from all other countries must be established in U.S. dollars, pounds sterling, the domes- tic currency of the beneficiary, or in the currency of the country of origin or shipment. No exchange control is exercised over transactions with Afghanistan, and settlements are made freely in Pakistan rupees or in Afghan currency. Trade transac- tions under "barter" agreements are settled through special accounts in inconvertible currencies. Trade in specified commodities with Bulgaria, the People's Re- public of China, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, North Ko- rea, Poland, Romania, Sweden, and the U.S.S.R. is settled through clearing accounts. There is a special trade and payments arrangement with the German Democratic Republic, with an indicative commodity list only. The clearing accounts with Bulgaria, the Peo- ple's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, and Hungary 370 are maintained in nonconvertible Pakistan rupees; those with the German Democratic Republic, Poland, Romania, Sweden, and the U.S.S.R. are in U.S. dollars; and the clearing account with North Korea is denomi- nated in deutsche mark. Payments to and from Iran and Turkey relating to visible trade (excluding border trade, Iranian oil, and defense materials) are settled through clearing accounts maintained by the respective central banks in U.S. dollars. Under a credit arrange- ment with the Central Bank of Ceylon, all trade with Sri Lanka is settled through a special U.S. dollar ac- count. Payments between Pakistan and the Republic of China, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are sus- pended. Restrictions on payments between Pakistan and India have been lifted insofar as they relate to trade transactions in terms of the Pakistan-India trade proto- col of November 30, 1974. Nonresident Accounts The accounts of individuals, firms, or companies res- ident in countries outside Pakistan are designated as nonresident accounts.1 Authorized banks are permitted to open nonresident accounts for nonbank nonresi- dents without the prior approval of the State Bank where the accounts are to be opened with funds re- ceived from abroad through banking channels or with rupee funds which have been accepted for remittance abroad. Debits and credits to nonresident accounts for specified purposes can be made by authorized banks without the prior approval of the State Bank. Accounts of residents of India, other than the accounts of the Indian High Commission and its personnel, are blocked. Pakistan nationals residing abroad and foreign na- tionals, whether resident abroad or in Pakistan, may open foreign currency accounts with banks in Pakistan without prior approval of the exchange control authori- ties. There are no restrictions on the currencies in which the accounts may be denominated and credit balances may be freely transferred abroad. However, a deposit holder wishing to make payments in Pakistan must first convert the foreign exchange drawn from his account into Pakistan rupees. If a Pakistan national holding such an account returns to Pakistan, he may retain the account unless his stay exceeds six months; thereafter the account must be closed and the exchange surren- dered. Banks in Pakistan receiving such deposits must sell the foreign exchange to the State Bank. Imports and Import Payments Permitted imports are classified in two lists: a free list and a tied list. Items on the free list may, in principle, be procured without restriction while items on the tied ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution list may be procured only from tied aid and barter trade sources. Items not on either list are effectively prohib- ited for import except under certain circumstances by export industries, as mentioned below. All imports re- quire licenses, except goods imported by the Central Government for defense or other purposes, goods in transit, personal baggage, certain imports over the land routes from Afghanistan and Iran, and certain other items permitted under a Ministry of Commerce Notifi- cation (No. 335/260/24 of June 12, 1951). Licenses for imports of a value up to PRs 500 incur no fee, but licenses above that amount up to PRs 100,000 are sub- ject to a fee of 1 per cent of the value of the license and licenses above PRs 100,000 are subject to a fee of 2 per cent payable at the time of the issue of the license. The basic two-list import regime is subject to certain supplementary qualifications, the most important of which are as follows: (1) Imports from the Republic of China, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohib- ited, as are imports of goods originating in these countries but shipped from third countries. Imports from India are only permitted in accordance with the trade protocol of November 30, 1974. (2) In order to facilitate barter trading and aid utilization and to se- cure economies through bulk imports, the import of specified items is restricted to the TCP, unless the items are procured with U.S. aid. (3) The import of certain other items is restricted to the public sector or to indus- trial consumers. (4) In conformity with Regional Coop- eration for Development arrangements between Iran, Pakistan, and Turkey governing procurements from joint industrial ventures, the import of ten items, in- cluding six chemical items, is restricted to procurement from Turkey. (5) Special provisions exist for the import for export industries of tied list items from nontied sources and items not on the two import lists. (6) Pri- vate sector importers, other than those importing goods for personal use, who apply for import licenses for goods valued at PRs 20,000 or more must be mem- bers of approved trade organizations. (7) Licenses for permissible imports of industrial plant and equipment are restricted to a c. & f. value of PRs 500,000 for imports against cash, PRs 1 million for imports under tied credit, and PRs 2 million for imports under bilat- eral payments arrangements (larger plant and equip- ment are to be procured under the auspices of the financing institutions and with the approval of the Min- istry of Industries). Except for imports of books, periodicals, and news- papers, irrevocable letters of credit must be opened for all commercial imports. Remittances are not normally permitted before shipping documents are received, but in special cases, e.g., machinery and other capital goods for which deposits have to be made with foreign manu- facturers, the State Bank may authorize advance pay- ments for a part of the value of the goods. No import payments are permitted to be made for goods originat- ing in or consigned from the Republic of China, India (other than imports covered by the trade protocol of PAKISTAN November 30, 1974), Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa. Except for specified items, including items on the tied import list, the State Bank requires banks to take a minimum margin of 25 per cent against import letters of credit.2 Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are controlled by the State Bank and in many cases require its prior approval. No remittances are permitted to be made to Bangladesh, the Republic of China, India, Israel, South Africa, or Rhodesia. Under authority delegated to them, autho- rized dealers may sell exchange or make remittances in accordance with detailed regulations. Certain remit- tances of a personal nature are subject to annual quo- tas, but most are approved at the discretion of the State Bank. Remittances by Pakistan nationals to their fami- lies abroad require special authorization. Payments for invisibles connected with imports are generally given the same treatment as that accorded the underlying trade transaction. Transport insurance must, except with respect to certain aid shipments, be taken out with insurance companies in Pakistan. The remittance of dividends declared out of current profits is allowed freely to foreign shareholders where the investment was made with the Government's ap- proval. Profits of branches of foreign companies may be remitted freely to their head offices. The same applies to head office expenses charged to a branch's profit and loss account and accepted for tax purposes by the Paki- stan income tax authorities. On an administrative basis, the State Bank approves an exchange allocation of US$500 a person a trip for private travel; this allocation can be taken up once every two years. Additional ex- change for business travel, medical treatment, educa- tion, and sponsored cultural trips may be granted on an individual basis. There are also specific allowances for pilgrims' travel to Saudi Arabia and other Middle East- ern countries. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency not exceeding the amounts they brought in and PRs 20 a person in Pakistan currency notes. Residents leaving for Afghanistan may take out PRs 50 in Pakistan cur- rency notes and coins and any amount of Afghan cur- rency. Residents traveling to other foreign destinations may take out PRs 20 a person in Pakistan currency and any amount in foreign currency notes and travelers checks granted by authorized banks under permissions issued by the State Bank. Pakistan currency notes in denominations of PRs 50 or higher may not be taken out. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of specified commodities to any destination, and all exports to the Republic of China, Israel, Rhode- sia, and South Africa are prohibited.3 Exports of most other commodities are allowed freely. However, export licenses are required for some 24 listed items, as well as 371 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PAKISTAN for certain types of sports goods and a few other items subject to minimum export prices, and for mill-made cotton piece goods and ready-made garments intended for export to the United Kingdom. The Cotton Export Corporation of Pakistan has a monopoly over exports of cotton, and rice is exported through the Rice Export Corporation. The State Bank exercises control over exchange re- ceipts and requires a declaration by the exporter that, when payment in accordance with the prescribed method is received, he will surrender the exchange within a certain period of time. After making certain that the exporter's declaration meets all conditions, the authorized dealer certifies the export form for ship- ment. Exporters are obliged to collect and surrender export proceeds within four months of shipment; the State Bank may, on the merits of each case, allow an extension of this period. The surrender of Afghan cur- rency accruing from exports to Afghanistan is not re- quired. Industrial units established under the Pay-As- You-Earn Scheme are permitted to utilize up to 50 per cent of the f.o.b. value of exports for the servicing of suppliers' credit on imports of plant and machinery. Export duties are levied on a range of export items, including raw cotton, rice, wool, and hides and skins. Proceeds from Invisibles With the exception of Afghan currency, which may be retained, incoming foreign exchange derived from invisibles must be surrendered within one month. Travelers may bring in PRs 20 in Pakistan currency notes a person and Rs 5 in coins that are legal tender in India; Pakistan currency notes in denominations of PRs 50 and above may not be brought in. There is no limitation on the import of other currency notes and coins. Capital Investments in Pakistan by nonresidents are subject to approval. In order to encourage industrial develop- ment in Pakistan, the Government follows a liberal policy toward foreign entrepreneurs, who can, with the approval of the Government, start any industry in the private sector without any conditions being laid down regarding the participation of local capital. It is, how- ever, expected that local rupee expenditure will ordi- narily be met from local equity capital. Repatriation facilities are as follows: (1) Foreign cap- ital invested in approved industries established after September 1, 1954 may be repatriated at any time thereafter to the extent of the original investment, and current profits may be transferred without restriction, to the country of origin of the capital. (2) Profits that are reinvested in approved industrial projects with the approval of the Government may be treated as invest- ment for the purpose of subsequent repatriation. (3) Appreciation of any capital investment under (1) and 372 (2) may also be treated as investment for the purpose of subsequent repatriation. These repatriation facilities do not apply to the purchase of shares on the stock exchange unless the purchase is an integral part of an approved investment project, or to capital invested in Pakistan before September 1, 1954. Guarantees provide for just and fair compensation in the currency of the country of origin of the investment in the event of nationalization of any project. Foreign nationals in Pakistan or abroad may register their investments in National Prize Bonds issued by the Government of Pakistan, and thus facilitate repatria- tion at any time of the principal and the prize winnings. Transfers of capital abroad by resident nationals are, in general, not permitted; the purchase of foreign secu- rities by resident Pakistanis requires approval by the State Bank and is seldom permitted. Detailed rules govern the transfer of capital by persons emigrating or retiring from Pakistan, depending upon the nationality of the person concerned and the country or monetary area to which the transfer is to be made. Foreign na- tionals temporarily residing in Pakistan are treated as nonresidents for purposes of transfer of securities. Gen- eral permission has been given in connection with the issue, sale, or transfer of securities issued in Pakistan in favor of nonresidents, provided the securities are regis- tered in Pakistan and investment is made on the basis of nonrepatriation of capital and return. Pakistan secu- rities held by nonresidents may be transferred to other nonresidents against payment abroad with the same facilities in respect of remittance of capital and earnings as those obtained by the transferor. A general permis- sion has also been issued allowing foreign nationals temporarily resident in Pakistan to make investments in units of the National Investment Trust, subject to certain stipulations. Exports of securities are subject to approval. Pro- ceeds accruing from the liquidation of nonresident cap-, ital assets that are not covered by repatriation arrangements must be credited to blocked accounts. Subject to approval by the State Bank, balances on blocked accounts may be invested in approved govern- ment securities payable in Pakistan rupees or placed on time deposit with banks. A general permission allows Pakistan nationals resi- dent abroad to acquire securities in Pakistan by remit- tance of foreign exchange or to the debit of their nonresident accounts in Pakistan; dividends or interest thereon, as well as the proceeds upon sale, must be credited to nonresident accounts and cannot normally be transferred abroad. Pakistan nationals require the prior approval of the State Bank to sell movable or immovable assets held abroad, and the liquidation pro- ceeds must be repatriated to Pakistan through normal banking channels. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Gold The export and import of gold are prohibited unless authorized by the State Bank. No such permission is granted, but there are no restrictions on the internal sale and purchase of nonmonetary gold. Changes during 1974 January 1. The Government announced its acquisi- tion with immediate effect of the ownership, manage- ment, and control of, and all shares held by private persons in Pakistan in the capital of, domestically owned banks, companies marketing petroleum prod- ucts, and maritime shipping companies. Foreign- owned shares in these enterprises, and foreign-owned banks and petroleum marketing companies operating in Pakistan, were not affected by these measures. How- ever, foreign banks would not be permitted to establish new branches in Pakistan. January 10. Imports of sulfur, wood pulp, tobacco, and safety equipment for the mining industry were transferred from the tied list to the free list. The first three items, which formerly could be imported only through the TCP, could now be imported freely. Mag- netic tapes, previously prohibited, could now also be imported under the free list. January 17. The Pay-As-You-Earn Scheme, permit- ting imports of plant and machinery for setting up export-oriented industries or expanding existing units on a deferred payments basis, was revised. Up to 50 per cent of an industrial unit's foreign exchange earnings could now be used for meeting the related debt service obligations, against 20 per cent previously. January 25. The prescription of currency for imports from countries with which Pakistan does not have pay- ments agreements was changed, prescribing payment in U.S. dollars, pounds sterling, or the local currency of the beneficiary, or in the currency of the country of origin or shipment, or in Pakistan rupees for credit to a nonresident rupee bank account. Previously, pay- ments could only be made in U.S. dollars, pounds ster- ling, or the currency of the country of origin or shipment of the goods. February 11. The commodity exchange agreement with A.B. Sukab of Sweden was extended until Decem- ber 31, 1974, but only for exports, while imports were temporarily discontinued. March 4. The State Bank of Pakistan and the Central Bank of Ceylon entered into a credit arrangement, valid until December 31, 1975, covering all payments relat- ing to trade between Pakistan and Sri Lanka; such payments would be settled through a special U.S. dol- lar account. March 5. Authorized dealers were permitted to open letters of credit providing for payment in sterling for imports from countries other than the United King- dom, instead of imports from the United Kingdom only. PAKISTAN March 15. The foreign exchange allocation of US$500 a person a trip for private travel, previously available for any number of trips, was restricted to one trip every two years. Simultaneously, the allocation for business travel was increased from US$40 a day, sub- ject to a maximum of US$1,000 a trip, to US$50 a day, subject to a maximum of US$1,500 a trip. Allocations for pilgrimage to Mecca were increased from US$300 to US$500. March 23. The export duty on cotton yarn was re- duced. April 27. Under the latter, settlements were to take place through two special accounts in nonconvertible U.S. dollars. May 31. The flood relief surcharge of 25 per cent of the applicable rate of customs duty, which had been levied on virtually all imports except machinery and tractors, was absorbed into the customs tariff. June 8. Import duties were reduced on tea, tendo leaves, and automobiles up to 1,300 cubic centimeters. June 8. Export duties were reduced on certain cotton products, raw cotton, cotton yarn, tanned and semi- tanned hides and skins, and fish meal, and were abol- ished for canvas cloth. June 21. The extension of forward exchange cover by authorized banks for imports was restricted. While banks could previously provide forward cover for peri- ods of up to 12 months, and grant one extension of 3 months, cover was now reduced to 6 months at most, except for certain machinery eligible for cover up to 12 months and 24 months. No extension would be permit- ted beyond the initial forward cover contract. June 26.
