Not for Redistribution PANAMA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.736662 gram of fine gold per Panamanian Balboa, corresponding to B 1.00 = US$1. Panama does not avail itself of wider margins. U.S. currency notes and coins circulate freely in Panama, and local currency is represented only by limited amounts of silver balboas and subsidiary coins, a com- memorative 20-balboa silver coin, and a commemora- tive 100-balboa gold coin. Exchange transactions by commercial banks are based mainly on New York mar- ket quotations. Panama has no exchange restrictions on foreign payments, with the exception of a prohibition on payments to Rhodesia other than those for pensions or for humanitarian, educational, medical, or informa- tional purposes. On November 26, 1946, Panama notified the Fund that it accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sec- tions 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Most import and export licenses are issued by the Price Regulation Office, a semiautonomous institution of the Panamanian Government. The Price Regulation Office is responsible for the implementation of restric- tions on imports of commodities that compete with national production and on certain exports. The Minis- try of Commerce and Industry determines the import quotas for commodities listed in trade agreements, and the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Develop- ment, jointly with the Price Regulation Office, those for agricultural commodities temporarily in short supply. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Quotas are imposed on imports of commodities competing with present or prospective domestic production; some of these are not being licensed. Import licensing also ap- plies to imports of various foodstuffs. Other imports are free. Payments abroad may be made freely. A tax of 6 per cent on the f.o.b. value is levied, in addition to import du ty, on private sector imports of all dutiable goods other than specified pharmaceutical products and foodstuffs, for which the rate is 2V2 per cent and 3V2 per cent, respectively; books are exempt. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited, except those for humanitarian, educational, medical, or informational purposes. Authorization is required for exports of cof- fee in any form, coconuts, copra, and beef cattle, and for certain manufactured products in short supply. Merchandise on which export taxes are imposed is also subject to licensing. Export taxes are imposed on gold, silver, platinum, manganese, other minerals, bananas, coconuts, scrap metals, pearls, animal wax, nispero gum, ipecac root, and rubber. Exports of cement, cer- tain foodstuffs, firearms, and ammunition are prohib- ited. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except for most payments to Rhodesia. A travel tax of 4 per cent is levied on air and sea tickets bought in Panama or on such tickets pur- chased for travelers starting their trip in Panama. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresi- dents, except for most payments to Rhodesia. Several foreign-controlled banks are authorized to conduct business only with nonresidents. Gold Panama has issued a commemorative gold coin with a face value of B 100, which is legal tender but does not circulate. Residents may freely hold gold in any form at home or abroad and may freely negotiate gold in any form with residents or nonresidents at home and abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry carried as personal effects by travelers are subject to license if made by residents other than the monetary authorities; import licenses are issued freely by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry and export licenses are granted by the Ministry of Finance and Treasury. Exports of unworked gold produced in Pan- ama are subject to an export duty of 1 per cent ad valorem, and exports of gold coins (other than U.S. coins, which are exempt) to a duty of V2 per cent. Changes during 1974 April 1. The export tax on bananas was increased to B 1 per 40-pound box. With retroactive effect from October 21, the tax was reduced in December to B 0.35. June 20. A free trade agreement was signed with Guatemala. September 17. Imports of clothing were restricted. Quotas for individual importers were based on their imports between August 15 and December 15, 1973. December 31. A legal tender gold coin with a face value of B 100 was issued. 375 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PARAGUAY (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System On March 1, 1956, a new par value for the Para- guayan Guarani was established by Paraguay with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. Exchange trans- actions take place in a dual exchange market. Transac- tions in the official exchange market (mercado libre bancario) must be carried out through the Central Bank (for all government transactions) or an authorized com- mercial bank; these transactions take place at a rate of 0 126 per US$1, subject to taxes and commissions. Transactions in the fluctuating free market {mercado libre fluctuante de cambio) are conducted through li- censed foreign exchange houses at a fluctuating rate which on December 31, 1974 was about 0 132 per US$1 buying, and & 135 per US$1 selling. All pur- chases and sales of exchange by banks are subject to a tax of 1Y2 per cent, except transactions with foreign embassies and diplomats; transactions with meat pack- ing plants; and transactions relating to investments in Paraguay that are covered by Law No. 216 of Novem- ber 9, 1970. In addition, banks charge a commission of 2 per cent on all sales of foreign exchange. There are no forward exchange facilities. The transactions settled in the official exchange mar- ket are exports and imports (except unrecorded border trade), certain current invisibles, all government trans- actions, registered private capital transactions, and re- lated profit remittances. All other transactions are channeled through the fluctuating free market, unless settlements are effected under reciprocal credit agree- ments with LAFTA countries. The authorized banks, but not the exchange houses, are required to sell 30 per cent of their gross foreign exchange receipts in specified currencies1 to the Central Bank. Administration of Control The Central Bank of Paraguay determines foreign exchange policy and supervises the foreign exchange transactions carried out by commercial banks and au- thorized foreign exchange houses. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements. Payments between Paraguay and Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, and Peru may be made through accounts which the Central Bank of Paraguay and the other central banks concerned maintain with each other, within the framework of the LAFTA multi- lateral clearing system. 376 Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few commodities require an import li- cense.2 Certain other items require a license from the Ministry of Interior; these are mainly narcotics and arms and ammunition. All other imports are free of quantitative restriction and licensing. Imports of most commodities are subject to an advance deposit of 100 per cent of the f.o.b. value, which is retained for 120 days, or if the deposit is made after the date of ship- ment, 180 days, or for nonexempt commodities im- ported through the Spanish free zone in Paraguay, 90 days. Advance deposits are not required for, inter alia, public sector imports, imports by foreign diplomats and by foreign staff of certain international organiza- tions, petroleum and petroleum derivatives, certain ma- chinery and agricultural equipment, wheat, and printed matter from any source, imports from neighboring countries and Uruguay, and imports from other LAFTA countries of items included in the Paraguayan concession list (the National List). The Central Bank has authority to grant exemptions on a case-by-case basis. Surcharges, calculated on the c.i.f. value, are payable on most imports even if no foreign exchange payment takes place. An import surcharge of 36 per cent applies to most general imports from any source; however, for goods originating in LAFTA countries and included in the Paraguayan National List the rate ranges from 3 per cent to 30 per cent, and for certain other LAFTA goods (mainly Pharmaceuticals) in a special list the rate is 8 per cent. Fuel derived from petroleum is subject to a surcharge of 15 per cent (10 per cent for neighboring countries and Uruguay). There is an additional sur- charge of 5 per cent on imports from all sources of telephone and telegraph equipment, television receiv- ers, and radios and record players and their parts and accessories. Commodities that are exempt from sur- charge generally are also exempt from advance deposit. These surcharges are collected by the banks at the time of delivery of the documents for customs clearance or when the import payment is made, whichever is earlier. The following are the principal exemptions from surcharge: wheat; crude petroleum; equipment for petroleum exploration and exploitation; agricultural tractors; imports for the Government; imports for reli- gious, charitable, cultural, or educational purposes; im- ports by foreign diplomats and certain international organizations; Spanish agricultural and industrial ma- chinery and implements imported through the Spanish free zone in Paraguay; agricultural machinery and equipment for the National Wheat Program; books and periodicals; and imports for investments under the new Capital Investment Law No. 216/70. Imports of in- vestment goods and of raw materials for export indus- tries receive exemption on a case-by-case basis. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution In addition to the above surcharges, a tariff sur- charge is levied on certain imports by virtue of Law No. 1334/67, which implemented Decree-Law No. 451 of March 31, 1967, and Law No. 10 of August 29, 1968. On goods that are not exempt, it is 12-24 per cent (8-16 per cent for certain goods subject to LAFTA concessions) and is levied on the c.i.f. value, which is calculated as follows: the f.o.b. value plus 10 per cent for imports from neighboring countries and Uruguay, and the f.o.b. value plus 20 per cent for imports from other countries. Exempt from this complementary im- port duty are public sector and diplomatic imports; raw materials and equipment for the production of goods that are subject to internal consumption taxes; imports under Capital Investment Law No. 216/70; and all imported goods taxed under the Internal Consumption Tax Law. Imports are also subject to sales tax at 5 per cent or 10 per cent by virtue of Law No. 69/68. In addition to those mentioned above, the following charges are levied on the c.i.f. value of imports: a con- sular fee of 5 per cent, an import clearance fee of 1 per cent, and a customs surcharge of IV2 per cent, from which wheat and certain other commodities are exempt and the proceeds of which go to the Institute of Tech- nology and Standards. Moreover, imports of construc- tion materials are subject to an additional customs surcharge of 1 per cent, the proceeds of which go to the Institute of Housing and Urbanization. Imports of specified goods (including television sets and precious metals) may not be financed with foreign credit. Imports on credit for a term of more than six months require approval from the Central Bank. This approval is normally granted only for imports of ma- chinery and other capital goods. Import payments must be made through banks, at the official market rate of exchange. Import payments are free from formal restriction, but certain arrears have arisen from time to time as a result of periodic releases of foreign exchange to the private commercial banks by the Central Bank. Payments for Invisibles Payments for all current invisibles may be made freely through the fluctuating free market. These in- clude travel, freight and insurance, interest and divi- dends on capital that has not been registered with the Central Bank, family remittances, and private dona- tions. There are allocations at the official rate for a few invisibles, such as payments related to study abroad. The General Banking Law of November 13, 1973 lim- its the remittance of profits'through the official market to 30 per cent of any one year's profits for commercial banks and financial institutions and to 60 per cent for investment, development, and mortgage banks; the re- maining profits may be remitted freely through the fluctuating free market. Travelers may take out any amount in foreign or domestic currency. PARAGUAY Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of logs and rough beams and a few other items are prohibited. Meat is subject to annual export quotas and certain other exports require licenses in order to assure domestic supplies. All other exports are free of license but some require a certificate issued by the Institute of Technology and Standards. The pro- ceeds of exports must be collected within 180 days after completion of shipping formalities, and the exchange sold to an authorized commercial bank; there are no legal sanctions for noncompliance with this require- ment unless this is notified to the Central Bank by the Superintendency of Banks. For all exports minimum surrender prices (aforos) denominated in U.S. dollars and calculated at fj 123.60 per US$1 are established; export proceeds corresponding to these prices must be surrendered in the official exchange market.3 Advance receipts of export proceeds must also be sold to autho- rized banks. Producers of coffee are permitted to retain 50 per cent of their export proceeds; such retained pro- ceeds may only be used to meet dividend and interest payments due to nonresidents and to pay for imports of machinery and equipment for the producers' own use. Most exports are subject to taxes payable in guara- nies ranging from 2V2 per cent to 7V2 per cent of the f.o.b. value; most exports also are subject to an addi- tional tax of 1V2 per cent of the f.o.b. value. Exports of meat products are exempt from export taxes. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds from invisibles may be retained or sold in the fluctuating free market. Travelers may bring in any amount in foreign or domestic currency. Capital Movements of registered capital take place in the official exchange market, through authorized banks, and all other capital movements are channeled through the fluctuating free market, through exchange houses. All inward and outward transfers must be recorded by the authorized banks and exchange houses. Authorized banks may grant exchange at the official market rate for transfers of registered capital, subject to presenta- tion of appropriate documentation. Other outward transfers of capital require the prior approval of the Central Bank. Law No. 216 of November 9, 1970, the Capital Investment Law, empowers the Government to grant special tax, customs, import surcharge, and ad- vance deposit concessions to proposed private foreign investments, provided that these are registered; the terms may vary from case to case. Capital imported under Law No. 216 may be retransferred in install- ments of up to 20 per cent from the third year after the beginning of production, in the currency originally im- ported. 377 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PARAGUAY Gold Decree-Law No. 18 of 1952 provides that the Cen- tral Bank may determine the maximum amount of gold and foreign exchange that residents may hold; exempt is any amount acquired by the Central Bank or institu- tions authorized to deal in foreign exchange. In practice residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, in Paraguay or abroad, and exchange houses may freely deal in gold coins, gold bars, and gold leaf with residents and nonresidents. Exports and imports of gold in any form other than jewelry require the prior approval of the Central Bank, for which residents and industrial users are eligible; payments for gold imports by industrial users must be made through authorized banks at the official exchange rate, and payments for imports by others must be made through exchange houses at the fluctuating free market rate. Changes during 1974 January 1. Decree No. 2373 of December 14, 1973 introduced a new customs tariff based on the Brussels tariff nomenclature. The decree also imposed a tax of 1.5 per cent on most exports. March 15. Decree No. 4509 lifted the prohibition on imports of liquid petroleum. April 19. Exchange houses authorized to operate in the fluctuating market were prohibited from entering into obligations of any kind vis-a-vis banks in Paraguay except with the express permission of the Central Bank. June 28. Decree No. 7005 consolidated in a single list those import duties that were effectively levied at levels lower than provided in the customs tariff. December 17. A regulation was issued providing that with effect from January 2, 1975 the full exchange pro- ceeds from exports had to be sold in the official market. Not for Redistribution PERU (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System On December 18,1946, a par value for the Peruvian Sol was established by Peru with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. There is a dual exchange mar- ket with two fixed exchange rates, an exchange certifi- cate market rate applying to all trade transactions and specified nontrade transactions, including the principal capital movements, and a draft market rate for services and most other nontrade transactions. The foreign ex- change requirements of the public sector are met en- tirely through the certificate market. Export proceeds must be converted into exchange certificates, which are valid for three days and are is- sued by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru in U.S. dol- lars only. These exchange certificates may be used, only through the intermediary of commercial banks, to pay for imports (f.o.b.) and for certain nontrade transac- tions. Generally, no exchange certificates are issued against export proceeds surrendered by the public sec- tor, nor are certificates used to cover foreign payments of the public sector, since normally the Central Reserve Bank buys and sells foreign exchange direct from and to government agencies at the certificate rate. When approved applications for certificates exceed the sup- ply, the Central Reserve Bank sells foreign exchange at the certificate market rate without any delay. All for- eign exchange receipts that are not required to be sur- rendered at the certificate rate must be sold in the draft market, in which only the government-owned Banco de la Nacion and its authorized agents operate. Access to the draft market is controlled and purchases of foreign exchange are permitted only for specified payments not eligible for exchange at the certificate rate. The banks are required to quote a single rate for buying and selling certificates, but they may charge a commission of V4 of 1 per cent on sales of certificates (none on purchases of certificates); they may charge a commission of V4 of 1 per cent, buy ing and selling, on transactions in the draft market. On December 31, 1974 the certificate market rate was S /. 38.70 per US$1 (buying and selling) and the draft market rate was S /. 43.38 buying, and S /. 43.50 selling, per US$1. A stamp tax of 1 per cent is payable on most outward remittances. Peru formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Administration of Control Export licenses are issued by the Directorate of For- eign Trade in the Ministry of Commerce. The Central Reserve Bank controls the use of certificates for import payments. It also authorizes the use of certificates for nontrade transactions; for profit remittances by branches of foreign companies, prior approval by the Ministry of Economy and Finance must be obtained in addition. All imports of, and most payments for ser- vices by, the public sector require the approval of the Board for Foreign Transactions of the Public Sector and a resolution of the Ministry of Economy and Fi- nance; a similar Board for Foreign Transactions- of the Private Sector approves import payments by the pri- vate sector on the basis of an annual forecast of imports that has been authorized by the competent sectoral ministries. Borrowing abroad by the public sector as well as borrowing abroad by the private sector with a government guarantee are subject to prior approval by Supreme Decree, upon favorable recommendation by the High Committee of the External Debt, the National Planning Institute, and the Permanent Commission on External Credit in the Ministry of Economy and Fi- nance. Prescription of Currency In principle, all export proceeds must be received in convertible currencies;1 exchange certificates at present are only issued in U.S. dollars, but the Central Reserve Bank is empowered to issue certificates denominated in any convertible currency. Settlements in respect of trade transactions with Hungary and Poland must be made through special accounts denominated in U.S. dollars, which have been established under bilateral payments agreements. No other prescription of cur- rency requirements are in force. Payments between Peru and Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Venezuela may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru and the other central banks concerned, within the framework of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system. Imports and Import Payments The import of a number of consumer goods that are considered nonessential is prohibited from any source other than LAFTA countries. Moreover, the import of a large number of manufactures included in the Na- tional Register of Manufactured Products requires the approval of the customs authorities, which is granted only in exceptional circumstances. Private sector im- ports require the prior authorization of the competent sectoral m in is try on the basis of an annual import fore- cast submitted by the importer. The Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector allocates exchange (in annual allotments to the individual importers) in accordance with the annual import forecast approved by the sectoral ministries; imports of goods originating in countries of the Andean Group are exempt from this 379 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU allocation system. The allocations are marked on indi- vidual importer's cards (tarjetas de importador). Pub- lic sector agencies may not place import orders without the prior approval of the Commission on Public Exter- nal Transactions and the Ministry of Economy and Finance. Certain agricultural commodities, such as rice and wheat, may be imported only by, or within quotas set by, the Public Company for Agricultural Services (EPSA) or the Fish Meal Marketing Agency (Empresa Publica de Comercializacion de Aceite y Harina de Pescado or EPCHAP), and crude petroleum and petro- leum derivatives only by PETROPERU, a government agency. Certain industrial raw materials may be im- ported only by the National Enterprise for Industrial Marketing (ENCI), and the National Fertilizer Service (FERTIPERU) has the exclusive right to import and mar- ket agricultural fertilizers. Virtually all private imports valued at over US$2,000 (c.i.f.) must be made on a letter of credit basis. Pay- ments for the f.o.b. value of private sector imports, whether under documentary letters of credit or on a documentary collection basis, and for interest charges on foreign import credits, may be made at the certifi- cate exchange rate; however, payments for freight and import-related banking charges other than interest must be made at the draft market rate. Transport insur- ance contracts for imported goods must be placed with national insurance companies unless a specific exemp- tion from this requirement is obtained from the Banco de la Nacion, in which case premium payments are made at the draft market rate. The full c.i.f. value of public sector imports may be paid with certificates. The use of certificates for import payments requires the prior authorization of the Central Reserve Bank, which provides the foreign exchange to the commercial banks against delivery of the certificates. The commer- cial banks must present evidence that the entire amount represented by the certificates will be used for the im- portation of merchandise. The relevant shipping docu- ments and the bill of lading, together with the commercial invoice and the remittance letter issued by the exporter, must be forwarded to a commercial bank and presented to the Central Reserve Bank for registra- tion and validation. Submission of import contracts or other evidence supporting the transaction is required for advance im- port payments when the shipping documents are not available; in addition, the intermediary bank must pro- vide a guarantee equal to the sol value of the advance payment. If the shipping documents are not presented within 30 days after the utilization of the foreign ex- change, the Central Reserve Bank will collect the guar- antee and refund this sum only when the required documents have been presented. Minimum credit terms have been prescribed for many imports. For imports of capital goods valued at over US$10,000 f.o.b., at least 80 per cent of the value must be financed abroad through loans either from suppliers or other foreign creditors or from the Peruvian state 380 development banks, to be repaid in accordance with minimum credit terms set by the Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector. The state develop- ment banks may only provide such financing for na- tional enterprises and these loans, although repayable in soles, must carry an exchange rate guarantee. The Central Reserve Bank may authorize the sale of ex- change certificates only for partial advance payments of up to 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value for imports of capital goods by the private sector (20 per cent of the c.i.f. value for public sector imports). These imports of capital goods must be covered by irrevocable documen- tary credits and the intermediary bank must guarantee refunding of the foreign currency if the import is not effected by the time the relevant documentary credit expires. For private sector imports of goods other than capi- tal goods from countries outside the Andean Group, the minimum external financing terms at the end of 1974 were as follows: (1) foodstuffs and pharmaceutical products were exempt; (2) a credit period of at least 90 days from the date of shipment was prescribed for cer- tain intermediate and finished goods; (3) the corre- sponding minimum period for all other goods was 120 days; (4) import shipments valued at up to US$5,000 (c. & f.) were exempt, up to a total value of US$50,000 a year for each importer. A maritime fre ight tax of 4 per cent of the ocean freight charges is levied on goods imported by sea other than certain agricultural and medical products, books, and coins. Public sector imports must, in principle, be shipped in Peruvian vessels. Payments for Invisibles Authorization is required in order to pay for invisi- bles with certificates or at the certificate rate. The trans- actions in invisibles that are eligible for the certificate market include government payments, profit remit- tances by branches of foreign companies operating in Peru, dividend remittances to foreign shareholders (provided that the original investment took place at the certificate rate), and interest payments on those loans for which amortization may be transferred through the certificate market. Remittances of net profits, including depletion and depreciation allowances, require a reso- lution of the Ministry of Economy and Finance, a prior tax clearance, and the visa of the Central Reserve Bank. Moreover, in compliance with the foreign investment regime approved by the countries of the Andean Group, new foreign investments must be authorized and registered with the competent agency. Access to the certificate market or the draft market for profit remittances is determined according to the market through which the investment is made. Remittances of profits on foreign capital invested in Peru are limited to 14 per cent a year;2 foreign-owned enterprises may not pay royalties under new contracts to a foreign parent company or its affiliates; and the effective interest rate ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution on a new loan from a foreign parent company or its foreign aff i l ia te may not exceed by more than 3 per cent the prevailing interest rate for first-class assets in the money market of the country in whose currency the transaction is denominated. Exchange for payments that are not eligible for ex- change certificates must be obtained in the d ra ft mar- ket, subject to the prior authorization of the Banco de la Nacion. For private sector payments in respect of a large number of current invisibles the sale of foreign exchange is authorized freely, either by the Banco de la Nacion or its agents, provided evidence is presented that genuine current payments are involved. These cat- egories include import freight charges, insurance pre- miums, the remuneration of technicians hired abroad, interest on loans for which amortization payments are permitted to be transferred through the d ra ft market, rental income, pensions, and commissions. Payments for royalties, patents, and trademarks require the prior approval of the contract by the competent agency. For certain other payments of the private sector basic allo- cations have been established up to which foreign ex- change is sold freely through the draft market by the Banco de la Nacion. These categories include expenses abroad connected with tourist and business travel, study, and fam i ly maintenance. The basic limit up to which foreign exchange for tourist travel may be sold is the equivalent of S /. 1,500 a person a day for a maximum of 30 days in any one calendar year for travel to any country. The Banco de la Nacion fixes basic maximum amounts of foreign ex- change which may be purchased annually by each eligi- ble company for business travel abroad by its officials. There is a travel tax, which takes the form of a tax on a traveler's acquisition of goods and services abroad (including the cost of passages and fares) of 10 per cent3 on amounts up to the daily limits specified above, and of 50 per cent on any amounts in excess of these limits; the minimum amount payable is S /. 50 a day for each day spent abroad. Exempt are residents traveling on official business and foreign diplomats. Travel for med- ical treatment or study abroad also is exempt. The tax is paid prior to departure on the basis of a sworn decla- ration specifying separately the amount of the fare, the value of anticipated services to be received, and daily expenses. Air and sea passages are in addition subject to a 7 per cent ad valorem tax (3 per cent for economy class fares). Foreign nationals resident in Peru must obtain a special travel permit for business travel abroad (permiso especial de salida y reingreso). Such permits cost S /. 1,000 and are valid for six months. The export of domestic currency in excess of S /. 1,000 by travelers is prohibited, but the Central Reserve Bank grants ex- emptions in special circumstances. Exports and Export Proceeds The Banco Minero del Peru has a monopoly over the export of precious metals, uncut precious stones, and PERU pearls, and the Empresa Minera del Peru (MINEROPERU) has a monopoly over all other mineral exports. EPCHAP has a monopoly over exports of fish meal, fish oil, and fish for human consumption. Coffee exports are controlled by EPSA. All exports are subject to license to assure the necessary supply of export pro- ceeds to the certificate market. Traditional exports must be sold against an irrevocable letter of credit con- firmed by a bank established in Peru; the latter must surrender the foreign exchange proceeds within ten working days of payment. In special cases, and with the authorization of the Central Reserve Bank and the Di- rectorate of Foreign Trade, exports may be sold against sight drafts, provided that payment is received within 180 days of shipment. Exporters of nontraditional exports or local handi- craft articles are granted transferable tax credit certifi- cates (CATs) equivalent to 15-30 per cent of the c.i.f. value (of the f.o.b. value when the goods are shipped in foreign vessels). These certificates may be used by the exporter in payment of his tax obligations or may be sold to other taxpayers, who may use them for the same purpose. The Banco de la Nacion administers an export credit guarantee program and the Industrial Bank pro- vides or arranges export finance for nontraditional ex- ports. Traditional exports are subject to a special tax. Proceeds from Invisibles Most public sector entities other than the state banks must surrender their full receipts at the certificate rate; the exceptions are earnings from services provided by the Peruvian Shipping Company (Compania Peruana de Vapores or CPV) and the Peruvian Airline Company (AEROPERU), which are eligible for the draft market rate. All other receipts from invisibles must be sold in the draft market. Travelers may not bring in more than S /. 1,000 in Peruvian currency, but the Central Re- serve Bank grants exemptions in special circumstances. Capital All outward capital transfers require prior approval. In addition to government payments, certain capital payments on private account may be effected through the certificate market. The use of exchange certificates may be authorized for the amortization of foreign loans contracted by the private sector, provided that the for- eign exchange proceeds of the loan have been surren- dered to the Central Reserve Bank. Where such debt was contracted before October 9, 1967, certificate ex- change may be allotted by the Central Reserve Bank only to public utility enterprises, to earners of foreign exchange, for payment of debts to international organi- zations, and for payments of debts guaranteed by the State. Payments in connection with all loans received before June 17, 1971 and not channeled through the certificate market must be transferred through the draft market. The proceeds of all foreign loans received after June 17, 1971 must be converted in the certificate mar- 381 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU ket; amortization and service payments in respect of these loans are also settled through the certificate mar- ket. All exchange receipts that are not required to be sold in the certificate market must be sold in the draft market. Only the Banco de la Nacion may receive funds origi- nating abroad for deposit to foreign currency accounts maintained in the name of nonresidents; these funds and the accrued interest thereon may be freely disposed of by the depositor and are exempt from income and inheritance taxes until December 31, 1978. Foreign investment in Peru is governed by Decree- Law No. 18900 of June 30, 1971, which ratified the Andean Common Market's policy on the treatment of foreign capital, by Decree- Law No. 18999 of Octo- ber 19, 1971, and by Decree-Law No. 19232, Decree- Law No. 19307, Decree-Law No. 19971, and the legislation ruling the Peruvian exchange system. All foreign investments in Peru require the prior approval of the competent authorities with a view to channeling such investments to projects considered essential for the country's development. If they wished to enjoy for their products the advantages deriving from the duty- free program of the Cartagena Agreement, foreign companies incorporated in Peru as at July 1, 1971 had to agree, by June 30, 1974, to the gradual acquisition by national investors of shares in such companies so as to transform them into mixed or national companies during a maximum period of 15 years following the entering into effect of this regime. For this purpose, mixed companies are defined as those in which national investors hold between 51 per cent and 80 per cent of the capital, while national companies are those in which at least 80 per cent of the capital is owned by national investors. After June 30, 1974, the participation of na- tional investors in the capital of an enterprise had to amount to not less than 15 per cent; this participation must increase to at least 45 per cent after 10 years and to at least 51 per cent at the end of the 15-year period. In the case of foreign companies established in Peru after June 30, 1971, the 15 per cent participation by national investors must be secured at the time of the initiation of production. Foreign investments in firms engaged in basic industries or in m in ing activities (in- cluding petroleum production) and in firms which ex- port at least 80 per cent of their production to countries outside the Andean Common Market are exempt from the requirement of gradual transformation in to mixed companies; however, these enterprises do not benefit from the duty-free program of the Cartagena Agree- ment. All insurance and reinsurance companies that are not branches of foreign firms had to become national enter- prises by June 30, 1974, and all insurance and reinsur- ance companies established in Peru after July 17, 1973, had to be completely owned by national investors. Investment in the mining sector is governed by the General Mining Law (Decree-Law No. 18880) of June 8, 1971, which replaced the Mining Code of 382 May 12, 1950. Companies holding mining concessions may enter into mining contracts with the Government providing for special incentives and guarantees or may constitute mixed enterprises with government partici- pation of at least 25 per cent. Under the regime of mining contracts, the Government may grant to mining concessionaires initiating large-scale investment pro- grams tax incentives and guaranteed availability of for- eign exchange for transfers of (1) recovery of investment; (2) interest payments if the rate does not exceed the prevailing rate for similar loans in the finan- cial market from which the loans originate; (3) pay- ments for justified services; and (4) reasonable profit remittances, together with guaranteed access to the most favorable exchange rate. Mixed mining enter- prises may receive all the benefits and incentives which may be granted by special contract and, in addition, special tax reductions. Gold The marketing of precious metals and their import and export are governed by Decree-Law No. 18882 of June 15, 1971 and Supreme Decree No. 065-71-EF of the same date. The import and export of gold and certain other precious metals and of precious stones are the monopoly of the Banco Minero del Peru. All im- ports and exports of gold are settled in the certificate market. The authorities do not make foreign exchange available for imports of gold other than by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users. Domestic sales and purchases of gold may be carried out by industrial and professional users, provided that they hold licenses issued by the Banco Minero del Peru, but only M INEROPERU is au- thorized to make the initial purchase of newly mined gold and other precious metals. Residents traveling abroad may not take out jewelry valued at over S /. 50,000 unless it has been registered with the cus- toms (S /. 15,000 for trips to bordering countries). Changes during 1974 During 1974, the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar remained unchanged in both exchange mar- kets. A number of commodities were added to the Na- tional Register of Manufactured Products. January 1. A M in is try of Commerce was established, to be responsible for certain activities formerly super- vised by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce; the latter was renamed the Ministry of Indus try and Tour- ism. January 1. A decree-law was issued nationalizing a major foreign-owned mining company. January 15. Decree-Law No. 20505 introduced with effect from March 1 a special tax on traditional ex- ports. This tax was 10 per cent of the excess of the actual price over the reference value determined by the Ministry of Economy and Finance for the goods con- cerned. The reference value was set at the registered ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution price for 1972 plus 25 per cent. The tax would be levied only on 1974 exports. Implementing rules were issued on February 27 by Supreme Decree No. 051-74-EF and on June 11 by Supreme Decree No. 157-74-EF. January 29. Decree-Law No. 20519 approved the approximation of import duties to the minimum com- mon du ty of the Andean Group, by December 31, 1975. March 5. Exports of fish meal and fish oil, which had been suspended since November 7, 1973, were re- sumed. May 11. The Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector introduced a 180-day foreign financing requirement for private sector imports of goods other than capital goods, as follows: (1) All imports required the opening of a letter of credit denominated in foreign currency and with a term of at least 180 days from the date on the bill of lading; sight letters of credit were permitted only if payment was financed for at least 180 days by a foreign bank or any other foreign source. (2) Imports on a consignment basis required a letter of guarantee denominated in foreign currency and issued by a Peruvian bank in favor of the foreign exporter. These provisions did not affect imports of investment goods valued at more than US$10,000 (f.o.b.), for which payment terms of two-five years continued to be required, nor were they applicable to imports originat- ing in countries of the Andean Group. May 11. Private importers had to submit their import budget for 1974 to the Central Bank by the end of May; in order not to interrupt imports, importers were au- thorized to use up to 60 per cent of their previously assigned quota, insofar as this had not already been utilized. May 11. The presentation of importer's cards was required also for imports under letters of credit. Previ- ously, the system covered only those imports paid for in cash or on a documentary collection basis. May 25. Imports valued at up to US$200 (c. & f.) were exempted from the letter of credit requirement and could be paid at sight. No importer, however, could use this facility for more than US$2,000 worth of imports in a year. May 25. The Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector announced that it would consider appli- cations for 1975 for imports of capital goods and of goods with long delivery periods. June 21. Decree-Law No. 20616 provided that with effect from January 1, 1975 imports from Chile, Co- lombia, and Venezuela of goods not on the exception list but included in the PID (punto inicial de desgrava- cion) list would be subject to reduced import duties. June 30. The deadline under Decree-Law No. 19863 expired, which provided that all foreign industrial com- panies operating in Peru must sign a transformation contract with the Ministry of Industry by June 30. Such companies were to be transformed into mixed or na- tional companies, and at least 15 per cent of the capital must be held by domestic private companies. PERU July 1. The Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector issued new importer's cards for private imports; allocations were itemized according to cus- toms tariff headings. July 26. The Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector discontinued its policy of itemizing im- port allocations and established overall allocations. July 30. The President announced the "Plan Inca." It provided for progressive nationalization of various types of economic activity and contained a statement on the refinancing of external debts. Subsequently, it was announced that the Government would sign no new exploration contracts with foreign oil companies. August 7. The Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector authorized imports shipped prior to June 30 to enter the country even if no prior foreign exchange allocation had been granted; no letter of credit requirement was applied in these cases. August 12. An economic cooperation agreement was signed with Cuba. August26. Supreme Decree No. 220-74-EF made the Directorate-General of Customs part of the Ministry of Commerce. September 17. EPCHAP was given a monopoly over the export and domestic marketing of cotton and cot- tonseed (Decree-Law No. 20736). September 24. The basic exchange allocation for tourist travel was increased from the equivalent of S /. 1,200 a person a day (S /. 1,000 for Latin America) to S /. 1,500 a person a day, irrespective of destination; as previously, the allocation was available for up to 30 days in any one calendar year. October 1. The entry into force of the new general customs law (Decree-Law No. 20165 of October 2, 1973) was postponed un t il January 1, 1975 by Decree- Law No. 20747. October 15. Decree-Law No. 20758 authorized the Central Bank to issue certain commemorative gold and silver coins. October 30. The Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector revoked the 180-day financing re- quirement for imports. No minimum financing was re- quired for foods tuffs and pharmaceutical products. The prescribed minimum credit term was reduced to 90 days for intermediate and certain finished products and to 120 days for all other goods (except capital goods, which remained subject to existing arrangements). In addition, the minimum financing requirement was waived on all import shipments of up to US$5,000 (c. & f.), up to a total of US$50,000 a year for a single importer. The letter of credit requirement and the guar- antee letter requirement were eliminated for imports costing up to US$2,000 (c. & f.). November 3. Supreme Decree No. 020-74- MINCOM of the Ministry of Commerce provided that consular invoices would no longer be required, with effect from January 1, 1975. 383 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.227864 gram of fine gold per Philippine Peso. All exchange transactions take place in a free market. The Bankers' Association establishes daily a "guiding rate"; between December 31, 1973 and December 31, 1974 this rate moved from about P 6.74 per U.S. dollar to about P 7.06 per U.S. dollar. In spot transactions with their customers, commercial banks are required by the Association to observe certain mar- gins. The maximum and minimum spot buying rates are V2 of 1 per cent and 1 per cent below the guiding rate, respectively. The minimum and maximum spot selling rates are Y4 of 1 per cent and 1Y4 per cent above the guiding rate, respectively. The Central Bank of the Philippines, which is not governed by the Association's trading rules, makes its own purchases and sales of foreign exchange within the above margins required by the Association. Neither the Central Bank nor the com- mercial banks quote currencies other than the U.S. dollar. Interbank trading takes place at the Foreign Exchange Trading Center (FOREX), where the Central Bank from time to time acts as a buyer or supplier. Administration of Control Exchange regulations are administered by the Cen- tral Bank, which issues circulars and memoranda to the authorized agent banks on the basis of policy decisions reached by the Monetary Board. Certain new foreign direct or portfolio investment in the Philippines re- quires the prior approval of the Board of Investments (BOI). Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements for outgoing payments, but all exchange proceeds from exports must be obtained in Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Nether- lands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, or U.S. dollars. Most payments and transfers to Rhodesia are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Bank accounts denominated in pesos may be opened in the name of nonresidents, whether individual or cor- porate, without prior approval of the Central Bank. Nonresident accounts are permitted to be credited only with the proceeds from inward remittances of foreign exchange or convertible foreign currencies and with peso income from, or peso proceeds of, conversion of properties (real or personal) located in the Philippines belonging to nonresidents. Nonresident accounts may be freely debited for peso withdrawals. However, with- drawals from nonresident accounts for transfer abroad are subject to individual application with supporting evidence, and to established limits where applicable, such as in the case of emigrants. Both residents and nonresidents may under certain circumstances maintain foreign currency accounts with authorized agent banks in the Philippines (see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, below). Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia and South Africa are prohib- ited. Imports of certain commodities are prohibited on grounds of health, morals, and national security and those of certain others, mostly agricultural commodi- ties, for protective purposes. There are no other quanti- tative restrictions on imports (other than imports of gold); however, payment for imports of specified com- modities is subject to prior approval of the Central Bank.1'2 Such approval is granted on a case-by-case basis for commodities classified under three consumer goods categories (unclassified, semiunclassified, and nonessential consumer goods) or for completely knocked-down parts for automobile assembly plants. Payments for imports of certain other commodities (wheat, raw cotton, and leaf tobacco) are permitted only if they are financed through certain official credit arrangements. Any importation of plant, machinery, equipment, and spare parts under deferred payments arrangements with maturity periods longer than 360 days is subject to prior approval by the Central Bank. If payment terms are cash or within 360 days, prior approval by the Central Bank is necessary for importa- tion by any single importer of nonagricultural machin- ery and equipment with an aggregate value in excess of US$50,000 within a calendar month, with the exception of (1) certified export-oriented firms, and (2) other im- porters who have obtained prescribed certification from the BOI. Imports from socialist or communist countries must be effected through NETRACOR, a government trading firm, with the exception that most imports from the People's Republic of China are handled by the Philip- pine International Trading Corporation. As a method of payment, commodities may be im- ported against letters of credit, on a document against acceptance (D/A) basis, or under open (O/A) arrange- ments. The use of the D /A and O /A procedures is limited mainly to firms with a history of importing under these arrangements prior to February 21, 1970; to producer firms established after that date and ex- pressly authorized by the Monetary Board to import under these arrangements; to producer firms that are export oriented, are registered with the BOI, or are franchised utility concerns; and to such others as may be approved by the Central Bank. Unless arrangements for such terms of credit are made, imports in excess of 385 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES US$100 (US$500 for books and supplementary read- ers) must be covered by letters of credit opened on or before the day of shipment. Imports financed by im- porters' own foreign exchange or not involving pay- ments from the Philippines (so-called no-dollar imports) are allowed subject to prescribed conditions. Such permissible no-dollar imports are exempt from the requirement of opening letters of credit. At the request of an authorized agent bank or other financial institution, a firm may be "watch listed" by the Central Bank for arrears on its loan repayment commitments. A firm thus "watch listed" may not open import letters of credit without the approval of the Central Bank, which will allow the opening of letters of credit only after a schedule for the repayment of over- due obligations has been agreed upon. Furthermore, it is the practice of certain authorized agent banks to require 100 per cent deposit against the opening of letters of credit for such firms, compared with 25 per cent or 50 per cent in normal cases. Payments for Invisibles V ir tua l ly all payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. In principle, all other payments are permitted, w i thout prior approval of the Central Bank, provided that amounts of more than US$100 are substantiated by documentary evidence regarding the purpose and the amount applied for. However, there are certain limits and regulations established by the Central Bank for purchases of foreign exchange for travel abroad by resi- dents, remittances for educational expenses, mainte- nance and expenses of dependents abroad of residents, remittances of profits, dividends, and interest, royal- ties, and film and other rentals (see below). Exchange for travel abroad is made available by authorized agent banks as follows: (1) US$25 a day, up to a maximum of US$750 a trip (for exporters an additional represen- tation allowance of US$500) for each person for busi- ness or professional travel; (2) US$500 a year for each adult resident for nonbusiness travel to Africa, North and South America, Australia, Europe, Japan, the Mid- dle East, and New Zealand; and (3) US$200 a year for each adult resident for nonbusiness travel to Guam, Hong Kong, Okinawa, the Republic of China, or any other neighboring country. Foreign travel by Philip- pine citizens, however, is not normally permitted. The following limits apply to exchange for educa- tional expenses abroad: for studies in the United States, US$250 a month for living and other out-of-school expenses, plus the cost of tuition, books, laboratory fees, and other school charges; for studies in Australia, Europe, Japan, and New Zealand, US$200 a month; and for studies in other areas, US$150 a month. Any scholarship allowances are deducted from these amounts. Remittances for educational expenses and student maintenance abroad are allowed only to stu- dents working for a degree at duly accredited colleges or universities. 386 The following limits apply for remittances to depen- dents of residents: US$250 a month for each dependent living in the United States; US$200 a month for each dependent living in Australia, Europe, Japan, and New Zealand; and US$100 a month for each dependent liv- ing in other areas. The maintenance allowances for de- pendents are allowed only for close relatives under certain conditions prescribed by the Central Bank. Remittances of profits and dividends (net of taxes) accruing to nonresidents out of net profits realized be- ginning January 1, 1973, are permitted in fu l l, provided that remittances are not financed from domestic credit resources. Profits earned and dividends declared before January 1, 1973 (which had been unremittable for some time) may be remitted over a period of two years. Remittances of royalties or rentals on patents, trade- marks, and copyrights are freely permitted (net of taxes) for contracts registered with the Central Bank, provided that (1) the royalties do not exceed 5 per cent of the wholesale price of the commodity which is manu- factured locally under the royalty contract (2 per cent in the case of marketing service contracts), and (2) contracts do not exceed five-year terms and do not include restrictions on the export of the product. Re- mittances of the producer's shares of earnings made on motion-picture films and rentals on television films are freely permitted, provided generally that the shares or rentals do not exceed 60 per cent of net proceeds from films. Foreign exchange within the above limits may be purchased, without prior approval of the Central Bank, for current payments for invisibles administratively withheld prior to November 26, 1969. Applications for certain invisibles for which no basic allowance has been set are considered on their merits by the Central Bank. No person may take out or export from the Philip- pines foreign currency or any other foreign exchange except as authorized by the Central Bank. Residents may take out, as part of their travel allowance, up to US$100 in foreign banknotes. Nonresident travelers may take out any amount of foreign currency that they had previously brought in and declared, minus any amounts converted into pesos. Resident and nonresi- dent travelers require prior authorization from the Cen- tral Bank to take out more than P 500 in domestic notes and coins or checks, money orders, and other bills of exchange drawn in pesos. Citizens of the Philip- pines and permanent resident aliens, when traveling abroad, must pay a travel tax of P 400 for first-class ship or plane tickets or P 300 for any other ticket. Exempt are, among others, foreign diplomatic staff and Filipino Muslims making their first pilgrimage to Mecca. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to South Africa and exports to Rhodesia of petroleum products and military equipment and supplies are prohibited. Exports of certain strategic ma- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution terials and items deemed essential for industrialization and economic development are also prohibited. Other- wise, exports are generally not restricted, but they are regulated to ensure that the foreign exchange proceeds are surrendered to an authorized agent of the Central Bank. Authorized agent banks issue the necessary ex- port permits upon registration of the exporter's report of foreign sales (except export permits for gold, which are issued by the Central Bank); reports of foreign sales for copra and coconut oil, however, are approved for registration only by the Central Bank. Authorized agent banks must sell to the Central Bank 10 per cent of their exchange receipts from export bills. As a general rule, no commodity may be exported unless it is covered by a draft drawn in one of the prescribed currencies and unless collection of the pro- ceeds will be undertaken by an authorized agent bank; however, payment by means of telegraphic transfer, check, or mail transfer may be allowed. Payments for exports on a cash, collection, or consignment basis must be arranged through an authorized agent bank, which must specifically contract with the exporter to buy the exchange proceeds. No shipment of exports will be allowed by the customs unless a certificate is issued by a bank stating that payment has been received or arranged by the bank. Proceeds from exports must be received in the prescribed currencies within 30 days from the date of shipment (or within such period as may be established in special cases) and surrendered to the agent bank within 3 business days of receipt. An irrevocable letter of credit is required for all exports of scrap metals, copra, and coconut oil, and for all exports to Guam, Hong Kong, the Republic of China, Indone- sia, and Japan. Exports of perishable commodities to Hong Kong require prepayment. Under an "export deduction" scheme, export- oriented industries are allowed, subject to the prior ap- proval of the Central Bank, to use a part of their export proceeds for the repayment of the loans obtained for their imports of machinery, equipment, raw materials, and other requirements. An export tax is levied on the f.o.b. value of major exports. The rate is 10 per cent for logs, 6 per cent for copra, centrifugal sugar, and copper ore and concen- trates,3 and 4 per cent for gold, molasses, coconut oil, dessicated coconut, iron ore and concentrates, chro- mite ore and concentrates, copra meal or cake, un- manufactured abaca, unmanufactured tobacco, veneer core and sheets, plywood, lumber, canned pineapples, shrimps and prawns, bunker fuel oil, bananas, cement clinker, portland cement, and petroleum pitch and resi- dues. Certain traditional export commodities are sub- ject to premium export duties. The Philippine Exchange Company has a monopoly over the export of sugar. Export trade with socialist and communist countries authorized under Executive Order No. 384 is handled through NETRACOR, with the exception that most exports to the People's Republic of China are handled by the Philippine International PHILIPPINES Trading Corporation. Exports to the People's Republic of China require the prior approval of the Department of Trade. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles must be sold within three business days by the recipient to an authorized agent bank. Philippine nationals employed abroad are per- mitted to open U.S. dollar deposit accounts with the Central Bank or authorized agent banks, in which they may retain any U.S. dollars they remit to the Philip- pines. To be eligible for credit to such accounts at the Central Bank, earnings must be transferred through Philippine diplomatic or consular establishments. Un- der a foreign currency deposit scheme, inward remit- tances by residents or nonresidents of foreign currencies for deposit in numbered foreign currency accounts are exempt from surrender requirements, pro- vided that the remittances neither represent current earnings or income of residents nor payments by non- residents pursuant to contractual obligations. Balances in such accounts are freely transferable abroad. Travel- ers may freely bring in any amount of foreign currency and up to P 500 in domestic notes and coins and checks, money orders, and other bills of exchange drawn in pesos, of which not more than P 50 may consist of Philippine coins. Capital All inward and outward capital movements, with the exception of certain banking operations and certain transactions related to financing of international trade (see below), are subject to the prior and specific ap- proval of the Central Bank. Virtually all payments and transfers to Rhodesia are prohibited. For the purpose of the approval of new inward foreign investments (in kind or in cash) as well as new foreign borrowings, preference is given to projects approved by the BOI, export-oriented industries, and other (nonexport-ori- ented) industries not utilizing domestic credit re- sources. The law guarantees full repatriation of cash investments made after March 15, 1973 in (a) ex- port-oriented industries that have been certified by the Central Bank, (b) enterprises registered with the BOI, and (c) securities certified by the Central Bank and traded on the Manila and Makati stock exchanges. Minimum repatriation periods, however, are pre- scribed; thus, foreign investors must hold securities for at least 90 days before the proceeds become eligible for repatriation. Foreign direct cash investments made after March 15, 1973 and registered with the Central Bank are freely repatriable, except investments in domestic commercial banks, which if made after March 31, 1973, are freely repatriable and if made before that date are repatriable according to the schedule in (4) below. There are certain restrictions on sales of foreign ex- change for the repatriation of foreign direct cash invest- 387 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES ments made before March 16, 1973 and noncash in- vestments made after March 15, 1973, depending on the category of industry where the investment is made, as follows: (1) export-oriented industries certified by the Central Bank—repatriable in full but no annual installment to exceed the applicant's share in the net foreign exchange earnings of the firm in the preceding year; (2) enterprises registered with the BOI, producing import substitutes or exports but not included in (1) above—repatriable in three equal annual installments starting one year after the liquidation of investment, but no annual installment to be more than total net foreign exchange earnings in the preceding year; (3) enterprises registered with the BOI, not included in (2) above and not utilizing domestic credit resources—in four equal annual installments starting one year after liquidation of investments; (4) remaining industries —repatriation according to the following schedule: US$0.25 million or less, five equal annual installments after liquidation; US$0.25-0.5 million, seven equal an- nual installments after liquidation; and over US$0.5 million, nine equal annual installments after liquida- tion. During the period between the date of investments and repatriation, liquidation proceeds may be rein- vested, subject to approval by the Central Bank, in foreign currency deposits under Circular No. 343, gov- ernment securities, or shares of stock in export-oriented industries registered with the BOI or certified by the Central Bank. Without prior Central Bank approval, commercial banks may not receive credit from abroad other than credit arising from normal international trade transac- tions. They may, however, freely accept from nonresi- dents of foreign nationality deposits in nine scheduled currencies (Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars); such deposits are freely repatriable at the prevailing ex- change rate and are exempt from the 35 per cent with- holding tax. Nonbank residents may obtain suppliers' credits from abroad provided that repayment terms are within the limits prescribed by the Central Bank. The maturity may not be less than 5 years for amounts up to US$250,000 (with certain exceptions), not less than 8 years for amounts between US$250,000 and US$500,000, and not less than 12 years for amounts greater than US$500,000. For export industries, amounts exceeding US$500,000 are approved if the credit has a maturity of at least 8 years, inclusive of a 3-year grace period on repayment of principal; and for amounts less than US$150,000, 3 or 4 year maturities may be permitted depending on the amount of credit and the type of export industry. Interest rates may not be more than 1Y2 per cent above the prime rate of the lending country. Applications are not approved if the proposed project expands capacity in an industry deemed to be overcrowded, or for firms which are in arrears with government financial institutions. Sales of foreign exchange for amortization of loans are permit- 388 ted in accordance with the terms of loan contracts ap- proved by the Central Bank. The same applies for loan contracts registered with the Central Bank prior to November 26, 1969. For those not falling under these two categories, prior approval by the Central Bank is required for sales of foreign exchange for repayment of loans. The Management of External Debt and Invest- ment Accounts Department in the Central Bank main- tains a comprehensive record of credit taken up abroad by the public and private sectors. Emigrants may repatriate up to US$5,000, subject to verification by the Central Bank. The remaining liquid assets may be withdrawn in five years beginning one year from emigration. Except as otherwise specifically authorized, resident persons, firms, or corporations may not enter into any contract or transaction which may involve settlement in foreign exchange, or involving any assets belonging to them expressed in foreign currencies or payable or deliverable abroad. This restriction also applies to con- tracts or transactions involving assets within the Philip- pines belonging to a nonresident person, firm, or corporation, and to their exportation or importation. Detailed regulations are in force concerning transac- tions in securities between residents and nonresidents. Under the Investment Incentives Act of 1967, all investors in enterprises registered with the BOI are guaranteed the right to repatriate their investments, and to remit earnings thereon and sums needed to meet payments of principal and interest on foreign loans; they are also guaranteed freedom from expropriation and requisition. There are different arrangements for "pioneer investments" and "preferred investments"; the former are granted certain incentives over and above those given to preferred investments. Normally, enterprises owned or controlled by for- eigners are permitted to operate only in "pioneer areas of investment," and normally at least 60 per cent of the outstanding voting capital stock of registered enter- prises in "preferred areas of investment" (mainly invest- ments related to the exploitation of export-oriented natural resources and the manufacturing of import sub- stitutes) must be owned by Philippine nationals. By virtue of the Laurel-Langley Agreement, U.S. citizens, corporations, and associations were given the same sta- tus for this purpose as Philippine citizens until July 1974. Under the Foreign Investment Law of 1968, new enterprises in which investment by non-Filipinos ex- ceeds 30 per cent and which are not covered by the Investment Incentives Act must obtain prior authority from the BOI in order to engage in any economic activ- ity in the Philippines. If purchases of shares of common stock by foreign nationals would reduce Philippine ownership in a firm to less than 70 per cent, permission from the BOI must first be obtained. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Gold Producers of gold may be eligible for assistance un- der the Gold Industry Assistance Act (Republic Act No. 3089, as amended by Republic Act No. 6364 of August 5, 1971), irrespective of whether this gold is a by-product or the principal or only product of their operations. However, gold producers who wish to take advantage of the floating exchange rate (the "guiding rate") in lieu of the subsidy must export their gold production. Exports of gold (as principal product) are subject to an export tax of 4 per cent. Primary gold producers may sell their production, in the form of refined standard bars, to Authorized Gold Dealers of the Central Bank or retain it abroad for their own account for sale either to other Authorized Gold Dealers or in the free market abroad. Purchases by Authorized Gold Dealers from primary producers are based on current London market prices (as quoted in U.S. dollars, multiplied by the interbank guiding rate on the date of sale); sales by Authorized Gold Dealers or primary producers in the free market abroad must be settled in "acceptable" foreign currencies. Residents other than the monetary authorities, Authorized Gold Dealers, and authorized industrial users are not al- lowed to purchase gold abroad in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Central Bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Changes during 1974 January 16. Exporters required prior clearance from the Department of Trade before negotiating export sales to the People's Republic of China. January 31. Registered bookstores could import books and supplementary readers valued at not more than US$500 for each order without opening letters of credit. January 31. All proposals for foreign borrowings by the public sector required the approval in principle of the Monetary Board as to purpose and credit terms. February 16. Premium export duties of 20 per cent or 30 per cent were levied (in addition to the export duties levied under R.A. 1937) on certain traditional export commodities (logs, lumber, veneer, plywood, copper, iron, chromite, clinker, cement, copra, other coconut products, and sugar and molasses); the base price ap- plied was 80 per cent of the February 1974 f.o.b. prices. February 22. Agent banks could without prior Cen- tral Bank approval act on (1) imports on a "no-dollar" basis exceeding the authorized amount by not more than US$500, and (2) imports of empty bottles and containers for drugs. March 1. Agent banks were authorized to provide full foreign exchange cover for their outstanding regu- lar sight letters of credit. Also, restrictions were im- posed on agent banks' net foreign liabilities. They could PHILIPPINES not maintain at any time an oversold foreign exchange position in any foreign currency. They could not avail themselves of overdrafts or foreign exchange borrow- ings against existing credit lines or any other form of foreign exchange borrowings abroad without the neces- sary spot exchange cover or forward exchange cover purchased from the Central Bank under swap arrange- ments. Agent banks currently having oversold foreign exchange positions had to cover their deficiencies within 30 days. March 27. Agent banks were required to refer to the Central Bank for appropriate action all imports of com- pletely knocked-down motorcycles, motorcycle frame group parts, chains, and engine parts. April 1. The proportion of wood exports which could be in the form of logs was increased from 40 per cent to 80 per cent of actual log production; however, ex- ports of logs would be prohibited from the end of 1975. April 24. Central Bank Circular No. 401 revised the regulations governing transactions in gold. Gold pro- ducers no longer were required to sell their entire out- put to the Central Bank (at the equivalent of US$42.22 an ounce, calculated at P 3.90 per U.S. dollar) in order to be eligible for assistance under the Gold Industry Act (R.A. No. 3089, as amended by R.A. No. 6364). The new regulations, which took effect on May 2, in- cluded the following: Philippine primary gold producers could (1) sell all or part of their refined gold production to Authorized Gold Dealers of the Central Bank (as defined below), or (2) retain such refined gold production abroad for their own account for sale at some future date to Au- thorized Gold Dealers or in the free gold market abroad in accordance with the new regulations. Pur- chases of gold by Authorized Gold Dealers from pri- mary gold producers were to be based on the current London market price, as quoted in U.S. dollars, multi- plied by the interbank guiding rate on the date of sale. Commercial banks with aggregate resources of not less than P 1 billion and net worth of not less than P 100 million as of May 2 were designated Authorized Gold Dealers of the Central Bank; other banks, however, could be authorized by the Monetary Board to act as gold dealers, on a case-by-case basis. Authorized Gold Dealers could buy gold offered for sale by primary gold producers provided it was in the form of international standard gold bars refined to not less than 0.995 fine by refineries approved by the Central Bank. The purchase and sale of gold in the Philippines had to be made in Philippine currency, with the exception that sales of gold by Authorized Gold Dealers or pri- mary gold producers in the international free gold mar- ket had to be effected in "acceptable" foreign currencies. Authorized Gold Dealers could freely buy and sell gold among themselves or sell gold in the free gold market abroad, based on its current free market price. They could fix among themselves the daily inter- bank gold price which they could use as a guide in their buying and selling operations. 389 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES Primary gold producers could borrow pesos from Authorized Gold Dealers up to 80 per cent of the value, based on the producer's assay of the gold shipment used as collateral, with maturities from 30 to 360 days and interest not exceeding 6 per cent per annum. Au- thorized Gold Dealers could borrow funds from the Central Bank either by discounting the promissory notes of gold producers with the Central Bank at 4 per cent, or by securing peso advances up to 100 per cent of the value of gold purchased outright from gold pro- ducers, for periods up to 360 days at an interest rate of 4 per cent. Authorized Gold Dealers could keep their refined gold with foreign and /or resident depositories. Refined gold purchased by Authorized Gold Dealers would form part of their foreign exchange assets, and Autho- rized Gold Dealers were to report daily to the Central Bank their gold transactions in the same manner as they reported their foreign exchange transactions.
