Not for Redistribution SIERRA LEONE (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.06641 grams of fine gold per Le- one. With effect f rom June 27, 1972, however, the leone was allowed to float w i th sterling. The Bank of Sierra Leone deals in sterling only and stands ready in trans- actions w i th commercial banks to buy and sell leones in exchange for sterling at the rate of Le 1 = £ stg. 0.50, subject to a maximum commission of 1 per cent on either side. The authorized banks in Sierra Leone base their rates for other currencies on the current London market rates. On December 31, 1974, the banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$1.18 and US$1.16, respectively, per Le 1. Sierra Leone avails itself of wider margins. Administration of Control Exchange control policy is made by the M in is try of Finance. The day-to-day administration of exchange control is carried out by the Bank of Sierra Leone. Authorized commercial banks are permitted to sell ex- change for permitted imports and, in small amounts, for travel expenses. The Bank of Sierra Leone has power to direct payments into Blocked Accounts. Im- port and export licenses are issued by the M in is try of Trade and Indus t ry. Prescription of Currency Sierra Leone has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Transactions with Sterling Area countries as well as non-Sterling Area countries are subject to exchange control. Sierra Leone's regulations define the Sterling Area so as to include Sierra Leone and to exclude South Africa. Settlements with other Sterling Area countries usually are made in sterling or other Sterling Area currencies. Certain settlements with the People's Republic of China must be channeled through clearing accounts established under the terms of a bilateral payments agreement.1 Authorized pay- ments to countries outside the Sterling Area other than the People's Republic of China and Rhodesia, includ- ing payments for imports, may be made in leones to the credit of an External Account in Sierra Leone, in ster- ling to the credit of an External Account in the United Kingdom, or in any other foreign currency2 except Rhodesian currency. Receipts from exports to non-Sterling Area countries other than the People's Republic of China and Rhodesia may be obtained in sterling from an External Account in the United King- dom, in leones from an External Account in Sierra Leone, or in any specified currency3 other than a cur- rency of the Sterling Area. Receipts from exports to Sterling Area countries may be obtained in leones from a Sterling Area Account or in any currency of the Sterling Area other than leones. Settlements with Rho- desia and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in leones held with authorized banks in Sierra Leone by residents of countries outside Sierra Leone other than residents of Rhodesia may be desig- nated External Accounts. Residents of Sterling Area countries may maintain Sterling Area Accounts de- nominated in leones. Rhodesian Accounts are accounts with banks in Sierra Leone conducted in the name of persons resident in Rhodesia. In addition, there are Blocked Accounts, to which are credited amounts that may not be remitted abroad and that are due to nonres- idents. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Af- rica are prohibited. Certain commodities4 from any source require individual import licenses. All other im- ports may be made freely under open general license from virtually any source.5 Foreign exchange is granted for all permitted imports, but not for insurance on imported goods. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to nonresidents require ap- proval, which for most current transactions is given freely. Insurance on imported goods must be taken out with insurance companies incorporated in Sierre Leone. For travel abroad, residents are entitled to a basic exchange allowance of Le 500 a calendar year. Applica- tions for larger amounts are considered on an individ- ual basis. In addition to the basic exchange allowance travelers may take out, regardless of destination, Le 20 in leone notes and the equivalent of Le 50 in foreign currency notes. Nonresident travelers may take out for- eign currency banknotes, including sterling notes, de- clared by them when entering Sierra Leone. Exports and Export Proceeds Except for a few commodities sold to certain destina- tions, exports require individual export licenses. Ex- ports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. The proceeds in specified curriences3 of ex- ports other than diamonds to countries outside the Sterling Area must be sold to an authorized bank in Sierra Leone within six months from the date of export, unless permission to do otherwise is obtained. By virtue of Public Notice No. 74 of December 7, 1972, the pro- ceeds from exports of diamonds must be obtained in a 411 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SIERRA LEONE specified currency or in a currency that is freely con- vertible into leones by the country of the purchaser, and must be sold to authorized banks in Sierra Leone. The buying and exporting of diamonds is carried out by five appointed firms. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified curriencies3 must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Subject to declaration upon entry, persons entering Sierra Le- one may bring in any amount of foreign banknotes. The importation of domestic banknotes is limited to Le 20 per traveler. Capital Capital payments to nonresidents of Sierra Leone are subject to exchange control. Residents of Sierra Leone require permission from the Bank of Sierra Leone to purchase foreign currency securities or real estate situ- ated outside Sierra Leone. Investments by nonresidents other than residents of Rhodesia may be repatriated at any time, together with profits, provided that exchange control permission was obtained initially for the invest- ment. The Sierra Leone Exchange Control Act of 1954 imposes control on the issue and transfer of securities. The placing of an issue in Sierra Leone requires permis- sion if either the person acquiring the securities or the person for whom he is nominee is resident outside Si- erra Leone. Permission must also be obtained before a security registered in Sierra Leone may be transferred to a person resident outside Sierra Leone. Capital in respect of securities registered in Sierra Leone may not be transferred outside Sierra Leone without permission. Where permission has been given for securities regis- tered in Sierra Leone to be sold to persons resident outside Sierra Leone, the company is usually required to obtain bank certification of the funds brought into Sierra Leone to ensure that permission will not be given later for taking out appreciably more than was brought in. The Development Ordinance of 1960 provides for income tax and customs du ty concessions to foreign and domestic companies undertaking industrial or agri- cultural activities that are needed for the development of the country. Noncitizens are prohibited from owning or controlling certain types of business. By virtue of Public Notice No. 50 of October 11, 1974 residents of Sierra Leone must sell to an autho- rized dealer in Sierra Leone their holdings of gold and specified currency. Exemption is made for authorized dealers, diplomats, and those exempt sterling assets held prior to June 24, 1972 for which exemption has been claimed and granted by the Bank of Sierra Leone. Exempted securities may be sold outside the Sterling Area and any income therefrom may be retained in the Sterling Area or reinvested in other Sterling Area secu- rities. Any certificate of security purchased with the proceeds of the sale of securities exempted under this 412 permission is exempt from deposit requirements. Any assets held outside the Sterling Area by any foreign national temporarily resident in Sierra Leone also are exempt from surrender and deposit requirements, pro- vided exemption has been claimed and granted by an authorized dealer or by the Bank of Sierra Leone. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Sierra Leone for numismatic purposes. Also, residents and nonresidents may freely purchase, hold, sell, or export certain Sierra Leonean gold coins issued for commemorative purposes. With these exceptions, residents other than the monetary authorities, gold pro- ducers, and authorized industrial users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal ef- fects of a traveler require individual import licenses. Exports of gold in any form require licenses issued by the Chief Inspector of Mines; such licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and local gold producers. Travelers, however, do not require a license to take out personal jewelry if the value of the total gold and plati- num content does not exceed Le 200. Exports of un- worked gold are not subject to export tax. Changes during 1974 January 1. Foreign exchange no longer was made available for insurance of imported goods. This action was taken in implementation of the Insurance (Amend- ment) Act, 1973, gazetted on October 16, 1973, which provided that insurance on imported goods must be taken out in Sierra Leone. February 28. Government Notice No. 206 an- nounced that with effect from April 15 the Comptroller of Customs and Excise would not enter goods imported unless they had been insured with insurance companies incorporated in Sierra Leone. March 15. The Government Diamond Office ceased to be the sole official agency entrusted with the buying and exporting of diamonds. May 8. Government Notice No. 509 abolished with effect from June 1 the import monopoly of the National Trading Company for a number of foodstuffs, includ- ing cooking oil, corned beef, refined sugar, tea, and coffee. Any importer could now import these goods without a specific license. June 28. The Budget Speech included a proposal for legislation which would introduce a 5 per cent tax on foreign travel tickets purchased by residents. The tax was not enacted in 1974. September 12. Government Notice No. 929 was pub- lished containing the general import license for 1975. It was amended by Government Notice No. 1086 pub- lished on October 31. The general license was applica- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ble also to the People's Republic of China, Hungary, and Romania. October 11. The Exchange Control (Surrender of Gold and Specified Currency) (No. 2) Order, 1974 (Government Notice No. 50) was published. It amended the regulations introduced by Public Notice No. 71 of December 4, 1972. November 1. The importation of domestic banknotes by travelers, previously unrestricted, was limited to Le 20 a person. November 14. The Exchange Control (Diamond and Other Mineral Export Payments) Order, 1974 (Gov- ernment Notice No. 57) was published. It required the proceeds of the sale of diamonds or any other minerals mined in and exported from Sierra Leone to be received by the vendors in the currency of the importing country or any other specified currency through the account of the Bank of Sierra Leone in the importing country, notified to them by the Bank of Sierra Leone. The Order was to come into effect on January 1, 1975. Not for Redistribution SINGAPORE (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.290299 gram of fine gold per Singapore Dollar, and Singapore avails itself of wider margins. Since June 20, 1973, however, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate within an- nounced margins, and therefore all transactions other than those in Brunei currency take place at a fluctuat- ing exchange rate. The closing selling and buying rates in the Singapore foreign exchange market for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were SS2.3110 and SS2.3115 per US$1, respectively, for telegraphic trans- fers. The authorized banks are free to deal spot and for- ward in all currencies. Forward cover for periods in excess of six months in respect of import or export transactions requires the prior approval of the Mone- tary Authority of Singapore, as does all forward cover on transactions of residents in the Asian currency mar- ket. Singapore and Brunei currency notes and coins are freely interchangeable, at par and without charge, in the two countries concerned, at the commercial banks and with the monetary authorities. Singapore formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from November 9, 1968. Administration of Control The Monetary Authority of Singapore administers exchange control. Much of the authority for approving normal current payments is delegated to commercial banks authorized for this purpose. The Trade Division of the Ministry of Finance administers import and ex- port controls. Prescription of Currency Singapore has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Singapore has made no changes in the list of Scheduled Territories (covering Singapore and all other Sterling Area territories) which appears in the first schedule to the Singapore Exchange Control Act. All payments to and from the Scheduled Territories may be made in either a Scheduled Territory currency or a specified currency.1 Certain payments to Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R. must be made through spe- cial accounts.2 Payments to other countries outside the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesia may be made in Singapore dollars or another currency of the Scheduled Territories through an External Account, or in any non-Scheduled Territory currency other than Rhode- sian currency. Receipts from exports to other countries 414 outside the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesia must be obtained in either Singapore dollars or another cur- rency of the Scheduled Territories through an External Account, or in any specified currency. Special regula- tions apply to settlements with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts The accounts of residents of other Scheduled Territo- ries are treated as resident accounts. The accounts of residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories are treated as nonresident accounts and, unless spe- cially restricted, are designated External Accounts. Ex- ternal Accounts may be credited with the proceeds of any non-Scheduled Territory currency, other than Rhodesian currency, sold to a bank in Singapore, with transfers of Singapore dollars or sterling from other External Accounts, and with funds eligible for transfer to countries outside the Scheduled Territories. Balances on External Accounts may be transferred to any other account, whether resident or nonresident, and may be converted into any non-Scheduled Territory currency other than Rhodesian currency. Accounts of residents of Rhodesia are designated Rhodesian Accounts. All debits and credits to such accounts require prior ap- proval. Imports and Import Payments Virtually all imports are permitted freely under open general license or specific licenses depending on the nature and origin of the goods. A few imports are controlled for health or security reasons. All imports originating in Rhodesia, South Africa, or any territory administered by either are prohibited. Specific licenses are required for (1) rice (excluding bran), irrespective of origin; (2) certain manufactured products, when origi- nating in Japan; and (3) all goods originating in, wholly or mainly manufactured in, or consigned from Albania, the People's Republic of China, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, the Mongolian Peo- ple's Republic, and North Viet-Nam. License applica- tions for goods under (3) must be submitted through the intermediary of Intraco Ltd., which levies a sur- charge of 0.5 per cent on the c.i.f. value of imports from these countries. Permission to make payments for permitted imports is readily given, provided that the prescription of cur- rency regulations are observed. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of the Scheduled Territories may be made freely. Payments related to commercial transactions and personal payments of a current nature to other countries, except Rhodesia, are also permitted freely. Authorized banks are permitted ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution to approve applications for payments in respect of many categories of current invisibles, either without limitation or up to established limits. Applications for payments in excess of these limits, or for purposes for which no delegation of authority has been granted, are approved by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, provided that no unauthorized capital outflow is in- volved. There are no restrictions on the amount of foreign exchange made available for travel abroad; there is a basic foreign exchange allowance equivalent to S$l 0,000 a person a year for travel outside the Sched- uled Territories and amounts in excess of this figure are allowed on application. Remittances to nonresidents of dividends, interest, and agreed profits on all bona fide investments are subject to exchange control approval, which is given freely. Unless special permission is ob- tained, not more than S$ 1,000 in Singapore notes and the equivalent of S$2,000 in foreign currency notes and Scheduled Territory banknotes (other than those of Singapore, Malaysia, and Brunei) may be taken out of Singapore by travelers; there is no restriction on the amount of Singapore notes, Malaysian and Brunei cur- rency notes, and currency notes issued by the Board of Commissioners of Currency, Malaya and British Bor- neo, that may be taken out of Singapore by travelers going direct to Brunei or Malaysia. Travelers visiting Singapore may take out any amount of foreign currency notes and Scheduled Territory banknotes (other than those of Singapore, Malaysia, and Brunei) that was declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports of certain textiles to Canada, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, the United Kingdom, and the United States are subject to quantitative restriction, as are exports of transistor radios to member countries of the EEC. All exports of copra, scrap metal, steel bars, cement, rice, and a few other items are restricted. Other commodities do not require an export license. Exchange control approval is required only for exports exceeding S$20,000 in value to countries outside the Scheduled Territories; this re- quirement serves to ensure that the proceeds are ob- tained in accordance with the provisions of the Exchange Control Act and are sold to an authorized bank, normally within six months of shipment. Export proceeds up to S$3 million for each recipient in speci- fied currencies may, however, be retained and may be used to make commercial current payments and any other approved payments to residents and nonresidents of Singapore. Proceeds from Invisibles The exchange control requirements governing ex- change receipts from invisibles are, in general, the same as those for export proceeds, including the facility for the retention and use of up to S$3 million in specified SINGAPORE currencies for each recipient. Travelers coming direct from Brunei or Malaysia may bring in any amount in Singapore notes, Malaysian and Brunei currency notes, and currency notes issued by the Board of Commission- ers of Currency, Malaya and British Borneo, and other travelers may bring in such currency notes up to the equivalent of S$ 1,000; otherwise, permission is required for the import of Singapore, Malaysian, and Brunei currency notes. Permission is also required for the im- port of currency notes of India in excess of Rs 270 and of Indonesia in excess of Rp 3,000. No limitations are imposed on the import of currency notes of other countries. Capital There are no restrictions on capital transfers to and from other countries in the Scheduled Territories. Capi- tal transfers from Singapore to countries outside the Scheduled Territories require exchange control ap- proval. Inward transfers of capital from such countries (with the exception of borrowing in non-Scheduled Ter- ritory currencies) do not require approval and the sub- sequent utilization of nonresident-owned funds in Singapore for investment purposes also is exempt from individual exchange control approval; however, gov- ernment approval is required for investment in residen- tial property and in any vacant land other than land already designated prior to September 11, 1973 for in- dustrial or commercial use.3 Investment by residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia in Singapore stocks and bonds, whether quoted or not, is freely permitted in any currency, in- cluding Singapore dollars from an External Account. Proceeds from sales of Singapore securities held in Singapore and of other investments may be freely repa- triated by residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories; the approval authority for such transfers has been delegated to authorized banks. Borrowing from local banks by nonresident-controlled companies is not restricted. Investments by Singapore residents in countries out- side the Scheduled Territories normally may be made only upon approval of the exchange control authorities; however, residents are permitted to invest up to certain prescribed limits in securities denominated in specified currencies or in deposits in specified currencies with authorized banks or with Asian Currency Units. The exchange allowance for cash gifts and personal loans by individuals is S$30,000 a remitter a calendar year. Singapore banks that have been licensed to operate an Asian Currency Unit, and thus to operate in the Asian dollar market, may freely accept deposits in spec- ified currencies and Scheduled Territory currency from an External Account from nonresidents of Singapore; banks require individual exchange control approval for corresponding borrowing or lending transactions with residents of Singapore. All transactions must be con- ducted over accounts held in the Asian Currency Units 415 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SINGAPORE of the banks concerned. Borrowing in the Asian dollar market by resident exporters to finance outstanding export bills is in practice unrestricted. Gold There is a free gold market in Singapore, to which residents and nonresidents have free access; settlements between residents and nonresidents must take place in a Scheduled Territory currency to an External Account or in any foreign currency, while receipts from nonresi- dents may be accepted in any currency or against debit to an External Account. Both resident and nonresident individuals and companies are permitted to import, hold, negotiate, and export gold freely; imports and exports require neither exchange control approval nor import or export licenses. A S$150 commemorative gold coin issued by the Board of Commissioners of Currency, Singapore, is legal tender; this coin is treated for exchange control purposes as local currency and its export and import is dealt with in the same way as that of Singapore currency notes. The price of gold used for the manufacture of orna- ments is fixed by the Singapore-Chinese Gold and Sil- ver Merchants Association. On December 31, 1974, this price was about S$560 per tael for 24-karat gold and S$510 per tael for 22-karat gold. Changes during 1974 January 1. Take-overs and mergers became subject to a nonstatutory Code on Take-Overs and Mergers, administered by the Securities Industry Council. March 5. The reserve requirement on the net foreign interbank liabilities of foreign and domestic banks es- tablished in Singapore was reduced from 5 per cent to zero per cent. April 26. An export licensing requirement was intro- duced for transistor radios for export to member countries of the EEC. May 31. The Price Control (Rice) Order, 1974 came into effect. No one was allowed to import or export rice, or carry on any wholesale business in rice, without a license issued by the Price Controller. June 12. Unless otherwise specified, the value date for spot exchange transactions henceforth was two working days after the transaction date. July 12. The Control of Exports (Licensing) Order, 1974 listed all goods subject to export licensing. July 12. The Control of Imports, Exports and Trans- shipments (Endorsement) Order, 1974 listed all goods subject to safety, health, or other control requirements for import, export, or transshipment. July 12. The Control of Imports (Licensing) Order, 1974 provided that henceforth specific import licenses were only required for the following: (1) rice (excluding rice bran), irrespective of origin; (2) certain manufac- tured products, when originating in or shipped from Japan; and (3) all products originating in or consigned from Albania, the People's Republic of China, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, the Mongolian People's Republic, or North Viet-Nam. As regards Japan, this measure removed the licensing re- quirement for 19 commodities or groups of commodi- ties. Among the items exempted from all sources were diamonds. December 27. Traders were informed that with effect from January 1, 1975 the special account arrangements for trade with the U.S.S.R. and Poland would cease, whereby 50 per cent of the proceeds of the import of goods of U.S.S.R. origin and 75 per cent of the pro- ceeds of the import of certain goods of Polish origin were to be used for the counter-import of goods manu- factured in Singapore. Not for Redistribution SOMALIA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.118193 gram of fine gold per Somali Shilling, corresponding to So. Sh. 6.23272 = US$1, and Somalia avails itself of wider margins. The Somali National Bank carries out exchange transac- tions in some of the "convertible" currencies1 with au- thorized dealers at fixed rates, taking into consideration those in leading exchange markets in Europe; on De- cember 31, 1974, the Bank's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were So. Sh. 6.2327 and So. Sh. 6.3573, unchanged since 1973. The exchange mar- ket in Somalia comprises the Somali National Bank and the commercial banks, operating as authorized ex- change dealers in respect of transactions in foreign cur- rencies. There is a foreign exchange commission (including banking commission) of 0.7 per cent for all exchange transactions other than purchases and sales of banknotes. Authorized exchange dealers generally do not conduct forward exchange transactions on be- half of the public, although this is not prohibited. Administration of Control The Ministry of Commerce is the principal govern- ment agency concerned with the implementation and operation of trade and exchange controls. It has been given the authority to regulate and control all foreign economic transactions and to establish policy for the licensing of imports, exports, and exchange. The So- mali National Bank is authorized to determine the rates at which foreign currencies are to be negotiated, to establish a list of "convertible" currencies,1 and to ap- point authorized exchange dealers. The two commer- cial banks have been appointed as authorized exchange dealers. The National Bank may also implement the trade and exchange controls on behalf of the Ministry of Commerce. An Advisory Commission, consisting of nine members, representing various ministries, the So- mali National Bank, the Customs Authority, and the police, advises the Ministry of Commerce on policy questions relating to the regulations and control of foreign economic transactions. The National and Local Licensing Committees, usually consisting of members representing the Ministry of Commerce, the Ministry of Finance, the Somali National Bank, the Customs Au- thority, and the police, decide on applications for li- censes for imports and exports and for transfers in respect of services. The Somali National Bank grants licenses for certain routine invisibles. Transfers in re- spect of capital are authorized by the National Licens- ing Committee in Mogadiscio, unless they are governed by the provisions of Law No. 10 of February 18, 1960 on foreign investments, as extended and amended by Decree-Law No. 3 of March 3, 1968 and Law No. 17 of June 15, 1968. Prescription of Currency Settlements with the People's Republic of China and the U.S.S.R. are made through bilateral clearing ac- counts denominated in pounds sterling. Settlements with Egypt must be made mostly in convertible curren- cies; 50 per cent of payments for imports from Egypt and all payments for invisibles to Egypt other than those for Suez Canal dues are to be debited to Somalia's creditor balance resulting from the terminated pay- ments agreement with that country; other payments normally are channeled through special accounts de- nominated in sterling. Settlements with all other countries must be made in Somali shillings or in "con- vertible" currencies;1 however, residents are not per- mitted to make settlements with Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts in Somali shillings or in "con- vertible" currencies may be opened with authorized exchange dealers by Somali nationals residing abroad and deriving income only from sources outside Soma- lia; foreign nationals and foreign institutions enjoying diplomatic status in Somalia; foreign persons custom- arily resident abroad and companies whose head office is abroad, provided that they do not derive income (including export proceeds) from sources within Soma- lia; and by other physical or juridical persons individu- ally authorized by the Somali National Bank to maintain a nonresident account. Imports and Import Payments Imports of goods originating in or shipped from Is- rael, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohib- ited. The import of a few commodities from all sources is temporarily prohibited for balance of payments rea- sons.2 Individual licenses are required for all other commodities. Some of these commodities may be im- ported only from specified sources.3 The state trading organization (the National Agency for Trade, Ente Na- zionale per il Commercio or ENC) is responsible, inter alia, for the import and /or distribution of certain com- modities received under aid programs. It also is the sole agent for the importation of animal and vegetable oils and fats, rice, wheat flour, coffee, tea, sugar, pasta, and certain other commodities. The Somali Petroleum Agency is the sole importer of fuel and fuel products, batteries, and rubber tubes and tires. The Pharmaceuti- cal Agency is the only agency entitled to import medi- cines while the Agency for Construction Materials is the sole importer of construction materials. Certain other commodities also are imported by state agencies only. 417 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SOMALIA If goods imported differ in weight, quantity, or value by more than 10 per cent from the specifications in the import license, a new import license must be obtained. All imports other than those made by the Government, diplomatic and consular agencies, and international or- ganizations are subject to a statistical and administra- tive tax of 10 per cent. Payments for imports are authorized by the Somali National Bank or an authorized exchange dealer on the basis of the import license and other documentation relating to the import transaction (bills, bills of lading, shipping notices, etc.). Provided that the Somali Na- tional Bank or the authorized exchange dealer is satis- fied that the transaction meets the legal requirements, permission to make payment for imports is granted to the applicant not later than the third business day fol- lowing the receipt of the application or on such other subsequent day as may be specified by the applicant. The Somali National Bank or the authorized exchange dealer may also permit advance payments for imports (i.e., payment for merchandise not actually passed through customs at the time of payment) provided that documentary evidence of actual shipment is produced. Advance payments for imports without documentary evidence of actual shipment are not permitted. Pay- ments for imports from neighboring areas4 are permit- ted only by letter of credit and by cash against documentation. Payments for Invisibles Payments to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Payments for current invisibles are subject to licensing, mainly to prevent unauthorized capital movements; provided that balance of payments considerations permit, genuine requirements are met. Transfers of salaries, wages, gratuities, and allowances paid in Somalia to their foreign personnel by enter- prises registered under the Foreign Investment Law are normally allowed up to 50 per cent. The Somali Na- tional Bank may grant licenses for exchange for travel purposes up to specified limits. Applications for all other invisibles are considered on their merits by the Licensing Committees in Mogadiscio, Hargeisa, and Burao. For tourist travel by residents, there is an allow- ance of the equivalent of So. Sh. 1,000 a person a year, which is applicable to all countries, except Canada, Japan, and the United States; for these three countries, the allowance is So. Sh. 1,400 a person a year. Nonresident travelers may take out without authori- zation any foreign exchange which they brought in and up to So. Sh. 200 in Somali notes and coins. Resident travelers may take out without authorization So. Sh. 200 in Somali notes and coins and up to the equiva- lent of So. Sh. 200 in foreign banknotes and coins. A currency declaration is required by all persons leaving the country. 418 Exports and Export Proceeds Exports and re-exports to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. The export of a few commodities to any destination may be prohibited for reasons of public policy. An export license is required for all other commodities. Bananas are exported only by the Banana Marketing Board. The ENC is the sole agent for the exportation of incense, myrrh, gum ara- bic, and charcoal. The export of salt, dried fish, and hides and skins also is a public sector monopoly. All export proceeds must be repatriated, declared, and offered for sale to the Somali National Bank or to an authorized exchange dealer within five business days after their receipt. The Somali National Bank may ex- empt exporters from the surrender obligation in respect of their export proceeds. Where no banks are operating, an advance payment deposit of 50 per cent of the value of livestock exports and 15 per cent of the value of other exports is required. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be repatriated, de- clared, and offered for sale to the Somali National Bank or to an authorized dealer within five business days after their receipt. The Somali National Bank may grant exemptions from the surrender requirement. Nonresidents may bring in freely with them any amount in foreign exchange and up to So. Sh. 200 in Somali banknotes and coins; they must make a cur- rency declaration when entering the country. Resident travelers may bring in up to So. Sh. 200 in Somali banknotes and coins and are obliged, upon arrival, to declare and offer to surrender any foreign exchange or gold they bring in. Capital Payments to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Capital transactions are subject to licensing unless they are authorized by the Foreign Investment Law of February 1960 (as amended in March and June 1968). In accordance with the provi- sions of that law, foreign enterprises must be registered with the Ministry of Planning and Coordination. For "productive" enterprises (i.e., those that engage in irri- gation, improvement of land, establishment of facto- ries, construction of aqueducts, and testing, analyzing, and drilling activities in connection with oil and min- eral exploration), profits may be transferred abroad freely up to a limit of 15 per cent per annum of the capital invested; the unused portion of this transfer right is cumulative for three years. Should profits in any one year be less than 15 per cent, the transfer right for the succeeding three years is correspondingly increased. The capital itself may be transferred abroad beginning five years after the date of registration. Profits resulting from other foreign investments may be transferred abroad up to a limit of 10 per cent per annum of the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution capital invested, and the capital itself may be trans- ferred abroad over a minimum period of three years, beginning seven years after the date of registration. The Ministry of Finance, upon the recommendation of other ministries concerned, may extend total or par- tial exemption to any enterprise from import and ex- port taxes, excise duty, income tax, and municipal tax for a period not exceeding five years. For investments registered prior to March 1968, the fiscal exemptions may be granted for up to ten years. Enterprises regis- tered in or after March 1968 must, to the largest possi- ble extent, employ residents; a program for the substitution of resident employees for nonresidents is to be submitted, for the record, to the Committee on Foreign Investments. Gold Residents may hold and acquire in Somalia, for nu- mismatic purposes only, gold coins that are not legal tender in any country. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require permissions issued by the Somali Na- tional Bank; such permissions are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Gold im- SOMALIA ported by jewelers must be melted down to a fineness of not more than 22 karats within one month. Imports of gold are exempt from customs duty when originating in EEC countries and are subject to a 10 per cent duty when of other origin. Changes during 1974 May L All imports and exports were made subject to license. Imports of certain nonessential goods were restricted. August 1. Imports of butter, cheese, tomatoes, nonal- coholic beverages, ready-made clothing, textiles and related materials, electrical appliances and their parts, and small passenger automobiles were temporarily pro- hibited for balance of payments reasons. Not for Redistribution SOUTH AFRICA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.04550 grams of fine gold per South African Rand. However, no exchange transactions take place at the par value. South Africa has since June 24, 1974 followed an exchange rate policy of independent managed floating. As at December 31, 1974 the South African Reserve Bank quoted a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.4500 per R 1. Exchange rates are based on the Reserve Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar against rand and the London market rates for the currencies concerned against the U.S. dollar. The commercial banks' spot rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were US$1.4537 buying, and US$1.4464 selling, per R 1. Subject to certain limita- tions, authorized dealers are permitted to conduct for- ward exchange operations among themselves and with overseas banks. The Reserve Bank provides forward cover in U.S. dollars only; such cover is given to autho- rized dealers at a charge of 3 per cent per annum, for import transactions only. South Africa formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree- ment, as of September 15, 1973. Exchange Control Territory For purposes of control over transactions in securi- ties, residents of Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland are regarded as nonresidents. Otherwise, there are virtually no exchange or trade restrictions between the Republic of South Africa (defined for exchange control purposes as including South West Africa), Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland, and these are regarded as forming, with the Republic of South Africa, a single exchange control territory, the Rand Monetary Area. Administration of Control Import and export licenses are issued by the Director of Imports and Exports acting on behalf of the Secre- tary for Commerce. Exchange licensing is the responsi- bility of the Treasury, which has delegated this authority to the South African Reserve Bank; in turn, the Reserve Bank has delegated to the commercial banks much of its licensing power. Appropriate ex- change for licensed imports is made available by the authorized dealers upon presentation of suitable docu- mentary evidence. Prescription of Currency South Africa has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. All countries outside the Rand Mone- 420 tary Area constitute the Nonresident Area.1 Settle- ments within the Rand Monetary Area take place in rand only.2 Swazi banknotes and coins are convertible into rand at par without restriction, but they are not legal tender in South Africa. Settlements with residents of the Nonresident Area, except Rhodesia, may be made in rand to and from a nonresident account and in any specified currency3 and, for outgoing payments only, in any other foreign currency.4 Settlements with Rhodesia may be made in rand to and from a local Rhodesian or other nonresident account, in Rhodesian currency and, for inward payments only, in any speci- fied currency. Nonresident Accounts The rand accounts of residents outside the Rand Monetary Area are divided into Rhodesian Accounts, Nonresident Accounts, and Blocked Accounts. Rhodesian Accounts are held by persons, firms, or companies (including banks) resident, domiciled, or registered in Rhodesia. They may be credited with all authorized payments by South African residents, with the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South Africa of Rhodesian currency and of any specified cur- rency, and with payments from local Nonresident or Rhodesian Accounts. They may be debited for pay- ments for exports to Rhodesia and other payments due by Rhodesian residents to South African residents, for payments to the account holder while he is temporarily resident in South Africa for short periods, for payments to other local Rhodesian Accounts, and for the cost of purchases of Rhodesian currency. Nonresident Accounts are held by persons, firms, or companies (including banks) resident, domiciled, or registered outside Rhodesia and the Rand Monetary Area. They may be credited with all authorized pay- ments by South African residents, with the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South Africa of specified currency, and with payments from other Nonresident Accounts in South Africa. They may be debited for payments to South African residents for any purpose; for payments to nonresidents for any purpose, i.e., by transfer to a local Nonresident or Rhodesian Account or for remittance to any country outside the Rand Monetary Area; for the cost of purchases of any foreign currency; and for payments to the account holder while he is temporarily resident in South Africa for short periods. Blocked Accounts are held by nonresidents of South Africa and are subject to exchange control restrictions.6 They represent mainly the proceeds from sales of South African securities by a nonresident of South Af- rica to a resident. Such proceeds may not be transferred from South Africa or to another Blocked Account in South Africa, but may be retained on deposit with an ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution authorized dealer, used within certain limits for the holder's living expenses while visiting South Africa, or reinvested in securities which are quoted locally; such securities may be exported and sold abroad. If invested in government, municipal, or public utility bonds, but not the national savings certificate series issued from October 1, 1974, the proceeds on redemption at matu- rity are freely transferable to the nonresident owner, provided that he had held the securities for a continu- ous period of at least five years to redemption. Blocked rand may also be used to subscribe to a special issue, made available by the Government to nonresidents of South Africa only, of five-year transferable bonds of- fered by tender on a discount basis and repayable at face value in foreign currencies applicable to the domi- cile of the holder. In special cases, blocked rand may be used for direct investment in manufacturing enter- prises. Emigrants' assets that exceed the permissible transferable amount, and the proceeds of South African securities held by immigrants prior to their arrival in South Africa or acquired abroad within three years of their arrival, are also blocked, but favorable consider- ation is given to the release of such immigrants' funds, with the exception of funds of persons who had been South African residents (see section on Capital, below). Imports and Import Payments All importers of goods requiring import licenses must be registered with the Director of Imports and Exports. Most licenses allow the importation of a range of commodities, but they are, in general, to be used for goods as prescribed on the relevant import permit. Im- port licenses are valid for imports from any country. Imports free of license include (1) all goods imported from Botswana, Lesotho, or Swaziland and (2) all goods imported from Rhodesia, Malawi, and Zambia that were grown, produced, or manufactured in those countries. The Import Control Regulations for 1975, as an- nounced in December 1974, distinguish generally be- tween the following broad categories of imports: (1) Goods which may be imported without an import permit. This free list contains 483 tariff headings or subheadings and corresponds to some 25.3 per cent of 1974 imports. (2) Goods which may be imported only under permit but subject to automatic licensing for bona fide mer- chants and manufacturers. These fall under an unspeci- fied number of tariff headings or subheadings and correspond to 56.1 per cent of 1974 imports. (3) Goods which may be imported only under permit and for which global quotas are determined from time to time. These account for about 5.6 per cent of 1974 imports. (4) Goods which may be imported only under permit and for which specific permits authorizing the import of these goods individually are issued. They cover some 13.0 per cent of 1974 imports. SOUTH AFRICA Provided that licensing regulations are respected and upon presentation to his bank of the necessary consign- ment documents (proof of importation), an importer is automatically granted exchange to pay for the import. Payments for Invisibles There are no restrictions on payments and transfers for current international transactions. All payments to nonresidents of the Rand Monetary Area for current invisibles require exchange licenses. Authority is, how- ever, delegated to the commercial banks to approve certain payments without limitation and others up to established limits. For current income payments, such as declared dividends, profits, royalties, etc., that ac- crue in South Africa, approval is given by the autho- rized banks without reference to the Reserve Bank, provided that the relative royalty agreement was ap- proved by the Department of Industries and the Re- serve Bank and the profits or dividends to be remitted by nonresident-owned branches and subsidiaries are based on profits earned since December 31, 1959 and their remittance does not involve the use of local credit facilities. Favorable consideration is, however, given by the Reserve Bank to such transfers where the use of local credit facilities is not regarded as excessive. In- come derived from securities acquired with blocked funds or otherwise held by nonresidents is freely trans- ferable to the owner's country of residence. Limited amounts of exchange to pay for membership fees, fam- ily maintenance, etc., are authorized. The basic allow- ance for tourist travel in a year is R 2,000 for an adult and R 800 for a child under the age of 12. Separately, there is another annual basic exchange allocation of R 500 for an adult (R 200 for a child under 12) for travel to Malawi, Rhodesia, Zaire, Zambia, and Portu- guese East and West Africa. Applications for larger amounts are considered on their merits by the Reserve Bank. Residents leaving South Africa for destinations out- side the Rand Monetary Area may take out not more than the equivalent of R 200 in banknotes. South Afri- can Reserve Bank notes, however, may not exceed R 50 but are not regarded as being part of the basic travel allowance. Foreign visitors leaving South Africa within 12 months after arrival may take with them up to R 5Q in Reserve Bank notes and any amount of foreign notes which they brought into the country or obtained from the disposal of instruments of exchange that they brought to and exchanged in South Africa. These limitations on the export of Reserve Bank notes do not apply in the case of Bantu returning to neighbor- ing countries, who are permitted to take with them reasonable amounts in the form of banknotes repre- senting their earnings in South Africa. There are no limitations on the export of domestic currency to Bot- swana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. 421 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SOUTH AFRICA Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of commodities considered as being in rela- tively short supply, or for which domestic prices are substantially lower than those obtainable overseas, re- quire licenses irrespective of destination (with the ex- ception of exports to Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland). Certain other goods are controlled for stra- tegic reasons only, and permits are required for their export to all destinations but no import certificate is required where the goods are exported to the United Kingdom, any Commonwealth country, any British colony, protectorate, or trust territory, or the United States. The re-export of imported goods to countries outside the Rand Monetary Area is controlled to pre- vent commodity and exchange arbitrage. Unless otherwise permitted, all export proceeds must be surrendered within six months from the date of ship- ment and 30 days from the date of collection. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered within 30 days from the date of their acquisition, unless ex- emption is obtained. Upon entry from countries outside the Rand Monetary Area, residents and nonresidents may bring in R 50 in South African Reserve Bank notes. There are no limitations on the import of domes- tic currency from Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. Capital* Inward capital transfers require exchange control ap- proval; all inward loan transfers require specific ap- proval,7 while inward transfers in respect of equity capital are freely permitted. Foreign exchange accruing to residents from capital transfers and transactions must be surrendered. Outward transfers of capital by residents to destinations outside the Rand Monetary Area require the approval of the South African Reserve Bank and are usually not allowed; when falling under the Securities Control Notices, transfers to Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland also require prior approval. Local borrowing by nonresident-owned or nonresi- dent-controlled firms is subject to limitation. Transfers by residents for the purchase of South African (or other) shares on the external stock exchanges are gener- ally not permitted (except in amounts not exceeding R 2,000 for each shareholder, to allow South African residents to exercise rights arising from existing hold- ings of shares in foreign companies quoted only on foreign stock exchanges), although South African stockbrokers may engage in arbitrage transactions in securities, subject to certain conditions designed to pre- vent any net outflow of exchange. Applications by South African residents to retain in, or transfer to, neighboring territories (this term excludes Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland) funds for bona fide long-term investment in specific development projects or for the expansion of existing projects that are owned or con- 422 trolled by South Africans are considered by the South African Reserve Bank and the Treasury on their merits. For three years after their arrival in South Africa, immigrants (excluding former South African residents) may dispose of their foreign assets (including foreign cash funds) held outside the Rand Monetary Area or otherwise invest them (including by purchase of South African securities abroad). The proceeds from the sale of all South African securities brought in by immi- grants are blocked; the blocking is normally for at least three years, but the restriction may be removed freely (except for former South African residents) on amounts up to R 20,000 or, subject to Reserve Bank approval, on additional amounts, to enable the immigrant to set up a home and to meet current living expenses. The proceeds of the sale of South African securities by nonresidents of South Africa to residents must be credited to Blocked Accounts (see section on Nonresi- dent Accounts, above). The following payments related to nonresident capital may be carried out by the autho- rized banks without reference to the South African Re- serve Bank: transfers to nonresidents of South Africa of the proceeds on maturity of government, municipal, and public utility bonds and national savings certifi- cates (except those issued on October 1, 1974), pro- vided that they were registered in the name of the nonresident transferee (who was not an emigrant) on June 16, 1961, or, if the stocks were acquired after June 16, 1961, provided that they are registered contin- uously in the beneficial owner's name for a period of not less than five years to redemption; normal capital repayments to nonresidents of South Africa by certain "dying" mines in regular periodic installments not ex- ceeding in any one year 10 per cent of the nominal value per share; transfers to nonresident owners of any bal- ance of up to R 50 left over from the reinvestment of blocked funds; and transfers of up to R 20,000 to a nonresident beneficiary from the proceeds of legacies from estates in South Africa that hold no foreign assets. Emigrant families whose net assets do not exceed R 20,000 may h av eR 10,000 transferred outside South Africa as a settling-in allowance, and those with greater assets may have 50 per cent of their assets, up to R 30,000, transferred; any balance exceeding the per- missible transferable amount is blocked, and the value of any foreign assets is deducted from the applicable settling-in allowance. Emigrants may, however, utilize such blocked funds up to an amount of R 30,000 a family unit to subscribe to the five-year nonresident bonds issued by the Government on a tender basis (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). The South African Reserve Bank approves transfers of repayments at maturity to nonresident holders of mortgage bonds registered in their names on or before June 16, 1961. Favorable consideration is given for the transfer by nonresident-owned branches and subsidiar- ies of open or approved loan account balances or undis- tributed current profits, or for the transfer of any dividends by them, provided that the remittance does ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution not involve the use of local credit facilities. The physical export from South Africa of nonresident-owned securi- ties is permitted, except by emigrants in excess of their settling-in allowance. There are normally three ways in which holders of blocked rand (including holders resident in Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland) can repatriate funds from South Africa: (1) by tak ing up special nonresident bonds issued by the Government (see above) —these mature in f ive years, when the redemption proceeds may be w i thd rawn at the official rate; (2) by holding certain government, municipal, and public u t i l i ty bonds and national savings certificates (except those issued on October 1, 1974) for at least f ive years to redemption, when the proceeds can be transferred abroad at the official rate; and (3) by exporting South African shares bought on the Johannesburg stock ex- change, provided that they have been restrictively en- dorsed, and selling them outside South Africa at a price which may involve a premium or a discount on the South African quo ta t ion; on December 31, 1974, the corresponding discount on blocked rand was about 33.5 per cent. Gold Residents of South Africa may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in South Africa for numismatic pur- poses. With this exception, residents of South Africa other than the monetary authorities, authorized deal- ers, registered gold producers, and authorized indus- trial and professional users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. All exports of gold require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank; the approval authority has been delegated to authorized dealers in respect of exports of jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler (subject to a written declaration to the effect that the jewelry will be brought back to South Africa on the traveler's re turn) and in respect of exports of gold jewelry by manufac tur ing jewelers (subject, ex- cept for exports to Malawi, Rhodesia, and Zambia, to a written declaration that the articles are in fu l ly manu- factured form and that the gold content of each does not exceed 75 per cent of the selling price to the ulti- mate consignee). Furthermore, authorized dealers may without reference to the Reserve Bank allow residents to export for numismatic purposes currency coins, in- cluding gold coins, up to R 300 for each applicant during a calendar year. The gold-mining industry sells its output to the Reserve Bank, except for sales effected on the industry's behalf in the free market. The Mint f rom time to time strikes gold coins with- out a face value (Kruger rands) that are legal tender but do not circulate freely in South Africa as currency; these are made available in limited numbers to resident collectors, while the bulk is sold in other countries. Imports of gold are confined mainly to coins for numismatic purposes and to certain types of jewelry. SOUTH AFRICA Changes during 1974 January 16. New regulations were issued regarding the capital structure of foreign-controlled companies with exclusive prospecting rights in South Africa. Each such company was expected to secure the participation of a local company though it would not be obliged to make available a share of more than one quarter of the equity. April 26. An additional permit allocation of 40 per cent of total 1973 allocations was made for consumer goods, clothing, confectionery, and alcoholic bever- ages. (An initial allocation for 1974, equivalent to 60 per cent of total 1973 allocations, had been announced in November 1973.) Allocations were fu r ther increased to 120 per cent of the 1973 level on September 16. May 13. The exchange control regulations governing the concessions to immigrants and the settling-in al- lowance for emigrants were modified. The existing sys- tem, whereby all requests for concessions to immigrants and applications for settling-in allowances where total assets exceeded R 10,000 were laid before the exchange control authorities, was modified to the extent that authorized dealers were empowered to auto- matically grant concessions to immigrants and allow the release of up to R 20,000 of blocked funds. In addition, authorized dealers were permitted to grant settling-in allowances where total assets do not exceed R 60,000 in value. The purpose of these amendments was purely to ease the administrative burden on the exchange control authorities. May 13. Royalty agreements involving the local manufacture of goods henceforth had to be submitted to the Department of Industries instead of to the Re- serve Bank. May 14. The basic exchange allowance for business travel was increased to R 100 a day, with a maximum of R 3,000 during a calendar year. May 14. Import restrictions were fu r ther relaxed by the addition of a large number of items to the free list and the sh i f t ing of certain other items from the list of goods subject to specific permits to that of goods for which importers' fu ll reasonable requirements are li- censed. June 4. The Reserve Bank henceforth was prepared to consider favorab ly any application by local entrepre- neurs to borrow abroad for a period of not less than one year, where the applicant was unable to raise the credit from his local bank or the domestic capital market, and where such credit was necessary for manufacturing and other productive purposes, but not for property devel- opment. On August 20 the minimum maturity was re- duced to six months. June 5. A draft Financial Institutions Amendment Bill was gazetted. (An amended bill will be submitted to Parliament during the 1975 parliamentary session. Among other things, it will provide for the amendment of the Banks Act, 1965 to limit shareholding in banking institutions and bank controlling companies, and will 423 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SOUTH AFRICA also provide for the reduction in certain circumstances of the shareholdings of foreign banks in such institu- tions and companies.) June 24. South Africa discontinued the existing prac- tice of maintaining a fixed rate of exchange between the rand and the U.S. dollar for lengthy periods and, in- stead, adopted an exchange rate policy of independent managed floating. The par value of the rand remained unchanged. It was envisaged that the rate for the U.S. dollar would only be adjusted when necessary in the light of foreign or domestic developments and not nec- essarily every day, every week, or at regular intervals of any kind. Under the new policy, the monetary authori- ties would not necessarily peg the rand to any weighted average value of all other currencies. June 24. Until further notice, the Reserve Bank quoted public buying and selling rates for U.S. dollars of US$1.5037 and US$1.4962, respectively, based on a new middle rate of US$1.50 per rand, with the same total spread of V2 of 1 per cent as before. (Previously, the middle rate was US$1.49 per rand.) On August 13 the middle rate was changed to US$1.47; several fur- ther changes took place in 1974. July 31. The number of Kruger rand coins made available to the domestic market every month was re- duced to 4,800 in order to increase their availability for export. August 14. It was announced in the budget that ex- emption from nonresidents' withholding tax on interest could be granted in respect of borrowing abroad for deserving projects. August 20. The Reserve Bank's commission charge in respect of foreign exchange purchased forward for the payment of imports was raised from 1 per cent to 2 per cent per annum. On September 5 it was fur ther in- creased to 3 per cent per annum. August 20. The Reserve Bank was prepared to favor- ably consider applications for forward exchange cover in excess of six months in respect of extended foreign credit granted to local importers of capital goods. September 2. Forward exchange cover for imports and exports was only granted to the parties concerned within seven days of their entering into the underlying foreign exchange transaction. September 5. Authorized dealers were informed that as from September 6, Swaziland would be issuing its own banknotes and coins, called emalangeni and cents, which would be convertible into rand at the Monetary Authority of Swaziland. The emalangeni would be at par with the rand but would not be legal tender in South Africa. Authorized dealers in South Africa could freely exchange emalangeni notes for rand notes at the Monetary Authority of Swaziland, at par, but subject to a normal handling charge. Authorized dealers also were informed that checks and other bills of exchange drawn by Swazi residents for payment in South Africa, Botswana, and Lesotho, must be denominated in rand; checks issued in emalangeni could only be accepted on a collection basis. 424 September 6. Botswana withdrew from the negotia- tions with South Africa, Lesotho, and Swaziland con- cerning an extension and revision of the Rand Monetary Area arrangements. Past arrangements would basically continue, however, until Botswana's central bank started operations. October 1. Blocked rand could be invested in three-year National Savings Certificates (Sixth Series) issued on October 1, 1974. On November 26 autho- rized dealers were advised that the proceeds on matu- rity of these certificates were not eligible for transfer to the nonresident holder. October 8. Blocked rand henceforth could also be utilized in respect of option money payable by nonresi- dent purchasers of a call. October 18. Exports of groundnut oil, sunflower-seed oil, cotton seeds, and cottonseed oil were prohibited, except under license. Licenses were not normally granted. November 22. The exchange allowances for travel to neighboring territories were increased from R 350 to R 500 during a calendar year for an adult and from R 150 to R 200 for a child. December 4. A further relaxation of import restric- tions was announced, to become effective on January 1, 1975. It provided for the transfer to the free list of 34 groups or classes of commodities that were subject to permit control, and for the transfer of 20 types of com- modities in paragraph 4 of the import control meas- ures, the importation of which was strictly limited, to paragraph 2, which implied that these goods would be licensed to meet the full reasonable requirements of importers. Furthermore, importers were given an ad- vance allocation for 1975 of 40 per cent of the total permits issued during 1974 for consumer goods, cloth- ing, confectionery, and alcoholic beverages. December 5. Agreement was reached with Lesotho and Swaziland concerning a formalization of, and cer- tain changes in, the existing Rand Monetary Area ar- rangements. Lesotho and Swaziland would have free access to the South African capital market. The Rand Monetary Area Agreement came into force on Decem- ber 5.
