SOUTH AFRICA 425 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0126953 gram of f ine gold per Spanish Peseta. Spain avails itself of wider margins. The official in terven t ion limits for the U.S. dollar have been suspended since January 22, 1974. The official buy ing and selling rates of the Bank of Spain on De- cember 30, 1974 were Ptas 56.027 and Ptas 56.197 per US$1. Official buying and selling rates for specified curren- cies 1 are fixed daily by the Bank of Spain acting in consultation with the authorized banks. Purchases and sales of clearing currencies are centralized in the Bank of Spain, which publishes the rates at which it settles the transactions it carries out direct. These rates are the same as the prevailing rates for the U.S. dollar. The Bank of Spain also quotes buying and selling rates for banknotes in specified foreign currencies on a weekly basis. Authorized banks are allowed to operate in foreign marke ts for spot transactions and forward transactions related to commercial transactions for up to 360 days; forward transactions with customers are restricted to currencies admitted to the Madrid foreign exchange market and to permitted import and export transac- tions with a ma tu r i ty up to 360 days. Exchange Control Territory The Peninsular Territories of the Spanish State, the Canary Islands, the Balearic Islands, Ceuta, Melilla, and Spanish Sahara constitute a single exchange con- trol territory. Administration of Control The guidelines on foreign exchange policy are formu- lated by an interministerial commission. The Ministry of Commerce is in charge of all administrative func- tions connected with the exchange control. The Bank of Spain is in charge of the operative functions (basi- cally, the handling of the external reserves). It is also responsible for the authorization of foreign currency loans to residents for nontrade purposes. Trade controls are administered by the Ministry of Commerce. This Ministry also is in charge of the con- trols over Spanish investment abroad, private Spanish lending abroad, foreign financing of trade, and the reg- istration of foreign investments in Spain. Technology contracts must be registered with the Ministry of In- dustry. Prescription of Currency Settlements on account of merchandise transactions and invisibles other than those with bilateral payments agreement countries may be made in any specified cur- 426 rency,1 but in practice they are usually made in the currency determined on the basis of the country of origin or destination. Settlements with bilateral pay- ments agreement countries2 are made through agree- ment accounts expressed in U.S. dollars. Nonresident Accounts There are six types of nonresident accounts: Foreign Accounts in Pesetas for Payments in Spain (A Ac- counts), Foreign Accounts in Convertible Pesetas (B Accounts), External Accounts in Internal Pesetas, Nonresident Accounts in Convertible Foreign Curren- cies, Bank Accounts in Pesetas with Andorra, and Emi- grants' Accounts. A Accounts may freely be credited with (1) the coun- tervalue in pesetas of convertible currencies sold on the Spanish foreign exchange market; (2) amounts trans- ferred from other A Accounts; (3) amounts transferred from B Accounts; and (4) any interest payable on the account concerned. These accounts may freely be deb- ited for (1) any payment in pesetas in favor of Spanish juridical persons and Spanish or foreign physical per- sons legally resident in Spain (including payments re- lating to foreign investment in Spain); and (2) transfers to other A Accounts. Debits for the purchase of foreign currency for remittance abroad are not permitted. B Accounts may freely be credited with (1) any peseta collections generated in Spain that under existing rules are transferable abroad under powers delegated to au- thorized banks; (2) amounts transferred from other B Accounts; and (3) any interest payable on the account concerned. The crediting of amounts originating from A Accounts is prohibited. B Accounts may be freely debited for (1) the countervalue in pesetas of foreign currency acquired on the Spanish foreign exchange market; (2) any payments in pesetas in favor of Spanish or foreign physical persons legally resident in Spain, including those relating to foreign investment in Spain; (3) transfers to other B Accounts; and (4) transfers to A Accounts. All other entries on A or B Accounts require the prior authorization of the Bank of Spain. Private banks are required to make special noninter- est-bearing deposits in cash at the Bank of Spain, in an amount equivalent to 100 per cent of the increases after October 18, 1971 in nonresident-held deposits in A and B Accounts (demand deposits, savings account deposits, or time deposits at less than three months' notice), and in an amount equivalent to 50 per cent of the increases in such deposits when held for three months or more (100 per cent of any increase after February 7, 1973). Furthermore, banks are prohibited from paying interest on any nonresident-held peseta deposits in A or B Accounts, whether demand, time, or savings deposits. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution External Accounts in Internal Pesetas are designed to hold funds accruing in Spain to nonresidents that are not transferable abroad ("blocked pesetas"). Balances are freely negotiable between nonresidents holding such accounts; if the recipient of pesetas does not hold an account of this type, he needs prior approval to open one. These accounts may be credited freely with (1) the full proceeds of the sale by a nonresident to a resident of Spanish real estate originally acquired with pesetas from an External Account in Internal Pesetas; (2) with receipts from the National Lottery (when no evidence is submitted that the ticket was acquired with foreign exchange); (3) with interest received on balances held in these accounts; and (4) with transfers from any other External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. They may be debited for (1) payments of personal expenses in Spain of the account holder and his close relatives (managers' personal expenses if the account is opened in the name of a juridical person); (2) the purchase of shares quoted on the stock exchange; (3) the purchase for the use of the account holder of urban and rural properties that do not represent investment for commercial, industrial, or agricultural purposes; (4) the purchase of National Lottery tickets; and (5) transfers to any other External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. All other entries on these accounts require prior authorization and the accounts may not be overdrawn.3 Nonresident Accounts in Convertible Foreign Curren- cies may be held by nonresident foreign nationals, non- resident Spanish nationals, and nonresident firms or banks; resident foreign nationals may maintain such accounts only if opened before January 1, 1968. The deposits may be either sight or time deposits. The ac- counts may be credited with convertible currencies quoted in the Spanish exchange market and with any amount of interest. They may be debited freely for reconversion into the currency initially deposited, for the purchase of other convertible currencies quoted in the Spanish exchange market, and for conversion into pesetas, including the transfers to an A Account or a B Account. Overdrafts are prohibited except for mail credits in favor of foreign banks. Emigrants9 Accounts—Since October 29, 1970, com- mercial banks have been authorized to open savings accounts in convertible pesetas for Spaniards working abroad. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Most im- ports are admitted under the following arrangements: (1) free imports, (2) global quotas, (3) state trading, and (4) individual licensing, also referred to as the "bilateral import regime." All imports require either an import license or an "import declaration" issued by the Direc- torate-General of Tariff Policy and Imports. Provided that import prices are not considered abnormal, import declarations are issued freely for a large number of goods (mostly foodstuffs not under state trading, raw SPAIN materials, capital goods, and spare parts, but also some consumer goods) included in an import free list that applies to most countries with which Spain has no bilat- eral payments agreements; the free list also applies to specified imports from Iran and Japan.4 All other im- ports require licenses. There are global quotas for specified imports from countries to which the free list applies, but licenses are usually granted for larger amounts.5 With certain ex- ceptions, the global quota regime also applies to goods of Japanese origin. Licenses for specified imports from Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R. are issued freely. Imports of raw cot- ton, certain other agricultural products, some raw ma- terials, petroleum products, and tobacco are state traded; some goods formally listed as being subject to state trading, such as feedgrains, may in fact be freely imported by private traders. Imports of certain agricul- tural products that are free of quantitative restriction and previously were state traded are subject to variable import levies. Import subsidies are paid on certain foodstuffs and specified other essential commodities. Exchange in the appropriate currency to pay for autho- rized imports is granted freely. Except for capital goods, suppliers' credit for imports is not normally permitted to exceed 90 days. All import transactions must be domiciled with an authorized bank, and the import payment must be made through the intermedi- ary of the bank of domiciliation; exempt from domicili- ation are transactions whose value is less than Ptas 500,000 provided that payment is to be made within one year. Payments for Invisibles All transfers abroad and payments by residents in favor of nonresidents on account of current invisibles are subject to authorization, for the purpose of check- ing capital transactions. Payments up to Ptas 5,000 for any purpose may be made freely. For a large proportion of invisibles, the banks are authorized to sell foreign exchange freely, provided that the request is supported by appropriate documents. For certain services, trans- fers may be made freely up to a pre-established amount; for transfers which exceed that amount licenses are required which are granted freely. Holders of Spanish securities (excluding securities issued by private companies and acquired through di- rect subscription) may freely transfer abroad accrued interest, dividends, and proceeds from the disposal of subscription rights; the securities must have been pur- chased with convertible pesetas, with pesetas resulting from the sale of foreign exchange quoted in the Spanish foreign exchange market, or with pesetas released on or after June 1, 1972 from External Accounts in Internal Pesetas.6 Profits and dividends on direct investments are also transferable abroad without restriction. Rents on nonresident-owned real estate are transferable, pro- vided the purchase price has been paid in full and the 427 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN owner has no outstanding tax liabilities applicable to the property concerned. A general license permits the reinsurance abroad of risks insured in Spain with Span- ish firms or w i th foreign insurance companies operating in Spain. Insurance contracts abroad may not be con- cluded, except where they concern exports and imports of goods. There is a basic tourist exchange allowance of Ptas 50,000 a person a year; however, amounts in ex- cess of this limit are approved free ly for bona fide tour- ist expenses. The authorized banks are also permitted to sell the equ iva lent of Ptas 2,000 a day for business trips, up to the equivalent of Ptas 100,000 a person for each trip. For larger amoun ts, the banks must apply for approva l, which is granted f ree ly for this purpose. Travelers may take w i th them Ptas 3,000 in notes of the Bank of Spain. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports are subject to prior licensing by the Di- rectorate-General of Exportation. Exports to all desti- nations of olives for oil production are suspended, while other types of olives may be exported freely. All export proceeds must be sold in the exchange market or to the Bank of Spain th rough authorized banks. Certain agricultural exports are subject to an export tax. Proceeds from In visibles All exchange proceeds f rom invisibles must be sold in the exchange market or to the Bank of Spain th rough authorized banks. Travelers may bring in a max imum of Ptas 50,000 in notes of the Bank of Spain. Capital Foreign capital participation in Spanish industries of up to 50 per cent of the capital of the enterprise is exempt from authorization, while investment that ex- ceeds 50 per cent requires the authorization of the Council of Ministers; for participation in Spanish ship- ping companies, or public service companies in general, the former ratio is 40 per cent or 25 per cent, respec- t ive ly .7 All foreign investment in a few specified indus- trial and agricultural sectors requires prior authorization by the Government. Foreign investment in Spanish companies manu fac tu r ing capital goods that are listed in the Appendix List of the Customs Code requires registration only; w i th in 30 days the registra- tion may be deemed authorization if no notification to the con t ra ry has been received. Foreign inves tment is not permitted in Spanish enterprises whose activity is directly connected w i th national defense, while invest- ment in firms dealing with public informa t ion and in certain public services is subject to specific regulations. Foreign investment for the purpose of modernizing, expanding, and establishing Spanish enterprises may be effected either by transferr ing currencies that are nego- 428 tiable in the Madrid exchange market, by using con- vertible pesetas, by bringing in capital goods, by rein- vesting prof i ts or capital transferable under the Foreign Investment Law, or by providing know-how, patents, or licenses. All technology contracts require prior regis- tra t ion w i th the M in is t ry of Indus t ry. Proceeds, including capital appreciation, from the l iqu ida t ion of foreign direct investments made for the purpose of establishing, modernizing, and expanding Spanish enterprises may be transferred freely. Purchases by nonresidents of shares in most Spanish companies are permitted free ly up to the percentages applicable to direct inves tmen t. This applies to shares acquired by Spaniards resident abroad, as well as by resident or nonresident foreigners, either with convert- ible pesetas or w i th pesetas resulting from the conver- sion of fore ign currencies negotiable in the Spanish exchange market. Proceeds, including capital gains, f rom the l iqu ida t ion of such shares may be transferred abroad at any time, or used for fu r ther purchases of shares. The above applies also to bonds and other fixed-income securities representing debts of Spanish companies; there is no limit on bond holdings. Inves tment in Spanish real estate by nonresidents is freely permitted if financed w i th pesetas derived f rom convertible currencies or from balances in nonresident peseta accounts (A or B Accounts). The Bank of Spain has empowered authorized banks to provide the inves- tor with a document certifying that he owns such pese- tas; this is the only requirement for official registration of the change in ownership. Certain investments in real estate may also be financed f rom External Accounts in In te rnal Pesetas. Irrespective of the method of financ- ing, rural properties purchased may not exceed 4 hec- tares of irrigated land or 20 hectares of unirrigated land. When Spanish real estate is sold to a resident, the fu ll sale proceeds are transferab le if the initial purchase was financed with convertible foreign currency or with pesetas f rom an External Account in Convertible Pese- tas, an A Account, or a B Account. If the initial pur- chase was financed w i th pesetas from External Accounts in In terna t ional Pesetas, no part of the sale proceeds is transferab le. Outward capital t rans fe rs by residents require ap- proval. Requests by firms to invest abroad in the same line of business are granted rather liberally, provided that the investment contributes to the expansion of Spanish exports; this includes participation in foreign enterprises. No authorization is required for such in- vestments when undertaken by Spanish enterprises with net assets in Spain of at least Ptas 100 million, provided that the f irm's total foreign investments do not exceed 40 per cent of its assets in Spain. Other direct investments are subject to more severe restric- tions. Portfolio investments by all residents and pur- chases of real estate abroad by private persons are severely restricted. However, registered investment funds with assets of at least Ptas 1 billion are permitted to place up to 10 per cent of their assets in foreign ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution securities that are officially quoted on specified stock exchanges abroad. Approval of requests by residents to grant loans to nonresidents is based on criteria similar to those ap- plied to residents' requests to make direct investments abroad. Suppliers' credits from Spanish residents to nonresidents require authorization by the Director- ate-General of Exportation; such authorization accom- panies the export license. There has been no experience with the issuing of bonds in the Spanish capital market by nonresidents, nor with short-term credits granted by Spanish banks to nonresidents other than certain export credit granted direct to foreign importers. Credits to nonresidents for transactions with Spain may, however, be authorized by the Ministry of Commerce. Also, the authorized banks may extend various types of credit to nonresi- dents, provided that this credit is financed with funds deposited in Spain in nonresident convertible currency accounts; some forms of such credit do not require prior approval by the Ministry of Commerce. Local borrowing at medium term or long term by Spanish firms with foreign participation in excess of 25 per cent is subject to special directives. For transfers abroad of bona fide inheritances and dowries, authorizations are granted liberally. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Spain for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. By law, only the Bank of Spain is allowed to import or export gold; industrial requirements are met by imports effected by the Bank of Spain. There is a global quota for imports of gold from member countries of the EEC. Changes during 1974 January 1. Settlements with the German Democratic Republic were placed on a convertible currency basis. Subsequently, the German Democratic Republic was included among the countries to which the import free list and the global import quotas are applicable. January 3. The global quotas for 1974 were pub- lished, totaling Ptas 16.8 billion. January 18. Decree No. 75 reduced most import duties by 5 per cent for three months. Exceptions were goods subject to import duties below 5 per cent, as well as certain textiles and petrochemicals on which duties had already been reduced or suspended. January 22. Spain ceased to observe, for the time being, the previously announced margins for the U.S. dollar, of Ptas 56.7237 buying, and Ptas 59.3350 sell- ing, per US$1. As a result, the peseta appreciated in terms of the U.S. dollar. February 28. Decree No. 677 extended to the auto- motive components industry the benefits available to SPAIN "preferential interest" industries, including tariff reduc- tions, tax remissions, and privileged access to official credit. March 8. It was announced that public sector bodies had been authorized to borrow abroad up to about Ptas 1 billion. March 11. Restrictions on imports of specified goods of Japanese origin were relaxed. March 18. The list of capital goods which could be imported at a concessional import duty rate of 5 per cent was amended with 41 additions, 11 extensions, and 4 deletions. The additions and extensions were generally valid for two years. The list was further modi- fied on several occasions in 1974. April 11. Decree No. 984 increased the across- the-board import duty reduction of Decree No. 75 from 5 per cent to 10 per cent and extended its validity to July 10. The exceptions were retained. May 30. Spain signed the OECD Declaration on Imports, Exports, and Other Current Account Trans- actions. June 17. The import of goods under 18 tariff head- ings (mainly rubber adhesives, certain intermediate silk products, certain jute products, bismuth, uranium, and domestic refrigerators) was liberalized by their transfer from the global quota list to the free import list. August 1. Bank of Spain Circular No. 3 of July 12 came into effect. It amended the regulations regarding accounts in convertible foreign currencies. Authorized banks could without prior approval by the Bank of Spain open accounts for sight and term deposits or deposits on prior notice, denominated in convertible currencies quoted on the Spanish foreign exchange market, on behalf of nonresidents, foreign companies (excluding their Spanish affiliates), and other autho- rized institutions. Holders of such accounts could oper- ate them freely. Without prior authorization by the Bank of Spain, the total amount of convertible currency deposits that banks could receive on such accounts was limited to twice the sum of paid-up capital and reserves; deposits at terms exceeding three years and deposits obtained from other Spanish banks were excluded from this ceiling. Authorized banks could freely use the for- eign exchange for deposits abroad, for loans to nonresi- dents, for deposits in Spain, or to finance the import and export operations for foreign currency loan re- quirements of resident customers. However, the amount in foreign currency loans that a Spanish bank could grant to nonresidents was limited to 5 per cent of its total deposits or to 20 per cent of the borrower's capital. Also, a bank's sight liabilities could be used only for sight lending, no more than 25 per cent of deposits at less than 12 months could be used for loans at over one year, and only 33 per cent of liabilities at one to three years could be lent at over three years. Foreign banks operating in Spain were exempt from these restrictions. 429 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN August 5. Decree No. 2177 extended the validity of the 10 per cent reduction in import duties until Octo- ber 10. August 12. A resolution of the Directorate-General of External Transactions of July 16 was published which introduced regulations for the granting of credit to foreign buyers of Spanish goods. (Earlier in the year, various arrangements relating to export credit, export subsidies, and export insurance had been revised by Decree-Laws Nos. 1837, 1838, and 1839.) October 10. The across-the-board tariff cut of 10 per cent expired. October 31. Decrees Nos. 3021 and 3022 consoli- dated the legislation and regulations relating to foreign direct investment in Spain. The degree of liberalization of inward direct investment remained essentially un- changed. A formula was provided by which the permit- ted foreign content of investments by Spanish companies with foreign participation (inversion de cas- cade^ could be determined. , October 31. Decree No. 3022 permitted the transfer abroad of capital gains realized on the sale of real estate investments which had been financed with pesetas from A or B Accounts; previously, such capital gains had to be credited to External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. Where the acquisition of the real estate had been made by means of a foreign monetary contribution, the fu ll market price was transferable, provided this price was not the result of speculative activity. Rentals could be transferred provided the purchase price had been paid in full and the owner had no outstanding tax liabilities applicable to the property concerned. October 31. Decree No. 3023 provided that prior au- thorization was no longer required for foreign majority investments in specified sectors of the economy. Within 30 days after registration of the investment, it could be deemed approved if no notification to the contrary had been received from the authorities. The decree limited this privilege to investments in firms whose sole pur- pose is the manufacture in Spain of capital goods listed in the Appendix List of the Customs Code. November 4. The import of goods under 55 tariff headings, which (by Resolutions of October 31, 1972 and June 5, 1973) had temporarily been classified as free imports, was deliberalized; these goods reverted to global quota status. Among the items affected were certain cosmetic products, certain plastic products, silk and silk remnants, carpets, coated textiles, ties, gloves, certain ceramic products, certain jewelry, lead, hand tools, domestic sewing machines, certain electronic products and accessories, arms and ammunition. November 12. Goods under 2 tariff headings were transferred from the import free list to the global quota list. However, the Sri Lanka rupee is pegged to sterling at the rate of SL Rs 15.60 = £ stg. 1 and the exchange ra te system for the t ime being is based on th is o f f ic ial ra te for s te r l ing. Ano ther e f fec t ive ra te of SL Rs 25.74 = £ stg. 1 arises f rom transac t ions in Foreign Exchange En t i t le- ment Certificates (henceforth called certificates), which exporters of non t rad i t ional exports (i.e., exports other than black tea, rubber, and major coconut products but inc lud ing green tea and in s tant tea) and most other earners or recipients of fore ign exchange are en t i t led to receive upon surrender of fo re ign exchange earned; on December 31, 1974 the corresponding exchange rate for the U.S. dollar was SL Rs 11.0354 = US$1. Non- resident travelers, when conve r t ing foreign exchange in to Sri Lanka rupees at the o f f ic ial rate, may also receive either corresponding certificates or the ir cash value in rupees. The certificates are denominated in Sri Lanka rupees and are issued w i th a face value equiva- lent at the official rate to the foreign exchange surren- dered; they are not transferab le and must be surrendered to authorized dealers w i th in 30 days of the date of issue for encashment at a price of SL Rs 65 per SL Rs 100 in certificates. Additional certificates are sold by commercial banks on behalf of the Central Bank of Ceylon upon demand and at the same price; such certificates also are not transferable. Certificates w i th a face value corresponding at the o f f ic ial ra te to the amount of fore ign exchange required must be sur- rendered when purchasing foreign exchange for pay- ments in respect of most imports and most invisibles. The commercial banks deal in certificates for up to four mon ths fo rwa rd, at SL Rs 66 selling, and SL Rs 64 buy ing, per SL Rs 100 certificate; transactions are per- mitted only when relating to anticipated genuine pay- men ts and receipts in foreign exchange to which the certificate requirements or privileges are applicable. The official exchange rate is applicable to receipts f rom major exports and to paymen ts for "A category" impor ts (rice, wheat f lou r, fertilizers, western pharma- ceuticals, and certain other imports classified as essen- tials), as well as some invisibles. The Central Bank deals in U.S. dollars, sterling, and Indian rupees on ly. While its rates for s ter l ing and the Indian rupee are fixed, the Central Bank determines exchange parities for some 20 other foreign currencies, inc lud ing the U.S. dollar, from time to time on the basis of London market rates for those currencies. Rates for other foreign currencies are determined by commercial banks, also on the basis of London ma rket rates. On December 31, 1974 the Central Bank's buy ing and sell- ing rates for the U.S. dollar were SL Rs 6.6870 and SL Rs 6.6875, respectively, per US$1. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Department of Exchange Control of the Central Bank of Ceylon as agent of the Government. A foreign exchange budget, inc lud ing an import program, is d rawn up annua l ly by the M in is t ry of P lann ing and Economic A f fa i rs. All remittances of foreign exchange in Sri Lanka must be made th rough commercial banks authorized to carry out operations in foreign currencies in accordance w i th the exchange control procedures prescribed by the Controller of Exchange. Remittances may also be made th rough post offices, under permits issued by the Con- tro l ler of Exchange. Licenses for some impor ts of the indus tr ial sector are issued by the Actual Users Divi- sion of the Ministry of Industries and Scientific Affa irs. Otherwise, import and export licensing is handled by the Controller of Impo r ts and Exports. Prescription of Currency Sri Lanka has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U .K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under cu r rent U .K. exchange con trol regulations con- t inues to be regarded as a coun t ry of the Overseas Sterling Area. Payments to countries that prior to June 23, 1972 were Scheduled Territories may continue to be made in the currencies of such countries, and receipts f rom such countries con t inue to be acceptable in the currencies of such countries. Settlements with ten countries with which Sri Lanka has bilateral paymen ts agreements1 and w i th Egypt must be made th rough the relevant special accounts. Payments in respect of trade with Pakistan also are effected through special accounts. Payments to all other countries except Rhodesia may be made by cred- i t ing sterling or Sri Lanka rupees to a sterling External Account or an External Rupee Account, or in the cur- rency of the creditor coun t ry. Furthermore, paymen ts for impor ts not or ig ina t ing in countries w i th which bilateral paymen ts agreements are in force (nor in Rho- desia) may be made in any foreign currency, i.e., any currency other than the Sri Lanka rupee. Receipts f rom all other countries except Rhodesia may be accepted in sterling or Sri Lanka rupees f rom a sterling External Account or an External Rupee Account, in any pre- scribed currency ,2 or in any other External Account Area currency marketable in the United Kingdom, i.e., freely exchangeable for sterling. Transactions involving deviations f rom the general procedures require the prior approval of the Controller of Exchange. Special procedures app ly to settlements w i th Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident Accounts may be held in Sri Lanka by banks, corporations, or persons residing abroad. 431 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SRI LANKA Transfers of balances in these accounts to sterling Ex- ternal Accounts or External Rupee Accounts require approval by the Controller of Exchange. Blocked Accounts are used for holding funds that may not be transferred abroad and that are owned by nonresidents, repatriates, and emigrants. Such funds, unless they originate from payments for imports, may be used in Sri Lanka for certain investments, subject to the prior approval of the Controller of Exchange. Pro- ceeds from the liquidation of such investments must be credited to Blocked Accounts. Also retained in Blocked Accounts is a proportion of local currency earnings, derived from the exhibition of foreign-owned films, if the takings exceed the amount specified in the import license; such retained funds may be used by the owner for certain specified purposes, including the making of films in Sri Lanka. Special Accounts may be maintained in Sri Lanka by nationals of Sri Lanka working abroad. Credits to the accounts are limited to the proceeds of remittances from abroad (inclusive of the value of the certificates to which the remittances entitle the holder) but the ac- counts may be freely debited for payments within Sri Lanka. Balances in such accounts are exempt from wealth tax, and income arising from investments made out of such balances with the approval of the Controller of Exchange is exempt from income tax; the value of such investments is also exempt from wealth tax. Imports and Import Payments All imports of goods originating in or shipped from Rhodesia are prohibited. Except for imports by the Food Commissioner's Department and certain minor imports (such as trade samples, gifts of up to SL Rs 250, and books up to certain specified amounts for each consignment), all imports require individual licenses. All trade imports are subject to quota restrictions. They are divided into two groups —the A category and the B category. Imports in the A category broadly comprise basic necessities, Western Pharmaceuticals, fertilizers, books and periodicals, and two-wheeled tractors. The B category includes all remaining im- ports. The value and composition of imports are estab- lished by an annual import program. Imports of many nonessential items or goods similar to locally produced items are either not permitted or considerably re- stricted. The right to import is restricted to government de- partments, government-sponsored corporations, and registered importers, although private individuals are allowed to import certain commodities for their own use, subject to special authorization. Imports of speci- fied commodities3 are restricted to government or state corporations, the Cooperative Wholesale Establish- ment, or the Lanka Salu Sala Ltd.; these commodities are referred to as "reserved items." In order to allocate foreign exchange, applicants for import licenses are di- 432 vided into three groups: (1) actual users of industrial raw materials, machinery, etc., (2) those who import other goods for their own use and not for resale, and (3) established importers who import goods for trading purposes. Public sector imports shipped or trans- shipped from places served by vessels of the Ceylon Shipping Corporation must be carried in vessels owned or chartered by the Corporation, whenever such ship- ping space is available. Holders of funds in Convertible Rupee Accounts may use these for certain imports, including items oth- erwise not permitted, subject to approval by the Con- troller of Imports and Exports and, in some cases, the Controller of Exchange. An authorized dealer may approve an application to remit foreign exchange or to credit a nonresident ac- count when the applicant furnishes or undertakes to furnish evidence of importation and the cost of the goods together with a valid importer's copy and an exchange control copy of the import license. Payment for imports in the B category requires, in addition to the rupee equivalent of the foreign exchange involved, surrender of certificates with a face value equal to the rupee payment; imports in the A category do not re- quire the surrender of certificates. Import licenses for certain imports (primarily food products, industrial raw materials, and machinery) are subject to a mini- mum deferred payment term. Letters of credit against such licenses may be opened provided that drafts are drawn payable either not earlier than 6 months after shipment or 12 mon ths or later after shipment, in ac- cordance with the terms of the import license. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require exchange control permission and, with certain exceptions, require surren- der of certificates corresponding to the full amount of the foreign payment. Exempt from surrender of certifi- cates are (1) expenditures for certain approved courses of study abroad; (2) remittances abroad by nonnation- als for family maintenance, up to certain limits; (3) provident fund contributions and life insurance premi- ums which commenced prior to the introduction on May 6, 1968 of the certificate scheme; (4) pensions and the final remittance, on retirement, of pension and provident funds, contributions to which commenced prior to May 6, 1968; (5) expenditures of foreign em- bassies, official international organizations, and foreign diplomatic personnel; and (6) other expenditures abroad specifically exempted from the certificate sur- render requirement by the Controller of Exchange. The remittance of life insurance premiums on policies in foreign currencies purchased by nonnationals resid- ing temporarily in Sri Lanka is permitted, and such policies are considered as part of the assets available to them on retirement. Foreign exchange for personal travel abroad is only granted for furloughs of nonnationals. Business travel ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution is generally limited to travel for the promotion of ex- ports and of tourism, and exchange up to a maximum of £ stg. 15 a day for persons of the rank of chairman or director of a firm or corporation and of £ stg. 10 a day for other executives for a maximum period of 30 days is allowed in such cases. Exchange for educational expenses is allocated only for certain courses of study that will be of positive value to the country and that are not available in Sri Lanka; allocations are subject to the approval of the Minister of Finance, acting on the personal recommendation of the Minister of Education. For study in educational institutions in "Asian group" countries,4 exchange up to a maximum of SL Rs 250 a month for undergradu- ate studies or up to SL Rs 450 a month for postgradu- ate studies is allowed, as well as SL Rs 250 a year for books plus actual fees. For study in the United King- dom, foreign exchange is made available at £ stg. 45 a month for undergraduate studies, and at £ stg. 60 a month for postgraduate studies, plus actual fees, and £ stg. 25 a year for the cost of books. Following the devaluation of the pound sterling in November 1967, students in countries whose currencies were not devalued were allowed supplementary remit- tances to enable them to receive the same amount as previously in the currency concerned. For study in such countries (other than the United States and Canada), the maximum allowable is £ stg. 53 a month for under- graduate studies and £ stg. 70 a month for postgradu- ate studies; the maximum for the United States and Canada is US$225 a month and US$240 a month for undergraduate and postgraduate studies, respectively (in addition to an annual book allowance and actual fees). For travel (and other expenses) for medical reasons, exchange is authorized if a certificate is produced from a medical specialist in Sri Lanka and supported by the Director of Health Services that equally effective treat- ment cannot be obtained in Sri Lanka; the amount authorized will depend on the estimated cost, as certi- fied by the specialist. Indian and Pakistani nationals are permitted to remit for family maintenance a maximum of SL Rs 750 a month or one third of their gross monthly income, whichever is less. Other foreign nationals are permitted to remit £ stg. 85 a month for a wife, £ stg. 105 for a boy in a senior school, £ stg. 100 for a girl in a senior school, £ stg. 75 for a child in a junior school, and £ stg. 25 for other children, up to a maximum of two thirds of the gross monthly income when dependents are direct ones. For other dependents, this ceiling is one third of the gross monthly income. When the amount claimed on this basis exceeds one third of the gross mon th ly income, the excess will be treated as an antici- patory transfer to be set off against the amount the repatriate is entitled to remit upon departure. Tempo- rary residents on short-term contracts are allowed to remit up to two thirds of their gross monthly income. SRI LANKA Nationals of Sri Lanka are not granted exchange for family remittances. Commissions up to 5 per cent of the c.i.f. value are allowed on export orders secured through agents abroad. No remittances for insurance on exports are permitted; these must be covered with the Insurance Corporation of Sri Lanka. Holders of funds in Convertible Rupee Accounts may use these funds for travel expenditures and other current invisibles, subject to approval by the Controller of Exchange. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign exchange declared to the customs at the time of entry; they may not take out Sri Lanka currency notes and coins. Resi- dents may Jake out foreign currency notes and coins not exceeding the equivalent of SL Rs 50 a person (SL Rs 25 for children under 12) once in 12 months, provided that they have been granted exchange for travel. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Permits is- sued by the Controller of Exchange are required for all commercial exports, and exports to countries with which Sri Lanka maintains bilateral payments agree- ments are subject to the approval of the Director of Commerce. Furthermore, most exports require an ex- port license issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports. Rubber exports to the People's Republic of China, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R. are under state trading. The State Gem Corporation has the ex- clusive right to export gems and exports of private exporters are made with the permission of the Corpora- tion; it also handles exports in the names of gem miners who wish to export gems through the Corporation. Re-exports of nonmonetary gold, silver, and diamonds are allowed only in special circumstances. The Controller of Exchange issues the permit for a commercial export when he is satisfied that payment representing fair value for the goods has been or will be received in Sri Lanka by approved methods of payment and, usually, within six months from the date of ship- ment. Foreigh exchange proceeds from exports must be surrendered. There are special arrangements, however, for gems and nontraditional exports. Exporters may maintain accounts, designated Convertible Rupee Ac- counts, with authorized dealers in Sri Lanka. These may be credited with 20 per cent of the f.o.b. Sri Lanka rupee value (inclusive of certificates) of the net export proceeds of gems, with 5 per cent of the f.o.b. value in Sri Lanka rupees (inclusive of certificates where appli- cable) of nontraditional exports, and with 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value in Sri Lanka rupees (inclusive of certificates) of net export proceeds of original and indi- vidual works of art by individuals. Debits to the ac- counts are permitted for imports, travel abroad, other payments which are not of a capital nature, and trans- fers to other Convertible Rupee Accounts. 433 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SRI LANKA Exporters of all goods other than black tea in bulk and in packets, rubber (excluding sponge rubber), co- conut oil, copra, desiccated coconut, and fresh coco- nuts are entitled to receive certificates with a face value in Sri Lanka rupees equal to the f.o.b. value of exports, upon surrender to an authorized bank of the foreign exchange actually earned. Exporters can use these cer- tificates as supporting documents when buying foreign exchange for payment of imports, or for other pay- ments abroad, which require the surrender of certifi- cates. Certificates have to be surrendered to the monetary authorities or to an authorized bank within 30 days of issue. The holders can use them when mak- ing foreign exchange payments within seven months from the date of issue; at the end of the seven-month period, the validity of the certificate lapses. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered. Receipts under the following headings en- title the recipient to obtain certificates with a face value equivalent to the value of the foreign exchange surren- dered to an authorized bank: (1) travel receipts; (2) insurance receipts; (3) investment income; (4) private transfers and donations; (5) small savings remitted to Sri Lanka by workers abroad;5 (6) miscellaneous other inward remittances as determined, on a case-by-case basis, by the Chief Accountant of the Central Bank. Nonresident travelers are eligible to receive certificates corresponding to the amount of foreign exchange con- verted with authorized dealers; alternatively, the latter may pay the traveler, in addition to the rupee equiva- lent of the foreign exchange sold, the cash value of the certificate. Part of the Sri Lanka rupee equivalent of certain proceeds from invisibles may be credited to Convertible Rupee Accounts; this proportion is 5 per cent of gross foreign exchange earnings from tourism, 20 per cent of foreign exchange earnings by individuals from the sale of their original and individual works of art to tourists in Sri Lanka and from the publication abroad of scien- tific and literary works, 20 per cent of foreign exchange earnings from professional and consultancy services performed abroad by individuals, and 5 per cent of the proceeds from such services performed by firms, com- panies, etc. A traveler entering Sri Lanka must declare his hold- ings, including currency notes and coins. The amount of foreign funds that may be carried into Sri Lanka in the form of travel credit instruments is not restricted. The import of Sri Lanka, Indian, and Pakistan currency is not permitted; however, Sri Lanka notes in denomi- nations of SL Rs 10 or less may be imported up to SL Rs 50, provided that evidence of prior export of such notes by the same traveler is produced. Other currency notes and coins may be taken in w i thout re- striction. 434 Capital Investments of foreign capital are permitted in projects which are specifically approved by the Gov- ernment, or, where the capital is drawn from a Blocked Account in Sri Lanka, in certain investments in Sri Lanka that have been approved by the Controller of Exchange, including shares of public companies incor- porated in Sri Lanka; capital transfers for direct invest- ment in Sri Lanka are entitled to receive certificates upon conversion of the foreign exchange into rupees. Proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments in approved projects other than investments made from Blocked Accounts may be repatriated, along with capi- tal appreciation; transfers require the surrender of cer- tificates. Proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments not approved by the Government may not be transferred abroad, but they may be reinvested with the approval of the Controller of Exchange; the current income thereon may be remitted abroad. New foreign investments in Sri Lanka that are con- sidered and approved by the Foreign Investment Advi- sory Committee of the Ministry of Planning and Economic Affairs are also granted special facilities in respect of remittances and taxation. Investments abroad by residents are not normally permitted. Resident-owned securities on which the principal, interest, or dividends are payable (either contractually or at the option of the holder) in any foreign currency must be declared to the Controller of Exchange, and the sale or transfer of such securities is allowed only with the permission of the Controller of Exchange. Emigrants are not permitted capital remittances ex- cept on grounds of dire hardship, nor generally, remit- tances of income (including pensions) accruing in Sri Lanka. However, certain remittances of income may be approved to persons over 55 who emigrated before June 26, 1973, and pension payments to persons pen- sioned by the Government of Sri Lanka who emigrated before 1964 have been continued without interruption. Repatriates leaving Sri Lanka for residence in the country of their permanent domicile are permitted, at the time of their departure, to transfer assets represent- ing their retirement funds and a reasonable amount of savings as determined by the Government from time to time. For persons who have been in business in Sri Lanka, the capital they originally brought into the country plus a reasonable amount of savings are al- lowed to be transferred, subject to certain limits. The transfer of personal assets and of income thereon re- quires the surrender of certificates; exempt are (1) bal- ances on provident and pension funds held abroad and representing contributions in respect of contractual ob- ligations entered into before May 6, 1968, (2) provi- dent and pension funds held in rupees in Sri Lanka, and (3) the value of insurance policies held abroad and taken out before May 6, 1968. Special provisions, gov- erned by an agreement between Sri Lanka and India, apply to Indian families returning to India. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Gold Imports and exports of gold in any form require licenses issued by the Controller of Imports and Ex- ports with the approval of the Central Bank. Such li- censes are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. The People's Bank is the sole importer of gold. It sells gold in small quantities to licensed craftsmen and jew- elers; the price charged at the end of 1973 was SL Rs 1,550 an ounce, i.e., the equivalent of US$231.75 an ounce (calculated at SL Rs 6.6881 per U.S. dollar). Small quantities are also sold to hospitals. Commercial imports of jewelry and of other articles containing gold are severely restricted. No credits to Convertible Rupee Accounts are allowed for the gold or silver content of commercial exports of jewelry. Changes during 1974 January 17. Not for Redistribution SUDAN (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.55187 grams of fine gold per Suda- nese Pound. The Sudanese pound is defined by law as having a gold content of 2.115368 grams of fine gold. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar is LSd 1 = US$2.87156. Fixed official rates for transac- tions in U.S. dollars are quoted by the Bank of Sudan (the central bank), whose rates for transactions with authorized banks and the Government on Decem- ber 31, 1974 were US$2.875877 buying, and US$2.867268 selling, per LSd 1. An effective exchange rate of LSd 1 = US$2.50 is applied to all exchange transactions other than the purchase of proceeds from exports of cotton and gum arabic, to which the ex- change rate of LSd 1 = US$2.87156 continues to ap- ply, as a result of the application of exchange taxes and subsidies of 5.18 piastres per U.S. dollar (i.e., 15 per cent) to the rate of LSd 1 = US$2.87. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Sudan, much of the detail being carried out by autho- rized banks. The issuance of registration forms and the licensing of imports and exports (except those of gold) are the responsibility of the Ministry of Finance and National Economy, but all registration forms and li- censes must be validated by the exchange control au- thorities (Bank of Sudan). Import payments and other foreign payments are approved within the framework of an annual foreign exchange budget that is drawn up by the Ministry of National Economy and approved by the Economic Council of the Cabinet. Prescription of Currency Transactions with bilateral countries1 are normally settled through the relevant bilateral account in Suda- nese pounds or pounds sterling; however, most non- commercial invisibles except those payable to Egypt2 have to be settled outside these accounts. Payments to all other countries and monetary areas (the "converti- ble area") may be made in Sudanese pounds to the credit of any nonresident account or in any foreign currency, while receipts from the "convertible area" may be accepted in Sudanese pounds from any nonresi- dent account or in any convertible currency. Nonresident Accounts Foreign diplomats are allowed to maintain accounts in Sudanese pounds designated as nonresident ac- counts. These accounts must be credited with convert- ible currencies. Other foreign personnel working in the Sudan under certain contracts, as well as foreign na- tionals residing in the Sudan, may maintain Deposit Accounts in Sudanese pounds. Blocked Accounts are maintained by former resi- dents; earnings accruing to these accounts may be used within the Sudan by the account holder for his personal expenses up to limits established in each case by the exchange control authorities. Except for the crediting of interest, all debits and credits to Blocked Accounts require approval. Imports and Import Payments Certain imports are prohibited for protective reasons and others are not being licensed. Imports from Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa also are prohib- ited. Permitted imports generally are licensed or ac- cepted for registration in accordance with allocations under the foreign exchange budget. Sugar and wheat are imported by a state agency only. For goods that require individual licensing, import licenses must be obtained from the Ministry of Finance and National Economy and validated (franked) by the Exchange Control Department of the central bank. "Nil" licenses, which also require franking, are issued for certain imports financed with foreign exchange held abroad by residents. Import insurance normally must be taken out with local companies. Most private sector imports are subject to an advance deposit of 2 per cent of the c.i.f. value, payable before validation, and a sur- charge of 5 per cent is levied on the c.i.f. value of all imports; capital goods, heavy trucks, tires and tubes, and medicines are exempt from advance deposits. Goods otherwise subject to the advance deposit re- quirement are exempt when financed with suppliers' credit of at least two years' maturity, provided that the amount of the transaction is at least LSd 500,000. If a letter of credit is opened, the authorized bank usually requires a cash margin of 10 per cent to 30 per cent. In practice, for many goods whose importation the banks are not allowed to finance, a 100 per cent margin de- posit must be made. A stamp duty of LSd 5 is levied on the application form for each remittance in respect of private sector imports. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require exchange control approval. Remittances are permitted for family mainte- nance (up to LSd 500 a person a year), educational expenses (up to LSd 1,200 a student a year for Western Europe, in addition to tuition fees; study in the United States is exempt from this ceiling), and for certain other purposes. Allowances for tourist travel to countries other than Egypt are authorized by the commercial banks up to a maximum of LSd 60 every other year for each adult traveling to Western Europe and the United 437 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SUDAN States, and LSd 50 every other year for travel to other areas. Allowances for nonbusiness travel to Egypt, however, are the equivalent of LSd 50 an adult, and LSd 30 a child, a year and are also authorized by the commercial banks. Exchange for travel must be pur- chased at an effective exchange rate of US$2.50 per LSd 1. Sudanese nationals resident abroad who remit for- eign exchange to the Sudan for conversion at the rate of LSd 1 = US$2.50 may at the same rate obtain for- eign exchange equivalent to 75 per cent of the amount converted in any one year and use this exchange to make personal remittances abroad. Sudanese Govern- ment officials (other than seconded staff) and students receiving educational allowances at the official rate are not entitled to avail themselves of this arrangement. Salaried foreign nationals not permanently resident in the Sudan are permitted to remit their bona fide current savings to any country other than Israel, Portu- gal, Rhodesia, or South Africa. Shipping charges, in- surance premiums, profits, interest, and dividends earned by nonresidents may be remitted freely upon presentation of the required documents. The remit- tance of income accruing from blocked assets in the Sudan (including income from Blocked Accounts) is prohibited, except for earnings from investments in government securities made before 1970. The exporta- tion of Sudanese currency is prohibited. Stamp duties are payable on the application forms for virtually all payments for invisibles. The duty is LSd 10 on applica- tions for remittances of profits and dividends, LSd 5 on applications for other transfers and for foreign ex- change for business travel, LSd 2 on applications for foreign exchange for tourism, and from LSd 1 to LSd 0.25 on applications for remittances for other pur- poses; government remittances and those by diplomats are exempt. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. With the exception of cotton and gum arable, all exports require a license. Exporters must submit an export form to an authorized bank. Authorized banks may approve these forms only if pay- ment is in the form of cash against documents or against sight letters of credit; exports on credit require the approval of the Bank of Sudan. All commodities are subject to minimum export prices. The proceeds of exports must be repatriated and surrendered through an authorized bank. When the terms of payment are cash against documents or sight letter of credit, pro- ceeds must be surrendered on delivery of the shipping documents; in other cases a surrender date is usually specified. Some major export commodities are exported solely by public sector entities. At the end of 1974, the export of some commodities was prohibited for supply reasons, and the export of certain others was permitted 438 only when the proceeds were to be received in convert- ible currencies. Proceeds from Invisibles Sudanese nationals resident abroad other than gov- ernment officials or students may remit foreign ex- change in convertible currencies to the Sudan for conversion at the rate of LSd 1 = US$2.50, and receive an incentive bonus of 60 per cent per annum which is paid on amounts so transferred to the Sudan and kept in a special account for at least six months;3 75 per cent of the remittances so received may be repatriated at the end of the six-month period but in that case the bonus is forfeited and the remittance becomes subject to the prevailing exchange tax. Receipts from abroad in re- spect of invisibles must be surrendered to authorized banks and are subject to the general prescription of currency requirements. Travelers entering the Sudan may bring in any amount in notes and coins of other countries permitted by their regulations to be taken out of those countries. However, the importation of Suda- nese currency is forbidden. Capital Under the Development and Promotion of Industrial Investment Act, 1972, which superseded the Organiza- tion and Promotion of Industrial Investment Act of 1967, incoming foreign capital for industrial invest- ment may be registered and thus may receive, among other advantages, a guarantee for repatriation of the original capital and profits thereon. Emigrants of Suda- nese nationality may on departure transfer up to the equivalent of LSd 1,500 to their new country. Upon emigration from the Sudan, resident foreigners may transfer up to the equivalent of LSd 2,500. Gold Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in the Sudan for numismatic purposes. Subject to certain conditions, residents may also purchase, hold, and sell in the Sudan domestically produced gold. With these exceptions, residents other than the monetary authori- ties and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Bank of Sudan; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Some newly mined gold is exported for processing and then reim- port ed. Changes during 1974 January 21. All other payments are settled through the bilateral account. 3 This bonus is payable only once, irrespective of the length of time by which the deposit period might exceed six months. 439 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SURINAM (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.457587 gram of fine gold per Surinam Guilder. Surinam has established a central rate of Sur. f. 1.78876 = US$1, and avails itself of wider margins. The fixed official rates for the U.S. dol- lar are Sur. f. 1.77 buying, and Sur. f. 1.80 selling, per US$1. There are also fixed official buying and selling rates of Sur. f. 1.75 and Sur. f. 1.80 for U.S. bank- notes. The rates for other foreign currencies, including the Netherlands guilder1 are set daily by the Central Bank of Surinam on the basis of the market quotations for the U.S. dollar and those currencies in Amsterdam and the fixed buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in Surinam, net of any commissions. There is no ex- change market in Surinam. Administration of Control In principle, all foreign exchange dealings are subject to license, as are dealings between residents and nonres- idents in domestic currency and other domestic assets. The authority to grant exchange licenses is vested in the Foreign Exchange Board, which has delegated much of this authority and issues licenses mainly for capital transactions and certain invisibles. The Board has au- thorized the Director of Economic Affairs (or, on his behalf, the Head of the Import, Export, and Foreign Exchange Division of the Ministry of Economic Af- fairs) to issue import and export licenses, and has em- powered the Central Bank of Surinam to provide foreign exchange for import payments (subject to pre- sentation of an import license); the latter authority is exercised through the commercial banks, which have all been appointed as authorized banks by the Foreign Exchange Board. The authorized banks are empowered to provide foreign exchange for specified current pay- ments without requiring an exchange license. They may also accept free of license those inward transfers of foreign exchange that do not result from borrowing abroad; the taking up of foreign loans is subject to Foreign Exchange Board approval. Except in the cir- cumstances specified above, the authorized banks are not permitted to sell foreign exchange without requir- ing the submission of an exchange license by the remit- ter. Prescription of Currency Settlements in Surinam guilders between Surinam and foreign countries other than the Netherlands Antilles are not permitted; they must, in general, be made in convertible currencies2 although payments to and from the Netherlands Antilles may also be made in Netherlands Antilles guilders or Surinam guilders. 440 Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents, whether banks or nonbanks, may freely open accounts in U.S. dollars with domestic banks; no overdrafts are permitted. Nonresidents other than banks may freely open accounts in Surinam guil- ders with domestic banks; certain debits and credits are covered by a general license, while all others are subject to a specific license. These accounts must not be over- drawn, and debits for certain specified purposes must not exceed a total of Sur. f. 3,000 a month. Authorized banks have also been granted a general license permit- ting them to open nonresident accounts in Surinam guilders in the name of nonresident banks; these ac- counts also must not be overdrawn. Nonresident guil- der or foreign currency accounts may not be credited with Surinam banknotes mailed from abroad or with the foreign currency equivalent. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses are required for all imports.3 Some items, such as specified explosives and narcotics, are prohibited for reasons of public policy or health. Im- ports of a few other commodities are prohibited from non-EEC sources for protective reasons and subject to quota when originating in EEC countries; they include coffee (roasted and unroasted), sugar, powdered milk, butter (in packs of 500 grams or less), most worked and unworked wood, and certain metal furniture. The im- port of prohibited goods may be allowed when there is a need for them, provided that they cannot be obtained in Surinam. Another group of commodities are subject to quota, irrespective of origin; these include matches, prefabricated wooden houses, certain women's wear, certain footwear, and certain wooden or cane furniture. Special conditions are attached to the import of copra, rice, butter (in packs of over 500 grams), wheat flour (in packs of over 1,000 grams), veneer, and furniture that is on neither the prohibited nor the restricted list; the import of these commodities also is restricted for protective reasons but the issuance of licenses is subject to administrative decision rather than to quota. A gov- ernment agency, the Surinam Central Import Service, acts as the sole importer of certain staple foodstuffs. All other imports are licensed freely from any source. The import license serves as a payment license, exchange being made available upon presentation of the license. Most licenses have a validity of six months, within which period the goods must be landed and paid for. Payments for Invisibles Payments for most invisibles require individual li- censes. The commercial banks and the General Post Office have authority to provide foreign exchange up to Sur. f. 150 an item a month on account of certain ser- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution vices (bank charges, legal fees, membership dues, copy and patent rights, and so forth); up to Sur. f. 150 an item a month for advertising expenses and payments for books; up to Sur. f. 300 a year from each remitter in respect of gifts, subject to a limit of Sur. f. 300 a year on any beneficiary's receipt of gifts from Surinam resi- dents; and up to Sur. f. 200-300 a month for the sup- port of each member of the remitter's own family in the Netherlands Antilles or the Netherlands, subject to a limit of Sur. f. 600-900 a month for a family unit (fam- ily remittances up to the same amounts to other countries require a license, which is granted upon appli- cation). The basic exchange allowance to residents for travel is Sur. f. 750-2,500 a person for each trip (50 per cent of these amounts for children under 14), depending on the destination;4 the authorized bank must enter on the travel ticket the amount of foreign exchange sold and the date, the purchase of travel exchange not being permitted until three days before departure. Travelers may take out Sur. f. 100 in Surinam currency. The ex- port by resident travelers of foreign banknotes (includ- ing Netherlands currency) is limited to the amount of their travel allowance. Nonresident travelers may freely purchase and take out foreign currency up to the equiv- alent of Sur. f. 250. Nonresident travelers may also freely take out any foreign banknotes they brought in, provided that amounts in excess of Sur. f. 5,000 were declared upon entry. Payments due as interest on loans and as net income from other investments, and payments of moderate amounts for amortization of loans or depreciation of direct investments, may be made if an application sup- ported by an auditor's report is duly presented to the Foreign Exchange Board for verification. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports require export licenses, which for most com- modities are issued freely, provided that the exporter undertakes to surrender the foreign currency proceeds to an authorized bank within six months of shipment. Export licenses for cattle and pigs, fresh beef and pork, and planting materials are granted only after favorable advice of the Director of Agriculture, Animal Hus- bandry, and Fisheries. The export of baboon wood is restricted and that of rice is subject to special regula- tions. Certain exporting companies have received spe- cial permission from the Foreign Exchange Board to maintain current accounts in foreign currency with their parent companies abroad and to use these for specified payments and receipts (including export pro- ceeds). Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to an authorized bank. Travelers may bring in foreign currency without limit, and up to SURINAM Sur. f. 100 in domestic currency; resident travelers must surrender any foreign currency in excess of the equivalent of Sur. f. 500. Capital A decision of September 21, 1960 of the Foreign Exchange Board provides for the transfer abroad of capital proceeds from the sale to residents or the liqui- dation of fully or partly foreign-owned companies or other forms of enterprise. The decision covers invest- ments made by nonresidents with foreign capital after July 31, 1953. It also provides for the annual transfer of profits and for the transfer at any time of the foreign exchange (including loans) imported by the nonresi- dent entrepreneur for the company's use. Profits must be transferred within a period of three years; otherwise, they are considered to have become part of the firm's working capital or to have been lent to the firm, and may only be transferred in annual quotas of 20 per cent. An Investment Law passed on February 3, 1960 pro- vides for additional incentives to private investment in Surinam. The Foreign Exchange Board grants licenses on ap- plication for transfers abroad from a deceased's estate, up to a maximum of Sur. f. 25,000. For estates of more than Sur. f. 25,000, further annual transfers are per- mitted so as to spread them over a period not exceeding ten years. The Board allows emigrants (heads of family) to transfer in foreign exchange the equivalent of Sur. f. 5,000 in a lump sum, and subsequently Sur. f. 5,000 a year. The head of a repatriating family is permitted to transfer the equivalent of Sur. f. 10,000 plus 10 per cent of his total taxable earnings in Surinam accrued during his period of residence; if his Surinam assets exceed the sum thus calculated, the excess may be transferred at a rate of Sur. f. 10,000 a year, or at a higher rate when this is necessary to ensure that the entire balance is released within ten years. Subject to certain requirements, residents may pur- chase or sell in specified countries5 Surinam corporate shares that have been designated as negotiable by the Foreign Exchange Board. Transfers for investment in Netherlands or other foreign securities or real estate by residents are not permitted, although exceptions may be made for direct investments abroad when it is con- sidered that Surinam interests will benefit. All borrow- ing from nonresidents by nonbank residents requires prior approval by the Foreign Exchange Board. The foreign transactions of authorized banks are restricted, in principle, to those undertaken for the account of their customers, and banks are required, in principle, to surrender to the Central Bank any excess of foreign currency purchased over foreign currency sold, but the Central Bank permits them to place part of their liquid funds abroad and they have received a general license to place abroad at short term U.S. dollars correspond- ing to balances in nonresident U.S. dollar accounts. 441 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SURINAM Gold Producers of gold may sell only to authorized gold buyers. Locally produced gold must be surrendered to the Foreign Exchange Board by sale to the Central Bank at Sur. f. 2,110 a kilogram fine for bars of at least 10 kilograms or at Sur. f. 1.80 a gram for unworked gold with an average smelting loss of 6 per cent and an average gold content of 940/iooo-6 Authorized gold buy- ers are permitted, however, to sell nuggets at freely agreed prices to the public for industrial and artistic purposes; dealings between residents in gold bars and other forms of unworked gold, with the exception of nuggets, are prohibited. As local production does not meet demand for industrial purposes, the Central Bank imports some gold, which it sells to authorized gold buyers. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Suri- nam for numismatic and investment purposes; autho- rized banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents. Residents other than the monetary authorities, producers of gold, and authorized industrial and dental users are not allowed without special permission to hold or acquire gold in any form other than nuggets, jewelry, or coins, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require exchange licenses7 issued by the Foreign Exchange Board; such licenses are not nor- mally granted except for imports and exports of coins by authorized banks, and for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, producers of gold, and industrial users. Residents arriving from abroad, however, may freely bring in gold, subject to declaration, and provided that they surrender it to the Central Bank within 20 days. Nonresident travelers also may freely bring in gold, subject to declaration; they may re-export the declared amount freely. Imports of gold coins are duty free and those of unworked gold are subject to a duty of Sur. f. 0.0375 a gram, irrespective of origin. The general tariff for gold ornaments is 60 per cent ad valorem, but those of EEC origin are subject to duty at 50 per cent ad valorem. Imports of all forms of gold are subject to a statistical fee of 1.5 per cent and a licensing fee of 0.5 per cent. Changes during 1974 April 18. Authorized banks receiving Surinam bank- notes from their correspondents abroad could no longer credit these to nonresident guilder accounts or convert them into foreign currency. The amount in domestic banknotes that could be brought in or taken out by travelers remained unchanged at Sur. f. 100 a person. June 15. The Barbados dollar was added to the list of convertible currencies in which international trans- actions must normally be settled. August 15. The basic exchange allowance for travel by foreign members of consular staffs was limited to Sur. f. 750-2,500 a person a trip, depending on desti- nation. November 8. The Fund was informed that Surinam subscribed to the Voluntary Declaration on Trade and Other Current Account Measures for Balance of Pay- ments Purposes. Not for Redistribution SWAZILAND (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange and Trade System Swaziland's currency is the Lilangeni, which is at par with the South African Rand. No par value has been established for the lilangeni.1 The par value of the rand is 1.04550 grams of fine gold per rand. However, the South African Reserve Bank has adopted an exchange rate policy of independent managed floating, and on December 31, 1974 it quoted a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.4500 per R 1. Exchange rates are based on the South African Reserve Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar against the rand and the Lon- don market rates for the currencies concerned against the U.S. dollar. Swaziland has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Swaziland also forms part of the Rand Monetary Area, which is a single exchange control ter- ritory comprising Botswana, Lesotho, South Africa, and Swaziland. For purposes of exchange control over transactions in securities or gold, residents of a member country of the latter area are not regarded as residents of another member country. The Ministry of Finance controls all external currency transactions. No restrictions are applied to payments within the Rand Monetary Area, and in principle these are uncon- trolled. In relation to countries outside the Rand Mon- etary Area, Swaziland applies exchange controls that are generally similar to those of South Africa, although Swaziland's treatment of certain capital transfers to other countries of the Sterling Area may be more lib- eral. Payments to nonresidents for current transac- tions, while subject to control, are not restricted, but applications for outward transfers of capital are consid- ered on their merits. The rulings on applications for inward and outward capital transfers may depend on whether the applicant is a temporarily resident foreign national, a nonresident, or a resident. Authority to ap- prove some types of current payments is delegated to commercial banks up to established limits; this is true, for example, of the basic exchange allowance for tourist travel (the equivalent of R 2,000 in a calendar year for an adult and R 800 for a child) and a smaller annual allocation for travel to neighboring countries. There are no bilateral payments arrangements. Swaziland is a member of a customs union with Bo- tswana, Lesotho, and South Africa, and there are no import restrictions on goods originating in any country of the customs union. Imports from South Africa do not require licenses and include an unknown quan t i ty of goods originating outside the customs union. Insofar as Swaziland imports goods direct from countries out- side the customs un ion, such imports are usually li- censed in con fo rm i ty with South Africa's import regulations. Import licenses are valid for all countries and entitle the holder to buy the foreign exchange re- quired to make the import paymen t. Certain exports are subject to licensing, mainly for revenue and similar reasons, but most exports are in the f i rst instance shipped free of license to or through South Africa. Changes during 1974 June 24. South Africa discontinued the existing prac- tice of maintaining a fixed rate of exchange between the rand and the U.S. dollar for lengthy periods and, in- stead, adopted an exchange rate policy of independent managed floating. A new middle rate was set for the U.S. dollar at R 1 - US$1.50 (formerly R 1 = US$1.49). The middle rate was changed in 1974 on a number of occasions. September 6. It was announced that w i th in two years Botswana would establish a central bank and issue its own currency, which would replace the rand as legal tender. Botswana w i thdrew from the negotiations with South Africa, Lesotho, and Swaziland on a formaliza- tion and revision of the Rand Monetary Area arrange- ments. Past arrangements would continue, however, un t il the central bank started in operations. September 6. Swaziland issued its own currency, the lilangeni, which was at par with the rand. Henceforth, both the lilangeni and the rand were legal tender. December 5. Agreement was reached in negotiations between Lesotho, Swaziland, and South Africa, con- cerning a formalization of, and certain changes in, the existing Rand Monetary Area arrangements. The re- sulting Monetary Agreement came into force on the same date.
