Not for Redistribution TURKEY (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0592447 gram of f ine gold per Turkish Lira. The central rate is LT 14 = US$1, and Turkey avails itself of wider margins. The official rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, are LT 13.850 buying, and LT 14.127 selling, per US$1. The Central Bank also establishes from time to time official buying and selling rates for certain other cur- rencies. Pending the enactment of new legislation to elimi- na te interest payments on remittances by Turkish workers resident abroad, Turkey maintains a separate nominal rate for these, though the resulting effective exchange rate conforms to the central rate of LT 14 per US$ 1. Workers' remittances are converted at a buying rate of LT 10.3878 per US$1; when the Turkish lira equivalent is credited to an account with a bank in Turkey, the account is immediately credited with an additional 331/3 per cent of the amount converted. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Ministry of Finance. Trade control is the responsibility of the Min- istry of Commerce, which is also in charge of the prepa- ration of import programs. The Ministry of Commerce, or the Central Bank on the advice of the Ministry, allocates foreign exchange; certain foreign exchange al- locations for imports require prior approval of the com- petent ministry, even if the commodity is included in the liberalized lists. The Central Bank issues import licenses on instructions of the Ministry of Commerce. Export registration is carried out by professional orga- nizations (the Exporters Union, the Chambers of Com- merce, of Industry, and of Commerce and Industry) according to the instructions of the Ministry of Com- merce; export licenses are issued by this Ministry, which may delegate the issuance of export licenses to the professional organizations. Import and export li- censes for gold, however, are issued by the Ministry of Finance. Prescription of Currency and Nonresident Accounts Settlements with countries with which Turkey has bilateral payments agreements1 are made in accordance with the terms of the relevant agreement, but proceeds from exports to these countries may be received in any convertible currency. Certain commercial settlements with the other members of the Regional Cooperation for Development (Iran and Pakistan) are made through special accounts denominated in U.S. dollars. Settle- ments with other countries are made in convertible currencies; proceeds from exports to specified countries in Western Europe2 must be received in the currency of 476 any country in this group. Nonresidents are not permit- ted to open demand or time accounts in Turkey that are denominated in convertible Turkish liras. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited; imports of old, used and reconditioned, defective, substandard, soiled, or poor-quality goods are forbidden, except with the authorization of the Ministry of Commerce. All commercial imports require import licenses, which are valid for five months,3 and, generally, goods must be cleared through the customs within six months. Import licenses are issued to registered importers (import mer- chants), industrialists (manufacturers importing for their own needs), state economic enterprises, and gov- ernment departments. Private individuals and corpo- rate bodies are required to secure an "importer's certificate" issued by the Ministry of Commerce before submitting applications through the authorized banks for licenses to import goods for commercial purposes. The importer's tax status is taken into consideration when granting such certificates. However, exporters, mine operators, shipowners, building contractors who have undertaken the construction of state establish- ments, tourist establishments, and registered manufac- turers are not required to secure an "importer's certificate" for imports to be used exclusively for their own needs; a certificate establishing their qualification is issued by the respective public authority, i.e., the Chambers of Commerce and Industry, the Exporters Union, or the Ministry of Tourism and Information. Most goods are imported in accordance with the provisions of import programs, which are planned for one year. The import programs classify imports in two categories: (1) an annual list of liberalized goods, con- sisting of two parts (lists I and II), for which import licenses are issued freely; and (2) a list of goods subject to global quotas published annually. Imports of goods that do not appear on any of these lists are prohibited; certain of these commodities, however, may be im- ported when specifically authorized by the Ministry of Commerce. The list of liberalized goods and the list of global quotas apply, in principle, only to imports from countries other than those with which Turkey has bilat- eral payments agreements;4 goods not included in ei- ther of these two import lists may not be imported under the bilateral quotas. Certain imports from member countries of the EEC are included in a list of liberalized items consolidated to the EEC and are free of quantitative restriction; most of the items on this list are included in liberalized lists I and II. Applications for import licenses for goods on the liberalized lists may be submitted at any time to autho- rized banks, which transfer them to the Ministry of ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Commerce (or other public authority indicated) for ex- amination and prepare the import licenses and forward these to the Central Bank for approval on the Minis- try's instructions. For certain liberalized goods, the prior approval of the ministry concerned is also re- quired. There are special arrangements administered by the Ministry of Commerce to facilitate priority allocation of foreign exchange for imports of raw materials and supplementary materials required for export produc- tion. The list of import quotas contains quotas for regis- tered importers and for industrialists. Quotas for indus- trialists are allocated annually and those for private commercial importers three times a year. Imports on the quota list can be subdivided into two broad catego- ries —imports which do not, and impor ts which do, require a permit from a specified public body. Foreign exchange allocations for quota imports within the quantitative limit established for each quota item are made by the Central Bank for imports not requiring a permit, and by the Ministry of Commerce (on the ad- vice of the responsible authority) for those requiring a permit. Some of the quota imports also require a certifi- cate confirming that the articles are not manufactured by local industry and do not exist in the local market in sufficient quantity and quality; the required certifi- cate is the responsibility of the M in is try of Indu s t ry and Technology, which may delegate authority to the Chambers of Commerce and Industry. Registered importers have to submit their applica- tions for goods not requiring a permit through an au- thorized bank and the Central Bank to the Ministry of Commerce during the f irst mon th of each semester. Upon examination of applications, the Ministry of Commerce instructs the Central Bank to issue a foreign exchange allocation letter valid for four months, and an import license must be secured from the Central Bank within the period of validity of the foreign exchange allocation letter. Applications for imports against in- dustrialists' quotas where no permit is required have to be submitted through the Chambers of Commerce and Industry to the Ministry of Commerce in April of each year. Applications for quo ta imports requ ir ing a permit from a specified public authority must be submitted to the responsible body each semester by importers and each year by industrialists. Upon examination of the application, the Ministry of Commerce instructs the responsible body to issue a foreign exchange allocation valid for four mon ths, but not longer than one mon th beyond the period of effectiveness of the quota list. An import license must then be secured from the Central Bank during the period of validity of the exchange allocation. Under a system of pre-import price control, which has been suspended but not abolished, imports are to be made at the best ruling world market prices. For this purpose, whenever the system is reinstated, a certificate TURKEY must be obtained from the Office of Price Registration and Control after issuance of the import license or the certificate of foreign exchange allocation. However, public sector imports of goods on liberalization list I may be authorized by the Central Bank without a price conformity certificate. The import license permits the necessary foreign ex- change payment to be made. Payments for imports may be made against letters of credit, documents, or goods (i.e., upon customs clearance). When the payment is to be made against a letter of credit, registered importers and industrialists are required to prepay in local cur- rency, at the time of application for an import license, the equivalent of the foreign exchange for which they have applied. For payments against documents or against goods, importers and industrialists are required to prepay half of the value of the imports with the application for an import license; this requirement, however, has been suspended. Importers are required to make the foreign exchange transfer within four months from the date of the import license for payments against documents and within two months f rom the date of customs clearance for pay- ments against goods. Imports from bilateral agreement countries are sub- ject to separate quotas. These are established only for commodities that appear on the liberalization or global quota lists. The import licensing procedure for goods from these countries is the same as for imports under global quotas, except that applications under the bilat- eral quotas specified in each agreement are submitted by the Central Bank or the responsible public authority to the Ministry of Commerce on a monthly basis. Guarantee deposits for imports are payable in ad- vance, generally as follows: for goods on liberalized list I, 20 per cent of the value of the merchandise is payable,5 and for items on list II, 10 per cent; for im- ports under global quotas, 10 per cent of the value of the import application is payable for goods on import- ers' quotas, and 2.5 per cent for industrialists' quotas and export manufacturers.6 For imports under bilateral quotas the rate of guarantee deposit depends on the list on which the goods are included if imported f rom a nonagreement country, but a rate of 10 per cent is applied to quotas which are not included in industrial- ists' quotas to be fixed by the Ministry of Commerce for agreement countries and all of the quotas indicated in the listed import quotas for which there exists no control authority. Guarantee deposits are payable irrespective of the method of payment. The public sector is exempt, how- ever, and in many cases industrialists make a symbolic deposit of 1 per cent (on imports under investment quotas set aside for their use and applicable to convert- ible currency countries only), or 10 per cent (on imports under investment quotas in bilateral agreements). The deposit remains blocked until the goods have been cleared through customs and the foreign supplier paid; it is then refunded to the importer. The guarantee de- 477 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY posits collected are transferred weekly to an account held by the Central Bank in the name of the authorized bank. Should imports not be made in conformity with the regulations, a part of the guarantee deposit corre- sponding to up to 10 per cent of the value of such imports is forfeited to the Treasury.7 Private compensation transactions are not permitted in any form, except that the Ministry of Commerce is authorized to conclude agreements to dispose of goods acquired through supporting purchases made by the State. Imports without an allocation of foreign exchange may be permitted by the customs authorities, the Cen- tral Bank, or the Ministry of Finance, under certain conditions. Travelers domiciled in Turkey may bring in for personal or professional (but noncommercial) use goods and machinery with a limit of LT 3,000, in addi- tion to personal effects. Separate limits and conditions apply to imports of goods for personal use, and of professional instruments and machines, by persons having resided abroad for employment or study; these limits and conditions vary with the stay abroad and with the transfer to Turkey of foreign exchange. Com- panies or cooperatives formed in Turkey by residents temporarily working abroad may import investment goods to the extent of the foreign exchange invested. In addition to personal effects, foreign tourists may im- port goods and machinery for their personal or family use. Foreign contractors may temporarily import ma- chinery, vehicles, and scientific instruments without re- questing an allocation of foreign exchange, provided that the goods are proved to be necessary for their operations in Turkey and may not be imported on a temporary basis under the relevant customs regula- tions. Foreign companies established in Turkey may import spare parts not intended for new investments w i thout requesting an allocation of foreign exchange, provided that the goods are necessary for their opera- tions. All such imports require the permission of the exchange control authorities. Goods imported on these terms must not be sold to third parties in Turkey. Import of an automobile8 without payment of for- eign exchange may be permitted by the Central Bank or the Ministry of Finance, provided that certain condi- tions are met relating to residence abroad and to remit- tance and sale to authorized banks in Turkey of foreign exchange. Automobiles imported without a foreign exchange allocation may be sold to residents by the Turkish na- tionals who have imported them. Foreign diplomats in Turkey may sell their automobiles to Turkish residents provided that the necessary import duties are paid at the time of the sale, that Turkish diplomats in the seller's country are granted reciprocal privileges, and that proceeds from such sales are not transferred abroad. Foreign officials, other than diplomats, may not sell to Turkish nationals any automobiles imported duty free under special agreements. Other foreign na- 478 tionals resident in Turkey may import automobiles un- der certain conditions, but they must be exported after three years; however, this three-year period may be extended, and the Ministry of Finance may also permit the sale of such cars to the State Supply Office or to nonprofit organizations. With these exceptions, auto- mobiles and any other commodities that have been imported du ty free may not be sold to residents. In addition to customs du ty, imported goods are subject to the following charges: (1) a customs sur- charge of 15 per cent of the applicable customs duty; (2) a stamp du ty of 9.0 per cent or 9.5 per cent of the declared value, depending on the type of commodity;9 (3) a quay duty of 5 per cent on the sum of c.i.f. value, customs du ty, customs surcharge, stamp duty, and cus- toms clearance expenses; and (4) a production tax rang- ing generally from 10 per cent to 75 per cent on the sum of c.i.f. value, customs duty, customs surcharge, stamp duty, customs clearing expenses, and quay duty. The quay du ty is not payable on goods imported by air. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles require exchange licenses which usually are issued by the Central Bank. These are granted liberally for the following purposes, provided that applications are accompanied by specified docu- ments: payments related to trade (including shipping costs and expenditures connected with other freight charges), subscriptions to newspapers and periodicals, purchases of books, payments for registration fees, ad- vertising expenses, consulate income, payments by the Government, payments by the Post Office Administra- tion and similar state institutions, banks' commissions and expenses, a proportion of insurance companies' payments, specified technical assistance, repair and as- sembly expenses, and legal fees for commercial transac- tions. The transfer of income related to foreign investments approved under the Law for the Encour- agement of Foreign Investment is permitted freely. In- terest on long-term loans and credits extended by nonresidents to enterprises in Turkey (including those of an agricultural nature) may be granted transferabil- ity between foreign nationals both in Turkey and abroad. Turkish citizens are not allowed to leave the country without having obtained an allocation of exchange for travel, but this does not apply to foreign nationals re- siding in Turkey. Tourist travel is restricted, in effect, to four trips a person a year, except for travel to Cy- prus. The allowance of exchange for tourist travel (ex- cept for persons traveling on a collective passport) is up to the equivalent of US$800 a calendar year;10 travelers are not allowed to leave the country unless they are carrying at least the equivalent of US$200 in foreign exchange (US$110 for persons under 18 years of age and the purchase of this amount is not mandatory). Turkish citizens traveling to Cyprus may obtain an exchange allocation equivalent to less than US$200 on ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution request; this does not affect their right to claim the tourist travel allowance. Exchange for business travel is granted within the limits of annual quotas, which vary according to the taxable income of the applicant firm. For exporting companies, the limit is related to their export proceeds. Exchange for travel abroad for other purposes (e.g., education, participation in inter- national meetings, fairs, athletic meets, and so fo r th, and personal business) is sold up to specified limits. In addition, persons who can certify that it is necessary for them to travel abroad for medical trea tment may pur- chase the necessary foreign exchange. Travelers are permitted to take out LT 100 in Turk- ish bankno tes and coins. Nonresidents may take out w i thout any restriction the unspent portion of the for- eign exchange which they b rought in. Nonresident travelers who wish to reconvert Turkish liras into for- eign currency when leaving the coun t ry are required to present a document showing that foreign exchange had previously been sold to an authorized dealer in Turkey. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are proh ib i ted. All exports des- tined to bilateral countries,11 exports of a few commod- ities to any des t ina t ion ,12 re-exports irrespective of des t ina t ion, and tempo ra ry exports requ ire an export license in order to prevent re-exports and to assure adequate supplies for the domestic ma rke t. Commer- cial export prices must conform to the checklist of prices fixed at in te rva ls by the M in i s t ry of Commerce on the basis of prices ob ta in ing in domestic and fore ign markets. For th is purpose, exporters must app ly for price reg is tra t ion to a professional organ iza t ion desig- nated by the M in i s t ry of Commerce w i t h in f ive wo rk ing days (three wo rk ing days in the case of haze lnu ts) of a sale, toge ther w i th a s ta tement of income earned and income and corpora t ion taxes paid du r ing the last three years. The professional organization will not accept for registration app l ica t ions not con fo rm ing to the check- list of prices. When registering sales, due consideration is given to de l ivery time, q u a n t i t y, sales cond i t ions, the income earned by the exporter on his commercial activ- ities in the course of the last th ree years, and income and corporation taxes assessed du r ing the same period. For exports requiring a license, the price registration application is subm i t ted by the responsible au tho r i ty to the M in i s t ry of Commerce; approved price registration bills cons t i tu te export licenses. Exporters in the public sector may apply direct to the M in is try of Commerce for price reg is tra t ion and export licenses. In issuing licenses for exports to bilateral agreement countries, export quotas are fixed by the M in i s t ry. Expor ts must be started w i th in 30 to 360 days of reg is tra t ion, de- pending on the type of goods, sales contracts, and coun t ry of des t ina t ion. C ircu la t ion certificates for ex- ports to member countries of the EEC benefiting f rom preferen t ial customs and tax t rea tment are issued by the Customs Au tho r i ty. TURKEY Exporters are required to sell to a bank in Turkey the foreign exchange proceeds of goods exported within three months from the date of export or within ten days from the date on which the foreign exchange is placed at their disposal. They are permitted to export a speci- fied list of commodities on 12-month credit terms, how- ever, against payment in convertible currency and subject to a bank guarantee. Forward sales may be made only when payment is to be received in convert- ible currencies; price conformity for forward sales is required at the time the export contract is concluded. Under an export tax rebate scheme, direct and indi- rect taxes paid are refunded when manufactures or products are exported. There are basically four rates of re fund: 5, 10, 20, and 25 per cent of specified direct and indirect taxes. However, 10 percentage points more in tax refunds is granted to exporters who sell more than US$1.8 million of goods benefiting from a refund. Re- duced rates of re fund apply for certain goods when exported to bilateral payments agreement countries, and other goods exported to these countries do not qua l i fy for a tax re fund. In addition, varying provi- sional rates of re fund exist. The tax refund must not exceed the amount of indirect taxes and charges actu- ally paid. Other tax incentives include the exemption of export earnings f rom income and corporation taxes and the exemption of export goods from the production tax (for foreigners). Exporters of specified goods also have access to credit at preferential interest rates from a special export fund. Proceeds from In visibles Firms or ind iv idua ls not in the category of autho- rized ins t i tu t ions cannot accept more than the equiva- lent of US$100 f rom foreign tourists and are required to surrender any exchange earnings in the form of for- eign banknotes and travelers checks to an authorized bank w i th in ten days.* Otherwise, foreign exchange ac- c ru ing to residents for services rendered by them to nonresidents must be surrendered to an authorized ex- change dealer w i th in three mon ths f rom the date on wh ich the service was rendered or w i th in ten days f rom the date of acquisition of the exchange. Remittances from Turkish workers abroad are sold to the Central Bank at LT 10.3878 per U.S. dollar; when the Turkish l ira equ iva lent is credited to a bank account in Turkey, an additional amount of 33V3 per cent is immediately credited to the account representing three years' inter- est at 11 .11 per cent per annum resulting in an effective exchange rate of LT 13.850 per U.S. dollar. The amoun ts deposited plus the interest can be w i thd rawn at any time. Foreign travelers wishing to take out arti- cles w i th a value exceeding LT 2,000 must show proof that they have converted foreign exchange to cover the portion of the cost exceeding this limit. The impo rt of Turk ish banknotes and coins by trav- elers (whe ther of Turk ish or foreign na t iona l i ty) is lim- 479 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY ited to LT 100. The import of foreign currency by trav- elers is unrestricted. Capital Foreign investments in Turkey require approval. Capital transfers abroad by residents and capital trans- actions between residents and nonresidents are subject to the approval of the exchange control authorities. Residents are not normally permitted to acquire for- eign securities or real estate. With the exception of certain investments made in accordance with the provisions of the Law for the En- couragement of Foreign Investments (No. 6224) or the Petroleum Law (No. 6326, as amended), foreign com- panies and contractors who wish to do business in Turkey must import the required capital and operating funds in the form of foreign exchange, although under certain conditions blocked funds may be used for in- vestment in the tourist industry. Borrowing in Turkish liras by such foreign companies and contractors is sub- ject to quotas set by the Ministry of Finance in accor- dance with their equity capital in Turkey, but special facilities exist for borrowing from the "Blocked Curren- cies Fund" at the Central Bank. Blocked funds are those accrued or accruing to non- residents but not transferable under the existing ex- change control regulations. These include the sales proceeds of real estate situated in Turkey and owned by nonresident physical or juridical persons, insofar as the property is not covered by Law No. 6224 or Law No. 6326. Except for approved investments, nonresi- dents may not convert into foreign currency any assets or balances owned by them, or earnings accruing to them; all earnings are blocked but if, at the end of the calendar year, such earnings are less than LT 10,000, the amount involved is deblocked. Subject to individual permission, blocked assets and balances may be utilized within Turkey, e.g., for the payment of taxes, insurance, and maintenance and repair of property; and for living expenses of up to LT 9,000 a month for each benefi- ciary for owners of such funds or their authorized rep- resentatives, and up to LT 5,000 for certain relatives. Normally, such blocked funds may not be transferred to others except by legal succession. The investment of blocked funds in the tourist industry is subject to the following conditions: (1) there must be a contribution in new foreign exchange or imported equipment equal to at least 50 per cent of the blocked funds to be used and (2) the investor must undertake not to request transfer for at least five years of that part of the capital financed by means of the blocked funds. Blocked funds used in this manner are considered as foreign capital imported under the Law for the Encouragement of For- eign Investments. A portion of 75 per cent of any holder's blocked funds can be transferred to the Blocked Currencies Fund at the Central Bank, from which nonresidents may receive credits for their partner companies' invest- 480 ment requirements in Turkey, provided the permission of the Ministry of Finance is obtained. Dividends and profits derived from these credits have to be blocked again and are nontransferable. Balances on nonresident accounts established at the Central Bank in accordance with the Paris Agreement on Commercial Debts Owed by Residents of Turkey (1959) may be used either partially or wholly by the creditors for investment or to pay expenses in Turkey at any time prior to the date, established under the Agreement, when the balances may be transferred. The use of these balances for investment purposes is subject to the provisions of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Investments. However, invested funds and in- come related thereto may not be transferred abroad before the transfer date established under the Agree- ment, except for investment in the export industries or in other industries earning foreign exchange; in such instances the equivalent of up to 25 per cent of the investment may be transferred annually. Foreign capital invested in Turkey under the terms of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Invest- ments is accorded preferential treatment, provided that the enterprise in which the investment is to be made is deemed to contribute to the economic development of the country, or will operate in a field of activity open to Turkish private enterprise and will not entail monop- oly or special privilege. Under this law, all or part of the invested capital or foreign loans may be remitted abroad in the original currency of the capital. Upon application, the Ministry of Finance guarantees the transfer of dividends and of the proceeds from the sale or liquidation of shares or stock certificates registered on the books of companies established under the law. Such registered shares or stock certificates are freely transferable between foreign nationals, both in Turkey and abroad, and between foreign nationals and resi- dents. The transfer guarantees pass on to the new owner, provided that his name is notified to the Minis- try of Finance; if the shares or stock certificates are sold to a resident, however, they must be presented to the Ministry of Finance for cancellation of the guarantees. The capital and interest on long-term loans and credits extended by nonresidents to enterprises in Turkey (in- cluding those of an agricultural character) may be ac- corded the same transfer benefits. Foreign capital imported under the Petroleum Law is accorded addi- tional preferential treatment. By virtue of a policy state- ment of December 1971, Turkish participation in new foreign investments no longer is subject to a minimum of 51 per cent. In addition to investments under Law No. 6224, foreign investments outside the petroleum sector may be made "under the monetary regulations," in which case the investor does not enjoy any transfer facilities for earnings or liquidation proceeds. Transactions in securities, including their export and import, require approval when nonresident interests are involved. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Nonresidents are permitted to open noninterest- bearing foreign exchange deposit accounts with Turk- ish banks. Nonresidents can no longer open or credit demand accounts in convertible Turkish liras, although existing balances can be maintained. The deadline for the termination of time deposits in convertible Turkish liras varies between July 2, 1973 and April 3, 1976, depending on the end-use of the counterpart domestic bank credit. However, time deposits with ma tur i ty dates going beyond 'the deadlines specified for the dif- ferent end-uses of the counterpart domestic bank credit are permitted to run their full term. No exchange guar- antee exists for demand deposits af ter April 3, 1973 and for time deposits after the original maturity date.13 The total amount of private and public sector bor- rowing abroad from private sources, including supplier credits, is determined in an annual program by the Ministry of Finance, which also specifies the eligible sectors and projects. The Ministry of Finance, after consultation with other ministries if appropriate, is au- thorized to approve such credits and to issue a guaran- tee of the transferability of the foreign exchange. It is up to the intermediating bank to guarantee the repay- ment in liras. Turkish borrowers pay that bank the prevailing domestic interest rate; the excess over the interest rate payable to the foreign lender, net of a banking commission, is credited to an "Interest Equal- ization Fund" established in the Central Bank. Regula- tions issued by the Ministry of Finance specify that, with certain exceptions, such credits must not amount to more than 60 per cent of the total cost of a project, their maturity must not be less than two years, and the rate of interest must not exceed the Euro-dollar rate (the London Interbank Offer Rate —LIBOR) by more than 1 per cent. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Turkey for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad; any unworked gold held in Turkey, however, may be pres- ented for minting by the State Mint. Imports of gold are free, provided that it is sold to the Central Bank. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Changes during 1974 January L The Interim Agreement with the EEC of June 30, 1974 came into force. (The supplementary protocol to the Association Agreement between the EEC and Turkey, consequent on the accession of the United Kingdom, Ireland, and Denmark to the EEC, did not come into force until early 1975.) TURKEY January 3. The 1974 import program was published. Total imports in 1974 were programmed to be US$3,036 million, compared with US$1,600 million for 1973. This included US$1,250 million for liberalized goods, US$1,236 million for quota goods, and US$100 million for imports from bilateral agreement countries. A large number of commodities was transferred from the global quota list to the liberalized lists. The guaran- tee deposit for imports on liberalized list I was reduced from 25 per cent to 20 per cent, and the rate was reduced to 1 per cent for the importation of tires and tubes, iron and steel, and certain other items. The spe- cial regime for imports financed by the U.S. Agency for International Development was terminated. Imports from bilateral payments agreement countries hence- forth could be made on the basis of cash payment, provided that prior consent was obtained from both the Ministries of Commerce and Finance. An emergency quota of US$500 for each transaction was established for imports of goods urgently needed by the private sector. It was also announced that full import duty exemptions on investment imports would be phased out. All imports under the program could be made on a collection basis (payment against documents or pay- ment against goods); previously, letters of credit were prescribed for certain imports. February 28. The nominal exchange rate of LT 9.3333 = US$1 for sales of foreign exchange for travel purposes was abolished, as was the tax of 50 per cent on sales of exchange for travel. The tax of 50 per cent payable on the purchase against payment in Turk- ish liras of travel tickets also was abolished (Decree No. 7 /7872). April 1. The bilateral payments agreements with Bul- garia and Poland expired. May 14. The official buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were changed from LT 14.000 and LT 14.301 to LT 13.50 buying, and LT 13.77 selling, per US$1, respectively. May 14. The nominal buying rate applicable to re- mittances made by Turkish workers abroad was changed from LT 10.50 to LT 10.1252 per US$1. The effective exchange rate for such remittances was changed from LT 14.00 to LT 13.50 per US$1. July 31. Communique No. 1 of the Ministry of Fi- nance regarding the methods and procedures for tax refunds on exports was issued. August 3. Resident physical and juridical persons were permitted to transfer to Turkey, in convertible currencies bought and sold by the Central Bank, any capital and income they had accumulated abroad that were not subject to compulsory repatriation. If the laws of the country where such assets were located prohib- ited their exportation in the form of foreign exchange, the Central Bank could allow instead the importation of goods on the liberalized list, up to US$50,000 for each holder of foreign assets. September 20. The official rates for the U.S. dollar were changed to LT 13.850 buying, and LT 14.127 481 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY selling, per US$1. The nominal rate applicable to remit- tances made by Turkish workers abroad was changed to LT 10.3878 per US$1, and the effective buying rate for such remittances became LT 13.850 per US$1. September 20. Authorized banks were allowed to open foreign exchange deposit accounts in the names of foreign nationals resident in Turkey and of Turkish nationals working abroad. Banks could pay interest on these accounts at rates corresponding to those ruling abroad. November 12. The bilateral payments agreement with Hungary expired. November 15. It was announced that the foreign ex- change allocation for Turkish tourists traveling on a collective passport could not exceed US$200 a person a year (US$100 for those under 18). December 12. The regulation governing short-term borrowing abroad for the purpose of financing exports was amended. Henceforth, such credits could be taken up only in foreign currencies sold or bought by the Central Bank, and the payment of interest was prohib- ited. If no exports took place within three months after the borrowing, the credits had to be repaid within the following month in the currency originally obtained. Not for Redistribution UGANDA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.103133 gram of f ine gold per Uganda Shilling. A central rate of U Sh 7.14286 = US$1 has been established, and Uganda avails itself of wider margins. The Bank of Uganda does not deal in foreign currencies1 other than deutsche mark, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars; its rates for the U.S. dollar are based on the central rate, and its rates for deutsche mark and pounds sterling are based on the previous day's New York rates against the U.S. dollar. On De- cember 31, 1974, the Bank's buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were U Sh 7.1407 and U Sh 7.1471, respectively. Authorized commercial banks in Uganda deal in all specified currencies2 and base their rates on the previous day's closing rates against the U.S. dollar in New York, except for Kenya shillings and Tanzania shillings, which are dealt in at par. Authorized banks may freely deal forward w i th customers in sterling, U.S. dollars, and other currencies, provided that there is an underlying approved import or export contract and that the term of the fo rwa rd contract does not exceed three months; contracts for longer periods require ex- change control approval. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Uganda on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Import and export control is administered by the Ministry of Commerce and Indus t ry and the Uganda Advisory Board of Trade under the External Trade Act (as amended) and by the Bank of Uganda. The Minister of Commerce and Indus t ry has powers to prohibit im- ports and exports. Together with Kenya and Tanzania, Uganda is part of the East African currency area but exchange control is applied to both Kenya and Tanza- nia. Prescription of Currency Uganda has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory under the terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a coun try of the Overseas Sterling Area. All payments to Kenya and Tanzania must be effected in the currencies of those countries through accounts held with each other by the central banks concerned. Payments to residents of countries in the Sterling Area other than Kenya, Tanzania, and South Africa may be made in Uganda shillings to the credit of a Sterling Area Account in Uganda or in any other Sterling Area currency; receipts from such countries may be obtained in Uganda shillings from a Sterling Area Account in Uganda or in any convertible currency. Authorized payments, including payments for imports, by residents of Uganda to residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Israel, Portugal (and its overseas territories), or Rhodesia may be made to an External Account in any Sterling Area country, in Uganda shillings to the credit of an Exter- nal Account in Uganda, or in any other non-Sterling Area currency except Rhodesian currency that is ap- propriate to the country of residence of the payee. Receipts from countries outside the Sterling Area other than Israel, Portugal (and its overseas territories), or Rhodesia may be obtained in Uganda shillings from an External Account, in any Sterling Area specified currency from an External Account, or in any other specified currency that is not a Sterling Area currency. Payments to Israel, Portugal (and its overseas territo- ries), Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Cer- tain settlements with Burundi, Rwanda, and Zaire are channeled through special accounts. Nonresident Accounts Sterling Area Accounts are held by residents of other Sterling Area countries except Kenya and Tanzania. They may be credited freely with all authorized pay- ments to such Sterling Area countries by Ugandan resi- dents, with transfers from other Sterling Area Accounts, with transfers from External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales to an authorized dealer in Uganda of any foreign currency or gold by residents of any other country in the Sterling Area except Kenya and Tanzania. They may be debited freely for payments for exports to other countries in the Sterling Area and other payments due by residents of other countries in the Sterling Area to Ugandan residents, for payments to residents of other countries in the Sterling Area for any purpose, for transfers to other Sterling Area Ac- counts in Uganda, for purchases of any Sterling Area currency, and for withdrawals by the account holder while he is temporarily resident in Uganda; provided that permission of the appropriate exchange control authorities in a Sterling Area country has been ob- tained, Sterling Area Accounts may exceptionally be debited for transfers to External Accounts in Uganda or elsewhere in the Sterling Area, and for purchases in Uganda of any non-Sterling Area currency or gold. Accounts in Uganda shillings held by residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Israel, Portugal (and its overseas territories), or Rhodesia with authorized banks are, with exchange control approval, designated External Accounts. They may be credited freely with authorized payments to such countries by residents of Uganda, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any non-Sterling Area currency (other than Israel, Portu- guese, or Rhodesian currency) and gold by nonresi- dents of the Sterling Area to authorized dealers; provided that the permission of the appropriate ex- 483 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA change control authorities in a Sterling Area country has been obtained. External Accounts may also be credited with transfers from Sterling Area Accounts. They may be debited freely for payments to residents of the Sterling Area, for transfers to other External Accounts in Uganda or in any other Sterling Area country, and for purchases of non-Sterling Area cur- rencies from authorized dealers. Nontransferable funds of persons not resident in Uganda are credited to Blocked Accounts. Subject to prior approval, balances on Blocked Accounts may be used for the purchase in Uganda of specified bonds and shares issued in Uganda; the redemption proceeds of government bonds so acquired are transferable begin- ning five years from the date of purchase. Subject to individual permission, such balances may also be used for payments to residents not related to export transac- tions. Transfers between Blocked Accounts in Uganda, and to Blocked Accounts in Kenya and Tanzania, re- quire prior approval. All Blocked Accounts must be held with the Uganda Commercial Bank. Imports and Import Payments All permitted imports require approval by the Uganda Advisory Board of Trade. Monthly allocations of foreign exchange for private sector and public sector imports together are limited in principle to a total of U Sh 100 million. Some imports from all sources are prohibited for reasons of public policy; imports prohib- ited for other reasons include passenger automobiles, cotton fabrics, blankets, electrical home refrigerators, transistor radios, and matches. There is an open general license for monthly imports up to U Sh 4.5 million each of milk and wheat. Import license applications are screened by eight specified companies, which are super- vised by the Uganda Advisory Board of Trade. Upon approval of the application, the importer must lodge a commission of 1 per cent of the license amount with the Uganda Advisory Board of Trade. All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited and imports from Portuguese-controlled territories in Af- rica are not being licensed. Imports normally must be purchased direct from the country of origin. Some im- ports of manufactured goods from Kenya and Tanza- nia are subject to transfer taxes. Documentary evidence showing that the goods have been imported into Uganda must be forwarded to the exchange control authorities within six months from the date of payment. Payments for nonessential im- ports are normally made after arrival of the goods, but advance payment is permitted for essential goods. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries are subject to approval by the Bank of Uganda and those to Portugal (and its overseas territories), Rhodesia, and South Af- rica are prohibited. The basic allowance for travel out- side Uganda is the equivalent of U Sh 3,000 a person 484 every three years, which may be taken out in foreign banknotes. The allowance is available for travel to any country except Kenya and Tanzania, for which nor- mally holiday facilities of up to U Sh 1,000 a person a year are available, and Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa, for which no allocation is granted. Sala- ried noncitizens recruited from outside East Africa may obtain allocations for travel outside East Africa at the time of their overseas leave. No foreign exchange is released for nursery, primary, and secondary education abroad except for children of diplomats, technical assistance personnel, nonnationals working in Uganda on overseas terms, nonnational missionaries, and other special cases. Facilities exist whereby salaried foreign nationals may during their stay in Uganda remit to their country of origin up to 33Y3 per cent of their gross monthly earnings, to cover family maintenance, savings, etc., provided that they are on a contract of employment which includes a firm commitment to leave Uganda upon expiry of the con- tract. The export of Uganda banknotes and coins by travel- ers is prohibited, except that travelers to Kenya and Tanzania may take out U Sh 100 in Uganda currency. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require licenses and may be restricted to ensure sufficient supplies for consumption in Uganda. All exports to Israel, South Africa, the Portuguese- controlled territories in Africa, and Rhodesia are pro- hibited. The Uganda Tea Board has a monopoly over the export of tea. Export proceeds in specified currencies2 must be col- lected within six months of exportation and offered to an authorized bank in Uganda for conversion into Uganda shillings. Coffee, cotton, copper, and hides and skins are subject to export duty. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies2 must be sold to an authorized bank. The import of Uganda banknotes and coins by travelers is prohibited, except that returning Ugandan residents may bring in U Sh 100 a person. Travelers may freely bring in foreign currency notes and foreign currency travelers checks. Capital Capital transfers to all countries are restricted and those to Israel, Portugal (and its overseas territories), Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Residents of Uganda, however, may be granted exemptions from the deposit and surrender requirements in respect of foreign assets for specified Sterling Area assets held prior to June 11, 1965. Capital transfers require individual exchange control approval. Residents of Uganda leaving permanently may normally transfer their assets up to the equivalent ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution of U Sh 50,000. The allowance is reduced by the amount of insurance premiums remitted after 1965 out- side the facilities for remittance of savings. A fur ther transfer of up to the equivalent of U Sh 20,000 upon each anniversary of the emigrant's departure is allowed. All remaining funds must be credited to a Blocked Account and may either be invested in certain ap- proved securities or held on deposit with commercial banks in Uganda; such funds become transferable after five years. The income from such investments is trans- ferable also during the period when the funds are blocked. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Uganda; to secure guaranteed repatriation, however, it is necessary to obtain "approved status" for the investment in terms of the Foreign Investments (Protection) Act, 1964, which in normal circumstances is given freely. Foreign and domestic investment in specified types of production require approval under the East African Industrial Licensing Act and the Uganda Licensing Act, 1969. Dividends and profits due to nonresidents from normal trading operations and distributed by companies operating in Uganda are in principle transferable, All imports and exports of securities require ap- proval. Approval is freely granted for the purchase by nonresidents of Ugandan securities, provided that pay- ment is received in an appropriate manner. The income from such securities is remittable, and the proceeds on resale are normally remittable also. Purchases of securi- ties outside Uganda by residents are not normally per- mitted. A resident of Uganda may not send, as a g if t, to any coun try more than U Sh 100 a year without specific exchange control approval. With minor exceptions, prior exchange control ap- proval is required for loans or overdraft facilities granted to a nonresident or to a body corporate resi- dent in Uganda which is by any means controlled, whether directly or indirectly, by persons resident out- side Uganda. Gold A commemorative gold coin w i th a face value of U Sh 500 is legal tender but does not circulate. Resi- dents may hold and acquire gold coins in Uganda for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in Uganda in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a trav- eler require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance. Export licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and UGANDA industrial users. The import of the following from all sources is subject to individual licensing: jewelry of gold, silver, or platinum; goldsmiths' or silversmiths' wares, including set gems; bullion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coins. Import licenses for gold bullion (ingots, bars, or sheets), gold jewelry, and gold coins are issued restrictively and only to goldsmiths. Changes during 1974 January 14. The central rate was changed from U Sh 6.90000 = US$1 to U Sh 7.14286 = US$1. Uganda continued to avail itself of wider margins. The relationship to the Kenya shilling and the Tanzania shilling remained unchanged. New buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were set at U Sh 7.1407 and U Sh 7.1471, respectively, per US$1. March 27. The Uganda Tea Board was established. It was given a monopoly over the export and sale abroad of tea grown or manufactured in Uganda. April 2. The Bank of Uganda substantially reduced the amount of foreign exchange that commercial banks were permitted to hold as working balances. Excess amounts had to be transferred to the Bank of Uganda. April 22. The Uganda Advisory Board of Trade De- cree, 1974 abolished the State Trading Corporation and established the Uganda Advisory Board of Trade, whose func t ions included the supervision and coordi- nation of the activities of eight specified companies. Private importers were henceforth required to apply through one of the eight specified companies for their licenses and foreign exchange allocations. April 22. The External Trade Act (Amendment) De- cree, 1974 provided that, notwithstanding the repeal of the State Trading Corporation Decree, 1972, any statu- tory order made under section 2 of that decree and in force immediately prior to the repeal would remain in force until revoked. June 13. An export du ty on copper was reintro- duced. September 2. The basic exchange allowance for travel within East Africa was increased from U Sh 500 to U Sh 1,000, and that for travel outside East Africa from U Sh 2,000 to U Sh 3,000. November 2. Remittances of prof i ts and dividends to nonresidents henceforth could only be made in respect of a completed trading year. Not for Redistribution UNITED ARAB EMIRATES l (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System On February 23, 1974, the United Arab Emirates established an initial par value of 0.186621 gram of fine gold per U.A.E. Dirham, corresponding at the time to Dh 1 = SDR 0.21. The United Arab Emirates avails itself of wider margins. The United Arab Emirates Cur- rency Board establishes daily quotations for the Bel- gian franc, the deutsche mark, the French franc, the Lebanese pound, the pound sterling, the Swiss franc, and the U.S. dollar. The rate of exchange for the U.S. dollar against the dirham is fixed daily at the discretion of the Board within the limits of the wider margins. Rates for other currencies are fixed in relation to the U.S. do l lar /d irham rate and the previous day's closing rates in New York. The Board deals with commercial banks, rulers of states, governments, and quasigovern- ment institutions. On December 31, 1974 the Board's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were Dh 3.978 and Dh 3.983, respectively, per US$1. The United Arab Emirates formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement on February 13, 1974. Administration of Control There is neither exchange control legislation nor an exchange control authority in the United Arab Emi- rates, and there are no registration requirements for inward or outward transfers. The United Arab Emi- rates has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Import and export licenses, where required, are issued by the authorities of the Emirate concerned. Prescription of Currency All settlements with Israel are prohibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Israel are prohibited, as are imports of products manufactured by foreign companies black- listed by the Arab League. Imports of a few commodi- ties are prohibited from all sources for moral, health, or security reasons. Virtually all other commodities may be freely imported without an individual import permit, but only licensed parties can enter the import trade and each importer can import only the commodity or com- modities specified in his license. In Abu Dhabi, certain 486 commodities (mainly rice, sugar, and flour) are im- ported by the state trading company, which, however, does not have an import monopoly in any commodity. There are no restrictions on the availability of foreign exchange for payments in respect of permitted imports. Payments for Invisibles All payments for current invisibles may be made freely, except to Israel. Travelers may take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel are prohibited. Virtually all com- modities may be exported freely, without an export license, to any other destination. Each Emirate estab- lishes its own export regulations. There are no require- ments attached to receipts from exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surrendered, and they may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no requirements attached to receipts from current invisibles. Travelers may bring in any amount in foreign or domestic banknotes. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresi- dents. Transactions and settlements involving Israel, however, are prohibited. Profits on foreign capital in- vested in the United Arab Emirates may be remitted freely. Gold With the exception noted below, residents and non- residents, including private persons, may freely pur- chase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. They may also, without an individual import or export permit, import and export gold in any form, but the import of gold for trade, like that of any other commodity, may only be undertaken by licensed parties. Transactions involving Israel or companies blacklisted by the Arab League are prohibited. Gold bullion is exempt from import duty but jewelry is not. Changes during 1974 February 12. The Currency Board instructed com- mercial banks to limit the spread between buying and selling rates for all currencies to no more than 2 per cent. ©International Monetary Fund.
