Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Pound Sterling. Since June 23, 1972, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the pound within announced margins, and therefore all transac- tions in the official exchange market, except those in currencies maintaining a fixed relationship with ster- ling, take place at a f luc tua t ing exchange rate. The closing selling and buying rates in the foreign exchange market for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1974 were US$2.3490 and US$2.3500 per £1, respectively. Authorized banks are allowed to engage in spot and forward exchange transactions in any currencies, ex- cept Rhodesian currency, subject to the observance of limits on open positions and the accumulation of spot foreign exchange. Forward rates may fluctuate under the influence of market forces; transactions with resi- dent customers may be entered in to only for approved purposes, where there is an underlying commercial con- tract (or where an exporter is tendering for an overseas export contract), and in the currency of the contract. There is also a market (referred to as the investment currency market) in which certain foreign currency pro- ceeds,1 resulting mainly from the sale outside the Scheduled Territories (the United Kingdom, the Chan- nel Islands, the Isle of Man, the Republic of Ireland,2 and Gibraltar) of foreign currency securities,3 and of most personal residential property situated outside the Scheduled Territories may be negotiated at freely deter- mined rates, usually attracting a premium over the offi- cial market rate; at the end of 1974, that premium was about 69Y2 per cent calculated at the ruling U.S. dollar rate in the official exchange market, the middle closing rate on December 31 being £1 = US$1.3807. These funds are normally available for reinvestment in mar- ketable foreign currency securities, for approved pur- chases of personal residential property in countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia, and, although little used for this purpose, for approved direct investments in non-Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia. The authorized banks may deal among themselves and with residents and nonresidents in foreign notes and coins (other than Rhodesian currency) at free mar- ket rates of exchange. The United Kingdom formally accepted the obliga- tions of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory In general, the United Kingdom does not impose restrictions on exchange transactions or payments and receipts between residents of the United Kingdom and residents of the Scheduled Territories. Exchange con- 488 trol applies mainly to transactions with residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories. The non-Scheduled Territories for administrative purposes are divided as follows: (1) the other member countries of the EEC, except the Republic of Ireland; (2) the Overseas Sterling Area (OSA), i.e., the countries other than the Republic of Ireland and Gibraltar which as at June 22, 1972 were treated as Scheduled Territories;4 (3) Rhodesia; and (4) all other countries, usually re- ferred to as the Rest of the Non-Scheduled Territories (RNST). Administration of Control Exchange control in the United Kingdom is adminis- tered by the Bank of England on behalf of the U.K. Treasury. However, practically all commercial banks are authorized to approve most current payments re- quiring exchange control permission. The licensing of imports and exports is handled by the Department of Trade. Prescription of Currency Receipts from Scheduled Territories may be in ster- ling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency; those from other countries, with the exception of Rhodesia, must be in sterling from an External Account or in any for- eign currency (other than Rhodesian currency), which must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless permission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Payments to Scheduled Territories may be made in sterling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency; payments to other countries, with the excep- tion of Rhodesia, may be made by crediting sterling to an External Account or in any foreign currency except Rhodesian currency. For security reasons, settlements with Rhodesia are subject to special regulations generally prescribing the use of Rhodesian Accounts, Suspense Accounts, or, in certain circumstances, the Rhodesian Special Account with the Standard Bank, London. However, unless spe- cifically included among the permitted debits to Rho- desian Accounts, all commercial payments, except those in respect of exports, due from persons resident in Rhodesia to residents of the United Kingdom must be received either in a foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or, with the specific permission of the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Account; authorized payments for exports from the United Kingdom to Rhodesia must be received in advance of shipment in a foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency, or, with the specific approval of the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Account. Persons normally resident in Rhode- sia who are living temporarily in the United Kingdom ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution as students or workers may open Temporary Resident Accounts in sterling with authorized banks in the United Kingdom; debits to such accounts are generally permitted only for living expenses within the United Kingdom. Nonresident Accounts The sterling accounts of residents of other Scheduled Territories are treated in the same way as those of residents of the United Kingdom. Thus, for transfers between Scheduled Territories no U.K. exchange con- trol permission is required; for payments to other countries by residents of any Scheduled Territory, the authorized banks are required to ensure that the pay- ment has the approval of the exchange control au thor- ity in the territory concerned. External Accounts. W i th the exception of Rhodesian Accounts and the Rhodesian Special Account (see be- low), the s ter l ing accounts of nonresidents w i th autho- rized banks in the United Kingdom, i.e., those of residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories, are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized payments by residents of Scheduled Territories, w i th t rans fe rs f rom other Exter- nal Accounts, w i th the proceeds f rom sales of gold or foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency (in- cluding banknotes), and w i th sterling banknotes mailed f rom outside the Scheduled Territories. Ex ternal Ac- counts may be debited, subject to general or special permission, for paymen ts to residents of the Scheduled Territories, for transfers to other Ex ternal Accounts, for t rans fe rs to Rhodesian Accounts other than in pay- ment for certain goods exported f rom Rhodesia, for payments in cash in the United Kingdom, and for pur- chases of any fore ign currency other than Rhodesian currency ( inc lud ing bankno tes) or gold. Rhodesian Accounts. These accounts are applicable to residents of Rhodesia only. Permitted credits include t rans fe rs f rom External Accounts, provided that the bank has no reason to believe that the payment is for a purpose prohibited by the Southern Rhodesia (United Na t ions Sanctions) (No. 2) Order 1968; pay- men ts by residents of Scheduled Territories other than the United Kingdom to residents of Rhodesia, subject to the approval of the exchange control au tho r i ty in the terr i tory concerned; and paymen ts by U .K. residents to residents of Rhodesia in respect of (1) the sale of foreign currencies other than Rhodesian currency, (2) the dis- count or ma tu r i ty proceeds of U.K. treasury bills, (3) permitted imports f rom Rhodesia which have entered customs in the Un i ted K ingdom, (4) insurance and f re ight charges resulting f rom permitted trade between Rhodesia and any Scheduled Terr i tory, (5) insurance claims directly related to such permitted trade, (6) pen- sions and widows' annu i t ies where associated w i th the deceased husband's employment, (7) charges and fees relating to patents, designs, and trademarks registered in Rhodesia, Zambia, or Malawi, (8) m a tu r i ty proceeds UNITED KINGDOM of certain endowment insurance policies, and (9) expen- diture in gathering news material. Permitted debits include transfers to the Rhodesian Special Account in respect of pensions and widows' annuities; payments for living expenses in the United Kingdom of persons resident in Rhodesia and their families; authorized purchases of U.K. sterling securi- ties to be held for the account holder; purchases in the United Kingdom of treasury bills to be held for the account holder; payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories for (1) interest on and repayment of out- standing personal loans, advances, and overdrafts granted before November 11, 1965, (2) patents, de- signs, trademarks, and royalties, (3) distributions from Rhodesian estates and trusts, and (4) subscriptions to newspapers and other periodicals; and payments to U .K. residents for (a) expenses arising out of property in the United Kingdom owned on or before Novem- ber 11 ,1965, (b) taxes, (c) educational fees and inciden- tal expenses, (d) insurance premiums and capital and annu i ty payments on personal policies taken out on or before November 11, 1965, (e) medical fees, (f) gifts and maintenance not exceeding £250 for any one pay- ment, to individuals and religious, medical, educa- tional, and charitable organizations, and subscriptions to such organizations, (g) contributions to pension funds provided the person was a member of the fund before November 11, 1965 or before taking up resi- dence in Rhodesia a f ter that date, and (h) bank and safe custody charges. Transfers between Rhodesian Ac- counts and from Rhodesian Accounts to External Ac- counts are not norma l ly allowed. Suspense Accounts. Unless eligible for credit to Rho- desian Accounts or to the Rhodesian Special Account, payments to persons resident in Rhodesia must be w i thhe ld unless the Bank of England directs otherwise; the funds may be placed on Suspense Accounts and, except w i th specific permission, may only be (1) used to meet U .K. tax payments and safe custody charges due on the monies in question, or (2) placed on deposit w i th banks or other f inanc ial ins t i tu t ions in the name of the U .K. resident by whom they are held. Permission is norma l ly given for residents of Rhodesia to use Sus- pense Account monies to purchase U.K. sterling securi- ties on a recognized stock exchange in the United Kingdom and to purchase U.K. treasury bills and sav- ings bonds and certificates. Permission is only given for them to purchase Rhodesian or foreign currency securi- ties, however, when the funds for the purchase are de- rived from the immediate sale proceeds of other Rhodesian or foreign currency securities, respec- t ive ly .5 The Rhodesian Special Account. This is an account operated by the Rhodesia Pensions Office s ta ff in Lon- don and ma in ta ined w i th the Standard Bank, London. Pensions and associated payments due to beneficiaries in Rhodesia from residents of the Scheduled Territories and the OSA, and pensions due f rom Rhodesia to resi- dents of the Un i ted Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, 489 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM and most parts of the OSA are normally settled through this account. Corresponding transfers from Rhodesian Accounts in the names of individuals to the Rhodesian Special Account are freely permitted. Per- mission is not normally given for payments of any other nature to be credited to the Rhodesian Special Ac- count. Subject to specific approval by the Bank of En- gland, any balance on the Special Account may be used to meet educational payments in the United Kingdom, the cost of permitted exports to Rhodesia from the Scheduled Territories and the OSA, and of services provided by residents of the Scheduled Territories and the OSA for account of persons resident in Rhodesia. Imports and Import Payments For import licensing purposes countries outside the United Kingdom other than Rhodesia6 are divided into eight groups: the Mediterranean Area,7 the Non-Com- mun i ty Area,8 the Non-CEFTA Area,9 the Dollar Area,10 Japan,11 Romania, the Eastern Area,12 and all other countries. Imports from countries other than Rhodesia are ad- mitted under an Open General Import License without restriction, with the following exceptions: (1) from all other countries, seven commodities or groups of com- modities;13'14 (2) from the Dollar Area only, four com- modities or groups of commodities; (3) from Japan only, certain textiles; (4) from the Non-CEFTA Area only, one commodity; (5) from the Non-Community Area only, one commodity; (6) from Romania only, two commodities; and (7) from the Eastern Area only, nine commodities or groups of commodities. Most arti- cles subject to import licensing can be imported in limited quantities under bilateral or global quotas. A few articles may be imported under open individual licenses, i.e., without limit as to quan t i ty or value. Im- ports of cereals and cereal products, beef and veal, mu t ton and lamb, poultry meat, and dairy products other than butter and cheese are subject to minimum import prices enforced through autonomously imposed variable import levies. Imports of many other agricul- tural, horticultural, and livestock products are subject to EEC regulations. Once licensing requirements have been met to import from countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia, whether under Open General Import License or some other form of license, U.K. residents may purchase foreign currency or credit sterling to an External Account to pay for the import, provided that evidence of customs entry is submitted or evidence that the goods have been dispatched to the United Kingdom or are to be dispatched immediately on receipt of pay- ment. Advance payments for imports are approved by the Bank of England where the payment is considered necessary or in accordance with the traditions of the trade and the continuance of the practice is considered to be essential. Current administrative practice is not to allow advance payments for consumer goods. Ex- 490 change control forms are not required for payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories; neither are they required for payments to residents of other countries, unless the payment represents part or final settlement for goods for which the total amount payable exceeds £5,000, and evidence of importation cannot be pres- ented to the bank before making the remittance. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of other Sched- uled Territories may be made freely. Payments to resi- dents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories require exchange control authorization, which (except for payments to residents of Rhodesia)15 is granted freely for all purposes other than sterling usance credits to finance trade directly between principals resident in non-Scheduled Territories outside the OSA, subject to the presentation of supporting evidence. The comple- tion of an exchange control form is required for pay- ments exceeding £1,000 or its equivalent. Authorized banks are permitted to approve applications for trans- fers on account of many categories of current invisibles without any limitation, and for other categories up to established limits. Applications for payments in excess of these limits or for purposes for which no delegation of authority has been granted are approved by the Bank of England, provided that no unauthorized capital out- flow is involved. Authorized banks may dispatch sterling banknotes to nonresidents except residents of Rhodesia against payment in sterling from an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. For any type of travel outside the Scheduled Territo- ries (except to Rhodesia), U.K. residents can obtain on demand from banks and authorized travel agents for- eign exchange up to the equivalent of £300 a person a trip; for travel for business or professional reasons, an allowance of £40 a day up to a maximum of £2,000 for any one journey can be authorized by banks and certain authorized travel agents. Applications for additional amounts are approved by the Bank of England unless there is reason to suspect that the exchange is to be used for purposes other than genuine travel expenditure. The cost of accommodation, fares, etc., can be paid for without limit in the United Kingdom. Travel exchange purchased in the United Kingdom must normally be recorded in the traveler's passport. Under arrange- ments agreed with certain banks, personal checks may be cashed abroad for travel purposes, up to £30 a check, if backed by check cards. Credit cards may be used freely to settle travel expenses. Resident travelers may take out up to £300 in foreign currency notes. Any unused travel exchange expressed in foreign currency may be retained for a period of one month from the date of return to the United Kingdom. Banks have authority to approve applications by U.K. residents who wish to open foreign currency accounts outside the Scheduled Territories for the receipt of travel funds for ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution use du r ing the ir stay abroad. Travel facilities expressed in sterling may be held for six mon ths from the date of issue or for one mon th from the date of re turn to the Un i ted K ingdom, if la ter. In add i t ion, resident trave l- ers may take w i th them up to £25 in U .K. and o ther Scheduled Terr i tory bankno tes, which may be ex- changed or spent abroad only for travel expenditure; but those t rave l ing direct to the Repub l ic of Ire land, the Channel Islands, or the Isle of Man may take out any amoun t. Visitors to the Un i ted K ingdom are, in add i t ion, allowed to take out any notes that they brought in w i th them, other than notes in excess of £25 expressed in the currencies of the Un i ted K ingdom or the Repub l ic of Ire land. Authorized banks are perm i t ted to approve, w i th in certain l im i ts and subject to the submission of appro- priate documen ta ry evidence of the amoun ts due, appli- ca t ions to pay fees, accommodation charges, and all inc iden tal expenses arising f rom the educa t ion of U .K. residents outside the Scheduled Territories. Special regulations app ly to all travel to Rhodesia. For approved o f f ic ial and essential business jou rneys the Bank of England will au tho r ize the issue of fore ign currency at a rate of up to £10 a day w i th a max imum of £300. Facilities for private travel are authorized only where there are compassionate grounds. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are subject to licensing control and licenses are normally issued only for the permitted exceptions (medical and educational supplies, food- s t u f fs where these are special medical preparations, news f i lm and pho tographs, and documen tary and printed ma t ter less than 100 years old) and for equip- ment for the essential replacement needs of the Rhode- sian Ra i lways and the Central African Power Corporation. V i r tua l ly all exports to other des t ina t ions are free of export control and no exchange control forms are normally required. Exporters to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia must norma l ly obtain appropriate payment w i th in six mon ths of sh ipmen t; special exchange control permis- sion to collect at a later date is required only where the exporter extends credit for more than six mon ths w i th- out cover f rom the Export Credits Guarantee Depart- ment (ECGD). Receipts in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless the recipi- ent has obtained specific permission to credit them to a retained currency account (subject to supervision) or permission has been given for them to be used for some other purpose. Permitted exports to Rhodesia must be paid for prior to shipment in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency or, if specific permission is granted by the Bank of England, in sterling f rom the Rhodesian Special Account. UNITED KINGDOM Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts in foreign currencies on account of invisi- bles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank, unless recipients of such currencies have permission to credit them to a retained currency account or to use them for some other purpose. British and other bank- notes may be brought in to the United Kingdom freely. Capital Residents of the United Kingdom who receive for- eign currency other than Rhodesian currency from cer- ta in capital account sources (mainly the sale or redemption of foreign currency securities and the sale of personal residential proper ty situated outside the Scheduled Territories) may, in certain circumstances and w i th permission, use the exchange (which is re- garded as inves tment currency once permission has been given) for the purchase of marketable foreign cur- rency securities, the purchase of personal residential property outside the Scheduled Territories, or the mak- ing of approved direct inves tmen ts outside the Sched- uled Territories; they may also sell the exchange for s ter l ing to other residents to be used for the same pur- poses. If permission is not forthcoming, the foreign currency must be offered for sale at the rates ruling in the official market to an authorized bank in the United K ingdom. If permission is gran ted, however, the equiv- alent in foreign currency of 25 per cent of the proceeds must normally be sold to an authorized bank for ster- l ing at the off ic ial ma rket rate of exchange.16'17 In cer- ta in circumstances, residents of the United Kingdom who have obtained exemption from their obligations under the Exchange Control Act in respect of assets denominated in any foreign currency other than Rho- desian currency may obtain permission for the sale pro- ceeds of exempted securities to be sold for sterling in the inves tment currency market up to 75 per cent of the amount concerned.18 In certain circumstances, ex- empted cash balances arising f rom the sale of property may also be sold as inves tment currency. There are no restrictions on capital transfers by resi- dents of the United Kingdom into the beneficial owner- ship of residents of other Scheduled Territories. All capital transfers by residents to countries outside the Scheduled Territories require approval. Each indi- vidual resident of the United Kingdom may, from his own resources, make cash gifts or personal loans not exceeding a total of £1,000, or the equ iva lent in foreign currency, du r ing each calendar year to residents of the OSA, as well as a fu r th er £300 or the equivalent to residents of other countries outside the Scheduled Ter- ritories except Rhodesia; additional amoun ts may be allowed under appropriate circumstances. The cash g i f ts allowance is noncumu la t ive and is not transferab le from one resident to another. A resident of the United Kingdom w i th dependents who are established resi- dents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia may make payments from his own 491 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM resources not exceeding £2,000 a year to support those dependents. Such payments, which may be gifts or loans, are outside the cash gift scheme and do not prejudice the normal cash gift allowances. For security reasons, no capital transfers are allowed to Rhodesia, whether in the form of direct investment or of the purchase of Rhodesian securities, or by any other means, except to relatives, or other Rhodesian residents where humanitarian reasons are given, to the extent of £75 during any period of two years. For direct investments in non-Scheduled Territories, official exchange is normally made available only for certain projects directly concerned with promoting ex- ports of goods and services where the prospective bene- fit to the U.K. balance of payments is expected to equal or exceed the total cost of the investment within 18 months and to continue thereafter; this benefit will normally occur by way of additional export receipts, but may also arise from profits and other foreign cur- rency receipts that would not take place without the investment. For such projects ("super-criterion" projects), official exchange may be made available up to £250,000 or 50 per cent of the total investment, whichever is larger; any balance must be financed by foreign currency borrowing, the use of investment cur- rency, the export free of payment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade forming an integral part of the in- vestment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresi- dents on appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an overseas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U.K. parent company, by approved profit reten- tion, or with foreign currency proceeds of disinvest- ment in the context of a group reorganization. Direct investment other than for super-criterion projects is considered on the basis that its capital cost should not fall directly upon the U.K. official foreign exchange reserves at least un t il an equivalent amount has been received in the United Kingdom by way of benefits arising from the investments; such investments can normally be financed by foreign currency borrow- ing, the use of investment currency, the export free of payment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade form- ing an integral part of the investment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresidents on appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an overseas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U.K. parent company, by approved profit retention, or w i th foreign currency pro- ceeds of disinvestment in the context of a group reorga- nization. The permitted proportion of retained foreign currency earnings normally is one third of net earnings after taxes, applied, if desired, on a global basis where more than one subsidiary is involved. The purchase outside the Scheduled Territories of marketable foreign currency securities for portfolio in- vestment must be financed either w i th investment cur- rency or with foreign currency borrowing. Such borrowing is freely permitted when undertaken by or through U.K. professional security managers, and the resale of foreign currency securities acquired in this 492 manner is exempt from the "25 per cent requirement" until the loan portfolio is liquidated and the profit repa- triated. Purchases of marketable foreign currency secu- rities with investment currency are freely permitted by virtue of certain general permissions granted to banks, stockbrokers, and other authorized depositories. Pur- chases from other residents may also be effected with sterling on The Stock Exchange (sterling prices reflect the prevailing investment currency premium). The purchase by U.K. residents of a house or an apartment for personal use in countries outside the Scheduled Territories requires specific approval and must be made either from another Scheduled Territory resident for sterling or another Scheduled Territory currency, or from a nonresident of the Scheduled Terri- tories with investment currency or borrowed foreign currency; payment for attendant expenses and im- provements, but not maintenance, must also be made with investment currency. (As an exception to this rule, residents temporarily employed in the OSA or member countries of the EEC may be authorized to purchase necessary accommodation at current official market rates of exchange.) Approval is normally limited to one property a family; purchases of investment currency are normally limited to reasonable amounts and may be made before exchange control approval is received pro- vided that the funds are held by an authorized deposi- tory and that a formal application is lodged to purchase the property w i th in six months. The approval authority for amounts up to £30,000 for a residential property has been delegated to authorized banks. All proceeds from the realization, redemption, or ma tur i ty of sterling capital assets (including direct in- vestments) owned by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories other than residents of Rhodesia are remit- table at the official rate of exchange. Payments to non- resident beneficiaries are authorized freely in respect of inheritances due from the estates of deceased residents; capital payments under life and other insurance policies taken up by nonresidents with resident insurance com- panies are also authorized freely. Residents of the United Kingdom who leave with the intention of residing for at least three years in a country outside the Scheduled Territories and apply to transfer their assets are, on their departure from the United Kingdom, regarded for exchange control purposes as nonresidents, and, with the following exceptions, their assets are treated accordingly. Repatriates (non-Sched- uled Territory nationals or citizens, other than Rhode- sians, who having been resident in the United Kingdom return to take up residence in any country outside the Scheduled Territories) may normally transfer all their sterling assets abroad at the official rate of exchange. Other residents leaving to take up residence in countries outside the Scheduled Territories and the OSA except Rhodesia are allowed on departure to transfer for a fam i ly unit up to £5,000 through the official foreign exchange market (£20,000 for older per- sons) and may export any foreign currency securities ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution they hold; the remaining declared assets in excess of £5,000 are restricted for a fou r -year period from the date of the depar t ing person's redesignation as a non- resident. U .K. residents tak ing up residence and em- p loyment in member countries of the EEC, however, may, w i th specific approva l, t rans fer sterling assets at the official ra te of exchange in excess of the £5,000 limit where this is necessary in order to ensure their freedom to take up the employment in question. For emigration to the OSA, the basic settling-in al- lowance is £20,000 (with a similar concession for those tak ing up emp loymen t), also available at the off ic ial rate of exchange, and holdings of foreign currency secu- rities are exportable. During the fou r -year period the restricted funds may be disposed of for foreign curren- cies other than Rhodesian currency th rough the invest- ment currency marke t, or may be invested in sterling securities which are quoted on The Stock Exchange, the income the re f rom being f ree ly remittable th rough the off ic ial exchange marke t. A f t er the fou r -year period any rema in ing assets are transferab le in accordance w i th the rules then applicable to the assets of a nonresident; at present, the t rans fer at the off ic ial ra te of exchange is norma l ly allowed. The par t ic ipa t ion of fore ign capital as a direct invest- ment in the Un i ted K ingdom is subject to ind iv idual au thor iza t ion, wh ich is norma l ly granted, provided that adequate capital for the project is supplied in an approved manner of payment (see section on Prescrip- tion of Currency, above) or by the impo rt of goods and services; the fore ign currency received must be surren- dered at rates ru l ing in the off ic ial market unless per- mission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Cases invo lv ing the take-over of existing companies that by the ir size or na tu re cons t i tu te a vital part of British indu s t ry are considered on the ir merits. Permissions given for direct inves tmen ts in the Un i ted K ingdom by nonresidents are norma l ly, unless other- wise agreed w i th the Bank of England, conditional on the consideration being paid in sterling f rom an Exter- nal Account or in fore ign currency (other than Rhode- sian currency) and, where nonresidents (other than residents of the EEC and the OSA) have a controlling interest, on any subsequent f inance being provided in fore ign currency or External Account s ter l ing at least in propor t ion to the nonresident interest in the equ i ty of the company. The acquisition in any manner by any person not resident in the Un i ted Kingdom of 10 per cent or more of the ou ts tand ing shares of a company registered in the Un i ted Kingdom requires prior ex- change control approva l. Foreign f irms and foreign ind iv idua ls must obtain permission f rom the Treasury in order to raise capital in the United K ingdom, and U .K. resident subsidiaries of foreign companies are required to obtain consent before issuing shares or other securities to nonresidents. U .K. residents also need permission to lend to U.K. companies controlled by nonresidents. Such permission is normally given for sterling lending for the purpose of UNITED KINGDOM f inanc ing the company's day-to-day business, but is not normally given for any expansion of manufac tur ing capacity except for companies whose activities are re- garded as bringing special advantages to the U.K. economy. There are three impo r tant exceptions to these principles: (1) Unlimited sterling finance in the United Kingdom is normally allowed to U.K. companies in which any nonresidents have less than a controlling interest, except to companies which are purely vehicles for portfolio inves tmen t. (2) U.K. companies con- trolled by residents of the EEC or the OSA that are not pure ly vehicles for po r t fo l io inves tment are norma l ly allowed unlimited sterling finance for their operations anywhere in the United Kingdom. (3) U .K. companies controlled by residents of any non-EEC coun try out- side both the Scheduled Territories and the OSA are upon application allowed similar facilities in respect of new expenditure in the areas of the United K ingdom which qua l i fy for special government assistance (the assisted areas), while their requests in respect of new expend i ture in other areas of the Un i ted Kingdom are considered on their merits. U .K. banks are proh ib i ted f rom prov id ing sterling loans or ove rd ra f ts to persons resident outside the Scheduled Territories and the OSA for the purpose of f inanc ing trade between non-Scheduled Territories, but sterling lend ing to residents of the OSA to f inance trade w i th such non-Scheduled Territories is unrestricted. Borrow ing by U .K. residents f rom nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories to f inance expenditure in the Un i ted Kingdom is subject to restriction. Private sector U .K. residents other than authorized banks normally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency f rom non- residents of the Scheduled Territories for conversion in to sterling for use in the United Kingdom, or to f inance current paymen ts to nonresidents of the Sched- uled Territories, unless the term of the borrow ing is at least two years (f ive years in the case of borrow ing for personal consumption, p rope r ty development, or f in an- cial transactions); exporters, merchants, and certain commodity traders are, however, permitted to borrow foreign currency for shorter periods f rom authorized banks or f rom nonresidents to f inance the ir sales or in some cases stock holdings. Public sector bodies nor- mally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency unless the term of the foreign borrowing is at least f ive years. Authorized banks must not lend foreign cur- rency to U .K. residents other than authorized banks for any other purpose w i thout prior reference to the Bank of England. U .K. companies normally are not permit- ted to borrow External Account sterling f rom nonresi- dents of the Scheduled Territories unless the term of the borrow ing is at least two years. Under certain permissions delegated to authorized depositories, transactions in securities of most types may generally be carried out freely between residents of the United Kingdom, except that transactions in Rho- desian securities may only be effected on The Stock Exchange. Residents are normally permitted, subject 493 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM to certain conditions, to sell foreign currency securities outside the Scheduled Territories, and, after 25 per cent of the proceeds has been sold to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange, to reinvest the balance of the exchange proceeds (investment cur- rency) in marketable foreign currency securities, or to sell the exchange to other residents for such invest- ments or for certain approved direct investment outside the Scheduled Territories. When foreign currency secu- rities are sold on The Stock Exchange for sterling, an amount of investment currency in the form of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be purchased in the investment currency market for resale to an au- thorized bank at the official market rate of exchange. Professional dealers making a "book" may on appli- cation be exempt from the 25 per cent requirement in respect of transactions on the "book." Investment cur- rency held for a continuous period of 6 months nor- mally ceases to be investment currency unless an amount of investment currency in the form of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the amount held is, at the end of the 6-month period, sold to an authorized bank at the cur- rent market rate in the official foreign exchange market. Investment currency may normally be retained as in- vestment currency for a maximum of 12 months, after which period any amount remaining must be offered for sale to an authorized bank at the current market rate in the official foreign exchange market.19 Professional security managers acting on their own behalf and for clients are permitted, subject to certain conditions, to borrow foreign currency for the purpose of making portfolio investments in marketable foreign currency securities. U.K. jobbers and other security dealers may, w i th permission, arrange day-to-day bor- rowing of foreign currency, whether from U.K. banks or from nonresidents, to finance a "book" in foreign currency securities, but not to finance holdings of such securities as investments. Residents of other Scheduled Territories are not pre- vented by the U.K. regulations from buying and selling sterling securities in the United Kingdom; they may also buy and sell, subject to certain conditions, Rhode- sian securities on The Stock Exchange, but they must obtain the permission of the U.K. authorities to buy and sell other securities in the United Kingdom. Permission is required for all transfers of securities in the United Kingdom in which a nonresident of the Scheduled Territories is involved as either transferor or transferee, but most transfers are covered by a general authority. In most cases, U.K. companies may issue sterling securities (including bearer securities) under a general permission given by the U.K. authorities. Nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesian residents may buy sterling securities on The Stock Exchange against payment in foreign currency or in sterling from an External Account. Securities so pur- chased may be exported from the United Kingdom. 494 Foreign currency securities may be bought and sold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories on The Stock Exchange for settlement in foreign currency or, in cer- tain circumstances, for settlement in sterling excluding the investment currency premium. Nonresidents must obtain permission to buy securities in the United King- dom other than on The Stock Exchange, whether or not the securities are quoted on a stock exchange. Nonresi- dents other than Rhodesian residents may sell sterling securities in the United Kingdom for sterling which may be held on External Account or, alternatively, may be transferred abroad at official market rates. All trans- actions in securities by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia require the specific approval of the Bank of England.20 Except in respect of U.K. companies controlled by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories (where Bank of England consent is required), warrants issued by registrars, company secretaries, and paying agents in respect of capital payments on matured securities regis- tered in the names of nonresidents other than Rhode- sian residents may be dispatched freely to addresses outside the Scheduled Territories. These warrants may be paid by crediting sterling to an External Account. Authorized banks may freely accept foreign currency deposits and employ them in their foreign currency business. They may also switch such deposits into ster- ling on a covered basis. Individual ceilings are set on each bank's overall open position in foreign currencies and on the amount of spot assets which may be held against forward liabilities in foreign currencies. The Bank of England has authority to call for differential Special Deposits against increases in overseas sterling liabilities, but this authority has not so far been in- voked. Gold21 Residents of the United Kingdom may freely buy, hold, sell, borrow, or lend domestic and foreign gold coins. With this exception, residents of the United Kingdom other than the monetary authorities and au- thorized industrial and professional users are not per- mitted to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, whether at home or abroad, unless they are specifically or generally permitted to do so. Permis- sion is granted restrictively and is generally limited to established genuine domestic requirements for indus- trial and professional purposes (including the manufac- ture of gold medals, medallions, etc.). The Mint from time to time strikes gold sovereigns. Although legal tender, these do not circulate in the United Kingdom. Gold coins which are legal tender have also been issued in Jersey and the Isle of Man. Except under license granted by the Treasury, it is an offense to melt down or break up any metal coin which is for the time being current in the United Kingdom or which, having been current there, has at any time after May 16, 1969 ceased to be so. ©International Monetary Fund. The export of gold bullion and all gold coins requires prior exchange control approval. Au- tho r i ty has been given to authorized dealers in gold to issue licenses in respect of exports of gold bullion and coin purchased by any non-Scheduled Territory resi- dent in the London gold market against payment in External Account sterling or foreign currency. A li- cense is required f rom the Department of Trade for the export of gold (and other) jewe l ry, etc., con ta in ing diamonds. The export of gold in manu fac tu red form over 100 years old and valued at £4,000 and over also requires a license from the Department of Trade. Manu fac tu res of gold may be impor ted w i thout quan t i ta t ive restriction under Open General Impo rt Li- cense f rom all sources except Rhodesia. There is a free gold market in London in which gold bars are f ree ly traded among (1) authorized dealers in gold, (2) any nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories, and (3) residents of the OSA who are sellers of new production. The U .K. authorities do not in tervene in the market as either buyers or sellers. A commission of Y4 of 1 per cent is charged on all purchases; there is no commission on sales. Authorized banks may enter in to fo rw a rd transactions in gold w i thout prior permission f rom the Bank of Eng land. Banks may also f inance purchases of gold by nonres iden ts of the Scheduled Territories by lending foreign exchange and accept gold as collateral for advances in fore ign currencies or Exter- nal Account s ter l ing to nonres iden ts of the Scheduled Territories. Changes during 1974 January 1. The second reduction of 20 per cent in impo rt du t ies on goods or ig ina t ing in EEC member countries took e f fec t. This was accompanied by the f i r st 20 per cent reduction in duties on ho r t icu l tu ral prod- ucts of EEC origin. In add i t ion, there was a f i r st move toward the adop t ion of the common EEC ta r i ff on impor ts f rom non-EEC countries, and, except in two respects, the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) of the EEC superseded that of the Un i ted Kingdom. Tar iffs on impor ts f rom the developed member countries of the Commonwea l th were raised, but ta r i ff preferences for other Commonwealth countries re- mained unchanged, the rates of du ty being maintained where they were lower than the t rans i t ional rates. Tar- i f fs on processed food s tu f fs f rom other developed countries were increased. Textiles f rom developing countries outside the Commonwealth were exempted f rom customs duties under the EEC's GSP scheme. January 1. A large increase in the import quota for Cuban cigars came in to effec t. The quo ta for cigars of UNITED KINGDOM Dollar Area origin also was increased, in accordance with the timetable agreed w i th the United States in July 1973 for the phasing out of the U.K.'s Dollar Area quo ta restrictions. January L A modification was made to the scheme for export f inance provided by the clearing banks for periods of two years and over and guaranteed by the ECGD. The single fixed rate, which had stood at 6 per cent since March 1972, was abolished and replaced by a two-tier system. Business transacted on credit terms of two to f ive years would carry a fixed rate of 7 per cent, but for over f ive years there would be a range of rates from 6 per cent to 8V2 per cent, w i th a specific rate w i th in that range being fixed by the ECGD for each contract. In accordance w i th international commit- ments, the rate for shipbuilding (including exports of ships) would remain at 7 per cent, regardless of the length of the credit. January 10. Exports of cocoa and cocoa products to all destinations were brought under specific license. January 17. A supplementary quota was established for imports of bananas from the Dollar Area. Further increases were announced on Janua ry 31, October 3, and October 24. February L Exports of petroleum oils and products in ind iv idual consignments of less than 100 tons, and exports of lubr ica t ing oils, were placed on Open Gen- eral License. February 18. As a result of the effects of a miners' strike, exports of coal and steel products were brought under licensing control, irrespective of destination. It was announced that licenses for these exports would be issued only in exceptional cases. The restrictions were removed w i th effect f rom Ju ly 1. March 15. The Treasury announced that the Govern- ment had under taken to extend its guarantee on certain official s ter l ing reserves of Sterling Area countries for a fu r th er n ine -mon th period, effec t ive f rom April 1, 1974 to December 31, 1974. The new guarantee ar- rangements would incorporate modifications to the ar- rangements due to expire on March 31, 1974, and would include a f u r t h er general reduction of 10 per cent in the m in imum sterling proportions and a change in the determination of the guarantee, which would be expressed in terms of the effective depreciation of ster- l ing f rom the Smithsonian parities —the exchange rate for sterling in terms of a trade weighted average of ma jor currencies. The guarantee would be given at the average effec t ive depreciation of sterling in the preced- ing six-month guarantee period (18.35 per cent below the Smithsonian rate) and would be implemented if the average effective depreciation of sterling in the period of the new guarantee was below the guarantee rate. If implemented, the guarantee would be settled in ster- ling, derived as the sum necessary to restore the value of eligible balances, calculated at the implementation rate, to their value calculated at the guarantee rate. (The eligible sterling balances of official holders were the total amounts of sterling held on September 24, 495 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM 1973 or March 29, 1974 or December 31, 1974, less the greater of either 10 per cent of total reserves or the value of sterling equities on the relevant date, which- ever was the lowest. Where 10 per cent of total reserves was deducted, the amount would not exceed that de- ducted during the previous implementation.) March 23. Agreement was reached with other mem- ber countries of the EEC providing for special treat- ment under the Common Agricultural Policy for certain sectors in the United Kingdom. The agreement permitted the continuation of existing subsidy arrange- ments and the introduction of temporary subsidies on the production of beef, pig meat, and butter. March 26. The Chancellor of the Exchequer an- nounced that the Government would borrow US$2.5 billion in the Euro-dollar market. The agreement was signed on May 7. March 26. The swap credit line between the Bank of England and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York was increased from US$2 billion to US$3 billion. March 27. A number of changes were introduced to the exchange control rules for direct and portfolio in- vestment. Their main effect was to terminate certain long-standing preferential treatment for the OSA and similar treatment accorded since early 1972 to the EEC. (1) The rules governing finance for outward di- rect investment in the OSA and EEC became the same as those applying to other Non-Scheduled Territories. Official exchange henceforth was available only for "super-criterion" projects and U.K. companies were normally expected to finance new investments in the OSA and the EEC by borrowing foreign currency or by one of the other permitted methods not involving the use of official exchange. (2) U.K. companies henceforth were expected normally to arrange for the repatriation to the United Kingdom of at least two thirds of the net after-tax earnings of their OSA subsidiaries, a require- ment already observed with respect to subsidiaries in other Non-Scheduled Territories (including the EEC). (3) The proceeds of the sale or liquidation of direct investments in Non-Scheduled Territory countries out- side both the EEC and OSA ceased to be eligible for sale in the investment currency market. These proceeds thereby had to be offered for sale for sterling at the official market rate of exchange, as had been applicable to realization proceeds in OSA and EEC countries. (4) Proceeds accruing to U.K. residents from the redemp- tion or sale of securities payable or optionally payable in OSA currencies (which since June 23, 1972 had been eligible for transaction in the investment currency mar- ket) became subject to the same 25 per cent surrender rules applicable to such proceeds of securities payable or optionally payable in non-Sterling Area currencies. March 28. The Chancellor of the Exchequer an- nounced that the Royal Mint would resume the pro- duction of gold sovereigns. None had been minted since 1968. March 31. The guarantee under the sterling guaran- tee arrangements for the period September 25, 1973 to 496 March 31, 1974 was implemented, in sterling, to com- pensate for the difference between the rate of US$2.3335 (the average of the daily U.S. dollar rate for sterling in that period) and the guarantee rate of US$2.4213. April 1. Changes in export insurance arrangements by the ECGD came into effect which provided for the inclusion of cover against buyer default in policies for trade between third countries when arranged and fi- nanced by U.K. merchants. April 1. The new Government announced that it pro- posed to seek a renegotiation of the terms of the United Kingdom's entry into the EEC. April 1. The rules for foreign currency borrowing by local authorities were modified. Following the estab- lishment of new local authorities grouping together ex- isting ones in England and Wales, the debt criterion for borrowing abroad, whether covered or uncovered, was increased from £100 million to £400 million; whereas previously eligible local authorities borrowed only on their own account, they were now expected to borrow on behalf of the county areas to which they belonged and the debt of their constituent parts counted toward their debt criteria. (In Scotland, however, the debt cri- terion of £100 million was retained, pending local au- thority reorganization in May 1975.) In addition, the reference date for the Government's lending rate used to calculate the rate payable by the borrower was changed from the date of draw-down to the date of the loan agreement. (The difference between the Govern- ment lending rate and the rate received by the lender, after allowing the borrower to keep a benefit of around 1 per cent, goes to the Treasury in return for a guaran- tee against exchange rate losses.) April 10. Henceforth, the Department of Trade was prepared to consider applications from any trader in- terested in the fruit-importing trade for individual im- port licenses for plantains of Dollar Area origin. May 30. The United Kingdom signed the OECD Declaration on Imports, Exports, and Other Current Account Transactions. June 20. It was announced that purchases of shares on The Stock Exchange by or on behalf of persons resident outside the Scheduled Territories would be exempted from the doubling of stamp duty introduced in the budget. With effect from August 1, the duty on such transactions was restored to 1 per cent. June 25. The published rules regarding sterling bor- rowing from nonresidents were amended to bring them into line with current exchange control practice. The amendments provided that U.K. companies would nor- mally be permitted to borrow External Account ster- ling from nonresidents provided that the loan was for a minimum term of two years and that the interest rate was fixed for the term of the loan at not more than Vz of 1 per cent above the Euro-dollar interbank rate for borrowing for the same period at the time the loan is taken up. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution July 4. The initial emigration allowance for older persons (i.e., where a member of the family unit, or an individual in the case of single persons, has attained 65 years for men or 60 years for women) emigrating to a country outside the Scheduled Territories other than OS A countries was increased from £5,000 to £20,000. Persons who had already emigrated and whose assets were subject to restriction were permitted to take out additional amounts up to £20,000, provided they met the specified age requirements. July 6. Exports of silver alloy coins to all countries outside the Scheduled Territories were made subject to individual licensing. Previously, individual licenses were required for Non-Scheduled Territory countries other than member countries of the EEC. Genuine nu- mismatic exports to EEC countries would not be re- stricted. July 15. Imports of cattle and beef from "third" countries were suspended in accordance with a decision of the EEC Ministers of Agriculture. July 18. The fixed lending rate for ships under the scheme for clearing bank finance guaranteed by the ECGD was raised from 7 per cent to 7V2 per cent, exclusive of bank and other charges. August 20. The Bank of England announced that most banks and deposit-taking institutions (including full subsidiaries of foreign banks but excluding clearing banks and branches of foreign banks) would be re- quired from September 30 to provide additional in fo r- mation for surveillance purposes, particularly with respect to maturities of sterling assets and liabilities. August 28. New exchange control regulations affect- ing the purchase and ownership by residents of prop- erty for private use outside the Scheduled Territories came into effect. (1) Authorized banks henceforth could approve applications by U.K. residents to pur- chase investment currency up to the equivalent of £30,000 to buy from nonresidents property abroad for private use (previously, all applications were consid- ered by the Bank of England). Banks approv ing the purchase of such property would also be able to autho- rize the maintenance of a foreign currency account in connection with the ownership of the property. (2) Consideration would be given to applications by resi- dents wishing to take advantage of foreign currency loans, mortgages, or extended credit facilities for pri- vate property purchases outside the Scheduled Territo- ries. (3) Applicants wishing to purchase a plot of land on which to build a private dwelling would no longer be required to sign a declaration to the effect that build- ing would be completed within 18 months of authority being given for the purchase of the land. They would be expected to declare their firm in ten t ion that comple- tion, including all payments for the land and building project, would take place w i th in two years of the autho- rization. (4) Provision was made for persons who had purchased investment currency in connection w i th the acquisition of property abroad and who were later granted emigration status, to recover all or part of the UNITED KINGDOM investment currency premium incurred. (5) Permission would no longer be given for foreign currency proceeds arising from the sale of part of a property abroad to be treated as investment currency. September 23. The Bank of England asked consor- tium banks in London for a formal acknowledgement that ultimate responsibility for their affa irs rested with their shareholder banks. Subsequently, similar assur- ances were asked of the London subsidiaries of foreign banks. October 1. Importers were required to submit more detailed information to the Bank of England when re- questing permission to make advance payments for im- ports. October 2. Import licenses for textiles were no longer issued automatically against documents provided by the authorities of the Republic of China. October 17. New arrangements agreed between the government departments concerned, the Bank of En- gland, and the London and Scottish clearing banks came into effect with respect to the finance of medi- um-term and long-term export and shipbuilding cred- its. November 12. It was announced that the sterling guarantee arrangements would be discontinued at the end of the year. November 27. The English Court of Appeal decided that where the currency of a contract is a foreign cur- rency, the English courts have jurisdiction to give judg- ment for a sum expressed in that foreign currency. (The decision is being appealed to the House of Lords.) December 4. The Government announced that inter- national agreement had been reached on a m in imum interest rate of 7Y2 per cent for export credit with a ma tur i ty over five years. December 10. The exchange control regulations gov- erning outward direct investment outside the Sched- uled Territories were modified, as follows: (1) Interest paid or accrued on foreign currency borrowing taken to f inance the investment would be taken into account when calculating the matching benefits which must be received by the United Kingdom f rom the investment before repayment of the borrowing with official ex- change would be allowed. (2) Approval would nor- mally be given for a U.K. company, as part of a group reorganization, to sell or liquidate direct investments outside the Scheduled Territories and to reinvest the proceeds in fu r th er direct investment outside the Sched- uled Territories, provided that (a) the sale or liquida- tion was associated at the time with the intention to reinvest; (b) any shortfall on the requirement that two thirds of the after tax profits by the subsidiary be remit- ted to the U .K. parent had been rectified and any out- standing current debts to the U.K. parent had been repaid; and (c) the reinvestment took place within six months. December 17. Residents of the Republic of Ireland and Gibraltar who received permission to sell foreign currency securities beneficially owned by them prior to 497 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM April 7, 1965, and any other foreign securities derived therefrom, e.g., by way of "switches," were no longer exempt from the 25 per cent requirement, i.e., 25 per cent of the proceeds from sales of such securities was to be sold at the official rate of exchange. December 17. Changes in policy concerning exemp- tions from the exchange control regulations came into effect. (1) A person possessing the nationality or citi- zenship of a Scheduled Territory was no longer pre- cluded from applying for exemption from certain provisions of the Exchange Control Act if he was other- wise eligible. (2) Former residents of OSA countries who were, or would become, residents of the United Kingdom, could apply for exemption in special circum- stances, even though they were not nationals or citizens of countries outside the Scheduled Territories. (3) Ex- emptions would henceforth cover assets expressed in any foreign currency (previously only assets expressed in the currency of the applicant's country of nationality were covered). (4) Exemptions, except in certain cir- cumstances, would no longer apply to foreign currency assets acquired after an applicant became resident in the United Kingdom, unless such assets were acquired by way of gifts, charitable donations, or capital distri- butions under wills, intestacies, or trusts from sources outside the Scheduled Territories, or were derived from exempted assets. December 17. New exchange control regulations pro- vided that the foreign exchange facilities available to repatriates would cover citizens or nationals of all countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia; previously, they were available only to na- tionals of such countries. In addition, the facilities would be available to such persons irrespective of the country outside the Scheduled Territories in which they intended to reside; previously, they were limited to the country of the person's nationality. December 20. It was announced that exports of fer- rous scrap and of reusable and rerollable steel products to other member states of the EEC would be allowed without restriction with effect from January 1, 1975. Exports to other destinations would remain subject to individual licensing. December 20. It was announced that imports of cot- ton yarn from Greece and Turkey would be subject to specific import license with effect from December 25, and that imports of cotton yarn from sources that al- ready were controlled would continue to be subject to quota restrictions in 1975. (Subsequently, it was an- nounced that existing restraint arrangements for the import of all textiles from quota-controlled sources were being continued for the first quarter of 1975.) December 20. The Bank of England sent a memoran- dum to all authorized banks outlining ways in which their internal controls applied to operations in foreign exchange might be made more effective. The Bank also asked all banks registered in the United Kingdom to keep it informed of the scope of the foreign exchange 498 dealing authorities delegated to branches and subsidi- aries abroad. December 31. The sterling guarantee arrangements were allowed to expire. No further implementation payments were required. In addition, the Bank of England ceased its sales of gold sovereigns to residents of the United Kingdom, with the ex- ception of sales to authorized gold dealers for export outside the Scheduled Territories. The ma in effect of these measures was that residents of the Un i ted Kingdom (other than authorized dealers in gold) could no longer import gold coins minted after 1837 or gold medals, etc., manufac tured after 1837; that any post-1837 gold coins that authorized dealers in gold might in the fu tu re purchase from persons resident outside the United Kingdom could not be resold to residents of the United Kingdom; and that the export of gold bullion and of post-1837 gold coins to G ib ra l tar and the Republic of Ireland was not normally pe rm i t ted except w i th the approval of the local control au- tho r i t ies. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value of the United States Dollar was estab- lished on October 18, 1973 at 0.736662 gram of fine gold, corresponding to US$42.22 a fine ounce or US$1.20635 = SDR 1. The convertibility of the U.S. dollar into gold and other reserve assets has been sus- pended and exchange rates are not maintained within any stipulated margin from parity. There are no restric- tions on foreign payments, except those imposed for security reasons on transactions involving the authori- ties or nationals of Cuba, North Korea, and North Viet-Nam,1 and those imposed pursuant to UN Secu- rity Council Resolutions Nos. 232 and 253 on any transfer of funds to, or on behalf of, or for the benefit of, any person in Rhodesia (including the authorities thereof), unless the funds are in payment of imports of strategic and critical materials of Rhodesian origin. The United States formally notified the Fund on December 10, 1946 that it was prepared to accept the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control The Treasury Department deals with license applica- tions involving financial or commercial transactions directly or indirectly with Cuba, North Korea, Rhode- sia, and North Viet-Nam, or their nationals, as speci- fied under the Foreign Assets Control Regulations, the Cuban Assets Control Regulations, and the Rhodesian Sanctions Regulations.1 It also deals with license appli- cations involving the blocked accounts in the United States of the People's Republic of China under the Foreign Assets Control Regulations.1 The Bureau of Customs of the Treasury Department administers im- port quotas; such quotas, however, are generally estab- lished and allocated by other agencies. Import quotas on specified dairy products are administered by the Department of Agriculture through the issuance of im- port licenses. The import quotas on sugar are allotted among eligible exporting countries in accordance with a statutory formula administered by the Department of Agriculture and are prorated among eligible importers under regulations administered by that Department.2 Allocations and licenses for imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products are issued by the Department of the Interior. For items subject to export control other than crude petroleum and petroleum products the Department of Commerce is, in general, the respon- sible authority. Imports and Import Payments The importation of merchandise, as well as payment therefor, is prohibited under Treasury regulations, un- less licensed, if such merchandise is of Cuban, North 500 Korean, or North Vietnamese origin,1 or, unless the goods are strategic and critical materials, if the mer- chandise is of Rhodesian origin. Import quotas are in effect for (1) beef, veal, pork, cattle, and hogs from Canada, pursuant to Section 252(A) of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962; (2) cotton, certain cotton waste and products, most dairy prod- ucts, and peanuts, pursuant to Section 22 of the Agri- cultural Adjustment Act; and (3) certain fish and certain potatoes. Import quotas established by the Sugar Act2 are in effect for sugar and confectionery. With the exception of the import quotas for peanuts, certain cotton and cotton products, and butter oil, the above quotas are on a country-of-production basis.2 The United States is a party to the new GATT Ar- rangement Regarding International Trade in Textiles, which provides a framework for the orderly expansion of international trade in textiles and apparel made of cotton, wool, or man-made fibers, and is a member of the Textile Surveillance Body established to supervise the Arrangement's implementation. The United States is nearing completion of an effort, begun in 1974, to bring all its bilateral textile agreements into conformity with the Arrangement's provisions. These agreements set the negotiated levels for the bilateral partners' ex- ports of textiles and apparel to the United States. As at the end of 1974, no limitations were applied to imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products, but these were generally subject to import licenses and import license fees.3 Imports of fresh, frozen, or chilled beef, veal, and mutton are governed by bilateral agreements as an alternative to mandatory quotas under the Meat Import Act of 1964; in June 1972, all meat quotas were suspended, but in 1974 certain quotas were applied against Canada (see above). The transfer of funds to Rhodesia for most purposes other than payment for imports of strategic and critical materials (see section on Exchange Rate System, above) is permitted only under license. Other payments and transfers abroad may be made freely, with certain exceptions which are permitted only under license; these exceptions are payments to or for the account of the authorities or nationals of Cuba, North Korea, and North Viet-Nam.1 Exports and Export Proceeds Munitions can be exported only under license issued by the Office of Munitions Control in the Department of State. Licenses are not granted for exports of arms and ammunition to South Africa. Most exports to Rho- desia require licenses and generally no licenses are is- sued except for food and humanitarian items. For many commodities, when exported to Western Euro- pean countries, Aus tra l ia, or Japan, single distribution licenses may be obtained to cover a fu ll year's ship- ments. The licensing requirements applicable to Po- land, Romania, and Yugoslavia are less restrictive than those applicable to other Eastern European countries. Exports of certain commodities to all destinations have f rom time to t ime been subject to controls for reasons of short supp ly; as at the end of 1974 such controls were applicable to ferrous scrap5 and to crude petroleum and petroleum produc ts. The Secretary of Agr icu l ture has pub l ic ly asked for cooperation in vo lun t a ry repo r t ing of export plans for wheat, corn, sorghum, soybeans, and soybean oil in order to avoid the need for con tro ls. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except that they are proh ib- ited to and f rom Cuba, No r th Korea, No r th V ie t -Nam, and Rhodesia.1 Individuals leaving or entering the coun t ry w i th more than US$5,000 in domestic or fo r- eign currency, travelers checks, money orders, a n d / or bearer-form negotiable securities must declare these to the customs at the point of exit or en t ry. Capital Incoming or ou tgo ing capital paymen ts by residents or nonresidents are not subject to exchange control. However, as noted above, there are restrictions on cer- tain transactions w i th or invo lv ing Cuba, Nor th Korea, North Viet-Nam,1 and Rhodesia, and there are certain reporting requirements for travelers entering or leaving the coun try (as well as corresponding repor t ing re- quirements for shipment of currency or bearer assets th rough the mails). Federal Reserve member banks must meet marginal reserve requirements of 8 per cent on Euro-dollar bor- their foreign branches;6 certain fo- rowings from reign-owned nonmember banks and agencies and branches of foreign banks comply vo lun tar i ly, at the request of the Federal Reserve Board. There are no regulations specifically governing the maximum size of any foreign currency positions banks may take, either over all or with respect to individual currencies, but surveillance of foreign exchange transactions of indi- vidual U.S. banks and their branches is effected through bank examinations. Gold U.S. citizens or residents may free ly purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Banks (but not savings and loan associations or Federal Home Loan Banks) may freely deal in gold bullion and gold UNITED STATES coins. U.S. gold coins remain legal tender at their face value. Treasury licensing of the importing and exporting of gold and the holdings or operations of producers, refin- ers, and processors of gold is no longer required. Pro- ducers of gold may sell their output at free market prices either to industrial users or abroad (except to monetary authorities). Gold may be freely imported, w i th the exception of counterfeit gold coins. Commercial imports of gold jewelry are free of quan- t i ta t ive restriction. Impor ts and exports of gold coins and gold bullion are free of customs du ty and other fiscal charges. Domestic sales of jewelry, including gold jewe lry, are subject to excise du ty at the ra te of 15 per cent, while domestic sales of gold in any other form, including gold coins, are free of fiscal charges. The use of the in terna t ional reserve assets of the Un i ted States has been limited to situations that might arise in which such use could contribute to interna- tional monetary stability and the interests of the United States. Changes during 1974 January 1. The Interest Equalization Tax (IET) pay- able by U.S. citizens or residents when purchasing for- eign stocks and debt obligations f rom foreigners was reduced f rom the equivalent of 3/4 of 1 per cent a year to the equivalent of V4 of 1 per cent for trades and acquisitions made a f ter December 31, 1973. January 1. The fo l low ing liberalization in the For- eign Direct Investment Program (FDIP) administered by the Office of Foreign Direct Investments became effective: (1) The m in imum world-wide allowable avail- able to smaller direct investors was raised from US$10 million to US$20 million. (2) The earnings allowable was increased f rom 60 per cent to 100 per cent of foreign aff i l ia te earnings for either 1973 or 1974, at the direct investor's election. This would permit compli- ance w i th the regulations w i thout the necessity of for- eign earnings remittance. (3) A new "debt repayment allowable" authorized a direct investor to repay 20 per cent of its total ou ts tand ing foreign borrowing allo- cated to positive direct investment as of the end of the 1973 compliance year. This repayment allowable was in addition to the m in imum, historical, and earnings al- lowables. The m in imum, historical, and earnings allow- ables were not, however, available for debt repayment, and direct investors were not permitted to reduce out- standing foreign debt below 80 per cent of the amount allocated effective as of year-end 1973. The regulations would operate to permit repayment of specific out- standing debt obligations, but direct investors would be required to refinance aggregate repayments in excess of the 20 per cent repayment allowable. Relief for bor- row ing hardsh ip situations would continue to be avail- able through specific authorization. January 1. The following amendments to the Volun- ta ry Foreign Credit Restraint Program (VFCRP) 501 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES guidelines became effective: (1) The ceiling for each commercial bank was increased to US$10 million or to an amount of 4 per cent above the ceiling in effect immediately prior to the present revision, whichever was higher. (2) The request that banks refrain from making nonexpert loans with maturities of over one year to residents of the developed countries of continen- tal Western Europe was eliminated. (3) U.S. agencies and branches of foreign banks were given a ceiling of at least US$10 million for making foreign loans and other investments of types restrained under the VFCRP, whereas the existing minimum ceiling was US$1 million. (4) Agencies and branches could recalcu- late the "base net foreign position," which determined the relationship between their foreign lending and for- eign borrowing, by using 96 per cent of their foreign liabilities for June 30, 1973. (5) The restraint against term loans to the developed countries of continental Western Europe was dropped for agencies and branches, as it was being dropped for banks. (6) The ceiling of each nonbank financial institution was in- creased to an amount 5 per cent above that in effect at the end of 1972 or to US$2 million, whichever was higher. (7) The request that nonbank financial institu- tions refrain from increasing their loans and invest- ments in the developed countries of continental Western Europe beyond the amount held at the end of 1968 was eliminated. The President signed legislation to termi- nate, by December 31, 1974 at the latest, the prohibi- tion on ownership of gold by U.S. citizens and residents. Under the new law, P.L. 93-373, no law, rule, regulation, or order might be construed to prohibit any person from purchasing, holding, selling, or otherwise dealing w i th gold in the United States or abroad. This provision was to take effect either on December 31, 1974, or at any time prior to that date that the Presi- dent m ight f ind and report to Congress that in terna- tional mone tary reform had proceeded to the point where elimination of regulations on private ownership of gold would not adversely affect the U.S. interna- tional monetary position. The Export Administration Act was amended and extended until September 30, 1976. It granted the President broad authority to retaliate against countries withholding supplies or charging ex- orb i tant prices. A total embargo of U.S. exports could be applied against countries whose foreign trade poli- cies un fa i r ly injured the U.S. economy. Also, the Presi- dent could place export controls on U.S. products in limited supply, could apply export quotas and fees whenever overseas demand threatened to have a serious inf la t ionary impact or depleted scarce U.S. resources, and could introduce a systematic export monitoring system.
