The Treasury Department promul- gated in f inal form the regulations, instructions, and fo rms for its survey of foreign por tfo l io investment in the United States under P.L. 93-479 (see October 26, above). Reports would be required on Form FPI-1 from all U.S. issuers of securities having assets of more than US$20 million, or US$50 million in the case of banks. Firms with assets of less than these amoun ts would be required to file Form FPI-1 only if they had evidence of foreign investment. Firms with assets of less than US$1 million were exempted f rom the reporting requirements applicable to U.S. issuers. Reports on Form FPI-2 would be required f rom U.S. persons act- ing as holders of record (e.g., nominees, trustees, fidu- ciaries) on behalf of foreign persons. Exempted were holders of record who held no more than US$25,000 of U.S. inves tmen ts on behalf of fore ign persons; parents or guardians acting as custodians for minors; and cer- tain estates and trusts. For purposes of the reports, foreign portfolio investment included all securities of a U.S. corporation, including stocks, bonds, and other evidence of ownersh ip or long-term indebtedness, held by a foreign person owning less than 10 per cent of the voting securities of the corporation. (Investment by foreigners owning a 10 per cent or greater equity inter- est would be reported to the Department of Com- merce.) In addition to corporate interests, the Treasury survey would cover foreign portfolio ownership of secu- rities of federal, state, or local governments or their ins trumen ta l i t ies, limited par tnersh ip interests, invest- ment t rust certificates, and other evidences of owner- ship or indebtedness of noncorporate enterprises. Excluded from the survey were debt obligations with an original ma tur i ty of one year or less. December 20. The U.S. Trade Bill was passed. Au- tho r i ty would be granted for the Adm in is t ra t ion to enter in to broad-scale international trade negotiations, while offer ing safeguards to domestic industries and workers hu rt by import competition. The main provi- sions would provide the President au thor i ty: (1) To negotiate on ta r i ff and non ta r i ff barriers to trade during a five-year period. (2) To mod ify the levels of tar iffs and quotas in order to deal with U.S. balance of payments deficits or surpluses for up to 180 days without Con- gressional approva l. (3) To g rant import relief and ad- ju s tment assistance on the basis of liberalized criteria and procedures. (4) To provide speedier relief from un fa ir foreign trade practices. (5) Subject to certain UNITED STATES provisos, to extend most-favored-nation status to com- munist countries. (6) To grant generalized tariff prefer- ences to developing countries. (The Trade Act of 1974, P.L. 93-618, was signed in to law and came in to force on January 3, 1975.) December 31. The U.S. Sugar Act expired (P.L. 92-138). December 31. P.L. 93-373 became effective. It re- moved the restrictions introduced in 1933 on persons (including banks) purchasing, holding, selling, or oth- erwise dealing with gold, notably the restrictions on private ownership of gold. Prior to this date, private U.S. citizens or residents were not permitted to hold gold at home or abroad except for industrial, profes- sional, or artistic purposes or in the form of numismatic coins or jewelry; imports of gold coins minted after 1959 (other than restrikes of older coins) were not nor- mally licensed as numismatic coins. Banks (but not federally chartered savings and loan associations or Federal Home Loan Banks) became free to purchase and sell gold bullion and gold coin, and they could accept both as collateral for loans. U.S. gold producers and refiners or processors of gold no longer needed Treasury licenses for their holdings and opera- tions. Trading in gold commodity fu tures and transac- tions involving margin and leverage contracts in gold bullion and bulk gold coins would on April 21, 1975 become subject to the jurisdiction and regulation of the new Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Upper Volta has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the CFA Franc,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange trans- actions in French francs, the intervention currency, be- tween the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de TOuest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02. The BCEAO levies a commission of YIO of 1 per mill for transfers within the West African Monetary Union and a commission of 2.50 per mill for transfers to countries outside the Union. Exchange rates for foreign currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West African Monetary Union, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. With the exception of those relating to gold, Upper Volta's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account (Cameroon, the Central African Repub- lic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Senegal, and Togo). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Upper Volta itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only with foreign countries are sub- ject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Bureau in the Directorate of the Treasury and of Public Accounts in the Ministry of Finance, which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertis- ing, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper Volta, inward direct investment and all outward invest- ment, and the soliciting of funds in Upper Volta for placement in foreign countries. The approval authority in respect of exchange control (except for imports and exports of gold, forward exchange cover, and business travel allocations in excess of CFAF 400,000) has been delegated to the BCEAO and, within limits specified in the exchange control regulations, to authorized inter- mediaries. The BCEAO also is authorized to collect, either direct or through the intermediary of banks, fi- nancial institutions, the Postal Administration, and no- taries public, any information necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. All exchange transac- tions relating to foreign countries must be effected 506 through authorized banks, the Postal Administration, or the BCEAO. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Commerce at the Ministry of Commerce, Industrial Development, and Mines. Im- port certificates or attestations for liberalized commod- ities and export attestations (when settled in foreign currencies) are made out by the importer or exporter himself and are visaed by the customs. Prescription of Currency Upper Volta is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settle- ments with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any Operations Account country. Cer- tain settlements with Ghana are made through special accounts. Settlements with all other countries are usu- ally made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. All settle- ments with Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO bank- notes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Ouagadougou by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresi- dent accounts of BCEAO banknotes, French bank- notes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports originating in or shipped from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Imports from countries in the French Franc Area may in princi- ple be made freely, although exceptionally, special reg- ulations may be issued. Imports shipped from and originating in EEC countries, with minor exceptions, are liberalized and require only an import certificate (attestation). Most imports from other countries are subject to licensing. Imports from non-EEC countries outside the French Franc Area are admitted in accor- dance with an annual import program, determined each year by the Directorate of Commerce. Under this pro- gram, global quotas are established up to which import licenses are issued for specified commodities. Imports from Ghana are subject to special regulations. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution All import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000. The import licenses or import certificates (attestations) entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to exchange control ap- proval, which for many invisibles has been delegated to the authorized banks. All payments to Portugal, Rho- desia, and South Africa are prohibited. Authorized banks and the Postal Administration have been em- powered to make payments to foreign countries freely, on behalf of residents, up to CFAF 50,000 a transfer. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been ap- proved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted. Residents traveling for tourism to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to CFAF 175,000 a person a trip (CFAF 87,500 for children under ten) for any number of trips a year; any foreign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 remaining af ter return to Upper Volta must be surrendered. The basic allocation for travel abroad for business purposes is the equivalent of CFAF 20,000 a day, with a max imum of CFAF 400,000 a trip. Resident travelers going to for- eign countries may take out up to a max imum of CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French bank- notes, and banknotes issued by any ins t i tu te of issue that maintains an Operations Account w i th the French Treasury. Resident travelers to other countries of the French Franc Area may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes, but if going to a coun try that is not a member of the West African Monetary Un ion, they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may free ly take out, in addi- tion to any means of payment established in their name abroad, foreign banknotes up to the equivalent of CFAF 175,000 or, subject to the submission of appro- priation (if it was either declared upon entry or ac- quired by drawing on a Foreign Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency or by exchange of foreign travelers checks, etc.), any larger amoun t. They may also take out any foreign means of payment other than banknotes acquired in Upper Volta by debit to a Foreign Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign UPPER VOLTA Currency, again subject to submission of documenta- tion. Finally, they may take out freely up to CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French bank- notes, and banknotes issued by Operations Account countries. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to countries of the French Franc Area may be made freely but for statistical purposes certain agri- cultural products require a license from the Directorate of Commerce. Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Exports to all other countries are permitted freely but some also require a license. Certain commodities can be exported in special circumstances only. Exports to Ghana are subject to special regulations. Export proceeds received in curren- cies other than those of France or another Operations Account country must be surrendered within two mon ths of the date on which the payment falls due (the due date stipulated in the commercial contract, which must not, in principle, be later than 180 days after arrival of the goods at their destination). All export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domi- ciled w i th an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000, and the exporter must sign a foreign exchange commitment and submit a customs certifica- tion. Proceeds from In visibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Ac- count countries in the French Franc Area may be re- tained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered w i th in two months of the due date. Such proceeds and earnings must not be received in or from Portugal, Rhodesia, or South Africa. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue ma in ta in ing an Opera- tions Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. Res- ident travelers must declare to the customs any foreign means of payment in excess of CFAF 5,000 that they bring in and within eight days after return surrender these to an authorized bank. Capital All capital movements between Upper Volta and Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Capital movements between Upper Volta and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Ac- count countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval and are 507 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, ad- vertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper Volta; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. With the ex- ception of those over foreign securities in Upper Volta, the control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member countries of the West African Monetary Union, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account. Spe- cial controls are maintained also over imports and ex- ports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and insti- tutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building opera- tions abroad; these special controls do apply also to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All investments abroad by residents of Upper Volta require prior authorization by the Minister of Finance.2 Foreign direct investments in Upper Volta3 must be declared to the Minister of Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to him. The total or partial liquidation of either type of invest- ment also is subject to prior declaration to the Minister. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Upper Volta investments abroad or foreign investments in Upper Volta, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and the BCEAO within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of for- eign securities in Upper Volta requires prior authoriza- tion by the Minister of Finance. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Upper Volta Government and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issue, offering for sale, or sale in Upper Volta has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authoriza- tion: (1) loans constituting a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance transac- tions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports into or exports from Upper Volta, or by international 508 trading houses previously approved by the Minister of Finance to finance international merchanting transac- tions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 100 million for any one borrower, provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate and that the proceeds are immediately surrendered by the sale of foreign currency on the exchange market or debited to a Foreign Account in Francs. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authorization of the Minister if the loan itself was sub- ject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Lending abroad is subject only to exchange control authorization by the BCEAO, acting on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Ordinance No. 70-074/PRES/PL-TP of Decem- ber 31, 1970, the Investment Code, provides preferen- tial treatment for foreign investment in Upper Volta. Two preferential categories (A and B) are established, in accordance with which preferential treatment with respect to stable rates of taxes, duties, and other fiscal charges may be accorded to specified enterprises for periods of up to 25 years. The benefits under Category B are far more liberal than those under Category A; they are negotiable between the investor and the Gov- ernment, and the enterprise accorded such benefits must be of exceptional importance to the development of the country. Law No. 25761 /AN set up an assis- tance fund for new industries. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Upper Volta. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the External Finance Bureau in the Ministry of Finance. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufac- tured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold objects up to a com- bined weight of 500 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Changes during 1974 January 19. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System On October 7, 1960 a par value for the Uruguayan Peso was established by Uruguay with the Fund; how- ever, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. There is a dual exchange market, consisting of a commercial market and a f inan- cial market. Payments and receipts in respect of imports, exports, freight, and insurance on imports and exports, and most public sector exchange operations are settled in the commercial market, where the exchange rates are fixed (although adjusted from time to time), while all other permitted exchange transactions take place in the financial market, in which the exchange rate fluctuates freely. On December 31, 1974 the buying and selling rates in the commercial market were Ur$ 1,640 and Ur$ 1,656 per US$1, respectively, and those in the fi- nancial market were Ur$2,150 and Ur$2,170 per US$ 1, respectively. The Central Bank of Uruguay supplies foreign ex- change to the commercial banks for imports, and the proceeds from exports (valued at the officially assessed price or aforo where applicable) must be surrendered to the monetary authorities.1 Commercial banks operate on their own account in the financial market, but are not permitted to exceed their combined overbought positions in both markets as specified below, and must surrender any excess exchange holdings to the Central Bank; the relevant limit is the equivalent in U.S. dollars of the sum of the U.S. dollar position on February 29, 1972 and the position in Argentine pesos and Brazilian cruzeiros on September 20, 1974. Various additional effective exchange rates arise from the following: (1) the application of exchange taxes (detracciones or retenciones) to the proceeds from certain traditional exports; (2) the payment of subsidies through tax credit certificates (reintegros) on proceeds from certain nontraditional exports; (3) the 40 per cent tax on certain profit remittances; (4) the minimum ex- ternal f inanc ing requirements for imports; (5) the sale in the financial market of the excess of the actual f.o.b. value over the aforo or the minimum surrender value (sobreaforos) on wool exports; and (6) the special de- posit requirements (consignaciones) on imports. Administration of Control Exchange transactions are carried out through au- thorized banks, banking houses, and the monetary au- thorities. The latter collect import surcharges and export taxes, hold the special deposits required for cer- tain imports, and receive export and import registra- tions. 510 Prescription of Currency Payments between Uruguay and the countries with which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agree- ments may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, within the framework of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system; these countries are Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colom- bia, Mexico, Peru, and Venezuela. Settlements with other countries are made in U.S. dollars or other con- vertible currencies. Imports and Import Payments* All imports are subject to registration prior to the placing of orders abroad. The registrations are gener- ally valid for 180 days, within which period goods must be cleared through customs. Certain imports are tem- porarily prohibited. Most imports are subject to an import surcharge (recargo), a special deposit (consigna- tion), and /or prescribed terms of payment. Goods are classified into nine categories; goods in one category bear no surcharge; goods in other categories are subject to surcharges of 10, 30, 40, 55, 75, 120, 150, or 200 per cent, payable at the time of registration. Imports from LAFTA countries receive a full or partial exemption from the surcharges. Many imports are subject to spe- cial deposits in Uruguayan pesos of a certain percent- age of the c.i.f. value; the deposit must be lodged with the monetary authorities at the time of registration and is refundable upon application after six months. For 1974, imports by each importer in each sur- charge category were exempt from special deposits when they did not exceed, per quarter, 80 per cent of the value of the goods he imported free of deposit dur- ing the second half of 1971; in addition, special deposits were waived up to a specified percentage of individual imports in 1970 and 1971 of certain special categories of imports. (In 1974, there were also some ad hoc allo- cations to cover special needs or to offset increased price levels abroad.) For imports in excess of the mar- gin exempt from special deposits, the required deposit rate varied depending on the surcharge category appli- cable as of July 21, 1971. For general category imports free of surcharge, or imports with surcharges as of that date of up to 50 per cent, the special deposit was 450 per cent of the c.i.f. value (315 per cent for imports from LAFTA countries); for imports with surcharges of more than 50 per cent and up to 110 per cent the rate was 900 per cent (630 per cent for imports from LAFTA countries); and for imports with surcharges of 150 per cent or more, the rate was 1,200 per cent (840 per cent for imports from LAFTA countries). The regime of special deposits is not applicable to goods designated as capital goods by Decree No. 482/971 of August 3, 1971; these are subject to a spe- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution cial regime. Capital goods for specified industries are exempt f rom special deposits, provided they meet cer- tain m in imum external f inanc ing requirements. Most impor ts are subject, in addition to any customs du ty required, to an additional import du ty of 18 per cent of the c . i .f. value, payable upon customs clearance. The tax is not applied to impor ts originating in GATT or LAFTA countries, nor to impor ts of specified agen- cies and public ins t i tu t ions; in add i t ion, an exemption of 100 per cent, 85 per cent, or 40 per cent of the applicable tax is provided for specified imports. All imports valued at over US$1.82 are subject to consular charges of Vi0 of 1 per cent of the peso amount result- ing f rom the conversion of the f .o .b. value at a rate of Ur$55 per US$1; the amount of the charges is payable in foreign exchange at a rate of U r $l = US$2.10 (at a ra te of U r $l = US$1 for pr iva te impor ts of petroleum and petroleum products, alcohol, and te trae thyl lead, at a rate of U r $l = US$0.50 for impor ts of the same commodities by the Administracion Nacional de Com- bustibles, Alcohol y Por t land (ANCAP) — the state oil, cement, and alcohol enterprise —and at a rate of U r$l = US$1.05 for certain other imports by ANCAP).3 Special deposits and surcharges in most cases are calculated either on assumed c.i.f. prices (aforos) estab- lished for many commodities or on the actual c.i.f. value, whichever is higher. In a few cases, the calcula- tion is based on an o f f ic ia l ly assessed price, which usu- ally is expressed in U.S. dollars per kilogram. Sales of foreign exchange for most private sector impo r ts are proh ib i ted unless m in imum f inanc ing re- qu iremen ts are fu l f i l led. At the end of 1974, foreign exchange was made available by the bank ing system for imports of goods other than capital goods only when payable 180 days or more a f ter the date of sh ipmen t; for capital goods the m in imum terms ranged from 180 days to f ive years, applicable to at least 80 per cent of the c . i .f. value. For general imports for which f inanc ing under these conditions could not be obtained, the Cen- tral Bank could authorize the sale of exchange on a case-by-case basis. The sale of exchange was made at the earliest 15 days prior to the ma tu r i ty date. Provided that the importer had deposited the peso equivalent of the transaction w i th in 30 days af ter the date of ap- proval of the application for customs clearance, the sale was made at the rate of exchange in effect on the date of the deposit; for importers not mak ing the deposit w i th in the 30-day period, however, the sale of exchange was made at the rate in effect on the date of payment. Special arrangements were applied to certain other import payments and an exchange rate guarantee was given subject to the lodging of a peso deposit w i th the Central Bank. Certain delays have arisen in the imple- mentation of these arrangements. Payments for Invisibles Freight and insurance on imports and exports are settled in the commercial marke t. Payments for all URUGUAY other invisibles may be made freely through the finan- cial market. Certain profit remittances are subject to a tax of 40 per cent. There are no limitations on the export of foreign or domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds The proceeds of the principal exports are subject to taxes (detracciones or retenciones), which are withheld by the monetary authorities on the basis of either the f.o.b. value or the aforo value of the commodity con- cerned. The tax is stipulated in pesos per unit of export commodity, but it may not be more than 50 per cent or less than 0.01 per cent of the peso proceeds of the export, except that for exports of meat the stipulated max imum is 25 per cent while for wool the permitted limits are 2 per cent and 35 per cent of the f.o.b. value. The exchange proceeds of traditional exports subject to taxes must be surrendered in fu ll to the monetary au- thorities. At the end of 1974 the prescribed surrender periods were as follows: generally, not later than 30 days after shipment has been authorized (180 days for combed wool); for exports of nontraditional products, however, w i th in 60 days if the sale is on a cash basis (75 days for certain leather goods) or within 210 days if the sale is made on credit. For certain exports, including wool and hides, mini- mum f.o.b. values (m in imum surrender prices or aforos) expressed in U.S. dollars per kilogram have been estab- lished for various grades and types. There are special arrangements for the advance surrender (anticipos and preanticipos) of the exchange proceeds from exports. Surrender before the export is registered (preanticipos) is permitted for wool, meat, cereals, oilseeds, and non- traditional exports; surrender af ter registration (an- ticipos) is limited to some traditional exports. Subsidies in the form of tax credit certificates (reintegros) of up to 50 per cent of the f.o.b. value are granted on certain non trad i t ional exports (80 per cent for new exports). Exports of certain types of beef and dairy cows, wool ewes, specified minerals (including iron, copper, zinc, a lum inum, and nickel), and protein concentrates used for animal feed are prohibited. As at the end of 1974 exports of certain animal fats, all types of sheepskin, and animal bristle were also temporarily prohibited. Exports of greasy wool, wheat, sorghum, corn, and sunflower seeds are prohibited from time to time. Proceeds from Invisibles All proceeds from invisibles may be held, utilized, or sold to the banking system. Department stores, hotels, and other tourist establishments are authorized to ac- cept foreign currencies at the rate prevailing in the financial market; the proceeds must be sold th rough the bank ing system. There are no limitations on the import of foreign or domestic banknotes. 511 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY Capital Inward and outward capital transfers by either resi- dents or nonresidents may be made freely through the financial market. However, certain borrowing abroad is controlled, and the amortization or liquidation pro- ceeds of foreign capital cannot normally be transferred abroad until three years after the date on which the investment was approved. Exchange rate guarantees are in effect available on certain inward capital trans- fers, whether made by residents or nonresidents; these consist of swaps with the Central Bank. New foreign investments in Uruguay, as well as certain existing for- eign investments, are governed by a Foreign Invest- ment Law (Law No. 14179 of March 28, 1974, as amended by Law No. 14244 of July 26, 1974 and De- cree No. 808/974 of October 10, 1974). Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Uruguay or abroad, provided that the transactions are registered. Gold may be exported only if accompanied by evidence of prior importation. Any private purchases abroad for nonindustrial use, how- ever, must either be financed from the buyer's own exchange holdings or settled through the financial mar- ket. Imports and exports of gold for industrial use are settled through the commercial market. Changes during 1974 During the year, the buying and selling rates in the commercial market were gradually depreciated from Ur$928 and Ur$937 to Ur$ 1,640 and U r$ 1,656 per US$1; those in the financial market moved from Ur$925 and Ur$930 to Ur$2,150 and Ur$2,170 per US$1. March 22. A special mterministerial commission (CIADE) was established to consider applications by the private sector for procurement abroad with exemp- tion from special deposits. (The commission was abol- ished on June 1, 1975.) March 28. An Industrial Promotion Law (Law No. 14178) was passed. It provided for tax and other incentives for industries declared to be of national inter- est. March 28. Law No. 14179, the Foreign Investment Law, came into effect. Foreign investment was autho- rized in principle in all sectors of the economy but special authorization by the Central Government was required for investment in many specified lines of busi- ness. Authorization guaranteed the transfer of capital and profits through the financial market. Outward cap- ital transfers could be made not earlier than three years after the date of approval of the investment contract. Profits that had not been remitted during the last three financial years could be treated as new capital invest- ment. Foreign exchange for profit remittances would be sold by the Central Bank at the rate of exchange pre- 512 vailing in the financial market on the day the profits were declared, provided an application was submitted within 60 days of that date; after that period, the ex- change rate on the day of application would apply. Foreign companies were defined as those companies whose capital was at least 50 per cent foreign owned. Foreign companies could not contract medium-term or long-term loans in Uruguay, and only in exceptional cases could they borrow at short term in Uruguay; in addition, they required prior authorization to borrow abroad. Existing companies in which foreign capital had more than a majority interest were given 180 days to register. (Some provisions were changed by Law No. 14244 of July 26, 1974 and Decree No. 808/974 of October 22, 1974.) March 28. Circular No. 504 increased the exchange allocation for travel to Argentina from $a 1,000 to $a 1,500 a person a trip and that for travel to Brazil from Cr$600 to Cr$900 a person a trip. March 29. A Hydrocarbons Law (Law No. 14181) came into force. Subsequently, bids were invited for offshore petroleum exploration contracts. April 1. Banking insti- tutions and private f irms could sell amounts of at least US$50,000, as follows: at Ur$700 per US$1 for maturi- ties of at least 18 months but less than 24 months; at Ur$750 per US$1 for maturities of at least 24 months but less than 30 months; and at Ur$800 per US$1 for maturities of at least 30 months. The difference between the buy ing and selling rates could not exceed the equiv- alent of 6 per cent per annum denominated in domestic currency. Banking institutions which combined a for- eign currency deposit with the Central Bank with a loan in domestic currency from the Central Bank were sub- ject to a separate regime. Amounts of at least US$200,000 and deposited for a period of 180 days (renewable for additional periods of 90 days) could be sold and repurchased at Ur$750 per US$1. The Central Bank would not pay interest on the foreign currency deposit but would charge 7 per cent interest on the relevant domestic currency loans combined with for- eign currency deposits when amounting to at least US$1,500,000, or 8 per cent for smaller amounts. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.265275 gram of fine gold per Venezuelan Bolivar. No transactions take place at the par value. Exchange transactions take place at the fol- lowing rates.1 The Central Bank of Venezuela pur- chases proceeds of the petroleum and iron ore exporting companies at the rate of Bs 4.20 per US$1. Any proceeds from exports of cacao and coffee that are offered for sale to the Central Bank must be purchased by it at the rate of Bs 4.285 per US$1. The Central Bank sells exchange to the Government and its agencies and to the commercial banks (for sales to the public only) at Bs 4.285 per US$1.2 The commercial banks purchase foreign exchange from the public at rates close to Bs 4.28 per US$1. Commercial banks must sell exchange to the public at Bs 4.30 per US$1 for all transactions; foreign banks may only sell foreign exchange that has not been ob- tained from the Central Bank. Some foreign exchange is also negotiated on the two stock exchanges, where buying and selling rates usually are slightly below Bs 4.30 per US$1. Exchange houses are permitted to deal only in banknotes, coins, and travelers checks. The Central Bank offers swap facilities under which it buys U.S. dollars at Bs 4.27 and resells at Bs 4.30 after 180 days. Administration of Control There is no exchange control mechanism. Import and export licenses, when required, are generally issued by the Ministry of Development or the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, depending on the commod- ity; for certain agricultural products, the prior approval of the Agricultural Marketing Corporation must be obtained before applications for export licenses are sub- mitted to these ministries. Under the terms of an agree- ment between the Government and the Central Bank, the latter has the responsibility of ensuring that a sub- sidy is applied to imports of wheat for human con- sumption and to certain exports of coffee and cacao. The Superintendency of Foreign Investments (SiEx) is charged with the supervision over foreign investment in Venezuela. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Payments between Venezuela and Argentina, Chile, Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Peru, and Uruguay may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Central Bank of Venezuela and the central banks of the countries con- cerned. 516 Imports and Import Payments The import of certain goods is either prohibited or reserved for the Government; these include fully assem- bled automobiles, certain textiles, coffee, citrus fruit, bananas, pineapples, melons, salt, opium, cigarette pa- per, natural pearls, and matches. In addition, a few other commodities require import licenses; quantitative restrictions applicable irrespective of origin are main- tained on these items for protective purposes. Licenses are valid for all countries except Rhodesia and South Africa. Import licenses for some products are issued on the condition that the importer has purchased domestic products equal to a prescribed percentage of the quan- tity import (contingentamiento). All other commodities are free from import licensing. Wheat for human consumption is imported by the Agricultural Marketing Corporation and receives a subsidy of 25.55 per cent of the f.o.b. value, calculated at Bs 4.30 per US$1. Imports from Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Import payments may be made freely. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles may be made freely; pri- vate sector purchases of exchange for this purpose are made from commercial banks or exchange houses. Transfers of profits and dividends are limited in princi- ple to 14 per cent per annum of registered foreign capi- tal. Resident and nonresident travelers must on departure pay a travel tax of Bs 80 a person a trip; exemptions exist for children under seven, foreign tour- ists, Venezuelan and foreign diplomats, and personnel of international organizations. Travelers may freely ex- port domestic and foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain furs and hides, scrap metals, and a few other commodities are prohibited. Licenses are required for the exportation of many other commodi- ties. Most export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Development, but those for coffee, cacao, rice, and sugar are granted by the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. Exports of products containing subsidized imported wheat are subject to special arrangements to ensure that the subsidy received is repaid. The export of gold and precious stones requires an export license issued by the Ministry of Finance. The petroleum and iron ore exporting companies must surrender to the Central Bank export proceeds, to the extent of their local currency requirements (includ- ing taxes), at a rate of Bs 4.20 per US$1. Otherwise, there are no surrender requirements for export pro- ceeds or other exchange receipts. Exporters of coffee and cacao may (but need not) sell exchange proceeds ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution to the Central Bank at Bs 4.285 per US$1; they may receive an export subsidy calculated to prevent the f.o.b. bolivar prices of these products in Venezuelan ports from falling below specified minimum amounts regardless of external prices for these products. Eligibil- ity for this subsidy is maintained even if the exchange proceeds are not surrendered. In principle, the benefit of these arrangements based on guaranteed minimum prices may be extended to firms processing domestic coffee or cacao for export. Nontraditional exports are eligible for freely negotiable tax certificates, as an ex- port incentive, provided that the value added nationally is at least 30 per cent. All exports to Rhodesia and South Africa are pro- hibited, as are exports of petroleum and military equip- ment to the People's Republic of China and North Korea. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles are freely dispos- able. Travelers may freely import domestic and foreign currency, with the exception that the Currency Law prohibits the importation for commercial purposes of foreign coins other than gold coins. The importation of Venezuelan gold coins is reserved for the Central Bank. Capital All inward and outward capital transfers are permit- ted freely. Brokerage activity in Venezuela, however, in shares or units of foreign investment trusts or mutual funds is prohibited. Foreign capital imported for in- vestment purposes and all foreign credits must be regis- tered with the Superintendency of Foreign Invest- ments. The Central Bank regulates bank credit to non- residents and companies whose capital is more than 50 per cent owned by physical persons or companies that are resident or domiciled abroad. The General Banking Law of December 30, 1970 (as amended on Septem- ber 7, 1974) authorizes the Government to regulate bank credit to companies whose capital is more than 40 per cent owned by nonresident or foreign physical per- sons or companies. This law also provides special regu- lations for foreign banks operating in Venezuela. Gold Venezuelan gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold coins in Venezuela for numismatic and investment pur- poses. The Central Bank does not deal in gold with the public, but gold coins, medallions, and bars are freely negotiated between licensed importers, exchange houses, and the public. Commercial banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents but do not normally deal in gold with the public. Imports and exports of monetary gold are re- served for the Central Bank, as is the import of gold coins that are legal tender in Venezuela. Other imports VENEZUELA and exports of gold require licenses. Imports require licenses from the Ministry of Finance and in certain cases also from the Ministry of Development, while exports are licensed by the Ministry of Finance only. The law prescribes a license for all imports and exports of gold by anyone not registered at the Ministry of Development as an industrial user, but in practice im- ports and exports by private persons are permitted free of license. Imports of gold coins and of gold bars and ingots weighing more than 12 kilograms are free of customs duty; all other gold imports are subject to duty at varying rates. All imports of nonmonetary gold are subject to consular duties ranging from 2 per cent to 3V2 per cent ad valorem. Changes during 1974 January 1. As a signatory to the Cartagena Agree- ment, Venezuela became a member of the Andean Group. February 5. Presidential Decree No. 1577 of Janu- ary 23, 1974 was published, which revoked with effect from February 6 the 30 per cent customs surcharge ("Antillian duties") on imports from certain neighbor- ing countries. February 8. Presidential Decree No. 1588 of Febru- ary 6 was published, which contained implementing regulations for the tax certificate scheme for nontradi- tional exports. March 17. It was announced that the petroleum in- dustry would be nationalized. March 22. Presidential Decree No. 1647 of March 7 was published, which implemented the law creating the Export Finance Fund. April 2. Decree No. 29 made exports of sugar subject to license. April 29. For the implementation of Decision No. 24 of the Cartagena Agreement, Decree No. 62 of April 28 specified the industries in which no new direct foreign investment in Venezuela was permitted. For- eign companies operating in these sectors had to trans- form into national companies, for which purpose they must put on sale at least 80 per cent of their shares for acquisition by national investors in a period of not more than three years from May 1, 1974. The sectors of insurance, commercial banking, and other financial institutions would continue to be governed by the spe- cial laws in force, but SIEX (see next entry) would have certain powers with respect to the representation of national investors in the management of the companies concerned. April 29. For the implementation of Decisions Nos. 24, 37, 37-A, and 70 of the Cartagena Agreement, Decree No. 63 of April 28 created the Superinten- dency of Foreign Investments (SlEx) in the Ministry of Development, set out its functions, and specified cer- tain provisions henceforth applicable to the following: direct foreign investment, reinvestment of profits, utili- zation of foreign and local credit, transformation of 517 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA foreign corporations into national or mixed corpora- tions, importation of technology and use and exploita- tion of patents and trademarks, and transfer of profits to foreign investors. The Decree also provided a defini- tion of direct foreign investment. Among the duties of SIEX was that of maintaining a Registry of Foreign Investments and a registry of approved contracts with regard to imports of technology, as well as trademarks, patents, licenses, and royalties. Companies which have foreign investors as stockholders, partners, or partici- pants, would only be able to distribute dividends, or remit these abroad, on foreign owners' holdings in amounts not exceeding annually 14 per cent of the foreign authorized and registered investment (after de- duction of the tax on dividends). These included cotton, coffee, cacao, to- bacco, rice, and sugar. June 14. Decree No. 181 gave the Agricultural Mar- keting Corporation a monopoly over the importation of powdered milk. June 17. Imports and Import Payments The bulk of imports comes under one of three head- ings: (1) imports financed with funds from the U.S. Agency for International Development (AID); (2) im- ports financed from Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange resources; and (3) "third-country-financed imports," i.e., imports financed with loans or grants from France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Japan, or other countries. Products imported under the AID programs or under third-country assistance may be financed with Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange when the specific approval of the Minister of Trade and Supply is ob- tained. Many imports are prohibited. Imports financed by the U.S. AID programs require licenses issued by the Ministry of Trade and Supply. Imports financed with Viet-Nam's own foreign ex- change or by third countries are subject to import cer- tificates; these are issued by authorized commercial banks, endorsed by the National Bank, and checked a posteriori by the Ministry of Trade and Supply. Import certificates are valid for six months. Goods eligible for import with Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange are lim- ited to those included in a list issued by the Ministry of Trade and Supply; imports by end-users of capital goods or raw materials not included in the list may be effected after approval by the Ministry of Trade and Supply. Some imports are permitted without foreign ex- change (sans Exchange Rate System No par value for the Vietnamese Piastre has been established with the Fund. The exchange rate structure is based on the official rate which is adjusted from time to time; on December 31, 1974 the rate stood at VN$685 per US$1. Foreign exchange transactions are subject to two commissions totaling about 2 per cent. Payments and receipts must be effected through the authorized banks. Authorized banks are allowed to en- gage in forward buying or selling of foreign exchange in the domestic or foreign exchange markets, but only in relation to payments for imports and only in certain specified currencies. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the National Bank of Viet-Nam (Directorate-General of Exchange). Most remittances must have the prior approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange; the authority to ap- prove some payments for private invisibles has been delegated to the authorized banks. Import and export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Trade and Supply, and import and export certificates by authorized com- mercial banks. Prescription of Currency Payments must normally be effected in one of the currencies specified and quoted by the National Bank.2 Receipts may be accepted either in those currencies or in any other convertible currency, provided that prior to repatriation such other currencies are converted into a currency quoted by the National Bank. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may maintain accounts w i th banks, subject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Nonresident Accounts in Free Piastres may be freely credited with the proceeds from the sale of convertible exchange and may be freely debited for most payments to residents. A category of nonresident accounts, Capital Ac- counts, covers piastres owned by nonresident foreign- ers that may not be transferred abroad. Balances in Capital Accounts may be used for investment. Their use is subject to the approval of the Directorate-Gen- eral of Exchange. Investments financed from Capital Accounts generally are not covered by the Investment Law of 1963 (see section on Capital, below), and pro- ceeds from the liquidation of such investments are cred- ited to Capital Accounts unless the Ministry of Economy has declared them eligible for the privileges raw materials imported by end-users; some imports of raw materials by end-users are subject to a 50 per cent advance payment. The settlement of all impor ts, except petroleum products and fertilizers, financed w i th Viet-NanVs own fore ign exchange takes place at the official exchange rate prevailing at the time of the utilization of the letter of credit. A special subsidy of VNS60 per US$1 is paid on goods imported under the Commercial Import Pro- gram (CIP), on impor ts of wheat f lour and cotton un- der U.S. P.L. 480, and on petroleum products and fe r t i l ize rs imported against f ree foreign exchange. Payments for Invisibles Most payments for invisibles require approval by the Directorate-General of Exchange. Students approved by a special commission are granted US$80 a month for s tudy in the Republic of China or Hong Kong and US$150 a mon th for study elsewhere; they are also gran ted allocations for tu i t ion and medical fees and for ex traord inary expenses. Students participating in short-term t ra in ing courses abroad are gran ted up to US$130 a month. Foreign specialists employed in Viet- Nam may t rans fer up to 50 per cent of their salary every mon th, but not more than US$600 a month. In principle, foreign firms are generally permitted to transfer up to 70 per cent of their net annual profit after tax, a f ter examination of their accounts and af ter de- duction of any losses in previous years. Profit transfers by foreign enterprises established or expanded between February 14, 1963 and June 2, 1972 under the terms of the 1963 Investment Law are governed by the provi- sions of that law unless they meet the requirements of the "Foreign Exchange Working Capital System" (see section on Capital, below). Although dividends de- clared in Viet-Nam and accruing to nonresidents and foreign residents may in principle be transferred abroad, under the terms of the 1963 Investment Law transfers of profits and dividends are limited to 20 per cent annua l ly of the declared capital. Net annual prof i ts after tax from projects covered by the new Investment Law, Law No. 4 / 7 2, may be transferred w i thout limit. Each resident authorized to travel abroad is entitled to purchase the fo l low ing amounts of foreign exchange at the official rate: travelers to the Khmer Republic and Laos US$30 a day, w i th a maximum of US$300 a per- son a trip, and travelers to other countries US$40 a day, w i th a max imum of US$2,400 a person a trip. The allocations mentioned may be supplemented by the equivalent of US$40 in foreign banknotes. Travelers are permitted to take with them up to VN$5,000 in Viet- namese banknotes. Foreign exchange not used by fo r- eign travelers may be re-exported. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports require a certificate issued by an autho- rized commercial bank which is responsible for the re- patriation of the foreign exchange. Some goods, mainly VIET-NAM scrap and certain products containing imported raw materials, require a license issued by the Ministry of Trade and Supply. A few commodities are exempt from certificates or permits. All exports to communist countries, exports to any destination of manufactured or semimanufactured products originally imported into Viet-Nam, gold, rice, rice products, and certain other items are prohibited; the prohibition does not apply to imported goods that have been processed in Viet-Nam, provided that the value added corresponds to, or ex- ceeds, a specified proportion of the export price. Ex- porters are allowed to retain in EFAC (Exportations-Frais Accessoires) accounts 10 per cent of their total export proceeds for the settlement of inciden- tal expenses related to the export transaction. Exports enjoy subsidies on the basis of the repatriated export value in terms of Vietnamese piastres. Proceeds from In visibles Proceeds f rom invisibles must be surrendered at the official rate. A traveler entering Viet-Nam may bring in any amount of foreign exchange and up to VN$5,000 in Vietnamese banknotes. Foreign military and civilian personnel (government officials) must surrender on ar- rival any foreign banknotes they bring into Viet-Nam. Capital Under general regulations, capital may be imported without formalities, but foreign investors must register their capital with the Vietnamese authorities and agree on the terms of the investment in order to be able to repatriate their capital and to transfer profits. Under the Investment Law of 1963, special benefits could be accorded to new foreign investments in those sectors of the economy that are given high priority. The minimum investment in agriculture was established at VN$0.5 million, and in industry at VN$1 million. Imports of equipment and spare parts needed by foreign undertak- ings covered by the law were exempt from customs duties. Foreign technicians employed by these enter- prises were exempt from income tax for 2 years. For- eign investments were free of taxes on profits, securities, and real estate for specified periods of time. The new investments were not subject to any national- ization measures for the first 15 years from the date of the written authorization granted to the investor; they were accorded the same treatment as that applicable to domestic investments. The law provided for the trans- fer of profits at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent of the invested capital, and for the repatriation of the original investment after 5 years at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent if the capital was newly imported (after 20 years for investment of foreign-owned capital previ- ously held in Viet-Nam). A new Investment Law promulgated on June 2, 1972 has superseded the Investment Law of 1963. The provisions of the 1963 law, however, are still applicable to the enterprises which were governed by them. Under 521 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM the new law, which mainly adds new fiscal benefits to the provisions of the 1963 law, fiscal incentives are granted to new investments whether financed in Viet- namese currency or in foreign exchange brought from abroad, provided that (1) the investments are made in a "priority sector" and (2) that the initial capital is over VN$10 million in the primary sector and over VN$20 million in the secondary and tertiary sectors. Besides fiscal exemptions the foreign enterprises enjoying the benefits of the law are authorized (1) to transfer abroad total net annual profits and (2) to repatriate after five years of operation the capital invested, in annual in- stallments of 20 per cent. Investments not covered by either Investment Law nor by the regime described in the following paragraph are subject to the regulations and case-to-case decisions of the Directorate-General of Exchange, which nor- mally authorizes the transfer of up to 70 per cent of net annual profits after taxes but does not permit disinvest- ment; such investments are not eligible for the above-mentioned tax exemptions. Under a "Foreign Exchange Working Capital Sys- tem," foreign capital imported in the form of direct investment or as medium-term and long-term credit in cash or in kind may be registered with the National Bank and treated as follows. Capital must be brought from abroad and sold through authorized banks, where it is credited to a "Foreign Exchange Working Ac- count." Profits, dividends, and interest on such capital may be transferred annua l ly up to a maximum of 20 per cent of the registered amount and repatriation may be made up to an annual maximum of 25 per cent of the registered capital. Imports and exports of capital are made at the off i- cial rate. Gold Within Viet-Nam, the holding of gold and all trans- actions in gold are subject to licensing, but the controls are not rigidly enforced and unlicensed holdings of gold by individuals are tolerated. Only the National Bank is empowered to import and export gold. All domestic transactions in gold are subject to a luxu ry tax of 10 per cent on the sale value or the manu fac tu r ing cost. The export of gold by physical or juridical persons other than the National Bank is prohibited. The import of gold by physical or juridical persons other than the National Bank is also prohibited, w i th the following exceptions: (1) Vietnamese settled in Laos may, when returning to Viet-Nam, bring in up to 13 taels3 of gold in the form of jewelry; (2) residents may import gold without allocation of foreign exchange, provided that they have an import license and pay a customs duty of 130 per cent; (3) nonresidents may, w i thout allocation of foreign exchange, bring into Viet-Nam any quan t i ty of gold, provided that its en try is declared and that it is deposited in safe custody with an authorized bank; the utilization of such gold is subject to prior authoriza- 522 tion by the Directorate-General of Exchange, and if it is sold in Viet-Nam, the sales proceeds must be credited to a Capital Account. In addition, the circular abolished the guarantee deposit of 30 per cent required against letters of credit for impor ts effected under the CIP and other fo re ign aid. July 25. Impor ts of petroleum products and fertilizers would not be sub- ject to the immediate payment of the counterpart in piastres of the amount of foreign exchange allocated by the National Bank. Commercial banks were required to pay the coun terpart in piastres to the National Bank when the payment in fore ign exchange was effected, and at the exchange ra te preva i l ing at that time. How- ever, for petroleum products the exchange ra te applied was that prevailing at the time of the opening of the letter of credit. July 25.
