Not for Redistribution WESTERN SAMOA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Western Samoa Tala has been established with the Fund. A central rate of WS$1 = US$1.67736 has been established, corresponding to 1.23565 grams of fine gold per WS$1. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar and Western Samoa avails itself of wider margins. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Minister of Finance operating as the exchange control authority; the Minister may delegate his approval au tho r i ty to the Financial Secretary, who in tu rn may delegate part of his powers to authorized banks. All paymen ts to non- residents of Western Samoa require the approval of the Ministry of Finance. The M in is t ry, however, has dele- gated to the Bank of Western Samoa, the only autho- rized bank, au tho r i ty to approve certain paymen ts up to any amount and certain other payments up to speci- fied amounts. Prescription of Currency Western Samoa has ceased fo be a Scheduled Terri- to ry in terms of the U .K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Most settlements w i th Sterling Area ter- ritories take place in Sterling Area currencies, but there are no prescriptions as to the currencies in which pay- ments to or from nonresidents of Western Samoa must be made or received. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between the accounts of resi- dents and nonresidents of Western Samoa. Imports and Import Payments The import of a few commodities is prohibited f rom all sources for reasons of security or health. Other com- modities may be imported f rom any source. Each li- censed commercial impor ter receives an annual allocation of foreign exchange, to be taken up on a quarterly basis, which may be used freely for the import of any commodity that is not prohibited, except auto- mobiles. The allocations are made by the M in i s t ry of Finance and communicated to the Bank of Western Samoa; the latter au toma t ica l ly provides the foreign exchange required for import payments upon submis- sion of documen tary evidence. Persons who are not licensed impor ters may import any commodity free ly up to WS$100 a person a year but require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance for imports of higher value. The import of motor vehicles, other than for exclusive use in p lan ta t ion wo rk, requires an ad- vance deposit of 50 per cent of the retail value. Payments for Invisibles Payments for certain invisibles, such as overseas con- tractual obligations and insurance, are approved auto- matically by the Bank of Western Samoa up to any amount or w i th in limits determined by the Ministry of Finance. Payments in excess of these limits as well as payments for all other invisibles require the prior ap- proval of the M in is t ry of Finance. Remittances in re- spect of s tudy abroad are freely authorized. The Ministry of Finance approves up to any amount the transfer of genuine income derived locally from pen- sions, rents, interests, and dividends by persons perma- nen t ly resident overseas. Residents trave l ing to American Samoa, whether for business or private pur- poses, are entitled to a foreign currency allowance equivalent to US$50 a person a quar ter; an additional allowance of US$15 a day is provided to cover hotel expenses. The basic travel allowance for other countries is equivalent to WS$10 a person a day, subject to a limit of WS$ 1,000. The Ministry of Finance grants supple- men ta ry allocations when evidence of genuine need is provided. Resident t rave le r s, may take out foreign banknotes, as part of their foreign currency allowance, up to WS$20 a person a trip. Resident and nonresident travelers may take out any amount in domestic cur- rency. Exports and Export Proceeds V i r tua l ly all exports require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance. Exports may be prohibited by the Director of Agriculture on grounds of low quality, or by order of the Head of State to alleviate domestic shortages. Copra exports are controlled by the Copra Board and banana exports by the Produce Marketing Division of the Ministry of Agriculture. Export pro- ceeds must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa w i th in a reasonable time af ter shipment. Where exceptional circumstances exist, the Ministry of Fi- nance may waive this requirement for certain export items. Proceeds from In visibles All receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa. Resident travelers must on return sell to the Bank all foreign currency brought in. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign and domestic banknotes. 525 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution WESTERN SAMOA Capital All ou tward capital transfers by residents require the specific approval of the M in is try of Finance and capital received by residents must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa. Inward capital remittances do not normally require approval, but borrowing abroad by nonbank residents does require approval. The transfer of legacies from estates of deceased local residents due to beneficiaries permanently residing overseas is ap- proved up to a limit of WS$ 10,000 a year. The Bank of Western Samoa approves transfers of gifts to relatives and dependents, either for special fam i ly occasions or by way of maintenance, up to WS$200 a year for each fam i ly group. Foreign investments in specified activi- ties in Western Samoa are encouraged. The Enterprises Incentive Act No. 27/1965, as amended in 1969, makes provision for the gran t ing of certain relief of customs duties, income tax, and business license fees to persons engaged in approved enterprises. Both the re- patriation of capital and profit remittances on foreign capital are subject to approval by the Minister of Fi- nance; such approval is normally granted. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form. There are no restrictions on imports or ex- ports of gold in any form. Changes during 1974 January 1. Foreign exchange allocations for import- ers came in to effect which were set at levels above those of 1973 (in terms of domestic currency). They included a special allocation to cover increased petroleum and transportation costs. 526 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The currency of the Yemen Arab Republic is the Yemen Rial, which is issued by the Central Bank of Yemen. No par value has been established with the Fund. All transactions take place in a free market at a fluctuating exchange rate, which in 1974 remained un- changed. On December 31, 1974 the rate for the U.S. dollar was YR1 1 = US$0.22. Exchange rates for other currencies are fixed daily by the Central Bank on the basis of London cross rates against the U.S. dollar. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered on behalf of the Minister of Economy by the Central Bank of Yemen, which has the authority to grant exchange licenses and licenses for imports and exports. The only commercial banks and authorized dealers are the Yemen Bank for Reconstruction and Development and four branches of foreign commercial banks. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements.1 Settlements are usually made in pounds sterling or U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Israel are prohibited. Imports of a few commodities are reserved for the Government. All other imports require import licenses. These are issued freely for all commodities for which government agen- cies or firms with government participation do not have the exclusive right of importation; three firms have such rights, for cigarettes, petroleum products, and medical supplies, respectively. In addition to a license, the im- portation of certain commodities requires the permis- sion of the Ministry of Economy. Imports that are financed by the importer with his own foreign exchange held abroad also require an import license. Importers who have obtained an import license may obtain the necessary foreign exchange from the local banks or the free market. In addition to the applicable customs du ty, imports are subject to a defense tax of 5 per cent and a statistical tax of 2 per cent. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles may be made freely when financed from foreign currency accounts held at home or abroad by exporters of goods or services, or when effected in foreign banknotes. All other payments in respect of invisibles require an exchange license is- sued by the Central Bank. Such licenses are issued freely for virtually all current invisibles, including tour- ist travel. Travelers may freely take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel are prohibited. For statistical pur- poses only, all exports require registration forms, which are issued freely by banks; export licenses are not re- quired. Exporters are not required to surrender the foreign exchange proceeds; these may be retained in foreign currency accounts with domestic banks. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered but may be retained in foreign currency accounts with do- mestic commercial banks. Travelers may freely bring in any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Capital In principle, all capital transfers require prior ap- proval and capital proceeds must be surrendered; in practice, no restrictions are imposed on inward or out- ward capital transfers. Both domestic and foreign in- vestment are regulated by Law No. 13 of 1970. Foreign investors in the Yemen Arab Republic are free to trans- fer abroad any desired proportion of their net profits after taxes or of their capital. Gold Two commemorative gold coins in denominations of YRls 20 and YRls 30 have been issued, which do not circulate in the Yemen Arab Republic. By virtue of Ministerial Decree No. 21 /1973 residents are free to purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in the Yemen Arab Republic and to import or export gold in any form without an import, export, or exchange license. Changes during 1974 No significant changes took place. NOTE 1 There is an inoperative bilateral payments arrangement w i th Egypt. 527 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System Nonresident Accounts The currency of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen is the Yemeni Dinar, which is issued'by the Bank of Yemen (the central bank) and is defined as equivalent to 2.13281 grams of fine gold. No par value for the Yemeni dinar has been established with the Fund. Since February 1973, the central rate has been YD 1 = US$2.89523 or US$1 = YD 0.345395. On December 31, 1974, the National Bank of Yemen's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were YD 0.343 and YD 0.350. Administration of Control The administration of exchange control is carried out by the Bank of Yemen's General Department for Ex- change Control through the Foreign Exchange Com- mittee, which has delegated certain powers to the Director of Exchange Control, a member of the Com- mittee. The Ministry of Economy and Industry issues import and export licenses; those for gold and other precious metals require the prior approval of the Direc- tor of Exchange Control. Exchange transactions must be carried out through the intermediary of authorized dealers (licensed commercial banks approved by the Director of Exchange Control); at present the only commercial bank and authorized dealer is the National Bank of Yemen. Except for payments for imports against letters of credit or documents, which may be approved by the authorized dealer, and for payments by the oil refinery, all payments for imports (including those of precious metals) require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Two public corpora- tions are engaged in foreign trade (see section on Im- ports and Import Payments, below). The oil refinery is treated as a resident entity but in its operations gener- ally is not affected by the existing exchange and trade controls. Prescription of Currency The People's Democratic Republic of Yemen has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Exchange transactions must be carried out through the intermedi- ary of authorized dealers in accordance with prescrip- tion of currency regulations that are in certain respects similar to those applicable in the United Kingdom. All payments to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Ex- port proceeds and certain receipts from invisibles must be received in prescribed currencies1 and surrendered to authorized dealers. Payments for imports must be made in prescribed currencies. 528 Nonresident accounts may be held by certain per- sons not resident in the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen. External Accounts in Yemeni dinars may be credited with proceeds from convertible foreign cur- rency transferred from abroad, with bank interest pay- able on such accounts, and with balances from other External Accounts. Transfers from abroad must be in the form of bank drafts; the accounts cannot be cred- ited with payments in the form of foreign banknotes (unless they have been declared to the customs on en- try), or with locally raised or locally earned funds (ex- cept in certain cases specified by the law). External Accounts may be debited for any payments to resi- dents, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for payments abroad in any convertible currency. Trans- fers abroad from Nonresident Accounts in Yemeni di- nars require the prior approval of the Exchange Control Department. The Foreign Exchange Commit- tee may direct any payment to a nonresident to a Blocked Account. Except with the Committee's prior approval, Blocked Accounts may be debited only for purchases of specified securities. Subject to certain conditions, Yemeni nationals working abroad may establish nonresident accounts in foreign currencies; balances in these accounts earn in- terest and are convertible into foreign currency on de- mand. Imports and Import Payments With minor exceptions, all imports other than those of the oil refinery require individual licenses. Most overland merchanting trade with the Yemen Arab Re- public is also exempt from the licensing requirements. Imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. An import program is drawn up annually, but its quotas are operated flexibly. Payments for imports on a c.& f. basis against letters of credit or documentary drafts can be made by authorized dealers without the prior ap- proval of the Director of Exchange Control; most other forms of payment for imports require approval. Insur- ance on imports must be effected locally. A Board of Trade is in charge of the trading activities of the nationalized companies. The National Company for Foreign Trade has a monopoly over imports of flour, sugar, wheat, rice, ghee, cooking oil, tea, and cigarettes. The National Import Company Ltd. im- ports certain consumer goods not mentioned in Law No. 37 of 1969. The National Company for Home Trade is the sole importer of automobiles and other vehicles, all government requirements, and most re- quirements of the public hospitals, as well as other specified items. Imports into and exports from the free port zones within the port of Aden are free of exchange ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution and trade controls (except in respect of transactions between these zones and the rest of the People's Demo- cratic Republic of Yemen) and are exempt from cus- toms duties. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. The basic exchange allowance for tourism, which residents may take up without applying for exchange control approval, is the equivalent of YD 125 a person a trip in travelers checks, drafts, and foreign notes and coins (50 per cent of this amount for children under ten).2 Allowances for other types of travel are granted on the merits of the application. Foreign employees of approved enterprises and the oil refinery are allowed to remit abroad up to 50 per cent and three eighths, respectively, of their total earnings (net of taxes). All insurance is nationalized; existing policies have been transferred to the National Insurance and Reinsurance Company, and payments abroad in respect of premiums are not permitted. Trav- elers may take out the equivalent of YD 5 in domestic banknotes and up to the equivalent of YD 125 in trav- elers checks, foreign banknotes, or other foreign means of payment. Furthermore, nonresidents may take out any foreign exchange declared upon en try. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports, including petroleum products, are ex- empt from licenses. All exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Except for exports to the Yemen Arab Republic specified by the Foreign Exchange Commit- tee, export proceeds must be received in prescribed currencies within six months of shipment and must be sold to authorized dealers upon receipt. The proceeds of exports or re-exports to the Yemen Arab Republic may be surrendered in the national currency of the importing coun try. Proceeds from Invisibles All claims of residents for services rendered to non- residents must be collected in foreign currency (or re- ceived from an External Account) when due and surrendered to authorized dealers. Travelers may freely bring in foreign banknotes but not more than YD 5 in domestic currency. Capital Virtually all capital payments and transactions re- quire prior approval. Expatriates are normally permit- ted upon departure to remit their liquid funds to their country of permanent residence. Foreign investments that have been approved under the Law for the Organization of Industry and the Pro- motion of Industrial Investment (Law No. 23 of PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN May 14, 1971) may be granted exemptions from im- port duty and various other tax facilities. All remittances abroad of interest and profits require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. Profit remittances abroad by foreign firms under Law No. 23 also are subject to the Exchange Control Law (Law No. 16) and in any one year should not normally exceed 50 per cent of the accrued net profit. Beginning five years after production has started, the net value of the enterprise (calculated on the basis of actual or book value or surrender or liquidation value, whichever is less) is transferable at the rate of 25 per cent a year; if an expatriate national or foreign investor encounters difficulties, however, his capital may be retransferred six months after entry. Interest due on any loans ob- tained abroad after the firm concerned has been estab- lished may also be remitted, provided that all duties, taxes, and other government dues have been paid. Gold Only the monetary authorities and authorized deal- ers may purchase, hold, or sell gold bullion. Licensed goldsmiths may purchase, hold, and sell other un- worked gold and gold coins and ornaments. Other resi- dents may hold gold only in the form of ornaments or numismatic coins. Exports and imports of gold by reg- istered goldsmiths require licenses issued by the Minis- try of Economy and Industry (General Department for Foreign Trade); in certain cases, the consent of the Foreign Exchange Committee must also be obtained. Travelers may bring in or take out reasonable amounts of gold, in the form of ornaments only (not exceeding YD 100 in value for departing travelers). Imports and exports of gold by travelers are subject only to customs control, but if incoming nonresident travelers wish to sell any gold coins or bullion, they must sell them to an authorized dealer. Changes during 1974 January 1. Yemeni nationals working abroad were allowed to establish nonresident foreign currency ac- counts. February 4. The limit of YD 250 on the value of gold ornaments that travelers could bring in was removed. July 9. Import duties on many consumer goods were increased by 10 per cent of the existing duty. July 14. Japanese yen, Kuwaiti dinars, and Lebanese pounds were added to the list of prescribed currencies. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0433330 gram of fine gold per Yugoslav Dinar, corresponding to Din 20.508 = SDR 1 or Din 17 = US$1. However, since July 12, 1973 the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the dinar within announced margins and there- fore all transactions, except for receipts and payments effected under the procedures set forth for certain countries with which Yugoslavia has bilateral pay- ments agreements, take place at a fluctuating exchange rate. The buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in the foreign exchange market in Belgrade on Decem- ber 30, 1974 were Din 17.0265 and Din 17.0777 per US$ 1, respectively. The foreign exchange market is lim- ited to spot transactions between authorized business banks and the National Bank of Yugoslavia. The cur- rencies dealt in are Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finn- ish markkaa, French francs, Iraqi dinars, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Kuwaiti dinars, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. Administration of Control On the basis of laws governing these matters, the Federal Executive Council prescribes the general provi- sions in respect of foreign trade and exchange transac- tions. The Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade, by virtue of these general provisions, establishes rules and regulations, makes decisions governing commercial transactions, and issues import and export licenses when required. It is also charged with securing bal- anced trade with payments agreement countries. The Federal Secretariat for Finance prescribes the specific provisions governing exchange transactions. This Sec- retariat and the National Bank of Yugoslavia adminis- ter the exchange controls. The National Bank prescribes the methods of payment to and from foreign countries; it also licenses compensation transactions. All foreign exchange transactions must be carried out through the National Bank or an authorized bank. The latter are of three types. Fully authorized banks, which must have a minimum credit fund of Din 500 million and deposits of at least Din 1,000 million, may engage in all foreign exchange transactions in Yugosla- via and abroad, as well as in foreign credit operations (including the granting of guarantees). Limited autho- rized banks, which must have a minimum credit fund amoun t ing to Din 100 million and deposits of at least Din 200 million, may conduct foreign exchange opera- tions in Yugoslavia only; they may neither keep foreign exchange accounts abroad nor engage in foreign credit operations, except through the intermediary of a fully authorized credit bank. Authorized exchange offices 530 may only deal in foreign banknotes and travelers checks; this status is open to all commercial and savings banks, hotels, and specifically authorized tourist agen- cies. Commercial exports and imports may be effected by all economic organizations (both producing and trad- ing undertakings) registered for this purpose. Registra- tion is effected automatically, provided that certain conditions, including the provision of minimum work- ing capital for trade enterprises, are fulfilled. Economic organizations that are not registered to conduct foreign trade channel their orders through economic organiza- tions which export and /or import on their own behalf. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Yugo- slavia has bilateral payments agreements are made in the currencies and according to the procedures set forth in those agreements. If no agreement exists, settlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Yugoslavia has payments agreements requiring settlements through bilateral accounts as follows: (1) in U.S. dol- lars with Afghanistan, Albania, Algeria, Brazil, Bul- garia, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Ghana, Greece, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Roma- nia, and the U.S.S.R.; (2) in pounds sterling with North Viet-Nam; and (3) in the partner country's currency with Iraq. Certain settlements with Bangladesh, Co- lombia, Mexico, and Pakistan take place through spe- cial accounts. A degree of multilateralization of payments is provided under the bilateral payments agreements with Afghanistan, Ghana, Hungary, and Iraq.1 For purposes of import and export licensing and the operation of nonresident accounts, Ghana and Hungary are considered to belong to the convertible area. Nonresident Accounts Foreign juridical and physical persons may maintain accounts denominated in foreign exchange and in di- nars in Yugoslavia according to the following rules. Foreigners resident outside Yugoslavia may freely open accounts in convertible currencies in Yugoslavia. For- eign missions and foreigners resident in Yugoslavia may freely open with authorized banks accounts ex- pressed in foreign currencies or dinars. Foreign exchange accounts in convertible currencies of nonresident juridical and physical persons are kept in the currency deposited.2 Balances on these accounts may be used for all payments in Yugoslavia, in dinars or in the currency concerned, and abroad, in any con- vertible currency. Transfers from these accounts are free if made in the currency in which the account is kept; outward transfers in other convertible currencies ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution are subject to the account-holding bank being prepared to make the necessary conversion. Nonresident foreign exchange accounts in bilateral currencies may be opened only for certain fore ign jur id- ical and physical persons resident in Yugoslavia. Bal- ances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugoslavia or for re t ran s fer to the bilateral coun t ry to which the account is related. Foreign juridical and physical persons may free ly open nonresident accounts in convertible dinars with authorized banks. Such accounts can be credited freely with amounts whose transfer in convertible currency has been authorized and they may be debited freely for permitted paymen ts in Yugoslavia and for transfer abroad in the convertible currency of the account holder's coun t ry of domicile. Nonresident juridical and physical persons may also open o ther d inar accounts w i th authorized banks. These other accounts may be credited with dinars ac- quired in Yugoslavia in accordance w i th the existing regulations. Balances are, in principle, nontransferable and may be spent in Yugoslavia only for noncommer- cial payments by the account holder or by members of his close fam i ly, or by the owner and staff of foreign firms if the account holder is a foreign juridical person. If balances on these accounts derive from copyright royalties or f rom work performed in Yugoslavia by foreigners, from pensions and disability allowances of persons who have emigrated from Yugoslavia, or from alimony paymen ts, transfers may be effected in accor- dance with the existing regulations. Resident nationals may maintain foreign exchange accounts or foreign exchange savings deposits in con- vertible currencies w i th any authorized bank. These accounts are kept in the currency deposited, are interest bearing, and interest is paid par t ly in the foreign cur- rency deposited and partly in dinars. Foreign exchange accounts may be retained for an indefinite period of time and may be drawn upon freely for payments in Yugoslavia and abroad on behalf of the account holder or his immediate family; balances are not transferab le to other persons or accounts (see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, below). Yugoslav emigrants residing abroad and former emigrants returning to Yugoslavia may also open foreign exchange accounts in Yugoslavia that may be used freely for payments in Yugoslavia or abroad. Foreign exchange accounts in bilateral currencies may be maintained by resident nationals. In the case of currencies of Eastern European countries3 and Mongo- lia, the accounts are denominated in dollars of account, and for North Viet-Nam in pounds sterling of account; for other bilateral currencies the accounts are kept in the currency deposited. In general, balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugoslavia or for re- transfers to the bilateral country to which the account is related. YUGOSLAVIA Imports and Import Payments Commercial imports may be effected only by eco- nomic organizations registered as participating in for- eign trade. In addition to economic organizations specializing in foreign trade, most major industrial pro- ducers are registered. The import of certain basic food- s tuffs, such as wheat, rice, coffee, lard, edible oils, and sugar, is carried out by economic organizations that have been selected by the Federal Office for Food Re- serves, on the basis of public bids. For most commodities import licenses are not re- quired. All commodities included in the foreign trade nomenclature are classified in five categories, largely in accordance with the manner in which exchange is made available: LB—liberalized goods; DL—goods liberal- ized under special license; GDK —goods imported un- der global exchange quotas; RK and DK—goods subject to individual quotas (RK if individual quotas are fixed by quan t i ty and DK if they are fixed in di- nars); and D —imports subject to ad hoc licensing. Goods in the LB category are mainly raw materials, foods tuffs, and spare parts, but they also include some consumer goods; at the end of 1974, 5,097 items (out of a total of 7,616) were classified under LB. Protective equipment for workers and all other goods not specifi- cally included in the GDK, RK, DK, or D lists were also liberalized and free f rom any quan t i ta t ive restric- tion. Imports of LB commodities accounted for 51.6 per cent of total imports in 1973, and 59.4 per cent of total imports in 1974. Exchange for payments for LB imports f rom the convertible currency area is made available freely in any convertible currency appropriate to the exporting coun t ry. Payments for imports of liber- alized goods from payments agreement countries must be made in the manner prescribed in the relevant pay- ments agreement and may be restricted according to the availability of funds in the appropriate clearing account. DL goods comprise certain previously restricted consumer items, such as watches, whose 1972 import value was negligible. Special licenses are required for these items for statistical and recording purposes. The Secretariat for Foreign Trade is obliged to issue the license within 20 days from the date of application. Once the license is obtained the importer may freely acquire foreign exchange for the import payment in the same manner as for LB goods. At the end of 1974, 32 items were liberalized under the DL regime, and im- ports of these items corresponded in 1974 to 0.4 per cent of total imports. The GDK list comprises raw materials, other repro- duction materials, most capital equipment, and most of those consumer goods not liberalized under the LB and DL regimes. In 1973 imports of commodities that were on this list amounted to 21.2 per cent of total imports, and in 1974 imports of the same items amounted to 14.4 per cent of total imports. Such imports can be made under several d ifferent procedures. Those for 531 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA nonconsumer goods are as follows: Each importer of raw materials and other reproduction materials re- ceives a global foreign exchange quota and may use the exchange so allocated to purchase any such goods listed as GDK. Payment for imports of capital goods on the GDK list may be financed from specific exchange allo- cations; a considerable portion may be freely financed from retention quota funds (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below), funds originating in deprecia- tion allowances, and credits obtained abroad, including suppliers' credits. The specific exchange allocations are limited mainly to large investment projects, including public utilities; the amounts are determined by the Fed- eral Assembly. Economic organizations may acquire foreign exchange at a predetermined proportion of their annual depreciation allowance, a ratio that varies ac- cording to the economic sector involved. For consumer goods, trading enterprises agree within the Economic Chambers on the distribution of GDK quotas among themselves. This agreement must be approved by the Federal Secretariat for Market and Prices, which issues a certificate to each trading enterprise for its share in the GDK quota allowing it to import the agreed quan- tity of the goods concerned. Imports under commodity quotas (list RK or list DK), mainly selected agricultural and mineral prod- ucts (such as wheat, sugar, rice, coffee, and salt) but also machine tools and certain plastics, are subject to quotas established for each commodity and cannot be imported under any other procedure. The quotas are established either in physical quantities (RK) or in di- nars (DK). There are separate quotas in each case for imports from convertible area countries and payments agreement countries; their allocation among importers is decided by negotiations among the economic organi- zations.4 Imports of RK and DK items amounted to about 20.6 per cent of total imports in 1973 and about 20.8 per cent of total imports in 1974. Exchange is provided automatically for payments for imports of goods subject to the RK and DK regime, but only up to a predetermined quan t i ty or amount for each item. Goods in list D comprise gunpowder, ammunition, opium, motor vehicles, tractors, certain textile fibers and yarns, television sets, railroad rolling stock, air- craft, fertilizers, natural gas, and bitumen. Import li- censes are required only for list D commodities. These licenses automatically entitle an enterprise to purchase the requisite foreign exchange. Imports of D items ac- counted for 6.5 per cent of total imports in 1973 and 5.0 per cent of total imports in 1974. There is also a special list of goods whose import by enterprises requires ad hoc permission by the Secretar- iat for Foreign Trade.5 At the end of 1974, the list comprised 46 items, such as refrigerators, television receivers, radios, record players, and tape recorders. For certain goods there is an additional requirement, irrespective of those set out above, of a special import license ("accordance") issued by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. At the end of 1974 these goods were 532 61 LB items, 5 RK items, 2 DK items, and 1 D item. For all items concerned, the Secretariat may prescribe direct importation from the country of origin; these items include a wide range of tropical foodstuffs and fruits, raw materials, fats, oils, and textiles, as well as tin and raw cotton. Private persons who are Yugoslav nationals and hold foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks may use these funds freely to import goods intended for their own use or for the use of close relatives residing with them, regardless of the import regime for the goods. Self-employed Yugoslav nationals may freely and at any time import machinery for small farms or equipment for handicraft production, up to Din 50,000 a shipment. Also, Yugoslavs returning from work abroad and nonresidents residing in Yugoslavia for more than three months may import goods up to Din 50,000 intended for their personal needs or the needs of their own household, provided such goods were paid for from the savings from their foreign earn- ings; such savings may be held abroad or in foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks. As an exception to the foregoing, owners of foreign exchange accounts and Yugoslav nationals working abroad may import automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, mopeds, and bicycles, together with mounted motors and essential spare parts for these vehicles, provided that importation is effected through a registered enter- prise and payment is made through a foreign exchange account held at a Yugoslav bank. Yugoslav and foreign nationals are exempt from this prescribed manner of payment and method of importation, however, under the following circumstances: when they return for per- manent residence in Yugoslavia, provided that they have spent at least five years abroad; when a vehicle is inherited; when a motor vehicle is purchased out of an insurance indemnity received for a motor vehicle that has been destroyed and had originally been paid for in foreign currency; and if they have spent at least two years abroad continuously and have owned a vehicle for at least two years. Yugoslav citizens returning from a tourist trip abroad may import any amount of goods intended for the needs of their household. However, if the value of the goods exceeds Din 1,000, these goods must be handed over, at the customs office at the point of entry, to a domestic forwarder for delivery to the owner's address; such delivery cannot be made unless the cus- toms duties are paid. Compensation transactions are only authorized in exceptional circumstances; in both 1973 and 1974 they accounted for less than 1 per cent of total imports. A 1 per cent special tax for customs evidence and a 3 per cent equalization tax ("contingency tax") are pay- able on all commodities not exempt from customs duty. In addition, an import surcharge of 6 per cent of the c.i.f. value at the border has to be paid for all dutiable commodities, with the exception that the surcharge has been reduced to 2 per cent for capital equipment for the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution development of basic primary product industries, for some reproduction materials, and for certain essential items such as butter, wheat flour, hides, and raw cot- ton. Many agricultural commodities and foodstuffs are subject to variable import levies. Certain goods are subject to advance import deposit requirements; the deposit is 30 per cent or 50 per cent of the c.i.f. value and is retained for 12 months or 6 months, respectively. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to merchandise trans- actions, including transpor ta t ion, are fu l ly liberalized. Exchange to cover export promotion expenses abroad is made freely available to exporters. Pensions, wages, and salaries are transferable under certain conditions. Payments in respect of royalties and alimony granted by court order are freely transferable, but if a payment is to be made to a country with which Yugoslavia maintains bilateral payments arrangements, then such paymen ts may be made only if the agreement in ques- tion provides for this to be done on a reciprocal basis. Authorized banks may sell foreign currency up to the equivalent of Din 600 for remittances for court and other fees abroad and for specified personal expenses. The National Bank may authorize the sale of any amount of foreign exchange for the foregoing and for unspecified purposes when justified in light of the cir- cumstances. Purchases of services abroad, as well as spare parts, fuel, etc., by Yugoslav enterprises involved in interna- tional freight and passenger transportation are liberal- ized. There is no basic exchange allowance for tourist travel abroad. However, travel agencies may sell orga- nized tours abroad against payment in dinars up to an amount equivalent to 100 per cent of their individual retention quotas. The National Bank may also autho- rize travel agencies to sell foreign exchange for both group and individual travel abroad. Payments for other invisibles may be made from the remittor's own foreign exchange funds (e.g., from retention quotas, or, when made by various social and sociopolitical organiza- tions, from specific annual allocations). Not more than Din 1,000 in domestic currency, in denominations of Din 100 or less, may be taken out by travelers. Foreign travelers may bring in and take out any amount in foreign exchange w i thout declaring it. Exports and Export Proceeds In principle, exports are free of control, except for certain raw materials that are in short supply on the domestic market (including petroleum and petroleum derivatives and certain livestock) and certain other ma- terials such as gunpowder, weapons, and narcotic drugs. Exports to countries with which Yugoslavia has a bilateral payments agreement are subject to approval by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade ("accor- YUGOSLAVIA dance"). Such approval may be given for a group of commodities or for all commodities to be exported within a certain period (global approval). Permission to export to bilateral countries may be made conditional on an under tak ing to import from such countries or to export to other countries. In accordance with bilateral arrangements, Yugoslavia restrains exports of certain commodities to France, the Federal Republic of Ger- many, Sweden, and the United States. Proceeds from exports must be repatriated within 90 days from the date of exportation, unless specific ap- proval is granted to deviate from this rule. The surren- der of these proceeds is not required. The full export proceeds may be credited to foreign exchange sight deposit accounts which the exporter maintains w i th an authorized bank of his choice; separate accounts must be established for each currency. Exchange on these accounts may either be used, subject to the relevant regulations, for payments for imports and invisibles or be sold to an authorized bank. Retention quotas may be used to pay for imports of certain consumer goods if such imports are made by economic organizations that are in the catering and tourist industries or are engaged in setting up trade fa irs, and by film enter- prises; such imports are also permitted as consignment stocks. The part of the export proceeds that remains at the free disposal of the exporter for payments abroad is referred to as the retention quota; the remainder may be retained indefinitely or used for certain payments abroad, but cannot earn interest. The permitted reten- tion rate is 20 per cent for all export earnings from goods and services, w i th the exception that a rate of 45 per cent applies to tourist organizations and a rate of 100 per cent applies to foreign exchange earnings of Yugoslav enterprises operating abroad and to Yugo- slav enterprises operating under long-term cooperation agreements w i th foreign companies. (Enterprises with long-term cooperation agreements may in any case im- port up to the value of their production which is a result of that cooperation.) In some instances (services ren- dered to foreign tourists and sales of newly mined gold to the National Bank), sales against payment in dinars are regarded as exports for retention quota purposes. Producing enterprises selling specified consumer goods in Yugoslavia for foreign currency may retain 20 per cent of the foreign exchange thus earned. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be repatriated within 90 days from the date on which the claim is payable. The performance of construction and engineering ser- vices in payments agreement countries is subject to an "accordance" issued by the Federal Secretariat for For- eign Trade. Receipts f rom services are eligible for reten- tion quotas; the quota for hotels and tourist agencies is 45 per cent. Exchange proceeds may be used for pay- ments abroad connected with the activities of the eco- 533 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA nomic organization concerned, including payments for purchases of equipment and other material for its own needs. The retained exchange is not transferable to eco- nomic organizations other than those with which the recipients are cooperating in technical and business matters, but it can always be sold to authorized banks. If the exchange is used to pay for imports, the usual import procedures apply. Residents who, while em- ployed abroad, deposited their savings in foreign sav- ings banks and obtained a "savings book," may withdraw their balances in the form of foreign exchange when in Yugoslavia. Residents may hold interest-bearing foreign cur- rency accounts in Yugoslavia. The accounts may be credited with the full amount of a person's savings in foreign exchange. These accounts may be used freely for the personal needs of the account holder and of close members of his family; they are not transferable to other persons or accounts and may be retained for an indefinite period of time. Authorized trade organizations may sell manufac- tured goods to foreign tourists in Yugoslavia against payment in foreign exchange at a discount freely estab- lished by the trade organizations themselves. This dis- count is granted only on purchases in authorized shops against checks expressed in foreign currencies or against certain foreign banknotes. Not more than Din 1,500 in Yugoslav banknotes, in denominations of Din 100 or less, may be brought in by travelers. Capital Foreign loans and credits may be freely contracted by fu l ly authorized banks and economic organizations, with the exceptions that no consumer goods may be imported on deferred payment terms, and that no for- eign financial credits may be taken up whose repayment terms include a grace period of less than two years.6 All other inward or outward transfers of a capital nature by residents or nonresidents require individual licenses. Foreign loans and credits must be recorded with the National Banks of the republics. Loans must ordinarily be repaid w i th foreign exchange that is either obtained by the economic organization concerned as export re- tention quotas and foreign exchange amortization (de- preciation) allocations or acquired from banks according to the regulations governing the foreign trade regime. Credits in the former category are subject to prior dinar deposit requirements; the deposits are noninterest bearing and are held with the National Banks of the republics until full repayment of the foreign credits. For financial credits and foreign exchange deposits received by business banks for the account of nonresidents, the five basic rates of deposit introduced in April 1972 range from 1 per cent for maturities over ten years to 40 per cent for maturities of less than two years. How- ever, as a temporary measure beginning in mid-Decem- 534 ber 1972, a dinar deposit of 75 per cent was required for all financial credits and foreign exchange deposits by nonresidents regardless of maturity. For credits for the importation of capital goods, the deposit rates at the end of 1974 were 20 per cent for credits with a maturity of up to three years; 10 per cent for credits of between three and five years; and 1 per cent for credits with a maturity over five years. However, if the capital goods were imported for investments in underdevel- oped regions of Yugoslavia, the latter deposit rates were 10 per cent for credits with a maturity of up to three years and 1 per cent for credits with a longer maturity and for all credits for the import of specially produced capital equipment. Certain foreign credits are specifically exempted from the foregoing deposit requirements; these include credits from specified international financial organiza- tions, credits contracted for or on behalf of the Federal Government or the National Bank, and credits con- tracted for the importation of equipment intended for high-priority sectors and activities as defined by Deci- sions of the Federal Executive Council. Foreign credits repayable with foreign exchange ac- quired according to the regulations governing the for- eign trade regime are trade credits for raw materials and intermediate goods, usually with a maturity of up to 360 days. These are exempt from deposit require- ments. As an exception, if the goods imported on credit are under the LB regime, 25 per cent must be deposited with the National Banks of the republics or the autono- mous provinces as a downpayment and the remaining 75 per cent is payable at maturity. Foreigners may invest in certain Yugoslav economic organizations but only through joint ventures; such foreign investment is limited to 49 per cent of the orga- nization's capital. Profit transfers abroad may be fi- nanced from the retention quota and, in addition, profit transfers are permitted up to one third of the joint venture's foreign currency earnings from exports of goods and services. If the law governing joint ventures were to be amended, the legal provisions in force on the date of registration of a joint venture would continue to be applied during the entire life of the investment contract, if the foreign investor so desires or, at the latter's option, any more favorable provisions of the amended legislation would be applied. Foreign firms are permitted to establish representational offices in Yugoslavia. Foreign juridical and physical persons are permitted to purchase bonds issued by Yugoslav enter- prises, sociopolitical communities, and other sociolegal persons. The investment income earned abroad by Yugoslav economic organizations must be repatriated within 90 days; however, when repatriated the profits are gov- erned by the regulations for retention quotas. Residents are obliged to repatriate and, with the exception of inheritances, to surrender all foreign exchange held or accruing abroad on capital account. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Outward capital transfers by residents who are phys- ical persons are not approved. Economic organizations wishing to participate in foreign enterprises may be allowed under special conditions, by the Federal Secre- tariat for Foreign Trade and the Federal Secretariat for Finance, to export the necessary capital. Also, a Deci- sion of the Federal Executive Council of October 14, 1955 requires the Yugoslav authorities to continue to permit the remittance of inheritances to citizens of the United States, provided that the remittance is requested within three years from the date of distribution of the estate. Gold The National Bank has issued certain commemora- tive gold coins, which are not legal tender. Foreign travelers are freely permitted to import and export these coins, subject to customs declaration and, for exports, subject to proof that they have been purchased in Yugoslavia. Residents who are private persons may hold gold coins in Yugoslavia, which may be sold to the National Bank or to any authorized bank, and they may freely hold, purchase, impor t, and sell gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Domestic economic organizations that have been registered as trading in gold may import gold jewelry under the GDK import regime; they may free ly export gold jewe lry and other articles of gold. Authorized banks may freely export gold coins. Sales of newly mined gold to the National Bank against payment in dinars (calculated by applying the rate of Din 17 per U.S. dollar to a price of US$42.22 an ounce) are re- garded as exports and entitle the seller to a retention quota of 20 per cent in convertible foreign exchange. Other domestic sales of new ly mined gold by the pro- ducers may be made at a price which equals the average quotation in free gold markets abroad. Domestic eco- nomic organizations using gold for their normal activi- ties may purchase gold f rom domestic producers or abroad on the basis of quotas allocated to each such organization individually. Changes during 1974 January 1. The system of expor t- import l ink ing ar- rangements was abolished. January 1. The preferential export regime for "major exporters" was abolished. January 1. Crude petroleum and gas oil were freed from import duties and the import surcharge on these goods was reduced from 6 per cent to 2 per cent. January 31. Conditions were established under which Yugoslav enterprises engaged in fore ign trade or in construction abroad could hold foreign exchange w i th foreign banks or f irms. February 14. Fertilizers, na tural gas, and bitumen were moved f rom the LB list to the D list. February 14. The reductions in import duties on fer- rous me ta l lurgy products and the du ty exemptions for YUGOSLAVIA certain raw materials and other reproduction materials were extended until December 31. February. Yugoslavia introduced a system of gener- alized tar iff preferences for developing countries. The beneficiaries were the 25 least developed countries in the UNCTAD classification, plus Bangladesh. March 15. Modifications were introduced in the con- ditions under which insurance premiums and indemni- ties could be settled in foreign exchange. April 25. The import surcharge was reduced f rom 6 per cent to 2 per cent for 27 agricultural and food products. April 25. Some 835 items were transferred from the GDK list; 651 of these were shifted to the LB list. June 14. A National Bank decision modified the specification of the types of borrowing abroad for which authorized banks and socialist enterprises could grant guarantees and super guarantees. The repayment period could not exceed five years. June 20. The transfer of fertilizers from the LB list to the D list was extended until December 31, 1975. July 16. The National Bank issued a revised decision on the manner in which settlements w i th foreign countries had to be effected. As previously, payments and receipts in relations with countries of the convert- ible currency area were to take place in convertible currencies, and those in relations with countries of the bilateral account area in the appropriate clearing cur- rencies. Exceptionally, however, the National Bank could introduce a temporary limitation on the use of any specific convertible currency for payments and re- ceipts in respect of goods and services. July 19. New regulations regarding foreign currency accounts held by foreign juridical and physical persons came into force. The National Bank Decision of April 6, 1973, published in Official Gazette No. 17/73, was revoked. August 3. The GDK quota for the second half of 1974 for the import of raw materials and semimanufac- tures was reduced by 10 per cent. August 3. The GDK quota for 1974 for goods for personal consumption was reduced by 15 per cent. August 3. A list of 45 commodities or groups of commodities was issued whose import by enterprises un t il the end of 1974 would require the ad hoc permis- sion of the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. The list included air conditioners, washing machines, refrig- erators, typewriters, television sets, transistor radios, vacuum cleaners, phonographs, and tape recorders. (With effect from January 1, 1975 this list was abol- ished.) August 6. The National Bank issued instructions for the implementation of the decision of July 19 regulat- ing the use of foreign exchange accounts in Yugoslavia by nonresident physical and juridical persons. Nonresi- dents could open foreign exchange accounts in autho- rized banks in convertible currencies. Deposits could be used for payments in dinars and foreign exchange in Yugoslavia and for transfers abroad. Banks were also 535 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA allowed to open foreign exchange accounts in curren- cies of the bilateral account countries area, but only for foreign diplomatic missions and other foreign agencies in Yugoslavia and for foreign physical persons resident in Yugoslavia; these accounts could be fed only by clearing currencies remitted from abroad and by checks and letters of credit in these currencies. Balances could be used by the account holders only for dinar payments in Yugoslavia and for transfers of the clearing curren- cies concerned to the country of origin. August 10. Socialist enterprises tak ing up foreign fi- nancial credits as well as authorized banks tak ing up foreign financial and bank credits were exempted from the obligation to place dinar deposits w i th the National Bank in the following cases: if the financial credits granted to socialist enterprises and authorized banks were used for payments abroad for services related to prospecting for mineral and ore deposits in Yugoslavia; and if the financial credits and deposits used by autho- rized banks were earmarked for purposes of placing deposits with their correspondent banks abroad and with other foreign banks with the highest credit rating. August 10. Import deposits of 30 per cent for 12 months on some 20 groups of commodities and 50 per cent for 6 months on some 63 groups of commodities were required. The cash deposits were to be kept in noninterest-bearing accounts with the National Bank. The deposit requirements were applicable both to im- ports on a cash basis and on a credit basis. There were certain exemptions when the imports were to be used for specified purposes. August 10. A National Bank decision provided that certain imports of goods and services on credit terms would be considered as cash operations rather than credit operations. They were imports of goods, when payment was made within 90 days after customs clear- ance, and imports of services (whether rendered in Yu- goslavia or abroad), when payment was made within 120 days. The limits on the amount of Yugoslav currency that could be taken out or brought in by travelers were increased from Din 500 to Din 1,000 and from Din 500 to Din 1,500, respectively. November 7. Their payment henceforth could be made by means of a bill of exchange either within 36 months of importation or within 5 months from the date of com- missioning of the project, whichever was earlier. December 11. Yugoslav citizens (physical persons) depositing foreign exchange in foreign exchange ac- counts no longer had to prove their right to such for- eign exchange. December 31. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE (Position on December 31, 1974) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.77734 grams of fine gold per Zaire. A central rate of Z 1 = US$2 has been established, and Zaire avails itself of wider margins. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar. The Bank of Zaire (the central bank) quotes an official rate of exchange for the Belgian franc based on the rate for the zaire quoted on the official exchange market in Brussels. The buying and selling rates for other quoted currencies, except the U.S. dollar, the French franc, and the CFA franc, also are based on official market rates in Brussels. For the U.S. dollar, the Bank of Zaire quotes a fixed rate of Z 1 = US$2, buying and selling. Quotations for the French franc and the CFA franc are based on daily quotations for the zaire in the official exchange market in Paris. Forward exchange transactions are prohibited. Administration of Control The Bank of Zaire has regulatory authority over all foreign trade and payments. Specifically, the Bank has discretionary power to authorize payments and receipts in foreign exchange by residents of Zaire, and to permit the importation, exportation, and transit of goods. Prescription of Currency Payments from nonresidents must be received in listed convertible currencies quoted daily by the Bank of Zaire.1 Special authorization for the acceptance of other currency may only be given in respect of curren- cies that can be exchanged freely without a discount. Payments to nonresidents must be made in the listed currencies. However, certain settlements with Burundi, Rwanda, and Uganda are made through special ac- counts established under arrangements concluded by the Bank of Zaire with the central banks of the countries concerned. Nonresident Accounts There are three categories of nonresident accounts: Nonresident Accounts in Zaires, Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts, and Convertible Accounts in Zaires. Nonresident Accounts in Zaires may only be debited with the approval of the Bank of Zaire. Such accounts, when opened by diplomatic missions and international organizations established in Zaire, may be debited freely but may be credited only with the proceeds of sales of foreign currency and with payments made by the Government. Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts may be cred- ited for any permitted payment in foreign currency; they may be debited freely for transfers to accounts abroad or to Resident and Nonresident Foreign Cur- rency Accounts, and for sales of foreign currency against domestic currency. Nonresident Zairian nation- als require special authorization from the central bank to open these accounts with authorized banks; nonresi- dent foreigners may open them freely. Convertible Accounts in Zaires may be credited in accordance with Circular No. 1312 and debited freely for conversion into foreign currency or for any pay- ments in domestic currency. Such accounts may be held by both residents and nonresidents but must not be credited with payments for exports of goods or services. Imports and Import Payments The importation of a number of goods is prohibited on grounds of public policy; these are mainly arms, ammunition, narcotics, and jukeboxes. The importa- tion of certain automobiles is prohibited for economic reasons. Import licenses, which must be submitted to the Bank of Zaire for prior approval, are only required for a few goods on list A (these include jewelry, pre- cious stones, precious metals, gold coins, rubber tires, certain iron and steel products, sugar, portland cement, mineral water, works of art, and antiques). All other imports are subject to import declarations, which do not require the approval of the central bank. The cen- tral bank has issued a general import and payments license which for all goods not on list A guarantees the availability of foreign exchange when payments fall due, provided that the importer files an import declara- tion with his bank following the actual placing of the order and provided that invoice price and quality have been verified and found acceptable by the foreign corre- spondents of the Office Zairois de Controle.3 Applications for import licenses, whether requiring foreign exchange or not, are made out at authorized banks; these forward the applications to the central bank after certification. After approval of the applica- tion by the central bank, which is given in the form of a visa, the import license application is returned to the intermediary authorized bank for validation. Import licenses are validated by the authorized banks without undue delay and remain valid for cus- toms clearance for six months starting from the first day of the month following that in which validation by the commercial bank takes place. Foreign exchange is in principle made available for all licensed imports, the validated license constituting at the same time an ex- change license; for payments purposes, the license re- mains valid as long as the relevant payments have not been completed. The counterpart of the value of goods imported under the Belgian food aid program, the U.S. import support program, and the agricultural aid pro- gram must be deposited within 120 to 180 days after their shipment. 537 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE All imports are subject to a statistical tax of 3 per cent ad valorem. In addition, most imports, irrespective of origin, are subject to a temporary import surcharge of either 5 per cent or 20 per cent ad valorem on the c.i.f. value. Payments for Invisibles Policy related to payments for invisibles is formu- lated by the central bank. Certain payments are subject to authorization by the central bank, which is given or refused on a nondiscriminatory basis; the approval au- thority for other current payments has been delegated to the authorized banks. The central bank will not authorize exchange for the payment of commissions in favor of shippers or purchasing agents or, except for imports payable on arrival, and provided that the sup- plier has arranged it, for insurance on imports. Further- more, imports and exports between Zaire and ports in Belgium, the Federal Republic of Germany, the Neth- erlands, and the Scandinavian countries must be shipped in vessels participating in the conference of the Associated Central West Africa Lines. Banks are not authorized to pay in foreign currency the maritime freight on shipments that do not meet these regulations, unless an immediate discount is obtained on the in- voice, and in the case of exports, banks are not autho- rized to validate export declarations unless these are marked accordingly. All other payments for services performed by nonresidents are in principle authorized. Transfers abroad of salaries of foreign nationals, how- ever, are restricted; for each enterprise concerned, their amount cannot exceed the countervalue in zaires of the amount spent on such transfers in 1972. Transfers in respect of certain administrative expenses abroad by enterprises, interest on private loans, and certain por- tions of insurance premiums are, as a rule, authorized. Net profits of firms with foreign capital participation are in principle transferable up to an amount propor- tionate to that participation. Transfers of royalties re- quire the prior approval of the Service de la Propriete Industrielle. Fares for travel abroad may be paid in Zaire in local currency. Zai'rian nationals traveling abroad may buy foreign exchange in amounts depending on the dura- tion of the journey, up to the equivalent of Z 400 a trip; applications exceeding this amount are subject to indi- vidual approval by the central bank. The export of domestic banknotes and coins is prohibited. Nonresi- dent travelers may take out any foreign means of pay- ment declared upon entry, minus the equivalent, at the official rate, of Z 20 for each day spent in Zaire. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports not covered by general license require individual declarations. Banks are normally authorized to approve such declarations, in which exporters under- take to collect the exchange proceeds. The declaration must specify the nature of the merchandise to be ex- 538 ported, the price, and the currency in which payment is to be received. Export declarations are normally valid for three months; within this period, the proceeds must be received and surrendered. Most exports of minerals are subject to special regulations to take into account the time required for processing abroad. For mineral products exported by the Generate des Carrieres et Mines du Zaire (GECAMINES), a provisional payment of a variable portion of the shipment's estimated value has to be received and surrendered within 8 days after ship- ment. For diamond exports, two thirds of the value established at a preliminary examination in Zaire must be surrendered before the shipment is dispatched. Ex- port proceeds from coffee must be surrendered within 45 days after shipment. Receipts from other agricul- tural exports must generally be repatriated within three months of validation. The exportation of coffee is a monopoly of the National Coffee Office. Minimum ex- port prices have been established for coffee, tea, ivory, and certain other commodities. All exports are subject to a statistical tax of 1 per cent ad valorem, and all commodities except cement are subject to export duties. Proceeds from Invisibles All exchange receipts from invisibles must be surren- dered. The import of domestic banknotes and coins is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign means of payment and may take out on departure the amount declared on entry, less the equivalent of Z 20 a calendar day spent in Zaire. Capital The repatriation of new foreign capital brought in under the provisions of the Investment Code (Ordi- nance-Law No. 69-032 of June 26, 1969) is guaran- teed, as is the transfer of profits and dividends on such capital. With minor exceptions, other transfers abroad of capital owned by residents or nonresidents are not permitted.4 Gratuitous transfers of real estate are sub- ject to approval by executive ordinance. When the local currency part is paid by the debtor, amortization on foreign loans can be transferred in accordance with the terms of contracts that the central bank has endorsed to guarantee the availability of exchange for such trans- fers. The foreign currency assets of the authorized banks are not permitted to exceed their short-term lia- bilities in foreign currencies. Gold Residents other than the monetary authorities, pro- ducers of gold, and industrial users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. The import and export of gold in any form, except jewelry constituting the per- sonal effects of a traveler, require the prior approval of the central bank. Producers are not required to sell ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution their production to the central bank. All newly pro- duced gold is exported, with the exception of small quantities used domestically for the manufacture of jewelry. Changes during 1974 January 15. The nationalization was announced of the foreign-owned petroleum distributing companies operating in Zaire. February 1. The existing attestation controls over imports and exports were transferred to the Office Zai- rois de Controle. February 14. Imports of dried and salted fish re- quired a license. July 10. The Societe Zairoise de Commercialisation des Minerais (SOZACOM) was established. It would take over the commercial operations of the Societe Generate des Minerais (SGM). August 5. Imports valued at less than Z 200 f.o.b. were made subject to attestation by agents of the Office Zairois de Controle before shipment; exempt were spare parts for industrial machinery, medicines, and medico-optical glasses. August 8. The regulation providing that imports could not be admitted at prices higher than the lowest 1971 list prices minus 3 per cent was withdrawn. Henceforth the Office Zairois de Controle a n d / or its representatives abroad were authorized to issue a sur- vey attestation for all imports, provided that the foreign supplier had granted the importer either a rebate of 3 per cent on the current list price or minimum payments ZAIRE terms, free of interest, of 90 days from the date of shipment. November 14. Import declarations and import li- censes for goods originating in or shipped from "East- ern bloc countries" required the prior visa of the Bank of Zaire. November 24. Imports of luxury passenger automo- biles were prohibited. November 26. Circular No. 146 added a number of iron and steel products to the list of goods for which an import license from the Bank of Zaire is required (list A). December 9. Zairian citizens required the prior ap- proval of the Bank of Zaire before importing for per- sonal use any jewelry, watches, or furn i ture.
