Not for Redistribution Exchange Rate System Nonresident Accounts ZAMBIA (Position on December 31, 1974) The par value is 1.14592 grams of fine gold per Zam- bian Kwacha, and Zambia avails itself of wider mar- gins. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, is K 1 = US$1.55556 or US$1 = K 0.642856. The Bank of Zambia maintains fixed buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar. Since February 15, 1973, these rates have been Y16 of 1 per cent below parity for buying (US$1 = K 0.64246) and V4 of 1 per cent above parity for selling (US$1 = K 0.64447). The Bank of Zambia deals only with authorized commercial banks in Zam- bia. The authorized banks normally charge an addi- tional V2 of 1 per cent plus any cable costs when dealing with customers. The Bank of Zambia bases its rates for sterling on the current rates for the U.S. dollar in the London market; it normally deals only in U.S. dollars and sterling. Authorized banks are free to deal with customers in other currencies, and base their rates on the Bank of Zambia's rates for the U.S. dollar and the current London market rates for the currencies con- cerned. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Zambia under powers delegated to it by the Minister of Finance. Much of the authority for approving normal current payments is in turn delegated to commercial banks authorized to deal in foreign exchange. The con- trol of trade is the responsibility of the Minister of Commerce, who also issues import and export licenses. Prescription of Currency Zambia has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Authorized payments, including pay- ments for imports, by residents of Zambia to residents of countries other than Rhodesia may be made in Zam- bian currency to the credit of an External Account, or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. Payments from residents of countries other than Rho- desia may be received in sterling or in Zambian cur- rency from an External Account, or in any foreign currency freely exchangeable for U.S. dollars or ster- ling. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rho- desia. All permitted payments to residents of Rhodesia must be made in Rhodesian currency, in Zambian cur- rency to an External Account—Rhodesia, in sterling to a Rhodesian Account in the United Kingdom, in U.S. dollars, or in Canadian dollars. Proceeds from exports to Rhodesia must be received in U.S. or Canadian dol- lars. 540 Accounts in Zambian currency held with authorized banks by residents of countries other than Rhodesia are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized payments from residents of Zambia, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any foreign cur- rency except Rhodesian currency by nonresidents to authorized banks. They may be debited for payments for any purpose to residents of Zambia, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for purchases of any for- eign currency other than Rhodesian currency from au- thorized banks. Blocked Accounts in Zambian currency held with authorized banks by residents of any country other than Zambia are credited with nontransferable capital sums in Zambian currency and with any unremittable portion of rents which have accrued to nonresidents. All debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. Nor- mally, approval is given for the investment of balances on blocked accounts in Zambian securities, provided that these are held in Zambia to the order of an autho- rized dealer. The interest on blocked account balances is freely transferable to the account holder's country of residence, except interest due to a resident of Rhodesia, which is also blocked. Imports and Import Payments Virtually all imports from Rhodesia are prohibited, as is the import from all countries of certain specified commodities for health, safety, or moral reasons. Per- sonal and household effects, samples, diplomatic ship- ments, and means of transportation entering Zambia temporarily do not require individual import licenses, nor do any other goods for personal use and consump- tion, provided that the person importing them does not import more than K 50 worth of such goods in any period of 90 days. The two major mining companies and the Ministry of Health are granted "blanket li- censes" for bona fide requirements. The Controller of Customs is authorized to admit emergency goods im- ported without prior reference to the Ministry of Com- merce. All other imports require individual import licenses. Import licensing aims at containing imports within a quarterly exchange allocation established by the Min- istry of Commerce in consultation with the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Zambia. All imports under individual licensing are first divided into SITC1 three-digit groups and further subdivided into end-use groupings. Exchange allocations are specified for each of these categories. Normally raw materials, intermedi- ate goods for further processing in Zambia, pharmaceu- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ticals, and fuel and electricity are licensed liberally; alcoholic beverages, tobacco, durable consumer goods, and other consumer goods are licensed restrictively. No licenses are being issued for 23 items, mostly luxury foods tuffs. The M in is try of Commerce has designated seven import agencies as authorized to allocate foreign exchange among individual applicants. These agencies are Indeco Industrial Holdings, National Import and Export Corporation, Steelbuild Holdings, Motor Trad- ers Association, Ministry of Health, Zambia Railways, and Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation. Foreign exchange for import payments is automatically made available once an import license has been obtained, subject to presentation of the relevant documents to an authorized bank. Prior approval by the Bank of Zam- bia, however, is necessary for payments to Rhodesia and South Africa in excess of K 20,000; payments for imports from Rhodesia and South Africa are not nor- mally permitted unless no alternative source of supply is available. Unless prior permission is otherwise ob- tained, all imports must be paid for within six months of the date of importation. All dutiable imports are subject to a customs surcharge of 10 per cent ad valo- rem. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes, such as travel, is provided by the commercial banks without prior reference to the exchange control authorities, ex- cept when payments and transfers in excess of K 20,000 to Rhodesia or South Africa are involved. Special reduced allocations apply to payments for invis- ibles to Rhodesia, and authorized dealers are not per- mitted to make foreign exchange available for travel to Rhodesia. For other countries, exchange is granted as follows. The basic exchange allowance for travel is K 20 a day for an adult, with a maximum of K 600 for each period of two calendar years, and K 10 a day for each child under 12 years of age, with a maximum of K 300 for two calendar years. Exchange is provided, subject to certain limits, for other purposes such as education, medical treatment, and business travel. Ap- plications for amounts exceeding the limits may in cer- tain circumstances be granted by the exchange control authorities if they are satisfied that exceptional treat- ment is justified. Applications for remittance abroad of part or all of payments for advertising, management, accounting, administrative, engineering, and consulting services rendered to residents by nonresidents are subject to individual approval by the Bank of Zambia, which gen- erally grants the required permission, provided that the fees charged are reasonable and that these services can- not be provided domestically.2 Profits and dividends of subsidiaries and branches of companies whose head offices are situated outside Zambia may be transferred abroad up to 30 per cent of the nonresident share of the ZAMBIA equity capital or one half of net profits accruing to the nonresident owners of incorporated companies, which- ever is smaller.3 Foreign companies operating in Zam- bia may remit declared profits and dividends once a year after the end of the accounting year. The remit- tance of depreciation allowances is not permitted. Re- mittances of rents to nonresidents are restricted to 50 per cent of net annual rental income. Foreign nationals employed in Zambia on a contract basis and recruited after December 4, 1971 are allowed to remit to their country of domicile a third of their annual earnings. Foreign nationals recruited before De- cember 4, 1971 and still employed on a contract en- tered into prior to that date are allowed to remit to their country of domicile one half of their annual earnings. Foreign nationals availing themselves of these arrange- ments are not entitled to the regular allowances for travel, education, maintenance, etc. To facilitate pay- ments of small amounts, individuals are freely permit- ted to remit abroad up to K 10 a month for purposes normally approved by the exchange control authorities (including family maintenance). Travelers may not take out more than K 10 in Zam- bian currency. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports valued at over K 50 require a license; minerals, however, are exported under general agree- ments with the mining companies. The export of certain metals is reserved, in principle, for an official agency, the Metal Marketing Corporation, but by the end of 1974 the implementing arrangements had not yet been agreed. Most exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Cer- tain commodities are subject to licensing mainly to ensure domestic supplies of needed goods and of certain strategic materials, such as implements of war, lead in any form, certain minerals, petroleum products, certain rough and uncut precious stones, scrap and old metals, and jute bags. For most goods, however, export li- censes are issued freely, and some goods are covered by an open general license. Export proceeds in foreign currency appropriate to the country of destination must be offered for sale to an authorized bank within six months of the date of shipment; the foreign ex- change proceeds of copper exports, however, must be credited to a Bank of Zambia account in London upon receipt. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any currency must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes that may be imported by travelers, except that travelers from Zaire are allowed to import only up to the equiva- lent of K 20. The import of Zambian currency is lim- ited to K 10 for each traveler, except travelers from Zaire, who are allowed up to K 20. 541 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted but, with the exception of overseas short-term financing of imports other than certain capital goods, all borrowing outside Zambia requires the approval of the exchange control authorities. Outward transfers of capital are controlled, but nonresidents are normally permitted to repatriate their investments when they have satisfied the authorities that the original investment was made with funds brought into the country from sources out- side Zambia. Local borrowing by companies controlled either directly or indirectly from outside Zambia is re- stricted to a debt/equity ratio of 1 to 2. However, the Bank of Zambia permits borrowings in excess of this limit for certain priority sectors of the economy, pro- vided the borrowings secure higher employment oppor- tunities and /or savings of foreign exchange. In general, residents are not permitted to transfer capital abroad and, with certain exceptions, are re- quired to offer for sale to an authorized bank any for- eign exchange which accrues to them. As a special measure, however, residents may purchase Zambian securities quoted on recognized stock exchanges abroad, provided that the securities so acquired are registered in the names of specified nominees and that in the event of subsequent disposal of these securities the sales proceeds are repatriated. All income earned from these investments must be repatriated. Emigrants are granted exchange as follows: (1) Per- sons 50 years of age and over are allowed K 8,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of K 5,000. (2) Married persons under 50 are allowed K 4,000 on departure, together with K 250 for each child, up to a maximum of K 5,000 for a family unit. Thereafter, annual transfers of K 3,000, together with K 250 for each child, up to a maximum of K 4,000 for a family unit are permitted. (3) Unmarried persons under 50 are allowed K 2,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of K 1,500. In addition to their emigration allowance, emigrants may remit gratuities, compensa- tion payments, and terminal benefits up to a maximum of K 8,000 on departure, and up to K 5,000 as annual transfers. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Zam- bia for numismatic purposes. With this exception, resi- dents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require exchange control approval as well as import or export licenses issued by the Minis- ter of Commerce; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. 542 Gold-bearing slime is exported by copper companies as a by-product for refining and sale abroad. Foreign ex- change for imports of gold may only be provided with the permission of the Bank of Zambia. Changes during 1974 January 2. Authorized dealers were advised that the use by importers of usance letters of credit and short-term bills raised overseas was being restricted. With effect from January 15, importers required Bank of Zambia approval to avail themselves of short-term foreign financing facilities; such approval would be granted in exceptional circumstances only. Also, fi- nancing fees levied by shipping or confirming houses or other overseas financing organizations (other than those relating to arrangements concluded prior to Jan- uary 15) could not be paid by importers without spe- cific prior exchange control approval. Letters of credit opened on a "sight" basis continued to be permitted. No usance letters of credit, bills, acceptances, or similar financing instruments representing claims on Zambian residents or companies could be held from January 15 by authorized banks, for collection for or on behalf of overseas correspondent banks or other overseas resi- dent entities, other than those negotiated by such resi- dents or companies prior to that date. The measure was intended to reduce exchange risks and interest charges, not to delay or restrict imports. March 18. Gifts to nonresidents could no longer be made by persons under 16. March 30. Authorized dealers were advised that the requirement to refer to the Bank of Zambia all pay- ments in foreign exchange on account of or on behalf of the two major copper companies was withdrawn. Authorized dealers could again provide the necessary foreign exchange within their delegated powers. May 15. The basic exchange allowance for business travel was increased from the equivalent of K 30 a day to K 40 a day, for up to 21 days (previously 15 days) in any calendar year and not more than two trips a year. August 2. Authorized dealers no longer were allowed to provide foreign exchange for travel to Rhodesia. September 12. The restrictions on remittances of profits, dividends, and rents were extended for another year. October 17. The restrictions imposed in January on short-term foreign financing of imports were with- drawn for consumer goods and all other goods, except capital goods for agriculture, industry, transportation, and construction. In principle, such capital goods still had to be financed locally, but importers could, subject to Bank of Zambia approval, arrange credit abroad provided that the rate of interest was reasonable. October 17. It was announced that no import licenses would be issued for a group of 23 commodities, mainly luxury foodstuffs. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution November 13. The exchange allowance that autho- rized dealers could approve for education abroad was increased to K 3,000 a student a year, except for study in Rhodesia, for which the basic allowance remained unchanged. November. In compliance with the guidelines laid down by the Council of Copper Exporting Countries, Zambia announced a reduction in its copper sales abroad for 1975.
